
---

////—1—//// 1:1:1,"**These are the names of the B’nei Yisrael.** Though [Scripture] has previously enumerated them during their lifetime by their names, it again enumerates them at their deaths. [This is] to show how dear they are [to God], because they are compared to the stars which He brings out and brings in by number and by their [individual] names; as it is said: “Who brings out their host by number, and calls each by its name.” "

§§—2—§§ 1:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל NOW THESE ARE THE NAMES OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL —  Although scripture has already enumerated them by name whilst they were living, when they went down into Egypt (Genesis 46:8-27), it again enumerates them when it tells us of their death, thus showing how dear they were to God — that they are compared to the stars which also God brings out and brings in by number and name when they cease to shine, as it is said, (Isaiah 40:26) “He bringeth out their host by number, He calleth them all by name” (Exodus Rabbah 1:3; Tanchuma Yashan 1:1:2)."

—3— **1, 1 <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמות. Und das sind die Namen der Kinder Israel,** obschon er ihre Namen bereits bei ihrem Leben aufgezählt hat, zählt er sie wieder nach ihrem Tode, um die Liebe zu ihnen zu bekunden; denn sie sind mit den Sternen verglichen, die Er nach ihrer Zahl und ihren Namen hinausführt und heimbringt; so heißt es (Jes. 40, 26), Er führt nach der Zahl ihr Heer hinaus, alle benennt Er sie mit Namen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 1:5:1,"**Yoseif [who] was [already] in Egypt.** But, were not he and his sons included in the seventy? Then what does [Scripture] intend to teach us? Would we not know ourselves that he was in Egypt? But, [the purpose is] to let you know how righteous Yoseif was — the same Yoseif who tended his father’s sheep, is the same Yoseif who was in Egypt and he became king, [yet] he remained steadfast in his righteousness. "

§§—2—§§ 1:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויוסף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במצרים lit., AND JOSEPH WAS IN EGYPT — But were not he and his sons included in the seventy? What, then, is this statement intended to tell us? Do we not know that he was in Egypt? But its purpose is to inform you of Joseph’s righteousness: this is the same Joseph who tended his father’s sheep; this is the same Joseph who was in Egypt and became king there, and yet he remained steadfast in his righteousness, and the change from a humble position to exalted rank in Egypt caused no deterioration in his character (cf. Sifrei <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האזינו; Exodus Rabbah 1:7)."

—3— **5. Und Josef war in Ägypten,** waren denn nicht er und seine Söhne in der Zahl der 70 inbegriffen? Was will er uns also lehren; haben wir denn nicht gewusst, dass er in Ägypten war? Nur, dich die Frömmigkeit Josefs zu lehren, das war derselbe Josef, der die Schafe seines Vaters weidete, derselbe Josef, der in Ägypten war und König wurde und in seiner Frömmigkeit verharrte (Sifre hasinu). 

---

////—1—//// 1:7:2,**And Prolific.** They bore six children at one time.

§§—2—§§ 1:7:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישרצו AND THEY INCREASED ABUNDANTLY (more lit., they swarmed, a word used of the prolificness of reptiles) — they bore six children at one birth (the six words from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרו to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאד suggest or imply the number six) (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 5)."

—3— **7. Und wimmelten,** sie gebaren sechs in einem Mutterschoß (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 1:8:1,"**A new king came into power.** Rav and Shmuel [disagreed as to the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֶלֶךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָדָשׁ]. One said, literally a new king while the other said, [he was actually the same king] but his edicts were new. "

§§—2—§§ 1:8:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חדש NOW THERE AROSE A NEW KING — Rab and Samuel (two Amoraim or Talmudical teachers) differed in their interpretation of these words. One said that he was really a new king; the other said that it was the same king but he made new edicts (Sotah 11a).

—3— **8. Da erstand ein neuer König,** Raw und Schemuel, der eine sagt, wörtlich ein neuer König, und der andere sagt, es gingen neue Verfolgungen von ihm aus (Sota 11a) 

---

////—1—//// 1:8:2,**Who did not know.** He acted <font color=d50505>»</font>as if<font color=d50505>«</font> he did not know [him].

§§—2—§§ 1:8:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידע WHO KNEW NOT [JOSEPH] — he comported himself as though he did not know him (Sotah 11a).

—3— **Der nicht kannte,** er stellte sich so, als ob er nicht kenne (dort). 

---

////—1—//// 1:10:1,**Come let us deal wisely.** Wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָבָה [appears in Scripture] it means “preparation and readiness” for a given matter; that is: “Prepare yourselves for this!”

§§—2—§§ 1:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתחכמה COME ON, LET US DEAL WISELY — Wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבה is used it has the meaning of preparing oneself and making oneself ready to do a particular matter; it signifies as much as: get yourself ready for this (cf. Rashi on Genesis 11:4 and Rashi on Genesis 38:16)."

—3— **10. Wohlan, lasst uns überlisten,** überall bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבה sich vorbereiten und sich rüsten für eine Sache, das heißt, bereitet euch dazu vor. 

---

////—1—//// 1:10:2,**Wisely with him.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹ — <font color=d50505>»</font>to him<font color=d50505>«</font> — refers] to the nation [of Israel]. “Let us wisely determine what to do to him.” Our Sages [however] explained [the singular <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹ] as: “Let us deal shrewdly with the Savior of Israel (God) by bringing about their fate through water for He has already sworn that he will never again bring a flood upon the world.” (They [the Egyptians] did not realize that [His promise was] not to flood the entire world but He might flood one nation. [From an old Rashi text]).

§§—2—§§ 1:10:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתחכמה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו LET US DEAL WISELY WITH THEM (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו more lit., with him) — i. e. with the people (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו, which is singular, refers to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם used in the preceding verse in the phrase <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל): let us consider wisely what to do to them. Our Rabbis, however, explained that the singular <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו refers to God, and that the words mean: “let us use our wisdom against Him who would show Himself Israel’s deliverer, by sentencing them to death by water, since He has already sworn that He will not bring another flood upon the world, and He will therefore be unable to punish us ‘measure for measure’, as is His way.”)"

—3— **Wir wollen es überlisten,** das Volk; wir wollen listig überlegen, was wir ihm tun können; unsere Weisen erklären, wir wollen Ihn überlisten, den Helfer Israels, indem wir jene durch Wasser richten; da Er bereits geschworen hat, keine Sintflut mehr über die Welt zu bringen (und sie verstanden nicht, dass Er eine solche nicht über die ganze Welt, wohl aber über eine Nation bringen würde. Alter Raschitext) (Schem. rab.). 

---

////—1—//// 1:10:3,"**Driving us from the land — ** against our will. Our Sages, however, explained it: [Pharoah spoke] as a person who expresses a curse about himself but attaches his curse to others. It is as if it had been written: “And <font color=d50505>»</font>we<font color=d50505>«</font> will go up out of the land and they will inherit it.” "

§§—2—§§ 1:10:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ AND HE WILL GO UP OUT OF THE LAND, against our will. Our Rabbis explained that they spoke like a person who is pronouncing a curse against himself but attaches the curse to others (because he does not wish to use an ominous expression of himself), so that it is as though Scripture wrote “and we shall have to go up out of the land” and they will take possession of it (Sotah 11a)."

—3— **Und verlässt das Land,** gegen unseren Willen; unsere Lehrer erklären, wie einer, der sich selbst verwünscht und seine Verwünschung anderen anhängt (Schem. rab.); und dann ist es, als wenn er geschrieben hätte, und wir müssen das Land verlassen, und sie werden es einnehmen. 

---

////—1—//// 1:11:1,**Over him.** [Meaning:] upon the nation.

§§—2—§§ 1:11:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליו [THEREFORE THEY DID SET] OVER THEM (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליו over him) i. e. over the people.

—3— **11. Über es,** über das Volk. 

---

////—1—//// 1:11:2,"**Conscription officers.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִסִּים] is derived from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַס — <font color=d50505>»</font>tribute.<font color=d50505>«</font> [Thus, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂרֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִסִּים are] officers who collect tribute from them. And what is the tribute? That they build warehouse [storage] cities for Pharaoh. "

§§—2—§§ 1:11:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסים has the meaning of tribute (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מס), a forced levy of labour, so that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסים are the officers who exact the tribute of labour from them. And what was this tribute? That they should build store-cities for Pharaoh."

—3— **Fronen,** von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מס Fron, Steuer; Vögte, die von ihnen die Fron forderten; und worin bestand die Fron? Dass sie Vorratsstädte für Pharao bauten. 

---

////—1—//// 1:11:3,"**To oppress him with their burdens.** I.e., [the burdens] of the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 1:11:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ענותו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסבלותם TO AFFLICT THEM WITH THEIR BURDENS — i. e. the burdens of the Egyptians.

—3— **Um es zu bedrücken durch ihre Lastarbeiten,** der Ägypter. 

---

////—1—//// 1:11:4,**Supply cities.** Should be translated as Onkelos does. Similarly: “Go to this (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַסֹּכֵן) treasurer.” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַסֹּכֵן refers to] the treasurer who is in charge of the warehouses.

§§—2—§§ 1:11:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכנות — Translate this as the Targum does: CITIES WHICH ARE PLACES FOR TREASURES; similarly we have, (Isaiah 22:15) “Go, get thes unto this steward (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הסוכן)” — the treasurer appointed over the stores (Exodus Rabbah 2:1)."

—3— **Vorratsstädte,** wie der Targum übersetzt; ebenso (Jes. 22,15), geh, begib dich zu diesem Verwalter, dem Verwalter, der über die Vorräte gesetzt war (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 1:11:5,**Pisom and Ramseis.** For they were originally not fit for this purpose so they strengthened and fortified them for warehousing.

§§—2—§§ 1:11:5, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעמסס PITHOM AND RAMESES — These cities already existed but were not adapted originally for this purpose; now they strengthened them and fortified them to serve as store-cities.

—3— **Pitom und Raamses,** die früher nicht dazu geeignet gewesen waren, und sie machten sie stark und zu einer Vorratskammer befestigt. 

---

////—1—//// 1:12:1,"**The more [the Egyptians] oppressed him.** To the extent that they set their hearts to oppress [them], God set His heart to increase and strengthen them. "

§§—2—§§ 1:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יענו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו AND AS THEY AFFLICTED THEM — In whatsoever matter it was that they set their hearts upon afflicting them so was the heart of the Holy One, blessed be He, set upon multiplying them and making them grow apace."

—3— **12. Aber je mehr sie es quälten,** je mehr sie ihr Herz darauf richteten, zu quälen, um so mehr war das Herz des Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, sie zu vermehren und auszubreiten. 

---

////—1—//// 1:12:2,"**The more [the B’nei Yisrael] increased.** [Meaning:] so did they increase and become strong. That is the plain interpretation. [However,] the Midrashic explanation is: the Holy Spirit is saying this, i.e., “You say, ‘lest he increase’, but, I say, ‘yes, they <font color=d50505>»</font>will<font color=d50505>«</font> increase’.” "

§§—2—§§ 1:12:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירבה signifies: so they multiplied and so they grew apace (i. e. God’s determination was carried out, the imperfect tenses of the verbs denoting the continuance of the increase and growth). This is the real meaning; but there is a Midrashic explanation of these imperfect tenses: The Holy spirit (God) said this: You say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירבה, “lest they increase”, but “I” say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירבה, “thus will they assuredly increase” (Sotah 11a)."

—3— **Um so mehr vermehrte es sich,** soviel wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרץ Vergangenheit; der Midrasch sagt, der göttliche Geist sprach so, ihr sagt, dass es sich nicht vermehre, und ich sage, um so mehr soll es sich vermehren (Sota 11a). 

---

////—1—//// 1:12:3,**[The Egyptians] came to loathe.** Their lives became abhorent to them. Our Sages explained: They were as thorns (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוֹצִים) in their eyes.

§§—2—§§ 1:12:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקצו the word means, THEY WERE WEARY OF THEIR LIVES. Our Rabbis explained that it means that they were as thorns (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוצים) in their eyes (cf. Sotah 11a)."

—3— **Es graute ihnen,** ihr Leben war ihnen zuwider; unsere Lehrer erklären, sie waren ihnen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוץ ein Dorn im Auge (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 1:13:1,**With body-breaking labor.** [Meaning:] with work that is so hard that it crushes (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְפַּרֶכֶת) the body and breaks it.

§§—2—§§ 1:13:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בפרך means with hard service which crushes (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מפרכת) the body and shatters it (cf. Sotah 11b).

—3— **13. Mit Härte,** mit harter Arbeit, die den Körper zermürbt und zerbricht (Sota 11b). 

---

////—1—//// 1:15:1,"**Midwives.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְיַלְּדוֹת has the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוֹלִידוֹת, but it sometimes comes in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל (light) conjugation and sometimes in the “heavy” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּעֵל conjugation as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שׁוֹבֵר (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל) or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשַׁבֵּר (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּעֵל) or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דוֹבֵר (speak) [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל conjugation] and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר (speak) [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּעֵל conjugation]. Similarly <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוֹלִיד [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל] and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְיַלֵּד — [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּעֵל]. "

§§—2—§§ 1:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למילדת (the Piel participle) — This is synonymous with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מולידות (the Hiphil participle, and both denote the women who assist the mother in bringing the child to birth). But some verbs are used in forms of a light conjugation (i. e. one which has no strong Dagesh as a characteristic) or in forms of a strong conjugation (one that has such a Dagesh), as e. g., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שׁוֹבֵר (Kal) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשַׁבֵּר (Piel); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דּוֹבֵר (Kal) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר (Piel). both having the same meaning; similarly here we may have <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוליד (the Hiphil — without a strong Dagesh) or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְיַלֵּד (the Piel), both signifying one who helps to bring to birth."

—3— **15. Zu den Hebammen,** der Ausdruck bezeichnet Frauen, die Geburtshilfe leisten; jedoch kommt die Wurzel in der leichteren Form (Hiphil) und in der schwereren Form (Piel) vor, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבר im Kal und im Piel; ebenso <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר im Kal und Piel; ebenso von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילד Hiphil und Piel. 

---

////—1—//// 1:15:2,"**Shifrah.** This is Yocheved, [and she was called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁפְרָה] because [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׁמְּשַׁפֶּרֶת] she would put the newborn into proper [physical] condition. "

§§—2—§§ 1:15:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שפרה SHIPHRAH — This was Jochebed; she bore this additional name because she used to put the babe after its birth into good physical condition (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משפרת) by the care she bestowed upon it (Sotah 11b).

—3— **Schifra,** das war Jochebed; weil sie die Kinder pflegte (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שפיר schön). 

---

////—1—//// 1:15:3,"**Puah.** This is Miriam, [and she was called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פּוּעָה] because she would make loud noises and speak and articulate to the newborn, as do women who pacify a child that is crying. "

§§—2—§§ 1:15:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פועה PUAH — This was Miriam, and she bore this additional name because she used to Call aloud and speak and croon to the babe just as women do who soothe a child when it is crying (Sotah 11b). "

—3— **Pua,** das war Mirjam, weil sie den Kindern zurief und mit ihnen sprach und sich mit ihnen unterhielt, wie Frauen tun, die ein weinendes Kind besänftigen (Sota 11b); Pua bedeutet laut rufen, wie (Jes. 42, 14), wie eine Gebärende will ich schreien. 

---

////—1—//// 1:15:4,[The word] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פּוּעָה means <font color=d50505>»</font>shouting loudly<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “I will scream like a birthing woman.”

§§—2—§§ 1:15:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פועה has the meaning of crying aloud, as (Isaiah 42:14) “I will cry (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפעה) like a travailing woman”."


---

////—1—//// 1:16:1,**When you deliver.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּיַלֶדְכֶן [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּעֵל conjugation] is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְהוֹלִידְכֶן [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל conjugation].

§§—2—§§ 1:16:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בילדכן WHEN YE DO THE OFFICE OF A MIDWIFE — This word (the Piel) has the same force as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהולידכן (the Hiphil): when you assist them to give birth.

—3— **16. Wenn ihr Geburtshilfe leistet,** wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוליד Hiphil. 

---

////—1—//// 1:16:2,**Birthstool.** The seat of a woman who is giving birth. In another place [in Scripture] it is referred to as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְׁבֵּר . Similarly: “He did work on the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָבְנָיִם” — the seat upon which are kept the tools of the pottery maker.

§§—2—§§ 1:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האבנים UPON THE STOOLS — the seat for the woman in the act of childbirth; in another passage (Isaiah 37:3) Scripture terms it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְׁבֵּר. Similar is, (Jeremiah 18:3) “He was at work on the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבנים"" — the place of the vessels of (being produced by) the craftsmanship of the potter."

—3— **Auf den Kreissstuhl,** den Sitz einer gebärenden Frau; an anderer Stelle (Jes. 37, 3) nennt er ihn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משבר; ähnlich (Jer. 18,3), er arbeitet auf der Töpferscheibe, dem Platz für das Handwerksgerät des Töpfers. 

---

////—1—//// 1:16:3,"**If it is a boy, etc.** He was particular only in regard to the male children because his astrologers had told him that a son was to be born who would liberate them. "

§§—2—§§ 1:16:3, '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו IF IT BE A SON etc. — He was particular only about the male children because his astrologers had told him that there was to be born to a Hebrew woman a son who would become their deliverer (Exodus Rabbah 1:18).

—3— **Wenn es ein Sohn ist,** er achtete nur auf die Knaben, weil seine Astrologen gesehen hatten, dass ein Sohn geboren würde, der Israel erlösen werde (Schemot Rabbah V. 

---

////—1—//// 1:16:4,**Let her live.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וָחָיָה being the same as] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְתִחְיֶה — “and she shall live.”

§§—2—§§ 1:16:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחיה has the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחיה THEN SHE SHALL LIVE.

—3— **22). Bleibe sie am Leben,** wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחיה Zukunft.

////—1—//// 1:17:1,"**And they kept the infant boys alive.** [Meaning:] they provided water and food for them. Onkelos’ translation of the first [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּחַיֶּיןָ] is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְקַיָּימָא — <font color=d50505>»</font>and they [the women] preserved [the newborn];<font color=d50505>«</font> whereas the second time [that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּחַיֶּיןָ appears — v. 18] [he translates it] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְקַיֵּימְתּוּן — <font color=d50505>»</font>and you [women] have preserved.<font color=d50505>«</font> This is because, in Hebrew, this word and any form thereof is used to mean: “they” (fem.) did something as well as: “you” (fem. pl.) did something. E.g., “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתּאֹמַרְןָ —) They said, “an Egyptian, etc.,” which is [fem. pl.] past tense as would be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֹּאמְרוּ — for masculine. [Another example:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּדַבֵּרְנָה) you [women] have spoken with your mouths” — the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבַּרְתֶּן corresponding to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּדַבְּרוּ in the masculine. Similarly: (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּחַלְּלֶנָה) “you [women] have maligned me to my nation” — which is in the past tense. The same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִלַּלְתֶּן corresponding to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּחַלְּלוּ in the masculine. "

§§—2—§§ 1:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחיין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הילדים This may mean THEY MAINTAINED THE CHILDREN IN LIFE — they provided them with food (Sotah 11b). The Targum renders <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחיין the first time it occurs (i. e. in this verse) by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקימא (which means, “and they — the women — preserved the babes”). and the second time (Exodus 1:18) by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקימתן (which means, “and ye women have preserved etc.”) The Targum is able to distinguish between the two meanings of this word, but this cannot be done in Hebrew because in the Hebrew language in the case of fem. plur. this word and similar forms (ending in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָה or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ןָ) are used in the sense of “they did something” (3rd person) and in the sense of “ye did something” (2nd person). For example: (Exodus 2:19) “And they (the daughters of Jethro) said, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתֹּאמַרְןָ) “An Egyptian man etc.”, which is the past tense (the Rashi text must read here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָבַר) (imperf. with Vau conv.), just as one would use <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֹאמְרוּ if one were speaking of men; (Jeremiah 54:25) “Ye women have spoken (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותדברנה) with your mouths”, having the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברתן, and corresponding to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותדברו when used of men; (Ezekiel 13:19) “And ye (women) have profaned Me (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחללנה) among My people” which is a past tense, the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חללתן corresponding to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחללו when used of men."

—3— **17. Und sie erhielten die Kinder am Leben,** versorgten sie mit Trank und Speise (Sota 11b); das erste <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחיין übersetzt der Targum mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקיימא und das zweite mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקיימתון weil im Hebräischen die weibliche Form in der Mehrzahl, und zwar dieselbe Form sowohl die dritte als auch die zweite Person bezeichnen kann; wie (2, 19) sie sagten, ein ägyptischer Mann, ist die Vergangenheit wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמרו in der männlichen Form; (Jer. 44, 25) ihr spracht mit eurem Munde wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברתם in der männlichen Form; ebenso (Jech. 13, 19) ihr habt mich bei meinem Volke entweiht, ist die Vergangenheit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חללתן wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותחללו in der männlichen Form.

////—1—//// 1:19:1,"**They know how to deliver.** [Meaning:] they are as knowledgeable as midwives. Onkelos’ translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְיַלְּדוֹת (midwives) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַיָיתָא . However, our Sages explained [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָיוֹת as “animals”] [i.e.] they may be compared to animals of the field who do not require midwives [when giving birth]. And where is it that they are compared to animals? “[Yehudah] is like a young lion,” “[Binyamin] is like a wolf that preys,” “[Yoseif] is like the first-born of his ox,” “[Naftali] is a gazelle-like messenger.” And [those of the Tribes] where no reference is made [to animals], Scripture includes them [in the comparison] [in the statement:] “And he blessed them.” It is also written: “What a lioness is your mother!” "

§§—2—§§ 1:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה signifies they are just as skilful as midwives. The Aramaic for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מילדות, midwives, is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיתא (hence the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיות in this verse). Our Rabbis, however, (taking this word in the sense of animals) gave the following explanation (Sotah 11b): they have been compared to the beasts of the field which do not require the help of midwives. And where are they compared to animals? (Genesis 49:9) “Judah is a young lion”; (Genesis 27) “Benjamin is a wolf that leareth”; (Deuteronomy 33:17) “Joseph is the firstling of his ox”; (Genesis 49:21) “Naphtali is a hind sent forth”. As for the ancestors of those tribes about whom such a comparison is not expressly written Scripture implicitly includes them in the several blessings bestowed upon their brothers, (and thus they also are compared, as their brothers, to animals), for Scripture states, (Genesis 49:28) “And he blessed them etc.” (cf. Rashi on these words). Then, again, it is written, (Ezekiel 19:2) “How was thy mother a lioness!” (The prophet is addressing the princes of Israel as the representatives of the people, and by the term “thy mother” means the progenitors of the nation; the chapter proceeds to speak of the mother’s offspring as “whelps”)."

—3— **19. Denn sie sind lebenskräftig,** erfahren wie Hebammen, der Targum von Hebammen ist <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חייתא; unsere Lehrer erklären, sie sind mit den Tieren des Feldes verglichen, die keine Hebammen brauchen (Sota 11b), und wo sind sie mit dem Gewild verglichen? (Gen. 49), ein junger Löwe, ein reißender Wolf; (Deut. 33) der Erstling seines Stieres; eine dahineilende Hirschkuh; und selbst diejenigen, bei denen es nicht steht, siehe, der Vers hat sie alle mit eingeschlossen, (Gen. 49,28) und er segnete sie; ferner heißt es (Jech. 19,2), was ist deine Mutter; eine Löwin.

////—1—//// 1:20:1,"**Elokim was good.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּיטֶב means:] He did good to them. The following is the difference concerning a word whose root letters are two and it is prefixed by a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וי""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו and a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד: When it intends to convey the idea of causing someone else to do something, the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד is vocalized with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צֵירֵי which is also called a <font color=d50505>»</font>kometz koton.<font color=d50505>«</font> For example: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּיטֶב) God did good to the midwives.” “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֶּרֶב [the mourning] of the daughter of Yehudah” [meaning:] He caused great mourning. Similarly: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֶּגֶל the remnant” [which is written] concerning Nevuzaraddan [meaning:] he caused the exile of the remnant. [Or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֶּפֶן tail to tail” [meaning:] he caused the tails to turn to each other. All these examples have the meaning: he caused others to do something. But, when it speaks in terms of “he did” the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד is vocalized with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִירִק . For example: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּיטַב in his eyes” [meaning:] it was good [in his eyes]. Similarly: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּרֶב the nation” [meaning:] the nation increased; “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּגֶל Yehudah” [meaning:] Yehudah was exiled; “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּפֶן) He looked all around” [meaning:] He turned here and there. Do not reject my [explanation] [because of the words] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵלֶךְ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵשֶׁב, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵרֶד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵצֵא, because these [words] are not from the same type of verbs as those [above] for the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד in these are part of the root — [in the words:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָלֹךְ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָשֹׁב, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרֹד, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָצֹא the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד is a third root letter. "

§§—2—§§ 1:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּיטָב means HE DID GOOD TO THEM. — The following is the difference between certain forms in a word (verb) whose root is two letters when one prefixes <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י to them: when it intends to express the meaning “and he caused someone or something to do a particular action” (i. e. the 3rd masc. sing, imperf. Hiphil with Vau conversive), the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י has the vowel Tzéré which is what we call Kametz Katan, as, (in this verse) “And God dealt well (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֶּיטָב) with the midwives” (to Rashi the root it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טב; we take it as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יטב); (Lamentations 2:5) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָרָב for the daughter of Judah [mourning]” i. e. He increased (made great) the mourning; (root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֹב; we take it as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבה). Similarly (II Chronicles 36:20) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּגָל the remnant” which occurs in connection with Nebuzaradon, i. e. he caused the remnant to be exiled; (Judges 15:4) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּפָן tail to tail”, i. e. he turned the tails one towards the other (more lit., he caused one tail to turn to the other) — all these express the meaning “he caused others to do something” (i. e. they are of the Hiphil conjugation). When, however, it speaks in the sense of “and he did something” (3rd masc. sing, imperf. Kal with Vau conv.), the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י has the vowel Chirik. For example, (Leviticus 10:20) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִיטַב in his eyes” — this means, “it was good”. Similarly (in this verse) the people”, i. e. the people became many; (2 Kings 25:21) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִגָל Judah”, i. e. Judah became an exile; (2:12) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִפֵן this way and that way”, i. e. he turned this way and that way. Do not answer me (do not raise an objection) by quoting the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּלֶךְ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּשֶׁב and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַרֶד and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּצֵא (saying that these verbal forms also have <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י prefixed and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י has the vowel Tzéré and yet they are Kal, not Hiphil forms), because these are not of the same class of verbs as those above-mentioned, for the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י is part of the root in them — in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵלֵךְ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵשֵׁב and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵרֵד and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵצֵא, the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י is a third root letter in each of these."

—3— **20. Tat Gutes,** erwies ihnen Gutes; das ist der Unterschied bei einem Worte, dessen Wurzel aus zwei Buchstaben besteht und dem Waw und Jud vorgesetzt werden; wenn es die Hiphilform ausdrücken soll, wird das Jud mit einem Zere (Kamez-Katon) (oder Segol = Patach-Katon) punktiert, wie, Gott tat den Hebammen Gutes; (Echa 2,5) Er mehrte in der Tochter Judas, vermehrte die Klage; ebenso (II Chron. 36, 20) er führte den Überrest weg, bei Nebusaradan, er führte den Überrest in die Verbannung; (Richt. 15, 4) er wandte Schweif zu Schweif, er wandte die Schweife einander zu; alle diese Beispiele bedeuten andere veranlassen (Hiphil); wenn er aber den Kal ausdrücken will, ist das Jud mit Chirek punktiert, wie (Lev. 10, 20), es war wohlgefällig in seinen Augen, soviel wie, es war gut; ebenso (hier), das Volk vermehrte sich, das Volk wurde zahlreich; (II Kön. 25, 21) Juda wanderte aus, Juda wurde weggeführt; (2, 12) er wandte sich dahin und dahin, wandte sich nach allen Seiten; wende mir aber nicht ein <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצא (mit Zere); denn diese sind nicht gleich jenen Wurzeln; sondern bei diesen gehört das Jud zum Stamme <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצא; das Jud ist hier ein dritter Wurzelbuchstabe.

////—1—//// 1:20:2,**Elokim was good to the midwives.** What was this good [that was done to them]?

§§—2—§§ 1:20:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וייטב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למילדת THEREFORE GOD DEALT WELL WITH THE MIDWIVES — What was the good He dealt out to them? The next verse gives the reply to this — 

—3— **Gott tat den Hebammen Gutes,** und worin bestand das Gute?

////—1—//// 1:21:1,"**[It was that] He gave them houses.** Houses of the Priesthood and the Levites and Royalty which are referred to as “houses” (dynasties), [as is written:] “And he built the House of God and the house of the king;” the Priesthood and the Levites [descended] from Yocheved and Royalty from Miriam; as is cited in Maseches Sotah. "

§§—2—§§ 1:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתים HE MADE THEM HOUSES — houses (dynasties) of the priesthood and the Levites and of royalty which are all termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתים, “houses”, as it is said, (1 Kings 9:1) “and Solomon built the house of the Lord and the house of the king”: “the house of the Lord” i. e. a dynasty of priests and Levites — from Jochebed (Shifrah); and “the house of the king”, i. e. a royal dynasty — from Miriam (Puah), just as it is stated in Treatise Sotah 11b."

—3— **21. Er machte ihnen Häuser,** Häuser der Priester, der Leviten und der Könige; sie nennt man Häuser, wie es heißt (I Kön. 9,1), das Haus des Ewigen und das Haus des Königs zu bauen; Priester und Leviten von Jochebed und Könige von Mirjam, wie im Traktat Sota (11b) steht.

////—1—//// 1:22:1,"**All his people.** Also upon them (the Egyptians) did he issue the decree. On the day that Moshe was born his astrologers told him, “Today, their savior was born, but we do not know whether he is from the Egyptians or the Jews, but we forsee that he is destined to be smitten through water.” Therefore, on that day, he (Pharaoh) issued a decree also regarding the Egyptians, as it is said: “<font color=d50505>»</font>Every<font color=d50505>«</font> son that will be born” and it does <font color=d50505>»</font>not<font color=d50505>«</font> say: “that will be born to the Hebrews.” They (the astrologers), however, did not know that he (Moshe) was destined to be smitten by the waters of Meriva. "

§§—2—§§ 1:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמו This may be translated AND PHARAOH GAVE COMMAND REGARDING ALL (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל) HIS PEOPLE — Regarding them, too, he made a decree (Sotah 12a). For on the day when Moses was born his astrologers said to him, “To-day their deliverer has been born, but we know not whether he is born of an Egyptian father or of an Israelite; but we see by our astrological art that he will ultimately suffer misfortune through water”. Pharaoh therefore made a decree that day regarding the Egyptians also, as it is said here, “Every son that is born [ye shall cast into the river]”, and it is not stated “[every son] who is born to the Hebrews”. They (the astrologers), however, were not aware that Moses was ultimately to suffer misfortune through the waters of Meribah and not through the waters of the Nile (Exodus Rabbah 1:18; Sotah 12a; cf. also Rashi on Numbers 20:13)."

—3— **22. Seinem ganzen Volke,** auch für dieses galt sein Befehl; an dem Tage, an dem Mosche geboren wurde, sagten seine Astrologen zu ihm, heute wird der Erlöser geboren; nur wissen wir nicht, ob er von den Ägyptern oder ob er von Israel stammt; ferner sehen wir, dass er zuletzt durch Wasser gestraft werden wird; darum verhängte er an jenem Tage auch über die Ägypter; so heißt es, jeden Sohn, der geboren wird, und es steht nicht, bei den Hebräern; sie wussten aber nicht, dass er beim Haderwasser (Num. 20, 13) gestraft würde (Schemot Rabbah).

////—1—//// 2:1:1,"**And married the daughter of Levi.** He (Amram) had separated from her due to Pharaoh’s decree and he [now] took her back and married her a second time. She, too, became youthful again. [Actually] she was 130 years old, for she was born upon their arrival in Egypt between the walls (the entrance of the city). They then spent 210 years there (in Egypt). When they left, Moshe was 80 years old. Thus, when she became pregnant with him she was 130 [years old]. [Yet,] she is referred to as “the daughter of Levi.” "

§§—2—§§ 2:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוי AND HE HAD TAKEN TO WIFE A DAUGHTER OF LEVI — He had lived apart from her in consequence of Pharaoh’s decree that the children should, on their birth, be drowned. Now he took her back and entered into a second marriage with her, and she also physically became young again. For really she was then 130 years old — for she was born “between the walls” when they were about to enter Egypt (cf. Rashi on Genesis 46:15) and they (the Israelites) remained there 210 years, and when they left Egypt Moses was 80 years old; consequently when she became pregnant with him she was 130 years old — and yet Scripture calls her <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוי a young daughter of Levi (Sota 12a; Bava Batra 119b)."

—3— **2, 1. Und nahm die Tochter Levis,** er hatte sich wegen Pharaos Befehl von ihr getrennt (und sie wieder genommen, das bedeutet, er **ging,** er folgte dem Rate seiner Tochter, die zu ihm sagte, dein Gesetz ist härter als das Pharaos; denn Pharao hat nur über die Knaben verhängt, du aber auch über die Mädchen; in einem alten Raschitext) und nahm sie wieder und vollzog mit ihr eine zweite Hochzeit; und auch sie wurde verwandelt und wurde wieder jung; denn sie war 130 Jahre alt, sie war beim Einzug Israels zwischen den Mauern von Mizraim geboren worden; 210 Jahre blieb Israel dort, und als sie auszogen, war Mosche 80 Jahre alt; als sie darum mit ihm Mutter wurde, war sie 130 Jahre alt, und der Vers nennt sie eine (junge) Tochter von Levi (Sota 13a; Bab. b. 119b).
