////—1—//// 2:2:1,**She saw that he was good.** When he was born the entire house was filled with light.

§§—2—§§ 2:2:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טוב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא THAT HE WAS GOODLY — When he was born the whole house became filled with light (Sotah 12a).

—3— **2. Dass er gut war,** als er geboren wurde, füllte sich das ganze Haus mit Licht (Sota 12a). 

---

////—1—//// 2:3:1,"**When she could no longer hide him.** Because the Egyptians calculated [the time] from the day that he (Amram) took her back, but she gave birth to him after six months and one day. [This is possible] because one who gives birth in the seventh month can give birth [even if the 7th month is] incomplete. [But] they (the Egyptians) inquired after her [only] at the end of the ninth month. "

§§—2—§§ 2:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יכלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצפינו AND SHE COULD NO LONGER CONCEAL HIM, because the Egyptians calculated the period from when he (Amram) took her back. She, however, bore him after a term of six months and one day — for a woman who gives birth to a child in the seventh month may do so in incomplete months (i. e. the seventh month of pregnancy may not be completed) (Niddah 38b) — and they (the Egyptians) made enquiry regarding her at the end of nine months (the normal term of pregnancy, but in this case three months after the child’s birth; therefore “she could no longer conceal him”)."

—3— **3. Und sie konnte ihn nicht länger verbergen,** denn die Ägypter hatten ihr von dem Tage an, da er sie wieder genommen, nachgerechnet; sie aber gebar mit sechs Monaten und einem Tag; denn eine Frau, die im siebten Monat gebiert, kann auch nach unvollständigen Monaten gebären; die Ägypter aber forschten ihr am Ende von neun Monaten nach (Sota 12a). 

---

////—1—//// 2:3:2,"**A Papyrus box.** It is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְמִי in Mishnaic Hebrew, and <font color=d50505>»</font>jonc<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. It is a pliable substance which can withstand soft or hard [pressure]. "

§§—2—§§ 2:3:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גמא PAPER-REED — In the language of the Mishna it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גמי (Shabbat 78a), and in old French junc. It is a flexible substance that offers resistance to the pressure of both soft and hard things (Sotah 12a)."

—3— **Schilf,** in der Mischnasprache (Schabbat 78a) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גמי, Binsen in anderen Sprachen; es ist dies etwas Weiches, das vor Weich und Hart standhält. 

---

////—1—//// 2:3:3,"**With clay and tar.** Tar on the outside and clay on the inside, so that the righteous [child] should not have to smell the bad odor of tar. "

§§—2—§§ 2:3:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובזפת — with pitch (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זפת) outside, but with slime (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמר) inside, in order that that righteous child might not smell the disagreeable odour of the pitch (Sotah 12a)."

—3— **Mit Lehm und Pech,** Pech von außen und Lehm von innen, damit jener Fromme nicht den schlechten Geruch des Peches wahrnehme (Sota 12a). 

---

////—1—//// 2:3:4,"**And placed it in the reeds.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוּף means <font color=d50505>»</font>marshland<font color=d50505>«</font> [on the side of a river], <font color=d50505>»</font>rosel<font color=d50505>«</font> (reeds) in Old French, similar to “reeds and marshes (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוּף) shall wilt.” "

§§—2—§§ 2:3:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותשם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסוף AND SHE PUT IT IN THE FLAGS — It (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף) has the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אגם. old French rosel. Another example of the word is (Isaiah 19:6) “And reeds and flags (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף) shall wither”.

—3— **Und legte ihn ins Schilf,** bedeutet soviel wie Röhricht, Schilf in anderen Sprachen; ähnlich (Jes. 19, 6), Rohr und Schilf welken dahin. 

---

////—1—//// 2:5:1,**To bathe by the river.** You must transpose [words in] the verse and [then] explain it [as follows]: “Pharaoh’s daughter went down to the river in order to bathe in it.”

§§—2—§§ 2:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לרחץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היאר — Invert the order of the words in this verse and then explain it: “The daughter of Pharaoh went down <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היאר, by the river, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לרחץ to bathe in it”."

—3— **5. An den Fluss, um zu baden,** stelle den Vers um und erkläre ihn so, die Tochter Pharaos stieg zum Flusse hinab, um darin zu baden. 

---

////—1—//// 2:5:2,"**Along the river’s edge.** [Meaning:] <font color=d50505>»</font>near<font color=d50505>«</font> the river, as in: “See Yoav’s property is next to mine (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָדִי).” It has the meaning of the actual hand because a person’s hand is next to him. Our Sages explained that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹלְכוֹת — walking refers to dying, as in: “Behold, I am going (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹלֵךְ) to die.” They were going to die because they opposed her (Pharaoh’s daughter).” The verse supports them (the Sages’ explanation), because [otherwise] why do we need to write: “And her maidens were walking [going]?” "

§§—2—§§ 2:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היאר means BESIDE THE RIVER. Similar is (II Samuel 14:30) “See, the field of Joab is beside mine (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידי)”. It really denotes even in this sense the actual hand, for a person’s hand is beside him (i. e. beside his body). Our Rabbis explained that the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלכת “they were going” denotes dying, similar to (Genesis 25:32) “Behold I am going (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הולך) to die” — they were going to their death because they attempted to prevent her from saving the child. Scripture, too, supports them in this explanation, for if this is not the meaning, why do we need that it should write “and her damsels were going”? (Scripture reports nothing as having happened because they were walking there. Why then stress this detail if it merely signifies that they were walking along the bank?)."

—3— **An der Seite des Flusses,** neben dem Fluss; wie (II Sam. 14, 30), seht, das Feld Joabs ist neben dem meinigen; es bedeutet wörtlich soviel wie Hand, da die Hand des Menschen dicht neben ihm ist; unsere Lehrer sagen, «sie gingen» bedeutet sterben, sie gingen zum Tode, weil sie ihr wehrten (Sota dort), und der Vers beweist für sie; denn wozu brauchte er sonst uns zu sagen, ihre Mägde gingen! 

---

////—1—//// 2:5:3,"**Her Maid.** [Meaning:] her handmaiden. But the Sages explained it as “hand.” However, according to Hebrew grammar, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲמָתָה should then have been vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font> in the <font color=d50505>»</font>mem.<font color=d50505>«</font> They explain <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲמָתָה as “her arm,” and her arm extended many cubits. "

§§—2—§§ 2:5:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמתה means her handmaid. Our Rabbis, however, explained it in the sense of hand (cf. Sotah 12b) — but according to the grammar of the Holy Language it should then have been written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַמָּתָה , dageshed in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ. — And the reason why they explained <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמתה to mean <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידה “she stretched forth her hand” is because they hold that Scripture intentionally uses this term to indicate that her hand increased in length several cubits (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמה, a cubit) in order that she might more easily reach the cradle."

—3— **Ihre Magd,** ihre Dienerin; unsere Weisen sagen, es bedeutet Hand (Arm); aber nach der Grammatik der hebräischen Sprache hätte dann <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמתח punktiert sein müssen, das Mem mit Dagesch; sie aber erklären, ihren Arm = ihre Hand; ihr Arm wurde viele Ellen lang (Sota dort). 

---

////—1—//// 2:6:1,"**She opened it and saw [the child].** Whom did she see? The child! That is the plain meaning. But, the Midrashic explanation is that she saw the Divine Presence with him. "

§§—2—§§ 2:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותפתח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותראהו lit., AND SHE OPENED IT AND SHE SAW HIM — whom did she see? <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הילד THE CHILD. This is the literal sense of the suffix in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותראהו. A Midrashic explanation is (taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את in the sense of “with”— she saw Him with the child): she saw the Shechina with him (cf. Sotah 12b). "


---

////—1—//// 2:6:2,**And behold a boy was crying.** His voice was like that of a[grown] boy.

§§—2—§§ 2:6:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נער <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכה lit., AND BEHOLD A BOY WEEPING — Although he was a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילד, “a child”, his voice was like that of a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נער, a grown up boy (cf. Sotah 12b)."

—3— **6. Sie öffnete und sah,** wen sah sie? Das Kind, das ist die einfache Erklärung; der Midrasch sagt, sie sah Ihn, die Schechina bei ihm (Schemot Rabbah; Sota dort). Und siehe, ein weinender Knabe, seine Stimme war wie die eines Knaben. 

---

////—1—//// 2:7:1,"**From the Hebrew women.** This teaches that she handed him around to many Egyptian women to be nursed, but he refused to nurse, for he was destined to speak with the Divine Presence. "

§§—2—§§ 2:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העבריות OF THE HEBREWS — She expressly said, “shall I call a nurse of the Hebrews?” because she (Pharaoh’s daughter) had handed him to many Egyptian women to suckle him and he had refused to take suck — this was because he was destined to hold converse with the Shechina (Exodus Rabbah 1:21 and Sotah 12b)."

—3— **7. Von den Hebräerinnen,** sie reichte ihn vielen Ägypterinnen hin, dass er trinke, aber er trank nicht, weil er bestimmt war, mit der Sehechina zu sprechen (Schemot Rabbah; Sota dort). 

---

////—1—//// 2:8:1,**The young girl went.** She went with eagerness and vigor like a young man.

§§—2—§§ 2:8:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העלמה AND THE YOUNG WOMAN WENT — she went eagerly and with vigour (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלמות) like a young man (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלם) (cf. Sotah 12b).

—3— **8. Und das Mädchen ging,** sie ging mit Hurtigkeit und Stärke wie ein Jüngling (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלם.)

---

////—1—//// 2:9:1,**Take this child.** She unknowingly prophesied: “Here is that which belongs to you!”

§§—2—§§ 2:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היליכי (the word may be explained as a compound of two Aramaic words, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הי, here is, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ליכי, that which belongs to thee — thine own) — she prophesied without knowing what she was prophesying (unconsciously she stated the actual fact) — here is thine own (Exodus Rabbah 1:21 and Sotah 12b)."

—3— **9. Hier hast du,** sie weissagte und wusste nicht, was sie weissagte, hier hast du den deinigen (Schemot Rabbah; Sota dort). 

---

////—1—//// 2:10:1,"**I drew him.** As Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁחַלִּתֵּיה which means “extracting” in Aramaic [as in:] “as one who extracts (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּמִשְׁחַל) a hair from milk.” In Hebrew <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשִׁיתִיהוּ means “I removed him,” as in “It shall not be removed [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמוּשׁ].” [Or:] “They did not remove themselves (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשׁוּ).” This is the meaning given [to “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש”] by Menachem. But it is my opinion that it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשִׁיתִיהוּ) is not derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשׁ or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמוּשׁ but from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשֹׁה which has the meaning of “extraction.” Similarly: “He extracts me (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַמְשֵׁנִי) from many waters.” For if it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשִׁיתִיהוּ) would have been from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָש, it would be incorrect to say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשִׁיתִיהוּ, but rather <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲמִישׁוֹתִיהוּ, just as from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָם — (<font color=d50505>»</font>arise<font color=d50505>«</font>) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲקִימוֹתִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>I established<font color=d50505>«</font>) and from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָב — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲשִׁיבוֹתִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>I caused to return<font color=d50505>«</font>) and from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָא — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲבִיאוֹתִי (<font color=d50505>»</font>I brought<font color=d50505>«</font>); or [another <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפעיל form:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְׁתִּיהוּ [should be used] as in: “I will remove the iniquity of the land,” whereas the form <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשִׁיתִי can only be derived from a word whose verb has a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א at the end of the [root] word. For example: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּגוֹן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשָׁה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּנָה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשָׂה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִוָּה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּנָה when the intent is first person singular, the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד is inserted in place of a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָנִיתִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>I built<font color=d50505>«</font>); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשִׂיתִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>I did<font color=d50505>«</font>); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִוִּיתִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>I commanded<font color=d50505>«</font>). "

§§—2—§§ 2:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתיהו The Targum renders this by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחלתיה which in the Aramaic language means drawing out. The word occurs in the Talmud, (Berakhot 8a) “as one draws out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משחל) a hair from milk”, and in the Hebrew language <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתיהו might be taken to mean “I have removed him”, just as, (Joshua 1:8) “it shall not depart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימוש)”; (Numbers 14:44) “they did not depart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משו)”. Thus indeed did Menachem b. Seruk classify it (i. e. he put <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתיהו under the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משו in the verses quoted; according to him a biliteral root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש, our <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ע""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוש). I, however, say, that it should not be classified together with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימוש but that it is to be derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה, and that it means taking out, similar to (II Samuel 22:17) “He draws me out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימשני) from many waters”. For if it were of the same class as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש, it would not be correct to say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתיהו (in the Kal), but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲמישׁוֹתִיהוּ a Hiphil form, (since this root in the Kal means “to depart” or “go away” and not “to make a thing go away”), just as from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קם one says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲקִימוֹתִי and from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שב — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲשִׁיבוֹתִי and from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲבִיאוֹתִי — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא; or one must say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְתִּיהוּ (which is also a form from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוש used in a causative sense), just as, (Zechariah 3:9) “And I will remove (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמַשְׁתִּי) the iniquity of that land”. But <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָשִׁיתִי can only be derived from a word whose verbal form has a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה as a root letter at the end of the word, as e. g., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בנה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צוה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנה. When it wishes to say in regard to these verbs, “I have done so-and-so” (a Kal), a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י takes the place of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה, as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּנִיתִי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשִׂיתִי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִוִּיתִי."

—3— **10. Habe ich ihn gezogen,** herausgezogen (Targ.),<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחל bedeutet herausziehen im Aramäischen; (Berach. 8a), wie man ein Haar aus der Milch zieht; im Hebräischen bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתי׳ soviel wie entfernen; wie (Jos. 1, 8) weiche nicht; (Num. 14, 44) wichen nicht; so verbindet es Menachem; ich aber meine, dass es nicht zur Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימוש gehört, sondern zur Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה und herausnehmen bedeutet; ebenso (II Sam. 22, 17) Er zog mich aus mächtigem Wasser; denn, wenn es zur Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מש gehören würde, dürfte es nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתי׳ heißen, sondern <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המישותי׳, wie man von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקימותיקם, von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השיבותי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שב, von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הביאותי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא, oder <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משתי׳, wie (Sech. 3, 9), ich lasse die Schuld des Landes weichen; aber <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משיתי׳ kann nur von der Wurzel eines Wortes, dessen Stamm am Ende ein <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה hat, kommen, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בנה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה; wenn man davon die Form <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פעלתי bildet, tritt an die Stelle des He ein Jud, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צויתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בניתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשיתי. 

---

////—1—//// 2:11:1,"**Moshe was grown.** Was it not already perviously written “And the lad had grown up”? R. Yehudah, son of R. Eloai said: the first reference is to height and the second to greatness for Pharaoh had appointed him [overseer] of his house. "

§§—2—§§ 2:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגדל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND MOSES WAS GROWN — But has it not already been written, (Exodus 2:10) “And the child grew”? Rabbi Judah the son of Eloai said: the first time it refers to growth in stature, the second time to greatness, — that Pharaoh appointed him to have charge over his palace (Tanchuma Yashan 2.2:17; cf. also Yalkut Shimoni on Torah 166:11)."

—3— **11. Mosche wurde groß,** fürwahr, es steht doch schon (V. 10), das Kind wuchs heran; nur R. Juda b. R. Elasar sagt, das erste bezieht sich auf seine Gestalt und das zweite auf die Würde, da ihn Pharao über sein Haus setzte (Tanchuma waera). 

---

////—1—//// 2:11:2,**And he saw their burdens.** [Meaning:] He cast his eyes and heart to feel their distress.

§§—2—§§ 2:11:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסבלתם AND HE SAW THEIR BURDENS — he set his eyes and mind to share in their distress. (Exodus Rabbah 1:27)

—3— **Und sah ihre Lastarbeiten,** er wandte ihnen seine Augen und sein Herz zu, da sie ihm leid taten (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 2:11:3,**An Egyptian.** He was one of the slavedrivers. He was an overseer over the Israelite officers and he would wake them at the crow of the rooster to their tasks.

§§—2—§§ 2:11:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרי AN EGYPTIAN MAN — This was one of the taskmasters appointed over the Israelite officers and he used to rouse them from their beds at cock-crow that they might proceed to their work (Exodus Rabbah 1:28 and Leviticus Rabbah 32:4).

—3— **Ein ägyptischer Mann,** es war ein Fronvogt, der über die Beamten Israels gesetzt war und der sie schon beim ersten Hahnenschrei zu ihrer Arbeit aufstehen machte. (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 2:11:4,"**Beating one of his Hebrew brethren.** He was beating and terrorizing him. He (the victim) was the husband of Shlomis, daughter of Divri, and he (the Egyptian) was attracted to her. During the night he woke him (her husband) and forced him to leave the house. Then he (the Egyptian) returned and entered the house and came upon his wife while she thought that he was her husband. The [Israelite] man returned home and sensed what had occurred. When that Egyptian realized that he sensed what had happened he beat and terrorized him the entire day. "

§§—2—§§ 2:11:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עברי SMITING A HEBREW MAN — beating and flogging him. The latter was the husband of Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri (see Leviticus 24:11), and the Egyptian taskmaster had set his fancy upon her. During the night he compelled him (her husband) to rise and made him leave the house. He, however, returned, entered the house and forced his attentions upon the woman, she believing it was her husband. The man returned and became aware of what had happened, and when the Egyptian perceived that he was aware of it he beat him and flogged him the whole day long (Exodus Rabbah 1:28)."

—3— **Der einen hebräischen Mann schlug,** er schlug ihn und unterdrückte ihn; es war der Mann von Schelomitb. Dibri(Lev. 24,11); jener hatte auf sie seine Augen geworfen, er machte ihren Mann bei Nacht aufstehen und sein Haus verlassen und ging selbst ins Haus und kam zur Frau des anderen, da sie glaubte, es sei ihr Mann; als der Mann wieder nach Hause kam merkte er die Sache; als ihm nun der Ägypter ansah, dass er die Sache gemerkt hatte, schlug und unterdrückte er ihn den ganzen Tag (dort). 

---

////—1—//// 2:12:1,**He looked all around.** He realized what he [the Egyptian] had done to him at home and what he had done to him in the field. But according to its plain meaning [it may be interpreted] according to its literal meaning.

§§—2—§§ 2:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויפן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכה AND HE TURNED THIS WAY AND THAT WAY — he saw what he had done to him in the house and what he had done to him in the field (outside the house. viz., the beating to which he had subjected him) (Exodus Rabbah 1.28). But according to the literal meaning it must be explained in its ordinary sense: he turned this way and that way."

—3— **12. Er wandte sich dahin und dahin,** er sah, was er ihm im Hause getan hatte und was er ihm auf dein Felde tat (dort); der einfache Sinn ist, wie aus der ÜberSetzung hervorgeht. 

---

////—1—//// 2:12:2,**And he saw that no man was there — ** that was destined to descend from him that would convert [to Judaism].

§§—2—§§ 2:12:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש AND HE SAW THAT THERE WAS NO MAN destined to issue from him, who would become an adherent of Israel’s religion (Exodus Rabbah 1:29; cf. Targum Jonathan on Exodus 2:12) ."

—3— **Und er sah, dass kein Mann da war,** keiner von ihm hervorgehen würde, der sich zum Judentum bekennen würde (Targum Jeruschalmi). 

---

////—1—//// 2:13:1,**Two Hebrew men.** [They were] Dosson and Avirom. They were the ones who left over some of the <font color=d50505>»</font>manna.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 2:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עברים TWO MEN OF THE HEBREWS — viz., Dathan and Abiram (Nedarim 64b); it was they, too, who left over some of the manna (Exodus Rabbah 1:29)."

—3— **13. Hebräische Männer,** Datan und Abiram, dieselben, die auch vom Man übrig ließen (Nedarim 64b). 

---

////—1—//// 2:13:2,**Were quarreling.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִצִּים means] <font color=d50505>»</font>quarreling.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 2:13:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נצים means quarelling.

—3— **Stritten,** zankten sich. 

---

////—1—//// 2:13:3,**Why are you beating?** Though he had not yet struck him he is referred to as a wicked person [just] for raising his hand [to strike].

§§—2—§§ 2:13:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תכה lit., WHEREFORE WILT THOU SMITE — Although he had not yet smitten him he is termed here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רשע wicked, because he had merely raised his hand against him (Sanhedrin 58b)."

—3— **Warum willst du schlagen;** obschon er ihn noch nicht geschlagen hatte, wird er wegen des Emporhebens der Hand ein Bösewicht genannt (Sanhedrin 58b). 

---

////—1—//// 2:13:4,**Your friend.** [Meaning:] “He is as wicked as you.”

§§—2—§§ 2:13:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעך THY FELLOW (the word denotes one who is the equal of another) — who is as wicked as yourself (Exodus Rabbah 1:29).

—3— **Deinen Nächsten,** der ein Bösewicht wie du (Tanchuma) 

---

////—1—//// 2:14:1,**Who made you a man — ** “and you are still a boy.”

§§—2—§§ 2:14:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאיש WHO MADE THEE A PERSONAGE (lit., a man), and you are yet only a boy (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 10)."

—3— **14. Wer hat dich zu einem Manne gemacht,** du bist ja noch ein Knabe (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:14:2,**Do you intend to kill me.** From here we infer that he killed [the Egyptian] with the Divine Name.

§§—2—§§ 2:14:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלהרגני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר lit. WILT THOU SPEAK IN ORDER TO SLAY ME — From this we may learn that he had killed him by the mere utterance of the “Shem Hamephorash” (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 10; Exodus Rabbah 1:30)."

—3— **Sprichst du, mich zu töten,** von hier lernen wir, dass er ihn (den Mizri) mit dem ausgesprochenen Gottesnamen getötet (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:14:3,**Moshe was frightened.** As its plain meaning would indicate. But its midrashic interpretation is: He was concerned that he saw among the Israelites wicked people who were informers. He thus thought: if this is so then perhaps they do not deserve to be redeemed.

§§—2—§§ 2:14:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND MOSES FEARED — Explain it in its literal sense: he was afraid of Pharaoh. A Midrashic explanation is: he felt distressed because he saw that there were wicked men among the Israelites — common informers. He said: Since this is so (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעתה), perhaps they are not worthy to be delivered from bondage (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 10)."

—3— **Da fürchtete sich Mosche,** wie der einfache Sinn ist; der Midrasch sagt, er war besorgt, weil er in Israel Bösewichter, nämlich Angeber, sah, da dachte er, wenn das ist, sind sie vielleicht nicht würdig, erlöst zu werden (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:14:4,"**So the matter is known.** As its meaning implies. But the midrashic interpretation is: “The thing has become known <font color=d50505>»</font>to me,<font color=d50505>«</font> for I had been wondering about it. In what respect was Israel’s sin more than that of all the seventy nations, to be subjugated by oppressive work. But, I now see that they are deserving of it. "

§§—2—§§ 2:14:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדבר SURELY THE THING IS KNOWN — Explain it in its literal sense: the fact that I have killed the Egyptian is known. A Midrashic explanation is: now there is known to me that matter about which I have been puzzled — how has Israel sinned more than all the seventy nations, that they should be oppressed by this crushing servitude? But now I see that they deserve this (Exodus Rabbah 1:30)."

—3— **Fürwahr, die Sache ist bekannt,** wie der einfache Wortsinn ist; der Midrasch sagt, jetzt ist mir die Sache klar, über die ich mich gewundert habe, was hat Israel mehr gesündigt als alle 70 Völker, dass es durch harten Dienst unterdrückt wird; aber ich sehe, dass sie es verdienen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:15:1,**Pharaoh heard.** They (Dosson and Avirom) informed on him.

§§—2—§§ 2:15:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישמע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND PHARAOH HEARD IT — they (Dathan and Abiram) slandered (denounced) him (Exodus Rabbah 1:31).

—3— **15. Pharao hörte,** jene zeigten ihn an (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:15:2,**And he planned to kill Moshe.** He handed him over to the executioner to be killed but the sword had no effect on him. That is what Moshe referred to when he said: “He saved me from Pharaoh’s sword.”

§§—2—§§ 2:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבקש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להרג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND HE SOUGHT TO SLAY MOSES — He handed him over to the executioner to slay him, but the sword proved powerless against him. It is to this that Moses referred when he said, (18:4) “And He delivered me from Pharaoh’s sword” (see Mechilta <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתרו and Exodus Rabbah 1:31). "

—3— **Und er trachtete danach, Mosche zu töten,** er übergab ihn dem Scharfrichter, ihn zu töten; doch das Schwert hatte keine Macht über ihn; das ist, was Mosche sagte (18, 4), und Er rettete mich vor dem Schwerte Pharaos (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:15:3,"**And resided in the land of Midian.** [Here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּשֶׁב means] he remained there as in, “And Yaakov resided.” "

§§—2—§§ 2:15:3," [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדין AND HE ABODE IN THE LAND OF MIDIAN — the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב means he stayed there, as (Genesis 37:1) “And Jacob abode (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב)‎”.]"

—3— **(Er ließ sich im Lande Midjan nieder,** hielt sich dort auf, wie, Jaakob Hess sich nieder). 

---

////—1—//// 2:15:4,**And he sat [lived] near the well.** [Here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֵּשֶׁב] means “sitting.” He (Moshe) learned from Yaakov who found his mate at the well.

§§—2—§§ 2:15:4,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבאר — Here the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב has the meaning of sitting down. He learnt to sit at the well from Jacob whose marriage had been brought about by means of a well (Exodus Rabbah 1:32).

—3— **Er setzte sich an den Brunnen,** er hatte von Jaakob gelernt, dem seine Frau am Brunnen zugesellt ward (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:16:1,**The priest of Midian.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹהֵן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִדְיָן means] the most prominent of them. He abandoned the worship of idols whereupon they (the Midianites) banished him.

§§—2—§§ 2:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולכהן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדין THE PRIEST OF MIDIAN — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כהן signifies the chief amongst them (see Targ. Onkelos and Mekhilta <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתרו); he had abandoned the idol-worship to which they were addicted and they banished him, driving him away from them (Exodus Rabbah 1:32)."

—3— **16. Der Vornehme von Midjan,** der große unter ihnen; er hatte sich vom Götzendienst getrennt, darum hatten sie ihn durch den Bann aus ihrer Mitte ausgestoßen. 

---

////—1—//// 2:16:2,**And fill the troughs.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַרְהָטִים means] the pools of rushing water that were made in the land.

§§—2—§§ 2:16:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרהטים THE GUTTERS — the troughs for the currents of water which are excavated in the ground.

—3— **Die Tränkrinnen,** die Behälter, in die das Wasser lief, die in der Erde gemacht waren. 

---

////—1—//// 2:17:1,**And chased them away.** On account of his (Yisro’s) being banished.

§§—2—§§ 2:17:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגרשם AND THEY DROVE THEM AWAY, because of the banishment into which their father and his family had been driven (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 11)."

—3— **17. Und vertrieben sie** wegen des Bannes (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:20:1,**Why did you abandon.** He realized that he was a descendant of Yaakov for whom the waters [of the Nile] rose.

§§—2—§§ 2:20:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזבתן — WHEREFORE HAVE YE LEFT [THE MAN]? — He recognised that he was of the offspring of Jacob because for him (Moses), as for Jacob, the water had risen in the well at his approach (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 11)"

—3— **20. Warum denn habt ihr verlassen,** er erkannte an ihm, dass er zu den Nachkommen Jaakobs gehörte, weil das Wasser ihm entgegen emporstieg (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:20:2,**And let him eat bread — ** “Perhaps he might marry one of you” as you say: “Except for the bread that he ate.”

§§—2—§§ 2:20:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם THAT HE MAY EAT BREAD — perhaps he will marry one of you — just as you say, (Genesis 39:6) “except the bread which he did eat” (cf. Rashi on this verse, where the word “bread” is explained as a euphemism) (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 11)."

—3— **Dass er ein Mahl bei uns einnehme,** vielleicht wird er eine von euch heiraten; wie wir sagen (Gen. 39,6), bis auf das Brot, das er ass (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 2:21:1,**And Moshe agreed.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיוֹאֶל means as is translated by Onkelos [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּצְבִי]. Similarly: “[<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹאֶל] Please agree to stay overnight” [or:] “Would that we would have consented” [or:] “I have agreed to speak.” But the Midrash translates [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיוֹאֶל] from the root [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָלָה] [i.e.] (Moshe) swore to him (Yisro) that he would not move from Midian unless he received his permission.

§§—2—§§ 2:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויואל — Translate this as the Targum does: AND HE WAS WILLING. Similar are: (Judges 19:6) “Be content (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הואל), I pray thee, and tarry all night”; (Joshua 7:7) “would that we had been content (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הואלנו)”; (Genesis 18:31) “I am content (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הואלתי) to speak”. A Midrashic explanation is that it has the sense of taking an oath (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלה), so that it should be rendered, “And Moses pledged himself by an oath to remain with the man” — he swore to him that he would not stir from Midian save by his permission (cf. Exodus 4:18) (Nedarim 65a)."

—3— **21. Da willigte ein;** wie der Targum sagt, (andere Lesart, wie der einfache Wortsinn ist) ähnlich (Richt. 19,6), willige doch ein und übernachte; (Jos. 7,7) hätten wir uns lieber entschlossen; (Gen. 18, 27) ich habe mich entschlossen, zu sprechen; der Midrasch sagt, es bedeutet einen Schwur; er schwur ihm, dass er Midjan nur mit seiner Erlaubnis verlassen werde (Nedarim 65a). 

---

////—1—//// 2:23:1,"**A long time passed —** during which Moshe was residing in Midian — **and the King of Egypt died — ** and the Israelites needed to be saved — **and Moshe tended [the sheep], etc. — **and salvation came through him. It is for this reason that these chapters were put together. (From an old Rashi text.) "

§§—2—§§ 2:23:1," [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בימים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרבים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ההם AND IT CAME TO PASS DURING THOSE MANY DAYS during which Moses was sojourning in Midian, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים THAT THE KING OF EGYPT DIED, and the Israelites felt the need of help; and therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה “And Moses fed the flock” and help came through him. For this reason these chapters are placed in juxtaposition]."

—3— **23. Es war in jenen vielen Jahren,** die Mosche in Midjan weilte, da starb der König von Mizraim, und Israel brauchte die Erlösung, und Mosche weidete … und durch ihn kam die Erlösung; darum sind diese Abschnitte aneinander angeschlossen (alter Raschitext). 

---

////—1—//// 2:23:2,"**And the king of Egypt died.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָמָת, here meaning:] he was stricken with leprosy, and was slaughtering Israelite infants and bathing in their blood. "

§§—2—§§ 2:23:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים THE KING OF EGYPT DIED — he became stricken with leprosy (and therefore may be spoken of as dead; cf. Numbers 12:12), and he used to slaughter Israelitish children and bathe in their blood as a cure for his disease (cf. Targum Jonathan and Exodus Rabbah 1:34)."

—3— **Da starb der König von Ägypten,** er wurde aussätzig und schlachtete Kinder von Israel und badete in ihrem Blute (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 2:24:1,"**Their groaning.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נַאֲקָתָם means:] their cry. Similarly, “From the populated city (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִנְִאָקוּ) a cry will arise.” "

§§—2—§§ 2:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נאקתם means THEIR CRY. Similar is, (Job 24:12) “from out of the populous city men groan (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ינאקו)”."

—3— **24. Ihr Weheklagen,** ihr Wehegeschrei, ebenso (Job 24, 12) aus der Stadt schreien die Männer empor. 

---

////—1—//// 2:24:2,**His covenant with Avraham.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַבְרָהָם means:] <font color=d50505>»</font>with<font color=d50505>«</font> Avraham.

§§—2—§§ 2:24:2,"‎ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בריתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אברהם — The words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אברהם, are the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אברהם, with Abraham (i. e. the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את means “with”, whilst in the preceding phrase, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בריתו, it is the sign of the accusative)."

—3— **Seines Bundes mit Abraham**, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם =<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את mit. 

---

////—1—//// 2:25:1,**Elokim took knowledge of them.** [Meaning:] He gave His attention to them and He [no longer] ignored them.

§§—2—§§ 2:25:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים AND GOD KNEW — He directed His heart to them and did not hide His eyes from them.

—3— **25. Und Gott erkannte,** richtete Sein Herz auf sie und entzog ihnen nicht Seine Augen. 

---

////—1—//// 3:1:1,**To the edge of the wilderness.** In order to distance himself from theft whereby [the sheep] will not graze in others’ fields.

§§—2—§§ 3:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המדבר [HE LED THE SHEEP] BEHIND THE DESERT — in order to keep them away from private property (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גֶזֵל i. e. things which can be appropriated only as the result of “robbery”) — that they should not graze in other people’s fields (Exodus Rabbah 2:3).

—3— **3, 1. Hinter die Wüste,** um sich vom Raub zu entfernen, dass sie nicht auf fremden Feldern weideten (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 3:1:2,**To the mountain of God.** So called because of what was destined to occur there.

§§—2—§§ 3:1:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האלהים TO THE MOUNTAIN OF GOD — Scripture so names it with reference to what happened there in the future (Sifrei on Deuteronomy 1:24).

—3— **Zum Berge Gottes,** nach der Zukunft so benannt (Sifre Deb.). 

---

////—1—//// 3:2:1,"**In the heart of a fire.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּלַבַּת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵשׁ means:] in the flame of the fire, [i.e.] the “heart” of the fire, as in: “in the heart (the middle) of the heavens” or: “in the heart (the middle) of the oak tree.” Do not wonder as to the (extra) letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' because we find similar examples: “How strong is (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִבָּתֵךְ) [the wickedness of] your heart!” "

§§—2—§§ 3:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אש means IN A FLAME OF FIRE, i. e. in the very heart of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב) the fire. Similarly is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב used of inanimate objects in: (Deuteronomy 4:11) “in the heart of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב) heaven”; (II Samuel 18:14) “in the midst of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב) the terebinth”. Do not be puzzled by the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת, although the ordinary word for heart, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב. does not require the suffix <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת in the construct form, because we have another example of this form, viz., (Ezekiel 16:30) “how weak is thy heart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבתך)”.‎ "

—3— **2. In einer Feuersflamme,** Flamme des Feuers, Herz (Mitte) des Feuers; wie (Deut. 4,11) Herz (Mitte) des Himmels; (II Sam. 18,14) Mitte der Eiche; und wundere dich nicht über das <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת; denn wir finden ähnlich (Jech. 16, 30), wie verdorben ist dein Herz. 

---

////—1—//// 3:2:2,**From the midst of the thorn-bush.** And not another tree because [of the idea expressed in]: “I (God) am with him (Israel) in his trouble.”

§§—2—§§ 3:2:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתוך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הסנה OUT OF THE MIDST OF A BUSH (a thornbush) — and not from any other tree, in accordance with the idea (Psalms 91:15) “I will be with him in trouble” (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 14)."

—3— **Aus der Mitte des Dornbusches,** aber nicht eines anderen (höheren) Baumes wegen (Ps. 91, 15), Ich bin mit ihm in der Not (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 3:2:3,**Consumed.** [Meaning:] consumed as in: “That has not been (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻבַּד) worked” “that was (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֻקַּח) taken from there.”

§§—2—§§ 3:2:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֻכָּל means DEVOURED, eaten. It is of the same grammatical form as, (Deuteronomy 21:3) “which hath not been wrought with (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻבַּר)”; (Genesis 3:23) “whence he was taken (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֻקַח): "

—3— **Verzehrt,** Pual wie Niphal verzehrt; ebenso (Deut. 21, 3), mit dem noch nicht gearbeitet worden; (Gen. 3, 23) von dem er genommen worden.

////—1—//// 3:11:2,**Am I able to bring the Bnei Yisrael out.** “And even if I <font color=d50505>»</font>am<font color=d50505>«</font> important what did the Israelites do to merit that a miracle be performed for them that [will enable me] to bring them out of Egypt?” **Because I will be with you.** And the fact that you will succeed in my mission —

§§—2—§§ 3:11:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אוציא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל AND THAT I SHOULD BRING FORTH THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL — and even if I am of sufficient importance for this, how has Israel merited that a miracle should be wrought for them and that I should bring them forth from Egypt?"

—3— **Und dass ich die Kinder Israel herausführe,** und selbst wenn ich würdig wäre, welches Verdienst hat Israel, dass ihnen ein Wunder geschehe, dass ich sie aus Ägypten herausführe?

////—1—//// 3:12:1,"**He [God] said, “Because I will be with you.** He (God) responded to his first question first and to his last question last: “Concerning that which you said, Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh? [My response is:] It is not <font color=d50505>»</font>your<font color=d50505>«</font> [mission] but, rather, Mine, <font color=d50505>»</font>for I will be with you,<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=d50505>»</font>and<font color=d50505>«</font> the vision that you saw in the thornbush <font color=d50505>»</font>is a sign to you that it is I who sent you<font color=d50505>«</font> and that you will succeed in My mission and I am capable of saving, as you yourself saw the thornbush carrying out My mission without being consumed. You, too, shall go on My mission and you will not be harmed. As to that which you asked: what merit do the Israelites have that they should go out of Egypt? I have a great purpose in bringing them out: for they are destined to receive the Torah on this mountain three months after they go out of Egypt. An alternate explanation: **will be the proof —** of another promise; for I promise you that when you will bring them out of Egypt they will serve Me on this mountain by receiving the Torah upon it. This is the merit which stands by Israel. We find a similar sentence structure “And this will be a sign to you — that this year you will eat that which grew of itself, etc.” [i.e.] the fall of Sancheriv [mentioned earlier] will serve you as a sign for [the fulfillment] of another promise: “for [although] your land is [now] barren of fruit I will abundantly bless that which grows of itself.” "

§§—2—§§ 3:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמך AND HE SAID, BECAUSE I WILL BE WITH THEE — He answered his first question first and his last question last: as regards what thou hast said, “Who am I that I should go unto Pharaoh?” i. e. of what importance am I to speak with kings, I reply, it is not an undertaking of yours, but it is partly mine for “I” will be with thee”,  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזה AND THIS — i. e. the sight which thou hast witnessed in the bush, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלחתיך SHALL BE A SIGN UNTO THEE, BECAUSE (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי) “I” HAVE SENT THEE and “I” am competent to save: just as thou hast seen the bush carrying out the mission I laid upon it and it was not consumed, so go thou too on the mission I entrust to thee and thou shalt suffer no harm. And as regards thy question: What merit have the Israelites that they should go forth from Egypt? — I reply that I have a great purpose in this, My bringing them forth, for they are destined to accept the Torah upon this mountain at the expiration of three months after they leave Egypt (cf. Exodus Rabbah 3:4). Another explanation is: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמך FOR I WILL BE WITH THEE and thou wilt therefore succeed, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזה AND THIS — viz., the fact that thou wilt succeed in thy mission <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האות WILL BE A SIGN UNTO THEE with respect to another promise: for I promise thee that when thou hast brought them forth from Egypt ye will serve Me upon this mountain — i. e. that ye will receive the Torah upon it. This is the merit which is an advocate for Israel. An exactly similar use of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אות, where something that will happen in the future is to serve as an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אות in regard to an event that will transpire in the more distant future we find elsewhere: (Isaiah 27:30.) “And this shall be a sign unto thee — for ye shall eat this year that which groweth of itself etc.” (the passage proceeds to state that after a few years the devastated land will have regained its former fertility) — this, i. e, the fall of Sennacherib promised in the preceding section of that chapter shall be a sign to thee in respect to another promise: for your land is now barren of fruits, but I will bless that which grows of itself and the land shall bring forth fruits in abundance."

—3— **12. Er sprach, ich werde mit dir sein,** Er antwortete ihm auf das Erste zuerst und auf das Letzte zuletzt; dass du gesagt, wer bin ich, dass ich zu Pharao gehe; nicht deine Sache ist es, sondern die meinige; denn ich werde mit dir sein; und diese Erscheinung, die du am Dornbusch gesehen, sei dir das Zeichen, dass ich dich geschickt habe und dass es dir gelingen wird, meinen Auftrag durchzuführen, und dass ich mächtig bin, zu retten; wie du gesehen, dass der Dornbusch meinen Auftrag erfüllt und nicht verzehrt wird, so sollst du in meinem Aufträge hingehen, und du wirst keinen Schaden erleiden. Und was du gefragt hast, welches Verdienst hat Israel, dass sie aus Ägypten ziehen sollen? Ein großes Ziel habe ich bei diesem Auszuge; denn sie werden an diesem Berge am Ende von drei Monaten, nachdem sie aus Ägypten gezogen, die Torah annehmen (Schemot Rabbah). Andere Erklärung: ich werde mit dir sein, und dass dir dein Auftrag gelingen wird, sei dir das Vorzeichen für eine andere Verheißung, die ich dir gebe, dass ihr nämlich, wenn du sie aus Ägypten geführt, mir an diesem Berge dienen werdet, indem ihr an ihm die Torah annehmet; und das ist das Verdienst, das Israel beisteht. Einen ähnlichen Ausdruck finden wir in Jeschaja (37, 30), das sei dir das Zeichen, dass ihr in diesem Jahre Nachwuchs genießen werdet… Der Sturz von Sancherib nämlich sei dir das Zeichen für eine andere Verheißung, in euerem Land ist die Ernte vernichtet, ich aber werde die Nachwüchse segnen.

////—1—//// 3:14:1,"**Ehyeh Asher Ehyeh.** **I will be that what I will be.** [Meaning:] “‘I, Who shall Be’ with them in this suffering [am the One] ‘Who will be’ with them when they will be subjugated by the other kingdoms.” [Whereupon] he (Moshe) said to Him, “Master of the Universe, why should I mention other suffering, it is sufficient [that they know of] their present suffering.” He (God) said to him, “You have spoken well, ‘This is what you must say, etc.’” "

§§—2—§§ 3:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהיה I AM THAT I AM — I will be with them in this sorrow — I Who I will be with them in the subjection they will suffer at the hands of other kingdoms (Berakhot 9b). Whereupon Moses said to him: Lord of the Universe! Why should I mention to them other sorrows: they have enough with this sorrow! God replied to him: You have spoken rightly —  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאמר THUS SHALT THOU SAY etc.… Ehyeh, “I am” — without the addition of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהיה which has reference to future sorrows — has sent me unto you”.

—3— **14. Ich werde sein, der ich immer sein werde,** ich werde mit ihnen sein in dieser Not, der ich mit ihnen sein werde in der Knechtung durch die anderen Reiche (Ber. 9b); da sagte er vor Ihm, Herr der Welt, warum soll ich ihnen schon eine andere Not erwähnen; sie haben an dieser Not genug; und Er sprach, du hast gut gesprochen, so sage…

////—1—//// 3:15:1,"**This is my eternal Name.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְעֹלָם] is missing the letter <font color=d50505>»</font>vav<font color=d50505>«</font> [after the <font color=d50505>»</font> ayin<font color=d50505>«</font>], [in effect] saying, “Conceal it.” so that it (My Name) not be read as written. "
"

§§—2—§§ 3:15:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעלם THIS IS MY NAME FOR EVER — The last word is written without <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו (so that it may be read <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְעַלֵּם and it would mean “this is My Name which is to be concealed”) to suggest: Conceal it (this Divine Name), so that it shall not be read exactly as it is written (but should be read as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדני; cf. Pesachim 50a; Exodus Rabbah 3:7)."""

////—1—//// 3:15:2,"**And this is how I am to be mentioned.** He (God) taught him how [the Name] is to be read. Similarly, David says: “Your Name is forever, The mention of Your Name is for all generations.” "

§§—2—§§ 3:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכרי AND THIS IS MY MEMORIAL (the word may signify “the mention of Me”) — He taught him how the Divine Name should be read. So, too, did David say, (Psalms 135:13) “O Lord, Thy name is for ever (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעולם), O Lord, Thy memorial is throughout all generations (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכרך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודר)."

—3— **Und dies ist mein Gedenken,** Er lehrte ihn, wie er ausgesprochen wird; und so sagte David (Ps. 135, 13), Ewiger, Dein Name besteht in Ewigkeit, Ewiger, Dein Gedenken von Geschlecht zu Geschlecht.

////—1—//// 3:18:1,"**They will listen to your voice —** of their own volition (i.e., without waiting for signs). “Once you tell it to them using this expression they will listen to your voice, for this sign has already been transmitted to them through Yaakov and Yoseif that with this expression they will be redeemed.” Yaakov said to them: “And Elokim will surely consider you.” Yoseif, [too,] said to them: “Elokim will surely consider you.” "

§§—2—§§ 3:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושמעו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקלך AND THEY SHALL HEARKEN TO THY VOICE — as soon as you will mention to them this expression (the double use of the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקד as in v. 16) they will hearken to your voice, for they have long had this sign as a tradition from Jacob and Joseph that by mention of this phrase their deliverance will be brought about. Jacob said to them “And God will surely visit you”, and Joseph said to them (Genesis 50:25) “God will surely visit you”."

—3— **18. Und sie werden auf deine Stimme hören,** von selbst, sobald du diese Worte zu ihnen sprechen wirst, werden sie auf deine Stimme hören; denn dieses Zeichen ist bereits seit Jaakob und Josef bei ihnen überliefert worden, dass sie mit diesen Worten erlöst würden, Jaakob sagte (durch Josef) zu ihnen (Gen. 50,24), Gott wird euer gedenken; Josef sagte zu ihnen (dort 25), Gott wird euer gedenken (Schemot Rabbah).

////—1—//// 3:18:2,"**Happened to meet with us.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִקְרָה is derived from] the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְרֶה (happening). Similarly, “And God [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּקָּר] happened to meet,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאָנֹכִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִקָּרֶה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹּה .” [Meaning:] I will be met (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִקָּרֶה) by Him here.” "

§§—2—§§ 3:18:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלינו GOD HATH HAPPENED TO MEET US — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקרה signifies a casual meeting. Similar are: (Numbers 23:4) “And God happened to meet (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקר) [Balaam]”; (Numbers 23:15) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואנכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִקָּרָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה which means “I will be met by him yonder”.

////—1—//// 3:19:1,**The king of Egypt will not allow you to go —** unless I show him My strong hand; meaning: “As long as I do not make him aware [of] My strong hand he will not allow you to leave.

§§—2—§§ 3:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להלך THE KING OF EGYPT WILL NOT LET YOU GO, if I do not (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא) show him My strong hand (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חזקה) — it is as much as to say: so long as I do not let him feel My strong hand he will not let you go."

—3— **19. Der König von Ägypten wird euch nicht erlauben zu gehen,** wenn ich ihm nicht meine starke Hand zeige, das heißt, solange ich ihm nicht meine starke Hand offenbare, wird er euch nicht erlauben zu gehen. Er wird nicht erlauben, nicht zulassen, wie (Gen. 20, 6) darum gestattete ich dir nicht; (Gen. 31, 7) Gott erlaubte ihm nicht, mir Böses zu tun; überall hat es die Bedeutung von geben; manche erklären, und nicht um der starken Hand willen, nicht weil seine Hand stark ist; denn, sobald ich meine Hand ausstrecke und Ägypten schlage… unser Targum übersetzt, und nicht darum, weil seine Macht stark ist. Im Namen von R. Jakob b. R. Menachem wurde mir dies gesagt.

////—1—//// 3:19:2,"**Will not allow.** [As Onkelos translates it:] He will not permit, as in: “Therefore I did not (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְתַתִּיךָ) allow you” — [or:] “God did not allow him to harm me.” These are all terms denoting <font color=d50505>»</font>giving.<font color=d50505>«</font> There are others who explain <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּיָד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲזָקָה: “And not because his hand is strong, for ‘once I will send forth My Hand and strike Egypt, etc.’” Onkelos translates it [accordingly]: “And not because his power is strong.” In the name of R. Yaakov b. R. Menachem this was told to me. "

§§—2—§§ 3:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתן — Translate this as the Targum does: he will not give leave. Similar uses of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתן followed by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל with the infinitive in sense of permitting are: (Genesis 20:6) “therefore I did not permit thee (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתתיך) to touch her”; (Genesis 31:7) “And God did not permit him (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתנו) to do me evil”. Still all these passages really have the sense of giving”. Some explain the phrase <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חזקה to signify: “He will not permit you to go, and this will not be because his hand is strong”, for (v. 20) “As soon as I stretch forth My hand I will smite the Egyptians [… and afterwards he will let you go]”. And so the Targum renders it: and not on account that his power is mighty. This explanation was told me in the name of Rabbi Jacob the son of Menachem."

////—1—//// 3:22:1,**From the woman living in her house.** [Meaning:] from the one that resides with her in the house.

////—1—//// 3:22:2,"**And you will divest [Egypt from its wealth].** As Onkelos translates it: <font color=d50505>»</font>You will empty.<font color=d50505>«</font> Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְנַצְּלוּ) And they emptied Egypt,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּתְנַצְּלוּ) The Israelites divested themselves of their ornaments.” The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ' in it is part of the root. However, Menachem places it in the Machberes [with the words beginning with a] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צד""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י together with: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּצֵּל) God took away your father’s cattle” [or:] “That (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִצִּיל) God took away from our father.” His (Menachem’s) words cannot be given credence for if the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ן were not part of the root and [since] it is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>chirik<font color=d50505>«</font> it cannot be used to express “And you shall do something” but, rather, a term of: “Something shall be done to you,” as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִסַחְתֶּם) You will be uprooted from the land,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִתַּתֶּם) You will be given over to an enemy,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִגַפְתֶּם) You will be stricken before your enemies,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִתַּכְתֶּם) You will be disintegrated in her midst,” [or:] “You shall say, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִצַּלְנוּ) ‘We have been saved.’” meaning: “Something was done to us.” Whereas, every letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ן which sometimes appears in a word and is sometimes omitted such as the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ן of: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹגֵף, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹשֵֹא, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹתֵן, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹשֵׁךְ when it speaks in terms meaning: “And you shall do something” is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>shva,<font color=d50505>«</font> e.g. “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְשָׂאתֶם) You shall carry your father,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְתַתֶּם) And you shall give them the land of Gilead,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְמַלְתֶּם) And you shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin.” I, therefore, say that this [letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נו""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ן] that is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font> chirik<font color=d50505>«</font> is part of the root and has the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִצּוּל which is one of the “strong” conjugations such as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבּוּר, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּפּוּר, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִמּוּד . When [these words] express the term “And you shall do something will be vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>chirik,<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְדִבַּרְתֶּם) You shall speak to the stone,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְכִּפַּרְתֶּם) And you will atone for the house,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלִמַּדְתֶּם) You shall teach it to your sons.” "

§§—2—§§ 3:22:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונצלתם render it as the Targum does: and ye shall empty out Egypt. Similar are: (Exodus 12:36) “And they emptied out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וינצלו) Egypt”; (Exodus 33:6) “And the children of Israel stripped themselves (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתנצלו) of their ornaments” The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ in it is a root-letter. Menachem ben Seruk placed it (this word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתנצלו) in section <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צ (taking the root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צל not as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נצל) together with, (Genesis 31:9) “And God took away (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצל) your father’s cattle”, and with, (Genesis 31:16) “which God hath taken away (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הציל) from our father”, but his view cannot be sustained. For if the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ is not a root-letter, then seeing that it (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונצלתם) is vowelled with Chirik, it cannot be used in the sense of “and ye shall do something” (the active voice, which is required here since <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים can only be the object of the verb), but in the sense of “and ye shall have something done to you” (the passive — “Niphal”), as (Deuteronomy 28:63) “And ye shall be plucked up (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִסַּחְתֶּם) from off your land”; (Leviticus 26:25) “and ye shall be given (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִתַּתֶּם) into the hand of the enemy”; (Leviticus 17) “And ye shall be smitten (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִגַּפְתָּם) before your enemies”; (Ezekiel 22:21) “And ye shall be melted (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִתַּכְתָּם) in the midst thereof”; (Jeremiah 7:10) “And ye say, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִצַּלְנוּ” — which expresses the idea “we have had something done to us” (the Niphal: we have been delivered). Then again, every <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ which sometimes appears in a word and sometimes is omitted, as e. g. the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוגף and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נושא and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נותן and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נושך, when the word expresses the sense “and ye shall do something” (the Kal), it is pointed with vocal Sheva (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטף a “snatched” sound), as, for instance, (Genesis 45:19) “and ye shall bear (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְשָׂאתָם) your father”; (Numbers 32:29) “And ye shall give (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְתַתֶּם) them the land of Gilead”; (Genesis 17:11) “And ye shall circumcise (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּנְמַלְתֶּם) the flesh of your foreskin”. Consequently I am of the opinion that this letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ which is vowelled with a Chirik is one of the root letters, and the grammatical form of the noun of the same root is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִצּוּל which is of the strong (dageshed) forms, just as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבּוּר and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּפּוּר and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִמּוּד. When, in the case of verbs formed from these roots one expresses the idea of “and ye shall do something” (active voice) the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ has the vowel Chirik (i. e. it is the Piel conjugation), as (Numbers 20:8) “And ye shall speak (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְדִבַּרְתֶּם) unto the rock”; (Ezekiel 45:20) “And ye shall atone (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְכִּפַּרְתֶּם) for the house”; (Deuteronomy 11:19) “And ye shall teach (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלִמַּדְתָּם) them unto your children”."

—3— **Und ihr werdet ausleeren,** wie der Targum übersetzt, ihr werdet leer machen; ebenso (12,36), sie leerten Ägypten aus; (33, 6) die Kinder Israel beraubten sich ihres Schmuckes, das Nun daran gehört zur Wurzel. Menachem verbindet es unter den Wurzeln von Zadi mit (Gen. 31, 9,16), und Gott sonderte die Herde eures Vaters ab, den Gott von unserem Vater genommen; aber seine Worte sind nicht richtig; denn, wenn das Nun nicht zur Wurzel gehört und mit Chirek punktiert wird, dann gehört die Form nicht zum Kal (Aktiv), sondern zum Niphal (Passiv); wie (Deut. 28, 63) ihr werdet aus dem Erdboden ausgerissen; (Levit. 26,25) ihr werdet in die Hand des Feindes gegeben; (dort 17) ihr werdet geschlagen von eueren Feinden; (Jech. 22, 21) ihr werdet darin geschmolzen; (Jer. 7, 10) und ihr saget, wir sind gerettet, passive Form. Das Nun aber, das zuweilen vor dem Worte steht und zuweilen ausfällt, wie das Nun von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נושך,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נותן,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נושא,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוגף, erhält, wenn es eine aktive Form ausdrückt, ein Schwa (Chatof), wie (Gen. 45, 19) und traget eueren Vater; (Num. 32, 29) gebet ihnen das Land Gilead; (Gen. 17, 11) beschneidet das Fleisch eurer Vorhaut. Darum sage ich, dass der mit Chirek punktierte Buchstabe zur Wurzel gehört und die Wurzel im Hauptwort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נצול lautet; dieses gehört zu den verschärften Formen wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למוד,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפור,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבור; wenn man von diesen die aktive Form bildet, punktiert man mit Chirek, wie (Num. 208 ״), sprechet zum Felsen; (Jech. 45, 20) sühnet das Haus; (Deut. 11, 19) lehret sie euere Kinder.

////—1—//// 4:2:1,"**“What is that in your hand?”** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זֶה] is written as one word so that it can be explained: “From that which is in your hand you deserve to be punished, for you were suspicious of righteous people.” The plain meaning of it is as a person who says to his friend, “Do you agree that the item before you is a stone?” “Yes,” he responds. “Well, watch as I turn it into wood.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בידך WHAT IS THAT IN THINE HAND? —The reason why the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה are written here as one word is to afford the opportunity to explain it thus: on account of this (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִזֶּה) that is in thine hand thou wilt make thyself liable to punishment because thou hast harboured suspicion about worthy persons (Exodus Rabbah 3:12). The real meaning, however, is that it is a question such as one puts to his fellow: “You admit that this object in front of you is a stone?” The other replies, “Yes”. The former says, “Well, I’ll turn it into wood”."

—3— **4, 2. Was ist dies in deiner Hand;** darum ist <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה in einem Worte geschrieben, damit man erkläre, mit diesem in deiner Hand verdienst du geschlagen zu werden, weil du Fromme verdächtigt hast (Tanchuma); der einfache Sinn ist, wie wenn einer zum anderen sagt, du gibst doch zu, dass das, was vor dir liegt, ein Stein ist, und jener sagt, ja; da spricht der erste, siehe, ich mache daraus ein Stück Holz. 

---

////—1—//// 4:3:1,"**And it turned into a snake.** He indicated to him that he spoke slanderous words against Israel, when he said, “They will not believe me,” and so he assumed for himself the occupation of the snake. "

§§—2—§§ 4:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנחש AND IT BECAME A SERPENT — This was an indication to him, that he had slandered the Israelites by saying (v. 1) “But, behold they will not believe me etc.”, and that he had made the serpent’s occupation (slander) his own (cf. Genesis 3:5) (Exodus Rabbah 3:12)."

—3— **3. Und er ward zu einer Schlange,** Er deutete ihm damit an, dass er böse Rede über Israel ausgesprochen (indem er gesagt, sie werden mir nicht vertrauen) und damit das Gewerbe der (ersten) Schlange ergriffen hatte (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 4:4:1,"**And took hold of it.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַחֲזֶק] has the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>grasping.<font color=d50505>«</font> There are a number of [such uses] in Scripture: “[<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּחֲזִיקוּ] The men took hold of his hand,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֶחֱזִיקָה) She took hold of his private parts,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֶחֱזַקְתִּי) I took hold of his beard.” Wherever the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִזוּק is followed by the prefix <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב' it has the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>grasping.<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 4:4:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחזק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו AND HE LAID HOLD OF IT —The phrase signifies “grasping” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחז). There are many examples of it in the Scriptures: (Genesis 19:16) “The men laid hold of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחזיקו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּ..) his hand”; (Deuteronomy 25:11) “And she layeth hold of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והחזיקה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּ..) his secret parts”; (I Samuel 17:35) “And I caught him by (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והחזקתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּ..) his beard”. [Wherever the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חזק in the Hiphil is followed by the preposition <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב it denotes “taking hold of a thing”].

—3— **4. Und ergriff sie,** bedeutet anfassen und kommt häufig im Vers vor; (Gen. 19,16) die Männer ergriffen ihn bei der Hand; (Deut. 25,11) und sie ergreift seine Scham; (I Sam. 17,35) und ich ergriff ihn am Bart; überall, wo <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חזוק mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב verbunden ist, bedeutet es anfassen. 

---

////—1—//// 4:6:1,"**A snow-like <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as.<font color=d50505>«</font>** It is usual for <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as<font color=d50505>«</font> to be white [as we find:] “If it be a white blemish.” With this sign, too, He hinted to him that he spoke slanderously when he said, “They will not believe me.” It is for this reason that He struck him with <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as,<font color=d50505>«</font> just as Miriam was struck for speaking slanderously. "

§§—2—§§ 4:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כשלג LEPROUS AS SNOW — It is the nature of leprosy to be white, and thus we read in reference to a leper, (Leviticus 13:4) “If the bright spot be white [in the skin of his flesh]”. By this sign, too, he indicated that he had made a slanderous statement when he said, (v. 1) “But, behold, they will not believe me”. Therefore He smote him with leprosy (Exodus Rabbah 3:13) even as Miriam was so smitten for the slander she had spoken (cf. Shabbat 97a)."

—3— **6. Aussätzig wie Schnee,** Aussatz pflegt weiß zu sein; (Lev. 13, 4) wenn es ein weißer Flecken ist; auch mit diesem Zeichen deutete Er ihm an, dass er böse Rede ausgesprochen, indem er gesagt, sie werden mir nicht vertrauen; darum schlug Er ihn mit Aussatz, wie Mirjam wegen böser Rede geschlagen wurde (Schabbat 97a). 

---

////—1—//// 4:7:1,"**And when he withdrew from his bosom, etc.** We can derive from this that [when God reveals] His attribute of goodness it is much faster in coming than [when He reveals] His attribute for punishment, for in the first instance [when he was struck with <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as<font color=d50505>«</font>] it does not state: “from his bosom.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויוצאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחיקו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבשרו AND HE BROUGHT IT OUT OF HIS BOSOM AND, BEHOLD, IT HAD RETURNED AS HIS OTHER FLESH — From this we may infer that the measure of Divine good comes more quickly than the measure of the punishment He inflicts, for in the former case it does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחיקו after the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויוצאה. (Shabbat 97a; Exodus Rabbah 3:13)."

—3— **7. Aus seinem Busen, und siehe, sie war wie sein Fleisch geworden;** von hier geht hervor, dass die Gnade Gottes schneller kommt als Seine Strafe; denn das erstemal (als die Hand aussätzig wurde) steht nicht (wie hier bei der Heilung), aus seinem Busen (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 4:8:1,"**Then they will believe the voice [of proof] of the latter sign.** “Once you tell them, ‘because of you I was struck [with <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as<font color=d50505>«</font>] for relating slanderous things about you, they will believe you, because they have already become experienced in this, that those who conspire to harm them are struck with <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as,<font color=d50505>«</font> such as Pharaoh and Avimelech [who were struck with <font color=d50505>»</font>tzora’as<font color=d50505>«</font>] on account of Sarah. "

§§—2—§§ 4:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והאמינו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האחרון THEY WILL BELIEVE THE VOICE OF THE LATTER SIGN — As soon as you say to them, “On your account have I been smitten — because I uttered slander about you”, they will believe you, for they are already experienced in this: that those who combine to harm them are smitten by plagues, e. g., Pharaoh and Abimelech who were punished on Sarah’s account."

—3— **8. So werden sie der Stimme des letzten Zeichens vertrauen;** wenn du ihnen sagst, um euretwillen wurde ich geschlagen, weil ich böse Rede über euch ausgesprochen, so werden sie dir vertrauen; denn daran sind sie schon gewöhnt, dass diejenigen, die sich mit ihnen einlassen, um ihnen Böses zu tun, mit Aussatzschäden geschlagen werden, wie Pharao und Abimelech um Saras willen. 

---

////—1—//// 4:9:1,"**You shall take from the water of the river.** He alluded to them that with the first plague He will exact retribution from their deity (Explanation: When God exacts retribution from the nations He first exacts retribution from their deity, for they had worshipped the Nile which gave them sustenance and He turned them (its waters) to blood. [This explanation is found] in an old Rashi manuscript."

§§—2—§§ 4:9:1,

—3— **9. So nimm vom Wasser des Flusses** (Er deutete ihm damit an, dass Er mit der ersten Plage zuerst ihren Abgott strafen würde [Schemot Rabbah]; denn sie beteten den Nil an, der sie ernährte; und ihn in Blut verwandeln würde. Alter Raschitext). 

---

////—1—//// 4:9:2,"**The water [you will take].** The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיוּ [appears] twice [in this verse]: It seems to me that had it said: ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמַּיִּם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּקַּח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיְאוֹר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְדָם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּיַּבָּשֶׁת"", I would conclude that while <font color=d50505>»</font>still in his hand<font color=d50505>«</font> [the waters] will turn into blood and also upon reaching the ground they would remain as they are but, now, [by repeating <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיוּ, i.e., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְדָם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּיַּבָּשֶׁת] it teaches us that they will not turn into blood until they reach the dry land. "

§§—2—§§ 4:9:2,"  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ — Here we have the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיו twice. It appears to me that if it was stated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היאר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביבשת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקח, I might understand it to mean that it would be turned into blood in his hand and that also when it reached the ground it would retain that state (more lit., it would be as it was). But now (as the text stands) it tells us that it would not become blood until it would come on the dry ground."

—3— **Und es werde das Wasser;** es steht zweimal <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיו; es scheint mir, wenn nur stehen würde, und es werde das Wasser, das du aus dem Flusse nimmst, zu Blut auf dem Trockenen, so würde ich daraus entnehmen, dass es sich schon in seiner Hand in Blut verwandeln werde und dann, wenn es auf die Erde falle, in diesem Zustand bleibe; jetzt aber lehrt er uns, dass es sich erst in Blut verwandeln werde, wenn es auf dem Trockenen sein werde.
