////—1—//// 4:10:1,"**[Not] since yesterday, etc.** This teaches us that for an entire seven days God had been trying to persuade Moshe, at the thorn-bush, to go on his mission: ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִתְּמוֹל, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁלְשֹׁם, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵאָז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּבֶּרְךָ"" represent three [days]: the three words “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גַּם” are extensions, making it six; and he was presently in the seventh day when he continued saying the following: “Please send the one You usually send,” until He (God) became angry and he (Moshe) accepted. All this [reluctance on the part of Moshe] was due to his not wanting to accept a greater position than his brother, Aharon, who was older than he and who was a prophet [as well], as it is said: “For I revealed Myself to your ancestor’s house when they were in Egypt, referring to Aharon.” Similarly: “I made Myself known to them in the Land of Egypt and I said to them, ‘Let each man throw away that which is repulsive in his eyes.’” And that prophecy was said to Aharon. "

§§—2—§§ 4:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתמול <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ NEITHER FROM YESTERDAY [NOR FROM BEFORE YESTERDAY] — This teaches us that for an entire period of seven days God had been endeavouring to persuade Moses at the thornbush to go on his mission, for the terms <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתמול and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשום and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברך imply three days, and the three-fold <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם which is mentioned here point to three extensions of the period, making six in all, and therefore he had now reached the seventh day when he further said to him, (Exodus v. 13) “Send, I pray thee, by the hand of him whom Thou wilt send” — until God became angry with him (Exodus v. 14), and he accepted the mission (cf. Leviticus Rabbah 11:6, and Seder Olam ch. 5). All this reluctance was because he was unwilling to assume any dignity that would make him superior to his brother Aaron who was older than he and was also a prophet, as it is said (I Samuel 2:27) that the man of God spoke to Eli, the high-priest, in God’s name, “Surely I revealed myself unto the house of thy father when they were in Egypt” — thy father means Aaron. Similary in : (Ezekiel 20:5, 7) “And I made myself known unto them in the land of Egypt … and I said unto them, “cast ye away every man the detestable things of his eyes”, and that prophecy was spoken to Aaron (Exodus Rabbah 3:16; and cf. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברייתא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דל""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדות)."

—3— **10. Weder seit gestern …** wir lernen daraus, dass ganze sieben Tage der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, Mosche am Dornbusch zuredete, in Seinem Aufträge zu gehen; seit gestern, ehegestern, seitdem Du gesprochen, das sind drei Tage; die drei <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם sind Hinzufügungen, das sind sechs, und er hielt bereits am siebten Tag, als er noch dies zu Ihm sprach, schicke doch, wen Du schicken willst, bis Sein Zorn gegen ihn entbrannte und er den Auftrag auf sich nahm (Sed. 01. 5); und all dies, weil er keinen Vorzug vor seinem Bruder Aharon annehmen wollte, der älter als er und ein Prophet war (Tanchuma); so heißt es (fürwahr, dein Bruder Aharon, der Levi, … und ferner zum Priester Eli) (I Sam. 2, 27), bin ich nicht deinem Vaterhause, als sie in Mizraim waren, erschienen; das ist Aharon; und ebenso (Jech. 20, 5), und ich erschien ihnen im Lande Mizraim … und ich sagte zu ihnen, ein jeder von euch werfe die Greuel seiner Augen weg; jene Prophetie wurde zu Aharon gesagt. 

---

////—1—//// 4:10:2,**I am clumsy of mouth.** [Meaning:] I speak with difficulty. <font color=d50505>»</font>Balbe<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — stutterer.

§§—2—§§ 4:10:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פה SLOW OF SPEECH (lit. heavy of mouth) — I speak heavily (with difficulty); old French balbus. (English = stammerer).

—3— **Schwer an Mund,** ich spreche mit Schwierigkeit, ein Stammler in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 4:11:1,"**Who gave a mouth, etc.** [I.e.] “Who taught you how to speak when you were put on trial before Pharaoh on account of the Egyptian [whom you killed]?” "

§§—2—§§ 4:11:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ WHO HATH MADE MAN’S MOUTH etc.? — Who taught you to speak when you were arraigned in judgment before Pharaoh on account of the Egyptian whom you slew?

—3— **11. Wer hat einen Mund verliehen,** wer hat dich gelehrt, zu sprechen, als du vor Pharao wegen des Ägypters gerichtet wurdest. 

---

////—1—//// 4:11:2,"**Or who makes a person dumb.** [I.e.] “Who made Pharaoh to be dumb so that he exerted no effort [to fulfil his] command to have you killed, [and who made] his servants deaf so that they would not hear his decree about you. And as for the killer excutioners — who made them blind so that they would not see when you ran away from the [execution] platform and escaped. "

§§—2—§§ 4:11:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>או <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלם OR WHO MAKETH THE DUMB — Who made Pharaoh dumb so that he could not insist upon the carrying out of his command to kill you? Who made his ministers deaf so that they could not hear when he gave orders concerning you? And the executioners whose task it was to slay — who made them blind so that they could not see when you fled from the platform (raised place of execution) and escaped? (Midrash Tanchuma, Shemot 10)"

—3— **Oder wer macht stumm,** wer hat Pharao stumm gemacht, dass er beim Befehle deiner Tötung sich nicht stark machte, und seine Diener taub, dass sie seinen Befehl gegen dich nicht hörten, und die Scharfrichter, die da töten sollten, wer machte sie blind, dass sie nicht sahen, als du vom Gerüst entflohst und dich rettetest (Tanchuma V. 2,15). 

---

////—1—//// 4:11:3,**Is it not I — [Adonoy]?** [I.e.] “Is it not I <font color=d50505>»</font>whose Name<font color=d50505>«</font> is Adonoy who did all this?”

§§—2—§§ 4:11:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' DID NOT I whose name is THE LORD do all this?

—3— **Fürwahr, ich,** dessen Name Ewiger ist, habe all dies getan. 

---

////—1—//// 4:13:1,"**The one You usually send** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּיַד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּשְׁלָח means:] “Through the one You usually send,” namely, Aharon. An alternate explanation: “Through someone else whom you will wish to send, for I am not destined to bring them into the land, nor to be their redeemer in the future — you have many messengers.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשלח signifies by the hand of him whom Thou art accustomed to send; viz., Aaron (Exodus Rabbah 3:16). Another explanation is: by the hand of some other person whom Thou wilt be pleased to send — for in the end “I” shall not bring them into the land of Palestine nor shall “I” become their deliverer in the future — and You have many messengers! (Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer 40)"

—3— **13. Wen du schicken willst,** durch wen Du gewohnt bist zu schicken, und das ist Aharon; andere Erklärung: durch jenen anderen, den Du schicken willst, da ich sie zuletzt doch nicht ins Land bringen und ihr einstiger Erlöser sein werde; Du hast ja viele Boten (P. d. R. El. 40). 

---

////—1—//// 4:14:1,"**[Adonoy] displayed anger.** Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcho says: Wherever anger [of God] is mentioned in the Torah, an impression (i.e., some punishment) is mentioned, but, in this case no impression is mentioned, and we do not find any punishment as a result of that anger! Rabbi Yosi responded to him: In this case, too, an impression is mentioned: ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲלֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַהֲרֹן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָחִיךָ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַלֵּוִי"" “For he was destined to be a Levite and not a <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein<font color=d50505>«</font> (priest) and I had planned that the priesthood would descend from you. But now this will not be so, but, rather, he will be a <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein<font color=d50505>«</font> and you a Levite.” As it is said: “And the descendants of Moshe, the man of God will be attributed to the Tribe of Leivi.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף AND [THE LORD’S] WRATH GLOWED — Rabbi Joshua the son of Korcha said: wherever the term “and God’s wrath glowed” occurs in the Scriptures it leaves a definite impression (mention of punishment of some kind follows), but here no such result is mentioned, for we do not find that any punishment came upon Moses in consequence of that anger of God. Rabbi José said to him: As a matter of fact here, too, some definite result is mentioned, viz., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחיך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלוי “Is not Aaron the Levite thy brother?” — which implies, that he was destined to be a Levite (an attendant on the priests) and not a priest, — and I intended that the priesthood should proceed from you. Now, however, this shall not be so, but he will be the Priest and you the Levite, as it is said, (I Chronicles 23:14) “But as for Moses the man of God his sons are named among the tribe of Levi” (Zevachim 102a)."

—3— **14. Da entbrannte der Zorn,** R. Joschua b. Korcha sagt, jede Zornesglut, die in der Torah erwähnt wird, hinterließ eine Spur, nur hierbei steht keine Spur, und wir finden nicht, dass durch jene Zornesglut eine Strafe kam; da sagte zu ihm R. Jose, auch bei dieser steht eine Spur, fürwahr, dein Bruder Aharon, der Levi, dem bestimmt war, Levi zu sein und nicht Kohen, und die Priesterwürde hatte ich bestimmt, von dir hervorgehen zu lassen; jetzt aber wird es nicht so sein, sondern er wird der Kohen sein und du der Levi, so heißt es (I Chron. 23, 14). Mosche, der Mann Gottes, seine Söhne werden nach dem Stamme Levi genannt (Sebach. 102a). 

---

////—1—//// 4:14:2,**Behold he is setting out to meet you —** when you set out to go to Egypt.

§§—2—§§ 4:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקראתך HE WILL BE GOING FORTH TOWARDS THEE, when you will be going to Egypt."

—3— **Siehe, er kommt dir entgegen,** wenn du nach Ägypten gehst. 

---

////—1—//// 4:14:3,"**And when he sees you he will rejoice in his heart.** “It is not as you think that he will resent you for your having reached a high position.” As a result of this, Aharon merited the adornment of the <font color=d50505>»</font>choshen<font color=d50505>«</font> which is placed over the heart. "

§§—2—§§ 4:14:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושמח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלבו AND WHEN HE SEETH THEE, HE WILL BE GLAD IN HIS HEART — not as you believe, that he will be angry with you because you have attained a high position. In consequence of this, Aaron was privileged to wear the ornament of the breastplate which was placed over his heart (cf. Exodus 28:29) (Shabbat 139a;  Exodus Rabbah 3:17)."

—3— **Und wenn er dich sieht, freut er sich in seinem Herzen,** nicht, wie du meinst, dass er dir zürne, dass du zu dieser Würde emporgestiegen; danach erwarb Aharon den Schmuck des BrustSchildes der auf dem Herzen getragen wurde (Schabbat 139a). 

---

////—1—//// 4:16:1,"**He will speak to the people for you.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְךָ here means:] “For you will he speak to the people.” This is an indication that wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְךָ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָכֶם, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָהֶם are preceded by the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִבּוּר (speaking), they all have the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל (<font color=d50505>»</font>for<font color=d50505>«</font>). "

§§—2—§§ 4:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך means HE WILL SPEAK to the people ON THY ACCOUNT (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְךָ). This passage is proof, regarding every usage of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם that follow after the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר, that they all have the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על “on account of”."

—3— **16. Und er spreche für dich,** an deiner Stelle wird er zum Volk sprechen; diese Stelle beweist für jedes <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם, die mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבור verbunden sind, dass sie alle über, für … bedeuten. 

---

////—1—//// 4:16:2,"**Will be your spokesman (<font color=d50505>»</font>lit. mouth<font color=d50505>«</font>).** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְפֶה here, means:] “as a spokesman, since you have a speech impediment.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:16:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפה HE SHALL BE TO THEE INSTEAD OF A MOUTH — he will be to thee as a spokesman because thou art slow of speech (Exodus Rabbah 3:17).

—3— **Sei dir zum Munde,** zum Dolmetscher, weil du schwer an Mund bist. 

---

////—1—//// 4:16:3,"**[His] master** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֵאלֹהִים, here, means:] a master and a superior. "

§§—2—§§ 4:16:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאלהים means a superior and chief (cf. Onkelos).

—3— **Zum Herrn,** zum Lehrer und Fürsten. 

---

////—1—//// 4:18:1,"**And returned to Yeser, his father-in-law —** in order to obtain permission, for he had sworn to him. [His father, in-law] had seven names: Reuel, Yeser, Yisro, Keini, Chovev, Chever, and Putiel. "

§§—2—§§ 4:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חתנו AND HE RETURNED TO JETHRO HIS FATHER-IN-LAW, to obtain his permission to go to Egypt, for he had sworn to him that he would not leave Midian except by his permission (Nedarim 65a). He is here called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתר and he had seven names: Reuel, Jether, Jethro, Keni, Hobab, Cheber and Putiel (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 18:2) "

—3— **18. Und kehrte zu seinem Schwiegervater Jeter zurück,** um sich von ihm Erlaubnis geben zu lassen (Nedarim 65a), da er ihm geschworen hatte, (nur mit seiner Erlaubnis aus Midjan wegzugehen); er hatte sieben Namen, Reuel, Jeter, Jitro, Keni … (Mechilta Jitro). 

---

////—1—//// 4:19:1,"**For they have died — all the men.** Who were they (these men)? Dasan and Aviram. [Actually,] they were still alive, but had become paupers and a poor person is considered as if dead. "

§§—2—§§ 4:19:1," FOR ALL THE MEN ARE DEAD — Who were these men? Dathan and Abiram: Really they were still alive, but they had come down in the world, having lost their property, and a poverty-stricken man may well be regarded as dead (Nedarim 64b). "

—3— **19. Denn gestorben sind all die Männer,** wer waren diese? Datan und Abiram; sie lebten zwar noch, aber sie hatten ihr Vermögen verloren, und der Arme wird wie ein Toter angesehen (Nedar. 64b). 

---

////—1—//// 4:20:1,"**The donkey.** [Meaning:] <font color=d50505>»</font>the<font color=d50505>«</font> donkey designated for this. This is the same donkey that Avraham saddled at the binding of Yitzchok, and the same one upon which the King Moshiach is destined to reveal himself, as it is said: [“The king will come to you] humble and riding on a donkey.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>החמור UPON “THE” ASS — the ass designated for this purpose: this was the ass which Abraham had saddled for the purpose of travelling to bind Isaac on Mount Moriah, and this, too, is the ass upon which King Messiah will once show himself in public, as it is said, (Zechariah 9:9) “[Behold, thy king cometh unto thee, …] lowly and riding upon an ass” (Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer 31)."

—3— **20. Auf dem Esel,** dem bestimmten Esel; das ist der Esel, den Abraham zur Opferung Isaaks gesattelt hatte und auf dem einst der gesalbte König erscheinen wird, wie es heißt (Sech. 9, 9), ein Demütiger, der auf einem Esel reitet (P. d. R. Elies. 31). 

---

////—1—//// 4:20:2,**And he returned to the land of Egypt. Moshe took the rod** “Earlier” or “later” are not exact in Scripture.

§§—2—§§ 4:20:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארצה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מטה AND HE RETURNED TO THE LAND OF EGYPT: AND MOSES TOOK THE STAFF [OF GOD] — “Earlier and later” are not strictly observed in the Scriptures (i. e. incidents are not necessarily related in the exact order in which they occur. Here it should state: He took the staff etc. and returned to Egypt; cf. v. 17).

—3— **Und kehrte ins Land Ägypten zurück; und Mosche nahm den Stab,** die zeitliche Reihenfolge ist im Verse nicht eingehalten. 

---

////—1—//// 4:21:1,"**On your way back to Egypt.** “Know, that your going is on the condition that you are strong in [carrying out] My mission, by doing all My wonders before Pharaoh without fear of him.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלכתך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשוב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרימה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ WHEN THOU GOEST TO RETURN TO EGYPT, [SEE THAT THOU DO etc.] — Understand that you should go thither with this purpose in mind: that you should be vigorous in carrying out my mission — to do all my wonders before Pharaoh and that you should not be afraid of him."

—3— **21. Wenn du gehst, um nach Ägypten zurückzukehren** … wisse, dass du zu diesem Zwecke gehst, stark zu sein in meinem Auftrage, alle meine Wunderzeichen vor Pharao zu vollbringen und dich nicht vor ihm zu fürchten. 

---

////—1—//// 4:21:2,"**That I have placed in your hand.** This does not refer to the three signs mentioned above, for, those, He did not command him to do before Pharaoh, but rather, before the Israelites so that they may believe him; and we do not find that he did them before him. But [this refers to] “the wonders (i.e., the plagues) which I shall, in the future, place in your hand in Egypt.” As it is said: “When Pharaoh speaks to you, etc.” Do not wonder as to why it is written: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׂמְתִּי — <font color=d50505>»</font>that I have placed<font color=d50505>«</font> (past tense) because it should be understood thus: “When you speak with him, I will have already placed them in your hand.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:21:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בידך [THE WONDERS] WHICH I HAVE PUT IN THY HAND — Not in reference to the three signs mentioned above was God speaking, for he had not commanded him to do these before Pharaoh, but before Israel in order that they might believe in him, nor do we find that he did them before him. But God meant: those wonders which I shall in future place in thy hand in Egypt — such as (Exodus 7:9) “When Pharaoh shall speak unto you, [saying, show a wonder (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מופת) for yourselves]”. Do not be puzzled because it is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמתי (a past tense), for the following is what it means: when you will be speaking with him I shall already have put them into thy hand."

—3— **Die ich in deine Hände lege,** nicht die drei Zeichen, die oben stehen; denn diese befahl Er ihm nicht vor Pharao zu vollbringen, sondern vor Israel, dass sie ihm vertrauten; wir finden auch nicht, dass er sie vor Pharao vollbrachte; sondern die Wunderzeichen, die ich in Ägypten in deine Hand legen werde, wie (7, 9), wenn Pharao zu euch sprechen wird … und wundere dich nicht, dass steht, die ich gelegt **habe;** denn der Sinn ist, wenn du mit ihm sprechen wirst, so werde ich sie bereits in deine Hand gelegt haben. 

---

////—1—//// 4:22:1,"**You will say to Pharaoh.** “When you hear that his heart is hardened and he refuses to send [the people away], tell him thus: "

§§—2—§§ 4:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואמרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND THOU SHALT SAY UNTO PHARAOH — When you perceive that his heart is stubborn and that he refuses to let them go speak to him thus:

—3— **22. Und sage zu Pharao,** wenn du hörst, dass sein Herz fest bleibt und er sich weigert, zu entlassen, so sage so zu ihm. 

---

////—1—//// 4:22:2,"**[Yisrael] is my son, my firstborn.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּכוֹרִי, here means:] of greatness as in: “I will also make him great.” This is its plain meaning. But, the midrashic explanation is: Here, God put His seal on the sale of the birthright which Yaakov had bought from Eisov. "

§§—2—§§ 4:22:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכרי [ISRAEL IS] MY SON, MY FIRSTBORN — The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור “firstborn” denotes high dignity as, (Psalms 89:28) “I also will appoint him a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור” (which is explained by the following words, “the highest of the kings of the earth”). This is the literal meaning; a Midrashic comment is: Here (in these words) the Holy One, blessed be He, set His seal to the sale of the birthright which Jacob had purchased from Esau (Genesis Rabbah 63:14)."

—3— **Mein erstgeborener Sohn,** ist ein Ausdruck für Würde, wie (Ps. 89,28), auch setze ich ihn zum Erstgeborenen ein; dies ist der einfache Sinn; der Midrasch sagt, hier besiegelte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, den Verkauf der Erstgeburt, die Jaakob von Esaw erworben (Bereschit Rabbah 63). 

---

////—1—//// 4:23:1,"**“And I have said to you —** as a messenger of God, ‘Send My son out, etc.’” "

§§—2—§§ 4:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליך AND I HAVE SAID UNTO THEE, as a messenger of the Omnipresent God,  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני LET MY SON GO,"

—3— **23. Und ich spreche zu dir,** im Auftrag des Ewigen. 

---

////—1—//// 4:23:2,"**Behold, I will slay, etc.** This will be the last plague [Yet, God] warns him with this first — because it is the most severe. This is what is meant regarding Iyov: “For God is powerful in His might,” therefore, “Who is a teacher like Him,” [the explanation being:] A human being, who seeks to take revenge from his fellow-man, is secretive about it so that the other will not seek to escape. But, God “is powerful in His might” and there is no possible escape from His Hand, unless he returns to Him (repents). Therefore He teaches him and warns him to repent. "

§§—2—§§ 4:23:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ BEHOLD I WILL SLAY etc. — This, it is true, was the last of the plagues, but it was by mention of it that God gave him the first warning regarding the plagues that would come upon him, because this was the severest of them all. This is what Scripture means by, (Job 36:22) “Behold God is mighty in His power”, therefore “Who is a teacher like unto Him?” — This signifies: A human being who intends to avenge himself upon his fellow keeps his plans secret in order that he may not seek means of escape. But the Holy One, blessed be He, is so mighty in His power that there is no possibility of escape from His hand except by returning to Him in penitence. Just on this account He teaches him (informs him what punishment will befall him) and so warns him to return to Him (Exodus Rabbah 9:9)."

—3— **Entlasse meinen Sohn … siehe, so töte ich …** Das ist die letzte Plage, und mit ihr warnte Er ihn zuerst, weil sie die schwerste war. Das ist, was er in Job (36, 22) sagt, siehe, Gott ist groß in Seiner Macht; darum, wer vermag gleich Ihm zu unterweisen; wenn ein Mensch an seinem Nächsten Vergeltung üben will, verbirgt er seine Absicht, damit jener nicht Rettung suche; aber der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, ist groß in Seiner Macht, und es ist nicht möglich, Seiner Hand zu entrinnen, nur wer zu Ihm zurückkehrt; darum unterweist Er ihn und warnt ihn, damit er zurückkehre. 

---

////—1—//// 4:24:1,"**When he was along the way, in the inn.** Moshe. "

§§—2—§§ 4:24:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי AND HE WAS — Moses was — DURING THE JOURNEY IN THE LODGING PLACE.

—3— **24. Als er auf dem Wege in der Herberge war,** Mosche. 

---

////—1—//// 4:24:2,"**And wanted to kill him.** I.e., the angel [wanted to kill] Moshe because he did not circumcise his son, Eliezer, and because he was negligent he deserved the punishment of death. The Beraisa taught: [however,] Rabbi Yosi said: God forbid! [Actually,] he was not negligent, but, he thought: “If I circumcise him and set out on a journey, the child’s life will be in danger for three days. [However,] I might circumcise him and wait three days, [but,] God has commanded me, “Go! Return to Egypt.” Then, why was he punished? Because his first concern was his lodging. Maseches Nedarim: The angel turned into a kind of snake and swallowed him (Moshe) from his head to his thigh [and spit him out] and then again swallowed him from his feet to that place (the membrum). Zipporah understood that this was on account of [delaying] the circumcision. "

§§—2—§§ 4:24:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבקש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המיתו AND HE SOUGHT TO PUT HIM TO DEATH — the angel sought etc., because he had not circumcised his son Eliezer; and because he had showed himself remiss in this, he brought upon himself the punishment of death. It has been taught in a Boraitha (Nedarim 31b): Rabbi José said: God forbid that this was so; Moses had not been remiss in this duty; but he thought, “If I circumcise him and immediately proceed on the journey, the child’s life will be in danger for three days. If, on the other hand, I circumcise him and wait three days — the Holy One, blessed be He, has commanded me, “Go return to Egypt!” Consequently, he obeyed His command, intending to circumcise the child as soon as the opportunity presented itself. There was therefore no remissness on his part; why, then, was he threatened with punishment? Because he busied himself with the affairs of the lodging place first, (i. e. because when he arrived at the inn he troubled himself first about eating and drinking. He should first have circumcised his son. Being now so much nearer Egypt, the danger that follows upon the circumcision was not so great, since the interval of time between the operation and his arrival in Egypt was now shorter than if he had circumcised him before he set out on the journey). See this in Treatise Nedarim. — The angel became a kind of serpent and swallowed him (Moses) from his head to his thigh, spued him forth, and then again swallowed him from his legs to that place (the membrum). Zipporah thus understood that this had happened on account of the delay in the circumcision of her son (Nedarim 32a; cf. Exodus Rabbah 5:8)."

—3— **Und wollte ihn töten,** wen, Mosche, weil er seinen Sohn Elieser nicht beschnitten hatte; weil er damit zögerte, wurde der Tod über ihn verhängt. In einer Baraitha steht, R. Jose sagt, der Ewige behüte, Mosche zögerte nicht, sondern er sagte, beschneide ich das Kind und trete die Reise an, so ist es bis zu drei Tagen eine Gefahr für das Kind; beschneide ich und warte drei Tage, der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, hat mir aber befohlen, gehe, kehre nach Ägypten zurück; warum wurde aber der Tod über ihn verhängt? Weil er sich zuerst mit der Herberge beschäftigte. Im Traktat Nedarim (32a) steht, der Engel machte sich einer Schlange gleich und verschlang ihn von seinem Haupte bis zu seinen Hüften, dann wieder verschlang er ihn von seinen Füßen bis zu jener Stelle, daraus entnahm Zipora, dass es um der Beschneidung willen war.

////—1—//// 4:25:1,"**And threw it at his feet.** I.e., She threw it at <font color=d50505>»</font>Moshe’s<font color=d50505>«</font> feet "

§§—2—§§ 4:25:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותגע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לרגליו AND CAST IT AT HIS FEET — i. e. she cast it before Moses’ feet (Talmud Yerushalmi Nedarim 3:9).

—3— **25. Und legte sie ihm zu Füßen,** warf sie vor die Füße Mosches.

////—1—//// 4:25:2,"**saying,** regarding her son — "

§§—2—§§ 4:25:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותאמר AND SHE SAID, referring to her son:"

////—1—//// 4:25:3,"**“You are a bridegroom of blood to me.”** I.e., “You were to have caused my bridegroom to be slain on account of you; you would thus have been my husband’s killer.” "

§§—2—§§ 4:25:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דמים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי which means, thou hast brought it about that my bridegroom (Moses) was on the point of being killed because of thee: thou hast been to me my husband’s murderer."

—3— **Denn du hast meinem Anverwandten den Tod verursacht,** du hast verursacht, dass mein Anverwandter um deinetwillen getötet wird, du tötest mir meinen Mann.

§§—2—§§ 7:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונהפכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדם AND THEY SHALL BE TURNED INTO BLOOD — Because rain does not fall in Egypt but the Nile rises and irrigates the land and the Egyptians on this account worshipped the Nile, therefore God first smote their deity and afterwards smote them (Exodus Rabbah 9:9)."

—3— **17. Und es verwandelt sich in Blut,** weil in Ägypten kein Regen fällt und der Nil steigt und das Land bewässert und die Ägypter den Nil anbeten, darum schlug Er ihren Abgott, und dann schlug Er sie selbst.

////—1—//// 7:18:1,**The Egyptians will weary themselves —** [attempting] to find a cure so that the waters of their river should be fit to drink.

§§—2—§§ 7:18:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונלאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים THE EGYPTIANS SHALL WEARY THEMSELVES in seeking a cure for the waters of the river that they may become fitted for drinking.

—3— **18. Und die Ägypter werden müde werden,** für das Wasser des Flusses ein Heilmittel zu suchen, damit es trinkbar werde.

////—1—//// 7:19:1,"**Say to Aharon.** Since the river protected Moshe when he was thrown into it, therefore it was not struck by him, neither at the plague of blood nor at the plague of frogs, but was struck by Aharon. "

§§—2—§§ 7:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן SAY UNTO AARON — Because the river had protected Moses when he was cast into it, therefore it was not smitten by him neither at the plague of blood nor at that of frogs, but it was smitten by Aaron (Exodus Rabbah 9:10)."

—3— **19. Sprich zu Aharon,** weil der Fluss Mosche geschützt hatte, als er in denselben geworfen worden war, darum wurde er nicht von ihm geschlagen, weder beim Blut noch bei den Fröschen, und wurde von Aharon geschlagen (Tanchuma).

////—1—//// 7:19:2,"**The rivers.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְהָרוֹת] are the flowing rivers, just like our rivers. "

§§—2—§§ 7:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נהרתם THEIR STREAMS — These are the flowing rivers, just like our rivers in France."

—3— **Ihre Flüsse,** das sind fließende Gewässer wie unsere Flüsse.

////—1—//// 7:19:3,**Their canals.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְאוֹרִים] are man-made irrigation canals that extend from the river’s edge to the fields. The waters of the Nile rise [periodically] and travel by way of the canals to irrigate the fields.

§§—2—§§ 7:19:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאריהם — These are canals which convey water being made by human agency and extending from the river bank into the fields. The waters of the Nile increase in volume and rise by way of these canals and so irrigate the fields.

—3— **Ihre Kanäle,** das sind fließende Kanäle, Kanäle, die von Menschenhand hergestellt sind vom Ufer des Flusses in die Felder; das Wasser des Nils wird gesegnet und steigt in die Kanäle und tränkt die Felder. 

---

////—1—//// 7:19:4,"**Their lakes.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲגַם is] a gathering of waters that do not spring up or flow but are stationary in one place, and called [in Old French] <font color=d50505>»</font>estanc.<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 7:19:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אגמיהם — A collection of waters that neither spring up from beneath the ground nor flow along, but which remain in one spot. In old French they call it étang."

—3— **Ihre Teiche,** WasserSammlungen, in denen keine Quelle vorhanden und die nicht fließen, sondern an demselben Orte stehenbleiben; man nennt sie Teiche in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 7:19:5,**Throughout all the land of Egypt.** Also in their bathhouses and the baths in their homes.

§§—2—§§ 7:19:5, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים [THERE WILL BE BLOOD] THROUGHOUT ALL THE LAND OF EGYPT— also in their bathing establishments and in the baths in their houses.

—3— **Im ganzen Lande Mizraim,** auch in den Bädern und Wannen in den Häusern. 

---

////—1—//// 7:19:6,**In the wood and stones.** [Meaning] the water in the wooden vessels and the stone vessels.

§§—2—§§ 7:19:6, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובעצים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובאבנים — the water which happened to be BOTH IN vessels of WOOD AND in vessels of STONE.

—3— **In Holz und in Stein,** das Wasser in Holz- und Steingefässen.

////—1—//// 7:22:1,"**With their magic art.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּלָטֵיהֶם refers to a] magical incantation which is said (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּלָט) secretly and in a (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַחַשׁ) whisper. Our Sages say: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּלָטֵיהֶם refers to works of demons, whereas <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּלַהֲטֵיהֶם (v. 11) refers to witchcraft. "

§§—2—§§ 7:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלטיהם SECRET ARTS — magic formulas which they utter secretly and in a whisper. Our Rabbis stated that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלטיהם refers to the work of demons, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלהטיהם to witchcraft (Sanhedrin 67b; Exodus Rabbah 9:11)."

—3— **22. Mit ihren Geheimkünsten,** Zauberformeln, die sie geheim und versteckt hersagten; unsere Lehrer sagen, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לטים ist Dämonenwerk, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להטים Zauberei (Sanhedrin 67b). 

---

////—1—//// 7:22:2,"**Pharaoh’s heart remained hardened — ** by claiming, “You are doing this through witchcraft, you are importing straw to Efarayim — a city that is full of straw, you, too, are bringing witchcraft to Egypt which is full of witchcraft.” "

§§—2—§§ 7:22:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחזק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND PHARAOH’S HEART WAS HARDENED so that he said: You are doing this by witchcraft: “You are bringing straw to Afarayim”— a city that is full of straw; thus you bring sorcery to Egypt, a land that is full of sorcery (Menachot 85a; Exodus Rabbah 9:6-7)."

—3— **Da blieb das Herz von Pharao fest,** indem er sagte, mittels Zauberei macht ihr das; ihr bringt Stroh nach Afraim, einer Stadt, die voll Stroh ist (Schemot Rabbah 9); auch ihr bringt Zauberei nach Ägypten, das voll Zauberei ist.

////—1—//// 7:23:1,"**Even to this.** [I.e., neither] to the wonder of the rod that turned into a serpent, neither to this [wonder] of the blood. "

§§—2—§§ 7:23:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לזאת [NEITHER DID HE SET HIS HEART] TO THIS ALSO — to the wonder of the staff which was changed into a serpent and also not to that of the blood.

////—1—//// 7:25:1,"**[Seven] full [days passed].** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִמָּלֵא refers to] <font color=d50505>»</font>the number<font color=d50505>«</font> of seven days that the river did not revert to its original condition. For each plague functioned for a quarter of a month, and for three quarters [of a month] he would caution and warn them. "

§§—2—§§ 7:25:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימלא AND THERE WAS COMPLETED (the verb is singular) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים the number of SEVEN DAYS during which the river did not return to its original condition. For each plague functioned a quarter of a month and for three quarters He warned and cautioned them (Midrash Tanchuma, Vaera 13; Exodus Rabbah 9:12)."

—3— **25. Es wurde voll,** die Zahl der sieben Tage, bevor der Fluss zu seinem früheren Zustande zurückkehrte; denn die Plage hielt einen Viertelmonat an, und dreiviertel verwarnte und ermahnte er sie (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 7:27:1,"**If you refuse.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאִם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָאֵן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַתָּה means:] If you are a refuser <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָאֵן meaning the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְמָאֵן “one who refuses”) or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְסָרֵב — “one who refuses.” [The difference being] only that it is describing a person based on an ongoing action, similar to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁלֵו — “a person at ease,” [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁקֵט — “a person serene” [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סַר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזָעֵף — “a person with anger.” "

§§—2—§§ 7:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה — AND IF THOU BE A REFUSER. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאן — The word has the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממאן, refusing, (the Piel participle) only the difference is that it is a description of a person having reference to the action he always does (i. e. it is an adjective and the full phrase would be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאן) similar to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁלֵו “a man at ease” (Job 16:12); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁקֵט “a man at ease” (Jeremiah 48:11); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזָעֵף [‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סר] “a man displeased” (1 Kings 20:43), whilst <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְמאֵן merely describes the person as refusing at some particular moment."

—3— **27. Wenn du dich weigerst,** wenn du widerspenstig bist, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממאן = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאן, widerspenstig; nur ist es (kein Partizip), sondern eine Bezeichnung für den Menschen nach seiner Tätigkeit, wie (Job 16,12) sorglos; (Jer. 48,11) ruhig; (I Kön. 20,43) missmutig und verstört. 

---

////—1—//// 7:27:2,"**I will plague all of your borders.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹגֵף means] striking a blow. Similarly, every form of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַגֵּפָה does not [necessarily] refer to killing, but, rather, refers to striking. Similarly, “They will strike (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָגְפוּ) a pregnant woman” does not refer to killing. Similarly, “Before your feet (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִתְנַגְּפוּ) strike against something,” [or] “Lest your feet (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּגּוֹף) strike a stone,” [or] “And as a stumbling stone.” "

§§—2—§§ 7:27:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גבולך I WILL PLAGUE ALL THY BOUNDARIES — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוגף means smiting. So, too, wherever a form from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגף occurs, it does not necessarily denote killing but it may mean merely smiting. Similarly, (Exodus 21:22) “and if they hurt (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונגפו) a woman with child”, does not mean they kill (as the context shows); so, too, (Jeremiah 13:16) “and before your feet stumble (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתנגפו)” (i. e. hit against something); (Psalms 91:12) “lest thou dash (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תגף) thy foot against a stone”; (Isaiah 8:14) ”and for a stone of stumbling (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגף)‎”."

—3— **Siehe, so schlage ich dein ganzes Gebiet,** ich schlage, ebenso bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מגפה überall nicht Tod, sondern Schlag; ebenso (21, 22), sie stoßen eine Frau, die Mutter wird, nicht töten; ebenso (Jer. 13, 16), bevor euere Füße anstoßen; (Ps. 91, 12) dass nicht am Stein dein Fuß strauchle; (Jes. 8,14) zum Stein des Anstoßes. 

---

////—1—//// 7:28:1,**They will emerge** — from the river.

§§—2—§§ 7:28:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועלו  AND THEY SHALL GO UP from the river

—3— **28. Sie steigen herauf,** aus dem Flusse. 

---

////—1—//// 7:28:2,"**Into your house** — and afterwards in your servants’ houses. [Since] he initiated the plan at the beginning: “He said to his nation” (1, 9), therefore the punishment began with him. "

§§—2—§§ 7:28:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בביתך — first into thine house and afterwards,    <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבדיך — into the house of thy servants; he took the first step in counselling evil against Israel, as it is stated (1:9) “He spake to his people, “[Behold, the children of Israel are more numerous and powerful than we]”, and with him, therefore, did punishment begin (cf. Sotah 11a and Exodus Rabbah 10:3)."

—3— **In dein Haus,** und dann in das Haus deiner Knechte; er hatte zuerst den Rat gegeben (1, 9), er sprach zu seinem Volke, und bei ihm fing auch die Strafe an (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 7:29:1,**Upon you and upon your people.** They would enter their intestines and croak.

§§—2—§§ 7:29:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובכה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובעמך AND UPON (or in) THEE AND THY PEOPLE [SHALL THE FROGS COME] — they made their way right into their bodies and crowed (Exodus Rabbah 10:3).

—3— **29. Zu dir und zu deinem Volke,** sie drangen in ihre Eingeweide ein und quakten. 

---

////—1—//// 8:2:1,"**And the frog emerged.** There was [only] one frog and [when] they struck at it it would split apart into various teeming swarms. That is its midrashic explanation. But as to its plain meaning, it may be said [that] the swarming of the frogs is referred to in the singular. Similarly <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּהִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכִּנָּם — [lit.] “There was lice” [referring to] the swarming. <font color=d50505>»</font>Pedoliere,<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — swarming lice, so, too <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתַּעַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַצְּפַרְדֵּעַ [is translated as] <font color=d50505>»</font>grenoilliere<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — a swarm of frogs. "

§§—2—§§ 8:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצפרדע AND THE FROGS (lit. frog) CAME UP — Really there was only one frog, but when they struck at it, it was split into many swarms. This is a Midrashic explanation of the usage of the singular noun here (cf. Sanhedrin 67b; Exodus Rabbah 10:4). But as a literal explanation one must say that the swarm of the frogs is denoted by the singular form. Similar is, (v. 14) “and there was the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנם” — the swarm of insects, in old French pedulier; i. e. a swarm of lice. So, too, here, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצפרדע means: and there came up a grenouillière (old French) i. e. a swarm of frogs."

—3— **8, 2. Da kamen die Frösche herauf,** es war ein Frosch, den schlugen sie und er zerteilte sich in viele Schwärme, das ist der Midrasch (Schemot Rabbah); nach dem einfachen Sinn kann man sagen, das Gewimmel von Fröschen nennt er einen Frosch; ebenso (V. 14), es war das Ungeziefer, das Gewimmel, Ungeziefer in anderen Sprachen; und auch der Frosch kam herauf = Gefrösche in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 8:5:1,"**Glorify yourself at my expense.** As in: (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲיִתְפָּאֵר) “Should the axe boast to the one who chops with it?” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲיִתְפָּאֵר meaning:] boasting by saying, “I am greater than you.” <font color=d50505>»</font>Wanter<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — to boast. This, too, is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְפָּאֵר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלַי: “You boast of your cleverness by asking [me to perform] something difficult and then saying that I will be unable to do it.” "

§§—2—§§ 8:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התפאר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלי GLORY OVER ME — Similar is, (Isaiah 10:15) “Should the axe <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתפאר against him that heweth therewith” i. e. should it boast, saying “I am greater than thou”; old French vanter. Therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התפאר means pride yourself on showing your cleverness and on asking of me a difficult matter asserting that I shall be unable to do it."

—3— **5. Rühme dich über mich,** wie (Jes. 10, 15), kann sich die Axt rühmen über den, der mit ihr Holz fällt, dass sie sich rühmt und sagt, ich bin größer als du; sich rühmen in anderen Sprachen, ebenso hier, rühme dich über mich, rühme dich so weise zu sein und eine so große Sache zu verlangen, von der du meinst, ich könne sie nicht ausführen. 

---

////—1—//// 8:5:2,"**[Exactly for] when shall I pray for you.** I will pray for you today for the destruction of the frogs — by when do you wish them destroyed so that you may see whether I will fulfill my promise at the appointed time you will set for me.” Had it said: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָתַי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַעְתִּיר [without the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל' prefix], it would have meant: “When shall I pray?” But, now that it says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמָתַי [with the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל' prefix], it means: “I shall pray for you today that the frogs be destroyed by whatever time you may set for me. Just say by which day you want them destroyed.” The words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַעְתִּיר (this verse), <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַעְתִּירוּ (v. 4) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעְתַּרְתִּי (v. 25) [are in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִפְעִיל form] and not: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶעְתַּר, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִתְרוּ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְעָתַרְתִּי [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל form], because wherever a form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָתֹר appears it denotes a great deal of praying. And just as it says: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְבֶּה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַרְבּוּ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִרְבֵּיתִי terms denoting <font color=d50505>»</font>to cause to do,<font color=d50505>«</font> so, too, does it say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַעְתִּיר, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַעְתִּירוּ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעְתַּרְתִּי [referring to an increase of] words. The main proof of all this is [the verse:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעְתַּרְתֶּם your words about me,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעְתַּרְתֶּם meaning] <font color=d50505>»</font>you have increased.<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 8:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתיר FOR WHAT PERIOD SHALL I ENTREAT FOR THEE — With reference to the entreaty which I shall make to-day regarding the destruction of the frogs, by what period do you wish that they should be destroyed, and you will see whether I can carry out my promise by the time which you will set me. If the text said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתיר (without <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל), it would signify “when shall I pray?” but now that it is said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למתי, it signifies I will pray to-day for you that the frogs should be destroyed by the time which you will set for me. Tell me, then, by what day you wish that they shall be destroyed. The words here, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתיר and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העתירו (v. 4) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העתרתי (v. 25) are Hiphil forms, and it does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶעְתַּר and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִתְרוּ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְעָתַרְתִּי (Kal forms) because wherever the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עתר is used it denotes to pray much (more lit. Rashi’s words signify “to multiply praying”, “to make much praying”), and just as one says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְבֶּה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַרְבּוּ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִרְבֵּתִי which all have the meaning of “causing an action to happen” (in this case, causing a thing to be much — our Hiphil conjugation), so one says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַעְתִּיר and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַעְתִּירוּ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵעְתַּרְתִּי “I increase”, “increase ye” and “I will increase” i. e. I will increase words. The passage which serves as evidence of the meaning of all these words is (Ezekiel 35:13) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵעְתַּרְתֶּם your words against Me” — which can only mean “Ye have multiplied” (being a transitive verb; cf. Rashi on Genesis 25:21)."

—3— **Für wann soll ich für dich flehen,** wenn ich heute für dich flehe um die Ausrottung der Frösche, zu wann willst du, dass sie ausgerotten werden; und du wirst sehen, ob ich mein Wort zur Zeit, die du mir bestimmst, erfülle. Wenn stehen würde,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתי wann soll ich flehen, würde es bedeuten, wann soll ich flehen; jetzt aber, da steht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למתי, bedeutet es, ich werde heute für dich beten, dass die Frösche zu der Zeit, die du mir bestimmst, ausgerottet werden mögen; sage, an welchem Tage willst du, dass sie ausgerottet werden. Ich werde flehen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתיר, flehet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העתירו, und ich werde flehen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעתרתי Hiphil; aber es steht nicht,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועתרתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עתרו,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתר, weil die Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עתר überall viel beten bedeutet; wie man <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והרביתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבה im Hiphil sagt, so sagt man auch <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעתיר,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העתירו, ich vermehre die Worte; der Beweis für alle Stellen ist der Vers (Jech. 35,13), ihr habt euere Worte gegen mich gemehrt, viel geredet.

////—1—//// 8:6:1,**He [Pharaoh] said by tomorrow.** [I.e.] “Pray today that they be destroyed by tomorrow.”

§§—2—§§ 8:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למחר AND HE SAID, FOR TO-MORROW — He said: Pray to-day that they may be destroyed by to-morrow."

—3— **6. Er sprach, zu morgen,** bete heute, dass sie morgen ausgerottet werden. 

---

////—1—//// 8:8:1,**They left — [and Moshe] cried out.** [He cried out] immediately that they be destroyed by tomorrow.

§§—2—§§ 8:8:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצא. . <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצעק THEY WENT … AND CRIED [UNTO THE LORD) immediately that they should be destroyed by to-morrow.

—3— **10. Er ging hinaus und rief,** sogleich, dass sie am nächsten Tage ausgerottet würden.

////—1—//// 8:10:1,"**Many heaps.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֳמָרִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֳמָרִים means] heaps [or mounds], as Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דְגוֹרִין which means <font color=d50505>»</font>heaps.<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 8:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמרים means IN HEAPS, just as the Targum renders it, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דגורין, which means <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גלין heaps (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דגורא is the Targum of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגל in Genesis 31:46)."

—3— **10. In Haufen,** Haufen, wie der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דגורין, Hügel. 

---

////—1—//// 8:11:1,"**He hardened his heart.** [The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכְבֵּד] is in the infinitive form the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָלוֹךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָסוֹעַ “going and travelling,” and similarly “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַכּוֹת (striking) the Moabites,” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשָׁאוֹל (and asking) Hashem for him” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכֵּה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפָצֹעַ striking and wounding.” "

§§—2—§§ 8:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והכבד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבו HE ALLOWED HIS HEART TO BE HARDENED — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכְבֵּד expresses doing something (the Hebrew infinitive but having a past meaning) just as, (Genesis 12:9) “going (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלוך) and journeying (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונסוע)”. So, too, (2 Kings 3:24) “and smiting (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והכת) Moab”; (I Samuel 22:13) “and enquiring (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושאול) of God for him”; (1 Kings 20:37); “smiting (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכה) and wounding (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופצוע)”."

—3— **11. Er verhärtete sein Herz,** ist der Infinitiv wie (Gen. 12, 9) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלוך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונסוע; ebenso (II Kön. 3, 24), und schlugen Moab; (I Sam. 22,13) und fragtest Gott für ihn; (I Kön. 20, 37) schlug und verwundete. 

---

////—1—//// 8:11:2,"**Just as Adonoy had spoken.** And where had He said this? When He said, “Pharaoh will not listen to you.” "

§§—2—§§ 8:11:2,"‎ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ AS THE LORD HAD SPOKEN — And where had He said this? When He said, (Exodus 7:4) “Pharaoh will not hearken to you”."

—3— **Wie der Ewige gesprochen,** und wo hatte Er dies gesprochen? (7,4) Pharao wird nicht auf euch hören.

////—1—//// 8:12:1,**Say to Aharon.** It was not fitting that the dust be struck by Moshe because it protected him when he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand and was [instead] struck by Aharon.

§§—2—§§ 8:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן SAY UNTO AARON — The dust did not deserve to be smitten by Moses because it had protected him when he slew the Egyptian, for “he hid him in the sand”; and it was therefore smitten by Aaron (Tanchuma; Exodus Rabbah 10:7)."

—3— **12. Sprich zu Aharon,** der Staub verdiente nicht durch Mosche geschlagen zu werden; weil er ihn geschützt hatte, als er den Mizri erschlagen hatte und ihn im Sande verbarg; darum wurde er durch Aharon geschlagen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 8:13:1,**And there was lice (lit. louse).** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכִּנָם refers to] the swarm of lice. <font color=d50505>»</font>Pedoliere<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — swarming lice.

§§—2—§§ 8:13:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנם means the swarming was. In old French pedulier.

—3— **13. Und es war das Ungeziefer,** das Kriechgetier, Ungeziefer in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 8:14:1,**To bring forth lice.** [Meaning] to create them from elsewhere.

§§—2—§§ 8:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להוציא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנים TO BRING FORTH GNATS — to create them and to bring them forth from some other place (not from dust but to turn some other material into gnats).

—3— **14. Das Ungeziefer hervorzubringen,** sie zu erschaffen und aus einem anderen Orte hervorzubringen. 

---

////—1—//// 8:14:2,**But they could not — ** because a demon has no power over a creature that is smaller than barley.

§§—2—§§ 8:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יכלו BUT THEY COULD NOT — for the demon (through whose agency this was to be done) is powerless in the case of a creature smaller than a barley corn) (Sanhedrin 67b). Therefore they had to admit,"

—3— **Aber sie konnten nicht,** weil der Dämon über ein Geschöpf, das kleiner als ein Gerstenkorn ist, keine Macht hat (Sanhedrin 67b). 

---

////—1—//// 8:15:1,"**“This is the finger of Elohim.”** [I.e.,] this plague was not brought about by witchcraft — it is from Hashem. "

§§—2—§§ 8:15:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא THIS IS THE FINGER OF GOD — This plague is not caused by sorcery: it is of the Omnipresent God!

—3— **15. Es ist ein Finger Gottes,** diese Plage ist nicht durch Zauberei, sondern vom Ewigen gekommen (dort). 

---

////—1—//// 8:15:2,**As Adonoy had spoken.** “Pharaoh will not listen to you.”

§§—2—§§ 8:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ AS THE LORD HAD SPOKEN — when He said, (Exodus 7:4) “Pharaoh will not hearken unto you”."

—3— **Wie der Ewige gesprochen,** Pharao wird nicht auf euch hören. 

---

////—1—//// 8:17:1,"**I will send against you.** [Meaning] incite against you. Similarly, it is said, (Devorim 32:24) “And the teeth of the animals will I send [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשַׁלַּח] against them,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשַׁלַּח] being a term of <font color=d50505>»</font>incitement.<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=d50505>»</font>Enticier<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — to incite. "

§§—2—§§ 8:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משליח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בך means I WILL INCITE AGAINST THEE. Another example is. (Deuteronomy 32:24) “I will incite (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשלח) the tooth of beasts against them”, where it signifies letting loose an animal against a person; old French inciter. English to incite. "

—3— **17. Ich schicke gegen dich,** treibe gegen dich an; ebenso (Deut. 32, 24) den Zahn der Tiere schicke ich gegen sie, bedeutet antreiben, in anderen Sprachen antreiben. 

---

////—1—//// 8:17:2,"**Swarms of wild animals.** All kinds of wild beasts, snakes and scorpions, en masse (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְעִרְבוּבִיָא from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָרֹב — <font color=d50505>»</font>a mixture<font color=d50505>«</font>), who caused devastation among them. There is a reason in aggadic writings for each and every plague why this particular one and why that particular one. With similar strategies of war as employed by kings did He (Hashem) come against them — as does a kingdom that besieges a city. First it ruins its springs (water supply) and afterwards they sound trumpets against them in order to frighten and terrify them: the frogs thus croaked and made loud noises, etc., as is recorded in Midrash Rabbi Tanchuma. "

§§—2—§§ 8:17:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הערב this means all kinds of wild beasts, serpents, and scorpions (a mixture [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערב] of noxious creatures) in a crowd (Exodus Rabbah 11:3) — these played havoc with them. There is a reason given in the Midrash in the case of each plague why this particular one and why that: God came against them with the tactics of warlike operations as carried out by kings in orderly sequence: a government (monarch) who is besieging a city first destroys its water supply, then they blow the trumpets and sound an alarm in order to terrify and dismay them — thus [their water supply was turned into blood], the frogs croaked and made a noise etc.  - just as you will find it stated in the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma 2:3:4."

—3— **Gewild,** alle Arten von bösem Gewild und Schlangen und Skorpionen durcheinander, die unter ihnen Verheerungen anrichteten; in der Agada wird für jede Plage eine Begründung angegeben, warum diese und warum diese. Gleich der Kriegführung von Königen kam Er gegen sie, nach der Art eines Herrschers, der eine Stadt belagert; zuerst zerstört er ihre Quellen; dann bläst und schmettert man mit Schofrot gegen sie, um ihnen Furcht einzujagen und sie zu erschrecken; ebenso machten die Frösche Lärm und quakten… wie im Midrasch von R. Tanchuma (Bo) steht. 

---

////—1—//// 8:18:1,"**I will set apart.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִפְלֵיתִי means] I will set apart. Similarly: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִפְלָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' — “Hashem will set apart.” Similarly: “It is not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִפְלֵאת from You,” [meaning] it is not set apart nor separated from You. "
<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והפליתי means I WILL SEPARATE. Similar is, (Exodus 9:4) “And the Lord will make a separation (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והפלה)”; so, also, (Deuteronomy 30:11) “It is not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפלאת from thee״ — that is, “it is not separated and set at a far distance from thee”."

—3— **18. Ich werde unterscheiden,** trennen; ebenso (Deut. 28, 59), der Ewige wird auszeichnen; ebenso (dort 30, 11), sie ist nicht zu schwer für dich, nicht getrennt und abgesondert von dir. 

---

////—1—//// 8:18:2,"**So that you will know that I am Adonoy in the midst of the earth.** Though My Divine Presence is in the heavens, My decree is fulfilled in the lower worlds. "

§§—2—§§ 8:18:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תדע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקרב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ IN ORDER THAT THOU MAYEST KNOW THAT I AM THE ETERNAL IN THE MIDST OF THE EARTH — although My Shechina is in the heavens My command is fulfilled amongst mankind (as we might say, “My writ runs on earth also”)."

—3— **Damit du erkennst, dass ich der Ewige bin inmitten der Erde;** obschon meine Schechina im Himmel ist, geht mein Gesetz doch auf Erden in Erfüllung. 

---

////—1—//// 8:19:1,**I will set a [sign of] deliverance —** which will set apart My nation from your nation.

§§—2—§§ 8:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושמתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פדות AND I WILL MAKE A DELIVERANCE which shall serve as a division BETWEEN MY PEOPLE AND THY PEOPLE.

—3— **19. Ich werde Freiheit einsetzen,** die zwischen meinem Volke und deinem Volke trenne. 

---

////—1—//// 8:20:1,**The land was devastated.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִשָּׁחֵת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָאָרֶץ means:] the land was devastated; [as Onkelos translates it] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִתְחַבָּלַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְעָא (past tense).
"

§§—2—§§ 8:20:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ means the ground was being destroyed (the imperfect tense denotes what was then going on continuously), and so the Targum has <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתחבלת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארעא (the participle) the ground was being ruined."""

—3— **20. Wurde das Land verheert,** wurde das Land verwüstet (Vergangenheit), so auch im Targum. 

---

////—1—//// 8:21:1,"**“Sacrifice to your God [here] in the land.”** [I.e.] “where you are, and do not go into the wilderness.” "

§§—2—§§ 8:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זבחו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאלהיכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארץ SACRIFICE TO YOUR GOD IN THE LAND, in the place where you are, and do not go into the wilderness."

—3— **21. Opfert eurem Gotte im Lande,** an euerem Orte, und geht nicht in die Wüste. 

---

////—1—//// 8:22:1,"**Abominable to Egypt.** [Actually] that which Egypt reveres (i.e., its idols) as in “and for Milkom the (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תוֹעֲבַת) abomination of B’nei Ammon” but only when speaking to Israel is it called abominable. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תּוֹעֲבַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִצְרַיִם can also be explained another way: It would be despicable to Egypt [to witness] the sacrifice which we are sacrificing for it is their god that we sacrifice. "

§§—2—§§ 8:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תועבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים THE ABOMINATION OF THE EGYPTIANS — This means: that which the Egyptians reverence (their idol), just as, (2 Kings 23:13) “and for Milcom the abomination (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תועבת) of the children of Ammon”, but in relation to the Israelites it (Scripture) calls it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תועבה. We may explain these words in another sense also: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תועבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים — The act of sacrifice which we practise is a hateful thing to the Egyptians seing that we sacrifice their god (sheep which were reverenced as gods in Egypt)."

—3— **22. Den Greuel der Ägypter,** den Abgott der Ägypter; wie (II Kön. 23, 13) Milkom, den Greuel der Söhne Amons; im Verhältnis zu Israel nennt er ihn einen Greuel. Man kann auch noch in anderer Weise erklären; den Greuel Ägyptens, das heißt, die Opferung, die wir vollziehen, ist für Ägypten eine verhasste Sache; denn ihren Abgott opfern wir.

////—1—//// 8:22:2,**And not have them stone us?** [Meant as] a wondrous question.

§§—2—§§ 8:22:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסקלנו — This must be read in the intonation of a question (although there is no interrogative prefix <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲ) AND WILL THEY NOT STONE US?

—3— **Werden sie uns nicht steinigen?** Es ist die Form einer Frage.

////—1—//// 8:25:1,**Deceive us.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָתֵל is] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְהָתֵל .

§§—2—§§ 8:25:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התל is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להתל (i. e. the infinitive may be used with or without <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל prefixed).

—3— **25. Zu betrügen** =. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להתל.

////—1—//// 8:26:1,"**And prayed to Adonoy.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֶּעְתַּר means] he exerted himself in prayer. Similarly, had he wished to say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּעְתִּיר he could have said so and it would mean he used many [words] of prayer. Now that he says it in terms of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּפְעַל it means he increased [the intensity] of the prayer. "

§§—2—§§ 8:26:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעתר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ AND ENTREATED THE LORD (the verb is the Kal) — he concentrated his energies on prayer. So, too, if it had wished to use the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַעְתִּיר (the Hiphil) it could have used it, and that would have signified, “and he increased words in prayer”. But when it uses an expression denoting “and he did something” (the Kal) it signifies “he prayed much (devoutly)”."

—3— **26. Und flehte zum Ewigen,** betete mit Inbrunst; wenn er dafür <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעתיר im Hiphil gesagt hätte, so hätte es dieselbe Bedeutung gehabt; der Sinn wäre dann gewesen, er mehrte das Gebet; jetzt, da er den Kal anwendet, bedeutet es auch, er mehrte zu beten.

////—1—//// 8:27:1,"**He caused the wild animals to depart.** They did not die as did the frogs, for had they died they would have benefitted from the skins. "

§§—2—§§ 8:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הערב AND HE REMOVED THE SWARM OF ANIMALS — He merely removed them and they did not die as the frogs had died; for had they died, they (the Egyptians) could have made some use of their skins (Exodus Rabbah 11:3)."

—3— **27. Und nahm das Gewild fort,** aber es starb nicht, wie die Frösche gestorben waren; denn, wenn sie gestorben wären, hätten die Ägypter Nutzen von den Fellen gehabt (Tanchuma).

////—1—//// 9:2:1,"**Holding them.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַחֲזִיק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּם means] <font color=d50505>»</font>holding them,<font color=d50505>«</font> as in “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֶחֱזִיקָה) and she took hold of his private parts.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחזיק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בם means WILT KEEP HOLD OF THEM, as in, (Deuteronomy 25:11) “and layeth hold of him etc. (...<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והחזיקה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב)”."

////—1—//// 9:3:1,"**Behold, the hand of Adonoy is directed.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹיָה] is in the present tense, for this is how [the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָיָה] is expressed in the feminine gender: in the past tense: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָיְתָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>she was,<font color=d50505>«</font> in the future tense: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּהְיֶה — <font color=d50505>»</font>she shall be,<font color=d50505>«</font> and in the present tense: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹיָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>she is;<font color=d50505>«</font> the same form as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוֹעָה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוֹצָה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוֹשָׂה . "

§§—2—§§ 9:3:1," ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹיָה BEHOLD THE HAND OF THE LORD IS — The verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הויה is in the present tense, for so one says in the feminine gender of the past <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היתה, “she was”, of the future, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהיה, “she will be” and of the present, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוֹיָה, the latter form being similar to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוֹשָׂה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוֹצָה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוֹעָה (Fem. part. sing. Kal of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה verbs)."

—3— **3. Siehe, die Hand des Ewigen senkt sich herab,** von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוה = sein; denn so lautet die weibliche Form in der Vergangenheit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היתה, in der Zukunft <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהיה und im Präsens <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הויה, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רועה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוצה,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עושה.

§§—2—§§ 9:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חפניכם HANDFULS (more lit., as much as will fill your fists), old French joincheiz; Engl, double-handfuls."

////—1—//// 9:8:2,"**Furnace soot.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּיחַ is] that which is blown from dying embers that have been burnt in a furnace, in Old French <font color=d50505>»</font>olves<font color=d50505>«</font> — furnace ashes. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּיחַ having the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַפָּחָה — <font color=d50505>»</font> blowing,<font color=d50505>«</font> for the wind blows and disperses them. "

§§—2—§§ 9:8:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פיח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכבשן SOOT OF THE FURNACE — the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פיח denotes a thing which is blown away (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפוח) from coals that have become extinguished after being burnt in a furnace; in old French oulvis. 

—3— **Ofenruss,** das, was von dunkeln, im Ofen verbrannten Kohlen wegfliegt; Russ in anderen Sprachen; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פיח kommt von blasen, der Wind bläst ihn weg und macht ihn wegfliegen.

////—1—//// 9:8:3,

§§—2—§§ 9:8:3,"  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פיח is derived from a root that signifies blowing, and it so called because the wind blows it about and scatters it abroad."

—3— **Und Mosche werfe ihn;** alles, was mit Kraft geworfen wird, kann nur mit einer Hand geworfen werden (Tanchuma); also waren dabei viele Wunder; einmal, dass die Hand von Mosche seine beiden Hände voll und die von Aharon fasste; ferner, dass sich der Staub über das ganze Land Mizraim verbreitete.

////—1—//// 9:8:4,"**And let Moshe throw it.** And since anything thrown with force is thrown only with one hand, [we may conclude that] there were a number of miracles: One, that Moshe’s one fistful held both his and Aharon’s handfuls. And another, that the soot spread over the entire land of Egypt. "

§§—2—§§ 9:8:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזרקו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND LET MOSES THREW IT — Since anything which is thrown with force must be thrown with one hand only, there were here several miracles: one, that Moses’ closed fingers (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קמץ) held as much as would fill his two fists and those of Aaron, and another, that this dust spread itself over the entire land of Egypt (Midrash Tanchuma, Vaera 14; Exodus Rabbah 11:8)."

////—1—//// 9:9:1,"**A rash which will break out into boils.** As Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְשִׁיחֲנָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סַגִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַבַעְבּוּעִין, (a rash producing boil) [meaning] that through it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁחִין) boils sprouted all over them. "

§§—2—§§ 9:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשחין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבעבעת A BOIL BREAKING FORTH INTO BLAINS — Render it as the Targum does: a boil growing blains, — the idea is, that through it (the boil) blains burst out on them (on the people).  "

—3— **9. Zu einer in Blasen ausbrechenden Entzündung,** wie der Targum sagt, Entzündung, die Blasen hervorbrachte; durch welche Blasen wuchsen.

////—1—//// 9:9:2,**A rash.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁחִין has the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>heat.<font color=d50505>«</font> There are several instances of this in the Mishnah: [e.g.] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁנָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁחוּנָה — “a hot year.”

§§—2—§§ 9:9:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחין has the meaning of “heat”. In the Mishnaic Hebrew there are many examples of its use; e. g., (Yoma 53b) “a hot (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחונה) year”. "

—3— **Entzündung,** soviel wie Hitze; der Ausdruck kommt häufig in der Sprache der Mischna vor; (Joma 53b) ein heißes Jahr.

////—1—//// 9:10:1,"**In man and beast.** Should you ask: from where did they have these animals, has it not already been stated: “and the livestock in Egypt died”? [I would answer] that the decree was only on those [that remained] in the fields exclusively, as it is said: “at your livestock that are in the field,” and whoever feared the word of Hashem made his livestock flee into the house. It is likewise taught in the Mechilta concerning: “He took 600 selected chariots.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באדם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובבהמה UPON MAN AND UPON CATTLE — If you ask, “Whence did they obtain these cattle”? Has it not already been stated, (v. 6) “And all the cattle of Egypt died”? I reply that this judgment was decreed only against the cattle that were in the fields, as it is said, (v. 3) “[The hand of the Lord is] upon thy cattle which is in the field”, and everyone who feared the Lord took his cattle in-doors. So it is taught in the Mechilta in the comment on (Exodus 14:7) “And he took six hundred chosen chariots.”"

—3— **10. An Menschen und an Vieh,** und wenn du sagen wirst, woher hatten sie Vieh; es steht doch oben, alle Herden der Ägypter starben? Aber die Strafe traf nur jene, die auf den Feldern waren; so heißt es, auf deine Herden auf dem Felde, und wer das Wort des Ewigen fürchtete, brachte seine Herden in die Häuser; so steht auch in der Mechilta bei dem Vers (14,7), er nahm 600 auserlesene Wagen.

////—1—//// 9:14:1,**All My plagues.** We learn from here that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורות is equivalent to all the plagues.

§§—2—§§ 9:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מגפתי [FOR I WILL THIS TIME SEND] ALL MY PLAGUES — We may gather from this that the plague on the first ripe ears outweighed all the previous plagues.

—3— **14. Alle meine Plagen,** von hier lernen wir, dass die Tötung der Erstgeborenen (oder die Vernichtung der Erstlingsfrüchte oder die Plage der Hungersnot) alle anderen Plagen aufwog.

////—1—//// 9:15:1,"**For now.** I [could] have extended my hand, etc. I.e., “for had I wished, [then] when My hand was [striking] at your livestock when I struck them with pestilence, I would have sent it and struck you and your people together with the animals — and you would have been obliterated from the earth. but it is for this reason that I have let you survive, etc. "

§§—2—§§ 9:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלחתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ FOR NOW I MIGHT HAVE STRETCHED OUT MY HAND etc. — For had I so desired it, when My hand was upon thy cattle which I smote with pestilence I could have stretched it forth and smitten thee and thy people together with the cattle, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותכחד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ AND THOU WOULDST HAVE BEEN EXTERMINATED FROM THE EARTH, BUT (this word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבל corresponds to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואולם in the Hebrew text) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעבור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זאת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העמדתיך FOR THIS REASON I MADE THEE REMAIN [IN LIFE IN ORDER TO SHOW THEE MY POWER], etc."

—3— **15. Denn hätte ich jetzt meine Hand ausgestreckt;** denn hätte ich damals gewollt, als meine Hand gegen deine Herden war, die ich mit der Pest schlug, so hätte ich sie ausgestreckt und
