////—1—//// 9:17:1,"**But you are still oppressing my people.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִסְתּוֹלֵל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּעַמִי is] as Onkelos translates it: “You are oppressing My people.” It (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִסְתּוֹלֵל) has the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְסִלָה, which is translated by Onkelos as: “a well-worn path.” <font color=d50505>»</font>Chalchier<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — a trodden path. I have already explained at the end of Parshas Miketz that any word whose first root letter is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סָמֶ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ךְ and intends to convey the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְפָּעֵל conjugation one places the prefix letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' in the middle of the root letters as in this case (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִסְתּוֹלֵל) and for example <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיִסְתַּבֵּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֶחָגָב — “the grasshopper will drag itself,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִסְתַּבֵּל having the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סָבֹל — carry a load, [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִשְׂתָּרֵר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֵינוּ — “that you would make yourself our ruler” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִשְׂתָּרֵר having the root of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׂר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָגִיד — “a prince and a nobleman,” [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׂתַּכַּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲוֵית — “I was reflecting.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עודך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסתולל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעמי Understand this as the Targum does: THOU TREADEST DOWN MY PEOPLE. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסתולל is of the same derivation as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְסִלַּה which we render in the Targum by “a trodden path”: old French caucher. I have already explained at the end of Sedrah <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקץ (see Rashi on Genesis 44:16) that in the case of every word (verb) whose first root letter is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ס (or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ש), when it is intended to express the idea of acting upon itself (our Hithpael conjugation) one puts the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת of the prefix (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְ or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִת or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִתְ etc.) between the root letters, just as in this case, and as in, (Ecclesiastes 12:5) ‘‘and the grasshopper shall drag itself along heavily (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסתבל)” which is derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סבל “to carry a load”; (Numbers 16:13) “that thou wouldst make thyself altogether a prince (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השתרר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשתרר) over us”, of the same derivation as the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שר in (II Chronicles 32:21) “a prince (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שר) and noble”; (Daniel 7:8) ‘‘I was considering (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסתכל)” from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סכל, “to reflect on.”"

—3— **17. Noch trittst du mein Volk nieder,** wie der Targum sagt, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבישת du drückst nieder, von der Wurzel (Num. 20, 19) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסלה gebahnte Straße, das wir im Targum mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אורח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבישא übersetzen, niedertreten in anderen Sprachen. Ich habe bereits am Ende von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקץ erklärt, jedes Wort, dessen Wurzel mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ס anfängt, stellt, wenn es in den Hithpael gesetzt wird, das <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת der Bedienung zwischen die Buchstaben der Wurzel, wie hier, und wie (Koh. 12, 5), zur Last wird die Heuschrecke (Körperteil), von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סבל; (Num. 16, 13) dass du dich zum Herrn über uns machen willst, von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונגיד Fürst und Führer; (Dan. 7, 8) ich schaute.

////—1—//// 9:18:1,"**Tomorrow at this time.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּעֵת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָחָר means] at the same time tomorrow. He scratched a mark in the wall [and said,] “Tomorrow when the sun reaches here the hail will come down. "

////—1—//// 9:18:2,"**It was founded.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִוָּסְדָה means] that it was founded. Every word whose first root-letter is a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י', e.g., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָסֹד (founded), <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָלֹד (gave birth) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָדֹעַ (knew), <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָסֹר (removed), when it is put in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְפָּעֵל form the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' replaces the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י', as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִוָּסְדָה or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִוָּלְדָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּוָּדַע — “it became known,” [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּוָּלֵד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְיוֹסֵף — “There was born to Yoseif,” [or] “With words will a servant <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִוָּסֶר — not be rebuked.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:18:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוסדה means [FROM THE DAY] WHEN IT WAS FOUNDED (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתיסדה). Every word (verb) the first root-letter of which is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י, as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסד and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילד and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידע and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסר, when it is used in the Hithpael sense (Rashi means our Niphal which often is the reflexive of the Kal), a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו replaces this <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י; e. g., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוסדה here, from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסד; (Hosea 2:5) “her being born (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִוָלְדָּהּ)”; (Esther 2:22) “and it was known (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויודע)”; (Genesis 66:20) “and there was born (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויולד) to Joseph”; (Proverbs 29:19) A servant will not be corrected (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יוסר) by words”."

—3— **Seitdem es gegründet worden,** gegründet worden, bei jedem Worte, dessen Wurzel mit Jud beginnt, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסר,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידע, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילד,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסד, tritt, wenn es in den Hithpael (Passiv) kommt, ein Waw an Stelle des Jud, wie hier gegründet ward; (Hosch. 2, 5) da sie geboren ward; (Esth. 2, 22) die Sache wurde bekannt; (Gen. 46, 20) Josef wurden geboren; (Spr. 29, 19) durch Worte wird der Sklave nicht zur Zucht angehalten.

////—1—//// 9:19:1,"**Send [word] and gather.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁלַח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעֵז is as Onkelos translates it: “send [word] and gather.” Similarly: “The inhabitants of Geibim (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֵעִיזוּ) gathered,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֵעִיזוּ) gather! children of Binyamin.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העז translate it as the Targum: SEND, GATHER. Similar examples of this sense are, (Isaiah 10:31) “The inhabitants of Gebim gather together (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיזו)”; (Jeremiah 6:1) “Gather together (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיזו), ye children of Benjamin”."

—3— **19. Schicke und flüchte,** wie der Targum sagt, schicke und sammle ein; ebenso (Jes. 10,31) die Bewohner von Gebim flüchten; (Jer. 6, 1) flüchtet, ihr Söhne Binjamins.

////—1—//// 9:19:2,**And will not be brought into the house.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵאָסֵף is a term meaning <font color=d50505>»</font>gathering in.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 9:19:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאסף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הביתה The verb denotes “bringing into a place” so that the translation is: AND WHICH IS NOT GATHERED INTO THE HOUSE.

—3— **Und nicht ins Haus gebracht werden,** bedeutet soviel wie einsammeln, hineinbringen.

////—1—//// 9:20:1,**Made flee.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֵנִיס means <font color=d50505>»</font>caused to flee<font color=d50505>«</font> from the word “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּנָס .”

§§—2—§§ 9:20:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הניס means HE MADE THEM FLEE.

—3— **20. Flüchtete,** flüchtete, von (Gen. 39, 12) er floh.

////—1—//// 9:22:1,**Toward the Heavens.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַשָּׁמַיִם means] toward the heavens. But the midrashic explanation is: Hashem lifted Moshe over the heavens.

§§—2—§§ 9:22:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השמים signifies towards the heavens (i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על is the equivalent of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל). A Midrashic comment is that the Holy One, blessed be He, raised Moses high above the heavens see Midrash Tanchuma, Vaera 15)."

—3— **22. Gen Himmel,** in der Richtung zum Himmel zu. Der agadische Midrasch sagt, der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, hob Mosche über den Himmel empor.

////—1—//// 9:24:1,"**Flashing Among the Hailstones.** [This was] a miracle within a miracle; the fire and the hail intermingled, yet the hail is water! And to do the bidding of their Creator they made peace between themselves. "

§§—2—§§ 9:24:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתלקחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתוך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הברד [AND FIRE] FLASHING UP AMIDST THE HAIL — a miracle within a miracle! Fire and hail mingled, although hail is water! But in order to perform the will of their Creator they made peace one with the other (Exodus Rabbah 12:4)."

—3— **24. Eingeschlossen im Hagel,** Wunder im Wunder, Feuer und Hagel waren miteinander verbunden; und der Hagel besteht aus Wasser, aber um den Willen ihres Schöpfers zu erfüllen, schlossen sie Frieden miteinander (Schemot Rabbah).

////—1—//// 9:28:1,**Enough.** [I.e.] let it be sufficient for Him with what He has already brought down.

§§—2—§§ 9:28:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורב AND IT IS ENOUGH — let it suffice Him with what He has brought down already.

—3— **28. Es ist genug,** es ist genug für Ihn das, was Er bereits hat herabfallen lassen.

////—1—//// 9:29:1,**When I leave the city.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעִיר has the same meaning as] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעִיר — from the city. But within the city he would not pray because it was full of idols.

§§—2—§§ 9:29:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כצאתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיר — This is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיר [AS SOON AS I AM GONE OUT] FROM THE CITY. But he did not pray within the city because it was full of idols (Exodus Rabbah 12:5).

—3— **29. Wenn ich aus der Stadt hinausgehe** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את; aber in der Stadt betete er nicht, weil sie voll von Götzen war (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 9:30:1,"**You are not yet in fear.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֶרֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּירְאוּן is translated:] “You are <font color=d50505>»</font>not yet<font color=d50505>«</font> in fear.” Similarly, wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֶרֶם appears in Scripture it has the meaning: <font color=d50505>»</font>not yet,<font color=d50505>«</font> and does not mean: <font color=d50505>»</font>before;<font color=d50505>«</font> as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֶרֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִשְׁכָּבוּ — [which Onkelos translates] “They did <font color=d50505>»</font>not yet<font color=d50505>«</font> lie down,” [or: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֶרֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִצְמָּח — [which Onkelos translates:] “did <font color=d50505>»</font>not yet<font color=d50505>«</font> sprout. This one (i.e., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֶרֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּירְאוּן), too, has a similar meaning: “I know that you [and your servants] do not yet fear, and that the moment there will be relief you will continue with your corruption. "

§§—2—§§ 9:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טרם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תראון means YE DO NOT YET FEAR. Wherever occurs in Scripture it signifies ״not yet”, and does not mean “before”. For example: (Genesis 19:4) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טרם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישכבו, which the Targum renders by “whilst yet they had not lain down”; (Genesis 2:5) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טרם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצמח which the Targum renders by “not yet sprung forth”. This, too, has the same meaning: I know that ye do not yet fear the Lord, and that as soon as there will be respite you will continue in your moral corruption."

—3— **30. Noch nicht fürchtet,** noch nicht fürchtet; so ist überall im Vers <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טרם zu erklären, noch nicht; es bedeutet aber nicht bevor; (Gen. 19, 4) sie hatten sich noch nicht niedergelegt; targ. sie hatten sich noch nicht niedergelegt; (Gen. 2,5) wuchs noch nicht, sprosste noch nicht; auch hier ist es so zu übersetzen, ich weiß, dass ihr euch noch nicht fürchtet, und sobald Erleichterung sein wird, in euerer Sündhaftigkeit verharrt. 

---

////—1—//// 9:31:1,"**The flax and barley have been broken.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכָּתָה meaning] has been broken, from the same term as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פַּרְעֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְכֹה — <font color=d50505>»</font>the lame Pharaoh;<font color=d50505>«</font> [or] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְכָאִים — <font color=d50505>»</font>broken.<font color=d50505>«</font> Similarly <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכּוּ [means “were not broken”]. It would not be correct to explain it as a term meaning “striking,” for the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ' cannot replace the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' so that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוּכָּתָה can be explained as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוּכָּתָה, or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכּוּ to be the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוּכּוּ . But rather, the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ' is part of the word-root and is [grammatically] the same form as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשֻׁפוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַצְמוֹתָיו — “his bones were bared.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והפשתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והשערה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכתה AND THE FLAX AND THE BARLEY <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכתה — i. e. were broken; it has the same meaning as in, (2 Kings 23:29) “Pharaoh-Necho (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכה)”, which denotes Pharaoh the lame i. e. broken in so far as the power of his legs is concerned (cf. II Samuel 9:3); (Isaiah 16:7) “brocken (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכאים)”, and so too <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכו (v. 32), “they were not broken”. It would not be correct to explain that it is connected in meaning with the word that signifies “smiting”, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכאה, for a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ cannot take the place of a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה that one may explain <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכָּתָה as being equivalent to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֻכָּתָה, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכּוּ to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֻכּוּ, but the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ is a root-letter in the verb, and the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֻכּוּ is of the same grammatical form as the verb in, (Job. 33:21) “and all his bones are laid bare” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֻׁפּוּ (i. e. Pual of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השערה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב "

—3— **31. Der Flachs und die Gerste waren zerschlagen,** zerbrochen, vom Ausdruck (II Kön. 23, 29), Pharao, der Hinkende; (Jes. 16, 7) zerbrochen; ebenso (V. 32) waren nicht zerschlagen; es wäre aber nicht richtig, es mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכאה schlagen, treffen zu übersetzen, denn für das He tritt kein Nun ein, um <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוכתה = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוכתה zu setzen und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכו = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכו; vielmehr gehört das Nun zur Wurzel, und es ist eine Bildung wie (Job 33, 21), entblösst sind alle seine Gebeine.

////—1—//// 9:31:2,"**Since the barley was ripe.** [Meaning] it has already ripened and is standing in its stalks and they [therefore] broke and fell. So, too, the flax has already become full-grown and has hardened so as to stand on its stems. "

§§—2—§§ 9:31:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השערה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב FOR THE BARLEY WAS IN THE EAR — it had produced its first ears and it stood on its stalks; these were therefore broken and fell. So, too, the flax had already grown and had become hard enough to stand in its capsules. "

—3— **Denn die Gerste war reif,** war schon reif und stand in Halmen, diese zerbrachen und sanken hin; ebenso war der Flachs schon gewachsen und fest geworden, so dass er in Stengeln stand. 

---

////—1—//// 9:31:3,"**The barley was ripe.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָבִיב meaning] stood in its stalks, from the same term as: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּאִבֵּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַנָּחַל — “the stalks of the stream.” "

§§—2—§§ 9:31:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השערה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב means [THE BARLEY] STOOD IN RIPE STATE, similar in meaning to, (Song 6:11) “[to look at] the ripe plants (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באבי] of the valley”."

—3— **Die Gerste war reif,** stand in Halmen, vom Ausdruck (Schir. 6, 11), die Gewächse am Bach. 

---

////—1—//// 9:32:1,"**Since they are late in sprouting.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲפִילֹת meaning] late, and were still soft [and pliable] and were able to stand [even] in the face of [a] hard [blow]. Although it has been stated: “All the vegetation in the fields was struck by the hail” one can explain the plain meaning of the verse as referring to the vegetation that stood in their stalks (i.e., were ripe), and were vulnerable to be broken by the hail. [However], in Midrash Rabbi Tanchuma, some Sages dispute this and explain <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲפִילֹת [as meaning] a wonder of wonders (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פֶּלֶא =wonder) occurred that they were not struck. "

§§—2—§§ 9:32:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפילת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה means FOR THEY WERE LATE in growing and they were still soft and able to resist the blow of anything hard. It is true that it is stated, (v. 25) “and every herb of the field did the hail smite”, but one must explain the real meaning of that verse as referring to herbs that stood on their stalks and were therefore liable to be broken by the hail. In the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma 2:2:16 some of our Rabbis differed in their explanation of this, and explained the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפילת to signify that most remarkable wonders (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פלאי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פלאות) happened to them in that they were not smitten."

—3— **32. Weil sie spätreif sind,** spät, sie waren noch weich und vermochten vor dem Harten standzuhalten; und obschon steht (Vers 25), alles Kraut des Feldes schlug der Hagel, so ist dies, um den einfachen Sinn des Verses zu erklären, auf die in Halmen stehenden Kräuter, die durch den Hagel geschlagen werden konnten, zu beziehen. Im Midrasch R. Tanchuma legen es manche unserer Lehrer anders aus und erklären,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפילות viele Wunder (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פלא) geschahen ihnen, dass sie nicht geschlagen wurden. 

---

////—1—//// 9:33:1,"**Did not reach.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִתַּךְ meaning] did not reach. Even those that were already in the air [never] reached the ground. Similar to this is: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתִּתַּךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֵינוּ the curse and the oath” in the Book of Daniel [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְתַּגִּיעַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֵינוּ meaning:] it reached us. Menachem ben Saruk classified it in the category of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּהִתּוּךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֶּסֶף meaning: the pouring (melting) of metal. I agree with his opinion, as Onkelos translates “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּצֹק as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַתִּיךְ [and] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָצֶקֶת” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְאַתָּכָא — to cast. So, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִתַּךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָאָרֶץ [has the meaning:] [The hail] was not poured to the ground. "

§§—2—§§ 9:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתך means [RAIN] DID NOT REACH the earth (i. e. no fresh rain came down) — that rain, too, which was alredy in the air at the moment when Moses was praying remained there and did not reach the ground. In a similar sense is “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותתך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלינו the curse and the oath” — a passage in the book of Ezra (really, Daniel 9:11) — which signifies, “the curse and the oath have reached us”. But Menachem ben Seruk classified it in the same section as, (Ezekiel 22:22) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כהתוך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כסף” which has the meaning of melting (pouring forth) metal. I agree with his opinion, because in the Targum we render <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצק, (Onkelos Exodus 38:5) “And he cast (metal)”, by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתיך, and (Onkelos Exodus 38:27) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לצקת, “to cast (metal)” by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאתכא, each of these Aramaic words being of the same root as our word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתך. Therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארצה would mean: rain was not poured out to the ground."

—3— **33. Ergossen sich nicht zur Erde,** gelangten nicht, und selbst, was bereits in der Luft war, gelangte nicht zur Erde; ähnlich (Dan. 9, 11), da ergoss sich auf uns die Verwünschung und der Schwur und erreichten uns; Menachem b. Seruk verbindet es mit der Wurzel (Jech. 22, 22), wie Silber im Tiegel geschmolzen wird; das ist der Ausdruck für Schmelzen von Metallen; und ich billige seine Worte, wie der Targum (38, 5) er goss mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתיך übersetzt; (dort 27) zu gießen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאתבא; auch hier, ergoss sich nicht zur Erde, wurde nicht zur Erde herabgegossen.

////—1—//// 10:1:1,**Adonoy said to Moshe “Go in to Pharaoh —** and warn him.”

§§—2—§§ 10:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES GO IN UNTO PHARAOH and warn him. 

—3— **1, 10 <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא. Der Ewige sprach zu Mosche, gehe zu Pharao hinein** und warne ihn.

////—1—//// 10:1:2,"**I will be able to set.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁתִי is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שׂוּמִי (another version: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׂימִי), [meaning:] “that I will set.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:1:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שתי means my setting (an infinitive of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שית), so that the phrase, which literally means “for the sake of my setting these my signs”, denotes “that I may set”.

—3— **Um einzusetzen,** niederzulegen; dass ich einsetze.

////—1—//// 10:2:1,"**I made a mockery.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְעַלַּלְתִּי means] I have mocked, as in: “For (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְעַלַּלְתְּ) you have mocked me;” [or:] “Is it not so, when (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִתְעַלֵּל) he mocked them?” which is said regarding the Egyptians. It does not mean <font color=d50505>»</font>doing<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>acting<font color=d50505>«</font> for if that were the case it should have been written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹולַלְתִּי, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְעוֹלֵל) Do to them as (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוֹלַלְתָּ) you have done to me,” [or:] “which (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹולַל) he has done to me.” "
"

§§—2—§§ 10:2:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התעללתי means I HAVE MOCKED, as in, (Numbers 22:29) “Because thou hast mocked (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התעללת) me”; (I Samuel 6:6) “Indeed, when he mocked (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התעולל) them”, which, also, is said in reference to Egypt. It is not an expression denoting doing and action, for were this so it should have written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוללתי, similar to (Lamentations 1:22) “And do (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עולל) unto them as thou hast done (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוללת) unto me”, and to (Lamentations 1:12) “which he has done (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עולל) unto me”."""

—3— **2. Zum Spott gemacht habe,** gescherzt habe; wie (Num. 22, 29), weil du mich verspottet hast; (I Sam. 6,6) fürwahr, als Er sie zum Spott machte, das sich auf die Ägypter bezieht. Es bedeutet aber nicht soviel wie Werk und Handlungen; denn dann hätte er schreiben müssen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוללתי wie (Echa 1, 12, 22), der mir geschehen; tue ihnen, wie Du mir getan.

////—1—//// 10:3:1,**To be humbled.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֵעָנֹת is] as Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְאִתְכְּנָעָא — <font color=d50505>»</font>to be humbled<font color=d50505>«</font> which is from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָנִי — <font color=d50505>»</font>poor<font color=d50505>«</font>. [The question: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָתַי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכו' conveys:] “you have refused to be poor and humble before Me.”

§§—2—§§ 10:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לענת Translate as the Targum: TO BE HUMBLED. It is of the same derivation as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עני poor, so that the passage signifies, “thou refusest to be poor and lowly before Me”."

—3— **3. Dich zu demütigen,** wie der Targum sagt, dich zu unterwerfen, von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עני arm, demütig; du weigerst dich, demütig und niedrig vor mir zu sein.

—3— **5. Die Oberfläche der Erde,** den Anblick der Erde. Dass, derjenige, der hinsieht, die Erde nicht sehen kann; er wendet einen kurzen Ausdruck an.

"

§§—2—§§ 10:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויושב [AND MOSES AND AARON] WERE BROUGHT BACK (The verb has a passive meaning [Hophal], not an active as the particle <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את before <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן might lead one to suppose) — They were brought back by a messenger: they (Pharaoh’s servants) sent people after them and these brought them back to Pharaoh."

////—1—//// 10:10:1,"**Just as I will send you and your little ones.** [I.e.,] “Surely were I to send the sheep and cattle as you have requested.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:10:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טפכם [MAY THE LORD BE WITH YOU] AS I WILL LET YOU AND YOUR LITTLE ONES GO — even though I were to let go also the flocks and herds as you have said.

////—1—//// 10:10:2,"**Beware, for evil confronts you.** This should be translated as Onkelos does. An aggadic explanation that I heard [states:] There is a star by the name of “Evil”; Pharaoh said to them: “I see by my astrological calculations that that star is rising towards you in the wilderness and it is a sign of blood and killing.” When [eventually] the Israelites sinned by [worshipping] the calf and God wished to kill them, Moshe said in his prayer, “Why should the Egyptians speak, saying: ‘He took them out with (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָעָה) the star “Evil,’” for this is meant by what he said, ‘Beware, for “Evil” confronts you’.” Immediately “God reconsidered the ‘Evil’” and turned the blood to blood of circumcision for Yehoshua circumcised them. This is meant by what is said: (Yehoshua said:) “Today I have removed the shame of Egypt from you” for they had been saying to you, “We see blood upon you in the wilderness.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:10:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניכם Understand this as the Targum takes it: See, the evil you are about to do wilt turn against yourself. I have heard a Midrashic explanation: There is a certain star the name of which is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה “Evil”. Pharaoh said to them, “By my astrological art I see that star rising towards you in the wilderness whither you wish to proceed. It is an emblem of blood and slaughter”. Consequently, when Israel sinned by worshipping the calf and the Holy One, blessed be He, intended to slay them, Moses said in his prayer, (Exodus 32:12) “Wherefore should the Egyptians speak and say, He brought them forth together with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה (i. e. under the influence of the star <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה); this is, indeed, what he (Pharaoh) has already said, “See, the ‘<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה’ is before you”. At once, “the Lord bethought Himself concerning ‘<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה’”, and He changed the blood of which this star was an emblem to the blood of the circumcision because indeed Joshua had them circumcised. This is the meaning of what is said, (Joshua 5:9). “This day have I rolled from off you the reproach of the Egyptians”, for they said to you. “We see blood impending over you in the wilderness. (Yalkut Shimoni on Torah 1:392; cf. also Rashi on Joshua 5:9.)"

—3— **Seht, ihr habt Böses im Sinne,** wie der Targum sagt (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאסתדורא wegzuziehen). Einen agadischen Midrasch (Jalk. 392) habe ich gehört, es gibt einen Stern, der <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה heißt; da sagte Pharao zu ihnen, ich sehe in meiner Astrologie, dass jener Stern in der Wüste vor euch aufgeht, und er ist ein Zeichen für Blut und Tötung; als nun die Kinder Israel durch das Kalb sündigten und der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, sie töten wollte, sagte Mosche in seinem Gebete, warum sollen die Ägypter also sprechen, mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה hat Er sie herausgeführt; das ist, was Pharao zu ihnen gesagt hat, seht, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה ist vor euerem Angesicht; sofort änderte der Ewige die Bedeutung von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעה und verwandelte das Blut in das Blut der Beschneidung, als Joschua sie beschnitt; das bedeutet der Vers (Jos. 5, 9), heute habe ich die Schmach Ägyptens von euch gewälzt, dass sie nämlich zu euch sagten, wir sehen Blut über euch in der Wüste.

////—1—//// 10:11:1,"**This is not right —** as you have said to take the children along with you, but, rather, let the men go and serve God.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן NOT SO as you have said, to take the children with you, but '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגברים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועבדו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה GO YE WHO ARE ADULT MEN AND SERVE THE LORD."

—3— **11. Nicht so,** wie ihr gesagt habt, die Kinder mit euch zu nehmen; sondern,

////—1—//// 10:11:2,**For this is what you desire.** “This (service) is what you requested till now: ‘Let us slaughter to our God’ and it is not customary for children to slaughter.

§§—2—§§ 10:11:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבקשים means FOR THAT IS WHAT YE DID SEEK till now: let us sacrifice to our God — and it is not the custom for little children to offer sacrifice.

—3— **ihr Männer, geht und dienet dem Ewigen, denn das verlangt ihr,** (jenen Dienst) habt ihr bis jetzt verlangt, wir wollen unserem Gotte opfern, und es ist nicht die Art der Kinder, Opfer darzubringen.

////—1—//// 10:11:3,**He** **had them expelled.** This is a shortened statement and does not state who expelled them.

§§—2—§§ 10:11:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגרש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אותם AND HE DROVE THEM OUT — This is an elliptical phrase and it does not expressly state who drove them out (i. e. the subject of the verb is omitted).

—3— **Man vertrieb sie,** dies ist ein kurzer Ausdruck; denn er sagt nicht, wer sie vertrieb.

////—1—//// 10:12:1,**For the locusts.** [The prefix letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב' denotes:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>On account of<font color=d50505>«</font> the locust plague.

§§—2—§§ 10:12:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארבה means on account of the plague of locusts (the prefix <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב signifies “on account of”).

—3— **12. Wegen der Heuschrecken,** wegen der Plage der Heuschrecken.

////—1—//// 10:13:1,**The east wind** The east wind carried the locusts because it (the wind) comes from opposite it (Egypt). For Egypt was southwest [relative to Eretz Yisrael] as has been explained elsewhere.

§§—2—§§ 10:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקדים THE EAST WIND — It was an east wind that brought the locusts because that came (blew) from the direction opposite to it (to Egypt), since Egypt was in the south-west, relative to Palestine, as it is explained in another place (Numbers 34:3)."

—3— **13. Und der Ostwind,** der Ostwind trug die Heuschrecken herbei, weil er Ägypten entgegenwehte; denn Ägypten liegt südwestlich (von Palästina), wie dies an anderer Stelle erklärt wird (Num. 34, 3).

////—1—//// 10:14:1,"**And never again after them.** The [locusts] that were in the days of Yoel about which it is said: “There was never one like it,” which teaches us that it was more serious than [the one in the days of] Moshe! It was so [only] in regard to multiple species, for, simultaneously, there were [the species called] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְבֶּה, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֶלֶק, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָסִיל, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָּזָם — <font color=d50505>»</font>Arbeh, Yelek, Chasil, Gazam.<font color=d50505>«</font> But [the one in the days] of Moshe was of only one species (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְבֶּה), the likes of which never had been and never would be. "

§§—2—§§ 10:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואחריו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן NEITHER AFTER THEM SHALL BE SUCH — That plague of locusts which happened during the days of Joel of which it is said, (Joel 2:2) “there hath not been ever the like” — which statement teaches us that it was more grievous than that in the days of Moses — was, however, caused by many species of locusts, together, those called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבה and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילק and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חסיל and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גזם; but that which happened in the days of Moses consisted of only one species (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבה) and any <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבה like that there never was and never will be."

—3— **14. Und nach ihnen werden nie wieder solche sein,** von jenen aber, die in den Tagen Joels kamen, wo es heißt (Joel 2, 2), seinesgleichen war noch niemals, erfahren wir doch, dass sie schwerer als die von Mosche waren? Nur, jene von Joel bestanden aus vielen Arten, da waren vier Heuschreckenarten, Arbe, Jelek, Chasil und Gasam, vereint; aber die von Mosche waren nur eine Art, und gleich ihr war nie vorher und wird niemals wieder sein.

////—1—//// 10:15:1,**No greenery.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֶרֶק here means] a green leaf. <font color=d50505>»</font>Verdure<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French.

§§—2—§§ 10:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירק means any green leaf (not “any herb”, since it speaks of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירק of the trees); old French verdure."

—3— **15. Alles Grüne,** grüne Blatt; das Grün in anderen Sprachen.

////—1—//// 10:19:1,**Westerly wind.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוּחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָם means] a westerly wind.

§§—2—§§ 10:19:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ים is A WEST WIND.

—3— **19. Westwind,** westlichen Wind.

////—1—//// 10:19:2,"**Into the Reed sea** It is my opinion that the Reed Sea was partially to the west [of Eretz Yisrael] opposite the entire southern side, and was also on the eastern side of Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, a westerly wind blew the locusts into the Reed Sea opposite [the east of Egypt] so, too, we find regarding boundaries [of Eretz Yisrael,] that it (the Reed Sea) veers to the east [of Eretz Ysrael,] for it is said: “from the Reed Sea to the Philistine Sea,” [referring to the extent of the land] east to west, since the Philistine Sea was to the west; as is said regarding the Philistines: “Those who inhabit the sea-coast, the Kereisi (Philistine) nation.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף INTO THE RED SEA — I say that the Red Sea was, as to part of it, in the west opposite the whole southern side of Palestine, and was also eastward of the Land of Israel; therefore a west wind blew the locusts into the Red Sea which was in the opposite direction to the west of Egypt. Thus do we find mentioned regarding the boundaries of Palestine that it (the Red Sea) faces the east of Palestine, since it states, (Exodus 23:31) “[And I will set thy boundaries] from the Red Sea even unto the sea of the Philistines”, which means from east to west since the sea of the Philistines was in the west, as it is said of the Philistines, (Zephaniah 2:5) “the inhabitants of the sea-coast, the nation of the Cherethites (the Philistines)”."

—3— **Ins Schilfmeer,** ich meine, das Schilfmeer war teils westlich und im ganzen Süden und auch noch östlich von Erez Israel; darum stiess der Westwind die Heuschrecken ins Schilfmeer, das ihm gegenüber war; und so finden wir auch bei den Grenzen, dass es sich nach Osten wendet; denn so heißt es (23, 31), vom Schilfmeer bis zum Meer der Pelischtim, von Osten nach Westen; denn das Meer der Pelischtim war im Westen; so heißt es bei den Pelischtim (Zeph. 2, 5), die an der Meeresküste wohnen, Volk der Kretim. 

---

////—1—//// 10:19:3,**Not a single locust remained.** Not even a salted one that they had salted.

§§—2—§§ 10:19:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשאר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחד THERE REMAINED NOT ONE LOCUST — not even those which they had salted — for they had salted some of them (Exodus Rabbah 13:7).

—3— **Es blieb nicht eine Heuschreke übrig,** auch von den gesalzenen, die sie davon eingemacht hatten (Schemot Rabbah).

////—1—//// 10:21:1,"**The darkness will be tangible.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵשׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹשֶׁךְ means:] There will be upon them a darkness greater then the darkness of night, [i.e.,] the darkness of night will become even more black and dark. "

§§—2—§§ 10:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חשך signifies and it (the darkness mentioned in the preceding phrase, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חשך) shall darken for them the natural darkness to a higher degree than the darkness of night: i. e. the darkness of night shall become even more black and dark. "

—3— **21. Und es verstärke sich die Finsternis,** die Finsternis werde noch dunkler über ihnen, mehr als das Dunkel der Nacht, und das Dunkel der Nacht werde noch stärker und dunkler. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמש = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימש (von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמש Nacht); wir haben viele Worte, bei denen das Aleph fehlt; weil die Aussprache des Aleph nicht so deutlich hörbar ist, lässt die Schrift zu, dass es ausfällt; wie (Jes. 13, 20), es zeltet dort kein Araber = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאהל er schlägt sein Zelt nicht auf; ebenso (II Sam. 22, 40), du gürtest mich mit Macht = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותאזרני. Onkelos übersetzt es mit weichen, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימוש es wird nicht weichen; wenn das Dunkel der Nacht weicht, wenn man bis kurz vor Tagesanbruch gekommen ist; aber diese Erklärung ist nicht leicht mit dem Waw von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימש zu vereinigen, weil es nach dem Satz, es entstehe Finsternis, steht. Der agadische Midrasch deutet es mit dem Ausdruck (Deut. 28, 29), am Mittag tasten, greifen, die Finsternis war doppelt und vielfach und dick, so dass sie greifbar war (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 10:21:2,"** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵשׁ (will be tangible) —** is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיַאֲמֵשׁ (<font color=d50505>»</font>He will darken<font color=d50505>«</font>). We have many words missing the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א' . Since the enunciation of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א' is not very noticeable Scripture is not particular if it is omitted. For example: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַהֵל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרָבִי [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַהֵל] being the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַאֲהִיל (<font color=d50505>»</font>with<font color=d50505>«</font> an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א') [meaning:] “[An Arab] will not pitch his tent [there].” Similarly, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתַּזְרֵנִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָיִל (“you have girded me with strength”) the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּאַזְרֵנִי — (<font color=d50505>»</font>with<font color=d50505>«</font> an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א'). Onkelos translates [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵש] as having the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>removing<font color=d50505>«</font> as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמוּשׁ — “It will not depart.” [Onkelos’ understanding of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵשׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חְשֶׁךְ is:] “After the darkness of night has departed” [i.e.,] when the light of day will approach. However, this statement does not fit the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵשׁ because it is written after <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וִיהִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹשֶׁך . A Midrash Aggada explains it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְיָמֵשׁ) from the term (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְמַשֵּׁשׁ) feeling his way in the afternoon,” for [the darkness] was doubled and redoubled and so thick that it was tangible. "

§§—2—§§ 10:21:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימש means as much as (is a contraction of) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמש (a Hiphil form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמש, evening darkness). We have many words in which an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א is omitted; since the sound of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א is not very marked, Scripture is not particular about omitting it. An example is: (Isaiah 13:20) “the Arabian <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַהֵל there”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַאֲהֵל, shall not pitch his tent. Similar is, (II Samuel 22:40) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתַּזְרֵנִי with strength”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַתְּאַזְרֵנִי “And thou hast girded me” (cf. Psalms 30:12). Onkelos translated it in the sense of removing, from the same root as, (Joshua 1:8) “it shall not depart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימוש)”, his rendering being, “[and there shall be darkness..] after the darkness of night has departed”, i. e. when the time approaches near to the light of day. But the statement does not then fit with the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימש, because this word is written after <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חשך. A Midrashic statement explains it in the sense of (Deuteronomy 28:29) “groping (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממשש feeling) at noon-day”, so that the meaning would be that it was of such a double character and so thick that there was something tangible in it (Exodus Rabbah 14:1-3). "


---

////—1—//// 10:22:1,"**There was total darkness. For three days, etc.,** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹשֶׁךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲפֵילָה means:] darkness of gloom so that one person did not see another during those three days, and for another three days afterwards [there was] a darkness twice as thick where no one was able to rise from his place. If he was sitting he could not stand and if he was standing he could not sit. Why did He bring darkness on them? Because there were among the Israelites of that generation evil people who did not wish to leave, and they died out during the three days of darkness so that the Egyptians not see their demise thereby saying, “They are being struck as we are.” Furthermore, [during the darkness] the Israelites searched and saw their [the Egyptians’ valuable] vessels and when they left [Egypt] and asked them [for the valuable vessels] and they (the Egyptians) responded, “We have nothing [to give you],” he (the Israelite) would say to him, “But I did see it in your house and it is in that particular place.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים denotes a triad of days. old French terziane; so, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים everywhere it occurs denotes in old French a septaine of days (a period of seven days)."

—3— **22. Drei Tage,** eine Dreiheit von Tagen, eine Dreiheit in anderen Sprachen; ebenso bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבעת sieben Tage überall eine Siebenheit von Tagen, Siebenheit in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 10:22:2,"**Three days.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁלֹשֶׁת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמִים means:] <font color=d50505>»</font>a threesome of days.<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=d50505>»</font>Terzaine<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — a threesome. Similarly, wherever it says: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁבְעַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמִים, it is <font color=d50505>»</font>septaine<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French] — a group of seven days. "

§§—2—§§ 10:22:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חשך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפלה … <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים — there was darkness of gloom when no man saw another during those three days, and there was moreover another period of three days’ darkness twice as thick as this when no man rose from his place: one who happened to be sitting when this second period of darkness began was unable to rise, and one who was then standing was unable to sit down. And why did He bring darkness upon them? Because there were wicked people amongst the Israelites of that generation who had no desire to leave Egypt, and these died during the three days of darkness so that the Egyptians might not see their destruction and say, “These, (the Israelites) too have been stricken as we have”. And a further reason is that the Israelites searched (the darkness came just in order that they might do this) and saw their (the Egyptians’) jewels, and when they were leaving Egypt and asked them for their jewels, and they replied, “We have none at all in our possession”, they answered them, “I have seen it in your house and it is in such and such a place” (cf. Midrash Tanchuma, Bo 1; Exodus Rabbah 14:3)."

—3— **Und es war dichte Finsternis drei Tage,** dichte Finsternis, dass sie einer den anderen jene drei Tage nicht sahen, und noch drei weitere Tage Finsternis, doppelt so stark wie die erste, dass keiner von seiner Stelle aufstehen konnte; wer stand, konnte sich nicht hinsetzen, und wer saß, konnte nicht aufstehen. Und warum brachte Er Finsternis über sie? Weil in jenem Geschlechte Frevler in Israel waren, die nicht ausziehen wollten; diese starben in den drei Tagen der Finsternis, damit die Ägypter ihren Sturz nicht sähen und sagen könnten, auch sie werden gleich uns geschlagen; und ferner suchte und sah Israel (in diesen Tagen) ihre Geräte; als sie dann auszogen und sie um jene baten und die Ägypter sagten, wir besitzen nichts; da erwiderte man ihnen, ich habe es in deinem Hause gesehen; es befindet sich an dem und dem Orte (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 10:24:1,**Stay behind.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֻצָּג means] shall remain in its place.

§§—2—§§ 10:24:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצג means SHALL REMAIN STANDING in its place.

—3— **24. Soll bleiben,** soll an seinem Orte stehenbleiben. 

---

////—1—//// 10:25:1,"**You too will give.** It will not be sufficient for you that our cattle go with us but, rather, “you too” will give of yours. "

§§—2—§§ 10:25:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תתן THOU MUST GIVE ALSO — It will not be enough for you that our cattle will go with us but you will give also of yours.

—3— **25. Auch du sollst geben,** nicht genug für dich, dass unsere Herden mit uns gehen; sondern auch du sollst uns noch geben. 

---

////—1—//// 10:26:1,"**Hoof.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פַּרְסָה means] the hoof of the foot, <font color=d50505>»</font>plante<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 10:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרסה is the hoof of the foot; in old French plante.

—3— **26. Klaue,** eine Fußsohle; Fußsohle in andere Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 10:26:2,"**We do not know with what we will worship.** [I.e.,] We do not know the magnitude of the service. “Perhaps He will ask of us more than we have in our possession.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:26:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נעבד means WE DO NOT KNOW WITH WHAT WE MUST SERVE we do not know how heavy will be the service: perhaps He will ask more than we have in our possession.

—3— **Wir wissen nicht,** wie wir dienen sollen, wie schwer der Dienst sein wird; vielleicht verlangt Er mehr von uns, als wir besitzen. 

---

////—1—//// 10:29:1,"**As you say.** [I.e.,] “You have spoken properly and you have spoken at the right time. It is true that I will never see your face again.” "

§§—2—§§ 10:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברת signifies RIGHTLY HAST THOU SPOKEN, and in its proper time hast thou spoken; for it is true that I will not see thy face again (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:31; Exodus Rabbah 18:1; cf. also Onkelos)."

—3— **29. Du hast recht gesprochen,** du hast gut gesprochen und zur rechten Zeit gesprochen; in Wahrheit, ich werde vor deinem Angesichte nicht mehr erscheinen (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 11:1:1,"**Completely.** [Onkelos translates <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּלָה as:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְמִירָא — <font color=d50505>»</font>completely<font color=d50505>«</font> [having the same meaning as] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּלִיל [Here, meaning] “He will send you all away.” "

§§—2—§§ 11:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלה Onkelos renders it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גמירא, taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלה in sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כליל entirely; i. e. he will send all of you away."

—3— **11, 1. Vollkommen,** ganz, vollkommen, er wird euch alle entlassen. 

---

////—1—//// 11:2:1,"**Speak, please** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָא can only indicate pleading. [i.e.,] “I ask of you, speak to them about this, so that that righteous person, Avraham, may not say, [The promise of] ‘They will enslave them and oppress them’ He fulfilled in them, [but the promise:] ‘And afterwards they will leave with great wealth,’ He did not fulfill in them.” "

§§—2—§§ 11:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא SPEAK <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא is always an expression of entreaty. Here it means: I entreat you, admonish them about this which follows (impress this injunction upon them), so that righteous man, Abraham, may not say: the prophecy (Genesis 15:13) “they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them” He permitted to be fulfilled in them, but the promise (Genesis 15:14) “and afterwards they shall go forth with great substance” He did not bring to fulfilment for them (Berakhot 9a-b)."

—3— **2. Sprich doch**,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא ist die Form einer Bitte; ich bitte dich, ermahne sie dazu, damit nicht jener Fromme, Abraham, sage, (Gen. 15, 13) man wird sie zu Knechten machen und sie bedrücken, hat Er an ihnen erfüllt, aber, nachher werden sie mit großer Habe ausziehen, hat Er nicht an ihnen erfüllt (Ber. 9a). 

---

////—1—//// 11:4:1,"**Moshe said, “This is what Adonoy has said.”** While still standing before Pharaoh this prophecy was told to him because once he left his (Pharaoh’s) presence he did not see his face ever again. "

§§—2—§§ 11:4:1," '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה AND MOSES SAID, THUS SAITH THE LORD — Whilst he was still standing before Pharaoh this prophecy was spoken to him, because after he left him, he did not see his face again (Exodus Rabbah 18:1)."

—3— **4. Mosche sprach, so spricht der Ewige;** als er vor Pharao stand, wurde ihm diese Prophezeiung mitgeteilt; denn, als er von ihm weggegangen war, erschien er nicht mehr vor seinem Angesichte. 

---

////—1—//// 11:4:2,"**About the time of midnight.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּחֲצֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַיְלָה lit. means:] <font color=d50505>»</font>when the night is divided. <font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּחֲצוֹת being the same form as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּעֲלוֹת (<font color=d50505>»</font> When [it] went up<font color=d50505>«</font>) or (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֲרוֹת) <font color=d50505>»</font>when they became angry at us.<font color=d50505>«</font> This is its (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּחֲצֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַיְלָה) plain meaning so that it fits within its context, for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲצוֹת is not the noun of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֵצִי . Our Sages [however] explained it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּחֲצוֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַיְלָה) as: <font color=d50505>»</font>about the time of midnight.<font color=d50505>«</font> And they [go on to] say that Moshe used the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּחֲצוֹת which implies at about [midnight], either [slightly] before or after, and he did not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֲצוֹת (<font color=d50505>»</font>at<font color=d50505>«</font> midnight) lest Pharaoh’s stargazers make a mistake and say, “Moshe is a liar!” But God who knows His [exact] times and moments, [actually] said, “<font color=d50505>»</font>At<font color=d50505>«</font> midnight.” "

§§—2—§§ 11:4:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כחצות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלילה means, WHEN THE NIGHT IS DIVIDED (i. e., when midnight arrives). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כחצות is an infinitive with prefix, of similar form to, (1 Kings 18:36) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעלות, “when went up” and (Psalms 124:3) “when their wrath was kindled (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרות)”. This is its literal meaning which fits in with the sense, for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצות is not a noun, being another form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֵצִי (when the meaning would be about midnight I will go out etc.”, for this does not fit in with the sense, since God would certainly have stated exactly when He would do this). But our Rabbis took it in this sense and explained it as meaning “about the middle of the night”, and they asserted that Moses said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כחצות “about midnight”, which implies near to it — either just before it or just after it, and he did not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחצות “at midnight” (as God had bidden him say) because he feared lest Pharaoh’s astrologers might make a mistake as regards the time when the slaughter of the firstborn actually took place, thinking that it was a little earlier or later than midnight, and would say, in consequence of this error, “Moses is a liar!” (cf. Berakhot 4a). "

—3— **Wenn die Nacht sich teilt,** wenn die Nacht in der Mitte geteilt wird;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחצות wie (I Kön. 18, 36), als emporstieg; (Ps. 124, 3) da ihr Zorn gegen uns entbrannte; dies ist der einfache Sinn, wenn man es seiner Stellung im Satz entsprechend erklärt; denn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצות ist kein Hauptwort von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצי; unsere Lehrer erklären es gleich <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבחצות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלילה und sagen, Mosche sagte, um die Mitternacht, das bedeutet, nahe daran, entweder kurz vorher oder nachher, und er sagte nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחצות in der Mitternacht, vielleicht könnten sich die Astrologen Pharaos irren und sagen, Mosche ist ein Lügner; aber der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, kennt genau alle Seine Zeiten und Augenblicke und sprach <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחצות (Ber. 4a). 

---

////—1—//// 11:5:1,"**To the first-born of the captive.** Why were the captives struck down? So that the captives should not say, their own god demanded [vengeance for] their humiliation and brought retribution upon the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 11:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השבי UNTO THE FIRSTBORN OF THE CAPTIVE (these words are used in 12:29 instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השפחה “unto the firstborn of the handmaid” in this verse) — Why were the captives smitten, for they had not enslaved the Israelites? In order that these might not say that their god had claimed satisfaction for the humiliation imposed upon them and had brought this punishment upon the Egyptians (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:29)."

—3— **5. Bis zum Erstgeborenen der Gefangenen,** warum wurden die Gefangenen geschlagen? Damit sie nicht sagen könnten, ihr Abgott habe ihre Schmach gefordert und Strafen über die Ägypter gebracht. 

---

////—1—//// 11:5:2,**From the first-born of Pharaoh to the first-born of the slave girl.** All those less [important] than the first-born of Pharaoh and more [important] than the first-born of the slave girl are included [in this description]. Why were the first-born of the slave girls struck? Because they too enslaved them (the Israelites) and rejoiced in their (the Israelites’) oppression.

§§—2—§§ 11:5:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השפחה FROM THE FIRSTBORN OF PHARAOH UNTO THE FIRSTBORN OF THE HANDMAID — All who were of less importance than the firstborn of Pharaoh and of more importance than the firstborn of the handmaid are included in this description. And why were the sons of the handmaids stricken? Because they, too, treated them (the Israelites) as slaves and rejoiced at their misery (Midrash Tanchuma, Bo 7)."

—3— **Vom Erstgeborenen Pharaos bis zum Erstgeborenen der Magd,** alle, die geringer als der Erstgeborene Pharaos und angesehener als der Erstgeborene der Magd waren, gehörten dazu. Und warum wurden die Söhne der Mägde geschlagen? Weil auch sie die Israeliten knechteten und sich mit ihrer Not freuten (Mech. 13). 

---

////—1—//// 11:5:3,**And every first-born animal.** Because they (the Egyptians) worshipped it. When God punishes an idol worshipping nation He punishes its gods [first].

§§—2—§§ 11:5:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהמה AND ALL THE FIRSTBORN OF BEASTS — because they worshipped these as gods. When the Holy One, blessed be He, exacts punishment from a nation, He punishes their gods at the same time (Genesis Rabbah 96:5)."

—3— **Und alles Erstgeborene vom Vieh,** weil sie dieses anbeteten; wenn der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, eine Nation bestraft, so straft Er auch ihre Abgötter (Mechilta 13). 

---

////—1—//// 11:7:1,**A dog will not sharpen its tongue.** I say that [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֶחֱרַץ] is a term meaning <font color=d50505>»</font>sharp<font color=d50505>«</font>. Similarly “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרַץ his tongue towards any man of the B’nei Yisroel.” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרַץ meaning:] <font color=d50505>»</font>He did not sharpen<font color=d50505>«</font>. [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תֶּחֶרֳץ — “Then you will utter a sharp sound. [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמוֹרַג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוּץ — “A sharp thresher.” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַחְשְׁבוֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוּץ” — “The thoughts of a sharp one” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוּץ meaning:] a sharp and clever person. [or:] “You bring wealth to the hand of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוּצִים” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוּצִים meaning:] the clever ones — sharp merchants.

§§—2—§§ 11:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יחרץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשנו NO DOG SHALL <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרץ HIS TONGUE — I say that it has the meaning of sharpening: “no dog shall whet his tongue”. So, too: (Joshua 10:21) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרץ his tongue against any of the children of Israel”, i. e. “none whetted”; (II Samuel 5:24) “then <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחרץ” — then thou shalt utter a sharp sound; (Isaiah 41:15) “a threshing-sledge <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרוץ” i. e. sharp; (Proverbs 21:5) “the plans of a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרוץ” — of “an acute and sharp man”; (Proverbs 10:4) “the hand of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרוצים maketh rich”, i. e. the hand of the acute — of sharp merchants."

—3— **7. Wird kein Hund seine Zuge spitzen,** ich meine, es bedeutet schärfen, er wird nicht spitzen; ebenso (Jos. 10. 21) gegen die Kinder Israel spitzte keiner seine Zunge; (II Sam. 5,24) dann sollst du eilen, scharf sein; (Jes. 41, 15) geschärfte Dreschwalze, scharf; (Spr. 21, 5) die Gedanken des Arbeitsamen, eines eifrigen, scharfen Menschen; (dort 10, 4) die Hand der Fleissigen wird reich, der Scharfen, geschärfter Kaufleute. 

---

////—1—//// 11:7:2,**That Adonoy distinguishes.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַפְלֶה means] <font color=d50505>»</font>He will make a distinction.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 11:7:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יפלה meant THAT HE MAKETH A DIFFERENCE.

—3— **Dass unterscheidet,** trennt. 

---

////—1—//// 11:8:1,"**Then all your servants will come down** [Moshe] showed respect to royalty [by using this phrase]. For ultimately Pharaoh himself came down to him at night and said: “Arise! get out from among my people!” though Moshe [out of respect] had not initially said, “You will come down and bow to me.” "

§§—2—§§ 11:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירדו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבדיך AND ALL THY SERVENTS SHALL COME DOWN [UNTO ME] — He showed respect to the king, for as a matter of fact ultimately Pharaoh himself came down to him at night, (Exodus 12:31) “And he said, Arise, go out from the midst of my people”; but Moses did not at the outset say to him, “And thou shalt come down to me and shalt prostrate thyself”, out of respect for the king, (Exodus Rabbah 7:3)"

—3— **8. Und alle deine Knechte werden herabkommen,** er erwies der Regierung Ehre; denn schließlich kam Pharao selbst zu ihm in der Nacht und sagte (12, 31), machet euch auf, verlasset mein Volk; aber Mosche sagte vorher nicht zu ihm, du wirst zu mir herabkommen und dich vor mir bücken (Sebach. 102a). 

---

////—1—//// 11:8:2,**That follow you.** [Meaning:] those who follow your advice and ways.

§§—2—§§ 11:8:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברגליך (lit., who are at thy feet) — who go after (follow) thy counsel and ways."

—3— **Das dir folgt,** die deinem Rate und deinem Schritte folgen. 

---

////—1—//// 11:8:3,**Then I will go out —** together with all the people from your land.”

§§—2—§§ 11:8:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצא AND AFTER THAT I WILL GO OUT, with all my people, from thy land."

—3— **Und dann werde ich ausziehen,** mit dem ganzen Volke aus deinem Lande. 

---

////—1—//// 11:8:4,**He then left Pharaoh.** [But only after] concluding his words did he (Moshe) leave his presence.

§§—2—§§ 11:8:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND HE WENT OUT FROM PHARAOH — After he had concluded his words he went forth from his presence.

—3— **Und er ging von Pharao hinweg;** als er seine Worte vollendet hatte, ging er von ihm hinweg. 

---

////—1—//// 11:8:5,"**In great anger.** Because he (Pharaoh) had said to him, “Do not see my face again!” (v. 28). "

§§—2—§§ 11:8:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף IN FIERCENESS OF WRATH because he (Pharaoh) had said to him, (Exodus 10:28) “Do not again see my face."

—3— **Mit entbranntem Zorne,** weil er zu ihm gesagt hatte, du sollst nicht ferner vor meinem Angesichte erscheinen. 

---

////—1—//// 11:9:1,"**Thus I will multiply My wonders.** The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוֹפְתַי [in the plural] represents two [wonders]. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְבוֹת — <font color=d50505>»</font>increase<font color=d50505>«</font> represents a third [wonder]: 1. the killing of the first-born, 2. the splitting of the Reed Sea, and 3. the turbulent stirring of the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 11:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מופתי SO THAT MY WONDERS MAY BE MULTIPLIED (more lit., so that my wonders may be many) — referring not to one wonder alone (the slaying of the firstborn) but to the slaying of the firstborn, the division of the Red Sea and the overthrowing of the Egyptians in it."

—3— **9. Um meine Wunderzeichen zu mehren,** die Tötung der Erstgeborenen und die Spaltung des Schilfmeeres und die Ägypter hineinzuschleudern. 

---

////—1—//// 11:10:1,"**Moshe and Aharon had done, etc.** This has already been written for us regarding all the wonders, and is repeated here only as a lead-in to the section that follows it. "

§§—2—§§ 11:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואהרן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND MOSES AND AARON DID etc. — It (Scripture) has already written this in the description of all the preceding wonders, and it repeats it here only in order to connect it with the chapter which comes after this (as giving a reason why the commands in the next chapter were given to Aaron as well as to Moses; cf. Rashi’s comment on the following verse)."

—3— **10. Und Mosche und Aharon taten,** er hat uns dies bereits bei allen WunderZeichen mitgeteilt, und wiederholt es hier nur darum, um es mit dem nächsten Abschnitt zu verbinden. 

---

////—1—//// 12:1:1,"**Adonoy said to Moshe and Aharon.** Since Aharon performed, and troubled himself, in regard to the wonders, just as much as Moshe, He (God) does him this honor at the first <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font>, by including him with Moshe in this message. "

§§—2—§§ 12:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן AND THE LORD SPAKE UNTO MOSES AND AARON — Because Aaron had worked and toiled in performing the wonders just the same as Moses He paid him this honour at the first command by including him with Moses in the communication (Tanchuma Yahshan 2:3:8).

—3— **12, 1. Der Ewige sprach zu Mosche und zu Aharon,** weil Aharon gleich Mosche sich mit der Vollbringung der Wunderzeichen bemühte, erwies er ihm diese Ehre beim ersten Gebote, dass er ihn mit Mosche in die Anrede einschloss. 

---

////—1—//// 12:1:2,"**In the land of Egypt —** [but] outside the city. or was that not so, but [it was] rather within the city? The Torah, therefore, states [concerning Moshe’s prayer]: “When I leave the city, etc.” Now, if [regarding] prayer, which is [relatively] less significant, he would not pray within the city for it was full of idols, then, [regarding] a message [from God], which is so much more significant, how much more so [that he would leave the city.] "

§§—2—§§ 12:1:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים IN THE LAND OF EGYPT — This must have been outside the city! Or perhaps this is not so, but it was inside the city? Scripture however states, (Exodus 9:29) “When I leave the city [I will spread my hands (pray) unto the Lord]”. Now how was it in regard to prayer which is of light importance in comparison with a communication from God? He did not recite the prayer inside the city! Then, in the case of a divine communication which is of so weighty importance does it not follow all the more that this was also so! — And why, indeed, did He not converse with him inside the city? Because it was full of idols (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:1:4)."

—3— **Im Lande Mizraim,** außerhalb der Stadt; oder vielleicht nicht so, sondern in der Stadt? Darum heißt es (9, 29), wenn ich aus der Stadt hinausgehe, … wenn er schon ein leichtes Gebet nicht in der Stadt verrichtete, weil sie voll Götzen war, war dann nicht eine so schwere Anrede wie diese um so mehr außerhalb der Stadt! (Mechilta). 

---

////—1—//// 12:2:1,"**This month.** He (God) showed him the moon at its renewal and said to him, “When the moon renews itself, let that be for you the beginning of a new month.” However, Scripture does not depart from its plain meaning: He (God) was telling him about the month of <font color=d50505>»</font>Nissan<font color=d50505>«</font>; [viz.] this (Nissan) shall be the start of the order of the counting of the months, so that <font color=d50505>»</font>Iyar<font color=d50505>«</font> will be called the second [month] and <font color=d50505>»</font>Sivan<font color=d50505>«</font>, the third. "

§§—2—§§ 12:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>החדש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה — He showed him the moon in the first stage of its renewal, and He said to him, “The time when the moon renews itself thus, shall be unto you the beginning of the month”. (The translation therefore is: “This stage of renewal (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חדש) shall be the moment of beginning the months”; cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:2:2). But no Scriptural verse can lose its literal meaning, and He really spoke this in reference to the month Nisan: this month shall be the beginning in the order of counting the months, so that Iyar shall be called the second, Sivan the third."

—3— **2. Dieser Neumond,** Er zeigte ihm den Mond bei seiner Erneuerung und sagte zu ihm, immer, wenn der Mond sich erneuert, sei für dich der Anfang des Monats (Mechilta; Schemot Rabbah). Der Vers geht aber niemals aus seinem einfachen Sinn heraus, und vom Monat Nissan sagte Er hier zu ihm, dieser soll der erste sein in der Reihe der Anzahl der Monate, so dass Ijar der zweite, Siwan der dritte genannt wird. 

---

////—1—//// 12:2:2,"**This.** Moshe had difficulty regarding the renewal of the moon how much of it must be visible so that it be fit to be consecrated. He (God) then showed him with His “finger” the moon in the sky, and said to him, “When you see it like this, sanctify it.” But how could He show it to him — did He not speak with him only by day, as it is said: “And on <font color=d50505>»</font>the day<font color=d50505>«</font> that God spoke,” [or:] “on <font color=d50505>»</font>the day<font color=d50505>«</font> that He commanded him,” [or:] “from <font color=d50505>»</font>the day<font color=d50505>«</font> that God commanded and beyond?” But [the answer is] it was near sunset [when] this section was told to him (Moshe) and He pointed it out to him at nightfall. "

§§—2—§§ 12:2:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה THIS [STAGE OF RENEWAL] — Moses was in perplexity regarding the Molad of (the exact moment when begins) the new moon — how much of it must be visible before it is proper to consecrate it as new moon: He therefore pointed it out to him in the sky with the finger and said to him, “Behold it like this, and consecrate it” (i. e., when you see the moon in a stage of renewal similar to this which you now behold you may proclaim that a new month has begun). But how could He point it out to him, for did He not conserve with him only by day, as it is said, (Exodus 6:28) “And it came to pass on the day when the Lord spake [unto Moses]”; (Leviticus 7:38) “On the day when he commanded”; (Numbers 15:23) “From the day that the Lord commanded and henceforward”? But the explanation is: This chapter was spoken to him close to sunset and He pointed it out to him at nightfall (more lit., near darkness) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:2:1)."

—3— **Dieser,** die Bestimmung der Erneuerung des Mondes fiel Mosche schwer, in welcher Größe er sichtbar sein müsste, damit er geeignet wäre, ihn zu heiligen; da zeigte Er ihm wie mit dem Finger den Mond am Himmel und sagte zu ihm, wenn du ihn so siehst, so heilige ihn. Und wie zeigte Er ihm denselben, da Er doch nur am Tage mit ihm redete, so heißt es (Ex. 6,28), es war am Tage, da der Ewige redete; (Lev. 7,38) am Tage, da Er befahl; (Num. 15,23) vom Tage an, da der Ewige befohlen, und weiter? Nur, kurz vor Sonnenuntergang wurde ihm dieser Abschnitt gesagt, und Er zeigte ihm den Mond vor dem Eintritt der Dunkelheit. 

---

////—1—//// 12:3:1,"**Speak to the entire community.** But did Aharon speak? Has it not already been stated “You (Moshe) speak?” But [the answer is] they bestowed honor on each other and said to one another: “Teach me [what to say].” The message would then emanate from both, as if both were speaking. "

§§—2—§§ 12:3:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדת SPEAK UNTO ALL THE CONGREGATION — But did Aaron speak? Has it not already been stated, (Exodus 7:2) “You (Moses) shall speak etc.”. But the explanation is: they paid respect one to the other, saying to each other, “Instruct me what to say”. and the divine communication in question issued from both of them, so that it was as though they were both speaking (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:3:2)."

—3— **3. Sprechet zur ganzen Gemeinde,** sprach denn Aharon, es steht doch bereits (7,2), du sollst sprechen? Nur, sie erwiesen einander Ehre und sagten einer zum anderen, belehre mich, und das Wort kam von beiden, als ob beide redeten (Mechilta). 

---

////—1—//// 12:3:2,"**To the entire community of Israel saying, “On the tenth [day] of this month.”** [I.e.,] “Speak today, on the first of the month that they should take it (the lamb) on the tenth of the month. "

§§—2—§§ 12:3:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחדש i. e. SPEAK to-day — on the first of the month — THAT ON THE TENTH OF THE MONTH they should take it (the lamb) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:3:3).

—3— **Redet zur ganzen Gemeinde Israel, am zehnten des Monats,** sprechet heute am Neumondstage, sie sollen es am zehnten dieses Monats nehmen (Mechilta); das Pessachopfer in Mizraim sollte am zehnten genommen werden, nicht aber das der späteren Geschlechter (Pess. 96a). 

---

////—1—//// 12:3:3,"**This.** The <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> in Egypt was acquired on the tenth, but not the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> of future generations. "

§§—2—§§ 12:3:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה [ON THE TENTH OF] THIS [MONTH] — As regards the paschal lamb sacrificed in Egypt it had to be taken from the flock on the tenth, but this did not apply to the paschal-lamb offered by future generations (Pesachim 96a)."

—3— **Ein Lamm für ein Haus der Väter,** eine Familie; siehe auch wenn sie zahlreich waren, hätte ich gemeint, nur ein Lamm für alle, darum steht noch, ein Lamm für ein Haus (Mechilta). 

---

////—1—//// 12:3:4,"**A lamb for [his] family.** [Meaning one lamb] per family. Thus, if there were many [members in the family], one might think that one lamb [suffices] for all. The Torah, therefore, states: “A lamb for each household.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:3:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבות A LAMB FOR THE HOUSE OF THEIR FATHERS — i. e. a lamb for one family (“family” here means the larger unit comprising the father or grandfather with his married sons and their families). Consequently, if they (the members of such a family) were numerous, one might think that they may take one lamb for all of them (irrespective of whether this would suffice to provide a piece as large as an olive, the minimum quantity, for each person)! Therefore Scripture states: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבית A LAMB FOR EACH HOUSEHOLD (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:3:7)."


---

////—1—//// 12:4:1,"**If the household [members] are too few for the lamb.** [I.e.,] If they are too few to be sufficient for one lamb, so that they are unable to eat it [all] and will thus come to [the transgression of] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹתָר, then “Let him and his neighbor take, etc.,” That is the implication here according to its plain meaning. However, there is also an exposition [of the Sages]: [This verse intends] to teach that [even] after they have been counted in it they may [still] be excluded [from the group] and withdraw their association from it and be counted as [partners] of another lamb. However, if they do decide to withdraw their association and be counted [as partners] of another lamb, then this should be done “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִהְיוֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשֶּׂה” — [i.e.,] they should be excluded while the lamb still exists, [that is to say,] while it is still alive and not once it has been slaughtered. "
