§§—2—§§ 12:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימעט <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה — This means: if they are too few to be sufficient for one lamb — that they are unable to eat the whole of it, and it would therefore come under the category of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נותר “left over”. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושכנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THEN LET HIM AND HIS NEIGHBOUR TAKE etc. — This is what these words and those that precede it imply in its literal sense, but there is also a derivation from it of a Halachic character — that the verse intends to teach that after they have counted themselves (formed themselves into a company) for it, they may reduce their number by withdrawing from it and may register themselves for a different lamb; but if they intend to withdraw and thereby reduce their number <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה — they must reduce only whilst the lamb is still in being — whilst it is alive (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה) — and not after it has been slaughtered (Pesachim 89a; cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:4:1)."

—3— **4. Wenn aber das Haus zu klein ist, um zu einem Lamme zu gehören,** wenn sie zu wenig sind, um zu einem Lamme zu gehören, so dass sie es nicht essen können und davon übrigbleiben würde, so nehme er und sein Nachbar; das ist der Inhalt nach dem einfachen Sinne; außerdem gibt es einen Midrasch hierzu, dass der Vers nämlich lehrt, nachdem sich Leute zu dem Lamm gezählt haben, können sie sich immer wieder entfernen und davon zurückziehen und auf ein anderes Lamm zählen; nur, wenn sie sich zurückziehen und entfernen wollen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהיות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה, so müssen sie sich entfernen, solange das Lamm noch existiert, solange das Lamm lebt, aber nicht, wenn es bereits geschachtet ist (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:4:2,**According to the number.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּמִכְסַת means: according to] <font color=d50505>»</font>the number.<font color=d50505>«</font> Similarly: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִכְסַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעֶרְכְּךָ [means <font color=d50505>»</font>the number of the evaluation<font color=d50505>«</font>].

§§—2—§§ 12:4:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במכסת means ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER. Similar is, (Leviticus 27:23) “The number (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכסת) of thy valuation”."

—3— **Nach der Anzahl der Seelen,** Zahl, ebenso (Lev. 27, 23) Summe der Schätzung. 

---

////—1—//// 12:4:3,"**According to what the person eats.** Each according to his fitness to eat, to exclude the sick and the old who cannot eat a <font color=d50505>»</font>kezayis<font color=d50505>«</font> (a piece the size of an olive). "

§§—2—§§ 12:4:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכלו [EVERY MAN] ACCORDING TO HIS EATING — every man who is fitted to eat the quantity prescribed by the Law; this excludes a sick person and an aged person who are unable to eat a portion the size of an olive (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:4:5). 

—3— **Soviel er essen kann,** wer imstande ist zu essen; das schließt Kranke und Alte aus, die nicht eine Olive groß essen können (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:4:4,**Shall you make your count.** [As Onkelos translates it:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּתְמְנוּן — <font color=d50505>»</font>you will be counted.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 12:4:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תכסו means ye shall number yourselves, as the Targum renders it. (It is not to be translated: ye shall number others.)"

—3— **Zählet euch,** rechnet euch. 

---

////—1—//// 12:5:1,**Flawless.** Without a blemish

§§—2—§§ 12:5:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמים PERFECT i. e. without blemish (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:5:1).

—3— **5. Fehlerlos,** ohne Leibesfehler. 

---

////—1—//// 12:5:2,"**A yearling** Its entire [first] year it is called a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בֶּן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁנָה, as if to say: it was born this year. "

§§—2—§§ 12:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה OF THE FIRST YEAR — the whole of its first year it is termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בן, as much as to say, that it was born during this year (it does not mean that it is one year old — in its second year) (cf.Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:5:2)."

—3— **Im ersten Jahr,** während seines ganzen ersten Jahres heißt es <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה, das heißt, ein in diesem Jahre Geborenes (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:5:3,"**From the sheep or goats.** Either one or the other, for a goat is also called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׂה as it is said: “And a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׂה of the goats.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:5:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכבשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העזים — i. e. either from these (a lamb) or from these (a goat) (i. e. the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומן does not signify “and”, but “or”); for a goat, also, is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה, as it is said, (Deuteronomy 14:4) “the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה of the goats” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה means the young animal, either of the sheep or of the goats) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:5:1)."

—3— **Von den Schafen und von den Ziegen,** entweder davon oder davon; denn auch eine Ziege wird Lamm genannt, so heißt es (Deut. 14,4), Ziegenlamm. 

---

////—1—//// 12:6:1,"**You shall hold it in safekeeping.** This term (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמִשְׁמֶרֶת) refers to “examining,” for it requires examination against any blemish for four days before its slaughter. Why was it necessary to acquire it four days before its slaughter — something not commanded regarding the Pesach of later generations? [In response] R. Masia b. Cheresh would say: Scripture says: “And I passed over you and saw you and behold your time was a time of love” — “the time has come [to fulfill] the oath which I swore to Avraham that I will redeem his children.” But they possessed no <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> with which to be occupied in order to merit redemption as it is said “And you are naked and bare.” So He gave them two <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> [regarding] the blood of the [<font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font>] <font color=d50505>»</font>pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> and the blood of circumcision, for that night they circumcized themselves; as it is said: [“when I passed over you I saw] you wallowing in your bloods (pl.),” referring to two bloods (Pesach and circumcision). It is also said: “As for you, because of the blood of your covenant I released your prisoners from the pit which had no water” And because they (the B’nei Yisroel in Egypt) were immersed in idol worship, He said to them, “Draw and take [a lamb],” [meaning:] “withdraw your hands from idol worship and take unto yourselves a lamb to fulfill a <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah.<font color=d50505>«</font>” "

§§—2—§§ 12:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשמרת AND IT SHALL BE IN YOUR KEEPING (or watching) — This expresses the idea of examining, and the text therefore implies that it requires examination against any blemish during the four days before slaughter (Pesachim 96a). And why did He order that it should be taken from the flock four days before its slaughter, something which He did not command in respect to the paschal-lamb that was offered by succeeding generations? Rabbi Mathia, the son of Cheresh, said, in answer: Behold, it (Scripture) says, (Ezekiel 16:8) “And I passed over thee (an allusion to God’s passing over the Israelites in Egypt) and looked upon thee, and behold, thy time was the time of love” — there had arrived the time to fulfil the oath which I had sworn to Abraham to redeem his children. They, however, possessed no divine commands in which to engage in order that they should merit to be redeemed — as it is said (Ezekiel 16:7) “thou wast naked and bare” (i. e. bare of all merit earned through the fulfilment of God’s commands). He therefore gave them two commands, relating respectively to the blood of the paschal-lamb and the blood of the circumcision — for that night they circumcised themselves, as it is said (Ezekiel 16:6) “[When I passed over thee] I saw thee wallowing in thy bloods (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּדָמַיִךְ is plural)” i. e. in two kinds of blood. Further it states, (Zechariah 9:11) “As for thee, also, because of the blood of the covenant I released thy prisoners out of the pit wherin there is no water”. And yet another reply to this question is, that because they were sunk in idolatry and had no merit gained by the practice of a divine command, He said unto them, (v. 21) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכו “Draw” — withdraw your hands from idols; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקחו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צאן “and take unto yourselves a lamb” to fulfil a divine command (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:2:1)."

—3— **6. Und es sei euch zur Aufbewahrung,** der Ausdruck bedeutet hier soviel wie untersuchen; denn es muss vier Tage vor dem Schächten auf Leibesfehler hin untersucht werden. Warum hat Er aber sein Nehmen schon vier Tage vor dem Schächten angeordnet, was Er bei dem Pessachopfer der späteren Geschlechter nicht befohlen hat? Darauf sagte R. Matja b. Cheresch, siehe der Vers sagt (Jech. 16, 8), ich ging an dir vorüber und sah dich; und siehe, deine Zeit war die Zeit der Liebe; der Schwur war herangekommen, den ich Abraham geschworen, seine Kinder zu erlösen; aber es waren in ihrer Hand keine Gebote, um sich mit ihnen zu beschäftigen, um durch sie erlöst zu werden; denn so heißt es (dort V. 7), und du warst nackt und bloss; da gab Er ihnen zwei Gebote, das Blut des Pessachopfers und das Blut der Beschneidung; denn in jener Nacht beschnitten sie sich, so heißt es, befleckt von deinem Blute, doppeltem Blute (V. 6); ferner heißt es (Sech. 9, 11), auch von dir befreite ich ob des Blutes deines Bundes deine Gefangenen aus der wasserlosen Grube; und weil sie in Götzendienst versunken waren, sagte Er zu ihnen (V. 21), ziehet und nehmet euch, ziehet eure Hände von den Götzen weg und nehmet euch Lämmer für das Gebot (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:6:2,"**They shall slaughter it, etc.** But did they all slaughter [the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font>]?! But [the answer is that] from here we derive [the rule] that “the agent of a person is as himself.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:6:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושחטו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND THEY SHALL SLAUGHTER IT etc. — But did they all slaughter it (one alone did this on behalf of the company formed to eat that particular lamb; cf. Chullin 29b)? But we derive from this statement the legal principle that a man’s agent is as himself (this is derived from the fact that although one alone slaughtered the lamb on behalf of many, Scripture still states: they shall slaughter it) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:6:2; Kiddushin 41b)."

—3— **Und sie sollen es schachten,** Schächten denn alle? Nur, von hier geht hervor, dass der Bote des Menschen gleich ihm selbst ist (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:6:3,"**Community of Yisrael.** [It speaks here of three groups:] <font color=d50505>»</font>assembly, congregation<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>Yisrael.<font color=d50505>«</font> From here they (the Sages) derived that the congregational <font color=d50505>»</font>Pesachim<font color=d50505>«</font> are slaughtered in three groups, one followed by the other — once the first group had entered the doors of the [Temple] courtyard were closed, etc., as is cited in Pesachim (64 b). "

§§—2—§§ 12:6:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קהל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל it speaks here of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קהל assembly, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדה congregation, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל Israel, whilst one of these terms alone would have sufficed; hence they (the Rabbis) said: the paschal-lambs of the congregation (a term used in contrast to that which was sacrificed by an individual on the 14th of the second month; cf. Numbers 9:9—14) are to be slaughtered in three groups, one after the other — the first group entered and the doors of the court were closed, etc. as is to be found in the Talmud, Treatise Pesachim (64a)."

—3— **Versammlung der Gemeinde Israels,** von hier lernten sie heraus, dass sie Pessachopfer der Gemeinde in drei Abteilungen geschachtet werden sollen; eine kam nach der anderen; war die eine Abteilung hineingegangen, so wurden die Tore des Vorhofes geschlossen … wie in Pessachim (64a) steht. 

---

////—1—//// 12:6:4,"**In the afternoon.** The period of time after the sixth hour of the day is referred to as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בֵּין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעַרְבַּיִם because then the sun [begins] inclining towards where it sets so that it will become dark. As for the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בֵּין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעַרְבַּיִם, it seems to me: [refers to] those hours that are between when the day begins to darken (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרִיבַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיּוֹם). and when night begins to darken (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרִיבַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַיְלָה). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרִיבַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיּוֹם is at the start of the seventh hour, when the afternoon shadows begin extending, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרִיבַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַלַּיְלָה is at the start of the night. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֶרֶב means <font color=d50505>»</font>blackness<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>darkness<font color=d50505>«</font>, as in: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָרְבָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִֹמְחָה — “All joy has darkened” "

§§—2—§§ 12:6:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הערבים AT EVENTIDE — The period beginning at six hours (reckoning from six o’clock in the morning) and hence forward is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הערבים (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:6:5), because the sun then inclines in the direction of the place of its setting to become darkened. The expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הערבים appears to me to denote those hours which are between the darkening of the day and the darkening of the night. The darkening of the day is at the beginning of the seventh hour in the day, from when the shadows of evening decline; and the darkening of the night is at the commencement of the night (this period is therefore from noon until the beginning of night). The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערב is an expression for gloom and darkness, as in (Isaiah 24:11). “All joy is darkened"". "

—3— **Am Nachmittag,** vom Ende der sechsten Stunde an und weiter wird die Zeit «zwischen den Abenden» genannt, weil von da an die Sonne zur Stätte hin, wo sie am Abend untergeht, hinneigt; der Ausdruck «zwischen den Abenden» scheint mir jene Stunden zu bezeichnen, die zwischen dem Abend des Tages und dem Abend der Nacht liegen; der Abend des Tages ist am Anfang der siebten Stunde, wenn sich die Abendschatten herabsenken, und der Abend der Nacht ist am Anfang der Nacht; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערב bedeutet Dämmerung und Dunkel, wie (Jes. 24, 11), getrübt ist alle Freude. 

---

////—1—//// 12:7:1,**They shall take of its blood.** This refers to the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font> of “taking the blood”(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַבָּלָה). I might think that it is taken by hand; Therefore the Torah states: “[And you shall dip it in the blood] which is in the basin.”

§§—2—§§ 12:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולקחו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדם AND THEY SHALL TAKE OF THE BLOOD — This refers to the ritual reception of the blood. One might think that they must take it in the hand; therefore Scripture states, (v. 22) “[and ye shall dip it in the blood] which is in the basin (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:7:1)."

—3— **7. Und sie sollen von dem Blute nehmen,** das ist das Auffangen des Blutes; man hätte meinen können, mit der Hand, darum steht, das in der Schale ist (V. 22). 

---

////—1—//// 12:7:2,"**Doorposts.** They are the upright [doorposts], one on one side of the entrance and one on the other side. "

§§—2—§§ 12:7:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המזוזת THE SIDE POSTS — These are the upright posts, one on this side of the entrance and one on that side."

—3— **Pfosten,** das sind die aufrechten Balken, von denen sich einer auf dieser Seite des Eingangs und einer auf jener befindet. 

---

////—1—//// 12:7:3,"**The lintel.** This is the upper [post] against which the door bangs when it is closed, <font color=d50505>»</font>Lintier<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁקִיפָה means <font color=d50505>»</font>banging<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוֹל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֶה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִדָּף [which Onkelos translates as] <font color=d50505>»</font> a leaf beating against another<font color=d50505>«</font> or: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַבּוּרָה [is translated by Onkelos as] a bang (wound). "

§§—2—§§ 12:7:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשקוף THE LINTEL — This is the upper post upon which the door beats (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שוקף) when it is being closed; old French lintel. The expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שקף (from which <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקוף lintel is derived) denotes beating, as may be seen from the Targum on, (Leviticus 26:36) “the sound of a leaf that is beaten (by another)”, which Onkelos renders by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דשקיף; and from the Targum on, (Exodus 21:25) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַבּוּרָה “wheal” (a beaten spot), where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקופי is the rendering."

—3— **Oberschwelle,** das ist der obere Balken, gegen den die Tür schlägt, wenn man sie zumacht; Türschwelle in anderen Sprachen; das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שקיפה bedeutet schlagen, wie (Lev. 26, 36), der Laut eines verwehten Blattes übersetzt der Targum mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טרפא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דשקיף (25, 21) Beule mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקופי.

---

////—1—//// 12:7:4,"**Of the houses in which they will eat.** But not on the upper and side posts of the house [in which you store your] straw, [nor] of the stable (lit. the cattle house) in which people do not reside [or eat]. "

§§—2—§§ 12:7:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבתים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאכלו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהם ON THE HOUSES WHEREIN THEY SHALL EAT IT — and not upon the lintel and the doorposts which are in the place used for storing straw or in the stalls of oxen, in which people do not live and eat. (Cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:7:2 and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגהות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגר״<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>א thereon)."

—3— **An die Häuser, in denen sie es essen,** nicht an die Oberschwelle und die Pfosten eines Strohschobers oder eines Rinderstalles, in denen man nicht wohnt. 

---

////—1—//// 12:8:1,**The meat.** But not the sinews or the bones.

§§—2—§§ 12:8:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבשר AND THEY SHALL EAT] THE FLESH — but not the sinews and bones (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:8:1).

—3— **8. Das Fleisch,** und nicht Sehnen und Knochen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:8:2,**With bitter herbs.** Any bitter herb is call <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָרוֹר He commanded them to eat bitter herbs as a remembrance of “And they made their lives bitter.”

§§—2—§§ 12:8:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומצות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מררים AND UNLEAVENED BREAD WITH <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מררים — Every bitter herb is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרור. He commanded them to eat something bitter as a reminder of: (Exodus 1:14) “And they made their lives bitter” (Pesachim 116b).

—3— **Und ungesäuerte Brote mit Bitterkräutern,** jedes bittere Kraut wird <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרור genannt; Er befahl ihnen Bitteres zu essen zur Erinnerung an (1, 14), sie verbitterten ihr Leben. 

---

////—1—//// 12:9:1,**You must not eat it half-cooked.** Anything not sufficiently roasted is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָא (<font color=d50505>»</font>naye<font color=d50505>«</font>) in Arabic.

§§—2—§§ 12:9:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאכלו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא DO NOT EAT OF IT HALF-DONE — flesh that is not roasted as much as it should be is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא in the Arabic language (cf. Pesachim 41a).

—3— **9. Esset nicht halbgar davon,** was nicht genügend gebraten ist, nennt man im Arabischen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא.

---

////—1—//// 12:9:2,**Or boiled.** All this is part of the prohibition: “Do not eat [it].”

§§—2—§§ 12:9:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובשל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבשל NOR SODDEN AT ALL — All this belongs to the prohibition, “Do not eat of it” (The text is, therefore, to be translated as above, and not: Do not eat of it half done, but boiled etc. The words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאכלו are to be supplied before <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשל and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אש) (Pesachim 41b)."

—3— **Oder gekocht,** das gehört alles zum Verbot, esset nicht davon (Pess. 41a). 

---

////—1—//// 12:9:3,"**In water.** From where do we know other liquids [as well]? The Torah tells us <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּבָשֵׁל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְבֻשָּׁל (not just <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמְבוּשָּׁל), [to include] anything [boiled]. "

§§—2—§§ 12:9:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במים [BOILED] IN WATER — Whence may it be deduced that this prohibition extends to other liquids also? Because Scripture states here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובשל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבשל, “or boiled at all” (Pesachim 41a.)."

—3— **Im Wasser,** woher wissen wir andere Getränke? Darum steht doppelt: gekocht, gekocht, auf irgendeine Weise (Pess. 41a). 

---

////—1—//// 12:9:4,"**But only roasted over fire.** Above (in the previous verse) the Torah decrees it as a positive precept whereas, here, it adds a negative precept. I.e., “Do <font color=d50505>»</font>not<font color=d50505>«</font> eat from it unless roasted by fire.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:9:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אש BUT ROAST WITH FIRE — Above (in the preceding verse) Scripture promulgates the law regarding this in the form of an affirmative command; here it adds to that a negative command: Do not eat of it … except roasted by fire. (Consequently one who eats of it in in any manner except roasted by fire is liable to the punishment laid down for transgressing a negative command as well as to that for the infringement of a positive command) (Pesachim 41b).

—3— **Sondern nur am Feuer gebraten,** oben (V. 8) bestimmte er dies mit einem Gebot, und hier fügt er noch ein Verbot hinzu, esset nicht davon, außer am Feuer gebraten. 

---

////—1—//// 12:9:5,"**Its head with its knees.** He roasts it all as one with its head together with its legs together with its inner parts and he places its intestines inside after having rinsed them. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּרָעָיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְעַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קִרְבּוֹ is similar to [the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל of] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִבְאוֹתָם (v. 51) which is the same as <font color=d50505>»</font>with their hosts — <font color=d50505>«</font> just as they are (i.e., everyone). Here, too, [it means] just as it is, [he roasts] all its flesh, whole. "

§§—2—§§ 12:9:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כרעיו ITS HEAD WITH ITS LEGS — One roasts it all in one, with its head and with its legs and with its inward parts, and one places its entrails inside it after having rinsed them (Pesachim 74a). The expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרבו, is like the expression, (Exodus 6:26) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבאותם”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בצבאותם, “with their hosts”, which means, “just as they are” (every one of the Israelites). So, too, this phrase means: they shall roast the flesh just as it is — all its flesh, whole."

—3— **Seinen Kopf mit seinen Kniestücken,** man brate das Ganze in **einem** Stück mit dem Kopf und den Kniestücken und dem Inneren, die Eingeweide lege man, nachdem man sie abgewaschen, hinein (Pess. 74a). Der Ausdruck <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כרעיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרבו ist gleich dem Ausdruck (6,26) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בצבאותם = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבאותם, soviel diese sind; auch hier, soviel es ist, alles Fleisch vollständig. 

---

////—1—//// 12:10:1,"**Any of it left over until morning.** What does the Torah intend to teach by mentioning <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בֹּקֶר a second time? This is to add an [earlier] morning to the [previous] “morning,” because “morning” signifies the time of sunrise and the Torah intends to move the time back — that it is prohibited to eat [the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font> Pesach] after daybreak. That is the plain meaning. There is another [halachic] midrash: It teaches that it (the leftover Pesach) may not be burned on Yom Tov, but rather the next day, and this is how you ought to explain it: “And that which is left over on the first morning, on the following morning go and burn it. "

§§—2—§§ 12:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנתר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקר AND THAT WHICH REMAINETH OF IT UNTIL THE MORNING — What does Scripture intend to teach by stating <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקר a second time? It intends to add an earlier stage of morning to the stage of morning already mentioned: because the term morning usually signifies the period beginning with sun-rise, and Scripture here intends to advance the hour and forbid eating it even from the break of day. This is the explanation according to what the text really implies. And there is still another Halacha derived from it: it teaches that it is not to be burnt on the festival itself but on the following day, and this is how you must explain it: “[and ye shall not leave anything of it until the morning]”; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנתר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממנו “and as regards that which is left of it” unto that first morning (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקר), until the second morning shalt thou wait, and then shalt thou burn it (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:10; Pesachim 83b; Shabbat 24b)."

—3— **10. Und was davon bis zum Morgen übrigbleibt,** warum steht noch ein Mal, bis zum Morgen? Um noch einen Morgen zum ersten Morgen hinzuzufügen; unter Morgen versteht man erst von der Stunde des Sonnenaufganges an; der Vers will aber eine frühere Zeit angeben, dass nämlich schon vom Anbruch des Morgens an verboten ist, davon zu essen; dies ist nach dem einfachen Sinn; ferner ist noch ein anderer Midrasch da, dass der Vers lehrt, dass es nicht am Festtag, sondern erst am nächsten Tag verbrannt werde; und du musst den Vers so erklären, wenn am ersten Morgen davon übriggeblieben ist, warte bis zum zweiten Morgen und verbrenne es (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:11:1,**With your waist belted —** ready to travel.

§§—2—§§ 12:11:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתניכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חגרים YOUR LOINS GIRDED — i. e. prepared for the journey (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:11).

—3— **11. Eure Lenden gegürtet,** zur Reise bereit. 

---

////—1—//// 12:11:2,"**In haste.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּחִפָּזוֹן is] a term denoting rushing and hurrying, as in: “And David (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶחְפָּז) rushed to leave,” [or:] “which the Aramites threw away (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְחָפְזָם) in their rush.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:11:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחפזון — This is an expression denoting hurry and haste, similar to, (I Samuel 23:26) “And David made haste (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נחפז) to get away”; (2 Kings 7:15) ”which the Arameans had cast away in their haste"" "

—3— **Mit Eilfertigkeit,** bedeutet Eile und Schnelligkeit, wie (I Sam. 23, 26), David beeilte sich, hinwegzugehen; (II Kön. 7, 15) die Aram in ihrer Eile weggeworfen hatten. 

---

////—1—//// 12:11:3,"**It is a Pesach-offering to Adonoy.** The <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font> (sacrifice) is called “Pesach” on account of the <font color=d50505>»</font>skipping<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>passing over<font color=d50505>«</font>, because God skipped over the Israelite houses that were among the Egyptian houses and He would jump from Egyptian to Egyptian and the Israelite in the middle escaped. “[Therefore,] you perform all its (the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font>) service for the sake of God” in a manner of skipping and springing (i.e., hastily) as a remembrance of its (i.e., the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font>’s) name which is called “Pesach” (“skipping or passing over”). Also, the word [for Passover] <font color=d50505>»</font>Paske<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French] denotes <font color=d50505>»</font>stepping-over<font color=d50505>«</font>. "

§§—2—§§ 12:11:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לה IT IS THE PASSOVER OF THE LORD — The offering is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסח in allusion to the springing and passing over — because the Holy One, blessed be He, passed over the houses of the Israelites in between the houses of the Egyptians and sprang from Egyptian to Egyptian, whilst the Israelite who was between them escaped. The words “And ye shall eat it in haste for it is a 'springing’-offering to the Lord” imply: Ye, therefore, do every act of sacrificial service connected with it (with the Paschal lamb) in honour of Heaven (God) by way of springing and leaping over (i. e. hastily), as a reminder of its name, which is called, the “springing”-offering. In old French, (Provencal) too, Pascua (the term for the Passover festival) signifies stepping over."

—3— **Ein Überschreitungsopfer ist es dem Ewigen,** das Opfer wird Überschreitung genannt nach dem Überschreiten und Auslassen; denn der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, überschritt die Häuser Israels zwischen den Häusern der Ägypter und eilte von Ägypter zu Ägypter, während der Israelite in der Mitte verschont blieb; ihr aber vollbringet alle seine Gebote dem Ewigen zu Ehren; (andere Erklärung): im Überschreiten und Eilen zur Erinnerung an seinen Namen, da es Überschreitungsopfer genannt wird, auch pasca Passahfest bedeutet überschreiten. 

---

////—1—//// 12:12:1,**I will pass.** [This is meant allegorically:] <font color=d50505>»</font>as if<font color=d50505>«</font> He were a king who passes from place to place [but here it was] with one passing and in one instant that all were struck.

§§—2—§§ 12:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועברתי AND I WILL PASS — This is not to be taken literally, but is speaks of God as one speaks of a king who passes from place to place (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:12:1) but in this case all were punished at a single passage and in one moment."

—3— **12. Ich werde ziehen,** wie ein König, der von Ort zu Ort zieht, bei einem Hindurchziehen und in einem Augenblick werden alle geschlagen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:12:2,**Every first born in the land of Egypt.** [This includes] also other first-born who were in Egypt. From where do we derive that also Egyptian first-born who were in other places [were struck]? Scripture tells us: “To the One that struck the Egyptians through their first-born”

§§—2—§§ 12:12:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים ALL THE FIRSTBORN IN THE LAND OF EGYPT — also the first-born of other nations who happened then to be in Egypt. And whence may we deduce that the first-born of the Egyptians who happened to be in other countries also died? From what Scripture states: (Psalms 136:10) “To Him that smote the Egyptians in their first-born” (an unqualified statement) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:12:2).

—3— **Alle Erstgeborenen im Lande Mizraim,** auch fremde Erstgeborenen, die in Mizraim sind; und woher weiß ich, auch die Erstgeborenen Ägyptens an anderen Orten? Darum heißt es (Ps. 136, 10), der Ägypten schlug an seinen Erstgeborenen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:12:3,"**From man to beast.** [From] him who first began sinning, it is from him that punishment begins. "

§§—2—§§ 12:12:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאדם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהמה FROM MAN TO BEAST — He who first began the wrongdoing, from him began the punishment (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:12:2)."

—3— **Von Mensch bis Vieh,** bei demjenigen, der zuerst gesündigt hatte begann die Strafe (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:12:4,"**And against all the gods of Egypt.** [If it was] of wood it would rot, [if it was] of metal it would melt and be poured onto the ground. "

§§—2—§§ 12:12:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים AND AGAINST ALL THE GODS OF EGYPT [WILL I EXECUTE JUDGEMENTS] — An idol of wood rotted, and one of metal melted and was poured out on the ground (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:12:3))."

—3— **Und an allen Götzen der Ägypter,** die von Holz faulten, die von Metall schmolzen und ergossen sich zur Erde. 

---

////—1—//// 12:12:5,"**I will execute judgments, I am Adonoy.** “I myself, not through an agent.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:12:5," '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שפטים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה I WILL EXECUTE JUDGEMENTS, I, THE LORD — I, Myself, and not by means of a messenger (Pesikta Zotarta)."

—3— **Werde ich Strafgerichte vollziehen,** ich, der Ewige, ich selbst und nicht durch einen Boten (Mech.) 

---

////—1—//// 12:13:1,**The blood will be for you as a sign.** “As a sign to you” but not as a sign to others. From here [we derive] that they put blood only on the inside [of the doorposts].

§§—2—§§ 12:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאת AND THE BLOOD SHALL BE UNTO YOU FOR A SIGN — it shall be to you for a sign, and not to others for a sign (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:13:1). From this we may learn that they put the blood only inside their houses."

—3— **13. Und das Blut sei euch zum Zeichen,** euch zum Zeichen und nicht anderen zum Zeichen; von hier lernen wir, dass sie das Blut nur von innen anbrachten. 

---

////—1—//// 12:13:2,"**I will see the blood.** [Surely] everything is revealed to Him! But [the explanation is:] God said, “I will set My attention to take note that you are occupied in the performance of My commands, and thereby I will pass over you. "

§§—2—§§ 12:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראיתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדם AND WHEN I SEE THE BLOOD — But surely everything is manifest to Him and He therefore did not need to look whether the blood had been put on the door-posts? But the meaning is: God says, I will set My eye (my attention) to take notice of the fact that you are engaged in the performance of My commands — then will I pass over you (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:13:1)."

—3— **Und ich werde das Blut sehen,** alles ist vor Ihm offenbar; nur sagte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, ich richte meine Augen darauf, um zu sehen, wie ihr euch mit meinen Geboten beschäftigt, und schreite über euch hinweg (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:13:3,"**And I will pass over.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וִּפָסַחְתִּי means:] I will take pity (or: <font color=d50505>»</font>spare<font color=d50505>«</font>). Similar to this is: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּסוֹחַ) taking pity and sparing.” But I say that all terms relating to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּסִיחָה have the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>skipping<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>jumping<font color=d50505>«</font>, [Thus] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפָסַחְתִּי means that He skipped from the Israelite houses to the Egyptian houses, for they dwelt amongst each other. Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פּוֹסְחִים) jumping between two opinions” Similarly all lame people [are called] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּיסְחִים [because] they walk as though they were jumping. This, too, is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּסוֹחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִמְלִיט — “He skips over and saves it (Yerushalayim) from among those being killed.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:13:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופסחתי — This signifies I WILL SPARE you; similar to this is, (Isaiah 31:5) “Sparing (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסוח) and delivering”. (This is the explanation of Menachem ben Seruk). But I say that wherever the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסח occurs it is an expression for leaping and springing over, so that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופסחתי here denotes that He sprang from the houses of the Israelites when He reached them, without having entered them, to the houses of the Egyptians — for they (the Egyptians and the Israelites) dwelt one next to the other. Of a like import is, (1 Kings 18:21) “How long will ye leap (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פוסחים) upon two twigs?” So, too, all <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסחים lame people walk as though they were springing, and are therefore termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסחים. This, too, is the meaning of, (Isaiah 31:5) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמליט “He springs over him and delivers him” from amongst those who are being killed."

—3— **Und überschreite,** verschone; ähnlich (Jes. 31, 5), überschreiten und entkommen lassen; ich meine, überall bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסח eigentlich überschreiten und auslassen; ich **überschreite,** Er eilte über die Häuser Israels hinweg zu den Häusern der Ägypter; denn sie wohnten untereinander; ebenso (I Kön. 18, 21), hinkt ihr auf zwei Meinungen; denn alle Lahmen gehen wie Springende; ebenso ist auch oben überschreiten und entkommen lassen (Jes. 31,5) = dass Er zwischen denen, die getötet werden, andere überschreitet und entkommen lässt. 

---

////—1—//// 12:13:4,**There will be no plague against you.** But it will be among the Egyptians. If an Egyptian was in a Israelite house I might have thought that he would be saved. The Torah therefore says: “There will be no plague against <font color=d50505>»</font>you.<font color=d50505>«</font>”

§§—2—§§ 12:13:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגף AND THE INFLICTION SHALL NOT BE UPON YOU — but it will be upon the Egyptians. — In the case that an Egyptian was in an Israelite’s house one might think that he would escape! Therefore Scripture says: “and the infliction shall not be upon you”, but it shall be upon the Egyptians who happen to be in your houses! In the case that an Israelite was in an Egyptians house, I might understand from this that he would be smitten just the same as he (the Egyptian)! Therefore Scripture says, “and the affliction shall not be upon you”, wherever you may happen to be (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:13:2)."

—3— **Dass keine Plage unter euch sei,** aber sie wird unter den Ägyptern sein; siehe, wenn ein Ägypter im Hause eines Israeliten war, hätte ich gemeint, er würde gerettet werden; darum heißt es, es wird keine Plage unter euch sein, aber unter den Ägyptern in eueren Häusern; siehe, wenn ein Israelit im Hause eines Ägypters war, hätte ich gemeint, er würde gleich ihm geschlagen werden, darum heißt es, es wird keine Plage unter euch sein (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:14:1,**A remembrance —** for [future] generations.

§§—2—§§ 12:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לזכרון [AND THIS DAY SHALL BE UNTO YOU] FOR A MEMORIAL — in future generations (i. e. in the future).

—3— **14. Zum Andenken,** für spätere Geschlechter. 

---

////—1—//// 12:14:2,"**You shall celebrate it.** The day which is for you a remembrance, you shall celebrate it. But we have not yet heard which day is the day of remembrance. The Torah therefore tells us: “Remember this day on which you left,” which teaches us that the day of the departure is the day of remembrance. And on which day did they depart? The Torah tells us: “On the day following the [<font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font>] <font color=d50505>»</font>Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> they departed.” Thus, you must say that the fifteenth day of Nissan is a Yom Tov for on the eve of the fifteenth they ate the [<font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font>] <font color=d50505>»</font>Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> and in the morning they departed. "

§§—2—§§ 12:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחגתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו AND YE SHALL CELEBRATE IT AS A FEAST— Scripture states: the day that is to serve you as a memorial, that day thou shalt celebrate as a feast, but we have not yet heard which is the day that is to be a memorial; therefore Scripture says (Exodus 13:3) “Remember (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכור) this day in which ye went out” and this teaches us that the day of the Exodus itself is the day which is to be the memorial (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכרון). Now, on which day did they go forth? Scripture states, (Numbers 33:3) “On the morrow after the Passover-sacrifice they went forth”. Thus you must say that the day of the fifteenth of Nisan is that of the Feast, for on the night of the fifteenth (i. e. what we would term the night following the day of the fourteenth) they ate the Passover-sacrifice, and consequently on the next morning they went forth (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:14:1)."

—3— **Und feiert ihn,** den Tag, der dir zum Andenken sei, sollst du feiern; wir haben aber noch nicht gehört, welcher der Tag des Andenkens sei; darum heißt es (13,3), gedenket diesesTages, an dem ihr ausgezogen seid; daraus lernen wir, dass der Tag des Auszugs der Tag des Gedenkens; und an welchem Tage zogen sie aus? Darum heißt es (Num. 33, 3), am Tage nach dem Pessachopfer zogen sie aus; daraus ergibt sich, dass der 15. Nissan der Festtag; denn in der Nacht zum 15. assen sie das Pessachopfer, und am Morgen zogen sie aus (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:14:3,"**Throughout your generations, etc.** I might conclude that the minimum of “generations” is two. The Torah therefore says: “As a statute forever shall you celebrate it.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:14:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדרתיכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ [YE SHALL CELEBRATE IT] FOR YOUR GENERATIONS etc. — I might understand from this that it need be celebrated only for the minimum of a plurality of generations, viz., two; therefore Scripture goes on to state “an ordinance for ever shall ye celebrate it as feast” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:14:3)."

—3— **Für euere Geschlechter,** daraus hätte ich nur die kleinste Mehrzahl, nämlich zwei Geschlechter, verstanden; darum heißt es, als **ewiges** Gesetz sollt ihr ihn feiern (Mech.) 

---

////—1—//// 12:15:1,**Seven days.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁבְעַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמִים denotes] a <font color=d50505>»</font>seiteine<font color=d50505>«</font> (Old French) of days

§§—2—§§ 12:15:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים denotes a septaine (old French) of days.

—3— **15. Sieben Tage,** eine Siebenheit von Tagen. 

---

////—1—//// 12:15:2,"**You must eat matzos for seven days.** Whereas elsewhere it states: “Six days shall you eat <font color=d50505>»</font>matzos;<font color=d50505>«</font>” this teaches that on the seventh day of Pesach, it is not obligatory to eat <font color=d50505>»</font>matzoh<font color=d50505>«</font>, [the] only [obligation] is not to eat <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font>. From where do we derive that the six other days are also voluntary? The Torah says: “Seven days.” This is one of the (thirteen) methods [through which] the Torah [is expounded]: Something that was included in a general rule and was singled out to teach [something new] was not singled out to teach only about itself but rather to teach [something new] concerning the rule as a whole [In this case it applies thus] just as [eating matzoh] the seventh day is voluntary so, too, are the [other] six days voluntary. You might think that the first night is also voluntary. Therefore, the Torah states: “In the evening [of the first day] you shall eat matzos.” Scripture [thereby] establishes it as an obligation. "

§§—2—§§ 12:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאכלו SEVEN DAYS SHALL YE EAT UNLEAVENED BREAD — But in another passage it slates: (Deuteronomy 16:8) “Six days shalt thou eat unleavened bread”! This teaches regarding the seventh day of the Passover that it is not obligatory to eat unleavened bread on it, but only this is required viz., that one should not eat leavened food. Whence may we derive that the other six days, too, are optinal as regards the eating of unleavened bread? From what Scripture states: “Six days [shalt thou eat unnleavened bread]”. For the following is a Rule by which the Torah may be expounded: Anything that is included in a general statement and goes out (i. e. Scripture singles it out) from this general statement for the purpose of teaching something, does not go out from it in order to teach something regarding itself alone but it goes out from it to teach something about everything that is included in the general statement. Now the seventh day is included in the general statement “Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread”, and in the text “Six days shall thou eat unleavened bread” it has left the general statement. How is it with the seventh day? It is optional as regards the eating of unleavened bread, (as explained in the earlier portion of this comment)! This, according to the above rule, applies also to everything that was included in the general statement i. e. to the whole seven days, and therefore the other six days are also optional in this respect! One might think that the first night of the Passover is also optional (since it is part of the first day when as we have just shown the eating of unleavened bread is optional), therefore Scripture states, (v. 18) “at evening ye shall eat unleavened bread” Scripture thus fixes it as obligatory for that night (Pesachim 120a)."

—3— **Sieben Tage sollt ihr Mazzot essen,** und an anderer Stelle (Deut. 16,8) sagt er, sechs Tage sollst du Mazzot essen; das lehrt, dass es am siebten Tage Pessach keine Pflicht ist, Mazzot zu essen, nur darf man an ihm nichts Gesäuertes essen; woher wissen wir, dass die Mazza auch an den ersten sechs Tagen freiwillig ist? Darum steht hier, sieben Tage; denn dies ist eine Regel in der Torah: Wenn etwas zur Regel gehörte und aus der Regel heraustritt, um eine neue Vorschrift zu lehren, so lehrt es diese Vorschrift nicht sich allein, sondern für alle in der Regel enthaltenen Beispiele; demnach so wie die Mazza am siebten Tag freiwillig, so ist sie auch an den sechs übrigen freiwillig; ich hätte nun meinen können, dass sie auch in der ersten Nacht freiwillig sei, darum heißt es (V. 18), am Abend** sollt ihr Mazzot essen; dieser Vers macht die Mazza zur Pflicht (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:15:3,"**But before the first day you must remove leaven.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּיּוֹם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָרִאשׁוֹן means:] from the day before Yom Tov, and it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רִאשׁוֹן (lit. <font color=d50505>»</font>first<font color=d50505>«</font>) because it comes <font color=d50505>»</font>ahead<font color=d50505>«</font> of the seven days. We find that that which precedes is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רִאשׁוֹן as in “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲרִאשׁוֹן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָדָם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּוָּלֵד” [which means] “Were you born before Adam?” But maybe it <font color=d50505>»</font>does<font color=d50505>«</font> refer to the first of the seven days? The Torah therefore states: “Do not slaughter upon <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz,<font color=d50505>«</font>” [meaning:] “Do not slaughter the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> while there is still <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> [in your possession]. "

§§—2—§§ 12:15:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הראשון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשביתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאור EVEN THE FIRST DAY YE SHALL HAVE PUT AWAY LEAVEN — This means on the eve of the festival ye shall put it away — and that day is termed “the first (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הראשון) day” because it is immediately before the seven days: We find in another passage, too, that a thing which precedes another is termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשון, as in (Job. 15:7) “Wast thou born <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשון Adam”, i. e. wast thou born before Adam? — But perhaps the text it referring only to the first of the seven days (i. e. the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשון has its ordinary meaning of first, and leavened food must be removed on the first day of the Festival and not on the preceding day)! Scripture, however, states: (Exodus 34:25) “Thou shalt not offer together with leaven [the blood of my sacrifice]” — i. e. thou shalt not slaughter the Passover sacrifice whilst leavened bread is still existent (but the Passover sacrifice was slaughtered on the afternoon of the day before the first day of the Festival; consequently all leavened food must have been removed by the hour of slaughter)(Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:15:4; cf. Pesachim 5a)."

—3— **Jedoch am Tage vorher sollt ihr den Sauerteig fortschaffen,** am Erew Jomtob; dieser wird <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשון genannt, weil er den sieben vorangeht; wir finden, dass der vorangehende <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשון genannt wird, wie (Job 15,7), bist du vor Adam geboren worden; vielleicht ist aber der erste der sieben gemeint? Darum steht (34,25), schlachte nicht bei Gesäuertem, schlachte nicht das Pessach, solange noch Gesäuertes vorhanden ist (Mech.) 

---

////—1—//// 12:15:4,**That soul.** When [that soul] has its full faculties and knowledge. This excludes [from <font color=d50505>»</font>kares<font color=d50505>«</font>] one who is forced.

§§—2—§§ 12:15:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנפש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ההיא [FOR WHOSOEVER EATETH ANYTHING LEAVENED..] THAT SOUL [SHALL BE CUT OFF] — if it eats unleavened bread when it is in its will (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפש) and with its full consciousness — this would exclude one who does so being under some external compulsion (force majeure) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:15:5).

—3— **Jene Person,** wenn sie über ihre Person und ihren Willen verfügt; das schließt den aus, der dazu gezwungen wurde. 

---

////—1—//// 12:15:5,"**From Yisrael.** It would seem that it is cut off from Yisrael and goes off to another nation. The Torah therefore tells us elsewhere: “[And the soul will be cut off] <font color=d50505>»</font>from My presence,<font color=d50505>«</font>” [i.e.,] “from anywhere which is My domain.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:15:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מישראל [THAT SOUL SHALL BE CUT OFF] FROM ISRAEL — I might understand from this that he shall be cut off from Israel and that he will be able to betake himself to another nation! Scripture therefore states in another passage, (Leviticus 22:3) “[that soul shall be cut off] from my presence” — in every place that is My territory (i. e. everywhere) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:15:5)."

—3— **Aus Israel,** daraus könnte ich entnehmen, sie soll aus Israel verstoßen werden und sich zu einem anderen Volke begeben; darum heißt es an anderer Stelle (Lev. 22, 3), **vor mir,** an jedem Orte, der mir gehört (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:16:1,"**A holy assembly.** The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְרָא is an infinitive — “you must proclaim its holiness by means of eating, drinking, and [special] clothing.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדש — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקרא is an infinitive and the translation is, “And on the first day there shall be “a calling it holy”, which implies: call it holy in regard to eating and drinking and raiment (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:16:1)."

—3— **16. Heilige Berufung,**<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקרא ist ein Hauptwort; nenne ihn heilig bezüglich Speise und Trank und Kleidüng (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:16:2,**[No work] shall be done on them.** Even by others.

§§—2—§§ 12:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהם NO WORK SHALL BE DONE ON THEM, even by the agency of others (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:16:2)."

—3— **Darf nicht an ihnen verrichtet werden,** auch nicht durch Fremde (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:16:3,"**That alone.** (I might think that you may [prepare food] for non-Jews as well. Therefore the Torah states: “That alone may be done <font color=d50505>»</font>for yourselves<font color=d50505>«</font>” — for yourselves and not for non-Jews.) [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוּא stresses] it (the work itself), but not the preparations for it which can be done before Yom Tov. "

§§—2—§§ 12:16:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבדו THAT ALONE — that and not such acts preliminary to it (to the preparation of food) as it was possible to do on the eve of the Festival (Beitzah 28b).

—3— **Das allein** (ich hätte meinen können, auch für Nichtjuden; darum heißt es, das allein darf für **euch** verrichtet werden, aber nicht für Nichtjuden); **das,** aber nicht die Vorbereitungen dazu, die man schon am Erew Jomtob verrichten konnte. 

---

////—1—//// 12:16:4,"**Every person.** Even for an animal [it is permitted to prepare food]. You might think for non-Jews as well, therefore, the Torah states <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָכֶם — <font color=d50505>»</font>for you<font color=d50505>«</font>. "

§§—2—§§ 12:16:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפש BY EVERY BEING — even by cattle. One might think that also food may be prepared for non-Israelites! Scripture however states, (in this verse) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם (i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם) for every being that belongs to you (the responsibility for feeding which belongs to you) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:16:4)."

—3— **Von jeder Seele,** auch vom Vieh; ich hätte meinen können, auch vom Nichtjuden; darum steht, nur (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:17:1,"**You must be vigilant regarding the matzos —** so that they do not become <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font>. From this [the Sages] said: “If [the dough] has begun to rise pat it with cold moisture.” Rabbi Yashia says: “Do not read it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמַּצּוֹת, but, rather, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמִּצְו‍<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ֹת (i.e., the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font>) [to teach us that] just as we hasten [in baking the <font color=d50505>»</font>matzos<font color=d50505>«</font>] so as not to permit the <font color=d50505>»</font>matzos<font color=d50505>«</font> to become <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> so, too, we must not permit the “leavening” of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> but, rather, if a chance [to fulfill a mitzvah] presents itself to you, do it immediately. "

§§—2—§§ 12:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושמרתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המצות AND YE SHALL WATCH THE UNLEAVENED BREAD that it shall not reach the stage of becoming leavened; hence the Rabbis said, if it (the dough) is rising (a sign that the leavening process is setting in) she (the woman kneading the dough) polishes it with cold water (i. e. she slaps the dough with hands dipped in cold water). Rabbi Josiah said: Do not read “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המַּצּוֹת”, the unleavened bread, but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמִּצְוֹת “[ye shall watch] the commandements” — just as we may not cause the unleavened bread to become leavened by letting the dough remain in its raw state too long so we may not let the commandment become “leavened” by waiting too long before we perform it; but if it (a commandment) comes to your hand, perform it immediately (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:17:1)."

—3— **17. Hütet die Mazzot,** dass sie nicht zur Säuerung kommen; von hier lernt man, dass man den Teig, wenn er anschwillt, mit kaltem Wasser beschlage; R. Joschija sagt, lies nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצות sondern <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בי^<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וית; wie man die Mazzot nicht sauer werden lassen darf, so darf man auch die Gebote nicht sauer werden lassen; sondern erfülle es sofort, sobald ein solches in deine Hand kommt (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:17:2,**You must preserve this day —** from doing <font color=d50505>»</font>melachah<font color=d50505>«</font> (work prohibited on Yom Tov).

§§—2—§§ 12:17:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושמרתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה AND YE SHALL GUARD THIS DAY — against work, "

—3— **Und hütet diesen Tag,** vor Arbeit. 

---

////—1—//// 12:17:3,"**For your generations it is an eternal statute.** Since “generations” and “an eternal statute” was not said in regard to working, but only regarding the celebration of the festival, it is, therefore, repeated here, so that you may not say that the negative prohibition: “No work shall be done” was not said for future generations and only for that generation. "

§§—2—§§ 12:17:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדרתיכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חקת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עולם THROUGHOUT YOUR GENERATIONS, AN ORDINANCE FOR EVER — Because the expressions, “[throughout your] generations”, and “an ordinance for ever” have not been mentioned in connection with the prohibition of work but only in reference to the celebration of the Festival (v. 14), it is therefore repeated here in order that you should not say: the prohibition, (v. 16) “no work shall be done”, was not spoken for future generations but for that generation alone to whom the words were addressed."

—3— **Für eure Geschlechter als ewige Satzung,** weil bis jetzt Geschlechter und ewige Satzung nicht beim Verbot der Arbeit, sondern nur bei der Feier des Festes (V. 14) vorgekommen ist, darum wiederholt er es noch einmal hier, damit du nicht sagest, das Verbot, es darf keinerlei Arbeit verrichtet werden, beziehe sich nicht auf die späteren Geschlechter, sondern nur auf jenes Geschlecht. 

---

////—1—//// 12:18:1,"**Until the twenty-first day.** Why is this said — has it not already said: “seven days?” Since it has stated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמִים — <font color=d50505>»</font>days<font color=d50505>«</font> from where do we derive “nights” as well? Therefore, the Torah states: until the [twenty]-first, etc., "

§§—2—§§ 12:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האחד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועשרים UNTIL THE TWENTY-FIRST DAY — Why is this stated? Has it not already been stated, (v. 15) “Seven days [shall ye eat unleavened bread]” (beginning on the fifteenth day, as Rashi shows in his comment on v. 14 and therefore terminating on the twenty-first)? The answer is: Since it is said in that verse, “[seven] days [shalt thou eat unleavened bread]”, we may ask whence do we derive that the prohibition of eating unleavened bread extends also to the nights of these seven days? Scripture therefore states here, “[Ye shall eat unleavened bread] until the twenty-first-day in the evening” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:18)."

—3— **18. Bis zum 21.,** warum steht das, da es doch bereits heißt, sieben Tage? Weil **Tage** steht, hätte ich die Nächte nicht gewusst; darum steht, bis zum 21…. (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:19:1,"**Leaven may not be found in your homes.** From where do we know [that this applies] to [your properties] outside your house? The Torah therefore states: “[Leaven may not be seen] in <font color=d50505>»</font>all<font color=d50505>«</font> your boundaries.” Then why does the Torah state: “in your houses?” [This is to teach that] just as your house is within your dominion so, too, [does the prohibition of having <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font>] “within your boundaries” [apply only to that] which is within your dominion. This would exclude a non-Jew’s <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> which is [stored] by a Jew for which the Jew accepted no responsibility "

§§—2—§§ 12:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבתיכם NO LEAVEN SHALL BE FOUND IN YOUR HOUSES — Whence may we derive that this applies also to the external properties which belong to you? From what Scripture states, (Exodus 13:7) “[Neither shall leaven be seen with thee] in all thy boundaries”. If this be so, why then need Scripture specify here “in your houses” (since this term is comprised in the more general term “in all thy boundaries”)? It is for the purpose of defining the latter term through the former. How is it the case of thy house? Everything contained in it is under thy control! So, too, the term “[leaven in all] your boundaries” means only such leaven as is in your boundaries and under your control, thereby excluding such leaven belonging to a non-Israelite as is deposited with an Israelite but for which he has accepted no responsibility (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:19:2)."

—3— **19. Darf nicht in euren Häusern gefunden werden,** woher weiß ich, auch nicht im Gebiete außerhalb des Hauses? Darum steht (13, 7), in deinem ganzen Gebiete; was lehrt nun, in euren Häusern? Wie dein Haus dir gehört, so auch dein Gebiet, das dir gehört; damit ist das Gesäuerte des Nichtjuden ausgeschlossen, das sich beim Israeliten befindet und für das dieser keine Haftpflicht übernommen hat (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:19:2,"**For whoever eats chametz.** [This verse comes] to provide the punishment of <font color=d50505>»</font>kares<font color=d50505>«</font> for [the eating of] leaven (<font color=d50505>»</font>yeast<font color=d50505>«</font>) [on Pesach]. But has it not already provided for the <font color=d50505>»</font>kares<font color=d50505>«</font> punishment regarding [the eating of] <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font>?! But [this was done so] that you should not say for <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> (bread) which is fit to eat, a punishment is provided, [whereas for] yeast, which is not fit to eat, he should not be punished. And [if the Torah] had provided punishment for yeast and not [mentioned] punishment for <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font>, I would have said that [for] <font color=d50505>»</font>yeast<font color=d50505>«</font>, which renders other foods <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> a punishment is provided, whereas <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> which does not render other foods <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> one should not be punished for [eating] it. Therefore, both [<font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> and yeast] are mentioned. "

§§—2—§§ 12:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחמצת FOR WHOSOEVER EATETH THAT WHICH LEAVENETH — The purpose of this statement is to mention the punishment of excision for eating <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאור (a synonym for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחמצת, which is something that causes the leavening process to set in, such as yeast etc., whilst <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמץ denotes food which has become leavened). But has not Scripture already mentioned this punishment for eating leavened food (v. 15)? But the mention of this punishment is repeated here in connection with leaven <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחמצת, in order that you should not argue as follows: For eating leavened food — a thing which is fitted to be eaten — it mentions this punishment, but if one eats leaven itself — which is something not fitted to be eaten — one should not be punished for it. If, however, it had mentioned the punishment for eating leaven but had not mentioned the punishment for eating leavened food, I might have said: For eating leaven — a thing which has the property of making other things leavened — it mentions the punishment, but if one eats leavened food — which is something that does not possess the property of making other things leavened — one should not be punished for it; therefore they are both mentioned (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:19:3; cf. Beitzah 7b)."

—3— **Denn jeder, der Gesäuertes isst;** damit bestraft er auch für Sauerteig mit Ausrottung; er hat zwar für Gesäuertes diese Strafe bereits ausgesprochen; nur, damit du nicht sagest, für Gesäuertes, das zum Essen geeignet ist, straft er; für Sauerteig aber, der nicht genießbar ist, soll der Betreffende nicht gestraft werden. Wenn er wieder für Sauerteig gestraft und für Gesäuertes die Strafe nicht ausgesprochen hätte, so hätte ich gesagt, für Sauerteig, der anderes weitersäuert, hat er gestraft; für Gesäuertes aber, das anderes nicht mehr säuert, soll der Betreffende nicht gestraft werden, darum steht beides (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:19:3,"**A proselyte or a native-born in the land.** Since the miracle [of the Exodus from Egypt] was experienced [exclusively] by the Israelites, it was necessary to [specifically] include the converts. "

§§—2—§§ 12:19:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בגר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובאזרח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ WHETHER HE BE A STRANGER OR A NATIVE OF THE LAND — Because the miracle of the Exodus was performed for Israel it is necessary expressly to include the stranger who has become an Israelite in this command (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:19:4).

—3— **Unter den Fremden und den Eingeborenen des Landes,** weil das Wunder Israel geschah, hatte er nötig, die Fremden hinzuzufügen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:20:1,**You must not eat chametz.** This is the warning against the eating of yeast.

§§—2—§§ 12:20:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחמצת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאכלו THAT WHICH LEAVENETH YE SHALL NOT EAT — Here we have the prohibition regarding eating <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאור (that which causes food to become leavened).

—3— **20. Gesäuertes esset nicht,** ist ein Verbot für den Genuss von Sauerteig; **alles** Gesäuerte, fügt noch seine Vermischung hinzu. 

---

////—1—//// 12:20:2,**Anything that is chametz.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּל] includes its mixture [as well].

§§—2—§§ 12:20:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחמצת [YE SHALL NOT EAT] ANYTHING THAT LEAVENETH — The use of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל, anything (even in the smallest degree), is intended to include food with which it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאור) is mixed (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:20:1)."

—3— **In allen euren Wohnsitzen esset Mazzot,** das kommt zu lehren, Mazzot, die in allen euren Wohnsitzen gegessen werden dürfen, und schließt den zweiten Zehnten und die Brote des Dankopfers aus, die nicht in allen Wohnsitzen, sondern nur in Jeruschalajim gegessen werden dürfen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:20:3,"**In all your dwellings you shall eat matzos.** This comes to teach that [the <font color=d50505>»</font>matzoh<font color=d50505>«</font>] <font color=d50505>»</font>must be fit<font color=d50505>«</font> to be eaten anywhere you reside This excludes <font color=d50505>»</font>Maaser Sheni<font color=d50505>«</font> and the breads of the thanksgiving <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font> (which may not be eaten in all places of residence, but only in Jerusalem.). "

§§—2—§§ 12:20:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מושבתיכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאכלו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצות IN ALL YOUR HABITATIONS SHALL YE EAT UNLEAVENED BREAD — This statement is intended to teach that it (the unleavened bread which you must eat on the first night of Passover) must be fitted to be eaten in all your habitations, thus excluding leavened bread which forms “the second tithe” and the unleavened meal cakes brought with the thanksgiving offering (which might be eaten only within the walls of Jerusalem) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:20:2)."


---

////—1—//// 12:21:1,**Draw.** Whoever owns lambs shall draw one of his own —

§§—2—§§ 12:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכו DRAW OUT — He who has sheep let him draw one out from his own, "

—3— **21. Nehmet,** wer selbst Schafe hat, nehme von den seinigen; **und erwerbet,** wer keine hat, kaufe auf dem Markte (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:21:2,**Or purchase.** Whoever does not own [lambs] shall acquire one from the marketplace.

§§—2—§§ 12:21:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקחו OR TAKE, and he who has no sheep let him purchase one in the market (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:21:2)."

—3— **Für eure Familien,** ein Lamm für jedes Haus der Väter. 

---

////—1—//// 12:21:3,**For your families.** A lamb for each household.

§§—2—§§ 12:21:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשפחתיכם [A LAMB] ACCORDING TO YOUR FAMILIES — this corresponds to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבות a lamb for the house of their fathers in verse 3.


---

////—1—//// 12:22:1,**Hyssop.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵזוֹב is a vegetable that has thin stems.

§§—2—§§ 12:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אזוב HYSSOP — a kind of herb which has thin stalks.

—3— **22. Ysop,** eine Art Kraut, das Stengel hat. 

---

////—1—//// 12:22:2,**A bunch of Hyssop.** Three stalks are called an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲגדָּה — <font color=d50505>»</font>a bunch<font color=d50505>«</font>.

§§—2—§§ 12:22:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אגדת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אזוב A BUNCH OF HYSSOP — three stalks are called a bunch (cf. Shabbat 109b; Sukkah 13a).

—3— **Bündel Ysop,** drei Stengel werden ein Bündel genannt (Schabbat 109b). 

---

////—1—//// 12:22:3,"**Which is in the basin.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּסָּף means:] <font color=d50505>»</font>in a vessel<font color=d50505>«</font>, as in: (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סִּפּוֹת) the pitcherlike vessels of silver.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:22:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסף means WHICH IS IN THE VESSEL, as in (2 Kings 12:14) “basins (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ספות) of gold.”"

—3— **Das in der Schale ist,** im Gefäss, wie (II Kön. 12, 14), silberne Schalen. 

---

////—1—//// 12:22:4,"**With some of the blood in the basin.** Why does [the verse] repeat (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּסָּף)? So that you should not say that one dipping [of the hyssop in the blood is sufficient] for the three sprinklings; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּסָּף is therefore written again so that each and every sprinkling should be from the blood which is in the basin — for every touching, a [separate] dipping. "

§§—2—§§ 12:22:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסף WITH THE BLOOD WHICH IS IN THE BASIN — Why does Scripture repeat this (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסף) again? In order that you should not say that one dipping of the hyssop in the basin suffices for the three sprinklings, therefore it is again stated: “[you shall touch the lintel…] “with the blood that is in the basin”, to show that each separate sprinkling must be with the blood which is in the basin — for each touching of the lintel and doorposts there must be a separate dipping (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:22:1)."

—3— **Von dem Blute in der Schale,** warum wiederholt er dies noch einmal? Damit du nicht sagest, ein Eintauchen genüge für die drei Gaben; darum steht noch einmal, in der Schale, es sei jede Gabe von dem Blute in der Schale, für jedes Hinbringen ein Eintauchen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:22:5,"**And all of you, let [no man] go out, etc.** This teaches that once dominion is given to the destroyer to do harm, he does not distinguish between a righteous person and an evil person. And night is when the destroying angels have dominion, as it is said: “[Then night comes] in which move about all the beasts of the forest.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:22:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תצאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND NONE OF YOU SHALL GO OUT etc. — This tells us that when once permission is given to the destroying angel to wound he makes no distinction between righteous and wicked (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:22:2) — and nighttime is the domain of the destroying agencies as it is said, (Psalms 104:20) “[Thou makest darkness and it is night], wherein all the beasts of the forest creep forth”."

—3— **Ihr aber verlasset nicht,** das lehrt, dass, wenn dem Zerstörer die Erlaubnis gegeben, zu verderben, er nicht mehr zwischen dem Gerechten und dem Bösen unterscheidet (Mech.); und die Nacht ist das Recht der Zerstörer; so heißt es (Ps. 104,20), in ihr regt sich alles Gewild des Waldes. 

---

////—1—//// 12:23:1,**Will pass over.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפָסַח means] “And He will take pity (or: spare).” One can also translate it: “And he skipped.”

§§—2—§§ 12:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופסח signifies AND HE WILL SPARE; and one can also explain it to mean, “and He will leap over them” (cf. Rashi on v. 13 and on Isaiah 30:5)."

—3— **23. Wird überschreiten,** sich erbarmen, man könnte dafür hinwegschreiten sagen. 

---

////—1—//// 12:23:2,"**And will not allow the destroyer.** He will not give the destroyer the ability to come, as in: “God will not give him [<font color=d50505>»</font>the ability<font color=d50505>«</font>] to harm me.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:23:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשחית AND HE WILL NOT GIVE THE DESTROYER He will not give him power to come in. The phrase is similar to (Genesis 31:9) “And God did not suffer him (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתנו — give him the power) to do me evil”.

—3— **Und den Zerstörer nicht lassen,** ihm die Macht nicht geben, hineinzugehen; wie (Gen. 31, 7), Gott ließ nicht zu, dass er mir Böses tue. 

---

////—1—//// 12:25:1,**When you come to the land.** Scripture makes this <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font> dependent upon their coming into the land (Eretz Yisrael). They had no obligation to do so in the wilderness except for the one [<font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font>] <font color=d50505>»</font>Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> which they fulfilled in the second year based on a Divine command.

§§—2—§§ 12:25:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבאן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS WHEN YE BE COME TO THE LAND — Scripture makes the observance of this service dependent upon their entrance into the land of Palestine (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:25), and they were not under any obligation, when in the wilderness, to keep more than the one Passover which they kept in the second year after the Exodus (cf. Numbers 9:1—5), and that, too, only in consequence of a special divine communication. (Cf. Rashi on Numbers 9:1 and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תוס׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קיד׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ע""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הואיל "

—3— **25. Wenn ihr kommen werdet,** der Vers hat dieses Gebot von ihrem Eintritt ins Land abhängig gemacht (Mech.); in der Wüste mussten sie nur ein Pessach darbringen, das sie nach göttlichem Befehl im zweiten Jahre bereiteten. 

---

////—1—//// 12:25:2,"**As He spoke.** Where [or when] did He speak? [When He said,] “And I will bring you, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:25:2, ACCORDING AS HE SPAKE — And where did He say that He would give them that land? In the following verse: (Exodus 6:8) “And I will bring you into the land” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:25).

—3— **Wie Er gesprochen,** und wo hat Er dies gesprochen? (6, 8) Und ich bringe euch in das Land (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:27:1,"**The people then bowed.** — [in thankfulness] for the foretelling of the redemption, and [their] coming into the land (Eretz Yisrael), and the foretelling of their having children. "

§§—2—§§ 12:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם AND THE PEOPLE BOWED THE HEAD in thanksgiving for the tidings of the approaching deliverance and for the promise of their coming into the land, and for the tidings regarding the children whom they would have (since v. 26 implies that they would be blessed with children)."

—3— **27. Da neigte sich das Volk,** für die Verheißung der Erlösung, den Eintritt ins Land und die Verheißung der Kinder, die sie haben würden (Mech.). 

---
