////—1—//// 12:28:1,"**The B’nei Yisrael went and did.** But had they already done — were they not commanded from the first of the month? But [the answer is] that once they committed themselves, the Torah considers it just as if they had done it. "

§§—2—§§ 12:28:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעשו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT AND DID — But did they really do this at once — was not all this spoken to them at the beginning of the month (cf. Rashi on v. 3) and they carried out the command only on the tenth and the fourteenth? But the explanation is: so soon as they had taken these duties upon themselves Scripture accounts it unto them as though they had already performed them (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:25).

—3— **28. Da gingen und taten die Kinder Israel,** taten sie denn jetzt schon; dies wurde doch bereits am Neumondstage zu ihnen gesagt? Nur, sobald sie es auf sich genommen hatten, rechnete es ihnen der Vers an, als ob sie es schon getan hätten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:28:2,"**They went and did.** The “going” is also mentioned in the Torah, in order to give reward for the “going” and reward for doing. "

§§—2—§§ 12:28:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעשו THEY WENT AND DID — Scripture enumerates their going also, to give them a reward for going and a reward for doing (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:25)."

—3— **Sie gingen und taten,** auch das Gehen rechnet der Vers auf, um ihnen Lohn für das Gehen und Lohn für das Tun zu geben (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:28:3,"**As Adonoy commanded Moshe and Aharon.** In order to relate the praise of [the B’nei] Yisrael that they omitted absolutely nothing of all the commands of Moshe and Aharon. And what is meant by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֵּן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשֹוּ — <font color=d50505>»</font>they did so<font color=d50505>«</font>? [This refers to the fact that] Moshe and Aharon, too, did so. "

§§—2—§§ 12:28:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואהרן [THEY DID] AS THE LORD HAD COMMANDED MOSES AND AARON — This is stated for the purpose of declaring Israel’s praise — that they did not omit a single matter of all the commandments of Moses and Aaron. And what is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשו SO DID THEY? Moses and Aaron also did thus!(Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:25).

—3— **Wie der Ewige Mosche und Aharon befohlen hatte;** damit verkündet er das Lob Israels, dass sie von allen Geboten Mosches und Aharons nichts versäumten; und was bedeutet noch, so taten sie? Auch Mosche und Aharon taten so (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:29:1,"**And Adonoy.** Wherever it states <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וה' (with the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' prefix), it means He and His Divine court, for the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' represents an addition as one says, “so-and-so as well as so-and-so.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וה׳ “AND” THE LORD — Wherever it is stated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וה׳ “And the Lord” it signifies He and His celestial Court, because the prefix <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו expresses an addition, just as one says, “Mr. So-and-so and Mr. So-and-so” (Genesis Rabbah 51:2; cf. Rashi on Genesis 19:24)."

—3— **29. Und der Ewige,** überall, wo so steht, bedeutet es, Er und Sein Gerichtshof (Jer. anf. Sanhedrin); denn das Waw ist der Ausdruck für eine Hinzufügung, wie der und der. 

---

////—1—//// 12:29:2,"**Struck down every first-born son.** Even if he was of another nation, who was [at the time] in Egypt. "

§§—2—§§ 12:29:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור SMOTE ALL THE FIRSTBORN — all: such, also, belonging to another people who happened to be in Egypt (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:29; cf. Rashi on v. 12)."

—3— **Schlug alle Erstgeborenen,** auch den anderer Völker, der in Mizraim war. 

---

////—1—//// 12:29:3,"**From the first-born son (of) Pharaoh.** Pharaoh, too, was a first-born son, but he was spared from the fate of the [other] first-born sons. It is he that is referred to when it states: “It is for this reason that I have spared you in order to show you My power in the Reed Sea.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:29:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבכר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרעה means FROM THE FIRSTBORN PHARAOH’S — Pharaoh too, was a firstborn, but he alone was allowed to remain of the firstborn; and regarding this it states, (Exodus 9:16) “[But for this cause I have maintained thee in life in order to show thee my power” — i. e. to show thee my power at the Read Sea (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:29)."

—3— **Vom Erstgeborenen Pharaos,** auch Pharao war ein Erstgeborener, er blieb aber von den Erstgeborenen übrig (Mech.), und von ihm heißt es (9, 16), um dessentwillen habe ich dich erhalten, um dir meine Macht am Schilfmeer zu zeigen. 

---

////—1—//// 12:29:4,"**To the first-born son of the captive.** 1. Because they rejoiced at the misfortune of the Israelites. Also, so that they might not say: “It is our god that brought the punishment [on the Egyptians].” 2. The first-born of the slave-girl is included [here], because [this verse] lists [everyone] from the most important [down] to the least important, and the slave-girl’s first-born son is more important than the captive’s first-born son. "

§§—2—§§ 12:29:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השבי UNTO THE FIRSTBORN OF THE CAPTIVE — because they rejoiced at the misfortune of the Israelites (Midrash Tanchuma, Bo 7); and a further reason why they were slain is that they should not say, — if they remained alive — it was our god who brought punishment upon our oppressors, the Egyptians (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:29) The firstborn of the handmaid, threatened with death in 40:5 but not mentioned here as having been slain, is included in those stated here to have been slain since it enumerates here (i. e. the terms used here are intended to include everyone) from the most important amongst all of them to the least important, and the firstborn of the handmaid as belonging to the Egyptian people, is certainly more important than the firstborn of the captive (cf. Rashi on 11:6)."

—3— **Bis zum Erstgeborenen der Gefangenen,** die sich über das Unglück Israels gefreut hatten (Mech.); und ferner, damit sie nicht sagen könnten, unser Abgott hat die Strafe gebracht; der Erstgeborene der Magd war auch miteingeschlossen; denn er zählt von dem allervornehmsten bis zum geringsten; und der Erstgeborene der Magd ist vornehmer als der Erstgeborene der Gefangenen. 

---

////—1—//// 12:30:1,**Pharaoh arose —** from his bed —

§§—2—§§ 12:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND PHARAOH AROSE from his bed, "

—3— **30. Da erhob sich Pharao** von seinem Lager. 

---

////—1—//// 12:30:2,**at night —** and not as is customary for kings [to arise] three hours into the day.

§§—2—§§ 12:30:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לילה AT NIGHT and not, as is the way of kings, at three hours in the day (9 o’clock in the morning) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:30; cf. Berakhot 9b). "

—3— **In der Nacht,** und nicht wie die Art der Könige in der dritten Stunde des Tages (Mech.). Er zuerst und dann seine Diener; das lehrt, dass er zu den Häusern seiner Diener umherging und sie aufstehen machte (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:30:3,"**He —** first, and <font color=d50505>»</font>afterwards<font color=d50505>«</font> his servants. This teaches us that he (Pharaoh) made the rounds of his servants’ houses and made them get up. "

§§—2—§§ 12:30:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא HE, first — and afterwards <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבדיו HIS SERVANTS — this informs us that he went round to the houses of his servants and made them get up (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:30)."

—3— **Denn es war kein Haus, in dem kein Toter war,** wenn ein Erstgeborerner da war, so war **er** gestorben; wenn kein Erstgeborener da war, so war der Größte im Hause gestorben; denn der Größte im Hause wird Erstgeborener genannt, so heißt es (Ps. 89, 28), auch mache ich ihn zum Erstgeborenen (Tanchuma). Andere Erklärung; die Ägypterinnen buhlten neben ihren Männern und gebaren von ledigen Burschen, so dass sie viele Erstgeborenen hatten; zuweilen hatte eine Frau fünf Söhne, und jeder war ein Erstgeborerner seines Vaters (Mech. V. 33). 

---

////—1—//// 12:30:4,"**For there was no house where there were no dead.** If a first-born son was there, he died If there was no first-born there, then, the eldest of the household is regarded as a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּכוֹר, as it is said: “I, too, will appoint him a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּכוֹר .” An alternate explanation: The Egyptian women were unfaithful to their husbands and bore children from single unmarried men and they (these men) thereby had many first-born sons, sometimes [as many as] five to one woman, each one being a first-born son to his father. "

§§—2—§§ 12:30:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מת FOR THERE WAS NOT A HOUSE WHERE THERE WAS NOT ONE DEAD — If there was a firstborn there, he died: if there was no firstborn there, then the chief person in the house died because the chief person in the house is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור, as it is said, (Psalms 89:28) “I also will appoint him to be a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור, [the highest of the kings of the earth]” (Mekhilta DeRashbi 12:30; cf. Rashi on 4:22; Pesachim Rabbah, Midr. Vajosha). Another explanation is: the Egyptian women were unfaithful to their husbands and bore children from young men, unmarried, and thus they (the Egyptian men) had many firstborn sons sometimes there were five to one woman, each being the firstborn to his own father (thus there might well be no house in which there was not a firstborn) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:33)."

—3— **31. Er rief Mosche und Aharon in der Nacht,** das lehrt, dass er an den Türen in der Stadt umherging und rief, wo wohnt Mosche, wo wohnt Aharon (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:31:1,"**He called for Moshe and Aharon that night.** This tells us that he (Pharaoh) went around to the various entrances (i.e., districts) of the city shouting, “Where does Moshe reside? — Where does Aharon reside?” "

§§—2—§§ 12:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולאהרן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לילה AND HE CALLED FOR MOSES AND AARON BY NIGHT — This tells us that he went round to the entrances leading into the city (i. e. to each different district) crying out, “Where does Moses reside? Where does Aaron reside?” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:31)."

—3— **Sowohl ihr,** Männer, 

---

////—1—//// 12:31:2,**Both you —** the men.

§§—2—§§ 12:31:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתם BOTH YE — the men, "

—3— **als auch die Kinder Israel,** die Kinder. 

---

////—1—//// 12:31:3,**And the B’nei Yisrael —** the infants.

§§—2—§§ 12:31:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL — the little ones (i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני must be understood literally).

—3— **Und gehet, dienet, wie ihr gesprochen,** ganz, wie ihr gesagt habt, und nicht, wie ich gesagt habe; aufgehoben ist, (4, 2) ich werde nicht wegschicken, aufgehoben, (10, 8) wer sind sie, die gehen sollen aufgehoben, (10, 24) nur eure Schafe und Rinder sollen bleiben. 

---

////—1—//// 12:31:4,"**Go worship, etc., as you have said.** Everything [shall be] as you have said and not as I have said. Void is [my statement:] “I will not send.” Void is [my statement:] “Who and who are going?” Void is [my statement:] “Only your sheep and cattle shall remain.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:31:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבדו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כדברכם AND GO, SERVE THE LORD, AS YE HAVE SAID — everything shall be as you have said and not as I have said: annulled is what I have said, (5:2) “I will not let you go” (“Arise, go out”); annulled is, (10:8) “who are they that shall go?” (“go, both you and the children of Israel”); annulled is, (10:24) “but your flocks and herds must remain” (“Take also your flocks and herds”) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:31)."


---

////—1—//// 12:32:1,"**Take your sheep and cattle too.** What is [stressed] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּאֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבַּרְתֶּם — <font color=d50505>»</font>as you have said<font color=d50505>«</font>? [It alludes to:] “You yourself will place in our hands [animals for] <font color=d50505>»</font>korbonos<font color=d50505>«</font> and burnt-offerings take, as you have said.” "

////—1—//// 12:39:2,"**They had also not prepared provisions for themselves —** for the journey. This tells the praise of the Israelites, that they did not say, “How can we go out into the wilderness without provisions?,” but rather they had faith and they went. This is what is explicitly told in the Prophets: “I (God) remember to you the love of your youth, the love of your betrothal [to Me], when you followed Me into the wilderness — into a land that was not sown.” And what reward is set forth afterwards? “Yisrael is hallowed to Adonoy, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:39:2,".<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצה NEITHER HAD THEY MADE FOR THEMSELVES ANY PROVISION for the journey. This is stated to tell how praiseworthy Israel was: that they did not say, “How can we go forth into the wilderness without provisions?” But they had faith and set forth. This it is that is referred to more explicitly in the prophets: (Jeremiah 2:1) “I remember for thee the affection of thy youth, the love of thine espousals, how thou wentest after me in the wilderness in a land that was not sown”. What reward is afterwards set forth there? “Israel is the Lord’s hallowed portion etc.” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:35)."

—3— **Auch hatten sie sich keine Wegzehrung gemacht,** für den Weg; das verkündet das Lob Israels, dass sie nicht sagten, wie können wir ohne Wegzehrung in die Wüste hinausgehen? Sondern sie vertrauten und gingen (Mech.); dies steht deutlich im Propheten (Jer. 2, 2), ich gedenke dir der Frömmigkeit deiner Jugend, der Liebe deiner Brautzeit, dass du mir in die Wüste folgtest, in unbesätes Land. Welcher Lohn aber wird dann verheißen? Heilig ist Israel dem Ewigen …

—3— **40. Den sie sich in Mizraim aufhielten,** nach den anderen Niederlassungen, wo sie als Fremde in einem Lande verweilt hatten, das nicht ihnen gehörte (Mech.).

////—1—//// 12:40:2,"**Four hundred and thirty years.** Altogether, from when Yitzchok was born until now, there were four hundred years. [Our reckoning is from then] because [only] from the time that Avraham had a child could there be a fulfillment [of the prophecy]: “For your descendant will be a stranger,” and thirty years passed from when the decree of “between the pieces” was decreed until the birth of Yitzchok. One cannot say [that the 430 years was] in the land of Egypt alone, for Kehos was among those who came with Yaakov. Now go and calculate all his years and all the years of his son Amram "

§§—2—§§ 12:40:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וארבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS — Altogether from the birth of Isaac until now were 400 years, and we must reckon from that event, for only from the time when Abraham had offspring from Sarah could the prophecy (Genesis 15:13) “Thy offspring shall be a stranger” be fulfilled; and there had been 30 years since that decree made at “the convenant between the parts” until the birth of Isaac. It is impossible to say that this means that they were 430 years in the land of Egypt alone, for Kohath was one of those who came into Egypt with Jacob (Genesis 46:11); go and reckon all his years and all the years of Amram his son and the whole eighty years of Moses, the latter’s son, until the Exodus and you will not find that they total to so many; and you must admit that Kohath had already lived many years before he went down to Egypt, and that many of Amram’s years are included in the years of his father Kohath, and that many of the 80 years of Moses are included in the years of his father Amram, so that you see that you will not find 400 years from the time of Israel’s coming into Egypt until the Exodus. You are compelled to admit, even though unwillingly, that the other settlements which the patriarchs made in lands other than Egypt come also under the name of “sojourning as a stranger” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גרות), including also that at Hebron, even though it was in Canaan itself, because it is said, (Genesis 35:27) “[Hebron] where Abraham and Isaac sojourned”, and it says, (Exodus 6:4) “[the land Canaan], the land of their sojournings wherein they sojourned”. Consequently you must necessarily say that the prophecy, “thy offspring shall be strangers… [four hundred years]” began only from the time when he had offspring. And only if you reckon the 400 years from the birth of Isaac will you find that from the time they came into Egypt until the time they left it, was 210 years (as alluded to in Genesis 15:13). This was one of the passages which they altered for king Ptolemy (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:40; Megillah 9a). "

—3— **430 Jahre,** im ganzen; von der Geburt Isaaks bis dahin waren 400 Jahre; als Abraham Nachkommenschaft erhalten hatte, ging in Erfüllung (Gen. 15, 13) ein Fremdling wird dein Nachkomme sein; und 30 Jahre waren vom Bunde zwischen den Stücken, wo diese Bestimmung verhängt waad, bis zur Geburt Isaaks. Man kann aber nicht sagen, im Lande Mizraim allein; denn Kehat gehörte zu denen, die mit Jaakob nach Ägypten gekommen waren; geh und rechne alle seine Jahre und alle Jahre seines Sohnes Amram und 80 Jahre von Mosche, so findest du doch nicht soviel; und notwendigerweise hatte Kehat schon viele Jahre gelebt, bevor er nach Mizraim hinabzog, und viele Jahre von Amram sind in den Jahren von Kehat enthalten, und viele Jahre von Mosche sind in den Jahren von Amram enthalten; du erhältst also keine 400 Jahre seit ihrer Ankunft in Mizraim bis dahin, und du bist notwendigerweise gezwungen, zu sagen, dass auch die anderen Niederlassungen Land der Fremde genannt werden, selbst Chebron, wie es heißt (Gen. 35, 27), wo sich Abraham und Isaak als Fremde aufhielten; ferner heißt es (6,4), das Land ihres Aufenthaltes, wo sie als Fremde geweilt hatten; darum musst du sagen, Fremde werden deine Nachkommen sein, beginnt mit dem Tage, da er einen Nachkommen erhielt. Und wenn du die 400 Jahre von der Geburt Isaaks an rechnest, so findest du von ihrer Ankunft in Mizraim bis zu ihrem Auszug 210 Jahre; hier ist eine von den Stellen, an welchen die 70 Gelehrten in der vom König Ptolemäus verlangten Übersetzung vom Text abwichen (Megillah 9a).

////—1—//// 12:41:1,"**It was at the end of [four hundred and] thirty years, etc. And on that very day** This tells us that the moment the bondage ended God did not detain them for even the blink of an eye: [This therefore tells us that] on the fifteenth of Nissan the serving angels came to Avraham to foretell to him (the birth of Yitzchok), On the fifteenth of Nissan Yitzchok was born and on the fifteenth of Nissan the decree of “between the pieces” was decreed. "

§§—2—§§ 12:41:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעצם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THE END OF THE 430 YEARS … EVEN ON THE SELF-SAME DAY — The addition of the latter phrase tells us that as soon as the predetermined end of the bondage arrived the Omnipresent did not detain them even as long as the twinkling of an eye (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:42). For on the fifteenth of Nisan the ministering angels had come to Abraham to announce to him the promised birth of Isaac, and on the fifteenth of Nisan Isaac was born, and on the fifteenth of Nisan the decree “between the parts” relating to Israel’s slavery was made."

—3— **41. Es war am Ende von 430 Jahren, es war an ebendiesem Tage;** das lehrt, dass, als das Ende herangekommen, der Ewige sie nicht einen Augenblick zurückhielt; am 15. Nissan waren einst die Engel des Dienstes zu Abraham gekommen, um ihm die Verheißung zu bringen, am 15. Nissan wurde Isaak geboren und am 15. Nissan die Bestimmung zwischen den Stücken ausgesprochen (Mech.).

////—1—//// 12:43:2,**[No] alien.** [So called] because his deeds have become alienated from his Father in heaven. Both a non-Jew and a Jewish apostate are included [in the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בֶּן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֵכָר].

—3— **Ein Entfremdeter,** dessen Handlungen seinem Vater im Himmel entfremdet sind (Seb. 22b), und es ist sowohl ein Nichtjude als auch ein abtrünniger Jude darunter zu verstehen (Mech.).

////—1—//// 12:44:1,"**You must circumcise him and then he may eat it.** [“He” refers to] his master. This teaches that his uncircumcised slaves prevent him from partaking of the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font>; This is the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua. Rabbi Eliezer says: His uncircumcised slaves do not prevent him from partaking of the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font>. If so, what is the meaning of “And then he may eat it”? [It refers to] the slave. "

§§—2—§§ 12:44:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומלתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו WHEN THOU HAST CIRCUMCISED HIM THEN SHALL HE EAT THEREOF — “he” means his (the slave’s) master; this tells us that the neglect to circumcise his slaves bars him from eating of the Paschal offering. This is the opinion of R. Joshua. Rabbi Eliezer, however, said: the neglect to circumcise his slaves does not bar him from eating of the Paschal offering. The objection was raised: if this be so what means “Then shall he eat thereof”? — The reply was given: “He” means the slave, not the master (the meaning being that the slave, so long as he is uncircumcised may not eat of it) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:44:2)."

—3— **44. Beschneide ihn, dann darf er davon essen,** sein Herr, das lehrt, dass die Beschneidung seiner Sklaven für den Genuss des Pessach- Opfers notwendig ist, so sagt R. Joschua, R. Elieser sagt, die Beschneidung seiner Sklaven ist für den Genuss des Pessachopfers nicht notwendig; wenn es so ist, was lehrt dann, dann darf er davon essen? Der Sklave selbst (Mech.).

////—1—//// 12:45:1,**A sojourner.** This refers to a stranger who settles in Eretz Yisrael.

§§—2—§§ 12:45:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תושב A TOLERATED SOJOURNER — this means a stranger who has settled in Palestine (having undertaken to observe the seven precepts of the “Sons of Noah”).

—3— **45. Ein Beisaße,** ein fremder Beisaße (der nur die sieben noachidischen Gebote und nicht das ganze Judentum angenommen hat).

////—1—//// 12:45:2,**Hired worker.** This refers to a non-Jew. But why does the Torah need to tell us this — are they not uncircumcised — and it states: No uncircumcised may eat of it? But [the answer is that it refers to] a circumcised Arab or a circumcised Givonite who is either a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תּוֹשָׁב or a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂכִיר .

§§—2—§§ 12:45:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושכיר AND A HIRED SERVANT — a heathen. But why need Scripture state at all that these (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תושב and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שכיר) may not eat of the Passover lamb? These are uncircumcised and it is said (v. 48) “And no uncircumcised person shall eat thereof”? But it refers to such a one as a circumcised Arabian or a circumcised Gibeonite who is a settler or a hired servant (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:45; Yevamot 71a).

—3— **Und ein Mietling,** das ist ein Nichtjude; was will das lehren, sie sind doch unbeschnitten, und es heißt (V. 48), ein Unbeschnittener darf nicht davon essen? Nur, hier ist z. B. ein beschnittener Araber und ein beschnittener Gibeoni gemeint, der ein Beisaße oder ein Mietling ist (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:46:1,"**It must be eaten in one house —** as one group — that those who were counted [as members] of it shall not [break up] into two groups and divide it up [among the two groups]. You say that [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּבַיִת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶחָד means] <font color=d50505>»</font>one group<font color=d50505>«</font> or maybe this is not so but [it means] <font color=d50505>»</font>in one house<font color=d50505>«</font> as is its plain meaning and it comes to teach that if they had begun and were eating in the courtyard and rain began to fall, that they may not enter the house. Therefore, the Torah tells us: “On the <font color=d50505>»</font>houses<font color=d50505>«</font> in which they will eat,” from this [we infer] that whoever eats it may eat it in two places. "

§§—2—§§ 12:46:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאכל IN ONE HOUSE SHALL IT BE EATEN — in one company (cf. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבית); meaning that those who have registered themselves for it (the Paschal offering) shall not form themselves afterwards into two companies and divide it. An objection was raised: You say that this means “in one company”, but perhaps this is not so, but it means “in one house” (or place) as it usually signifies, and it intends to teach that if they had begun to eat, for example, in the courtyard of a house and rain fell they may not enter the house to complete the eating of the offering? The reply was given: this cannot be so, because Scripture says, (v. 7) “[They shall put the blood] upon the houses (plural) wherein they shall eat it” — and from here it follows that one who is eating the Paschal offering may eat it in two places (consequently the only meaning of the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בית is “company”, as was suggested) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:46:1 and Onkelos)."

—3— **46. In einem Hause werde es gegessen,** in einer Gesellschaft, und die darauf Gezählten dürfen nicht zwei Gesellschaften machen und es teilen. Du sagst, in einer Gesellschaft, vielleicht aber heißt es nicht so, sondern wörtlich in einem Hause, um zu lehren, dass, wenn sie im Hofe angefangen haben zu essen und es anfing, zu regnen, sie nicht ins Haus gehen dürfen? Darum steht (V. 7), an den Häusern (Mehrz.), in denen sie es (Einz.) essen; daraus geht hervor, dass es der Essende an zwei Orten essen darf (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:46:2,**You must not remove from the house.** [Meaning:] from the group.

§§—2—§§ 12:46:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תוציא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבית THOU SHALT NOT CARRY FORTH OUT OF THE HOUSE this must therefore mean away from the company (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:46:2).

—3— **Bring nicht aus dem Hause hinaus,** aus der Gesellschaft. 

---

////—1—//// 12:46:3,"**And you must not break any of its bones.** [A bone] that is edible as, for example, if it has upon it a <font color=d50505>»</font>kezayis<font color=d50505>«</font> piece of flesh, there is the prohibition against breaking the bone. If it does not have upon it a <font color=d50505>»</font>kezayis<font color=d50505>«</font> of flesh or marrow, there is no prohibition against breaking the bone. "

§§—2—§§ 12:46:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועצם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשברו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו NEITHER SHALL YE BREAK A BONE THEREOF — any bone that is fitted for eating (for the purpose of the performing the command of eating the Paschal lamb) as, for instance, one upon which there is flesh of the size of an olive — to it there is (applies) the prohibition relating to the breaking of a bone, but if there is not upon it flesh of the size of an olive there does not apply to it the prohibition of breaking a bone (cf. Pesachim 84b)."

—3— **Und einen Knochen zerbrechet nicht daran,** der zum Essen geeignet ist; für den Fall, dass ein olivengroßes Stück Fleisch daran ist, besteht dabei das Verbot, den Knochen zu zerbrechen; ist aber kein olivengroßes Stück Fleisch oder kein Mark daran, so besteht dabei nicht das Verbot, den Knochen zu zerbrechen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:47:1,"**The entire community of Yisrael must make this offering.** Why is this said? Because about the Pesach in Egypt it states: “A lamb for a family” [i.e.,] they were assigned to it according to families; I might therefore think that this holds true for the Pesach of later generations. The Torah therefore tells us: “The entire community of Israel shall make it.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:47:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעשו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו ALL THE CONGREGATION OF ISRAEL SHALL KEEP IT — Why is this stated? Since it says of the Paschal offering offered in Egypt, (v. 3) “a lamb for the house of their fathers” which means that they are to be registered for it by families, one might think that in the case of the Paschal offering offered by future generations this must also be so! Therefore Scripture states: “All the congregation of Israel may eat it” (i.e. any of them may eat it whoever they may be who combine to do so) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:47)."

—3— **47. Die ganze Gemeinde Israel bereite es,** warum steht das; weil er beim Pessachopfer in Ägypten sagt, ein Lamm für jedes Vaterhaus, sie sollten sich nach Familien darauf zählen, hätte ich gemeint, das gelte auch für das Pessach der späteren Geschlechter; darum steht, die ganze Gemeinde Israels (und nicht nach Familien geteilt) bereite es (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:48:1,"**And wants to make the Pesach-offering.** I might think that when one converts he must immediately do the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> service, the Torah therefore tells us: “and he shall be like the native born” — just as the native-born [brings the Pesach] on the 14th so, too, the convert [brings it] on the 14th. "

§§—2—§§ 12:48:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסח AND HE WILL KEEP THE PASSOVER (the words may mean, then he shall keep the Passover) — One might think that this verse implies that any-one who becomes a proselyte (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גר) must keep the Passover-offering rite immediately after his circumcision (even though this has not taken place just before Passover), therefore Scripture states <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאזרח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הארץ “but he shall be as a native of the land”. How is it in the case of a native? He brings the offering on the fourteenth! So, too, a proselyte must bring it only on the fourteenth (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:49)."

—3— **48. Und er bereitet ein Pessach dem Ewigen,** ich hätte meinen können, jeder, der Jude wird, bereite sogleich ein Pessach, darum steht, er sei gleich dem Eingeborenen des Landes, wie der Eingeborene nur am 14., so auch der Fremde am 14. (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 12:48:2,"**But no uncircumcised male may eat it.** [This is stated] to include [in the prohibition] someone whose brothers have died as a result of circumcision whereby he is not an apostate regarding circumcision, and [his prohibition against eating it] cannot be ascertained from “any alien may not eat of it.” "

§§—2—§§ 12:48:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יאכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו AND NO UNCIRCUMCISED PERSON SHALL EAT THEREOF — This is stated in addition to the somewhat similar text in v. 43 in order to include in the prohibition of eating the Paschal offering any person whose brothers have died in consequence of circumcision (in which case the parents are exempted from circumcising any of their children born after the death of these), because such a one is not to be regarded as an apostate who of set purpose remains uncircumcised, and the law regarding such a one cannot be derived from the statement in v. 43, “no strange person shall eat thereof” (because Rashi has explained this to refer to an Israelite whose doings have estranged him from God)."

—3— **Ein Unbeschnittener esse nicht davon,** das fügt auch den hinzu, dessen Brüder durch die Beschneidung gestorben sind, der nicht aus Abtrünnigkeit unbeschnitten geblieben und nicht aus jenem Vers (43) zu entnehmen ist, ein Entfremdeter esse nicht davon. 

---

////—1—//// 12:49:1,"**One law, etc.** To equate the convert with the native-born regarding the other <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> of the Torah. "

§§—2—§§ 12:49:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תורה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ ONE LAW etc. — This is stated in addition to the similar text in v. 48 in order to declare that the proselyte is equal to the native also in respect to all other commands of the Torah (i. e. the preceding text has reference only to the Paschal offering whilst this is a general statement) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:49).

—3— **49. Eine Lehre,** dies macht den Fremden dem Einheimischen auch für die übrigen Gebote der Torah gleich (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:2:1,"**That open the womb.** [Meaning:] that is the first to open the womb as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פֹּטֵר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַיִם) As one who makes an opening for water, [so is] the beginning of an argument.” Similarly “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַפְטִירוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְשָׂפָה” — <font color=d50505>»</font>they will open their lips<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 13:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רחם THE FIRST OFFSPRING OF EVERY WOMB — The words mean: that which first openeth the womb, the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר meaning to open, as in (Proverbs 17:14) “As one makes an opening (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פוטר) for water so is the beginning of strife”; and so, too, is (Psalms 22:8) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יפטירו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשפה i. e. “they open the lips”."

—3— **13,2. Was jeden Mutterschoß erschließt,** was zuerst den Mutterschoß geöffnet hat; wie (Spr. 17, 14), wie einer, der Wasser frei lässt, so ist der Anfang des Streites; ebenso (Ps. 22, 8), öffnen die Lippen. 

---

////—1—//// 13:2:2,**It is mine.** “I have acquired them for Myself by My having struck down the Egyptian first-born”

§§—2—§§ 13:2:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא IT IS MINE — I have acquired him for Myself through My having smitten the first born of the Egyptians.

—3— **Gehört mir,** ich habe sie für mich erworben dadurch, dass ich die Erstgeborenen Ägyptens schlug. 

---

////—1—//// 13:3:1,**Remember this day.** This teaches that mention of the Exodus from Egypt should be made every day.

§§—2—§§ 13:3:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה REMEMBER THIS DAY — This teaches that one must make mention of the Exodus from Egypt every day (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:3; cf. Rashi on Deuteronomy 27:9).

—3— **3. Gedenket dieses Tages,** das lehrt, dass man an jedem Tage des Auszuges aus Ägypten gedenke (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:4:1,"**In the month of Aviv (Nissan)** But did they themselves not know in which month they went out? But this is what He said to them: “See the kindness that He has bestowed upon you, that He took you out in a month in which it is fit to go out — not hot, not cold and not raining. So, too, is it said: “He brings out prisoners <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּכּוֹשָרוֹת,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּכּוֹשָׁרוֹת meaning:] a month that is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּשֵר (fit) to go out. "

§§—2—§§ 13:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחדש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האביב IN THE MONTH ABIB — But would we not know in which month they went out (even though it were not stated here)? But Moses spake to them as follows: See the kindness which God has bestowed on you — that He brought you forth in a month that is fitted for going out, not hot, nor cold nor rainy. In the same sense it says (Psalms 68:7) “He bringeth forth the prisoners <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכשרות” i. e. in a month that is fitted (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כשר) for going out (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:4:1)."

—3— **4. Im Monat der Ährenreife;** wussten wir denn nicht, in welchem Monat? Nur, so sagte er zu ihnen, seht die Wohltat, die Er euch erwiesen hat, dass Er euch in einem Monat hinausgeführt hat, der zum Auszug recht geeignet ist, ohne Sonnenglut, ohne Kälte und ohne Regen; so sagt er auch (Ps. 68,7), Er führte die Gefangenen zur rechten Zeit hinaus, in einem Monat, der zum Auszug recht war (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:5:1,"**To the land of the Canaanite, etc.** And although only five nations are enumerated [nevertheless,] all seven nations are implied because Canaan includes them all. There was, however, one among the family of Canaan who had no other name except “Canaanite.” "

§§—2—§§ 13:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנעני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ TO THE LAND OF THE CANAANITE — And although it enumerates here only the five peoples, all the seven nations are implied (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:5:1) for all are included in the generic term Canaanite, although there was one of the races of Canaan which had no other name than that of Canaanite (whilst the other races had, beside the generic name Canaanite, some special designation as Hittite etc.: hence under the term Canaanite one may understand either the one race bearing this name or any of the other races. Here, therefore, the introductory word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנעני alludes to the particular tribe so called and to the two others included in this generic term, or it may allude to three tribes included in the generic term. In either case we get the “seven peoples of Canaan”)."

—3— **5. In das Land des Kenaani,** wenn er auch nur fünf Völker aufzählt, so sind doch alle sieben Völker inbegriffen; denn alle gehören zum Begriff Kenaani; und eine von den Familien Kenaans bekam keinen besonderen, sondern den Namen Kenaani (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:5:2,"**Swore to your fathers, etc.** Concerning Avraham it states: “On that day Adonoy made a covenant with Avram, etc.” Concerning Yitzchok it states: “Stay temporarily in this land, etc.” Concerning Yaakov it states: “The land upon which you are lying, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 13:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאבתיך WHICH HE SWORE UNTO THY FATHERS — In the case of Abraham it says, (Genesis 15:18) “On that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram [saying, To thy seed I will give this land]”; in the case of Isaac it says, (Genesis 26:3) “Sojourn in this land … [for to thee and to thy seed I will give all these countries]”; and in the case of Jacob it says, (Genesis 28:13) “the land wheron thou liest [to thee will I give it and to thy seed]” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:5:4)."

—3— **Das Er deinen Vätern zugeschworen hat;** bei Abraham heißt es (Gen. 15, 18), an jenem Tage schloss der Ewige mit Abram… bei Isaak (Gen. 26, 3), weile in diesem Lande, und bei Jaakob (Gen. 28, 13), das Land, auf dem du liegst (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:5:3,**A land flowing with milk and honey.** Milk flows from the goats and the honey flows from the dates and figs

§§—2—§§ 13:5:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבש FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY — milk flows from the goats and honey flows from the dates and from the figs.

—3— **Das von Milch und Honig fließt,** Milch fließt von den Ziegen, und Honig fließt von den Datteln und den Feigen (Raschi Megillah 6a). 

---

////—1—//// 13:5:4,"**This service.** [I.e., the service] of the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach.<font color=d50505>«</font> But was this not already stated above: “When you come to the land, etc?” why (then) did he go back and restate it? Because of something new that is introduced. In the previous chapter it is stated, “When your children will ask you, ‘What is this service of yours?’” Scripture [there] is speaking of the evil son, for he excluded himself from the community. But here [it states] “You must tell your son,” referring to the son who does not [even] know what to ask, whereby Scripture teaches you that you must initiate conversation with him with aggadic explanations which attract the heart (i.e., arouse his interest). "

§§—2—§§ 13:5:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העבודה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזאת THIS SERVICE — that of the Paschal offering. But has it not already been said above, (Exodus 12:25) “And it shall come to pass when ye be come into the land … [that ye shall keep this service]”? Why then does it repeat it again? On account of a new matter that is introduced here; viz., in the former chapter it says, (v. 26) “And it shall come to pass when your children shall say unto you, What mean ye by this service?” and there Scripture is speaking about a wicked son who excludes himself from the Israelite community (by saying ye, as though he does not wish to participate in the service), whilst here it states, (v. 8) “And thou shalt tell thy son”, referring to a son who does not know how to enquire, and Scripture teaches you that you yourself must open up the conversation with Agadic explanations which attract the heart (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:14:1; Shabbat 87a)."

—3— **Diesen Dienst,** des Pessachopfers; das steht aber doch schon oben (12, 25), und es sei, wenn ihr in das Land kommen werdet; warum wiederholt er es noch einmal? Wegen einer Sache, die hier neu steht; im ersten Abschnitt steht (12, 26), wenn eure Söhne zu euch sprechen werden, was soll euch dieser Dienst; dort spricht der Vers von einem frevelhaften Sohne, der sich aus der Gesamtheit ausgeschlossen hat, und hier, du sollst deinem Sohne erzählen, von einem Sohne, der nicht zu fragen versteht, und der Vers lehrt dich, du sollst mit ihm Worte der Agada anfangen, die das Herz an sich ziehen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:8:1,"**Because of this.** “Because I will fulfill His <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos,<font color=d50505>«</font> such as these: <font color=d50505>»</font>Pesach, Matzo,<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>Maror<font color=d50505>«</font>. "

§§—2—§§ 13:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעבור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה FOR THE SAKE OF THIS — for the sake that I should carry out His commands, such as this Passover offering, this unleavened bread and this bitter herb (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:8:1)."

—3— **8. Um dessentwillen,** damit ich Seine Gebote erfülle wie diese, Pessach, Mazza und Bitterkraut. 

---

////—1—//// 13:8:2,"**Adonoy did [this] for me.** This is an allusion to a response to the evil son, saying: “Adonoy did this for <font color=d50505>»</font>me<font color=d50505>«</font>” — “for <font color=d50505>»</font>me<font color=d50505>«</font>, but not for you, for had you been there [in Egypt] you would not have been worthy to be redeemed. "

§§—2—§§ 13:8:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי GOD DID FOR ME — Here is an indication of the reply to be given to the wicked son: that one should say to him, “God did for me” — and one should not say “what God did <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנו, for us” — thus implying “not for thee”, for if thou hadst been there (in Egypt) thou wouldst not have been regarded as worthy of being redeemed (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:14:1)."

—3— **Hat der Ewige für mich getan,** er deutet damit die Antwort für den frevelhaften Sohn an, ihm zu sagen, hat der Ewige für mich getan, aber nicht für dich; wärest du dort gewesen, so hättest du nicht verdient, erlöst zu werden (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:9:1,**It shall be to you as a sign.** The Exodus from Egypt will be to you as a sign —

§§—2—§§ 13:9:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאות AND IT SHALL BE FOR A SIGN UNTO THEE — i. e. the Exodus from Egypt shall be to thee as a sign

—3— **9. Und es sei dir zum Zeichen,** der Auszug aus Ägypten sei dir zum Zeichen auf deinem Arm und zum Gedenken auf deinem Haupte; er will sagen, du sollst diese Abschnitte aufschreiben und sie auf Haupt und Arm binden. 

---

////—1—//// 13:9:2,**on your hand and a reminder between your eyes.** Meaning: that you write these sections and tie them upon the head and upon the arm.

§§—2—§§ 13:9:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולזכרון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עיניך UPON THINE HAND AND AS A MEMORIAL BETWEEN THINE EYES — meaning, that you shall write these paragraphs (verses 1—10 and 11—16) and bind them upon the head and upon the arm."

—3— **Auf deinem Arme,** dem linken; darum steht im zweiten Abschnitt (V. 16) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידכה voll, um dabei zu erklären, der Arm, der <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כהה schwächer ist (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:9:3,**On your hand.** On the left hand. This is why <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָדְכָה is written “full” (with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה') in the second section (v. 16) so that it may be explained [as a contraction] of two words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׁהִיא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֵהָה (the weak hand).

§§—2—§§ 13:9:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידך UPON THY HAND — on the left hand; that is why the word is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָדְכָה in its full form (not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָדְךָ) in the second section (v. 16), so that we should explain it (by dividing this word into two: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה) as meaning the hand that is weak (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כהה) (Menachot 36b)."


---

////—1—//// 13:10:1,**From year to year** (lit. <font color=d50505>»</font>days to days<font color=d50505>«</font>). [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִיָּמִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָמִימָה means] from year to year.

§§—2—§§ 13:10:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מימים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימימה means FROM YEAR TO YEAR (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים frequently signifies a year) (Menachot 36b).

—3— **10. Von Jahr zu Jahr,** von Jahr zu Jahr (dort 36b).

////—1—//// 13:11:1,"**When Adonoy brings you.** There are some of our Sages who learned from here that the first-born of the wilderness were not sanctified. The one whose opinion it is that they <font color=d50505>»</font>were<font color=d50505>«</font> sanctified explains this “coming into [Eretz Yisrael]” thus: If you will fulfill it (the sanctification of the first-born) in the wilderness, you will merit entering the land and you will [continue to] fulfill it there. "

§§—2—§§ 13:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יביאך AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS WHEN [THE LORD] SHALL BRING THEE … [THOU SHALT SET APART etc.] — There are some of our Rabbis who learned from this statement that the firstborn who were born in the wilderness were not thus hallowed. He who says that these were thus hallowed explains this “coming” (i. e. this verse, which appears to make the hallowing of the firstborn dependent upon their arrival in the land) as follows: if you observe it (this command) in the wilderness, you will be privileged to enter the land and to observe it there (cf. Bekhorot 4b)."

—3— **11. (Und es sei,** wenn dich bringen wird, einige von unseren Lehrern lernen von hier heraus, dass die Erstgeborenen, die in der Wüste geboren wurden, noch nicht heilig waren; und derjenige, der sagt, sie waren heilig, erklärt dieses Hineinkommen ins Land so: Wenn ihr dies Gebot in der Wüste erfüllet, werdet ihr das Glück haben, ins Land zu kommen und es dort zu erfüllen [Bech. 4b]). 

---

////—1—//// 13:11:2,"**He swore to you.** And where did He swear this to you? [when He said,] “I will bring you to the land about which I raised My Hand [as an oath], etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 13:11:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך HE SWORE UNTO THEE — And where did He swear this unto thee? (Exodus 6:8) “And I will bring you unto the land concerning which I did lift up my hand etc.” (cf. Rashi on this verse where he explains that “lifting up the hand” denotes taking an oath) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:11:2).

—3— **Dir zugeschworen hat,** und wo hat Er dir dies zugeschworen? (6, 8) Und ich bringe euch in das Land, von dem ich geschworen… (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:11:3,**And He will have given it to you.** You should consider it as if He had given it to you on the same day and do not consider it as if it were an inheritance from your ancestors.

§§—2—§§ 13:11:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונתנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך AND SHALL GIVE IT TO THEE Let it be in thine eyes (regard it) as though He had given it to thee on that same day (when on each occasion you carry out this command) and do not regard it as an inheritance from your ancestors (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:11:4).

—3— **Und es dir geben wird,** es sei in deinen Augen, als hätte Er es dir an jenem Tage erst geschenkt; und es sei nicht wie ein Erbe der Väter in deinen Augen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:12:1,**You must set aside.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעֲבַרְתָּ is a term denoting <font color=d50505>»</font>setting aside<font color=d50505>«</font> similarly it says: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעֲבַרְתֶּם — You shall set aside his inheritance for his daughter.”

§§—2—§§ 13:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעברת This word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעברת is an expression for “setting apart”. Similarly it says, (Numbers 27:8) “And ye shall set his inheritance apart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעברתם) for his daughter” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:12:1)."

—3— **12. Sollst du übergeben**, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העברת bedeutet nichts anderes als absondern (Mech.); so sagt er auch (Num. 27,8), lasset sein Besitztum an seine Tochter übergehen. 

---

////—1—//// 13:12:2,"**That is dropped (born) by animals.** One prematurely born where the mother “drops” him and sends him out before his time. Scripture teaches you [that though it will not survive] that it is sanctified as a first-born in so far as exempting the one born afterwards. Although even one not born prematurely is also referred to as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׁגֶר as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁגַר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲלָפֶיךָ — “those born of your herds,” nevertheless, here it refers only to one of premature birth because it has already stated: “everyone that is first to open the womb.” Should you ask: does it refer also to a first-born of an unclean animal? [I would answer:] the Torah already was explicit elsewhere: “of your cattle and sheep.” There is a possible alternate explanation. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַעֲבַרְתָּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פֶּטֶר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֶחֶם it is to the first-born of man that Scripture refers. "

§§—2—§§ 13:12:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהמה DROPPED BY BEAST— a premature birth; and this is termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר because its mother casts it out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר) and expels it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלחתו) from the womb before its due time (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר is a synonym of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלח “to let go”). Scripture teaches you that although it is a premature birth it is nevertheless holy by reason of its being first born, in so far that it exempts from the law regarding the firstborn the young that comes (is born) after it (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:12:2). It is true that an animal that is not a premature birth) is also called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר, as (Deuteronomy 7:13) “the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר of thy kine” (where it speaks of blessing this, and it is therefore evident that it cannot there denote a premature birth), but this <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר (i. e. its use here) is intended only to tell us something about a premature birth, because, you see, it has already written in this verse: “Every first offspring of the womb”! And if you say that also the firstborn of an unclean animal (and not a premature birth) is implied by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר (and that this also must be hallowed) then I reply that Scripture comes and expressly states in another passage, (Deuteronomy 15:19) “[All the firstling males that are born] of thy herd and of thy flocks (thus only clean animals) [shalt thou sanctify etc.]”. Another meaning may be given in explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעברת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רחם “thou shalt set apart every first born of the womb” — viz., that Scripture by the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רחם is speaking of the firstborn of man (consequently the following words, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהמה, need not denote an animal of premature birth, but an animal born in the natural course as it certainly means in Deuteronomy 7:13, and we thus avoid the necessity of here assigning to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר a meaning different from that which it bears in the latter passage)."

—3— **Des Wurfes des Viehes,** (Mech.) eine Fehlgeburt, die deren Mutter ausgeworfen und vor der Zeit ausgestoßen hat; und der Vers lehrt dich, dass sie doch als Erst gebürt heilig ist, um das, was nach ihr kommt, frei zu machen; und obschon sonst dasjenige, das keine Fehlgeburt ist, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגר genannt wird, wie (Deut. 7, 13) den Wurf deiner Rinder; hier kommt es nur, für die Fehlgeburt eine Vorschrift zu geben, da er bereits geschrieben, alles, was den Mutterschoß erschließt; wenn du aber sagen solltest, auch das Erstgeborene des unreinen Viehes sei inbegriffen, darum erklärt er an anderer Stelle (Deut. 15,19), unter deinen Rindern und deinen Schafen; andere Erklärung, man kann den Vers, du sollst alles, was den Mutterschoß erschließt, absondern, auf den Erstgeborenen des Menschen beziehen. 

---

////—1—//// 13:13:1,**Firstling donkey.** But not the firstling of any other unclean animal. This is a Scriptural decree because the Egyptian first-born are compared to donkeys. Also because [the donkeys] were helpful to Israel when they left Egypt [for there was not a single Israelite who did not take many donkeys] loaded with the silver and gold of Egypt.

§§—2—§§ 13:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמור AND EVERY FIRST OFFSPRING OF AN ASS — but not the first offspring of other unclean animals. This exception is the enactment of Scripture, because the firstborn of the Egyptians are compared to asses (Ezekiel 23:20; Bereishit Rabbah 96); and a further reason for this exception is because they (the asses) were of assistance to the Israelites when they left Egypt, for there was not a single Israelite who did not take with him from Egypt several asses laden with the silver and gold of Egypt. (Bekhorot 5b)."

—3— **13. Das Erstgeborene des Esels,** und nicht das Erstgeborene anderen unreinen Viehes; es ist dies eine Bestimmung der Torah, und zwar darum, weil die Erstgeborenen Ägyptens mit Eseln verglichen wurden; ferner halfen diese Israel bei ihrem Auszug aus Ägypten (denn es war keiner in Israel, der nicht viele Esel mitnahm), mit dem Silber und Golde Ägyptens beladen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:13:2,**Redeem with a sheep.** He gives a sheep to the <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein.<font color=d50505>«</font> and the firstling donkey is permitted to be used. The sheep is not sacred in the possession of the <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 13:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפדה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשה THOU SHALT REDEEM WITH A LAMB — one gives a lamb to the priest, and the first offspring of the ass is then permitted to be made use of, whilst the lamb remains in the priest’s possession with the character of a non-holy object (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולין — an ordinary animal) (cf. Bekhorot 9b)."

—3— **Sollst du mit einem Lamm auslösen,** er gibt dem Kohen ein Lamm (das Erstgeborene des Esels darf dann benutzt werden, und das Lamm ist in der Hand des Kohen ebenfalls unheilig [Bech. 9b]). 

---

////—1—//// 13:13:3,"**You must break its neck.** He breaks its neck with an ax from behind and kills it. He caused the <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein<font color=d50505>«</font> a monetary loss. Consequently, he suffers a loss of <font color=d50505>»</font>his<font color=d50505>«</font> money. "

§§—2—§§ 13:13:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וערפתו THEN THOU SHALT BREAK ITS NECK — one breaks its neck with a hatchet from behind and so slays it (Bekhorot 13a). The reason is: he (the owner of the ass) has caused a loss to the possessions of the priest (by not giving him the lamb), therefore must he suffer loss in his own possessions  (Mekhilta d['Rabbi Yishmael 13:13:2)."

—3— **Sollst du es durch einen Genickschlag töten,** er schlägt ihm mit einem Hackmesser ins Genick und tötet es; weil er dem Vermögen des Kohen Schaden gemacht hat, darum soll er auch an seinem Vermögen Schaden erleiden (Bech. 10b; Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:13:4,**Redeem every first-born male among your sons.** His five <font color=d50505>»</font>selaim<font color=d50505>«</font> redemption value is established in another place.

§§—2—§§ 13:13:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בניך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפדה AND ALL THE FIRSTBORN OF MAN AMONGST THY SONS SHALT THOU REDEEM — His redemption money is fixed in another passage (Numbers 18:16) at five Sela’im.

—3— **Und alles Erstgeborene des Menschen unter deinen Kindern sollst du auslösen,** fünf Schekel sind für seine Auslösung an anderer Stelle festgesetzt (Num. 18,16). 

---

////—1—//// 13:14:1,"**When your son asks you at a later time.** There is a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָחָר that is immediate and there is a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָחָר that denotes a later time, for example this one [of this verse], and, for example: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָחָר) tomorrow your children will say to our children.” in the matter of the children of Gad and Reuvein. "

§§—2—§§ 13:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישאלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בנך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר WHEN THY SON ASKETH THEE <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר — There is a usage of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר that refers to “now” (i. e. to the period of time that is nearest to “now” viz., to-morrow), and there is another usage of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר that refers to a day following after the lapse of some time, as, for example, this <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר here and as, for example, (Joshua 22:27) “That your children may not say to our children in time to come (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר)” which occurs in the chapter about the sons of Gad and the sons of Reuben (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:14:1)."

—3— **14. Wenn dich dein Sohn später fragen wird,** es gibt ein <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר, das gleich ist, und ein <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר, das erst später ist, wie dies; und wie (Jos. 22, 24), damit nicht eure Kinder später zu unseren Kindern sagen, bei den Söhnen Gads und den Söhnen Rubens (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:14:2,"**“What is this?”** [The question] of a dull child who is unable to ask a profound question and asks indefinitely, “What is this?” Elsewhere it states: “What are [the meanings] of the testimonies the statutes, and the laws, etc.?” That is the question of the wise son. The Torah thus speaks of four [different] sons: The dull one, the wicked one, the one who does not know what to ask and the one who asks wisely. "

§§—2—§§ 13:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זאת WHAT IS THIS? — This is the question of a dull child who has not sufficient understanding to question very profoundly and who therefore asks in an indefinite fashion, “What is this?” In another passage (Deuteronomy 6:20) it states, “[When thy son asketh thee…], What mean the testimonies and the statutes and the judgments … [which the Lord our God hath commanded you?]” This, however, is the question of a wise son. The Torah in mentioning four different explanations of the Passover sacrifice-rite to be given by a father to his children, is speaking in reference to four different types of son: the wicked son (12:25 and in the second half of 13:8), and one who has not sufficient understanding how to ask (in the first half of 13:8), and one who asks in an indefinite manner (13:14), and one who asks in a wise fashion (Deuteronomy 6:20) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:14:1; Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 10:4)."

—3— **Was ist dies,** das ist ein einfältiges Kind, das nicht tief zu fragen versteht; es fragt einfach, was ist dies; an anderer Stelle sagt er (Deut. 6, 20), was bedeuten die Zeugnisse, die Satzungen und die Rechte … ? Das ist die Frage eines weisen Kindes; die Torah spricht von vier Kindern, dem einfältigen, dem frevelhaften, dem, das nicht zu fragen versteht, und dem, das weise fragt (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:16:1,"And for <font color=d50505>»</font>totafos<font color=d50505>«</font> between your eyes. [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּלְטֹטָפֹת refers to] <font color=d50505>»</font>tephillin<font color=d50505>«</font> Since they consist of four compartments they are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טֹטָפֹת — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טַט in the Kathphi language is <font color=d50505>»</font>two<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פַּת in the Afriki language is <font color=d50505>»</font>two.<font color=d50505>«</font> Menachem records it in his <font color=d50505>»</font>machberes<font color=d50505>«</font> with: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַטֵּף) and <font color=d50505>»</font>speak<font color=d50505>«</font> to the south” and: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּטִּיפוּ — “Do not speak” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַטֵּף and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּטִּיפוּ being] terms for <font color=d50505>»</font>speaking,<font color=d50505>«</font> corresponding to: “and a reminder between your eyes” which is said in the first section, for whoever sees them tied between the eyes, will remember the miracle and speak about it. "

§§—2—§§ 13:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולטטפת this denotes the Tephillin; and because they consist of four houses (compartments) they are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טטפת, for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טט denotes “two” in Katpi and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פת in Afriki denotes “two״ (Sanhedrin 4b). Menachem ben Seruk, however, placed it in the same section (gave it the same meaning) as, (Ezekiel 21:2) “And speak (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הטף) to the south״; and as, (Micah 2:6) “speak ye (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תטיפו) not”; so that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טטפת would be an expression denoting “speaking”, and corresponds to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולזכרון (in v. 9 where it really replaces <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טוטפת), because whoever sees them (the Tephillin) bound between the eyes will remember the miracle (so that they become a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכרון, a reminder) and will speak about it (so that they become a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טטפת. something that causes one to speak about the miracle)."

—3— **16. Zum Schuck,** Tefillin (Onkelos), wegen der vier Abteilungen werden sie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טטפת genannt, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טט bedeutet auf Katpi zwei und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פת auf Afriki zwei (Sanhedrin 4b); Menachem verbindet es mit (Jech. 21, 2), weissage dem Süden; (Mich. 2, 6) weissaget nicht, in der Bedeutung von sprechen, wie (V. 9) zum Gedenken auf deinem Haupte, das im ersten Abschnitt steht; denn, wer sie aufs Haupt gebunden sieht, gedenkt des Wunders und spricht davon.

////—1—//// 13:17:1,"**When Pharaoh sent away, etc. Elohim did not lead them.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָחָם means] He did not lead them, as in: “Go, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְחֵה) lead the nation!” [or] “When you go, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּנְחֶה) it will lead you.” "

§§—2—§§ 13:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה... <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נחם AND IT CAME TO PASS WHEN PHARAOH HAD SENT [THE PEOPLE AWAY] THAT GOD GUIDED THEM NOT — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נחם means He guided them, just as, (Exodus 32:34) “Go, guide (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נחה) the people”, and (Proverbs 6:22) “when thou goest it shall guide (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תנחה) thee”."

—3— **17. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשלח. Es war, als Pharao entließ …, führte sie nicht,** leitete sie, wie (32, 34) geh, führe das Volk; (Spr. 6, 22) wenn du wandelst, geleitet sie dich. 

---

////—1—//// 13:17:2,"**Because it was the shortest route** And it was, therefore, easy to return by that route to Egypt. There are many midrashic explanations. "

§§—2—§§ 13:17:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרוב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא BECAUSE IT WAS NEAR, and it would therefore be easy to return by the same route to Egypt. — Of Midrashic explanations there are many (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:17)."

—3— **Weil er nahe war,** und bequem, um auf jenem Wege nach Ägypten zurückzukehren; agadische Midraschim gibt es hierzu viele. 

---

////—1—//// 13:17:3,"**Should they encounter war.** For example the war of: “And the Amaleikites and Canaanites came down, etc.” Had they travelled a straight route they would [then] have returned [to Egypt]. If, when He led them on a round-about route, they said, “Let us appoint a leader and let us return to Egypt,” then had He led them on a straight [route] how much more so [would they have said so]. "

§§—2—§§ 13:17:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בראתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלחמה WHEN THEY SEE WAR — For instance the war mentioned in (Numbers 14:45) “Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites came down etc.” If they had proceeded by the direct route they would have then turned back. This is evident, for what would have been the case? If, when He led them about by a circuitous way, they said, (Numbers 14:4) “Let us appoint another chief and go back to Egypt”, had He led them by a direct route how much the more certainly would they have spoken so."

—3— **Wenn sie Krieg sähen,** wie den Krieg (Num. 14, 45), da kam der Amaleki und der Kenaani herab; wenn sie den geraden Weg gegangen wären, so wären sie umgekehrt; wenn sie schon, als Er sie einen gekrümmten Weg führte, sagten (Num. 14,4), wir wollen uns einen Führer einsetzen und nach Mizraim zurückkehren, um wieviel mehr erst, wenn Er sie den einfachen Weg geführt hätte (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:17:4,"**[The people] might change their minds.** They might have second thoughts about going out, and set their hearts to return [to Egypt]. "

§§—2—§§ 13:17:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ינחם PERADVENTURE [THE PEOPLE] REPENT — peradventure they cherish a different thought (they change their mind) about having gone out and set their hearts on returning (cf. Rashi on Genesis 6:6).

—3— **Dass nicht bereue,** darüber nachdächten, dass sie ausgezogen waren, und sich vornähmen, zurückzukehren. 

---

////—1—//// 13:18:1,**He led [the people] round-about.** [Meaning:] He led them round-about from the direct route to the round-about route.

§§—2—§§ 13:18:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסב means HE LED THE PEOPLE ABOUT from the direct route to a circuitous route.

—3— **18. Da ließ abbiegen,** Er Hess sie vom einfachen Wege zu einem gekrümmten Wege abbiegen. 

---

////—1—//// 13:18:2,"**Reed Sea.** As if it were written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְיַם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוּף — to the Reed Sea. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוּף is a term meaning a marsh in which reeds grow, as in “she put him (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּסּוּף) in the reeds.” [or:] “The flags (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וָסוּף) and reeds will wither.” "

§§—2—§§ 13:18:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף TO THE RED SEA. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף has the meaning of a marshy tract in which reeds grow; examples are: (Exodus 2:3) “She placed him in the reeds (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בסוף)”; (Isaiah 19:6) “The flags and the reeds (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וסוף) shall wither”.

—3— **Schilfmeer**, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוף; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לים = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ים bedeutet einen Sumpf, in dem Rohr wächst, wie (Ex. 2, 3), sie setzte es ins Schilf; (Jes. 19, 6) Rohr und Schilf welken. 

---

////—1—//// 13:18:3,"**Armed.** The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲמוּשִים means <font color=d50505>»</font>armed<font color=d50505>«</font>. (Because He took them on a round-about route in the desert, He caused them to go up armed. For had He taken them by way of settled areas they would not have armed themselves with all their needs, but, rather, as one traveling from place to place, whose intention it is to obtain what he needs there. But when he sets out into the wilderness he must prepare for himself all his needs. This verse was written only to make it understandable to the ear — so that you not say: during the war against Amaleik and the wars against Sichon and Og, and Midian, — from where did they have weapons that enabled Israel to defeat them by the sword? — From an old Rashi manuscript.) Likewise, it is written: “You shall pass by with arms.” Similarly, Onkelos translates [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲמֻשִים] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְזָרְזִין — <font color=d50505>»</font>armed<font color=d50505>«</font>, as [he translates] “And he armed his servants” by “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזָרֵיז .” An alternate explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַחֲמֻשִׁים one of every five went out [of Egypt] and four-fifths died during the three days of darkness. "

§§—2—§§ 13:18:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחמשים — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמשים means provided with weapons (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:19:2). — [Because He led them by a circuitous route through the wilderness He brought it about that they went up from Egypt well-provided; for had He led them circuitously by the route of an inhabited district they would not have provided for themselves every thing that they needed, but only a part, like a person who is travelling from place to place and intends to purchase there whatever he will require. But if he were setting out for the wilderness he must provide all that he will require. — This verse (statement in the verse) is written only with the view of making the ear understand (preparing you for a later statement) viz., that you should not wonder with regard to the war with Amalek and the war with Sihon and Og and Midian where they obtained weapons, since they smote them with the sword]. In a similar sense it says, (Joshua 1:14) “and ye shall pass over armed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמשים)”. Onkelos, too, translated it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזרזין which signifies “armed” in Aramaic, just as he translates the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירק in (Genesis 14:14) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חניכיו which means, “And he armed his trained servants” by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזריז. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמשים is: only one out of five (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמשה) went forth from Egypt, and four parts of the people died during the three days of darkness because they were unworthy of being delivered (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:19:3; cf. Rashi on 10:22)."

—3— **Ausgerüstet, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמושים** hießt nichts anderes als ausgerüstet (Mech.), weil Er sie in die Wüste abbiegen ließ, dadurch veranlasste Er sie, ausgerüstet auszuziehen; denn, wenn Er sie durch bewohntes Land geführt hätte, so hätten sie sich nicht mit allem ausgerüstet, was sie brauchten; sondern wie ein Mensch, der von Ort zu Ort zieht und dort zu kaufen gedenkt, was er braucht; wer aber in die Wüste zieht, muss alles Nötige für sich vorbereiten; dieser Vers steht nur, um (das Spätere) dem Ohr verständlich zu machen, damit du nicht beim Krieg mit Amalek und beim Krieg mit Sichon und Og und Midjan fragest, woher hatten sie Waffen, dass sie jene mit dem Schwerte schlugen? (Alter Raschitext). So sagte er auch (Jos. 1, 14), und ihr zieht gerüstet hinüber, so übersetzt auch Onkelos gerüstet; wie (Gen. 14, 14), er bewaffnete seine Geübten, er rüstete sie. Andere Erklärung: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמשים ein Fünftel zog aus, und vier Fünftel waren an den drei Tagen der Finsternis gestorben (Mech.).
