////—1—//// 13:19:1,"**He had bound by oath.** He (Yoseif) made them swear that they will make their children swear. Why did he not bind his sons by oath that they immediately carry him to the land of Canaan, as Yaakov bound [them] by oath? Yoseif said: “I was a ruler in Egypt, and I had sufficient power to do [so], but the Egyptians will not permit my sons to do [so].” He therefore bound them by oath that when they will be redeemed and go out of there, that they carry him [with them]. "

§§—2—§§ 13:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השביע HE HAD STRAITLY ADJURED — He had made them swear that they would make their children swear. But why did he not make his sons swear that they would take him to the land of Canaan immediately on his death, as Jacob had made his sons swear? Joseph said: I was a ruler in Egypt and I had sufficient power to do what my father desired; but my sons — the Egyptians will not permit them to do this. Consequently he made them swear that when they would be delivered and would go forth from there that they would take him up with them (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:19:8)."

—3— **19. Hatte beschworen** (zweimal), er hatte sie beschworen, dass sie ihre Kinder beschwören sollten. Warum aber beschwor er nicht seine Söhne, ihn sofort nach dem Lande Kenaan zu bringen, wie sie Jaakob beschworen hatte? Josef sagte aber, ich war Herrscher in Mizraim und hatte die Macht, es zu tun; aber meinen Söhnen werden die Ägypter nicht gestatten, es zu tun, darum beschwor er sie, dass, wenn sie erlöst und von dort ausziehen würden, sie ihn mitnehmen sollten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:19:2,**And then you must carry up my bones out of here with you.** It was his brothers that he bound by this oath. Consequently we learn from this that also the bones of <font color=d50505>»</font>all<font color=d50505>«</font> the brothers [lit. tribes] did they carry up with them as it says: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִתְּכֶם — <font color=d50505>»</font>with you<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 13:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעליתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עצמתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתכם THEN YE SHALL BRING UP MY BONES AWAY HENCE WITH YOU — It was his brothers whom he made swear thus; consequently this tells us that they (the Israelites who left Egypt) must have brought up with them the bones of all Jacob’s sons (lit., the tribes) since it is said “with you” (with your own bones) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 13:19:11)."

—3— **Dann nehmet meine Gebeine von hier mit euch hinauf,** seine Brüder beschwor er so; daraus lernen wir, dass sie auch die Gebeine aller Begründer der Stämme mit sich hinaufbrachten; da es heißt, mit **euch** (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 13:20:1,"**They journeyed from Sukkos.** On the second day, for on the first day they had come from Raamses to Sukkos. "

§§—2—§§ 13:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסעו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכת AND THEY JOURNEYED FROM SUCCOTH — on the second day, for on the first day they had come from Rameses to Succoth (Exodus 12:37)."

—3— **20. Sie brachen von Sukkot auf,** am zweiten Tage; denn am ersten gingen sie von Raamses nach Sukkot. 

---

////—1—//// 13:21:1,"**To lead them on the way** [The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל' of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַנְחֹתָם is] vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>patach<font color=d50505>«</font> which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְהַנְחוֹתָם, similar to: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַרְאֹתְכֶם the way in which to go” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַרְאוֹתְכֶם being the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְהַרְאוֹתְכֶם — to show. Here, too, [it means] <font color=d50505>»</font>to lead them<font color=d50505>«</font> by means of an agent. And who is this agent? The pillar of cloud. [Though] God Himself, in His glory, led it (the cloud) before them, nevertheless, He provided the pillar of cloud to lead them by its means for they travelled by means of the pillar of cloud. The pillar of cloud was not for providing light, but, rather, to show them the way. "

§§—2—§§ 13:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנחתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדרך TO GUIDE THEM IN THE WAY — It (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנחתם) is punctuated with Patach, because it (the word) is like <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְהַנְחוֹתָם (being a contracted form of this); similar is, (Deuteronomy 1:33) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַרְאֹתְכֶם the way in which ye shall go”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְהַרְאֹתְכֶם to show you. Thus, too, here: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנחתם means as much as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להנחותם to make them be guided i. e. by means of an agent. And who was this agent? The pillar of cloud — and the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory (Himself) led it before them. Nevertheless He Himself did not act as their immediate guide, but He provided the pillar of cloud that they might be guided by means of it, for, as a matter of fact, as the Scriptural account shows, it was by means of the pillar of cloud that they set forth on their journeys. The pillar of cloud was not for giving light to them but to show them the way."

—3— **21. Sie auf dem Wege zu führen,** das Lamed ist mit Patach punktiert; denn es ist = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להנחותם; wie (Deut. 1, 33) euch den Weg zu zeigen, den ihr gehen sollt = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותכם; auch hier, sie durch einen Boten zu führen; und wer war der Bote? Die Wolkensäule; der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, in Seiner Ehre führte sie selbst vor ihnen her, doch hatte Er die Wolkensäule dazu bestimmt, die Israeliten durch sie zu führen; denn sie folgten der Wolkensäule; die Wolkensäule war nicht zum Leuchten bestimmt, sondern ihnen den Weg zu zeigen. 

---

////—1—//// 13:22:1,"**He did not remove.** [I.e.,] God [did not remove] the pillar of cloud by day [nor] the pillar of fire at night. This tells us that the pillar of cloud gave way to the pillar of fire and the pillar of fire gave way to the pillar of cloud, that before one would depart the other would arrive. "

§§—2—§§ 13:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימיש means He — the Holy One, blessed be He — did not let depart (did not remove) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יומם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועמוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לילה THE PILLAR OF CLOUD BY DAY NOR THE PILLAR OF FIRE BY NIGHT. — This tells us (we may gather from this) that the pillar of cloud handed over the camp to the pillar of fire and the pillar of fire handed it over to the pillar of cloud — that before the one set the other rose (Shabbat 23b)."

—3— **22. Er ließ nicht weichen,** der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, die Wolkensäule am Tag und die Feuersäule in der Nacht; das lehrt, dass die Wolkensäule die Ankunft der Feuersäule abwartete und die Feuersäule die Ankunft der Wolkensäule abwartete; bevor die eine unterging, ging die andere auf (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:2:1,"**And have them turn back.** They kept moving nearer to Egypt the entire third day in order to mislead Pharaoh so that he might say: “They are lost in the wilderness,” as it is said: “Pharaoh said of the B’nei Yisrael, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישבו THAT THEY TURN backwards; all the third day they were moving nearer towards the Egyptians, in order to mislead Pharaoh, so that he should say: They have lost their way, as it is said, (v. 3) “so that Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel, [They are entangled in the land]”."

—3— **14, 2. Dass sie zurückkehren,** rückwärts, in der Richtung nach Mizraim näherten sie sich den ganzen dritten Tag, um Pharao irrezuführen, dass er sage, sie irren auf dem Wege umher; wie es weiter heißt, und Pharao wird von den Kindern Israel sagen … 

---

////—1—//// 14:2:2,"**And camp before Pi Hachiros** [Pi Hachiros] is <font color=d50505>»</font>Pisom,<font color=d50505>«</font> but was now called <font color=d50505>»</font>Pi Hachiros,<font color=d50505>«</font> because there they became free men (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּנֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חוֹרִין) They (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִירוֹת) were two high, upright rocks and the valley between them was called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פִּי (<font color=d50505>»</font>the mouth of<font color=d50505>«</font>) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַסְּלָעִים (of the rocks). "

§§—2—§§ 14:2:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>החירת AND ENCAMP BEFORE PI-HAHIROTH — This is identical with Pithom (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:2:2), but now it obtained the name of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>החירת, because there they became <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חורין free-men (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חירת is explained as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרות freedom). This was two high, precipitous rocks and the valley between them was called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הסלעים the mouth (opening) of the rocks."

—3— **Und vor Pihachirot lagern,** (Mech.) das ist Pitom und wurde jetzt Pihachirot (Tor der Freiheit) genannt, weil sie dort frei wurden; es waren dies zwei hohe, steile Felsen, und das Tal in der Mitte wurde Felsentor genannt. 

---

////—1—//// 14:2:3,"**Facing Ba’al Tzephon.** It alone was left from all the gods of Egypt, in order to mislead them — so that they might say that their god was [too] difficult [to defeat]. It is concerning this that Iyov expressly said, “He causes the nations to err so that he might destroy them.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:2:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צפון BEFORE BAAL-ZEPHON — It (the idol of this name) alone had been left by God of all the gods of Egypt and, this, too, in order to mislead them — that they should say that their god was a difficult one to overcome. It was with reference to this that Job expressly said, (Job 12:23) “He causes the nations to err (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְׂגִיא, is taken in the sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַשְׁגִיא from root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שגה to err) and then destroyeth them” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:2:2; cf. Rashi on this passage)."

—3— **Vor Baal Zefon,** dieser war allein von allen Götzen Ägyptens übriggeblieben, um sie irrezuführen, damit sie sprächen, ihr Abgott sei stark; und darauf sagt Job (12,23), Er führt Völker in die Irre und vernichtet sie (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:3:1,** Pharaoh will then say —** — when he will hear that they have turned to go backwards.

§§—2—§§ 14:3:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה THEN PHARAOH WILL SAY — when he hears that they are turning back. 

—3— **3. Dass Pharao spreche,** wenn er hören wird, dass sie rückwärts ziehen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:3:2,"**Of the B’nei Yisrael.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִבְנֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִשְׂרָאֵל means] <font color=d50505>»</font>of<font color=d50505>«</font> the B’nei Yisroel. Similarly: “God will fight <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָכֶם (for you)” [or:] “Say (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי), ‘He is my brother’” [meaning:] “Say of me.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:3:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל means <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני ABOUT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Similarly. (v. 14) “The Lord will fight <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם”, i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליכם for you; (Genesis 20:13) “Say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי, he is my brother” i. e. say about me. "

—3— **Von den Kindern Israel,** über die Kinder Israel; ebenso (V. 14), der Ewige wird für euch streiten, für euch; (Gen. 20,13) sage von mir, er ist mein Bruder, sage über mich. 

---

////—1—//// 14:3:3,"**They are confused.** [Meaning:] they are shut in and sunk <font color=d50505>»</font>serez<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — <font color=d50505>»</font>locked in<font color=d50505>«</font>. [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְבֻכִים being from] the same [root] as [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִבְכֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָם — “the depths of the sea.” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּעֵמֶק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַבָּכָא — “The valley of weeping.” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִבְּכִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְהָרוֹת — “from the depths of rivers” [Thus] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְבֻכִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֵם” means “They are locked in, in the wilderness — they do not know how to get out of it nor where to go.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:3:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נבכים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הם means, shut up and sunk deep. old French serrer. Of similar meaning are (Job 38:16) “the depths of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נבכי) the sea”; (Psalms 84:7) “in the vale of dejection (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבכא)”; (Job 28:11) “from the depths (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבכי) of the rivers.”"

—3— **Sie sind verirrt,** eingeschlossen und versenkt, eingeschlossen in anderen Sprachen; wie (Job 38, 16) die Schlösser des Meeres; (Ps. 84, 7) Tal der Bedrängnis; (Job 28, 11) die verborgene Quelle der Ströme; sie sind verirrt, in der Wüste eingeschlossen; sie wissen nicht, wie sie aus ihr herauskommen und wohin sie gehen sollen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:3:4,

§§—2—§§ 14:3:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נבכים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הם means THEY ARE SHUT UP in the wilderness — so that they do not know how to get out of it and whither they should go.

////—1—//// 14:4:1,"**I will be glorified through Pharaoh.** When God takes vengeance from the wicked His Name is magnified and glorified. So, too, is it stated: “I will take up judgment with him, etc.,” and afterwards: “I will be magnified, I will be sanctified and I will become known, etc. It also states: “There He broke the fiery arrows of the bow,” and afterwards: “God will be known in Judah.” It also states: “God has made Himself known, He has executed judgment” "

§§—2—§§ 14:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואכבדה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בפרעה AND I WILL BE HONOURED THROUGH PHARAOH — When the Holy One, blessed be He, takes vengeance on the wicked His name is magnified and honoured. Thus, too, it states, (Ezekiel 38:22, 23) “And I will plead against him [with pestilence and with blood etc.]”, and afterwards, “Thus I shall be magnified and sanctified etc.” And it states, (Psalms 76:3) “There He broke the fiery shafts of the bow”, and afterwards (after He has done this) (v. 2) “In Judah is God known. “Further it states, (Psalms 9:17) “The Lord is known because He executeth judgment” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:4:2)."

—3— **4. Dass ich durch Pharao verherrlicht werde;** wenn der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, an den Frevlern Vergeltung übt, wird Sein Name erhöht und geehrt; so sagt er auch (Jech. 38, 22), ich werde mit ihm rechten … und dann, ich werde gerühmt und geheiligt und erkannt werden … ferner heißt es (Ps. 76,4), dort zerbrach Er die Pfeile des Bogens, und dabei (V. 2), erkannt wird Gott in Juda; ferner (Ps. 9, 17), erkannt wird der Ewige, da Er Strafgericht vollzogen hat (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:4:2,**Through Pharaoh and his entire army.** [Pharaoh first because] he began sinning. Therefore punishment begin with him.

§§—2—§§ 14:4:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בפרעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חילו THROUGH PHARAOH AND THROUGH ALL HIS FORCES — He began the wrongdoing and with him began the punishment (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:4:2; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 7:28).

—3— **Durch Pharao und sein ganzes Heer,** er hatte mit der Sünde begonnen, und bei ihm fing die Strafe an (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:4:3,"**They did just that** [This is told to us] to relate their praises that they listened to Moshe and did not say: “How can we move nearer to our pursuers? We must, rather, flee.” But instead they said: “Our sole [mission] is [to obey] the words of the son of Amram. "

§§—2—§§ 14:4:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעשו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן AND THEY DID SO — This is stated in order to tell their praise — that they hearkened to Moses and did not say, How can we move nearer to our enemies; we ought rather to flee,” but they said, ‘‘It is ours only to carry out the bidding of the son of Amram” (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:4:3)."

—3— **Und sie taten so;** das verkündet ihr Lob, dass sie auf die Stimme Mosches hörten und nicht sagten, wie können wir uns unseren Verfolgern nähern, vielmehr müssen wir fliehen; sondern sie sagten, wir haben uns nur nach den Worten des Sohnes von Amram zu richten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:5:1,"**The king of Egypt was told.** He sent officials along with them. Once they reached the point of three days [journey], which had been fixed for them to go and to return and they (the officials) saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they came on the fourth day and told Pharaoh. On the fifth and sixth days they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh they went down into the sea. In the morning they chanted the <font color=d50505>»</font>shirah<font color=d50505>«</font> and that [day] was the seventh day of Pesach. It is for this reason the we read [in the Torah] the <font color=d50505>»</font>shirah<font color=d50505>«</font> on the seventh day [of Pesach]. "

§§—2—§§ 14:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים AND IT WAS TOLD THE KING OF EGYPT — He sent public officers with them, and as soon as they had reached the three days’ journey which he had fixed for them to go and return, and these perceived that they were not going back to Egypt, they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:5:1). On the fifth and sixth they pursued after them: on the night of the seventh day they went down into the sea and on the following morning they (the Israelites) sang the Song of Praise and this was the seventh day of Passover. And that is why we read “The Song” (Exodus 15:1 ff.) as the Scriptural lesson on the seventh day of the Festival (Megillah 31a; Seder Olam 5; cf. Sotah 12b)."

—3— **5. Da wurde dem König von Ägypten berichtet,** er hatte Beobachter mit ihnen geschickt; als sie nun die drei Tage erreicht hatten, die sie festgesetzt hatten, zu gehen, und zurück zukehren, und die Beobachter sahen, dass sie nicht nach Mizraim zurückkehrten, gingen sie und erzählten es Pharao am vierten Tag; am fünften und sechsten jagten sie ihnen nach, in der Nacht zum siebten stiegen sie zum Meer hinab, am Morgen sagten sie das Loblied, das ist der siebte Tag von Pessach, darum lesen wir am siebten Tag das Loblied vor (Mech.; Seder Olam 5; Megillah 31a). 

---

////—1—//// 14:5:2,"**Had a change [of heart]** — changed from what it had been, for he had [at first] said to them: “Set out! Get out from among my people.” His servants, too, had a change of heart, for earlier they had been saying to him: “How much longer will this man be a menace to us,” and now they changed [their minds] so as to pursue them because of their property which they gave them. "

§§—2—§§ 14:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהפך [AND THE HEART…] WAS TURNED — it was turned (changed) from what it had been, because he had said to them (Exodus 12:31) “Arise, go out from the midst of my people”, and his servants’ hearts were changed because formerly they had said to him, (Exodus 10:7) “How long shall this man be a snare unto us? [let the men go etc.]”. Now, however, they (their hearts) were changed, prompting them to pursue them, because of the property that they had handed over to them (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:5:3)."

—3— **Da verwandelte sich,** wandte sich von seiner früheren Meinung ab; denn, siehe, er hatte zu ihnen gesagt (12,31), macht euch auf und verlasset mein Volk; und auch das Herz seiner Diener verwandelte sich; denn früher hatten sie zu Pharao gesagt (10, 7), wie lange noch soll uns dieser zum Fallstrick sein; und jetzt wurden sie anderen Sinnes, ihnen nachzujagen wegen ihres Vermögens, das sie ihnen gegeben hatten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:5:3,**From serving us.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵעָבְדֵנוּ means] from serving us.

§§—2—§§ 14:5:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעבדנו means from serving us (i. e. the word is an infinitive with an objective suffix and not a noun signifying “from our service”, which would require <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵעֲבוֹדָתֵנוּ)."

—3— **Aus unserem Dienste,** dass sie uns nicht mehr dienen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:6:1,**He harnessed his chariot** — he himself.

§§—2—§§ 14:6:1,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאסר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רכבו AND HE MADE READY HIS CHARIOT — he himself (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:6:1)

—3— **6. Er bespannte seinen Wagen,** er selbst (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:6:2,"**And he took his people with him.** He enticed them with words: “We have been stricken and they have taken our property and we have sent them away. Come with me and I will not deal with you as other kings [do.] — It is the way of other kings that their servants go ahead of them in war, but I will go ahead of you.” As it is said: “Pharaoh drew near,” [meaning:] he drew himself near and rushed ahead of his armies. “It is the way of other kings to take the choice booty of whatever he chooses, but I will take an equal share with you,” as it is said: “I will share in the spoils.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:6:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמו AND TOOK HIS PEOPLE WITH HIM — he drew them on by fine words, as follows: “We have been stricken and they have taken our money and yet we have let them go free. Come with me and I will not behave with you as other kings. It is the way of other kings that their subjects go in front of them into the battle, but I will go in front of you” — as, indeed, it is said, (v. 10) “And Pharaoh <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקריב” (the Hiphil): which signifies he brought himself near and hastened in front of his army. — “It is the way of other kings to take the booty at the beginning as he chooses (to have first pick of the booty), but I will be equal to you in the division of the booty” — as, indeed, it states that he said, (Exodus 15:9) “I will divide the spoil”Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:6:2."

—3— **Und sein Volk nahm er mit sich,** er zog sie durch Worte mit, wir sind geschlagen worden, und sie haben unser Vermögen genommen, und wir haben sie entlassen; kommt mit mir, und ich werde euch nicht wie andere Könige behandeln; es ist Brauch bei anderen Konigen, dass ihre Diener vor ihnen in die Schlacht ziehen; ich aber werde euch voranziehen; so steht (V. 10), Pharao kam nahe, er näherte sich und eilte seinen Herren voran; es ist die Art anderer Könige, sich zuerst von der Beute das zu nehmen, was sie sich wählen; ich aber werde euch gleich sein bei der Teilung; so steht (15,9), ich werde die Beute teilen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:7:1,**Elite** [Meaning] selected. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּחוּר is in the singular form. Each and every chariot in this count was [especially] selected.

§§—2—§§ 14:7:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחור means CHOSEN. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחור is singular number — the idea is: each and every chariot in that number was a selected one.

—3— **7. Auserlesene,** ausgesuchte,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחור ist Einzahl, jeder einzelne Wagen in dieser Zahl war ausgesucht. 

---

////—1—//// 14:7:2,"**And all the chariots of Egypt.** [Meaning:] And along with them (the elite chariots), all the remaining chariots. From where did all these animals come? If you will say that they were of the Egyptians, but it is said: “All the flocks of the Egyptians died!” And if [you say that they] were of the Israelites, is it not said: “Also our flocks shall go with us?” Then whose were they?! [They were] of those who feared the word of God. It is from here that Rabbi Shimon would say: “The best of the Egyptians — kill him, the best of the snakes — crush his brains.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:7:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רכב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים signifies AND with these were ALL THE other CHARIOTS OF EGYPT. And whence came all these animals required for the chariots? If you say that they were from the cattle of the Egyptians — but you know it is stated, (Exodus 9:6) “And all the cattle of the Egyptians died”. And if you say that they were from the Israelites’ cattle — but is it not stated, (Exodus 10:26) “Our cattle, also, shall go with us”! Then whose were they? They were of those “who feared the word of the Lord” and saved their cattle by bringing them into their stables (Exodus 9:20). Deriving it from here (on account of this fact) R. Simeon said: The best amongst the Egyptians — kill him (otherwise he will afterwards devise evil against you); the best amongst the serpents — crush its brains (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:7:1)."

—3— **Und alle Wagen Ägyptens,** mit ihnen alle anderen Wagen; woher aber hatten sie die Tiere dazu? Wenn du sagst, von Ägypten; es heißt aber doch (9,6) es starben alle Herden Ägyptens, und wenn von Israel, es heißt aber doch (10, 26), und auch unsere Herden sollen mit uns gehen; von wem waren sie also? Von dem, der das Wort des Ewigen fürchtete (9, 20); von da sagte R. Schimon, selbst den Frommen unter den Ägyptern beseitige; der besten Schlange zertrümmere den Kopf (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:7:3,"**And commanders over all of them.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשָלִשִׁים means] army officers, as Onkelos translates it. "

§§—2—§§ 14:7:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושלשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלו means army-captains, as the Targum has it."

—3— **Und Anführer waren auf allen,** Heerführer, wie der Targum übersetzt. 

---

////—1—//// 14:8:1,"**Adonoy hardened the heart of Pharaoh.** Because he was not sure whether to pursue them, He hardened his heart so that he <font color=d50505>»</font>would<font color=d50505>«</font> pursue. "

§§—2—§§ 14:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחזק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND THE LORD ALLOWED THE HEART OF PHARAOH TO BE HARDENED — the meaning is, that he was in doubt whether to pursue or not, and He hardened his heart to pursue (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:8:1)."

—3— **8. Da machte der Ewige das Herz Pharaos fest,** denn er war schwankend, ob er verfolgen solle oder nicht, und Er machte sein Herz fest, dass er verfolgte (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:8:2,"**Highhandedly** I.e., with lofty and open might (daring) "

§§—2—§§ 14:8:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה WITH A HIGH HAND — with high and open daring (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:8:2).

—3— **Mit erhobener Hand,** mit hoher, offenkundiger Macht (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:10:1,**Pharaoh drew near** It should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפַרְעֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָרַב (in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַל conjugation). Why does it say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִקְרִיב — [in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִפְעִיל form]? He made himself draw near and he exerted himself to be ahead of them (his soldiers) as he had arranged with them.

§§—2—§§ 14:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקריב — It should have written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרב “and Pharaoh came near” — what is the force of the Hiphil <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקריב, “He caused to come near”? He made himself come near — he forced himself to go in front of them as he had arranged with them (cf. Rashi on v. 6)."

—3— **10. Und Pharao nahte,** es müsste stehen, Pharao <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרב (Kal), warum steht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקריב (Hiphil)? Er näherte sich und machte sich stark, vor ihnen herzuziehen, wie er mit ihnen abgemacht hatte. 

---

////—1—//// 14:10:2,"**Coming after them.** With one heart (mind), as one man. An alternate explanation: And behold the Egyptian (sing.) is coming after them: [meaning:] They saw the guardian angel of Egypt coming from the heavens to help the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 14:10:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחריהם [EGYPT] JOURNEYED AFTER THEM (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסע is singular) — the Egyptians journeyed after them with one mind and as one man (hence the use of the singular) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:10:3). Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחריהם is: the singular denotes that they saw, not the Egyptians, but the guardian angel of Egypt coming from heaven to assist the Egyptians. Thus is it explained in the Tanchuma (cf. Exodus Rabbah 21:5)."

—3— **Zog hinter ihnen her** (Einzahl), einmütig, wie ein Mann (Mech.); andere Erklärung: und siehe, Mizraim zog hinter ihnen her, sie sahen den Schutzengel Ägyptens vom Himmel kommen, um Ägypten zu helfen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 14:10:3,**They cried out.** They grasped the trait of their forefathers. Regarding Avraham it is written: “To the place where he stood.” Regarding Yitzchok: “To meditate (pray) in the field” Regarding Yaakov: “He reached the place (prayed in the place).”

§§—2—§§ 14:10:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצעקו AND THEY CRIED — they took to hand the handicraft of their fathers (they had recourse to prayer as their fathers had always done in times of trouble). In the case of Abraham it is said, (Genesis 19:27) “[And Abraham went] to the place where he had stood in prayer”. In the case of Isaac: (Genesis 24:63) “[He went out towards evening] to pray”. In the case of Jacob: (Genesis 28:11) “He prayed to the Omnipresent God” (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:10:4; Midrash Tanchuma, Vayera 9, and Rashi on the texts quoted)."

—3— **Da schrieen sie empor,** sie ergriffen den Brauch ihrer Väter (Mech.), bei Abraham heißt es (Gen. 19, 27), an den Ort, wo er zu stehen (beten) pflegte; bei Jizchak (Gen. 24, 63), auf dem Felde zu beten; bei Jaakob (Gen. 28,11), er traf auf den Ort (betete daselbst). 

---

////—1—//// 14:11:1,"**Were there not enough graves in Egypt.** [Meaning:] Is it due to a lack of graves, that there are not (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵין) graves in Egypt to be buried there, that you took us from there?” <font color=d50505>»</font>se por feilance de non foses<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 14:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המבלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קברים signifies, was it on account of lack of graves — because there were no graves in Egypt in which to be buried — that thou didst bring us out from there? old French si pour faillance de non fossés."

—3— **11. Hast du uns etwa darum, weil es … keine Gräber gibt;** etwa aus Mangel an Gräbern, weil es in Ägypten keine Gräber gibt, um darin begraben zu werden, von dort genommen? Ist es etwa aus Mangel, weil es dort keine Gräber gibt, in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:12:1,**That we told you in Egypt.** Where was it that they told him? “Let God look at you and judge.”

§§—2—§§ 14:12:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במצרים [THE WORD] THAT WE SPOKE UNTO THEE IN EGYPT — And where had they said this? (Exodus 5:21) “The Lord look upon you and judge!” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:11)

—3— **12. Das wir in Ägypten zu dir gesprochen haben,** und wann hatten sie es gesprochen? (5, 21) Der Ewige möge auf euch schauen und richten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:12:2,"**Than we should die in the desert.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִמֻּתֵנוּ means] than that we should die. Had it been vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>melopum<font color=d50505>«</font> it would have been explained as: <font color=d50505>»</font>than our death<font color=d50505>«</font>! But now that it is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>shuruk<font color=d50505>«</font> we explain it as: <font color=d50505>»</font>than that we should die.<font color=d50505>«</font> Similarly: “If only (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתֵנוּ) we would die.” Similarly: “If only (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתִי)” regarding Avshalom [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתִי meaning:] I would die, As in: “Till the day <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוּמִי forever,” [or:] “Until <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שוּבִי in peace,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוּמִי, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שוּבִי meaning:] that I arise, that I return. "

§§—2—§§ 14:12:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממתנו means THAN THAT WE SHOULD DIE. If the word had been punctuated with a Melopum (our <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִמּוֹתֵנוּ) it would have to be explained “than our death” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוֹתֵנוּ our death from the noun <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָוֶת) but now that it is punctuated with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שורק (our Kibbutz) it must be explained by “than that we should die”. And similar is, (Exodus 16:3) “Would that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתֵנוּ” i. e. “that we should die”; similar is, (II Samuel 19:1) “Would that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתִי” in the history of Absalom, which means “that I should die”. It is an infinitive like (Zephaniah 3:8) “Until the day <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קוּמִי for ever”, and as (II Chronicles 18:26) “Until the day <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שׁוּבִי in peace” — which signify <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאקום “that I shall arise”, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שאשוב “that I shall return”. "

—3— **Als dass wir sterben** (Zeitwort); wenn es aber mit Cholem punktiert wäre, müsste es erklärt werden, als unser Tod (Hauptwort); jetzt, da es mit Schurek punktiert ist, erklären wir, als dass wir sterben. Ebenso (16,3), oh, wären wir gestorben; ebenso (II Sam. 19,1), oh, wäre ich an deiner Stelle gestorben, bei Abschalom, dass ich doch gestorben wäre. Wie (Zeph. 3, 8), auf den Tag, da ich mich in Ewigkeit erhebe; (I Kön. 22, 27) bis ich in Frieden heimkehre; dass ich mich erhebe, dass ich heimkehre. 

---

////—1—//// 14:13:1,"**For the Egyptians you have seen [this day].** [I.e.,] the fact that you have [now] seen them is only this day. This is the day that you saw them, but you will never again [see them]. "

§§—2—§§ 14:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראיתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ means WHAT (the fact that) YE HAVE SEEN them (THE EGYPTIANS), is only <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום THIS DAY — to-day it it that ye see them, BUT YE SHALL NEVER AGAIN see them."

—3— **13. Denn, wie ihr die Ägypter gesehen habt;** dass ihr sie gesehen habt, ist nur noch heute; heute habt ihr sie gesehen, ferner werdet ihr es nicht mehr.

---

////—1—//// 14:14:1,**Adonoy will fight for you** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָכֶם means:] for you. Similarly: “For Adonoy is fighting <font color=d50505>»</font>for<font color=d50505>«</font> them.” Similarly: “Will you argue <font color=d50505>»</font>for<font color=d50505>«</font> God?” Similarly: “And the one who spoke <font color=d50505>»</font>for<font color=d50505>«</font> me” Similarly: “Will you argue <font color=d50505>»</font>for<font color=d50505>«</font> the Ba’al”

§§—2—§§ 14:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכם means He will fight on your behalf; similar is (v. 25) “For the Lord fighteth for them (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם)”; so too, (Job. 13:8) “will ye contend for God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאל)?” and thus, too, (Genesis 24:7) “and who spoke on my behalf (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי)”, and so, too, (Judges 6:31) “Will ye plead for Baal (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבעל)?”"

—3— **14. Wird für euch streiten,** euretwegen; ebenso (V. 25), denn der Ewige streitet für sie; ebenso (Job 13, 8), oder wollt ihr für Gott streiten; ebenso (Gen. 24, 7), der für mich gesprochen; ebenso (Richt. 6, 31), wollt ihr für den Baal kämpfen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:15:1,"**Why do you cry to Me?** [From this] we learn that Moshe was standing and praying [when] God said to him, “Now is not the time to pray <font color=d50505>»</font>at length,<font color=d50505>«</font> when Yisrael is in trouble.” An alternate explanation: “Why do you cry out? <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵלָי — This thing depends on Me, not on you.” [This is] similar to what is written elsewhere: “Concerning My sons and concerning My handiwork do you need to command Me?!” "

§§—2—§§ 14:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תצעק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי WHEREFORE CRIEST THOU UNTO ME? — there is no mention that he prayed to God concerning this, but this teaches us that Moses stood in prayer. Whereupon the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, “It is no time now to pray at length, when Israel is placed in trouble”. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תצעק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי (taking it in the sense of “Wherefore criest thou? <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי it is to Me — concerns Me”) — upon Me rests this matter and not upon thee. The idea contained in this explanation is similar to what is expressed elsewhere: (Isaiah 45:11) “Concerning My sons and concerning the work of My hands will ye command Me?” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:15:2)"

—3— **15. Was rufst du zu mir,** daraus lernen wir, dass Mosche stand und betete; da sagte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, zu ihm, jetzt ist nicht die Zeit, lange zu beten, da sich Israel in der Not befindet. Andere Erklärung: was rufst du zu mir, die Sache liegt mir ob und nicht dir, wie an anderer Stelle steht (Jes. 45, 11), wollt ihr mir für das Werk meiner Hände Befehle geben (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:15:2,"**Speak to the B’nei Yisrael and let them move on.** There is nothing for them to do but move on because the sea will not stand in their way. The merit of their ancestors as well as the trust they had in me, when they went out [of Egypt], is effective to split the sea for them. "

§§—2—§§ 14:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסעו SPEAK UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL THAT THEY JOURNEY ONWARDS — There is nothing for them to do but to journey on, for the sea will not stand in their way: their ancestors’ merits and their own, and the faith that they placed in Me so that they left Egypt will suffice to divide the sea for them (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:15:1; Shemot Rabbah 21:8)."

—3— **Sprich zu den Kindern Israel, dass sie aufbrechen,** sie sollen nur aufbrechen; denn das Meer hält vor ihnen nicht stand, es reichen hin die Frömmigkeit ihrer Väter und die ihrige und das Vertrauen, das sie auf mich setzten, dass sie auszogen, um ihnen das Meer zu spalten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:19:1,"**And went behind them.** To separate the Egyptian camp from the Israelite camp and to receive the arrows and the projectiles of the Egyptians. Everywhere else it says: “The angel of Adonoy” but here [it states] “The angel of Elokim.” “Elokim” wherever it occurs denotes only “judgment.” This teaches that Israel was placed in judgment at that moment, whether [they were worthy] to be saved or whether to be destroyed with the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 14:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאחריהם AND WENT BEHIND THEM to divide the camp of Egypt from the camp of Israel and to receive the arrows and the missiles of the Egyptians. Everywhere it says “The Angel of the Lord (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳)” whilst here we have The Angel of God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים).”! The name <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים really denotes, wherever it occurs, “Judge” (lit., “judgment”). Therefore the use of this term here teaches us that Israel was, at that moment, arraigned in judgment, whether to be saved or to be destroyed together with Egypt (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:19)."

—3— **19. Und begab sich hinter sie,** um zwischen dem Lager Ägyptens und dem Lager Israels zu trennen und die Pfeile und Wurfgeschoße Ägyptens aufzufangen. Überall sagt er, der Engel des Ewigen (Allbarmherzigen), und hier, Engel Gottes (des Richters), dieser Name (Gott) weist stets auf das Gericht hin; das lehrt, dass Israel in jener Stunde gerichtet wurden, ob sie gerettet oder mit Ägypten vernichtet werden sollten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:19:2,"**The pillar of cloud moved.** After it became dark and the pillar of cloud completed its tour over the camp [and gave way] to the pillar of fire, the cloud was not removed as it was usually removed in the evening — completely, but, rather, it continued to move behind them to make it dark for the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 14:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן AND THE PILLAR OF CLOUD WENT [FROM BEFORE THEM] — When it became dark and the pillar of cloud handed over the camp to the pillar of fire, the cloud did not go away as it was accustomed to go away altogether in the evening, but it went and betook itself behind them to make it dark for the Egyptians."

—3— **Da brach die Wolkensäule auf;** als es Nacht war und die Wolkensäule das Lager der Feuersäule übergab, entfernte sich die Wölke nicht vollkommen, wie sie sich abends zu entfernen pflegte, sondern sie brach auf und begab sich hinter Israel, um den Ägyptern dunkel zu machen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:20:1,"**It came between the Egyptian camp.** This can be compared to a person on a journey, with his son walking ahead of him. If highway men would come to kidnap him (the son), he would take him from in front and place him behind. Then, if a wolf would come up from behind he would place him (the son) in front. If highway men would approach from the front and wolves from behind, he would place him on his arm and fight them. So, too, [did God do for the Israelites]: “I led Ephraim (Israel) — He took them upon His arms.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:20:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים AND IT CAME BETWEEN THE CAMP OF EGYPT — A parable: it may be compared to one who is proceeding on a journey, his son walking in front of him. If, now, brigands come to capture him (the son), he takes him away from in front of him and places him behind himself. If a wolf then comes behind him he places him again in front. If brigands come in front of him and wolves behind him, he places him on his arm and fights against them. Thus did God do for Israel, as it says, (Hosea 11:3) “I led Ephraim — He took them upon His arms” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:19)."

—3— **20. Und kam zwischen das Lager Ägyptens,** das gleich einem Wanderer, vor dem sein Sohn hergeht; da nahen Räuber, um diesen wegzuführen; der Vater nimmt ihn vorn weg und stellt ihn hinter sich; da kommt ein Wolf von hinten, und der Vater stellt den Sohn wieder vor sich hin; da kommen Räuber von vorn und Wölfe von hinten, und der Vater nimmt das Kind auf den Arm und kämpft mit jenen; so(Hosch. 11, 3), ich habe Efraim geleitet, auf die Arme genommen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:20:2,**There was the cloud and darkness** — for the Egyptians.

§§—2—§§ 14:20:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והחשך AND THERE WAS CLOUD AND DARKNESS to the Egyptians.

—3— **Und es war Wolke und Finsternis** für Mizraim. 

---

////—1—//// 14:20:3,"**And lit up.** [I.e.,] the pillar of fire [lit up] the night for the Israelites and moved in front of them, as was usual for it to travel all night, while the darkness of the cloud was turned toward the Egyptians. "

§§—2—§§ 14:20:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאר AND IT — the pillar of fire — ILLUMINATED the night for the Israelites, and went before them as was its way to go every night, whilst the darkness of the cloud was turned towards the Egyptians."

—3— **Und es erleuchtete** die Feuersäule 

---

////—1—//// 14:20:4,"**They did not approach each other** [I.e.,] one camp to another. "

§§—2—§§ 14:20:4,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה SO THAT ONE APPROACHED NOT ANOTHER — [This does not mean that one person did not approach another but]: this camp did not approach that camp (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:20:2).

—3— **die Nacht** für Israel und zog wie gewöhnlich vor ihnen her, dass sie die ganze Nacht gehen konnten, und die Finsternis der Wolke war den Ägyptern zugewandt. **Und einer nahte dem anderen nicht,** ein Lager dem anderen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:21:1,"**With a strong east wind,** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּרוּחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָדִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַזָּה — with an east wind, which is the strongest of all the winds. It is this wind with which God punishes the wicked as it is said: “I will disperse them with the east wind.” [or:] “And east wind will come — the wind of God.” [or:] “The east wind has shattered you in the heart of the seas.” [or:] “He removed with His strong wind on the day of the east wind.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזה BY A POWERFUL EAST WIND — i. e. by the east wind which is the most powerful of the winds. This is the wind by which the Holy One, blessed be He, exacts punishment from the wicked, as it is said, (Jeremiah 18:17) “I will scatter them as with an east wind”; (Hosea 13:15) “An east wind shall come, the wind of the Lord”; (Ezekiel 27:26) “The east wind hath broken thee in the heart of the sea”; (Isaiah 27:8) “He hath removed her with His rough blast in the day of the east wind” (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:21:2)."

—3— **21. Mit einem starken Ostwind,** mit einem Ostwind, das ist der stärkste der Winde, das ist der Wind, mit dem der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, die Frevler bestraft (Mech.); so heißt es (Jer. 18, 17), wie der Ostwind zerstreue ich sie; (Hosch. 13, 15) der Ostwind wird kommen, der Wind des Ewigen; (Jech. 27,26) der Ostwind hat dich zerbrochen im Herzen der Meere; (Jes. 27, 8) Er sprach durch Seinen harten Wind am Tag des Ostes. 

---

////—1—//// 14:21:2,**And the waters were divided** — all the waters of the world.

§§—2—§§ 14:21:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבקעו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המים AND THE WATERS WERE DIVIDED — all the waters in the world (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:2:2).

—3— **Und das Wasser wurde gespalten,** alles Wasser in der Welt (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:23:1,All of Pharaoh’s <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס ** horse(s).** Was there only one horse?! This teaches us that all of them are considered before God as but one horse.

§§—2—§§ 14:23:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה (The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס is singular) — But was there only one horse? But the use of the singular teaches us that they were all accounted before the Omnipresent as only one horse (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:1:6).

—3— **23. Alle Roße Pharaos;** war es denn nur ein Roß (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס)? Das lehrt, dass alle vor dem Ewigen einem Roß gleichgeachtet waren (Mech. 15, 2). 

---

////—1—//// 14:24:1,"**The morning watch.** The three parts of the night are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַשְׁמוּרוֹת, and the one before the morning is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַשְׁמֹרֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַבֹּקֶר — “The morning <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַשְׁמֹרֶת .” It is my opinion that because the night is divided into watches for the song of the ministering angels, one group [of angels] after another, in three parts, therefore, it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַשְׁמוֹרֶת . It is for this reason that Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַטְּרַת — [meaning: <font color=d50505>»</font>a watch<font color=d50505>«</font>]. "

§§—2—§§ 14:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באשמרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הבקר IN THE MORNING WATCH — The three divisions of the night are each called an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשמורה “a watch” (Berakhot 3b), and that which immediately precedes the morning is called “the morning watch”. I am of opinion that because the night is divided for the watches (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משמרות) of the song of the ministering angels — company after company — into three divisions, therefore each division of the night is termed, for all purposes, an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשמרת (another form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משמר the angel’s watch), and this is what Onkelos has in mind when he translates <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשמרת by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מטרת."

—3— **24. In der Morgennachtwache,** die drei Drittel der Nacht werden Nachtwachen genannt (Berach. 3b), und jene unmittelbar vor dem Morgen nennt er Morgennachtwache; ich meine, weil die Nacht für die Gesangesabteilungen der Engel des Dienstes, für eine Abteilung nach der anderen, in drei Teile geteilt ist, darum wird jeder Teil eine Wache genannt; so übersetzt auch Onkelos <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מטרת, Wache. 

---

////—1—//// 14:24:2,"**Gazed down.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּשְׁקֵף means literally] he gazed; as if to say: He turned His attention to them to destroy them. Onkelos’ translation of it as: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאִסְתְּכֵי, is also a term referring to <font color=d50505>»</font>gazing<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְֹדֵה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צֹפִים [which Onkelos translates as:] the field of the gazers. "

§§—2—§§ 14:24:2,"‎ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישקף means HE LOOKED, as much as to say, He turned towards them to destroy them (cf. Rashi on Genesis 18:16), and its rendering in the Targum, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואסתכי, is also an expression denoting looking, just as he translates (Numbers 23:14), “the field of the watchers (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צפים)” by “the field of ,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סכותא” which denotes “looking”."

—3— **Schaute,** blickte, das heißt, Er wandte sich ihnen zu, um sie zu vernichten; der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אסתבי, das bedeutet ebenfalls schauen, wie (Num. 23, 14) Feld der Wächter, Feld des Schauens. 

---

////—1—//// 14:24:3,**Through the pillar of fire and cloud.** The pillar of cloud descended and made it (the sea floor) like clay and the pillar of fire heated it up so that the horses’ hooves fell off.

§§—2—§§ 14:24:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעמוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וענן THROUGH THE PILLAR OF FIRE AND CLOUD — viz., the pillar of cloud descended and made it (the bed of the sea) like clay, and the pillar of fire made it boiling hot so that the horses’ hoofs fell off (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:24)."

—3— **In einer Säule von Feuer und Wolke,** die Wölkensäule, senkte sich herab und machte es weich wie Lehm, und die Feuersäule erhitzte es, dass die Hufe ihrer Roße abfielen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:24:4,"**And He caused panic.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּהָם is derived from] the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְהוּמָה — confusion, <font color=d50505>»</font>estordison,<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French (tumult, confusion). He put them into a state of confusion; [i.e.] He took away their senses. We learned in the Chapters of R. Eliezer the son of R. Yose haGlili: wherever the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְהוּמָה is used, it indicates a thunderous noise and the following is the forerunner of them all: “And God thundered with a great sound, etc. upon the Plishtim (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְהֻמֵּם) and threw them into confusion.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:24:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהם has the meaning of confusion. old French estordison. He cast them into confusion; He took away their ensigns. And we read in the Chapters of Rabbi Eliezer, the son of Rabbi José, the Galilean: Wherever it speaks of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהומה (forms from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המם) it signifies a thundering sound; and the following passage is the father of all of them (i. e. that from which this meaning is quite evident): (I Samuel 7:10) “And the Lord thundered with a great sound … upon the Philistines and discomfited them (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהמם)”."

—3— **Und verwirrte,** bedeutet Betäubung, Verwirrung in anderen Sprachen; Er verwirrte sie, nahm ihnen die Feldzeichen fort (Mech.). Wir lernen in den Pirke R. Elieser b. R. Jose Hagelili, überall, wo der Ausdruck Verwirrung vorkommt, bedeutet er lauten Donner; und dies ist die Beweißtelle für alle (I Sam. 7, 10); und der Ewige ließ lauten Donner über den Pelischtim erschallen und verwirrte sie. 

---

////—1—//// 14:25:1,**He removed the wheels of their chariots.** As a result of the fire the wheels burnt up causing the chariots to be dragged and those who were sitting in them were thrown about causing their limbs to break apart.

§§—2—§§ 14:25:1,‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרכבותיו AND HE REMOVED THEIR CHARIOT WHEELS — Through the power of the fire of the pillar of fire the wheels were burnt and the chariots were thus dragged along and those who were sitting in them were thrown about and their limbs were all put out of joint (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:25).

—3— **25. Und er nahm die Räder seiner Wagen fort,** durch die Kraft des Feuers verbrannten die Räder, dass die Wagen geschleift und die Insaßen hin und hergeworfen und ihre Glieder erschüttert wurden (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:25:2,"**And made them move heavily.** [He moved them] with a movement that was heavy and hard for them — in the same measure that they (Egypt) meted out. [Egypt acted thus:] “He <font color=d50505>»</font>hardened<font color=d50505>«</font> his heart, he and his servants;” here, too, “He treated them <font color=d50505>»</font>hard<font color=d50505>«</font> (harshly).” "

§§—2—§§ 14:25:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וינהגהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכבדות signifies: And He treated them with a treatment that was hard and harsh to them. In the measure that they (the Egyptians) had meted out to the Israelites was it meted out to them, for (9:34) “He hardened his heart, he and his servants”, and therefore here: “He treated them (the Egyptians) in a hard manner” (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:25)."

—3— **Und führte es mit Beschwerlichkeit,** mit einer Führung, die schwer und schmerzhaft für sie war, mit dem Maße, mit dem sie gemessen hatten, (9,34) da machte er sein Herz fest <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבד, er und seine Knechte, dafür hier, Er führte das Lager mit Beschwerlichkeit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבדות (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:25:3,"**Is fighting for them against Egypt.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּמִצְרַיִם means:] against the Egyptians. An alternate explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּמִצְרַיִם: — <font color=d50505>»</font>in the land of Egypt<font color=d50505>«</font> [viz.] that just as these are being struck on the sea, so, too, are those left <font color=d50505>»</font>in Egypt<font color=d50505>«</font> being struck. "

§§—2—§§ 14:25:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נלחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במצרים FIGHTETH FOR THEM <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במצריים — means against the Egyptians. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במצרים is: in the land of Egypt, for just as these were smitten at the Sea so, too, were smitten those who remained in Egypt (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:25)."

—3— **Kämpft für sie gegen Mizraim,** gegen die Ägypter; andere Erklärung: im Mizraim, im Lande Ägypten; denn, wie diese am Meere geschlagen wurden, so wurden auch jene geschlagen, die in Mizraim geblieben waren (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:26:1,**And the water will come back.** [The waters] that were standing erect as a wall will return to their place and cover the Egyptians.

§§—2—§§ 14:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המים means THE WATERS that were standing erect as a wall SHALL RETURN to their places and form a cover over the Egyptians.

—3— **26. Dass das Wasser zurückkehrte,** das wie eine Mauer aufgerichtet dastand; es sollte an seine Stelle zurückkehren und die Ägypter bedecken. 

---

////—1—//// 14:27:1,**Toward morning.** At the time that the morning <font color=d50505>»</font>turns<font color=d50505>«</font> to come.

§§—2—§§ 14:27:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפנות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקר AT THE TURNING OF THE MORNING at the time when the morning turns to come). 

—3— **27. Um die Morgenwende,** um die Zeit, da der Morgen anzubrechen beginnt. 

---

////—1—//// 14:27:2,**To its strength.** — to its <font color=d50505>»</font>original<font color=d50505>«</font> strength.

§§—2—§§ 14:27:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאיתנו means TO ITS ORIGINAL STRENGTH (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:27).

—3— **Zu seiner früheren Kraft,** seiner früheren Stärke (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:27:3,"**Were fleeing toward it.** Because they were confused and in panic, they ran <font color=d50505>»</font>toward<font color=d50505>«</font> the waters. "

§§—2—§§ 14:27:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקראתו FLED TOWARDS IT — because they were thrown into confusion and were bewildered and on that account ran towards it.

—3— **Flohen ihm entgegen,** sie waren verwirrt und bestürzt und liefen dem Wasser entgegen. 

---

////—1—//// 14:27:4,"**Adonoy overturned.** As a person who stirs a pot and overturns that which is on top to the bottom and that which is at the bottom to the top, so, too, did they (the Egyptians) go up and down and were broken apart in the sea; and God kept them alive so that they receive the pain [longer]. "

§§—2—§§ 14:27:4," '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וינער <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה AND THE LORD OVERTHREW (or, shook out or emptied out) — as a person empties out a pot, turning what is on top underneath and what is underneath on top: thus they were emptied out of their chariots and they rose and fell till at last they were broken to pieces in the sea, and the Holy One, blessed be He, put vitality (strength) in them so that they could bear the pain (and thus their agony was protracted) (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:27)."

—3— **Und der Ewige schüttete,** wie ein Mensch, der einen Topf ausschüttet und das Obere nach unten und das Untere nach oben wendet; so stiegen sie empor und sanken hinab und zerschellten im Meere; und der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, gab ihnen Leben, die Schmerzen zu erdulden (Mech.). Er schüttete, Targ. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שניק, ist ein Ausdruck für hin und her werfen im Aramäischen und kommt häufig in agadischen Midraschim vor. 

---

////—1—//// 14:27:5,**Stirred.** [Onkelos translates it:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשַׁנֵּיק which is a term meaning <font color=d50505>»</font>to stir<font color=d50505>«</font> in Aramaic. There are many such usages in Midrash Aggadah.

§§—2—§§ 14:27:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וינער — Onkelos renders this by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושניק which is an expression for confounding in Aramaic, and there are many examples of it in the Agadic expositions."


---

////—1—//// 14:28:1,"**They covered the chariots, etc.** **including Pharaoh’s entire army.** This is usual for [Biblical] verses to write a redundant <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְכָל all its vessels you shall make of copper.” Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְכֹל) all the vessels of the Mishkon in all its service.” [or:] “and their pegs and their ropes (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְכָל) and all their vessels.” This is done only for the purpose of style. "

§§—2—§§ 14:28:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכסו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרכב ... <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה AND COVERED THE CHARIOTS … AND ALL THE FORCES OF PHARAOH — in regard to the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל, this is the way of Scripture verses (of Biblical Hebrew) to write a redundant <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל, as in (Exodus 27:3) “all (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל) its vessels shalt thou make of copper”.. So, too, (Exodus 27:19) ‘‘all (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל) the vessels of the dwelling in all the service thereof”; (Numbers 4:32) “and their pins and their cords and all (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לכל) their vessels”. It is only an elegancy of style."

—3— **28. Und bedeckte die Wagen, das ganze Heer Pharaos,** so ist die Art der Verse, ein übriges Lamed zu schreiben, wie (27, 3), alle seine Geräte mache aus Kupfer, ebenso (27,19), alle Geräte der Wohnung bei ihrem ganzen Dienst; (Num. 4, 32) ihre Pflöcke und ihre Seile, alle ihre Geräte; und es hat nur stilistische Bedeutung. 

---

////—1—//// 14:30:1,"**Yisrael saw the Egyptians dead.** — because the sea expelled them (the Egyptians) onto its shore, so that Yisrael would not say: “Just as we are coming up from this side so, too, are they coming up from the other side, at a distance from us and they will pursue us.” "

§§—2—§§ 14:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מת AND ISRAEL SAW THE EGYPTIANS DEAD — because the sea threw them out on its shore in order that the Israelites should not say: “Just as we have come up from out of the sea on this part, so they have come up on another part of this shore, but far away from us, and they will pursue us” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:31:1; Pesachim 118b; Arakhin 15a)."

—3— **30. Israel sah die Ägypter tot,** das Meer warf sie ans Ufer, damit nicht Israel sage, wie wir auf dieser Seite heraufgekommen sind, so steigen sie auf der anderen Seite, von uns entfernt, wieder hinauf und werden uns nachjagen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 14:31:1,"**The great hand.** [Meaning:] the great power which was effected by the hand of God. There are many meanings that fit the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָד, and they all signify the actual <font color=d50505>»</font>hand<font color=d50505>«</font> and the one explaining it should fit the meaning according to the context. "

§§—2—§§ 14:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגדלה denotes THE GREAT power which the HAND of the Holy One, blessed be He, had exercised. There are many meanings that are appropriate to the expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יד, hand, but all of them really signify the actual hand, and he who is explaining it must adapt the language according to the meaning of the passage."

—3— **31. Die große Hand,** die große Tat, welche die Hand des Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, vollbracht hatte; viele Bedeutungen sind in dem Wort Hand enthalten, und alle decken sich mit dem eigentlichen Begriff Hand, nur muss der Erklärer den Ausdruck nach dem Zusammenhang des Satzes wählen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:1:1,"**Then Moshe sang.** [I.e.,] <font color=d50505>»</font>Then,<font color=d50505>«</font> when Moshe saw the miracle, it entered his mind (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׁיָּשִׁיר) to sing a song. Similarly: “Then <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְדַבֵּר Yehoshua.” Similarly: “And a house <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַעֲשֶׂה for Pharaoh’s daughter,” [meaning:] he thought in his heart to make it for her. Here, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָשִׁיר [means] his heart told him that he should sing, and he did so [as is immediately added:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיֹּאמְרוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֵאמֹר and they said, ‘I will sing to Adonoy’” Similarly in the case of Yehoshua — when he saw the miracle, his heart told him to speak, and he did so [as it says:] “And he said before the eyes of Israel.” This also applies to the Song of the Well, which begins with: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָשִׁיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִשְׂרָאֵל it explicitly states afterwards: “Come up, you Well — sing to it” [similarly:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִבְנֶה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁלֹמֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּמָה, which the Sages of Israel explained that he <font color=d50505>»</font>wanted<font color=d50505>«</font> to build [an altar for an idol] but he did not [actually] build one. We learn from this that the prefix letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' is used to express intention. All of the above is to satisfy [the verse’s] plain meaning. However, its midrashic explanation: Our Sages, of blessed memory, said: From here we derive an allusion that the resurrection of the dead [has its source] in Scripture. This applies to all [the examples cited] except for the one regarding Shlomo which they explained “he intended to build but did not build.” One cannot say and explain this usage the same way as other things written in the future tense and, yet, referring to the present; for example: “Thus (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַעֲשֶׂה) is Iyov doing” [or:] “At the command of God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַחֲנוּ) they encamp” [or:] “Sometimes the cloud is [on the Mishkon].” This is because they are things that were continuously happening and they can accept both future and past. But this (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָשִׁיר and the other examples) which was only a one-time occurrence cannot be explained in these terms. "

§§—2—§§ 15:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה THEN SANG MOSES — with regard to the usage of the future <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר, the meaning is: THEN — i. e. when he saw the miracle it entered his mind that HE WOULD SING a song. Similar is, (Joshua 10:12) “Then Joshua would speak (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידבר)”; and similar, (1 Kings 7:8) “and a house he would make (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעשה) for Pharaoh’s daughter”, which signifies “he purposed in his heart that he would make it for her”. So, also, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר here signifies: his heart told him that he should sing, and thus did he actually do, as it states, “and they (Moses and Israel) spake as follows, ‘I will sing unto the Lord’”. And in the same way, in the case of Joshua, it means: then (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>או) — when he saw the miracle mentioned in that narrative — his heart told him (prompted him) to speak, and thus did he actually do, as it is stated, “and he spake before the eyes of all Israel”. The same applies to the Song of the Well (Numbers 21:17) which begins with the words: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל, “then would Israel sing”; it expresses the intention quite plainly in the following words, “Come up, O Well — sing ye unto it” (i. e. these words are a call to the people to sing to it after Israel had expressed their intention so to do and are not part of the song itself which begins with the words that follow). With regard to (1 Kings 11:7) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יבנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלמה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במה our Rabbis explained that He proposed to build a high place for Chemosh but actually did not build it (Sanhedrin 91b). This, too, teaches us that the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י as a prefix of the imperfect is used in reference to intention to do a thing. This explanation serves to settle the literal meaning of the text. But so far as its Midrashic explanation is concerned our Rabbis, of blessed memory, said: from here (i. e. from the fact that the future tense is used) we may derive an intimation that the tenet of the Resurrection of the Dead is from the Torah (is alluded to, although only by inference, in the Torah) (Sanhedrin 91b). And thus, also, do they explain in the case of all them (all of the examples quoted) except in the case of that referring to Solomon which they explained in the sense that he purposed to build a high place but did not build it. — One cannot say that this can be appropriately explained in the same way as one explains other passages which are written in the future tense, but which really refer to an immediate action (i. e. to a then present time); for example, (Job. 1:5) “Thus was Job doing (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעשה)”; (Numbers 9:18) “At the command of the Lord were they encamping (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יחנו)”; (Numbers 9:20) “And there were occasions when the cloud was (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה) upon the tabernacle”, because these were each of them something that was continuously happening, and there is proper to it either the future tense or the past tense (cf. Rashi on Genesis 29:3). But this (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר and other passages quoted) which happened only at the particular moment mentioned (once and once only), one cannot fittingly explain in this sense (i. e. of continuous action)."

—3— **15, 1. Damals sang Mosche,** damals, als er das Wunder sah, fasste den Entschluss, das Lied zu singen (Zukunft); ebenso (Jos. 10,12), damals sprach Josua; ebenso (I Kön. 7, 8), ein Haus baute er für die Tochter Pharaos, er dachte in seinem Herzen, es für sie zu bauen; auch hier <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר (Zukunft), sein Herz sagte ihm zu singen, und er tat so; 

---

////—1—//// 15:1:2,"**For He is most high.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָּאֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָּאָה is as Onkelos translates it. (An alternate explanation: The repetition [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָאֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָּאָה] intends to convey that He did something that is impossible for a human to do. When he (the human) fights against his fellow man and overpowers him, he will throw him from his horse, whereas, here: “The horse <font color=d50505>»</font>and<font color=d50505>«</font> its rider he threw into the sea.” And regarding anything that cannot be done by anyone else [except Him], the correct expression is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גֵאוּת (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גָאָה) as in: “For (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גֵאוּת) gloriously has He done.” Similarly, everywhere in the <font color=d50505>»</font>Shira<font color=d50505>«</font> you will find repetitive expressions, [e.g.,] “the <font color=d50505>»</font>strength<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>retribution<font color=d50505>«</font> of God was the cause of my deliverance.” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>Adonoy<font color=d50505>«</font> is the master of war <font color=d50505>»</font>Adonoy<font color=d50505>«</font> is His name.” And so on [in the rest of the verses]. — From an old Rashi manuscript) Another explanation: For He is most high, He transcends all songs. and as much as I may praise him, there is still more in Him [to be praised] and not like a king of flesh and blood who is praised and does not possess [those attributes]. "

§§—2—§§ 15:1:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאה FOR HE IS GLORIOUSLY SUBLIME — render this as the Targum does: for He is exalted above all exalted beings and real exaltation (supremity) is His alone. [Another explanation: the repetition of the word is intended to state that He has done something which it is impossible for a human being (lit., flesh and blood) to do. When he (the latter) fights against another and vanquishes him he throws him off the horse, but here — horse and its rider together hath He hurled into the sea. The usage is, that in the case of everything which cannot possibly be done by anyone except Him the appropriate expression to use is a form of the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאה, as in (Isaiah 12:5), “for He hath done <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאות” — gloriously. In the same way you will find that throughout the whole Song the words are repeated: (v. 2) “The strength and vengeance of the Lord have become my help”; (v. 4). “The Lord is a man of war, the Lord is His name” (cf. Rashi’s explanation of this), and this is the case in all the verses]. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאה: I will sing unto the Lord although (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי) He is exalted high above all songs and however much I may praise Him there will still remain something additional in Him to be praised (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תוספת — I can never exhaust his praises), and not as is the practice in respect to a human king whom one praises, attributing to him certain virtues whilst these are really not in him (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:1:6)."

—3— **sie sprachen also, ich will dem Ewigen lobsingen;** ebenso bei Josua, als er das Wunder sah, sagte ihm sein Herz, dass er spreche, und er tat so, er sprach vor den Augen Israels; ebenso beim Lied am Brunnen, wo er beginnt (Num. 21, 17), damals sang Israel, erklärt er nachher, steige empor, Brunnen, rufet ihm zu; (I Kön. 11,7) damals wollte Schelomo eine Opferhöhe bauen, dabei erklären die Weisen Israels (Schabbat 56b), er wollte bauen, aber er baute nicht; daraus lernen wir dass das Jud der Zukunft die Absicht wiedergibt; das Gesagte erklärt den einfachen Sinn. Aber als Midrasch sagen unsere Lehrer s. A. (Sanhedrin 91b), hier ist in der Torah eine Andeutung für die Wiederbelebung der Toten, ebenso in allen diesen Beispielen, außer dem von Schelomo, das sie erklären, er wollte bauen, aber er baute nicht, man soll aber nicht sagen, dass man diesen Ausdruck <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר wie andere Stellen, wo die Zukunft steht und doch die Gegenwart gemeint ist, erklären wolle; wie (Job 1,5), so pflegte Job zu tun; (Num. 9,18,20) auf Ausspruch des Ewigen lagerten sie, zuweilen blieb die Wolke; weil es sich dort um Dinge handelt, die sich immer wiederholten und auf welche sowohl die Form der Zukunft als auch die der Vergangenheit passt, aber unsere Begebenheit, die nur damals vorkam, kann man nicht mit dieser Regel erklären. 

---

////—1—//// 15:1:3,"**Horse and its rider —** both tied to each other and the water brought them up high and then threw them to the depths and, yet, they did not come apart. "

§§—2—§§ 15:1:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורכבו THE HORSE AND ITS RIDER — both of them attached one to the other; and the waters lifted them up and then they descended into the depths and yet they did not become separated (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:1:6).

—3— **Denn er ist hocherhaben,** wie der Targum sagt (erhaben über den Hohen, und die Hoheit ist Sein). Andere Erklärung: die Verdopplung will uns sagen, dass Er eine Sache vollbrachte, die Fleisch und Blut nicht imstande sind zu tun; wenn ein Mensch mit dem andere kämpft und ihn besiegt, stürzt er ihn vom Roß, hier aber schleuderte Er das Roß **und** seinen Reiter ins Meer; und auf alles, was von keinem anderen vollbracht werden kann, passt der Ausdruck Erhabenheit, wie (Jes. 12, 5), Er hat Erhabenes vollbracht; und so findest du im ganzen Lied doppelte Ausdrücke, die Macht und die Ahndung sind des Ewigen, und sie ward mir zur Hilfe; der Ewige ist der Mann des Krieges, Ewiger ist Sein Name, und so alle; alter Raschitext. Andere Erklärung: denn Er ist hocherhaben, über alle Lieder, und zu allem, was ich von Ihm rühme, möchte man noch hinzufügen, nicht wie bei einem irdischen König, den man rühmt, ohne dass er es verdient (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:1:4,"**He threw.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָמָה means] He threw. Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּרְמִיו) They were thrown into a burning furnace.” There is a Midrash Aggada: One verse states <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָמָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>thrown upwards,<font color=d50505>«</font> whereas another verse states <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>thrown downwards.<font color=d50505>«</font> This teaches that they went up to the heights and went down to the abyss; as in: “who (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרָה) threw down the cornerstone?” — from above to below. "

§§—2—§§ 15:1:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה means HE HATH CAST. Similar is (Daniel 3:21) “and they were cast (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורמיו) into the midst of the fiery furnace”. And an Agadic explanation is: One verse says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה, which involves the idea of raising (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רום), and another verse (v. 4) says, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה which implies casting from a height (cf. Rashi on <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יירה 19:13)! This teaches us that they first went up on high and then went down into the depths (i. e. they were tossed up and down). The meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה here is the same as in (Job. 38:6) “Who laid (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה) the corner-stone thereof?” — implying laying from above to below (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:1:6)."

—3— **Roß und Reiter,** beide waren miteinander verbunden, und das Wasser hob sie empor und schleuderte sie in die Tiefe, ohne dass sie getrennt wurden (Mech.). **Schleudert Er,** warf Er; ebenso (Dan. 3, 21), und man warf sie in den Feuerofen. Der agadische Midrasch (Mech.) sagt, ein Vers sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה, Er erhob sie, und ein Vers sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה, Er schleuderte, das lehrt, dass sie zur Höhe emporstiegen und zur Tiefe hinabsanken, wie (Job 38,6), wer hat ihren Grundstein hinabgesenkt, von oben nach unten. 

---

////—1—//// 15:2:1,"**The strength and retribution of God.** Onkelos translates [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת as:] “my might and my praise,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִי being the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִי, vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>shuruk<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת being the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָתִי . But I wonder at the wording of the verse for there is none vocalized like it in Scripture, except in three places where it is placed next to “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת,” whereas, everywhere else it is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>shuruk,<font color=d50505>«</font> [e.g.] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמָעֻזִּי [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזּוֹ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵלֶיךָ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶשְׁמֹרָה .
