Similarly, every two-letter word that is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>malopum<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=d50505>»</font>cholam<font color=d50505>«</font>), when it is extended by a third [suffix] letter, and the second one is not a <font color=d50505>»</font>sheva<font color=d50505>«</font> or <font color=d50505>»</font>chatef<font color=d50505>«</font>, then the first [letter] is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>shuruk<font color=d50505>«</font>: For example: [The word] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹז [becomes] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי, [the word] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֹק [becomes] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֻקִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹק [becomes] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֻקִּי, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹל [becomes] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻלּוֹ [e.g.] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָסוּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוּלּוֹ,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹּל [becomes] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֻּלֹוֹ [e.g.] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשָׁלִישִׁים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֻּלּוֹ . But [in] these three — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת which appears here, and the one in Yeshaiyahu (12, 2) and the one in Tehillim (118, 14) — [the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ע'] is vocalized with a short <font color=d50505>»</font>kamatz. <font color=d50505>«</font> And furthermore in none of them is it written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָתִי, but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת and they are all followed by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְהִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִישׁוּעָה Therefore, I say, so that the wording of the text fit, that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי does not mean the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי nor does <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת mean the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָתִי, but, rather, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִי is a noun as in: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיּשְׁבִי (the One Who dwells) in the heavens,” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֹׁכְנִי (the one who dwells) in the cracks of the rock,” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֹׁכְנִי (the one who dwells) in the bush.” And the following is the praise [conveyed here]: “The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹז and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִמְרָה of God were a deliverance for me,” and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת is in the construct to the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה', as in: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְעֶזְרַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' — “to the help <font color=d50505>»</font>of<font color=d50505>«</font> God,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּעֶבְרַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' — “by the anger <font color=d50505>»</font>of<font color=d50505>«</font> God,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבְּרַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּנֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָאָדָם — “because of the speech <font color=d50505>»</font>of<font color=d50505>«</font> men.” The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת is from the same root as “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִזְמוֹר” [or:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זְמִיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָרִיצִים” — “The cutting down of the evil ones” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זְמִיר] being a term for <font color=d50505>»</font>mowing down<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font> cutting off.<font color=d50505>«</font> [Thus the meaning here is] “The strength and retribution of our God was a deliverance for us.” Do not wonder about the use of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְהִי (lit. “it will be”) that it does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָיָה (“it was”), for there <font color=d50505>»</font>are<font color=d50505>«</font> verses that express themselves in this way, and the following is an example: “around the walls of the house, for the Temple and the Holy of Holies, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּעַשׂ) he made side-structures all around,” where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשָׂה [instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּעַשׂ]. Similarly in Divrei Hayomim: “And [as for] the B’nei Yisrael who dwelt in the Judean cities, Rechavom <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּמְלֹך (reigned) over them,” where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָלַךְ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַלֵיהֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְחַבְעָם [instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּמְלֹךְ]. [Or:] “Due to the inability of God, etc. He slaughtered them, where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁחָטָם [instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּשְׁחָטֵם]; [Or:] “And the men that Moshe sent, etc. (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּמֻתוּ) died,” where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵתוּ [instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּמֻתוּ]; [Or:] “Whoever paid no heed to the word of God. (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּעֲזֹב) left [his cattle, etc.],” where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזַב [instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּעֲזֹב]. "

§§—2—§§ 15:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יה — Onkelos translated this by “my might and my praise”, taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָתִי. But I wonder at the wording of the text if this translation is correct, for you will find no similar example of its punctuation (i. e. of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי) in the Scriptures except in three passages where it is, in each case, followed by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת. In all other passages it is punctuated with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שורק (i. e. our Kibbutz); e. g., (Jeremiah 16:19) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומעזי (Psalms 59:10) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזּו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשמרה So, too, every word of two letters that is punctuated with a Melopum (our <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם) when it is lengthened by the addition of a third letter (i. e. when it has a pronominal suffix as in the examples given below), and the second has not a Sheva (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטף), the first is punctuated with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שורק (Kibbuts) — as, for instance, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹז and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי; ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֹק and ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֻקִי ; ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹק and ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֻקִי ; ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹל and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻלִי as in (Isaiah 14:25) “then shall his yoke (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻלּוֹ, from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֹל) depart from him”; — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹּל and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֻּלּוֹ, as in (Exodus 14:7) “and captains over each of them (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֻּלּוֹ) — from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹּל. But these three examples of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִּמְרָת, viz., that occuring here and that in Isaiah (12:2) and that in Psalms (118:14), are punctuated with short Kametz, whereas the translation of Onkelos would require <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי and not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי. Then further, in not one of them (these three passages) is it written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרתי, as Onkelos translates, but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת and remarkably enough all of them are immediately followed by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לישועה. — Therefore I say in explanation of the wording of the text that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי is not the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֻזִּי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָת is not the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְזִמְרָתִי, but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָזִּי is a noun without a suffix of any kind, as we find in (Psalms 123:1) “The one who sits (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיֹּשְׁבִי) in heaven”; (Obadiah 3:3) “The one who dwells (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֹׁכְנִי) in the cleft of the rock”; (Deuteronomy 33:16) “He that dwelleth (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֹׁכְנִי) in the bush” (where the syllable at the end of the word is part of the noun and is not the pronominal suffix denoting “my”). The praise, therefore, proclaimed in these words is this: The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עז and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִמְרָת of God, this was to me as a help. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת is a noun in the construct state to the word which expressess the Divine Name (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָהּ), in the same sense as (Judges 5:23) “to the help of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעזרַת — const.) the Lord”; (Isaiah 9:18) “through the wrath of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעברת — constr.) the Lord”; (Ecc. 3:18) “because of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברַת — const.) the sons of man”. The expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת has the meaning of the root which we find in (Leviticus 25:4) “thou shalt not prune (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תזמר)” and in (Isaiah 25:5) “the cutting down (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמיר) of the terrible ones”, both of which have the meaning “lopping off” and “cutting down”. Thus the verse signifies: “The strength and vengeance of our God has become to us a help”. Do not be puzzled by the expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי — that it does not state <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היה — for we have other verses also that use this idiom, and the following is an example of such a construction: (1 Kings 6:5) “round about the wall of the house, both of the temple and the most holy place, he made (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעש) a side structure”, and it should have said (instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעש etc.) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צלעות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סביב. Similarly in Chronicles, (2 10:17) “But as for the children of Israel who dwelt in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam reigned (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימלך) over them”, where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליהם. Other examples are: (Numbers 14:16) “Because the Lord was unable etc…. He slaughtered them (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישחטם)”, where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחטם; (Numbers 14:36, 37) “And the men whom Moses sent … they died (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימתו)”, where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתו; (Exodus 9:21) “And he that regarded not the word of the Lord left (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעזב) his cattle, etc.”, where it should have said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזב‎."

—3— **2. Die Macht und die Ahndung sind des Ewigen,** Onkelos übersetzt, meine Macht und mein Sang, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נזי = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזי^ mit Schurek und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרתי = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת; ich wundere mich über den Ausdruck des Verses; denn du findest eine ähnliche Punktierung im Verse nur an drei Stellen, immer in Verbindung mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת; an allen anderen Stellen ist mit Schurek punktiert; (Jer. 16, 19), der Ewige ist meine Macht und meine Zuversicht; (Ps. 59, 10) bei seiner Macht harre ich auf dich. Und so wird bei jedem Wort aus zwei Buchstaben, das mit Cholem punktiert ist, wenn es noch einen dritten Buchstaben erhält und der zweite weder (ruhendes) Schwa noch bewegliches hat, der erste mit Schurek punktiert, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עול <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלו;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ךוקי;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ךקי;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עז ^<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נזי, (Jes. 14, 25) sein Joch wird von ihnen weichen; 7 ',14), <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלו) Anführer auf allen; diese drei aber <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזמרת hier und in Jesaias (12, 2) und in den Psalmen (118, 14) sind mit kurzem Kamez punktiert; ferner steht an keiner dieser drei Stellen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרתי, sondern nur <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת, und an alle schließt sich an, und sie wurden mir zur Hilfe. Darum meine ich, um den Ausdruck des Verses zu erklären, dass <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זי}/ nicht = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נזי/und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת nicht = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרתי; sondern dass <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ז}/ein Hauptwort ist wie (Ps. 123, 1), du, im Himmel Thronender; (Obad. 3) in Felsenklüsten Wohnendes; (Deut. 33, 16) des im Dornbusch Thronenden; und das ist die Bedeutung dieser Verherrlichung, die Macht und die Ahndung des Ewigen wurden mir zum Heil;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת ist mit dem Namen des Ewigen verbunden, wie (Richt. 5,23) zur Hilfe des Ewigen; (Jes. 9,18) durch den Zorn des Ewigen; (Koh. 3, 18), was die Menschen betrifft. Und das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמרת kommt von (Lev. 25, 4), sollst du nicht beschneiden; (Jes. 25, 5) die Vernichtung der Gewalttätigen, in der Bedeutung von niederhauen und abschneiden; die Macht und Vergeltung unseres Gottes wurden uns zur Hilfe. Und wundere dich nicht über den Ausdruck <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי, dass nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היה steht; denn es gibt noch mehr Verse, die diese Form anwenden; folgendes ist dafür ein Beispiel (I Kön. 6, 5), an den Wänden des Hauses ringsum, am Heiligtum und am Allerheiligsten, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעש machte er ringsum Anbauten, wo er hätte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה sagen müssen; ebenso (II Chron. 10, 17), über die Kinder Israel, die in den Städten Judas wohnten, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימלוך regierte Rechabeam, wo er hätte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלך sagten müssen; (Num. 14, 16) weil dem Ewigen die Macht fehlt, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישחטם hat er sie dahingeschlachtet, wo er hätte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחטם sagen müssen; (Num. 14, 36) und die Männer, die Mosche schickte,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימותו starben, so er hätte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתו sagen müssen; (Ex. 9, 21), wer aber auf das Wort des Ewigen nicht achtete, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעזב der Hess, wo er hätte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזב sagen müssen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:2:2,**This is my Almighty.** With his glory (His very Self) did He reveal Himself to them and they pointed at Him with a finger. A handmaiden saw at the Sea what even the prophets could not see.

§§—2—§§ 15:2:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי THIS IS MY GOD — In His glory did He reveal Himself to them and they pointed to Him — as it were — with the finger exclaiming “This is my God!” (Shir HaShirim Rabbah 3:15) A maid servant beheld at the Red Sea what even the prophets never saw (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:2:2). 

—3— **Dieser ist mein Gott,** in Seiner Herrlichkeit erschien Er ihnen, und sie zeigten auf ihn mit dem Finger; eine Magd am Meere sah, was die Propheten nicht sahen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:2:3,"**And I will glorify Him.** Onkelos translates it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַנְוֵהוּ) from the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָוֶה [from:] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָוֶה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁאֲנָן” — “peaceful dwelling,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִנְוֵה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צֹאן — “A dwelling for sheep.” An alternate explanation: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַנְוֵהוּ denotes <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹי — <font color=d50505>»</font>beauty<font color=d50505>«</font> [and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַנְוֵהוּ means] I will relate His splendor and praise to the inhabitants of the world. For example: [The nations ask Israel:] “What is your beloved more than any other beloved, etc.,” “My Beloved is white and ruddy” and [all the praises of God expressed] in that section. "

§§—2—§§ 15:2:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואנוהו Onkelos translates this in the sense of a dwelling (viz., I will build Him a temple) as in (Isaiah 33:20) “a peaceful habitation (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוה)” and in (Isaiah 65:10) “a dwelling (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוה) for flocks”. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואנוהו is that it has the sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוי, “beauty”, and the meaning is: I will relate His splendour and praiseworthiness to the inhabitants of the world as, for example, was actually done by Israel: (Song 5:9, 10) The nations of the world ask, “What is thy beloved more than another beloved?” … and Israel replies, “My beloved is white and ruddy”, and thus you will find it in that whole section (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:2:2). "

—3— **Ich will ihn verherrlichen,** Onkelos übersetzt von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוה Stätte (ich will ihm ein Heiligtum bauen) (Jes. 33,20), eine ruhige Stätte; (Jes. 65,10) eine Stätte für die Schafe. Andere Erklärung: ich will Ihn verherrlichen von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוי (Schönheit) (Mech.), ich will seine Herrlichkeit und Seinen Ruhm den Menschen verkünden, wie (Schir 5, 9), was ist dein Trauter mehr als ein anderer Trauter … mein Trauter ist blendend weiß und rot, und der ganze Abschnitt. 

---

////—1—//// 15:2:4,"**The God of my father —** is this, and I will exalt Him. **The God of my father.** I am not the first to hallow Him but [this concept] has been held and has remained with me — this holiness and Godliness over me — from the days of my fathers."

§§—2—§§ 15:2:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבי MY FATHER’S GOD is this <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וארממנהו AND I WILL EXALT HIM. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבי He is not merely my God but He was MY FATHER’S GOD also — I am not the beginning of the sanctity (i. e. I am not the first to hallow Him by proclaiming Him God), this hallowing of Him and the proclamation of His Godship over me is something that has been held by me and has remained mine since the days of my fathers."

—3— **Der Gott meines Vaters** ist dieser, ich will ihn erheben; der Gott meines Vaters, nicht erst bei mir beginnt die Heiligkeit, sondern die Heiligkeit verweilte und wohnte schon längst bei mir, und Seine göttliche Waltung ist seit den Tagen meiner Väter über mir. 

---

////—1—//// 15:3:1,"**Adonoy is the master of war.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִלְחָמָה means] master of war as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָעֳמִי — “the master (husband) of Naomi.” Wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישׁ or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישִׁי, or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישֵׁךְ [appear] they are translated by Targum as “master of.” Similarly: “Be strong and be an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישׁ” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְאִישׁ having the same meaning as] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְגִבּוֹר . "

§§—2—§§ 15:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלחמה means The Lord is a Master of war; just as, (Ruth 1:3) “the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש (i. e. the master) of Naomi”. (Cf. Rashi on that verse). Wherever the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אישך occur they must be translated by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעל; so, too, (1 Kings 2:2) “Be thou strong and show thyself an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש” — a mighty person."

—3— **3. Der Ewige ist der Mann des Krieges,** der Herr der Kriege, wie (Ruth 1, 3) der Mann Noemis; überall, wo <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש oder <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אישך steht, werden sie mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעל übersetzt; ebenso (I Kön. 2r2) sei stark und werde ein Mann, ein Held. 

---

////—1—//// 15:3:2,"**Adonoy is His Name.** He does not conduct His wars with weapons but, rather, He wages war with His Name, as David said (to Goliath): “I come against you in the Name of Adonoy of Hosts.” An alternate explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁמוֹ: Even while He wages war he retains His attribute [expressed by “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהוה”] to be compassionate to His creatures by feeding all the inhabitants of the world; not as is the practice of earthly kings that when he is occupied by war he turns away from all his other functions and does not have the power to do both. "

§§—2—§§ 15:3:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמו THE LORD IS HIS NAME — His wars are not waged with martial weapons but He fights by means of His Name, just as David said, (I Samuel 17:45) “But I come against thee in the name of the Lord of Hosts”. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמו — He is a man of war, but His Name is the Lord (the God of Mercy): even at the time when He battles against and avenges Himself upon His enemies He retains His attribute (that expressed by His name <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳) showing pity to His creatures and feeding all the inhabitants of the world; not as is the nature of the kings of the world each one of whom when he is engaged in war turns aside from all other engagements, and has not the power to do both this and that (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:3)."

—3— **Ewiger ist Sein Name,** Seine Kriege führt Er nicht mit Waffen, sondern mit Seinem Namen, wie es heißt (I Sam. 17,45), und ich komme zu dir im Name des Ewigen der Heerscharen. Andere Erklärung: ist Sein Namen, auch in der Stunde, da Er kämpft und an Seinen Feinden Vergeltung übt, hält Er an Seiner Eigenschaft fest, Sich über Seine Geschöpfe zu erbarmen und alle Menschen zu ernähren, nicht wie die Eigenschaft der Könige der Erde; wenn ein solcher Krieg führt, wendet er sich von allen Geschäften ab; denn er hat nicht die Kraft, beides zugleich zu tun (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:4:1,"**He hurled into the sea.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַיָּם is translated by Onkelos:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁדִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְיַמָּא, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁדִִּי having the meaning of <font color=d50505>»</font>hurling.<font color=d50505>«</font> Similarly it says: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אוֹ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִיָּרֶה, where Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אוֹ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִשְׁתְּדָאָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִשְׁתְּדִי (from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁדִי), and the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' is used in these words (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִשְׁתְּדָאָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִשְׁתְּדִי in place of (i.e., indicating) the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִתְפְַַּל (reflexive) form. "

§§—2—§§ 15:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בים Onkelos translates this by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בימא: HE HATH CAST IN THE SEA. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי is an expression for “casting”. And thus, also, it says, (Exodus 19:13) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>או <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יירה which Onkelos renders by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>או <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשתדאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישתדי “or he shall certainly be thrown down” where the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת is used in both these words in place of (as marking) the Ithpael form, so that in these Targum words the root is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי‎."

—3— **4. Schleuderte Er ins Meer,** Targum, schleuderte Er ins Meer, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי bedeutet schleudern; ebenso sagt er (19, 13), oder wird herabgeschleudert <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשתדאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישתדי, das Taw dient in diesen Formen dem Hitpael. 

---

////—1—//// 15:4:2,"**Elite.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמִבְחַר] is a noun [having the same form] as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֶרְכָּב, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׁכָּב and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְרָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קֹדֶשׁ . "

§§—2—§§ 15:4:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומבחר AND THE CHOICEST — This word is a noun of similar form to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֶרְכָּב and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׁכָּב and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְרָא [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדש]‏.

—3— **Die Besten,** ist ein Hauptwort wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרכב Reitzeug (Lev. 15, 9); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משבב Lager (Lev. 15, 4); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדש heilige Berufung (Lev. 23, 3). 

---

////—1—//// 15:4:3,"**Were sunk.** The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טְבִיעָה always denotes sinking in a muddy place, as in “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טָבַעְתִּי I am sunk in muddy depths.” [or:] “Yirmiyahu (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּטְבַּע) sank in the mud.” This indicates that the sea turned to mud to pay them (the Egyptians) back in kind, for they had subjugated Yisrael with mortar (mud) and with bricks. "

§§—2—§§ 15:4:3," ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טבעו ARE SUNK — The root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טבע always denotes sinking in slimy matter, as may be seen from (Psalms 69:3) “I am sunk (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טבעתי) in deep mire”, and from (Jeremiah 38:6) “And Jeremiah sank (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויטבע) in the mire”. The fact that this expression is used teaches, therefore, that the sea became slime (cf. Rashi on 14:24) to requite them according to their own measure — because that they had made the Israelites work as slaves with slime and with bricks (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:3)."

—3— **Versanken,** versinken sagt man nur von einer schlammigen Stelle (Mech.); wie (Ps. 69, 3), ich versinke in der schlammigen Tiefe; (Jer. 38, 6) da versank Jirmejahu im Lehm; das lehrt, dass das Meer zu Lehm wurde, um ihnen nach ihrem Maß zu vergelten, weil sie Israel mit Lehm und Ziegeln geknechtet hatten. 

---

////—1—//// 15:5:1,"**Covered them.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוּ is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסוּם with the middle letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' being extra. This is usual in the verses [of Scripture]; as in: “Your cattle and sheep (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִרְבְּיֻן) will increase,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִרְוְיֻן) They will be satiated from the abundance of Your House.” The first letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוּ], which denotes the future tense, is explained as follows: They sank in the Reed Sea so that the water should return and cover them. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוּ has no similar vocalization in Scripture, and is normally vocalized <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוֹ with a <font color=d50505>»</font> melopum<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=d50505>»</font>cholam<font color=d50505>«</font>). "

§§—2—§§ 15:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יכסימו THEY COVER THEM — this is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסּוּם and the middle <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י is redundant. This is quite usual in Scripture–verses (in Biblical Hebrew), just as in (Deuteronomy 8:13) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וצאנך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירביון, and (Psalms 36:9) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירויון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדשן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביתך,  and the force of the first <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י which expresses the future tense you must explain as follows: they have been sunk in the Red Sea in order that the waters should return and should cover them. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יכסימו has no similar example in Scripture so far as its punctuation is concerned; ordinarily it would be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוּ with Melopum (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם)‎."

—3— **5. Bedeckten sie = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יבסום,** das mittlere Jud ist hinzugefügt, wie es zuweilen in Versen vorkommt, wie (Deut. 8,13), deine Schafe vermehren sich; (Ps. 36, 9) sie laben sich an der Fülle deines Hauses; das erste Jud, das auf die Form der Zukunft hinweist, erkläre so, sie versanken im Schilfmeer, damit das Wasser zurückkehre und sie bedecke; für die Punktierung von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יבסימו finden wir nichts Ähnliches im Vers; nach der Regel müsste es mit Cholem am Ende <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְכַסְיֻמוּ punktiert sein. 

---

////—1—//// 15:5:2,"**Like stone.** Elsewhere it says: “They sank like lead” and elsewhere it says: “consumed them like straw.” [This is because] the wicked ones were like straw being continuously scrambled as they were thrown up and down. Those who were average were like stone, and the relatively righteous were like lead and came to their rest immediately. "

§§—2—§§ 15:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבן AS A STONE — But in another passage (v. 10) it states, “they dropped like lead”, and in yet another passage (v. 7) “it consumes them as stubble”! The wicked amongst the Egyptians were as stubble, being continually dashed about, and tossed up and down; those of average worth sank as a stone, suffering less agony, whilst the best amongst them sank as lead so that they came to their rest at once (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:5)."

—3— **Wie ein Stein,** an anderer Stelle (V. 10) steht, sie wirbelten wie Blei, und an einer dritten Stelle (V. 7) steht, er verzehrte sie wie Stroh; die Frevler wurden wie Stroh lange hin und her geschleudert, stiegen empor und sanken hinab; die Mittelmässigen nur wie ein Stein, und die Guten wie Blei, sie hatten sofort Ruhe (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:6:1,"**Your right hand, Your right hand.** Twice! When Israel does God’s will the left hand, too, becomes a right hand. "

§§—2—§§ 15:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימינך ... <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימינך THY RIGHT HAND — twice! — When Israel performs the will of the Omnipresent the left hand (intended for punishment) becomes a right hand (bestowing reward, so that God has two right hands as it were) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:5)."

—3— **6. Deine Rechte, deine Rechte,** zweimal; wenn Israel den Willen des Ewigen erfüllt, wird auch die Linke zu einer Rechten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:6:2,"**Your right hand, Adonoy, is adorned with power —** in order to save Yisrael, while Your other right hand crushes the enemy. However, to me it seems [that the second <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִמִינְךָ means] that very same right hand crushes the enemy, which is something impossible for a human — to do two acts with one hand. However, the plain meaning of the verse is: “Your right hand, which is adorned with power.” What is its function? “Your right hand crushes the enemy.” There are many verses that are like it. “For <font color=d50505>»</font>behold, Your enemies,<font color=d50505>«</font> Adonoy, for <font color=d50505>»</font>behold Your enemies<font color=d50505>«</font> shall perish.” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>How long shall the wicked ones,<font color=d50505>«</font> Adonoy, <font color=d50505>»</font>till when will the wicked ones<font color=d50505>«</font> exult?” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>The rivers have raised<font color=d50505>«</font> Adonoy, <font color=d50505>»</font>the rivers have raised<font color=d50505>«</font> their voice.” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>Not for our sake,<font color=d50505>«</font> Adonoy, <font color=d50505>»</font>not for our sake.<font color=d50505>«</font>” “‘<font color=d50505>»</font>I will respond,<font color=d50505>«</font>’ says Adonoy, ‘<font color=d50505>»</font>I will respond<font color=d50505>«</font> to the heavens.’” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>I<font color=d50505>«</font> to Adonoy, <font color=d50505>»</font>I<font color=d50505>«</font> will sing.” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>Had it not been for Adonoy ... had it not been for Adonoy,<font color=d50505>«</font> who was with us when man rose up against us.” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>Awaken! awaken!<font color=d50505>«</font> Devorah, <font color=d50505>»</font>Awaken! Awaken!<font color=d50505>«</font> sing a song!” [or:] “<font color=d50505>»</font>A foot<font color=d50505>«</font> shall trample her, <font color=d50505>»</font>the foot<font color=d50505>«</font> of a pauper.” [or:] “He gave their land as <font color=d50505>»</font>an inheritance,<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=d50505>»</font>an inheritance<font color=d50505>«</font> to Israel, His people,” and their like. "

§§—2—§§ 15:6:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימינך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נאדרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכח THY RIGHT HAND, O LORD, IS GLORIOUS IN POWER to deliver Israel, and thy second right hand dashes the enemy in pieces. But it seems to me that if we have to take it in the sense: Thy right hand is glorious to save, thy right hand dashes in pieces etc. the explanation is that the self-same right hand itself dashes the enemy in pieces, something which it is impossible for a human being — to do two actions with one hand. But the literal sense of the text is: “Thy right hand, that is glorious in power — what does it do?” — “Thy right hand, O Lord, dashes the enemy in pieces”. There are many Scriptural verses exactly in this poetical form, e. g., (Psalms 92:10) “For, behold, thine enemies, O Lord, for behold, thine enemies shall perish” and others similar."

—3— **Deine Rechte, Ewiger, ist herrlich an Kraft,** Israel zu retten, und deine zweite Rechte zerschmettert den Feind; und mir scheint, dieselbe Rechte selbst zerschmettert den Feind, was einem Menschen nicht möglich ist, zwei Arbeiten mit einer Hand zu tun; der einfache Sinn des Verses ist, deine Rechte, die herrlich an Kraft ist, was vollbringt sie? Deine Rechte, sie zerschmettert den Feind; es gibt viele ähnliche Verse; (Ps. 92, 10) denn, siehe, deine Feinde, Ewiger; denn, siehe, deine Feinde gehen unter; und ähnliche Stellen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:6:3,"**Adorned.** The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' is extra as in “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רַבָּתִי) full of people,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂרָתִי) the princess among countries, [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּנֻבְתִי) stolen during the day.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:6:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נאדרי The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י is redundant as in (Lamentations 1:1) “full of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבתי) people . . . princess (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שרתי) amongst the provinces”; (Genesis 31:39) “stolen (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גנבתי) by day”.

—3— **Herrlich,** das Jud ist hinzugefügt wie bei (Echa 1, 1), zahlreich an Volk, Fürstin unter den Ländern; (Gen. 31, 39) am Tage Gestohlenes. 

---

////—1—//// 15:6:4,"**Crushes the enemy.** It is constantly crushing and breaking the enemy. Similar to this (the use of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְעַץ to mean <font color=d50505>»</font>to crush<font color=d50505>«</font>) is: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּרְעֲצוּ) They crushed and shattered the B’nei Yisrael” in the Book of Shoftim (10, 8). (An alternate explanation: “Your hand that is adorned with power is the one that <font color=d50505>»</font>breaks<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>strikes<font color=d50505>«</font> the enemy. [This is connected to the next verse as follows:] "

§§—2—§§ 15:6:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרעץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אויב means, it always crushes and shatters the enemy; similar in meaning to it is, “And they crushed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירעצו) and broke the children of Israel”, in the Book of Judges (Judges 10:8). [Another explanation is: Thy right hand that is glorious in power shatters and punishes the enemy, and these words must be connected with the following:"

—3— **Zerschmettert den Feind,** (Zukunft) immer zerschmettert und zerbricht sie den Feind; ähnlich (Richt. 10, 8), sie bedrückten und traten die Kinder Israel nieder. Andere Erklärung: Deine Rechte, die herrlich an Kraft ist, zerbricht und schlägt den Feind. 

---

////—1—//// 15:7:1,"**In Your great majesty.** If the hand alone crushes the enemy, then when He raises it in His great majesty, He will <font color=d50505>»</font>destroy<font color=d50505>«</font> His opponents. And if in His great majesty alone His opponents are destroyed then, certainly, when He sends forth His fury, it will consume them.) "

§§—2—§§ 15:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וברב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גאנך AND THROUGH THE GREATNESS OF THINE EXCELLENCY: if the hand alone crushes the spirit of the enemy, then when He raises it aloft IN THE GREATNESS OF HIS EXCELLENCY surely then HE WILL OVERTHROW THEM THAT RISE UP AGAINST HIM; and if through the greatness of His excellency alone His enemies are overthrown, how much more sure is it that when HE SENDETH FORTH THE FIERCENESS OF HIS WRATH against them IT WILL CONSUME THEM]."

—3— **7. In der Fülle Deiner Hoheit,** wenn die Hand allein den Feind zerbricht, so reisst Er, wenn Er sich in der Fülle Seiner Hoheit erhebt, Seine Widersacher vollends nieder; und wenn schon durch die Fülle Seiner Hoheit allein Seine Feinde niedergeworfen werden, um so mehr, wenn Er Seine Zornesglut gegen sie schickt, verzehrt sie diese. 

---

////—1—//// 15:7:2,"**You destroy.** You constantly destroy your opponents, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָמֶיךָ) those who stand up against You. Who are considered those who stand up against Him? It is those who stand up against Yisrael. Similarly, it says: “For behold your enemies are in an uproar —” and what is this uproar? — “against your people they plot deceitfully,” and it is for this that they are called “enemies of God.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:7:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהרס means, Thou always overthrowest  <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קמיך i. e. those that rise up against thee. And who are those who rise up against Him? They are those who rise up against Israel; and similarly it says, (Psalms 83:3, 4) “For, lo, thine enemies are in an uproar!” And what is this uproar? “against thy people they take crafty counsel”, and on this account — because they are Israel's enemies — it calls them the enemies of the Omnipresent (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:7:1)."

—3— **Wirfst du nieder,** immer wirfst Du Deine Widersacher nieder, die sich gegen Dich erheben; und wer sind diejenigen, die sich gegen Ihn erheben? Die sich gegen Israel erheben; und so sagt er auch, (Ps. 83, 3) denn, siehe, Deine Feinde lärmen, und was ist das Lärmen? Gegen Dein Volk schmieden sie einen Plan; und darum nennt er sie Feinde des Ewigen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:1,"**The wind of Your nostrils.** The wind that comes out of the two nostrils. The verse speaks — as if this were possible — regarding God, as if compared to a human king, in order to attune the ears of people in accordance with [their own] experience so that they might understand the matter. When a person becomes angry breath [furiously] comes from his nostrils. Similarly: “Smoke arose from His nostrils.” Similarly: “By the breath of His nostril are they consumed.” This is meant by Scripture’s saying: “For the sake of My Name I will lengthen My breath.” When one’s anger is calmed, his breath is longer, but when he is angry his breath is short. [The verse there continues] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּתְהִילָּתִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶחֱטָם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָךְ [which means] “For the sake of My praise, I will place a nose-ring in My nose in order to close up My nostrils against the anger and the breath so that they not come out.: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָךְ [here means] <font color=d50505>»</font>for your sake.<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶחֱטָם [has the same meaning as:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְאָקָהּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֲטָם which is found in Maseches Shabbos This is what it seems to me. Whenever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַף and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוֹן are joined together in Scripture I say that the following is the explanation: [In the expression] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרֹה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַף [the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרָה] is similar to [the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרָה in:] “My bone is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרָה from the heat” [where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרָה] means <font color=d50505>»</font>burning<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>heat<font color=d50505>«</font>, because the nostrils become hot and burning, at a time of anger. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרוֹן is derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרֹה . The same way <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָצוֹן is derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָצֹה . Similarly the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֵמָה (wrath) is also derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲמִימוּת (heat). It is for this reason that it says: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַחֲמָתוֹ) and his anger burnt within him,” and when anger subsides one says: “His mind has <font color=d50505>»</font>cooled off.<font color=d50505>«</font>” "

§§—2—§§ 15:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וברוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפיך AND WITH THE BREATH OF THY NOSTRILS — the breath that issues from both nostrils. Scripture speaks — if this were at all possible (i. e. if one may be permitted to speak so of God) of the Shechina (God) in the same manner as it does of a human monarch, in order to make peoples’ ears hear the facts in accordance with what usually happens to that they may understand the matter: when a man is angry the breath issues from his nostrils (and Scripture attributes this to God, also, when He is in anger). A similar idea is: (Psalms 18:9) “Smoke rose up in His nostril”, and also, (Job. 4:9) “By the breath of his nostril they are consumed”. And this is the meaning of what He said, (Isaiah 48:9) “For My name’s sake <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אאריך I will make long My <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף”: when one’s anger subsides his breathing becomes long, whilst when one is in anger his breathing is short (consequently <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אאריך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפי signifies “I will not be angry”). The text continues <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותהלתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחטם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך which means “for the sake of My praise I will place a nose-ring in My nose to close up the nostrils against the anger and the breath so that they should not issue forth”. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך, for thee, in this text, means “for thy sake”, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחטם has the same meaning and root as in “a wild camel with a nose-ring (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֹטֶם)” which occurs in Mishna Treatise Sabbath (Mishnah Shabbat 5:1). Thus does the explanation appear to me. And wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרון (i. e. where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף and words formed from the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרון) occur in the Scriptures I say that it has the following sense: In the phrase <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אף the first word is the same as (Job 30:30) “My bone is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרה with heat”, where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרה denotes burning and glowing, and this metaphor is used because the nostrils become hot and burning in a time of anger. The noun <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרון is a derivation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרה, just as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רצון is a derivation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רצה, and therefore signifies “burning”. In the same way, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַמה which also signifies wrath really denotes heat (from a root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יחם, not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמם, since the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַמָה has no Dagesh. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַמָה is formed from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יחם as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֵדָה, congregation, from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעד). That is why Scripture says, (Esther 1:12) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחמתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בערה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו “his wrath burned in him”, and when one’s wrath subsides one says, “his mind has become cooled” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתקררה from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קר cold)."

—3— **8. Durch den Odem Deines Angesichtes,** der aus den beiden Öffnungen der Nase kommt; der Vers spricht, wenn der Ausdruck erlaubt ist, von Ewigen wie von einem irdischen König, um das Ohr der Menschen etwas, das häufig vorkommt, hören zu lassen, damit sie die Sache begreifen können; wenn ein Mensch zürnt, kommt starker Odem aus seiner Nase; ebenso (Ps. 18, 9) Dampf steigt auf in Seiner Nase; ebenso (Job 4, 9), durch den Odem Seines Angesichtes schwinden sie dahin; das bedeutet auch der Vers (Jes. 48, 9), um meines Namens willen halte ich meinen Zorn zurück (eigentlich atme ich lang); wenn der Zorn nachlässt, wird der Atem lang; beim Zornigen aber ist der Atem kurz; (dort) und um meines Ruhmes willen bin ich langmütig gegen dich, um meines Ruhmes willen lege ich einen Ring an meine Nase, die Öffnungen vor dem Zorn und dem Odem zu schließen, dass sie nicht herauskommen; gegen dich = für dich; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחטם wie (Trakt. Schabbat 51b), das Dromedar mit dem Nasenring; so scheint es mir; und überall, wo Zorn und Glut im Vers vorkommt, erkläre ich so; der Zorn entbrennt wie (Job 30, 30), mein Gebein glüht von der Hitze, soviel wie Brand und Glut; die Öffnungen der Nase werden heiß und glühen zur Zeit des Zornes; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרון kommt von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרה, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רצון von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רצה; ebenso bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמה Hitze; darum sagt er (Esth. 1,12), sein Zorn brannte in ihm; und wenn der Zorn nachlässt, sagt er (Jebam. 63a) sein Sinn kühlt ab, beruhigt sich. 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:2,"**The waters were heaped up.** Onkelos translates [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶעֶרְמוּ] as derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַרְמִימוּת (cleverness). However, according to the clarity of Scripture it has the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲרֵמַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִטִּים — “A mound of wheat.” The expression “stood like a wall” indicates this. **Heaped up.** [I.e.,] from the heat of the breath that came out of Your nostrils the water dried up and became like piles and mounds of grain-stacks which are high. "

§§—2—§§ 15:8:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נערמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מים THE WATERS WERE HEAPED UP — Onkelos translated this in the sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערמימות, subtlety (the waters showed themselves clever); (cf. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערום Genesis 3:1); but it is more in accordance with the elegance of Biblical style to take it as the noun of the same root as in (Song 7:3) “a stack of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערמת) wheat”, and the following words, “the floods placed themselves like a mound”, prove that this is so (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:8:2). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נערמו — Through the burning heat of the breath that issued from thy nostrils (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וברוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפיך) the waters were dried up and they became like heaps and piles of gain-stacks (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערמה) which are high."

—3— **Türmten sich die Wasser,** Onkelos übersetzt mit List; die stilistische Feinheit des Ausdrucks aber ist = (Schir 7, 3), ein Weizenhügel; sie standen aufrecht wie eine Mauer, ist ein Beweis dafür. 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:3,**Like a wall.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּמוֹ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֵד means] as Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּשׁוּר — “like a wall.”

§§—2—§§ 15:8:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד — Render this as the Targum does: like a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שור, i. e. a wall. "

—3— **Türmten sich,** durch den Gluthauch, der aus Deinem Angesichte kam, vertrocknete das Wasser und wurde gleich hohen Wellen und Hügeln von Getreide. 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:4,"**A wall.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֵד is a term for <font color=d50505>»</font>heaped up<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>gathered,<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “As a (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֵד) pile of branches on a day of sorrow,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כֹּנֵס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּנֵּד — “He gathers like a mound.” It is not written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כּוֹנֵס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּנֹּאד but rather <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּנֵּד, and if <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּנֵּד would be the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַנֹּאד and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כּוֹנֵס would have the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכְנָסָה, it should have been written: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַכְנִיס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּבַנֹּאד) He gathers, as if into a leather water-pouch the waters of the sea.” But <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כּוֹנֵס denotes <font color=d50505>»</font>gathering<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>piling up<font color=d50505>«</font>. Similarly: “[the waters] rose up as one mound” [and:] “they stood as one mound. The terms rising and standing do not apply to water-pouches, only to walls and piles. [Also] we find <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹאד vocalized only with a <font color=d50505>»</font>cholam<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “place my tears (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְנֹאדֶךָ) into your flask,” [or:] (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹאוד) — the milk pitcher.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:8:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד is an expression for anything heaped up and gathered together, as, (Isaiah 17:11) “a heap (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד) of boughs in the day of grief”; (Psalms 33:7) “He gathereth as a heap (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּנֵד) [the waters of the sea]”. It is not written “He gathereth <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנאד”, but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנאד”, and if <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנד, were the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנאד “like a water-skin”, and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כונס were an expression for “bringing a thing in”, it should have written: “He gathered in (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכניס and not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כונס) the waters of the sea as in a water-skin”, (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבנאד and not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנד), but <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כונס denotes gathering together and heaping up. And this must also be the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד in (Joshua 3:16) “[the waters] rose up as one <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד”, and (Joshua v. 13) “and they shall stand in one <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד”; for the expressions “rising up” and “standing up” cannot be used in reference to water in water-skins but only to water that stands up as walls and heaps (and this must therefore be the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד in our text also). And, then again, we find the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹאד punctuated only with a Melopum (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם), as, (Psalms 56:9) “Put thou my tears into thy bottle (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹאדֶךָ)” and (Judges 4:19) “the bottle of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֹאד) milk”."

—3— **Wie eine Mauer,** wie der Targum sagt, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כשור wie eine Mauer. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נד bedeutet gesammelt und aufgehäuft; wie (Jes. 17, 11) hoch ist die Ernte für den Tag des Schmerzes; (Ps. 33,7) Er häuft wie eine Mauer; es steht nicht, Er sammelt wie in einem Schlauch, sondern <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנד, wenn aber <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנאד = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנד wäre und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כנס sammeln bedeutete, so hätte er schreiben müssen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכניס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבנאד; vielmehr bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כונס einsammeln und aufhäufen; ebenso (Jos. 3, 13, 16), es wird wie eine Mauer stehen, stand wie eine Mauer; man sagt auch nicht bei Schläuchen sich erheben und stehen, sondern bei Mauern und Haufen; wir finden ferner <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נאד nur mit Cholem punktiert, wie (Ps. 56, 9) lege meine Träne in deinen Schlauch; (Richt. 4, 19) den Schlauch mit Milch. 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:5,"**Congealed.** As in: “And like cheese (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַקְפִּיאֵנִי) you have solidified me,” for they (the depths) hardened and became as stone and the waters threw the Egyptians upon the stone with force, and battled against them with all kinds of harshness. "

§§—2—§§ 15:8:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קפאו WERE CONGEALED, like (Job 10:10) “thou hast curdled me (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקפיאני) like cheese”; the meaning is that the depths were hardened and became like stones, and the waters cast the Egyptians against the stony wall with force and battled against them with every harsh means (cf. Mekhilta)."

—3— **Erstarrten,** wie (Job 10. 10), gleich Käse ließt Du mich festwerden; sie wurden hart und gleich Steinen, und das Wasser warf die Ägypter mit Gewalt auf die Steine und bekämpfte sie mit allen Arten von Mühseligkeit. 

---

////—1—//// 15:8:6,"**In the heart of the Sea.** [Meaning:] In the very strongest part of the sea. It is usual for Biblical verses to speak this way: [e.g.] “to the very middle of the heavens,” [or:] “in the very middle of the oak-tree,” denoting the essence and strength of a thing. "

§§—2—§§ 15:8:6," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ים means IN THE VERY STRENGTH OF THE SEA. It is the way of Scripture-verses to speak thus (to use <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב in a metaphorical sense); e. g., (Deuteronomy 4:11) “unto the very midst of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב) heaven”; (II Samuel 18:14) “in the midst of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלב) the terebinth”. It is an expression denoting the essence and strength of a thing. "

—3— **Im Herzen des Meeres,** in der Stärke des Meeres; es ist die Art der Verse, so zu sprechen; (Deut. 4,11) bis zum Herzen des Himmels; (II Sam. 18,14) im Herzen der Eiche, in der Bedeutung von Stamm und Stärke einer Sache. 

---

////—1—//// 15:9:1,"**The enemy said —** to his nation, when he seduced them with words, “I will pursue and overtake them and I will divide the spoils with my ministers and my servants.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אויב THE ENEMY SAID to his people, when he was persuading them with words (cf. Rashi on 14:6), I WILL PURSUE and I WILL OVERTAKE them and I WILL DIVIDE THE SPOIL with my captains and my subjects."

—3— **9. Es sprach der Feind** zu einem Volke, als er sie überredete, ich werde nachjagen, einholen und mit meinen Fürsten und Knechten Beute teilen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:9:2,"**I will satisfy [myself].** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמְלָאֵמוֹ means] my soul will be filled with them. —[<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נַפְשִׁי meaning:] My spirit and my will. Do not wonder about a word that expresses something expressed by two words, [viz.,] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמְלָאֵמוֹ [expresses the same thing as] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמְלָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵהֶם, for there are many instances of such an expression: [e.g.] “For the southern land <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְתַתָּנִי,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְתַתָּנִי being] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָתַתָּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי — “You have given me.” [or:] “They could not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּבְּרוֹ peaceably,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַבְּרוֹ being] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּבֵּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִמּוֹ — “Speak with him,” or: “My children <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְצָאוּנִי,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְצָאוּנִי being] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָצְאוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִמֶּנִי — “went away from me,” [or:] “The number of my steps <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַגִּידֶנּוּ” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַגִּידֶנּוּ being] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַגִּיד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹ — “I will tell him.” Here, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמְלָאֵמוֹ means: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמְלָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נַפְשִׁי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵהֶם — “My soul will be filled from them.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:9:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלאמו means SHALL BE FILLED WITH THEM (not it shall fill them). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפשי MY SOUL — my spirit, my desire. Do not be puzzled at a word, that expresses an idea usually expressed by two, viz., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלאמו for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמָּלֵא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵהֶם, for there are many examples of this way of speaking; e. g., (Judges 1:15) “the south country <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְתַתָּנִי”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָתַתָּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי, “thou hast given to me”; (Genesis 37:4) “And they were not able <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּבְּרוֹ peaceably”, which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּבֵּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִמּוֹ “to speak with him”; (Jeremiah 10:20) “My children <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְצָאוּנִי which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָצְאוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִמֶּנִי “have gone away from me”; (Job. 31:37) “the number of my steps <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַגִידֶנּוּ which is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַגִּיד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹ “I would declare unto him”. Similarly here: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלאמו means <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּמָּלֵא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נַפְשִׁי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵהֶם “my soul shall be filled with them”."

—3— **Es sättige sich an ihnen,** fülle sich durch sie, meine Seele, mein Geist und mein Verlangen; wundere dich nicht, dass ein Wort von zwei Personen spricht, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהם = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלאמו; diese Form kommt häufig vor, (Richt. 1, 15) denn ein trockenes Land hast du mir gegeben = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי; (Gen. 37, 4) sie vermochten nicht, friedlich mit ihm zu sprechen = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמו; (Jer. 10, 20) meine Kinder haben mich verlassen = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממני; (Job. 31, 37) die Anzahl meiner Schritte will ich Ihm verkünden; auch hier, es sättige sich meine Seele an ihnen = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מהם.

---

////—1—//// 15:9:3,"**I will draw my sword.** [As Onkelos translates it:] “I will draw.” It is because he empties (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵרִיק) the sheath upon drawing it and it remains empty (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֵיק) the term “emptying” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַרָקָה) fits it, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְרִיקִים) They empty their sacks” [or:] “And his vessels (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָרִיקוּ) they will empty.” Do not claim that the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֵיקוּת — emptying does not apply to that which is being removed but, rather, [it applies only] to the container, or the sack and to the vessel from which it has been removed, but not to the sword or the wine and, therefore, have to resort to a forced explanation [that] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָרִיק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַרְבִּי has the same meaning as: “[<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּרֶק] And he armed his trained servants,” [thereby making the meaning here:] “I will arm myself with my sword.” [This is unnecessary for] we find the term [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲרָקָה] referring also to that which is being removed, [e.g.] “Oil (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תּוּרַק) which is emptied,” [or:] “It (the wine) was not emptied from vessel to vessel.” It does not state here: “The vessel was not emptied” but, rather: “The <font color=d50505>»</font>wine<font color=d50505>«</font> was not emptied from vessel to vessel.” Thus we find the term referring to the wine: Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵרִיקוּ) They will draw their swords against the beauty of your wisdom” [in the narrative] concerning Chiram. "

§§—2—§§ 15:9:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אריק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרבי Translate this as the Targum: I WILL DRAW [MY SWORD]. Because one empties the scabbard when one draws out the sword and it (the scabbard) then remains empty (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריק), the, expression “emptying” is appropriate to it (to the act of drawing the sword), as in (Genesis 42:35) “emptying (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מריקים) their sacks”; (Jeremiah 48:12) “And they shall empty (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יריקו) his vessels (of wine)”. Now do not say that the expression “emptiness” in these examples does not apply to the thing which comes out, but that it applies to the scabbard and the sack and the vessels from which these things come out and not to the sword and to the wine (it is the scabbard, the sack and the vessels which are empty not the sword, the corn and the wine), — and consequently give a forced explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אריק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרבי in the sense of the verb in (Genesis 14:14) “He armed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירק) his trained servants”, saying that it means, “I will arm myself with my sword”, for we do, indeed, find the expression “empty” applied also to the thing which, comes out of a receptacle; e. g., (Song 1:3) “oil which is emptied (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תורק)”; (Jeremiah 48:11) “it (the wine) hath not been emptied (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הורק) from vessel to vessel”. It does not say here “the vessel hath not been emptied”, but “the wine has not been emptied (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הורק) from vessel to vessel”; consequently this expression is applied to the wine. Exactly like the phrase in this verse, is (Ezekiel 28:7) “And they shall draw their swords (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והריקו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרבותם) against the beauty of thy wisdom”, in the chapter about Hiram."

—3— **Ich zücke mein Schwert,** ich ziehe es; weil er durch das Herausziehen die Scheide ausschüttet, dass sie leer zurückbleibt, passt darauf der Ausdruck ausleeren; wie (Gen. 42, 35), als sie ihre Säcke leerten; (Jer. 48, 12) seine Gefässe leeren sie aus. Wende aber nicht ein, den Ausdruck ausleeren könne man nicht auf das, was herauskommt, sondern nur auf den Behälter, auf den Sack und das Gefäss anwenden, aus dem der Inhalt herauskommt, aber nicht auf das Schwert und auf den Wein, und wir müssten uns zwingen und erklären, ich zücke mein Schwert, gleich dem Ausdruck (Gen. 14, 14), er bewaffnete seine Geübten, ich bewaffne mich mit meinem Schwert; wir finden aber, dass sich der Ausdruck auch auf das bezieht, was herauskommt; (Schir 1, 3) wie Öl ergießt sich; (Jer. 48, 11) und ward nicht von Gefäss in Gefäss geleert; es steht hier nicht, das Gefäss wurde nicht ausgeleert, sondern der Wein wurde nicht von einem Gefäss ins andere geleert; wir finden also, dass sich der Ausdruck auf den Wein bezieht; ebenso (Jech. 28, 7), dass sie ihre Schwerter zücken über die Pracht Deiner Weisheit, bei Chirom. 

---

////—1—//// 15:9:4,"**Will destroy them.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תּוֹרִישֵׁמוֹ is a term denoting <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רֵישׁוּת (poorness) and poverty, as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוֹרִישׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמַעֲשִׁיר — He impoverishes and enriches. "

§§—2—§§ 15:9:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תורישמו This is an expression for poverty and need, (meaning “my hand shall make them poor”), just as, (I Samuel 2:27) “He maketh poor (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוריש) and maketh rich.”"

—3— **Dass sie aufreibe,** von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רישות Dürftigkeit und Armut; wie (Sam. 2, 7) macht arm und macht reich. 

---

////—1—//// 15:10:1,**You made [Your wind] blow.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָשַׁפְתָּ is] a term meaning <font color=d50505>»</font>blowing<font color=d50505>«</font>. Similarly: “He also (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָשַׁף) blew upon them.”

§§—2—§§ 15:10:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשפת — an expression for “blowing”. Similar is (Isaiah 40:24) “He bloweth (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשף) upon them”.

—3— **10. Du ließest wehen,** bedeutet anwehen, ebenso (Jes. 40,24), auch weht sie der Wind an. 

---

////—1—//// 15:10:2,"**They sank.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צָלֲלוּ means] they sank, they went deep from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְצוּלָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>depth<font color=d50505>«</font>. "

§§—2—§§ 15:10:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צללו means THEY SANK, they went deep, — an expression of the same root as (Psalms 69:3) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצולה “the depths”."

—3— **Sie sanken,** sie versanken, gerieten in die Tiefe, von (Ps. 69, 3), der Tiefe. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעופרת Blei, plomb = Blei in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:10:3,"**Like lead.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עוֹפֶרֶת means:] lead, <font color=d50505>»</font>plom<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 15:10:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כעופרת LIKE LEAD: old French plomb.


---

////—1—//// 15:11:1,"**Among the mighty.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּאֵלִים means] among the mighty, as in: “And (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵילֵי) the mighty of the land he took,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֱיָלוּתִי) My strength, hasten to help me.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באלם means AMONGST THE MIGHTY, just as (Ezekiel 17:13) “and the mighty of (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אילי) the land he took away”; (Psalms 22:20) “O, thou my strength (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אילותי) hasten to my help”."

—3— **11. Unter den Mächtigen,** den Starken, wie (Jech. 17, 13), die Starken des Landes nahm er mit; (Ps. 22, 20) Du, meine Stärke, zu meiner Hilfe eile herbei. 

---

////—1—//// 15:11:2,"**Awesome in praise.** [I.e.,] it is fearsome to relate Your praises, for one might fall short [in his praises], as is written: “For You, silence is praise.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:11:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נורא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהלות means Thou art an object of dread so that people do not recount thy praises fearing lest these may be enumerated less then they really are, just as it is written (Psalms 65:2) “To Thee, silence is praise”."

—3— **Ehrfurchtbar an Ruhm,** Du bist gefürchtet, (und man wagt nicht) Deine Ruhmestaten zu verkünden, weil sie dadurch verringert werden könnten, wie es heißt (Ps. 65, 2), vor Dir ist Schweigen Ruhmesverkündung. 

---

////—1—//// 15:12:1,"**You extended your right hand.** When God extends His hand the wicked become extinct and fall, because all things are held in His hand and they fall when it is extended. Similarly it says: “When God will extend His hand then the helper will stumble and the one being helped will fall.” This can be compared to glass vessels that are held in a person’s hand; if he extends (opens) his hand slightly they fall and break. "

§§—2—§§ 15:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נטית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימינך THOU INCLINEST THY RIGHT HAND — When the Holy One, blessed be He, inclines His hand the wicked cease to be and fall — because everything is held in His hand and consequently falls when He inclines it. Similarly it states, (Isaiah 31:3) “When the Lord inclineth His hand, he that helpeth shall stumble and he that is helped shall fall”. A parable: it may be compared to glass vessels held in a man’s hand: if he inclines his hand a little they fall and are shattered to pieces (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:12:3)."

—3— **12. Du neigest Deine Rechte,** wenn der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, Seine Hand neigt, hören die Frevler auf und sinken hinab, weil alles in Seiner Hand ruht und durch deren Neigen sie hinabsinken; so sagt er auch (Jes. 31, 3), der Ewige neigt Seine Hand, und es strauchelt, der helfen will, und stürzt, dem geholfen wird; wie bei Glasgefässen, die in den Händen eines Menschen ruhen, neigt er nur ein bissehen seine Hand, so fallen sie zur Erde und zerbrechen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:12:2,"**The earth swallowed them.** From this we derive that they were privileged to be buried, as a reward for having proclaimed, “Adonoy is the righteous One!” "

§§—2—§§ 15:12:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבלעמו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארץ THE EARTH SWALLOWED THEM — From this it may be gathered that they received the privilege of burial as a reward for having said, (Exodus 9:27) “The Lord is righteous” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:12:2)."

—3— **Da verschlang sie die Erde,** von hier lernen wir, dass sie das Glück hatten, begraben zu werden, als Lohn dafür, dass sie gesagt (9,27), der Ewige ist der Gerechte (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:13:1,"**You guided —** has the same derivation as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְנַהֵל — <font color=d50505>»</font>leader<font color=d50505>«</font>. Onkelos, however, translates it [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוֹבַרְהִי] relating to <font color=d50505>»</font>carrying<font color=d50505>«</font> and <font color=d50505>»</font>bearing,<font color=d50505>«</font> but he was not meticulous to explain it according to the exact Hebrew language. "

§§—2—§§ 15:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נהלת is of the same root, conjugation and meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנהל a leader; Onkelos translated it in the sense of bearing and carrying, but he was not particular to translate according to the Hebrew expression (i. e., to translate literally)"

—3— **13. Du führtest,** von (Jes. 51,18) führt, geleitet; Onkelos übersetzt von tragen und bringen und übersetzt damit nicht wörtlich den hebräischen Ausdruck. 

---

////—1—//// 15:14:1,**And they tremble.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִרְגָּזוּן means] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִתְרַגְּזִין — <font color=d50505>»</font>they tremble.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 15:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירגזון means THEY TREMBLE (not they will tremble).

—3— **14. Erbebten,** wurden unruhig. 

---

////—1—//// 15:14:2,"**The inhabitants of Philistia.** Because it was they who killed Ephraim’s descendants who had calculated prematurely the end [of the Egyptian exile] and went out [of Egypt] by force, as is related in Divrei Hayomim: “The men of Gath (the Philistines) killed them” "

§§—2—§§ 15:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישבי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פלשת [REIGS SEIZED] THE INHABITANTS OF PALESTINE, because they slew the children of Ephraim who anticipated the end fixed for the period of slavery and left Egypt forcibly, as is explained in Chronicles (1 7:21) “[The sons of Ephraim…] whom the men of Gath slew” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:14:3)."

—3— **Die Bewohner von Peleschet,** weil sie die Söhne Efraims, die das Ende der Verbannung hatten beschleunigen wollen und mit Gewalt ausgezogen waren, getötet hatten, wie in der Chronik (I, 7, 21) steht, es töteten sie die Einwohner von Gat (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:15:1,"**The chiefs of Edom the mighty men of Moav.** But, surely, they had nothing to fear for they (the B’nei Yisrael) were not going against them! But [the explanation is:] it was because of greivance, for they were greived and pained over the honor of Yisrael. "

§§—2—§§ 15:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלופי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אילי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מואב [THEN WERE PERTURBED] THE CHIEFTAINS OF EDOM, THE MIGHTY MEN OF MOAB — But surely they had no cause to fear anything because they (the Israelites) were not marching against them! But the explanation is, that they were perturbed by annoyance, because they were annoyed and distressed by the glory that Israel had achieved (cf. Yalkut Shimoni on Torah 251:11)."

—3— **15. Die Fürsten von Edom, die Mächtigen Moabs,** fürwahr, diese brauchten sich gar nicht zu fürchten; denn Israel zog nicht gegen sie zu Felde; vielmehr war es nur Trauer, sie trauerten und grämten sich über die Ehre Israels (Jalk. Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:15:2,"**Melted away.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָמוֹגוּ means] <font color=d50505>»</font>they melted away,<font color=d50505>«</font> as in: “With showers (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּמֹגְגֶנָּה) you make it soft.” They said: “They are coming against us to annihilate us and inherit our land.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נמגו means THEY MELTED — just as, (Psalms 65:11) “Thou makest it soft (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמגגנה) with showers”. They said, “They are marching against us to destroy us and to take possession of our land” (therefore they melted away from fear, and were not merely perturbed in mind) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:15:1)."

—3— **Es lösten sich auf,** zerschmolzen (Mech.), wie (Ps. 65,11), durch reichen Regen machst Du sie schmelzen; sie dachten, sie kommen über uns, uns zu vernichten und unser Land einzunehmen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:16:1,**Horror fall upon them.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵימָתָה is fear] upon those who are far away.

§§—2—§§ 15:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליהם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אימתה THERE SHALL FALL UPON THEM DREAD — upon those of them who are far away (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:16:1),"

—3— **16. Es möge auf sie fallen Angst,** auf die Fernen (Mech.), und Schrecken auf die Nahen, wie es heißt, (Jos. 2,10), denn wir vernahmen, dass trocken werden ließ… **bis vorübergezogen, bis vorübergezogen,** wie der Targum sagt (über den Arnon und den Jarden). 

---

////—1—//// 15:16:2,"**And dread.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פַּחַד is fear] on those who are nearby. This is similar to what is said: “For we have heard how He has dried up, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופחד AND HORROR — shall fall upon those of them who are near by; and all this really happened just as the matter is stated, (Joshua 2:10) “For we have heard how the Lord dried up [the waters of the Red Sea]” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:16:1)."

—3— **Erworben,** das du liebst mehr als die übrigen Völker, wie ein Gegenstand, der für einen hohen Preis erworben wird, dem Menschen lieb ist. 

---

////—1—//// 15:16:3,"**Until they cross over, until they cross over.** As Onkelos explains it. "

§§—2—§§ 15:16:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעבר ... <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעבר TILL THY PEOPLE PASS … TILL THE PEOPLE PASS — The repetition must be explained as the Targum takes it (until they pass over the Arnon, until they pass over the Jordan)."


---

////—1—//// 15:16:4,"**You acquired.** [I.e.,] “You hold it dearer than other nations, similar to an object acquired (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָנוּי) at a high price that is held dear by the person. "

§§—2—§§ 15:16:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנית denotes [THE PEOPLE] WHICH THOU HOLDEST DEAR above all peoples — like an article purchased (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנוי) at a high price and which is therefore held in affection by the man who bought it.


---

////—1—//// 15:17:1,**You will bring them.** Moshe prophesied that he would not enter the land. It therefore does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּבִיאֵנוּ — “You will bring <font color=d50505>»</font>us<font color=d50505>«</font>.”

§§—2—§§ 15:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבאמו THOU WILL BRING THEM IN — Moses foresaw by prophetic inspiration that he would not enter the Holy Land: on this account it is not stated here, “Thou wilt bring us in” (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:17:1)."

—3— **17. Du bringst sie,** Mosche weissagte, dass er nicht ins Land kommen werde, darum heißt es nicht, du bringst uns. 

---

////—1—//// 15:17:2,**The place for Your habitation.** The Temple below is lined up exactly opposite the Throne above that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּעַלְתָּ — You made.

§§—2—§§ 15:17:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשבתך THE PLACE FOR THY RESIDENCE — the Sanctuary here below will be exactly opposite the Divine Throne above which <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פעלת THOU HAST MADE (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:17:4).

—3— **Gegründet zu Deiner Stätte,** das Heiligtum auf Erden wird sich gegenüber dem Throne im Himmel befinden, den Du geschaffen (Mech). 

---

////—1—//// 15:17:3,"**The Sanctuary.** The intonation on it (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְדָשׁ) is a <font color=d50505>»</font>zakef godol<font color=d50505>«</font> in order to separate it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְדָשׁ) from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' which follows it, [thus giving it the meaning of] “the Sanctuary, which your hands, Adonoy, established.” [This indicates the] preciousness of the Beis Hamikdosh, for the world was created with “one hand,” as it is said: “Truly My hand has established the earth,” whereas the Mikdosh [was made] with “two hands.” And when will it be built with “two hands?” when the time comes that “Adonoy will reign forever and ever,” in the future when all the kingdom will be His. "

§§—2—§§ 15:17:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקדש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ The accent on it (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקדש) is a Zakef Gadol (a disjunctive accent) which serves to separate it from the word expressing the Divine Name (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳) which follows it, so that the translation is: “The sanctuary which Thy hands have established, O Lord”. The Temple is an object of affection to God because the Universe was created by one hand — as it is stated, (Isaiah 48:13) “Yea, My hand hath laid the foundation of the earth” — whilst the Temple by two hands, as stated here. And when will it be rebuilt by God, with the two hands? At the time when “the Lord shall reign for ever and ever”: at that future period when all the kingdom will be His (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:17:5)."

—3— **Dem Heiligtum, Ewiger,** der Ton auf <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקדש ist ein Sakef-Gadol (Trennungszeichen), um es von dem darauffolgenden Worte Haschern zu trennen, das Heiligtum, das Deine Hände gegründet haben, o Ewiger; lieb ist das Heiligtum; denn die ganze Welt ist nur mit einer Hand erschaffen worden, so heißt es (Jes. 48, 13), auch gründetete meine Hand die Erde; das Heiligtum aber wird es mit beiden Händen; und wann wird es mit beiden Händen erbaut werden? Zur Zeit, da der Ewige immer und ewig regieren wird, einst, da das ganze Reich Ihm gehören wird (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:18:1,"**Forever and ever.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וָעֶד is an expression denoting eternity and the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' in it is part of the root therefore it is vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>patach<font color=d50505>«</font> But [in the verse] “I am the One Who knows (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וָעֵד) and bears witness,” where the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' in it is a prefix, it bears the <font color=d50505>»</font>kametz<font color=d50505>«</font> vowel (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וָעֵד). "
