§§—2—§§ 15:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעלם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועד The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועד is an expression denoting ETERNITY — The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו in it is a root-letter, and consequently it is vowelled with a Patach; but in the similar word in (Jeremiah 29:23) “I am He that knoweth and am witness (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועד)”, where the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו is a servile letter (a prefix) it is vowelled with a Kametz."

—3— **18. Immer und ewig, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועד** bedeutet Ewigkeit, und das Waw gehört zum Stamm, darum hat das Wort ein Patach (Segol); aber (Jer. 29,23), ich weiß und bin Zeuge, wo das Waw Bedienungsbuchstabe ist, hat das Wort ein Kamez (Zere). 

---

////—1—//// 15:19:1,**When Pharaoh’s horse came.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָא means] <font color=d50505>»</font>when<font color=d50505>«</font> it came.

§§—2—§§ 15:19:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרעה means WHEN [THE HORSES] CAME.

—3— **19. Als die Roße Pharaos gekommen,** nachdem sie gekommen waren. 

---

////—1—//// 15:20:1,"**Miriam, the prophetess, took.** Where was it that she prophesied? It was when she was [only] <font color=d50505>»</font>Aharon’s sister,<font color=d50505>«</font> before Moshe was born. She [then] said: “My mother is destined to give birth to a son, etc.,” as is related in Maseches Sotah. An alternate explanation [as to why she is identified as] <font color=d50505>»</font>Aharon’s<font color=d50505>«</font> sister: Because he put his life in jeopardy for her when she was struck by leprosy, she is identified by his name. "

§§—2—§§ 15:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנביאה AND MIRIAM THE PROPHETESS TOOK — But where had she prophesied? When she was THE SISTER OF AARON alone — before Moses was born she said, “My mother will at some time bear a son who will deliver Israel etc.”, as is stated in Treatise Sotah 12b (cf. Megillah 14a). Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן, the sister of Aaron: because he jeopardised his life for her by entreating on her behalf and so possibly incurring God’s displeasure when she was stricken with leprosy, she is called by his name (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:20:1; cf. Rashi Genesis 34:25). "

—3— **20. Da nahm Mirjam, die Prophetin,** wann hatte sie geweissagt? Als sie die Schwester Aharons war, bevor Mosche geboren war, damals sagte sie, meine Mutter wird einen Sohn gebären … wie in Sota (13a) vorkommt; andere Erklärung: die Schwester Aharons, weil er sich für sie einsetzte, als sie aussätzig war (Num. 12, 11), wird sie nach seinem Namen genannt (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:20:2,**The drum.** An instrument for certain kinds of music.

§§—2—§§ 15:20:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>התף A TIMBREL — an instrument for a particular kind of music.

—3— **Die Pauke,** ein Musikinstrument. 

---

////—1—//// 15:20:3,**With drums and dancing.** The righteous women of that generations were sure that God would perform miracles for them so they took drums out of Egypt.

§§—2—§§ 15:20:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתפים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובמחלת WITH TIMBRELS AND WITH DANCES — The righteous women in that generation were confident that God would perform miracles for them and they accordingly had brought timbrels with them from Egypt (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:20:2).

—3— **Mit Pauken und im Reigen,** die frommen Frauen in jenem Geschlecht waren voll Vertrauen gewesen, dass der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, ihnen Wunder erweisen würde, darum hatten sie Pauken aus Mizraim mitgenommen (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:21:1,**Miriam led them in the response.** Moshe sang the song for the men — he would say it and they would respond after him. And Miriam sang the song for the women.

§§—2—§§ 15:21:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרים AND MIRIAM SANG UNTO THEM — Moses sang the Song to the men — he sang it and they repeated it after him; and Miriam sang the Song to the women and they repeated it after her (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:20:2).

—3— **21. Und es begann zu ihnen Mirjam,** Mosche sprach das Lied zu den Männern, er sprach vor, und sie antworteten nach ihm, und Mirjam sprach das Lied zu den Frauen (Mech. 15, 1; Sota 30b). 

---

////—1—//// 15:22:1,"**Moshe led.** He made them travel against their will. For the Egyptians adorned their horses with gold and silver ornaments and precious stones and the Israelites kept finding them in the sea [to the point that] the booty of the sea was greater than the booty [taken out] of Egypt, as it is said: “We will make gold bracelets for you (from the booty of the sea) together with silver studs (from the booty of Egypt).” Therefore he had to make them travel against their will. "

§§—2—§§ 15:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויסע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND MOSES CAUSED [ISRAEL] TO JOURNEY — He made them journey against their own will, because the Egyptians had adorned their horses with ornaments of gold and silver and with precious stones, and the Israelites were finding these in the sea. Greater, indeed, was the booty they obtained at the Red Sea then the booty they had brought out of Egypt — as it is said (Song 1:11) “Circlets of gold (the booty of the Sea) will we make thee together with the studs of silver” (which we brought forth from Egypt) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 12:36). On this account he was compelled to make them journey on against their will."

—3— **22. Mosche machte aufbrachen,** gegen ihren Willen hieß er sie weiterziehen; denn die Ägypter hatten ihre Roße mit Zierat aus Gold und Silber und Edelsteinen geschmückt, und Israel fand all die am Meere, so dass die Beute am Meere größer war als die Beute in Ägypten; so heißt es (Schir 1, 11), goldenen Schmuck wollen wir für dich machen mit silbernen Punkten; darum hatte er nötig, sie gegen ihren Willen aufbrechen zu machen (Tanchuma; Mech. bo).

////—1—//// 15:23:1,"**They came to Marah.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָרָתָה is] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמָרָה — <font color=d50505>»</font>to Marah.<font color=d50505>«</font> The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' at the end of the word is in place of the letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל' at its beginning. The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' is in place of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' which is part of the root-word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָרָה, and when it in the construct state when it is joined to a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' which is added in place of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל', then the <font color=d50505>»</font>root-letter<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' is changed to a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' . Similarly any <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' that is part of the root-word changes to a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' in the construct state, as in: “I have no <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֵמָה (anger),” “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַחֲמָתוֹ (And his anger) burned within him.” There you have a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' of a root-word changing to a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' because it is joined to the added <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו': Similarly: “A slave and an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָמָה (servant-maiden),” [which changes to] “Here is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲמָתִי (my hand-maiden) Bilhah” [or:] “to a creature <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַיָּה (of life)” [becomes] “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַיָּתוֹ (his life) makes bread repulsive to him” [or:] “Between <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָמָה (Ramah and Bethel)” [which changes to] “His return was <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָרָמָתָה (to Ramah). "

§§—2—§§ 15:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרתה AND THEY CAME TO MARAH — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרתה is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למרה: a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה at the end of a word (as a suffix) replaces a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל at its beginning (as a prefix). The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת takes the place of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה which is rooted in (an integral part of) the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרה; when it is joined with another letter, viz., when it is attached to the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה which is added to the word in place of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל, the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה of the primary form (the ordinary form of the noun from which longer forms are made by the addition of suffixes) is changed into a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת. Thus, also, every <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה which is a root-letter (a letter in the primary form of the noun) is changed into a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת when it is joined to another letter. E. g., we have (Isaiah 27:4) “Fury (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמה) is not in Me”, but (Esther 1:12) “And his fury (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמתו) burned within him”; you see that the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה of the ground-form is changed into a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת because it is to be joined to the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו which has been added. Similar are: (Leviticus 25:44) “Manservant and handmaid (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמה)”, but (Genesis 30:3) “Behold, my handmaid (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמתי) Bilhah”; (Genesis 2:7) “a creature of life (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיה)”, but (Job 33:20) “His life (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חיתו) maketh him to abhor bread”; (Judges 4:5) “Between Ramah (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה) [and Beth-el]”, but (I Samuel 7:17) “And his return was to Ramah (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרמתה)” the latter example being exactly parallel to that in this verse (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרתה - <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרה‎)."

—3— **23. Und sie kamen nach Mara, = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למרה,** He am Ende des Wortes ist gleich Lamed am Anfang; und das Taw ist an Stelle des He, das zur Wurzel des Wortes <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרה gehört; durch die Verbindung, da es mit He, das er an Stelle des Lamed hinzugefügt hat, verbunden ist, verwandelt sich das He der Wurzel in Taw; und so verwandelt sich jedes He, das zur Wurzel des Wortes gehört, durch seine Verbindung in Taw; wie (Jes. 27,4), ich habe keinen Grimm, dagegen, (Esth. 1, 12) und sein Grimm brannte in ihm; da verwandelte sich das He der Wurzel in Taw, weil es sich mit dem hinzugefügten Waw verbindet; ebenso (Lev. 25,44), Knecht oder Magd, und (Gen. 30,3) siehe meine Magd Bilha; (Gen. 2, 2) zum lebenden Geschöpf, und (Job 33, 20) seine Seele verwirft jede Speise; (Richt. 4, 5) zwischen Rama, und (I Sam. 7,17) und seine Rückkehr war nach Rama. 

---

////—1—//// 15:24:1,"**They complained.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּלֹּנוּ] is in the <font color=d50505>»</font>nifal<font color=d50505>«</font> form: Onkelos, too, translates it in the <font color=d50505>»</font>nifal<font color=d50505>«</font> form: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאִתְרָעָמוּ . (In Aramaic the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִתְפְּעֵל represents the Hebrew <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִפְעַל .) This is the way of expressions of complaint to revert the statement to the person [complaining], [e.g.] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִתְלוֹנֵן (complain), <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִתְרוֹעֵם (resent) and it is not said in the form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוֹנֵן, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רוֹעֵם . The French man also expresses it this way: “<font color=d50505>»</font>decomplaisant se<font color=d50505>«</font>.” The action reverts to himself by the use of the expression “<font color=d50505>»</font>se.<font color=d50505>«</font>” "

§§—2—§§ 15:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילנו AND THEY MURMURED — This is a Niphal form, and similarly the Targum is a Niphal form: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתרעמו (the Ithpael form in Aramaic corresponds to the Hebrew Niphal). And such is the way in which the expression denoting murmuring (from root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לון) is employed: to refer back the matter (the action of murmuring) to the person (the subject of the verb); thus one says <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתלונן and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתרועם and one does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לונן and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רועם. So, too, the Frenchman says “decomplaisant se” in old French, where it turns back the matter (the action) to himself (the subject) by saying, “se”, English himself."

—3— **24. Da murrte,** ist Nifalform; ebenso ist Targum Nifalform, sie murrten; das ist die Art des Ausdrucks <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלונה, dass man die reflexive Form auf das Subjekt anwendet, er beklagt sich <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתלונן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתרעם, und man sagt nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לונן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רעם; so sagt man auch in andere Sprachen, sich beklagen, das ist die reflexive Form, indem man «sich» hinzufügt.

////—1—//// 15:25:1,**There He set before them.** In Marah He gave them some sections of the Torah so that they occupy themselves with [studying] them: [the sections dealing with] Shabbos the <font color=d50505>»</font>Parah Adumah<font color=d50505>«</font> (the red heifer) and the administration of justice.

§§—2—§§ 15:25:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו HERE HE MADE FOR THEM [A STATUTE AND AN ORDINANCE) — At Marah He gave them a few sections of the Torah in order that they might engage in the study thereof; viz., the sections containing the command regarding the sabbath, the red heifer and the administration of justice (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:25; Sanhedrin 56b)."

—3— **25. Dort gab Er ihm,** in Mara gab Er ihnen einen Teil der Abschnitte der Torah, dass sie sich mit ihnen beschäftigten, den Sabbat, das Gesetz betreffs der roten Kuh und Rechte (Sanhedrin 40b; Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 15:25:2,"**And there He tested them. (lit. Him).** [Meaning:] the nation, and saw their stubbornness, for they did not consult with Moshe with respectful language, [i.e.] “Pray for compassion for us so that we may have water to drink,” but, rather, they complained. "

§§—2—§§ 15:25:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסהו AND THERE HE TRIED THEM (lit., He tried him) — “him” (singular) means the people; and He saw their stubbornness: that they did not consult with Moses in a respectful fashion: “Entreat mercy for us that we may have water to drink” — but that they murmured."

—3— **Und dort prüfte Er es,** das Volk, und sah seine Hartnäckigkeit, dass sie nicht mit Mosche mit würdigen Worten berieten, bete für uns, dass wir Wasser zum Trinken erhalten, sondern murrten. 

---

////—1—//// 15:26:1,**If you vigilantly obey.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׁמוֹעַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּשְׁמַע] implies acceptance — that they accept upon themselves [God’s commands].

§§—2—§§ 15:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשמע IF THOU WILL DILIGENTLY HEARKEN — this implies acceptance — that they should take upon themselves the duty of performing God’s commands.

—3— **26. Wenn du hören wirst,** das ist die Bereitwilligkeit, das Gesetz anzunehmen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:26:2,**Do.** [Meaning:] the actual performing [of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font>].

§§—2—§§ 15:26:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תעשה AND IF THOU WILT DO — this implies the performance of the commands.

—3— **Tun wirst,** das ist die Ausführung. 

---

////—1—//// 15:26:3,**Give ear.** Incline the ears in order to be exact in [fulfilling] them.

§§—2—§§ 15:26:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והאזנת means THOU WILT INCLINE THE EAR to be punctilious in the practice of the details.

—3— **Und lauschst,** neigst das Ohr, um genau zu verstehen. 

---

////—1—//// 15:26:4,"**All His statutes.** Things that are solely a decree of the king with no [given] reason, where the evil inclination finds fault with them: [by saying:] “What is the sense in their prohibition — why were they prohibited?” For example: [the prohibition against:] wearing <font color=d50505>»</font>shatnez<font color=d50505>«</font> and the eating of pork [and the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font> of] the <font color=d50505>»</font>Parah Adumah<font color=d50505>«</font> (red heifer), and their like. "

§§—2—§§ 15:26:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חקיו ALL HIS STATUTES — Matters which are only the decrees of the King (decrees of God imposed by Him, as King, upon us, His subjects) and which appear to have no reason, and at which the evil inclination cavils saying, “What sense is there in prohibiting these? Why should they be prohibited?” — For instance: the prohibition of wearing a mixture of wool and linen, and of eating swine’s flesh, and the law regarding the red heifer, and similar matters (cf. Yoma 67b)."

—3— **Alle Seine Satzungen,** Worte, die nur Verordnungen des Königs sind, ohne dass uns eine Begründung dafür bekannt ist, und gegen die der böse Trieb einwendet, was für ein Verbot kann auf diesen Dingen ruhen, warum sollen diese verboten sein, wie das Anziehen einer Verbindung von Wolle und Leinen, der Genuss von Schweinefleisch, das Gesetz betreffs der roten Kuh und ähnliche (Joma 67b). 

---

////—1—//// 15:26:5,"**I will not bring upon you.** [Meaning:] and if I do bring it it will be as if it were not brought — “for I am Adonoy, Who heals you.” That is its midrashic explanation. But its plain explanation is: “For I am Adonoy, Who heals you, and teaches you Torah and <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> so that you may be saved from them (the diseases).” It is like a doctor who tells a person: “Do not eat this particular thing lest it bring you to disease this represents listening to the mitzvos. this is what is meant when it says. “It (obedience to <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font>) will be healthful to your navel.” "

§§—2—§§ 15:26:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליך I WILL NOT PLACE ON THEE — and if I do place them on thee because thou refusest to hearken to My voice, it will be as though they had not been placed on thee, for if thou repentest of thy disobedience I will remove them immediately, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רפאך BECAUSE I AM THE LORD THAT HEALETH THEE. This is its Midrashic explanation (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:15). But according to its literal sense the meaning is: For I am the Lord who healeth thee and teacheth thee the Law and Commandments in order that thou mayst be saved from them (these diseases) — like a physician who says to a man: Do not eat this thing lest it will bring you into danger from this disease. So, too, it states, (Proverbs 3:8) “It (obedience to God) will be wholesome to thy body” (implying that disease will not fall upon thee) (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:15)."

—3— **Werde ich nicht auf dich legen,** und wenn ich sie lege, wird es sein, als wären sie nicht auf dich gelegt, weil ich, der Ewige, dein Arzt bin; das ist der Midrasch (Mech.); nach dem einfachen Sinn, denn ich, der Ewige, bin dein Arzt und lehre dich Torah und Gebote, damit du vor jenen bewahrt bleibest; wie ein Arzt zu einem Menschen spricht, iss dies nicht, es könnte dich krank machen (das ist das Lauschen auf die Gebote); und so heißt es auch (Spr. 3, 8), das wird Heilung sein für deinen Leib.

§§—2—§§ 15:27:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שתים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עינת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מים TWELVE SPRINGS OF WATER — A number corresponding to the twelve tribes of Israel were ready for them (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:27).

—3— **27. Zwölf Wasserquellen,** den Stämmen entsprechend wurden sie ihnen zuteil, und siebzig Dattelpalmen, den siebzig Ältesten entsprechend (Mech.).

////—1—//// 15:27:2,**And seventy date trees.** Corresponding to the seventy elders.

§§—2—§§ 15:27:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושבעים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמרים AND SEVENTY PALM-TREES — corresponding to the seventy elders (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:27).

////—1—//// 16:1:1,"**The fifteenth day.** The date of this encampment is specifically mentioned because on that day they finished the[ir supply of] cake which they took out of Egypt. and [now] they needed the manna. We learn from this that from the remains of the dough they ate sixty one meals [through the 15th of Iyar] and the manna descended for them on the sixteenth day of Iyar, which was on the first day of the week as is cited in Maseches Shabbos. "

§§—2—§§ 16:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחמשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יום ON THE FIFTEENTH DAY — The day of this encampment is specially mentioned because on that day there came to an end the cake (provisions) they had brought with them from Egypt and they now needed the Manna, thus informing us that of the remains of the dough they had prepared in Egypt (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 12:33) they ate sixty-one meals. For the Manna fell for them on the sixteenth day of Iyar, which was the first day of the week, just as is stated in the Treatise Shabbat 87b."

—3— **16, 1. Am fünfzehnten Tag,** der Tag dieses Lagerns ist angegeben, weil an diesem Tag das Gebäck zu Ende war, das sie aus Mizraim mitgenommen hatten, und sie das Man brauchten (Mech.). Das lehrt uns, dass sie von den Überresten des Teiges (oder der Mazza) 61 Mahlzeiten assen; das Man fiel für sie am 15. Ijar, das war am ersten Tage der Woche, wie im Traktat Schabbat (87b) steht.

////—1—//// 16:2:1,**They complained.** Because their [supply of] bread was finished.

§§—2—§§ 16:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וילנו AND THEY MURMURED, because the bread had come to an end."

—3— **2. Da murrte,** weil das Brot zu Ende gegangen war.

////—1—//// 16:3:1,"**If only we had died.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתֵנוּ means:] “that we should die.” It is not a noun as is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִיתָתֵנוּ — “our death” but rather like <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲשֹוֹתֵנוּ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲנוֹתֵנוּ, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שׁוּבֵנוּ which mean: <font color=d50505>»</font>that we should make, that we should set up camp, that we should die.<font color=d50505>«</font> Onkelos translates it (i.e., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִתֵּן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מוּתֵנוּ) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְוַי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דְמִיתְנָא as [he translates] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַתְנוּ [meaning:] “If only that we should die.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מותנו WOULD THAT WE HAD DIED — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מותנו means “that we should die”; it is not a noun with the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתתנו “our death”, but it is an infinitive like <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשותנו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חנותנו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שובנו which signify “that we should make”, “that we should encamp”, “that we should return”. In the Targum it is rendered by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דמיתנא which is really the Targum rendering of (Numbers 14:2) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתנו “Would that we were dead” (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 14:12)."

—3— **3. Oh, wären wir doch gestorben;** dass wir doch gestorben wären; es ist kein Hauptwort wie, unseren Tod, sondern wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שובנו,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חנותנו,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשותנו, dass wir tun, zurückkehren, lagern, dass wir sterben; der Targum sagt, wären wir doch gestorben; (Num. 14, 2) wären wir doch gestorben, wir wünschten, gestorben zu sein.

////—1—//// 16:4:1,**Enough for each day.** The food requirements for the day they shall gather on <font color=d50505>»</font>that<font color=d50505>«</font> day. They may not gather today for tomorrow’s needs.

§§—2—§§ 16:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביומו THE THING OF THE DAY ON ITS DAY — what is needed for a day’s eating shall they collect on its (that) day, and they shall not today collect what will be needed tomorrow (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:4)."

—3— **4. Den Bedarf des Tages an seinem Tag,** was sie an einem Tag zum Essen gebrauchten, sollten sie an dem betreffenden Tage sammeln, und nicht von einem Tag schon für den nächsten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 16:4:2,"**That I may test them [to see] If they will walk [in the way of] My teaching.** Whether they will keep the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> dealing with it [viz.,] that they not leave any of it [overnight] and that they not go out on Shabbos to gather [it]. "

§§—2—§§ 16:4:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנסנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הילך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתורתי THAT I MAY TRY THEM WHETHER THEY WILL WALK IN MY LAW — whether they will observe the commands associated with it: viz., that they should not leave any overnight, and that they should not go out on the Sabbath to collect it."

—3— **Damit ich es prüfe,** ob es in meiner Lehre wandelt, ob sie die Gebote hüten, die damit verbunden sind, dass sie nichts davon übriglassen und am Sabbat nicht hinausgehen, um zu sammeln.

////—1—//// 16:5:1,**It will be twice as much.** For today and for tomorrow.

§§—2—§§ 16:5:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה AND IT SHALL BE DOUBLE — for today and for tomorrow.

—3— **5. Und es wird das Doppelte sein,** für den Tag und den nächsten Tag. 

---

////—1—//// 16:5:2,"**Twice as much.** As they usually gathered each day of the rest of the days of the week. I say that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָבִיאוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׁנֶה [should be joined] [and it means:] “After they bring it [home] they will find twice as much upon measuring it over what they had been gathering and measuring every day.” This is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָקְטוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֶחֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׁנֶה: [i.e.,] upon having gathered it it was found to be a double portion of bread. This, too, is the meaning of: “Therefore He gives you on the sixth day bread for two days.” He gives you a blessing (<font color=d50505>»</font>foison<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French) in the house, to fill the <font color=d50505>»</font>omer<font color=d50505>«</font> twice, so as to have bread for two days. "

§§—2—§§ 16:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה DOUBLE of what they were accustomed to collect on each day of the other days of the week. I say that the words, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יביאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה “what they bring shall be double”, imply that after they have brought it home they will find it double in measure of what they had been gathering and measuring each day. This is the force of: “they collected double bread” (v. 22) — when it was collected it was found by them to be double food, and this is the meaning of (v. 29), “therefore he giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days”: He gives you a blessing — old French foison, — abundance in the house that you may fill the Omer twice, as bread for two days."

—3— **Doppelte,** von dem, was sie gewohnt sind, jeden Tag von den anderen Tagen der Woche zu sammeln; ich meine, die Worte, was sie nach Hause bringen, und es wird das Doppelte sein, bedeuten, nachdem sie es nach Hause gebracht, werden sie beim Messen das Doppelte von dem finden, was sie jeden Tag sammeln und messen; dasselbe sagt auch (V. 22), sie hatte doppeltes Brot gesammelt, nach dem Sammeln stellte sich heraus, dass es doppeltes Brot war; und das bedeutet der Vers 29, darum gibt (schenkt) Er euch am sechsten Tag Brot für zwei Tage, Er gibt euch Segen, Überfluss ins Haus, um das Omer zweimal zu füllen für Speise von zwei Tagen.

////—1—//// 16:6:1,**In the evening.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֶרֶב is] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָעֶרֶב — “in the evening.”

§§—2—§§ 16:6:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערב is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לערב AT EVENING 

—3— **6. Am Abend = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לערב. Und ihr werdet erkennen,** dass der Ewige euch aus dem Lande Mizraim geführt hat; weil ihr zu uns gesagt habt, ihr habt uns herausgeführt, sollt ihr erkennen, dass nicht wir euch herausgeführt haben, sondern der Ewige euch herausgeführt hat; denn Er wird für euch die Wachteln lostrennen.

////—1—//// 16:6:2,"**You will know that Adonoy brought you out from the land of Egypt.** “Since you said to us: ‘for <font color=d50505>»</font>you<font color=d50505>«</font> have brought us out,’ you shall [now] know that it was not we who brought [you] out but rather Adonoy Who brought you out for He will will make the quails available to you.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:6:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידעתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוציא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים YE SHALL KNOW THAT THE LORD HATH BROUGHT YOU OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT — Since you said to us, (v. 3) “for ye have brought us forth” you shall know that it was not we who brought you forth, but it was God who brought you forth for He will bring quails for you. "

////—1—//// 16:7:1,"**And in the morning you will see.** This is not a reference to the glory that is mentioned [in the verse]: “and behold the glory of Adonoy was visible in the cloud.” But <font color=d50505>»</font>this<font color=d50505>«</font> is what he said to them: “In the evening you will know that He has the power in His hand to give you your desires and [though] He will give [you] meat He will not give it to you with a bright countenance for you asked for something improperly, and on a full stomach. But the bread for which you asked out of necessity, when it will descend in the morning you will see the glory of His bright countenance for He will bring it down to you in a loving manner: (a) in the morning, when there is time to prepare it, (b) with dew above it and dew below it as if packed in a box. "

§§—2—§§ 16:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובקר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראיתם AND IN THE MORNING YE SHALL SEE [THE GLORY OF THE LORD] — Not in reference to that glory of which it stated, (v. 10) “And behold the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud” is this said, but thus, in effect, did he say to them: In the evening ye shall know that His hand has the power to give you your desire and He will give you flesh; but not with a radiant countenance will He give it to you, because you have asked Him something that is not proper (since one can exist without eating meat), and out of a full stomach (i. e. you really have meat for you have an abundance of cattle); but the bread for which you have asked out of necessity — when it falls in the morning you will behold the glory of the radiance of His countenance (His glory), because He will make it fall for you in a manner that is indicative of His love (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:7) — in the morning, whilst there is yet time to prepare it, and there shall be dew above it and dew below it as though it were carefully packed in a chest (Yoma 75b)."

—3— **7. Und am Morgen werdet ihr sehen,** das bezieht sich nicht auf die Erscheinung, von der es (V. 10) heißt, und siehe, die Herrlichkeit des Ewigen erschien in der Wolke; sondern so sagte er zu ihnen, am Abend werdet ihr erkennen, dass Er die Macht hat, euer Verlangen zu erfüllen, und Er wird euch Fleisch geben; doch wird Er es euch nicht mit leuchtendem Angesichte geben, weil ihr es nicht würdig verlangt habt und aus vollem Bauche; aber wenn das Brot, das ihr verlangt habt, weil ihr es brauchtet, am Morgen herabfällt, werdet ihr die Herrlichkeit Seines leuchtenden Angesichtes schauen; denn Er wird es euch in liebevoller Weise am Morgen herabfallen lassen, dass ihr Zeit habt, es zuzubereiten; und es wird Tau von oben und von unten sein, als läge es in einem Behälter (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 16:7:2,**Your complaints against Adonoy.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' is] the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=d50505>»</font> that<font color=d50505>«</font> are against God.

§§—2—§§ 16:7:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלנתיכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ this is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלנתיכם] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳] YOUR MURMURINGS WHICH ARE AGAINST THE LORD. 

—3— **Euer Murren gegen den Ewigen,** = das gegen den Ewigen gerichtet ist. 

---

////—1—//// 16:7:3,"**But what are we.** [I.e.,] What is our importance — "

§§—2—§§ 16:7:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונחנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה (lit., and we, what?) means AND WE, WHAT ARE WE accounted (of what importance are we?),"

—3— **Wir aber, was sind wir,** welches Ansehen haben wir? 

---

////—1—//// 16:7:4,"**that you cause complaints against us?** That you should set everyone complaining against us — your sons, your wives, your daughters, and the mixture of nationalities. It is with no choice that I am forced to explain the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַלִּינוּ as meaning “to cause another to do” because of its <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font> and the way it is read. For if it had been the “weak” form (without a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font>) I would have explained it in the form <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּפְעֲלוּ, as in “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּלֶן) The nation <font color=d50505>»</font>complained<font color=d50505>«</font> against Moshe.” Or if it had had a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh,<font color=d50505>«</font> without a letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' [after the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל'] and would have been read: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּלוֹנוּ, I would have explained it in the form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּתְלוֹנְנוּ — “you have made yourselves complainers.” But now [in the form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַלִּינוּ] it has the meaning of: “You have caused others to complain,” as in the case of the spies [where it says]: “They caused to complain against him the entire congregation.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:7:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלינו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלינו THAT YOU MAKE everyone MURMUR AGAINST US — your sons, and your wives, and your daughters and the mixed multitude. — And whether I like it or not I am forced to explain the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַלִּינוּ in the sense of “you make (people) do something”, viz., murmur (i. e. what we call the Hiphil conjugation), because of its (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל) be eshed and because of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרי. For if it (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל) were weak (i. e. without a Dagesh), I would explain it in the sense of “ye do something” (our Kal), just as, (Exodus 17:3) “And the people murmured (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָלֶן) against Moses”, or, if there was still a Dagesh but there was no <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י in it, so that it could be read <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִלּוֹנוּ, I would explain it as meaning “ye put yourself in a state of murmuring” (our Niphal; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 15:24). Now, however, it being as it is, it must imply “you make others murmur”, just as in the case of the spies it states, (Numbers 14:36) “And they made all the congregation to murmur (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּלִּינוּ) against him” (where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּלִּינוּ is the same grammatical form, so far as conjugation is concerned, as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַלִּינוּ, but as it has an object, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העדה, it cannot mean “And they murmured”, and must necessarily mean “they made the congregation murmur)."

—3— **Dass ihr gegen uns Murren erreget,** dass ihr alle gegen uns zum Murren bringt, euere Söhne, euere Frauen und euere Töchter und das viele Mischvolk. Notwendigerweise muss ich <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלינו wegen seiner Dageschierung und seiner Punktierung für einen Hifil erklären; denn wäre nicht das Dagesch, so hätte ich es als Form des Kal erklärt, wie (17, 3), da murrte das Volk gegen Mosche; oder hätte es wohl ein Dagesch, aber kein Jud und würde <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלונו gelesen, so hätte ich es als Hitpael erklärt; so aber bedeutet es, ihr bringt andere zum Murren, wie bei den Kundschaftern, (Num. 14, 36) und hatten gegen ihn die ganze Gemeinde zum Murren gebracht. 

---

////—1—//// 16:8:1,"**Meat to eat.** But not to [your] fill. The Torah, thereby, teaches proper manners — that meat should not be eaten to satiety. Why did He see fit to make the bread fall in the morning, whereas the meat [fell] in the evening? Because for bread they asked properly for it is impossible for man [to live] without bread, but for meat they asked improperly because they had an abundance of cattle. Furthermore, they could get along without meat. He therefore gave it to them at an inconvenient time [which was correspondingly] improper. "

§§—2—§§ 16:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאכל FLESH TO EAT— but it does not add as it does in the next phrase <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִשְׂבֹּעַ, “to satisfaction”; the Torah thus teaches us a rule of conduct — that one should not eat meat to satiety. And what did He see (what reason had He) that He made bread fall for them in the morning and flesh at evening? Because the bread they asked for was a proper thing to demand since it is impossible for a person to exist without bread; but meat they asked for improperly, for they had abundant cattle, and besides it was possible for them to exist without flesh. On this account He gave it to them at evening, at a time of (when it would cause them) trouble, a manner which was not favourable to them (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:8; Yoma 75)."

—3— **8. Fleisch zum Essen,** und nicht zur Sättigung; die Torah lehrt uns Lebensart, man esse nicht Fleisch bis zur Sättigung (Mech.). Und aus welchem Grunde ließ Er ihnen das Brot am Morgen und das Fleisch am Abend herabfallen? Weil sie das Brot würdig verlangt hatten, da der Mensch das Brot nicht entbehren kann; aber Fleisch sie ungebührlich verlangt hatten; denn sie hatten noch viel Vieh; und ferner hätten sie das Fleisch entbehren können; darum gab Er es ihnen in einer Stunde, wo es ihnen Mühe machte, dass es für sie keine Ehre war (Joma 75a). 

---

////—1—//// 16:8:2,"**That you cause complaints against Him.** [I.e., “You cause] others to do so, who hear you complain.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:8:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלינים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליו means [YOUR MURMURINGS] WHICH YOU MAKE others who hear you murmuring MURMUR AGAINST HIM.

—3— **Das ihr gegen ihn erreget,** die anderen, die euch hören, murren auch.

////—1—//// 16:9:1,**Come near [before Adonoy].** To the place where the cloud will descend.

§§—2—§§ 16:9:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרבו APPROACH [BEFORE THE LORD] — to the place where the cloud will descend.

—3— **9. Tretet zum Ewigen hin,** zu dem Orte, an dem die Wolke herabkommen wird.

////—1—//// 16:13:1,**Quails.** It is a kind of bird and it is very fat.

§§—2—§§ 16:13:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השליו THE QUAILS — a species of fowl which is very fatty (cf. Yoma 75b).

—3— **13. Die Wachteln,** eine Vogelart, die sehr fett ist (Joma 75b).

////—1—//// 16:13:2,"**There was a layer of dew.** The dew was lying on the manna. However elsewhere it says: “When the dew descended, etc. [The answer is: first] the dew descended on the earth, [then] the manna descended upon it, then the dew descended upon it and it [the manna] was as if stored in a box. "

§§—2—§§ 16:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שכבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הטל THERE WAS A LAYER OF DEW — Consequently the dew was lying upon the Manna. In another passage, however, it says, (Numbers 11:9) “And when the dew came down [upon the camp at night, the manna fell upon it]” and so there was dew under the Manna! Thus we see that the dew fell upon the ground and the Manna fell upon it, and then dew fell again upon this, and so it was as though it were carefully packed in a chest (Yoma 75b)."

—3— **War eine Schicht Tau,** der Tau lag über dem Man, und an anderer Stelle sagt er (Num. 11, 9), wenn der Tau herabkam…; der Tau kam auf die Erde herab, und das Man fiel auf ihn, und dann kam wieder Tau auf es herab, so dass es wie in einem Behälter lag (Joma 75b). 

---

////—1—//// 16:14:1,"**The layer of dew had risen, etc.** When the sun shines then the dew which is on the manna rises towards the sun as is the way of dew to rise towards the sun. Even were you to fill an eggshell with dew and close up its opening and place it in the sun, it will, on its own, rise into the air. Our Sages explained that the dew [initially] rose from the earth into the air and when the layer of dew rose up, the manna was revealed and they saw: “and behold on the surface of the desert, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:14:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שכבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הטל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND WHEN THE LAYER OF DEW WENT UP etc. — When the sun rose the dew which was lying upon the Manna ascended sunward, as is the manner of dew — that it ascends sunward; even if you were to fill an egg-shell with dew and close up its opening and place it in the sun, it (the egg-shell with the dew in it) will rise of its own accord into the air, (in consequence of the tendency of the dew to rise upwards). — But our Rabbis explained that these words imply that the dew rose from the ground into the air. — When the layer of dew went up the Manna became visible, and they looked, (cf. Midrash Tanchuma, Beshalach 20; Shemot Rabbah 38:4) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק AND BEHOLD, UPON THE SURFACE OF THE DESERT there was etc."

—3— **14. Da erhob sich die Schicht Tau;** wenn die Sonne aufging, erhob sich der Tau, der auf dem Man war, der Sonne entgegen; wie es die Art des Taus ist, dass er der Sonne entgegen emporsteigt; selbst, wenn du eine Eierschale mit Tau füllst, ihre Öffnung verschließt und sie in die Sonne legst, erhebt sie sich von selbst in die Luft. Unsere Lehrer erklären (Schemot Rabbah 38; Tanchuma), der Tau stieg von der Erde in die Luft empor; und wenn sich die Tauschicht erhob, war das Man aufgedeckt; und sie sahen, **siehe auf der Oberfläche der Wüste… Etwas Feines,** eine feine Maße. 

---

////—1—//// 16:14:2,**Thin.** [Meaning:] a thin object.

§§—2—§§ 16:14:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק, a THIN object,"

—3— **Geschältes,** aufgedecktes; es gibt hierfür keine Parallelstelle im Vers; man kann sagen, dass <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחספס mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חפיסא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודלוסקמא (Behälter und Tasche) in der Mischna (Bawa Metzia 20a) Zusammenhänge; als die Tauschicht von ihm fortgenommen war, sahen sie, dass etwas Feines darin aufbewahrt war zwischen den beiden Tauschichten. Onkelos übersetzt Geschältes von (Gen. 30, 37), das Weisse entblössend.

////—1—//// 16:14:3,"**Thin [uncovered] flakes.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְחֻסְפָּס means:] “uncovered” and there is none like it (this word) in Scripture. It may be said that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְחֻסְפָּס [comes from the phrase] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲפִיסָה) a box and a chest” which is a term that appears in Mishnah. When it was uncovered from the layer of dew, they saw there had been a thin object enclosed inside it between the two layers of dew. Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְקַלַּף (<font color=d50505>»</font>flaked<font color=d50505>«</font>) meaning: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַחְשֹף) the peeling of the white.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:14:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחספס uncovered — and there is no other example of this word in the Scriptures. One may also explain <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחספס as having the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המיסה in (Mishna Bava Metzia 1:8) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חפיסה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודלוסקמא, “a valise and chest”, in Mishnaic Heberw, and the meaning would be, that when it became uncovered from the layer of dew they saw that there had been a thin object enclosed in it i. e. enclosed between the two layers of dew. Onkelos tranlates it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקלף peeled (flaky), taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחספס in the sense of, and from a similar root as, (Genesis 30:37) “peeling off (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחשף) the white”."

—3— **Wie Reif,** Reif = Gefrorenes in anderen Sprachen; Targum <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דעדק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בגיר; (Jes. 27, 9) wie Kalksteine; das ist eine Art schwarzer Farbe, wie wir beim Blutbedecken (Chullin 88b) sagen: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והזרניך־ (Schwärze und Mennige); fein wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר, wie Gefrorenes auf der Erde, es war fein wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר und lag gefroren wie Eis auf der Erde; und so ist die Erklärung; fein wie Reif, eine dünne Schicht und zusammenhängend wie Gefrorenes; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק dünn in anderen Sprachen; es war von oben mit einer dünnen Haut überzogen; das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בגיר im Targum Onkelos ist zum hebräischen Ausdruck hinzugefügt, im Vers steht dafür kein Wort. 

---

////—1—//// 16:14:4,"**As frost.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּפוֹר is <font color=d50505>»</font>jelede<font color=d50505>«</font> (frost) in Old French. [Onkelos translates it] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַעֲדַק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּגִיר, [the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גִר occurring in] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּאַבְנֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גִר which is a type of black color as we say regarding the “covering of the blood:” “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַגִּיר) Black fine earth and orpiment.” [Thus Onkelos translates it:], <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּעְדַּק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּגִיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּגְלִידָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְעָא, meaning: “It was as fine as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גִּיר and lay on the ground congealed as ice. And this is the explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּכְּפֹר thinly spread yet attached as a frost. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַק in Old French is <font color=d50505>»</font>tenuis<font color=d50505>«</font> (thin), for it was encrusted with a thin crust on top. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּכְגִיר which Onkelos uses in his translation is an addition to the Hebrew and it has no corresponding word in the verse. "

§§—2—§§ 16:14:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככפר AS HOAR FORST — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפר is old French gelide. The Targum renders <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דעדק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כגיר, the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר occurring in (Isaiah 27:9) “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר-stones” — this is a kind of black colour — just as we enumerate amongst the kinds of earth which may be used for covering the blood of a wild animal or bird after it has been slaughtered “powdered chalk (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר) and orpiment” (Chullin 88b). Onkelos renders the entire phrase by “powdered like <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר, like hoar-frost upon the ground”, meaning that it was as fine as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גיר and lay congealed as frost in the ground. This is therefore the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככפור: “spread out fine but yet one atom hanging to another like hoar-frost”. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דק is old French tenuis — meaning that it formed a thin incrustation on top. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכגיר which Onkelos has in his translation is an addition to the Hebrew text, there being no word corresponding to it in the verse."

////—1—//// 16:15:1,"**It is a food.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוּא means] “it is something <font color=d50505>»</font>prepared<font color=d50505>«</font> for food,” as in “The king (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְמַן) prepared for them.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא means this is something prepared for food, as in (Daniel 1:5) “And the king appointed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימן) for them,”."

—3— **15. Es ist Man,** eine Vorbereitung zur Speise, wie (Dan. 1, 5) es bestimmte für sie der König.

////—1—//// 16:15:2,**For they did not know what it was.** So that they could call it by its name.

§§—2—§§ 16:15:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידעו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא FOR THEY KNEW NOT WHAT IS WAS so that they could call it by its name.

—3— **Denn, sie wussten nicht, was es sei,** um es mit seinem Namen zu benennen.

////—1—//// 16:16:1,**An omer.** The name of a particular measure.

§§—2—§§ 16:16:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמר — the name of a measure.

—3— **16. Omer,** ist der Name eines Maßes.

////—1—//// 16:16:2,"**The number of your people.** <font color=d50505>»</font>According to<font color=d50505>«</font> the number of people that a person has in his tent, shall they take an <font color=d50505>»</font>omer<font color=d50505>«</font> per head. "

§§—2—§§ 16:16:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מספר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפשתיכם — The second half of the verse means ACCORDING TO (supply <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כ before <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מספר) THE NUMBER OF PERSONS WHOM A MAN HAS (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאשר being the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאיש) IN HIS TENT SHALL YE TAKE AN OMER FOR EVERY HEAD (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַגֻּלגֹּלֶת the definite article with the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל having distributive force: each and every).

—3— **Für die Anzahl euerer Seelen,** nach der Zahl der Seelen, die ein jeder in seinem Zelte hat, nehmet ein Omer für jeden Kopf. 

---

////—1—//// 16:17:1,"**Some more, some less.** Some gathered much, some gathered little and when they came home each person measured with an <font color=d50505>»</font>omer<font color=d50505>«</font> what he had gathered, and they found that the one who had gathered more did not have more than an <font color=d50505>»</font>omer<font color=d50505>«</font> per person in his tent, and the one who gathered less did not find less than an omer per head, and this was a great miracle that occurred with it. "

§§—2—§§ 16:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המרבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והממעיט SOME MUCH, SOME LITTLE — There were some who gathered much and there were some who gathered little; and when they came home they measured it out by an Omer, each what he had gathered, and they then found that he who had gathered much had no excess over an Omer for each head that was in his tent, and that he who had gathered less did not find less than an Omer for each head, and this was a great miracle that was wrought in respect of it (the Manna)."

—3— **17. Der eine viel, der andere wenig,** manche hatten viel gesammelt, und manche hatten wenig gesammelt; und als sie nach Hause kamen, maßen sie es im Omer, ein jeder, was er gesammelt hatte, und fanden, wer viel gesammelt hatte, hatte nicht mehr als ein Omer für jeden Kopf in seinem Zelt, und wer wenig gesammelt hatte, fand nicht weniger als ein Omer für den Kopf; das war ein großes Wunder, das damit geschah.

////—1—//// 16:20:1,**Some men left [some] over.** [They were] Dosson and Aviram.

§§—2—§§ 16:20:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויותרו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנשים BUT SOME MEN LEFT OF IT — Dathan and Abiram (Shemot Rabbah 24:10; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 2:13).

—3— **20. Und es Hessen Männer übrig,** Datan und Abiram (Schemot Rabbah).

////—1—//// 16:20:2,**It became wormy.** [The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּרֻם is derived] from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רִמָּה — “worm.”

§§—2—§§ 16:20:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תולעים AND IT BRED WORMS — the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירם is of the same meaning and root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רִמָּה, worm."

—3— **Da entstanden Würmer darin,** von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רמה Gewürm. 

---

////—1—//// 16:20:3,"**And putrid.** This verse is inverted for it first became putrid and then wormy, as is indicated by what is said: “It did not become putrid and it had no worms,” this is the usual manner for all things that turn wormy. "

§§—2—§§ 16:20:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבאש AND IT STANK — This is an inverted verse, because first it must have stunk and afterwards have become wormy, just as it is said, (v. 24) “And it did not stink and there was no worm therein — for this is the way of all things that become wormy (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:20)."

—3— **Und es roch übel,** (Mech.) dieser Vers ist umgestellt; denn zuerst roch es übel, und dann wurde es wurmig, wie es (V. 24) heißt, es roch nicht übel, und Gewürm war nicht darin; und so ist es bei jeder Sache, die wurmig wird. 

---

////—1—//// 16:21:1,"**[When] the sun became hot it melted.** That which remained in the field melted and turned into running streams and bucks and deer drank from it and the nations of the world captured some of them and through them had a taste of the manna, and thereby knew the praises of Israel.  [The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָמָס is translated by Onkelos] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּשָׁר from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פּוֹשְׁרִים — lukewarm water — because of the sun it became warm and turned into lukewarm liquid. "

§§—2—§§ 16:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השמש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונמס AND WHEN THE SUN WAXED HOT, IT MELTED — What was left in the field (outside the inhabited camp) melted and ran in streams; the harts and the roes drank therefrom, and the nations of the world hunted them and experienced through them the taste of the Manna, and thereby understood how great was Israel’s excellency (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:21)."

—3— **21. Wenn die Sonne heiß wurde, schmolz es,** was auf dem Felde geblieben war, wurde zu Bächen, und davon tranken Rehe und Hirsche; die Völker der Welt jagten von ihnen und schmeckten auf diese Weise den Geschmack des Man und erkannten daran die Größe Israels (Mech.); <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונמס Targum <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פשר von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פושרים laues Wasser; durch die Sonne wurde es erwärmt und löste sich auf. 

---

////—1—//// 16:21:2,<font color=d50505>»</font>Destemprer<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French] similar to [what is found] in Sanhedrin at the end of the Chapter “Four deaths.”

§§—2—§§ 16:21:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונמס Onkelos translates by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּשָׁר, having the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פושרים, tepid waters: through the sun it became warm and turned into tepid water; old French détemperer. An example of it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פשר) occurs in Treatise Sanhedrin at the end of the chapter that begins, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתות‎ (Sanhedrin 67b)."

—3— **Schmolz,** weich werden in anderen Sprachen; ähnlich in Sanhedrin am Ende von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתות (67b). 

---

////—1—//// 16:22:1,**[Lit.] They gathered double bread.** In their tents they measured what they gathered and they found it to be twice as much — two <font color=d50505>»</font>omers<font color=d50505>«</font> for each one. There is a Midrash Aggadah: [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֶחֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִשְׁנֶה meaning:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֶחֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשׁוּנֶּה — “different bread;” on that day it changed for the better regarding its smell and its taste.

§§—2—§§ 16:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקטו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה THEY COLLECTED DOUBLE BREAD — when they measured in their tents what they had gathered they found it double — two Omers for each person (cf. Rashi on v. 5). (Rashi appears to supply <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר before <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקטו: It came to pass on the sixth day, what they gathered <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַקטו, was double bread.) A Midrashic explanation is that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה signifies <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשֻׁנָּה different, changed, — that day it was changed for the better as regards its smell and its taste (Tanchuma Yashan)."

—3— **22. Hatten sie doppeltes Brot gesammelt,** als sie das Gesammelte in ihren Zelten maßen, fanden sie das Doppelte, zwei Omer für einen jeden. Der agadische Midrasch deutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משונה = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משנה verändert; an jenem Tage war es zu seinem Vorteil verändert, an seinem Geruch und seinem Geschmack (Mech.) (denn wollte er nur sagen, dass es doppelt war, so steht schon, zwei Omer für einen jeden; nur es war auch an Geschmack und Geruch verändert).

////—1—//// 16:22:2,"**And told Moshe about it.** They asked him: “What is [different about] today from other days?” From here we may learn that Moshe had yet not told them the section pertaining to Shabbos which he had been commanded to tell them: “On the sixth day [when] they prepare, etc.” Until they asked: “What is this?” He responded to them: “This is what Adonoy has said,” i.e., “that I had been commanded to tell you.” It is for this [oversight] that Scripture (God) punished him, when He said to him (i.e., addressing Moshe) “How long will you refuse [to keep My commands]?” and he (Moshe) was not excluded from the general group. "

§§—2—§§ 16:22:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגידו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשה AND THEY TOLD IT TO MOSES — They asked him, “How is this day different from other days?” — From this we may learn that Moses had not yet told them the section regarding the Sabbath which he had been commanded to say to them: (v. 5) “And it shall come to pass on the sixth day they shall prepare etc.” — he did not do this until they asked him, “What is this?” Then he said to them, (v. 23) “This is that which the Lord hath said” this is that which I was commanded to say to you previously, but I forgot to do so (Cf. Shemot Rabbah 25:10). On this account Scripture (God) punished him, in that He said to him, (v. 28) “How long will ye refuse [to keep my commandments]”, and He did not exclude him from the general body, by saying, “how long will they refuse etc.”"

—3— **Und berichteten es Mosche,** sie fragten ihn, warum ist dieser Tag von den anderen Tagen verschieden; von hier kann man entnehmen, dass ihnen Mosche den Abschnit über den Sabbat, der ihm befohlen worden war, ihnen zu sagen, (V. 5) am sechsten Tage sollen sie vorbereiten …, noch nicht verkündet hatte, bis sie ihn fragten, was bedeutet dies; da sprach er zu ihnen, das ist, was der Ewige gesprochen, das mir befohlen worden, euch zu sagen; und darum strafte ihn der Vers, indem er zu ihm sagte (V. 28), wie lange noch weigert ihr euch, und schloss ihn nicht aus der Gesamtheit aus (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 16:23:1,"**Bake what you want to bake.** What you wish to bake [of the two <font color=d50505>»</font>omers<font color=d50505>«</font>] in the oven, bake today everything [you need] for two days, and whatever of it you need to cook in water, cook today. The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲפִיָיה — “bake,” applies to bread whereas the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בִּישּׁוּל — “cook,” to a boiled dish. "

§§—2—§§ 16:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאפו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפו THAT WHICH YOU WOULD BAKE, BAKE whatever you wish to bake (cf. Onkelos: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>די <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עתידין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למפא and Rashi on <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אז <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה) in the oven bake to-day — all that you will need for two days; and what you require to boil of it in water boil to-day. The expression baking applies to bread, (cf. Rashi on Genesis 40:1) and the expression boiling to a cooked dish. "

—3— **23. Was ihr backen wollt, backet;** was ihr im Ofen backen wollt, backet heute, alles für zwei Tage; und was ihr davon im Wasser kochen müsst, kochet heute; der Ausdruck «backen» passt auf Brot und der Ausdruck «kochen» auf ein Gericht. 

---

////—1—//// 16:23:2,"**To preserve.** [I.e.,] for storage. "

§§—2—§§ 16:23:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשמרת means as something put by (to be kept).

—3— **Zur Aufbewahrung,** zum Weglegen.

////—1—//// 16:25:1,"**Moshe said, “eat it today”, etc.** In the morning, when they were accustomed to go out and gather the manna, they came to ask, “Shall we go out or not?” He responded to them: [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִכְלֻהוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַיּוֹם] [I.e.,] “That which is in your possession, eat.” In the evening they again came before him and asked him, “What about going out [now]? He answered them, “It is Shabbos today!” He then saw them worrrying lest the manna ceased, and will descend no more. He then said to them, “<font color=d50505>»</font>Today<font color=d50505>«</font> you will not find it.” Why the stress on the word “today”? “<font color=d50505>»</font>Today<font color=d50505>«</font> you will not find it, but tomorrow you will find it.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:25:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכלהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום AND MOSES SAID, EAT THAT THIS DAY etc. — In the morning, when they had been accustomed to go forth and gather it, they came to enquire, “Shall we go out or not?” He replied to them, “What you have in your possession eat (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכלהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום)”. In the evening they again came before him and asked him, “How is it now about going out?” He answered them, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היום “Today is the Sabbath”. He saw that they were worried believing perhaps the Manna had stopped and would not again fall; he therefore said to them, “Today ye shall not find it [in the field]”. What reason was there to say “Today”? — Today you will not find it, but tomorrow you will find it (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:7)."

—3— **25. Und Mosche sprach, esset es heute,** am Morgen; da sie gewohnt waren, hinauszugehen und zu sammeln, kamen sie, um zu fragen, sollen wir hinausgehen oder nicht; da sagte er zu ihnen, esset, was ihr habt; am Abend kamen sie wieder zu ihm und fragten, sollen wir hinausgehen; da sprach er zu ihnen, heute ist Sabbat; als er sah, dass sie besorgt waren, das Man könnte aufgehört haben und würde nicht wieder herabfallen, sagte er zu ihnen, heute werdet ihr es nicht finden, was bedeutet, heute? Heute werdet ihr es nicht finden, aber morgen werdet ihr es wieder finden (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 16:26:1,**But the seventh day is Shabbos.** [Meaning:] “It is Shabbos; there will be no manna on it.” This verse comes only to add Yom Kippur and holidays.

§§—2—§§ 16:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וביום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השביעי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבת means but on the seventh day is a day of rest (supply the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא); and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו means the Manna shall not be on it; and this verse comes (is written) only to include the Day of Atonement and the Festivals [as being also days when no Manna would fall] (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:26).

—3— **26. Und am siebten Tag ist Sabbat,** ist Sabbat, **an ihm fällt kein Man;** der Vers kommt nur, den Jomhakipurim und die Festtage hinzuzufügen (Mech.) 

---

////—1—//// 16:28:1,"**How long will you refuse.** There is a proverb among common people: “The cabbage is stricken with the weeds.” Through the wicked, the righteous are disgraced. "

§§—2—§§ 16:28:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאנתם HOW LONG WILL YE REFUSE — A common proverb says: with the thorn the cabbage which is near it, is also stricken — through the wicked the good are brought into disgrace (cf. Rashi on v. 22) (Bava Kamma 92a)."

—3— **28. Wie lange noch weigert ihr euch,** ein Sprichwort des Volkes sagt, mit den Dornen wird auch das Gemüse getroffen, durch die Bösen werden auch die Guten getadelt (Bab. kam. 92a). 

---

////—1—//// 16:29:1,"**See.** With your own eyes that God Himself warns you regarding the Shabbos, for a miracle occurs every Shabbos eve when He gives you bread for two days. "

§§—2—§§ 16:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראו SEE with your very eyes (i. e. the word is used literally and not figuratively in the sense of “consider”) that the Lord in His glory (i. e. the Lord Himself) admonishes you regarding the Sabbath, for, behold, a miracle is performed for you on the eve of every Sabbath in that He gives you then bread for two days."

—3— **29. Sehet,** mit euren Augen, **dass der Ewige** mit Seiner Herrlichkeit euch die Heilighaltung des Sabbats gebietet, da jeden Erew Sabbat ein Wunder geschieht, indem Er euch Brot für zwei Tage gibt. 

---

////—1—//// 16:29:2,**Every man must remain in his place.** From here the Sages found an allusion [to the law] that there are four <font color=d50505>»</font>amos<font color=d50505>«</font> [designated] for someone who has gone out of the [Shabbos] limit: three for his body and one more to stretch his arms and legs.

§§—2—§§ 16:29:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחתיו ABIDE YE EVERY MAN IN HIS PLACE (lit., beneath himself) — From here the Sages derived a support for the permission that a person who has gone beyond the Sabbath limit may move within a space of four cubits (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:7; Eruvin 51a)."

—3— **Bleibet ein jeder an seinem Ort,** an diese Stelle lehnten die Weisen die Vorschrift der 4 Ellen für denjenigen an, der über die Sabbatgrenze hinausgegangen ist, 3 Ellen für den Körper und 1 Elle für das Ausstrecken von Händen und Füßen (Eruwin 41b). 

---

////—1—//// 16:29:3,"**[No man] may go out, etc.** [An allusion to] the 2,000 <font color=d50505>»</font>amos<font color=d50505>«</font> of the Shabbos-limit. But this is not explicit [in the verse] for [the laws of] Shabbos-limits are only Rabbinic prohibitions. The main thrust of the verse was said regarding the manna gatherers. "

§§—2—§§ 16:29:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממקמו LET NO MAN GO OUT OF HIS PLACE — These are the 2,000 cubits of the Sabbath limit (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:29); but this is not expressly mentioned here, because the command relating to the Sabbath limits is only an institution of the Sopherim. The text itself was really spoken about those who gathered the Manna (i. e., it does not constitute a prohibition regarding the Sabbath for all men and at all periods but was intended to forbid anyone to go out into the field to gather the Manna; cf. Sotah 30b)."

—3— **Keiner verlasse seinen Ort am siebten Tag,** das sind die 2000 Ellen der Sabbatgrenze, nicht, als ob es deutlich stehe, da die Sabbatgrenzen nur ein Gebot der Weisen sind; vielmehr bezieht sich der eigentliche Inhalt des Verses auf die Sammler des Man (Mech.; Sota 30b). 

---

////—1—//// 16:31:1,"**It was like white coriander seed.** A kind of herb called <font color=d50505>»</font>aliendre<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French] whose seed is round but not white, Whereas the manna <font color=d50505>»</font>was<font color=d50505>«</font> white. It is compared to the coriander seed only in so far its roundness is concerned. [Thus the verse is to be understood:] “It was like a coriander seed but it (the manna) is white.” "

§§—2—§§ 16:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והוא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כזרע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבן AND IT WAS LIKE THE CORIANDER SEED, WHITE — a herb, the name of which is (in old French) coriandre; its seed is round and is not white, whilst the Manna was white. It follows therefore, that it is compared to coriander seed only in respect to its roundness — so that the meaning is: it was like coriander seed, and it was white (Yoma 75a)."

—3— **31. Es war wie Koriandersamen, weiß;** ein Kraut, das Koriander heißt, dessen Samen rund, aber nicht weiß ist; das Man aber war weiß und wird nur wegen seiner runden Gestalt mit Koriandersamen verglichen; darin war es wie Koriandersamen, es war aber weiß (Joma. 75a). 

---

////—1—//// 16:31:2,"**Like wafers.** Dough which is fried in honey, and is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִסְקְרִיטִין in the language of the Mishnah. This (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִסְקְרִיטִין) is Onkelos’ translation. "

§§—2—§§ 16:31:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כצפיחת LIKE FLAT CAKES — dough which is fried in honey. In the Mishnaic speech it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אסקריטין (Pesachim 37a), and this is the translation of Onkelos here."

—3— **Wie Honiggebäck,** ein Teig, den man in Honig röstet; in der Sprache der Mischna (Challa 1, 4) nennt man ihn Honiggebäck; so übersetzt auch Onkelos. 

---

////—1—//// 16:32:1,**To preserve.** For storage.

§§—2—§§ 16:32:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשמרת means to put by.

—3— **32. Zur Aufbewahrung,** zum Weglegen. 

---

////—1—//// 16:32:2,**For your generations.** In the days of Yirmiyahu: When Yirmiyahu would admonish them: “Why are you not involved in the study of Torah?” they would respond: “Shall we abandon our work and study the Torah?! From where will we support ourselves?” He would take out the jar of manna and say to them: “This generation! See this thing of God!” It does not say: “Hear!” but rather: “See! With this your forefathers were supported. God has many messengers to prepare sustenance for those who fear Him.”

§§—2—§§ 16:32:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדרתיכם FOR YOUR GENERATIONS e. g., in the days of Jeremiah: when Jeremiah was rebuking them (the people), saying, “Why do you not engage yourselves with the Torah?”, and they answered him, “Shall we leave our work and engage ourselves with the Torah? From where shall we earn a living?”, he brought out to them the cruse of Manna and said to them, (Jeremiah 2:31) “[O Generation], see ye the thing of the Lord!” It is not said “Hear the word” but “See the thing”! — This thing is what your fathers were fed with. The Omnipresent God has many messengers (many means) to provide food for those who fear Him (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:33)."

—3— **Für eure Geschlechter,** in den Tagen Jirmejahus, als Jirmeja sie zurechtwies, warum beschäftigt ihr euch nicht mit Torah, und sie erwiderten, sollen wir unsere Arbeit lassen und uns mit Torah beschäftigen; woher sollen wir uns ernähren? Da holte er die Flasche mit Man heraus und sagte zu ihnen (Jer. 2, 31), Geschlecht, ihr sollt das Wort des Ewigen sehen; hören, steht nicht, sondern sehen; damit wurden eure Väter ernährt; viele Boten hat der Ewige, um Nahrung zu bereiten für diejenigen, die ihn fürchten (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 16:33:1,"**A jar.** A flask made of earthenware, as Onkelos translates it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צְלוֹחִית). "

§§—2—§§ 16:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צנצנת is an earthern flask, as it is translated in the Targum (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 16:33)."

—3— **33. Eine Flasche,** eine irdene Flasche (Mech.), wie auch der Targum übersetzt. 

---

////—1—//// 16:33:2,**Place it before Adonoy.** In front of the Ark This verse was not said until the “meeting-tent” was built but it was written here in the section dealing with the manna.

§§—2—§§ 16:33:2," ‘<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה AND LAY IT UP BEFORE THE LORD — before the Ark; this verse, of course, was not spoken until the tent of meeting had been built and the Ark was placed therein, but it is written here in the chapter about the Manna, as being its appropriate place."

—3— **Und lege sie vor dem Ewigen nieder,** vor der heiligen Lade; dieser Vers wurde erst nach der Erbauung des Zeltes der Offenbarung gesagt, nur wurde er an dieser Stelle im Abschnitt vom Man niedergeschrieben.
