Andere Erklärung: in allem was ich euch gesagt habe, sollt ihr euch hüten, und den Namen fremder Götter sollt ihr nicht erwähnen, das lehrt dich, dass Götzendienst alle Gebote aufwiegt, und wer sich davor hütet, ist, als ob er alle Gebote hüte. 

---

////—1—//// 23:13:3,"**You must not cause it to be heard — ** from the gentile. **Through your mouth [responsibility].** Do not make a [business] partnership with the gentile, whereby he may [ultimately] swear to you in the name of his idol, for consequently you will have caused [the idol’s name] to be mentioned through your actions. "

§§—2—§§ 23:13:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישמע IT SHALL NOT BE HEARD from a heathen, THROUGH THINE AGENCY — i. e. you shall make no business partnership with a heathen through which it might happen that he will take an oath by the name of his god, for consequently you will have brought it about that it has been mentioned through your agency (cf. Sanhedrin 63b)."

—3— **Er werde nicht gehört,** selbst aus dem Munde eines Heiden, durch deine Veranlassung; verbinde dich nicht mit einem Heiden; er würde dir bei seinem Götzen schwören, und es fände sich, dass du veranlasstest, dass er durch dich erwähnt würde (Sanhedrin 63b). 

---

////—1—//// 23:14:1,**Times.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְגָלִים means:] “times.” Similarly: “that you have struck me three (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְגָלִים) times.”

§§—2—§§ 23:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רגלים means TIMES. Similar is, (Numbers 22:28) “that thou hast smitten me these three times (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רגלים‎)”."

—3— **14. Male = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פעמים;** ebenso (Num. 22, 28), dass du mich schon dreimal geschlagen hast. 

---

////—1—//// 23:15:1,"**The month of <font color=d50505>»</font>aviv<font color=d50505>«</font> —** when the grain ripens in its (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִבֶּיהָ) stalks. [An alternate explanation:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָבִיב is from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַב i.e., “mature” and the first month to ripen its fruit. "

§§—2—§§ 23:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חודש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האביב THE MONTH OF <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב — it is the month when the grain becomes full in its ripe state (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באביה). The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב is connected with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַב which signifies maturity, and being the first of the fruit to ripen (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 9:31)."

—3— **15. Des Monats der Ährenreife,** in dem das Getreide in den Halmen voll wird; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אביב kommt von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אב, der Früheste und Erste, die Früchte zu reifen. 

---

////—1—//// 23:15:2,"**Do not appear before My Presence empty handed.** “When you come to appear before Me at the festivals, bring Me burnt-offerings.” "

§§—2—§§ 23:15:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יראו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריקם AND NONE SHALL APPEAR BEFORE MY FACE EMPTY — When you come to appear before My face on the festivals, bring Me burnt-offerings (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 23:15:2; Chagigah 7a)."

—3— **Und man erscheine nicht leer vor meinem Angesichte,** wenn ihr kommet, an den Festen vor meinem Angesichte zu erscheinen, bringet mir Ganzopfer dar (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 23:16:1,**The Festival of Harvest.** This refers to the holiday of Shavuos...

§§—2—§§ 23:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקציר AND THE FESTIVAL OF HARVEST — this is the Feast of Weeks,"

—3— **16. Und das Fest der Ernte,** das ist das Wochenfest. 

---

////—1—//// 23:16:2,"**The first fruits of your Labor —** which is the time for bringing the first fruits because the offering of the “two loaves” which are brought on Shavuos, permit the new crop [to be used] for meal offerings and to bring <font color=d50505>»</font>bikkurim<font color=d50505>«</font> to the Beis Hamikdosh, as it is said: “On the Day of Bikkurim, etc....” "

§§—2—§§ 23:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעשיך which is the time for bringing the first-fruits, for the offering of the two loaves that were brought on the Feast of Weeks made it permissible for the first time during the year to use the new harvest of wheat for the meal offerings (Menachot 68b), and to bring the first fruits into the Temple, (Mishnah Bikkurim 1:3) for it is said, (Numbers 28:26) “And on the day of the first fruits etc., [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשבעתיכם on your weeks etc.]” (cf. Rashi on that verse)."

—3— **Der Erstlinge deines Ertrages,** das ist die Zeit, da man die Erstlingsfrüchte bringt; denn die beiden Brote, die am Wochenfeste gebracht wurden, machten, dass man vom neuen Getreide Speiseopfer darbringen (Menachot 68b) und dass man die Erstlingsfrüchte ins Heiligtum bringen durfte (Bicc. I, 3); so heißt es (Num. 28,26), am Tage der Erstlingsfrüchte. 

---

////—1—//// 23:16:3,**The Festival of Ingathering.** This refers to the holiday of Succos —

§§—2—§§ 23:16:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האסף AND THE FESTIVAL OF THE INGATHERING — that is the Feast of Tabernacles.

—3— **Und das Fest des Einsammelns,** das ist das Hüttenfest. 

---

////—1—//// 23:16:4,**when you gather in [the fruits] of your labor.** Because the entire summer the grains dry in the fields and during the Succos [season] it is gathered indoors out of the rains.

§§—2—§§ 23:16:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באספך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעשיך WHEN THOU HAST GATHERED IN THY LABOURS — For during the whole summer-time the fruits are drying in the fields and about the Festival (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָחָג is a Talmudical term for the Feast of Tabernacles) they are gathered into the barns on account of the rain that is then due.

—3— **Wenn deinen Ertrag einsammelst;** denn den ganzen Sommer hindurch trocknet das Getreide auf den Feldern, und um das Hüttenfest bringt man es vor dem Regen ins Haus. 

---

////—1—//// 23:17:1,"**Three times, etc.** Since the subject here deals with <font color=d50505>»</font>shemittah,<font color=d50505>«</font> it was necessary to state that the Three Festivals will not be cancelled from [taking place at] their allocated times. "

§§—2—§§ 23:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פעמים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THREE TIMES etc. — Because this section speaks mainly of the Sabbatical year, it was necessary to state that the sequence of the festivals should not be disturbed even in this year of agricultural rest (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 23:16; cf. Rashi on v. 12)."

—3— **17. Dreimal,** weil der Abschnitt vom siebten Jahre spricht, muss dies stehen; dass nämlich die Feste in ihm nicht von der Stelle gerückt werden (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 23:17:2,**Every male among you.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זְכוּרְךָ means:] the males among you.

§§—2—§§ 23:17:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכורך means all the male population among you.

—3— **Jeder Männliche von dir,** die Männlichen in deiner Mitte. 

---

////—1—//// 23:18:1,**You must not sacrifice — while <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz<font color=d50505>«</font> is present — etc.** Do not slaughter the Pesach <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon<font color=d50505>«</font> on the fourteenth day of Nisan until you remove your <font color=d50505>»</font>chametz.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 23:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תזבח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ means, you shall not sacrifice the Passover-lamb on the fourteenth day of Nisan before you have removed the leavened bread from your house (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 23:18:1). (This verse is to be connected with v. 15). "

—3— **18. Opfere nicht bei Gesäuertem,** schlachte nicht das Pessach am 14, Nissan, bevor du das Gesäuerte weggeräumt hast (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 23:18:2,"**You must not allow to remain overnight — the fat of My festival-offering, etc. —** away from the altar — "

§§—2—§§ 23:18:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חגי NEITHER SHALL THE FAT OF MY SACRIFICE REMAIN away from the altar (cf. the Targum).

—3— **Und es übernachte nicht, das Fett meines Festopfers,** außerhalb des Altares (Onkelos). 

---

////—1—//// 23:18:3,"**Until morning.** One might think that even [if it were] on the wood-pile [of the altar], it would nevertheless become unfit due to its having remained overnight. Therefore the Torah says: “On the fireplace, on the altar all night.” "

§§—2—§§ 23:18:3,"UNTIL MORNING. One might think, however, that the meaning is, that it shall not remain overnight on the altar and that the sacrifice would therefore become invalid even through the fat remaining overnight on the “wood-pile” of the altar! Scripture, however, states, (Leviticus 6:2) “[This is the law of the burnt-offering; it is that which may go up] on the fire-place of the altar all the night, [any time until the morning]”(Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 23:18:2), — "

—3— **Bis zum Morgen;** ich hätte meinen können, dass es auch auf der Brandstätte durch Übernachten untauglich werde; darum heißt es (Lev. 6, 2), auf der Brandstätte, auf dem Altäre, die ganze Nacht (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 23:18:4,"**You must not allow to remain overnight.** It is not considered [unfit due to] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִינָה unless it [was not placed on the altar] by dawn, as it is said: “Until morning.” But the entire night he may lift it up from the ground onto the altar. "

§§—2—§§ 23:18:4,"Therefore the statement <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילין means, that this law of leaving the fat away from the altar overnight is infringed only if it has not been placed on the altar by the dawn of the morning, for it says, “[neither shall the fat remain] until morning”, but any time during the whole night one may lift it up from the pavement on to the altar (cf. Megillah 20b)."

—3— **Und es übernachte nicht, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לינה** ist erst mit Tagesanbruch; denn so steht, bis zum Morgen; aber die ganze Nacht hindurch kann er es vom Steinboden des Vorhofs auf den Altar bringen (Megillah 20b). 

---

////—1—//// 23:19:1,"**The beginning of the first fruits of your land.** Even during the seventh year <font color=d50505>»</font>bikkurim<font color=d50505>«</font> is obligatory. It is for this reason that [the Torah] states even here [regarding the seventh year]: “The first fruits of your land.” What is the procedure [for setting aside <font color=d50505>»</font>bikkurim<font color=d50505>«</font>]? A man who, upon entering his field, sees a fig that has ripened. He ties a reed around it to identify it and thereby designates it [as <font color=d50505>»</font>bikkurim<font color=d50505>«</font>]. <font color=d50505>»</font>Bikkurim<font color=d50505>«</font> need to be brought only from the seven species which are listed in Scripture: “A land of wheat, barley, etc; (grapes, figs pomegranates, olives, dates.)” "

§§—2—§§ 23:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדמתך THE FIRST OF THE FIRST-FRUITS OF THY GROUND [THOU SHALT BRING etc.] — Even in the seventh year the offering of the first fruits is obligatory in some cases, therefore here also (where Scripture mainly deals with the laws of the Sabbatical year) it is stated: “the first of the first-fruits of thy land [shalt thou bring, etc.]”. How was the procedure at the setting apart of the first fruits? A man goes into his field and sees a fig which was the first to ripen; he ties a piece of reed-grass round it to distinguish it and so marks its sacred character (Mishnah Bikkurim 3:1). The law of the first fruits applies only to the seven kinds of produce that are mentioned in Scripture: (Deuteronomy 8:8) “a land of wheat and barley etc.”, for which Palestine is praised in that verse (Mishnah Bikkurim 3:1)."

—3— **19. Das Vorzüglichste der Erstlingsfrüchte deines Bodens,** auch das siebte Jahr ist zu Erstlingsfrüchten (Omer und zwei Broten) verpflichtet; darum steht auch hier, die Erstlingsfrüchte deines Bodens. Wie sonderte man die Erstlingsfrüchte ab? Wenn jemand auf sein Feld kam und eine frühreife Feige sah, umwickelte er sie zum Zeichen mit einem Schilfgras und erklärte sie für heilig (Bicc. III); Erstlingsfrüchte waren nur von den sieben Arten, die in dem Verse stehen (Deut. 8, 8), Land des Weizens und der Gerste … 

---

////—1—//// 23:19:2,"**You must not cook a young animal.** A calf and a sheep are also implied in “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי” because “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי” represents any tender, newborn animal, [as can be inferred] from the fact that you find in a number of places in the Torah that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי is written, and it is necessary to explain afterward: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזִּים — goats, for example: “I will send <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזִּים — a goat,” or: “the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעִזִּים — goat,” or: “two <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדַיֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזִּים — goats,” thereby teaching you that wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי is mentioned without specification, then a calf and a sheep are also implied. [The prohibition of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֹא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְבַשֵּׁל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֲלֵב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִמּוֹ] is written three times in the Torah: once to prohibit the eating [of meat cooked with milk], another to prohibit deriving any benefit from them, and once to prohibit cooking them. "

§§—2—§§ 23:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבשל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי THOU SHALT NOT COOK A KID — A calf and a lamb also are comprehended under the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי, for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי means nothing more than a young tender animal, as you may gather from the fact that you will find in several passages in the Torah that the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי is used and that the writer felt it necessary specially to explain it by adding after it the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים, as, e. g., (Genesis 38:17) “I will send forth a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי of the goats”; (Genesis 38: 20) “the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי of the goats”; (Genesis 27:9) “two kids of the goats (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדיי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים)”. This fact serves to show you that wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי is mentioned without further description the term implies also a calf and a lamb. — In three different passages the law <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבשל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי is written: once for the purpose of prohibiting the eating of meat-food with milk-food, once to prohibit us from deriving any other benefit (besides eating) from such mixture, and once to prohibit the boiling of meat with milk (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 23.19.2; Chullin 115b)."

—3— **Koche nicht das Böckchen,** auch Kalb und Lamm sind unter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי zu verstehen; denn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי bedeutet nur ein ganz zartes Junges; da du an vielen Stellen in der Torah findest, dass <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי steht und es darauf durch <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים näher erklärt werden muss, wie (Gen. 38, 17, 20), ich werde ein Ziegenböckchen schicken, das Ziegenböckchen; (Gen. 27, 9) zwei Ziegenböckchen; um dich zu lehren, dass überall, wo nur <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי steht, auch Kalb und Lamm darunter zu verstehen sind; an drei Stellen in der Torah steht dieses Verbot, einmal, um das Essen, einmal, um den Nutzen, und einmal, um das Kochen zu verbieten (Chullin 115b). 

---

////—1—//// 23:20:1,"**Behold, I will send an angel.** Here they are foretold that they are destined to sin, and the Shechinah would then say to them: “For I will not go up among you.” "

§§—2—§§ 23:20:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אנכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאך BEHOLD, I SEND A MESSENGER [BEFORE THEE] — Here they were informed that they would once sin and that the Divine Majesty would have to tell them, (Exodus 33:3) “for ‘I’ will not go up among thee” (cf. Exodus Rabbah 32:3)."

—3— **20. Siehe, ich schicke einen Engel vor dir her,** hier wurde ihnen mitgeteilt, dass, wenn sie sündigen würden, die Schechina zu ihnen sagen würde, (33, 3), ich ziehe nicht in deiner Mitte hinauf (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 23:20:2,"**That I have prepared.** That I have prepared to give to you (i.e., Eretz Yisrael). That is its plain meaning. But its midrashic explanation is: “to the place that I have established [for the Temple] [for] My Place (i.e., the Temple of Heaven) has already been set up in line with it. This is one of the verses [in Scripture] which indicate that the <font color=d50505>»</font>Beis Hamikdosh<font color=d50505>«</font> of Heaven is directly in line with the <font color=d50505>»</font>Beis Hamikdosh<font color=d50505>«</font> below. "

§§—2—§§ 23:20:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנתי means, WHICH I HAVE PREPARED in order to give unto you. This is the literal meaning of the verse. The Midrash (taking the word as connected in meaning with the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּוֵן “to put a thing in a line with” or “to make it correspond with” another thing) explains <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המקום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנתי to signify “to the place opposite to which I have long since established the seat of my Glory” (“the place” therefore denotes the Temple; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 15:17). This is, according to the Midrash, one of the verses which implicitly state that the Temple in Heaven is situated exactly opposite (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְכֻוָּן) that on the earth (Midrash Tanchuma, Mishpatim 18)"

—3— **Den ich vorbereitet habe,** den ich bestimmt habe, ihn euch zu geben; das ist der einfache Sinn; der Midrasch (Tanchuma) sagt, an den Ort, den ich vorbereitet habe; meine Stätte ist bereits jener gegenüber sichtbar, und hier ist einer von den Versen, die sagen, dass das Heiligtum im Himmel dem auf Erden gegenüber errichtet sei (Tanchuma Pekude). 

---

////—1—//// 23:21:1,"**Do not rebel against him.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּמֵּר is from the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמְרָאָה — “robbing,” as in: “Whoever (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יַמְרֶה) will rebel against your order.” "

§§—2—§§ 23:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בו EXASPERATE HIM NOT — This verb is a term denoting rebellion (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המראה), similar to, (Joshua 1:18) “Whosoever he be that rebel (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימרה) against thy commandment”."

—3— **21. Sei nicht widerspenstig gegen ihn,** bedeutet Auflehnung; wie (Jos. 1, 18), wer sich deinem Ausspruch widersetzt. 

---

////—1—//// 23:21:2,**For he cannot bear your transgression.** He is not accustomed to this (the act of sinning) for he is of the group [of beings] who do not sin. An alternate explanation: [He has no power to forgive] for he is only a messenger and can only to do his mission.

§§—2—§§ 23:21:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפשעכם FOR HE WILL NOT PARDON YOUR TRESPASS — He is not accustomed to it (to sin) for he is one of a class of beings who never sin. Besides he is only a messenger and only carries out the mission entrusted to him (i. e. he has no right to pardon you, for this is My prerogative: it is his only to insist upon obedience to My commands) (Midrash Tanchuma, Mishpatim 18)."

—3— **Denn er verzeiht nicht eure Missetat,** er hat darin keine Übung, weil er zu jener Schar gehört, die nie sündigen, und ferner ist er ein Bote und vollzieht nur seinen Auftrag (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 23:21:3,**As My Name is in him.** This follows the beginning of the verse: “Be careful in his presence... for My Name is linked with him.” Our Sages said that this angel is Metatron whose name is the same as his Master’s (God) for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְטַטְרוֹן has the same numerical value as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁדַּי (314).

§§—2—§§ 23:21:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקרבו FOR MY NAME IS IN HIM — This passage must be connected with the beginning of the verse: Take heed of him etc. — for (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי) My Name is associated with his (i. e. whatever he does, he does in My Name). Our Rabbis said that he (the angel) is Mattatron (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מטטרון) whose name is even as the name of his Master, for <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מטטרון has the numerical value  of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי “the Almighty” (Sanhedrin 38b)."

—3— **Weil mein Name in seinem Inneren;** dies gehört zum Anfang des Verses, **hüte dich vor ihm, weil mein Name** ihm beisteht. Unsere Lehrer sagen, das ist der Engel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ׳, dessen Name dem seines Herrn gleicht; denn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ׳ ist im Zahlenwert gleich <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שדי (Sanhedrin 38b). 

---

////—1—//// 23:22:1,**And I will attack.** As Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאָעִיק — “I will oppress.”

§§—2—§§ 23:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וצרתי — render this as the Targum does: I will distress.

—3— **22. Und bedränge,** wie der Targum, enge ein. 

---

////—1—//// 23:24:1,**You must [totally] destroy —** their idols.

§§—2—§§ 23:24:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרס <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהרסם [BUT] THOU SHALT UTTERLY OVERTHROW THEM — those gods.

—3— **24. Sondern du sollst sie niederreißen,** jene Götzen.

////—1—//// 23:24:2,**Their monuments.** The stones that they set up [for the purpose] of bowing down to them.

////—1—//// 23:26:1,**No woman will suffer miscarriage —** if you act according to My will.

§§—2—§§ 23:26:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכלה THERE SHALL NOTHING BE BEREAVED OF YOUNG, if you will act according to My will."

—3— **26. Es wird keine Fehlgebärende sein,** wenn du meinen Willen erfüllst.

////—1—//// 23:26:2,** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשַׁכֵּלָה .** [A woman] who suffers miscarriages or buries her children is called a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשַׁכֵּלָה .

§§—2—§§ 23:26:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכלה BEREAVED OF YOUNG — A woman who miscarries or who buries her children at a very early age is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכלה.

—3— **Fehlgebärende;** eine, die fehlgebiert, oder, die ihre Kinder begräbt, heißt . <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכלה

---

////—1—//// 23:27:1,"**I will bring panic.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמֹּתִי is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָמַמְתִּי . Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וֶאֱשַׁגֵּשׁ — “I will confuse.” This is true of any word whose verb-root has its last root-letter doubled, when it is conjugated in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּעַלְתִּי form. There are instances where the doubled letter is taken and given a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font> and vocalized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>melopum<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=d50505>»</font>cholam<font color=d50505>«</font>), for example: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמֹּתִי from the root: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָמַם) A confused sound was made by the wheel of his cart,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְסַבּוֹתִי — “I circled” from the same root as: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְסָבַב) He circled Beth El,” [or:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַּלּוֹתִי — “I was brought low” from the root: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דָּלְלוּ) They became low and dried up,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַקֹּתִיךְ) I have engraved you on the hands,” from the same root as: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חִקְקֵי) engraved in the heart,” [or:] “whom have (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רַצּוֹתִי) I crushed,” from the same root as: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רִצַּץ) He has crushed and abandoned the poor.” Whoever translates <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמּוֹתִי as: “I will kill” is in error, for if it were from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִיתָה then its <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' would not receive a <font color=d50505>»</font>patach<font color=d50505>«</font> nor would its <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ' get a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh,<font color=d50505>«</font> and its vowel would not be a <font color=d50505>»</font>melopum<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=d50505>»</font>cholam<font color=d50505>«</font>), but [would take the form:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵמַתִּי, as in “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵמַתָּה) You shall kill this nation.” And [the reason that] the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהֵמַתָּה] is with a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font> is because it is in place of two letters <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת', one of them being part of the root for no form of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִיתָה exists without a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת', and the other one serving as [a suffix-letter], as in: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָמַרְתִּי — “I said,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָטָאתִי — “I sinned,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָשִׂיתִי — “I did.” Similarly: the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָתַתִּי has a dagesh because it comes in the place of two [letters <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת'], for it should have been written with three letters <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת': two as part of the root, as in: “On the day (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תֵּת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה') that God gave,” [or:] “It is (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַתַּת) a gift from God”; and the third [letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת'] serves as a suffix. "

§§—2—§§ 23:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמתי I WILL CONFOUND — This is equivalent to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָמַמְתִּי (i. e. the root is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המם). Its rendering in the Targum is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואשנש “and I will confound”. Similar is every verb the root of which has its last letter doubled (verbs <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ע""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ע): when it is changed (conjugated) to express the idea of “I have done something” (i. e. the first person singular perfect of the Kal; the same really applies to some inflected forms of other conjugations also) there are occasions when one omits the doubled letter (it is actually the first of the two similar letters) and dageshes the remaining letter of these two and vowels it with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאפום (our <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם). Examples are: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמֹּתִי which is of the same derivation as, (Isaiah 28:28) “and the wheel of his cart makes a confused noise (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המם)”; (Ecclesiastes 2:20) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְסַבֹּתִי, “and I turned about” which is of the same derivation as, (I Samuel 7:16) “and he went round (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וסבב) to Bethel”; (Psalms 116:6) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דַלֹּתִי “I was low”, of the same derivation as, (Isaiah 19:6) “The waters shall become low (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דללו) and dried up”; (Isaiah 49:16) “I have graven thee (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַקֹּתִיךְ) upon the palms of my hand”, of the same derivation as, (Judges 5:15) “things engraved (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חקקי) in the heart”; (I Samuel 12:3) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רַצֹּתִי “whom have I crushed”, of the same derivation as, (Job 20:19) “because he hath crushed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רצץ) and hath forsaken the poor”. He, however, who translates it in the Targum by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאֶקְטַל , is in error. For if it were derived from the root denoting death (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מות), the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה in it would not be vowelled with Patach and its <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ would not be dageshed nor vowelled with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולם, but it would read <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמַתִּי, as, (Numbers 14:15) “Now if Thou shalt kill (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַמַתָּ) this people”, the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת being dageshed because it would come in place of two <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת’s, one being a root-letter — for no form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מות can be written without at least one <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת (that in the root) — and the other being a servile letter (part of the suffix), just as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּי in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר-<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חמא-<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תי and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשי-<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תי. Similarly with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נתתי: the second <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת is dageshed because it comes in the place of two <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת’s — since it (the word) really requires three <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת’s, two for the root, as in, (Joshua 10:12) “the day when the Lord giveth (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תת)”, and in, (Ecclesiastes 3:13) “it is the gift (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתת) of God”, — and the third as a servile letter."

—3— **27. Und bringe in Verwirrung = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והממתי,** der Targum, ich verwirre; und so ist es bei jedem Wort, in dessen Wurzel der letzte Buchstabe verdoppelt ist; wenn es flektiert wird, um die Form der Vergangenheit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פעלתי anzunehmen, gibt es Stellen, wo man den doppelten Buchstaben fortgenommen, ein Dagesch dafür eingesetzt und mit Cholem punktiert hat; wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמותי von (Jes. 28, 28), er rollt das Rad seines Wagens;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וסבותי (Koh. 2, 20), ich wandte von (I Sam. 7, 16), er zog nach Betel;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דלותי (Ps. 116, 6), ich bin arm von (Jes. 19, 6), es versiegen und vertrocknen; (Jes. 49, 16) über den Wolken habe ich dich eingegraben, von der Wurzel (Richt. 5, 15) Herzensgrübler; (I Sam. 12, 3) wen habe ich unterdrückt von (Job 20, 19), weil er Arme unterdrückte und dann verließ. Wer aber <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמותי mit, ich werde töten, übersetzt, irrt sich; denn, wenn es von der Wurzel <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתה käme, dann hätte das He kein Patach, das Mem kein Dagesch und wäre nicht mit Cholem punktiert; sondern <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמתי, wie (Num. 14,15), wenn du dieses Volk tötest, das Tkw hat ein Dagesch, weil es an Stelle von zwei Taw steht; das eine gehört zum Stamm, weil <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתה nie das Taw verliert, und das andere ist Bedienungsbuchstabe wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשיתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הטאתי,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמרתי. Ebenso bei <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונתתי hat das zweite Täw ein Dagesch, weil es an Stelle von zwei Taw steht; denn es müssten drei Tkw stehen, zwei zum Stamm gehörig, wie (Jos. 10, 12), am Tage, da der Ewige gab <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תת, (Koh. 3, 13) das ist eine Gabe Gottes <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתת, und das dritte zur Bedienung.

////—1—//// 23:27:2,**Their Backs.** [I.e.] that they will flee from you and thereby turn the backs of their necks to you.

§§—2—§§ 23:27:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערף NAPE OF THE NECK — i. e. they will flee before you and so turn the napes of their necks to you.

—3— **Den Nacken,** sie werden vor dir fliehen und dir den Nacken zuwenden.

////—1—//// 23:28:1,"**The hornets.** It is a kind of flying insect which would strike them in their eyes and inject a poison into them, and they would die. The hornets did not cross the Jordan River and the Chittites and Canaanites [mentioned here as being driven out] were from Sichon and Og. It is for this reason that of all seven nations, only these [three] are enumerated here. [The fact that] the Chivites [are mentioned here], though they resided on the other side of the Jordan and somewhat further on, is explained by our Sages in Maseches Sotah: It (the hornet) stood at the edge of the Jordan and hurled the poison into them. "

§§—2—§§ 23:28:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצרעה THE HORNETS — This is a kind of insect which wounded their eyes and injected poison in them, so that they died. The hornets did not cross the Jordan and the Hittite and the Canaanite whom Scripture mentions here as being driven out by them were the inhabitants of the land of Sichon and Og (on the east side of the Jordan). It is for this reason that Scripture enumerates here of all the seven nations that Israel fought against when entering Palestine only these two (cf. Joshua 24:12, where the text expressly states that the peoples driven out by the hornets were those of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלכי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האמרי, “of the two kings of the Amorites” who are identical with Sihon and Og). But the Hivites lived on the other bank of the Jordan and somewhat beyond it and yet it states here that the hornets would drive them out! They were indeed driven out by the hornets, for our Rabbis have explained in Treatise Sotah 36a that the hornets placed themselves on the east bank of the Jordan and from there cast the poison against them."

—3— **28. Die Hornisse,** eine Art fliegenden Kriechtieres; sie stach sie in die Augen und warf Gift hinein, dass sie starben; die Hornisse überschritt nicht den Jarden, der Chitti und der Kenaani wohnten im Lande von Sichon und Og; darum zählt er von allen sieben Völkern nur diese hier auf; und obschon der Chiwi auf der anderen Seite des Jarden und weiter wohnte, so lehren unsere Weisen im Traktat Sota (36a), die Hornissen befanden sich am Ufer des Jarden und schleuderten das Gift auf ihn hinüber.

////—1—//// 23:29:1,"**Desolate.** [I.e.,] empty of people, since you are few and there are not enough of you to fill it. "

§§—2—§§ 23:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שממה DESOLATE — empty of human beings, for you are but few and not sufficient to fill it all up."

—3— **29. Öde,** leer von Menschen; weil ihr wenig und nicht genug seid, um es auszufüllen.

////—1—//// 23:29:2,**Will multiply against you.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְרַבָּה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֶיךָ is to be understood as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְתַרְבֶּה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עָלֶיךָ .

§§—2—§§ 23:29:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורבה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליך means, [LEST THE ANIMALS OF THE FIELD] MULTIPLY AGAINST THEE."

—3— **Und es würde sich gegen dich vermehren,** = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותרבה, für dich zuviel werden.

////—1—//// 23:30:1,"**Until you have increased.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּפְרֶה meaning:] increased, from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּרִי (fruit), as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּרוּ) Be fruitful and multiply.” "

§§—2—§§ 23:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפרה UNTIL THOU BE FRUITFUL — i. e. until you become many. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפרה is of the same root and meaning as no fruit, as, (Genesis 1:28) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורבו “be fruitful and multiply”."

—3— **30. Bis du fruchtbar geworden,** dich vermehrt hast, von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרי Frucht, wie (Gen. 1, 28), seid fruchtbar und vermehret euch. 

---

////—1—//// 23:31:1,"**I will set.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשַׁתִּי is] from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲשָׁתָה — “setting.” The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' carries a <font color=d50505>»</font>dagesh<font color=d50505>«</font> because it comes in the place of two [letters <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת'], for any form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שִׁיתָה must have a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' while the other one is a suffix. "

§§—2—§§ 23:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושתי is of the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שית or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שות. The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת is dageshed, because it comes in place of two <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת’s (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושת-<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תי) — one is necessary because no grammatical form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שות can be without the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת of the root, and the other is a servile letter (part of the suffix)."

—3— **31. Und ich setze,** von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השתה einsetzen; das Taw hat ein Dagesch, weil es für zwei Taw steht; denn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שיתה hat immer ein Taw, und das andere ist zur Bedienung.

////—1—//// 23:31:2,**To the river.** The Euphrates.

§§—2—§§ 23:31:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנהר UNTO THE RIVER — the Euphrates.

—3— **Bis zum Strome,** Euphrat.

////—1—//// 23:31:3,** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְגֵרַשְׁתָּמוֹ .** And you will drive them away.

§§—2—§§ 23:31:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגרשתמו means AND THOU SHALT DRIVE THEM OUT.

—3— **Und du wirst sie austreiben** = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותגרשם.

////—1—//// 23:33:1,"**That you [might] worship.** Here you have the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי used in the sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר . This is also true in various places. This (the usage here) is actually <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִי which is one of the four meanings of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי . We often find [the word] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִם being used to convey <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר, as in: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאִם you will offer a <font color=d50505>»</font>minchah<font color=d50505>«</font> of the first fruit” which is actually obligatory. "

§§—2—§§ 23:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תעבד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ FOR IF THOU SERVE etc. — Both particles <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי in this verse have the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר “that”. It has this meaning in several passages. This is really the sense of the Aramaic word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אי (Hebrew <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם) which itself is one of the four meanings in which <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי is used (cf. Gittin 90a. where the four usages of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי are given). In fact we find <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם (‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אי) used in many passages in the sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר, e. g., (Leviticus 2:14) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקריב where it certainly should not be translated “if” — but ”when thou offer an offering of thy first-fruits”, for this offering is not optional but is obligatory (cf. Rashi on that verse)."

—3— **33. Wenn du dienen würdest**… diese <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי stehen an Stelle von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר, und so an vielen Stellen; das ist die Bedeutung <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אי, eine von den vier Bedeutungen, die <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי haben kann. Auch finden wir an vielen Stellen, dass <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם in der Bedeutung von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר steht; wie (Lev. 2, 14), wenn (sobald) du das Speiseopfer der Erstlingsfrüchte darbringst; was eine Pflicht ist.

§§—2—§§ 24:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר AND UNTO MOSES HE SAID — This section was spoken before the Ten Commandments were given (i. e. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר is the pluperfect); it was the fourth of Sivan when “Come up” was said to him (Shabbat 88a).

—3— **24,1. Und zu Mosche sprach Er,** dieser Abschnitt wurde vor den zehn Geboten gesagt, am 4. Siwan wurde ihm gesagt, steige empor.

////—1—//// 24:3:1,**Moshe came and told the people —** on that same day.

§§—2—§§ 24:3:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויספר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעם AND MOSES CAME AND RELATED TO THE PEOPLE — on that same day (the 4th of Sivan).

////—1—//// 24:3:2,**All the words of Adonoy.** [I.e.] the command to separate [from their wives] and the setting up of boundaries [at Mount Sinai].

§§—2—§§ 24:3:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ ALL THE WORDS OF THE LORD — the commands concerning their keeping apart from women and the setting of bounds at Mount Sinai.

—3— **Alle Worte des Ewigen,** das Gebot der Absonderung und der Abgrenzung. 

---

////—1—//// 24:3:3,"**And all the laws.** [I.e.] the seven <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> given to the descendants of Noach [as well as the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> of:] Shabbos, honoring one’s parents, the red heifer, and administering justice which were given to them in Marah. "

§§—2—§§ 24:3:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשפטים AND ALL THE JUDGMENTS which had been ordained before the Sinaitic legislation: the seven commands given to the “Sons of Noah” (the non-Israelite world), the law of the Sabbath, of filial respect, of the “red heifer” and regarding the administration of justice, all of which had been given to them already in Marah (cf. Sanhedrin 56b)."

—3— **Und alle Rechte,** die sieben Gebote, die den Nachkommen Noachs befohlen waren, und Sabbat, Elternehrung, Gesetz der roten Kuh und die Rechte, die ihnen in Mara gegeben worden waren (Mech. Jitro; Sanhedrin 50b). 

---

////—1—//// 24:4:1,**Moshe wrote down —** [everything] from Bereishis until the giving of the Torah and he also wrote down the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> that they were commanded at Marah.

§§—2—§§ 24:4:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכתב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND MOSES WROTE [ALL THE WORDS OF THE LORD] — from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בראשית up to (but not including) the account of the Giving of the Torah and he wrote down the commandments that were given to them in Marah (cf. Mekhilta on Exodus 19:10).

—3— **4. Mosche schrieb auf,** von Bereschit bis zur Gesetzgebung, und schrieb die Gebote, die in Mara befohlen worden, auf (Mech. Jitro). 

---

////—1—//// 24:4:2,**He arose early in the morning —** on the fifth of Sivan.

§§—2—§§ 24:4:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישכם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבקר AND ROSE UP EARLY IN THE MORNING — on the fifth of Sivan (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 19:11) (Shabbat 88a).

—3— **Und stand früh am Morgen auf,** am 5. Siwan. 

---

////—1—//// 24:5:1,**The young men.** [I.e.] the first-born.

§§—2—§§ 24:5:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נערי THE LADS — the first-born sons (Zevachim 115b; Onkelos).

—3— **5. Die Jünglinge,** die Erstgeborenen (Onkelos). 

---

////—1—//// 24:6:1,**Moshe took half the blood.** Who divided it?! An angel came and divided it.

§§—2—§§ 24:6:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדם AND MOSES TOOK THE HALF OF THE BLOOD — Who divided it into halves? An angel came down and divided it (Leviticus Rabbah 6:5). 

—3— **6. Mosche nahm die Hälfte des Blutes,** wer teilte es? Ein Engel kam und teilte es (Lev. rab. 6). 

---

////—1—//// 24:6:2,"**In the basins.** There were two basins — one for half the blood of the burnt-offering, and one for half the blood of the peace-offerings so as to sprinkle them both on the people. It is from here that our Sages concluded that our forefathers entered the Covenant through circumcision, immersion and the sprinkling of sacrificial blood. [Immersion is indicated by the fact that] there is no sprinkling [that is valid] which is not preceded by immersion. "

§§—2—§§ 24:6:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באגנת IN BASONS — There were two basons, one for holding the half of the blood of the burnt offering and the other for holding the half of the blood of the peace offerings, in order to sprinkle it (both bloods) on the people. From here have our Rabbis inferred (Keritot 9a) that our ancestors entered into the covenant with God by means of circumcision, immersion and sprinkling of blood — and although immersion is not mentioned in this paragraph it must have taken place, for no sprinkling is effective without immersion preceding it (cf. Tosafot Yevamot 46b <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דאין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזאה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טבילה).‎ "

—3— **In Schalen,** zwei Schalen, eine für die Hälfte des Blutes des Ganzopfers und eine für die Hälfte des Blutes des Friedensopfers, um sie auf das Volk zu sprengen; von hier lernten unsere Lehrer, dass unsere Väter durch Beschneidung, Untertauchen und Blutsprengen in den Bund eintraten; denn es gibt kein Sprengen ohne ein Untertauchen (Kerit. 9a). 

---

////—1—//// 24:7:1,**The Book of the Covenant —** from Bereishis till the Giving of the Torah and the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> they were commanded in Marah.

§§—2—§§ 24:7:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ספר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הברית THE BOOK OF THE COVENANT — the book which we have said contained the part of the Torah from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בראשית till the “Giving of the Torah” including the Commandments that were given to them at Marah (Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 19:10:2; cf. Rashi on v. 4).

—3— **7. Das Buch des Bundes,** von Bereschit bis zur Gesetzgebung und die in Mara befohlenen Gebote. 

---

////—1—//// 24:8:1,"**He cast.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּזְרֹק has] the meaning of sprinkling. However, Onkelos translates it [literally]: “He cast it on the altar to atone for the people.” "

§§—2—§§ 24:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויזרק means sprinkling — he sprinkled it on the people (not he threw it against the people, as this word might imply; cf. e. g., Exodus 9:8: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וזרקו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השמימה). The Targum, however, renders it by: and he poured it (the blood) upon the altar as atonement for (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על) the people, adding the words “upon the altar”, and taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם to denote “on behalf of the people”, i. e. he poured it out to atone for the people."

—3— **8. Und sprengte, = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזאה** sprengen; der Targum sagt, sprengte auf den Altar, um für das Volk zu sühnen. 

---

////—1—//// 24:10:1,"**They saw [a vision of] the God of Yisrael.** They intentionally looked and intently gazed and thereby became liable to death. But God did not want to disturb the joy [of the receiving] of the Torah and therefore waited to punish Nadav and Avihu until the day that the Mishkon was dedicated. As for the elders [He waited] until: “The people were as complainers, etc. and a fire from God burnt among them and consumed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בִּקְצֵה of the camp,” [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בִּקְצֵה meaning] the leaders of the camp. "

§§—2—§§ 24:10:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויראו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל NOW THEY SAW THE GOD OF ISRAEL — They gazed intently and failing in this they peeped in their attempt to catch a glimpse of the Supreme Being, and thereby made themselves liable to death. But it was only because God did not wish to disturb the joy caused by the Giving of the Torah, that He did not punish them instantly, but waited (postponed the punishment) for Nadab and Abihu until the day when the Tabernacle was dedicated, when they were stricken with death, and for the elders until the event of which the text relates, (Numbers 11:16) “And when the people complained …. and the fire of the Lord burned among them and destroyed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקצה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המחנה” — those who were the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קצינים “nobles” of the camp (Midrash Tanchuma, Beha'alotcha 16)."

—3— **10. Sie sahen die Erscheinung des Gottes Israels,** sie schauten und betrachteten und wurden dadurch todesschuldig; nur wollte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, die Freude der Torah nicht trüben und wartete Nadab und Abihu bis zum Tage der Einweihung des Heiligtums und den Ältesten bis (Num. 11, 1), das Volk war wie Missmutige, da entbrannte unter ihnen ein Feuer des Ewigen und verzehrte am Saume des Lagers, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קצה = von den Vornehmen im Lager (Tanchuma behaal.). 

---

////—1—//// 24:10:2,"**Like a brickwork of sapphire.** This was before Him at the time of their enslavement, as a reminder of the oppression of Israel, for they were subjugated to do brick-work. "

§§—2—§§ 24:10:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כמעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבנת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הספיר AS IT WERE THE BRICKWORK OF SAPPHIRE — This had been before Him during the period of Egyptian slavery as a symbol of Israel’s woes — for they were subjected to do brick-work (cf. Jerusalem Talmud Succah 6:3; Leviticus Rabbah 23:8).

—3— **Gleich dem Werk des Glanzes des Saphirs; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבנת** (Ziegelstein), ein solcher war vor Ihm in der Zeit der Knechtschaft Israels, damit Er stets der Leiden der Kinder Israel gedenke, die durch das Werk von Ziegelsteinen bedrückt wurden (Lev. rab. 23). 

---

////—1—//// 24:10:3,**And like the essence of heaven in purity.** [This symbolizes that] when they were redeemed there was light and joy before Him.

§§—2—§§ 24:10:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכעצם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השמים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לטהר AND AS IT WERE AS THE BODY OF HEAVEN FOR PURITY — This implies that as soon as they (the Israelites) were delivered there was radiance and rejoicing before Him.

—3— **Und gleich dem Wesen des Himmels an Reinheit;** als sie erlöst wurden, waren Licht und Freude vor Ihm. 

---

////—1—//// 24:10:4,**And like the essence.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּכְעֶצֶם should be translated as Onkelos does — a term meaning appearance.

§§—2—§§ 24:10:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכעצם — Translate it as the Targum does: “as the appearance”.

—3— **Gleich dem Wesen,** wie der Targum sagt, gleich dem Aussehen. An Reinheit, bedeutet Klarheit und Durchsichtigkeit. 

---

////—1—//// 24:10:5,**In purity.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָטֹהַר has the meaning of bright and clear.

§§—2—§§ 24:10:5, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לטהר means FOR BRIGHTNESS AND CLEARNESS.


---

////—1—//// 24:11:1,"**But against the nobility.** These were Nadav, Avihu and the elders. "

§§—2—§§ 24:11:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצילי AND UPON THE NOBLES — these were Nadab and Abihu and the elders —

—3— **11. Zu den Vornehmen,** das sind Nadab und Abihu und die Ältesten. 

---

////—1—//// 24:11:2,"**He did not send His hand (i.e., punish).** Suggesting thereby that they actually deserved that a hand be sent against them. "

§§—2—§§ 24:11:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידו HE LAID NOT HIS HAND — This implies that they well deserved that God should stretch forth His hand against them (Midrash Tanchuma, Beha'alotcha 16)."

—3— **Strecke Er Seine Hand nicht aus;** daraus geht hervor, dass sie verdient hatten, geschlagen zu werden. 

---

////—1—//// 24:11:3,"**They envisioned God.** They gazed at Him insolently [as someone who converses with a king] while engaged in eating and drinking. This is how Midrash Tanchuma explains it. But Onkelos does not translate it so. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲצִילֵי means “the great ones,” as in: “I called you (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֵאֲצִילֶיהָ) from its <font color=d50505>»</font>great<font color=d50505>«</font> ones,” [or:] “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּאצֶּל) He made <font color=d50505>»</font>great<font color=d50505>«</font> some of the spirit,” “six <font color=d50505>»</font>ammos<font color=d50505>«</font> (cubits) in its <font color=d50505>»</font>great<font color=d50505>«</font> size.” "

§§—2—§§ 24:11:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויחזו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האלהים AND THEY BEHELD GOD [AND DID EAT AND DRINK] — They gazed at him intimately as though their association with Him were a matter of eating and drinking. Thus does the Midrash Tanchuma, Beha'alotcha 16 explain it. Onkelos, however, does not translate the passage this way (i. e. he does not take it in a depreciative sense that Nadab and Abihu and the elders acted improperly. His translation is: they beheld God’s Glory and rejoiced in their offerings which were accepted as though they were eating and drinking). —"

—3— **Sie schauten die göttliche Erscheinnung,** sie schauten dahin ohne Scheu, nachdem sie gegessen und getrunken hatten; so erklärt der Tanchuma <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהעלתך; Onkelos aber übersetzt nicht so (sie freuten sich mit ihren Opfern, die wohlgefällig aufgenommen worden waren, so, als würden sie essen und trinken.).<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצילי heißt große; wie (Jes. 41, 9), von ihren großen habe ich dich herbeigerufen; (Num. 11, 25) und breitete von dem Geiste aus; (Jech. 41, 8) sechs Ellen in der Breite. 

---

////—1—//// 24:11:4,

§§—2—§§ 24:11:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצילי means “the great men”, as, (Isaiah 41:9) “I called thee from the chief men (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אציליה) thereof”; (Numbers 11:17) “And he increased (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאצל) some of the spirit” (cf. Rashi on Numbers 11:17 and Onkelos on 11:25); (Ezekiel 41:8) “six cubits in its size (largeness) (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אצילה‎)”."


---

////—1—//// 24:12:1,**Adonoy then said to Moshe —** after the giving of the Torah.

§§—2—§§ 24:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה’ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND THE LORD SAID TO MOSES — after the Giving of the Law,"

—3— **12. Der Ewige sprach zu Mosche,** nach der Gesetzgebung. 

---

////—1—//// 24:12:2,**Come up to Me to the mountain and remain there —** for forty days.

§§—2—§§ 24:12:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ההרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם COME UP TO ME INTO THE MOUNTAIN AND REMAIN THERE forty days.

—3— **Steige zu mir zum Berge empor und bleibe da,** vierzig Tage. 

---

////—1—//// 24:12:3,"**The tablets of stone, the Torah and the Commandments which I have written [in order] to teach them.** All 613 commandments are implicitly contained in the Ten Commandments. Rabbeinu Saadiah specifically shows, in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַזְהָרוֹת which he composed, for each and every one of the Commandments, the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> which are associated with it. "

§§—2—§§ 24:12:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האבן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והתורה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והמצוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כתבתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להורתם [AND I WILL GIVE THEE] THE TABLETS OF STONE, AND THE LAW, AND THE COMMANDMENT WHICH I HAVE WRITTEN TO TEACH THEM — All the six hundred and thirteen commandments are implicitly contained in the Ten Commandments and may therefore be regarded as having been written on the tablets. Rabbi Saadia specified in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אזהרות which he has composed those commandments which may be associated with each of the Ten Commandments."

—3— **Die Tafeln von Stein und die Lehre und das** Gebot, die ich aufgeschrieben habe, sie darin zu unterweisen; alle 613 Gebote sind in den 10 Gebote enthalten; R. Sadja hat in den <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אזהרות (Zusammenstellung der 613 Gebote als Festgebet für Schebuot), die er verfasst hat, zu jedem der 10 Gebote die davon abhängigen Mizwot erklärt. 

---

////—1—//// 24:13:1,"**Moshe and Yehoshua, his attendant, set out.** I do not know what Yehoshua’s purpose was here. But I think that the disciple was accompanying the master until the place where the bounds of the mountain indicated that he was not permitted to go from there and on. And from there “Moshe went up” himself “to the mountain of God.” There Yehoshua pitched his tent and remained there the entire forty days for we find that when Moshe came down: “Yehoshua heard the voice of the people yelling,” indicating to us that Yehoshua was not with them. "

§§—2—§§ 24:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהושע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משרתו AND MOSES ROSE AND HIS MINISTER JOSHUA — I am not sure in what capacity Joshua appears here, but I think that as a disciple he was accompanying the teacher as far as the place where the bounds of the mountain were marked out, whence onward he was not permitted to proceed. From that point <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה MOSES alone ASCENDED <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האלהים THE MOUNTAIN OF GOD, whilst Joshua pitched his tent there and stayed there during the whole forty days which Moses spent on the mountain. For thus we find that when Moses came down from the mountain it states, (Exodus 32:17) “and Joshua heard the voice of the people that they shouted” — from which we may infer that he was not with them in the camp."

—3— **13. Da machten sich Mosche und sein Diener Joschua auf;** ich weiß nicht, in welcher Eigenschaft Joschua dabei war; und ich meine, als Schüler begleitete er den Lehrer bis zu dem Orte, wo die Grenzen um den Berg errichtet waren; denn von da an und weiter durfte er nicht mitgehen; von da stieg Mosche allein zum Berge Gottes empor, und Joschua schlug dort sein Zelt auf und blieb dort die ganzen 40 Tage; denn so finden wir, als Mosche herabkam, da hörte Joschua die Stimme des Volkes in seinem Lärmen (32, 17); daraus entnehmen wir, dass Joschua nicht bei ihnen gewesen war. 

---

////—1—//// 24:14:1,**He said to the elders —** when he left the camp.

§§—2—§§ 24:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזקנים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר BUT UNTO THE ELDERS HE SAID when he left the camp (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר in the sequence of verbs which we find here denotes the pluperfect; the translation therefore is: and to the elders he had said).

—3— **14. Und zu den Ältesten sprach er,** als er das Lager verließ. 

---

////—1—//// 24:14:2,**“Wait here for us —** and remain here with the rest of the people in the camp so as to be prepared to render decisions for each person’s dispute.

§§—2—§§ 24:14:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בזה ABIDE YE HERE FOR US and stay ye with all the other people in the camp so as to be ready to decide his dispute for each man.

—3— **Bleibet für uns hier,** bleibet hier bei dem übrigen Volke im Lager, um bereit zu sein, einem jeden seinen Rechtsstreit zu entscheiden. 

---

////—1—//// 24:14:3,"**Chur.** He was Miriam’s son, and his father was Koleiv ben Yefuneh, as it is said: “Koleiv took Efras [for a wife] and she bore him Chur.” Efras is Miriam, as is cited in Sotah. "

§§—2—§§ 24:14:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חור [AND] HUR — He was the son of Miriam and his father was Caleb the son of Jephunneh, as it is said, (1 Chr. 2:9) “Caleb took unto him Ephrath, who bare him Hur”; and Ephrath is identical with Miriam, as it is stated in Treatise Sotah 11b."

—3— **Chur,** war der Sohn von Mirjam, und sein Vater war Kaleb; so heißt es (I Chr. 2, 19), Kaleb nahm sich Efrat, und sie gebar ihm Chur; Efrat ist Mirjam, wie in Sota (11b) steht. 

---

////—1—//// 24:14:4,**Whoever has a claim.** [Meaning:] whoever has a lawsuit.

§§—2—§§ 24:14:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברים HE WHO HAS ANY MATTER TO DO — i. e. he who has any law-suit.

—3— **Wer ein Anliegen hat,** wer eine Rechtssache hat. 

---

////—1—//// 24:16:1,**And the cloud covered it (or Him).** There is a dispute among our Sages regarding this: There are some who say [that these six days] were from Rosh Chodesh — the first day [of Sivan] [until the Festival of Shavuos — the day that the Torah was given — from an old Rashi manuscript].

§§—2—§§ 24:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכסהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן AND THE CLOUD COVERED IT (lit., “him”) [SIX DAYS] — Our Rabbis are of different opinions as to what this passage means. Some of them hold that these were the six days from the first of Sivan (until the Feast of Weeks, the day of the Giving of the Law) — "

—3— **16. Und die Wolke bedeckte ihn,** unsere Lehrer sind darüber verschiedener Meinung (Joma 4a); manche sagen, das sind die sechs Tage von Rosch chodesch bis Schebuot, dem Tage der Gesetzgebung (alter Raschitext). 

---

////—1—//// 24:16:2,**[and] the cloud covered it [refers —]** to the mountain — [whereupon]

§§—2—§§ 24:16:2,and that the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכסהו in the phrase <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכסהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן “the cloud covered him” or covered “it” means that it covered the mountain.

—3— **Und die Wolke bedeckte ihn,** den Berg. 

---

////—1—//// 24:16:3,"**He called to Moshe on the seventh day —** to proclaim the Ten Commandments. Really, Moshe and all the B’nei Yisroel were standing there, [yet the verse states only, “He called to Moshe”]. But [in this way] Scripture gives honor to Moshe. But there are others who say that... **The cloud covered Him** — refers to Moshe [and this occurred] six days after the [giving of] the Ten Commandments. And they (these six days) were at the beginning of the forty days when Moshe went up to receive the Tablets. This teaches you that whoever intends to enter the camp of the Shechinah requires seclusion for six days."

§§—2—§§ 24:16:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השביעי AND HE CALLED UNTO MOSES ON THE SEVENTH DAY of Sivan to utter the Ten Commandments. It is true that Moses and all Israel were standing there but the text states, “He called unto Moses” merely to give special honour to Moses calling him by name. Others, however, say that the passage means: AND THE CLOUD COVERED HIM — Moses, FOR SIX DAYS after the Ten Commandments had been given. These were at the beginning of the forty days which Moses spent on Mount Sinai when he went up to receive the Tablets, and Scripture teaches you that whosoever enters the camp of the Divine Majesty (here the mountain and later on the Holy of Holies) requires separation from others (must live in seclusion) for six days (Yoma 4a). "

—3— **Und Er rief Mosche am siebten Tage,** um die 10 Gebote zu verkünden, und Mosche und ganz Israel standen dabei, nur erweist der Vers Mosche besondere Ehre. Und manche sagen, die Wolke bedeckte ihn, Mosche, sechs Tage **nach** der Gesetzgebung, und diese gehörten zum Anfang der 40 Tage, zu denen Mosche hinaufstieg, die Tafeln zu empfangen. Und der Vers lehrt dich, dass jeder, der in das Lager der Schechina eintreten will, sich sechs Tage vorher vom Hause absondern muss. 

---

////—1—//// 24:18:1,"**Into the midst of the cloud.** This cloud was like thick smoke, but God made a path for Moshe in the midst of it. "

§§—2—§§ 24:18:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בתוך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן INTO THE MIDST OF THE CLOUD — This cloud was thick like smoke and God made a path for Moses through it (Yoma 4b).

—3— **18. In die Wolke,** unter dieser Wolke ist eine Art Rauch zu verstehen, und der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, machte für Mosche einen Pfad in dessen Mitte (Joma 4b). 25 <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומה

---

////—1—//// 25:2:1,**Have them take for Me a terumah-offering.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִי [means] for the sake of My Name.

§§—2—§§ 25:2:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקחו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומה THAT THEY TAKE ME A HEAVE OFFERING — “Me” means to the glory of My Name (Midrash Tanchuma, Terumah 1)."

—3— **25, 1. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומה Sie sollen für mich eine Hebe nehmen,** für mich, in meinem Namen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:2:2,"**A terumah-offering.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּרוּמָה means:] setting aside, [i.e.,] let them set aside from their possessions a donation. "

§§—2—§§ 25:2:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומה is something set apart (cf. Onkelos); the meaning is: let them set apart from their possessions a voluntary gift in My honour.

—3— **Eine Hebe,** eine Hebe sollen sie für mich von ihrem Vermögen als freiwillige Gabe absondern. 

---

////—1—//// 25:2:3,"**Whose heart impels him to generosity.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִדְּבֶנּוּ has the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְדָבָה — “a donation.” It is a term meaning “good-will,” <font color=d50505>»</font>presant<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French (wholehearted gift). "

§§—2—§§ 25:2:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידבנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבו — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידבנו is of the same root as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדבה (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נ in the latter being replaced by the Dagesh in the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד); it is a term denoting “good-will”, apaisement in old French (cf. Rashi on Genesis 33:10 and Leviticus 19:5)."

—3— **Den sein Herz antreibt,** bedeutet Edelmut im Sinne von Freigebigkeit; Befriedigung in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:2:4,"**Shall you take My terumah-offering.** Our Sages said: The expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּרוּמָה is mentioned here three times, [thereby alluding to three different <font color=d50505>»</font>terumah<font color=d50505>«</font>-offerings]. One is the <font color=d50505>»</font>terumah<font color=d50505>«</font>-offering of a <font color=d50505>»</font>bekka<font color=d50505>«</font> (half-shekel) per head from which the “sockets” were made, as is explained in the <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵלֶּה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְקוּדֵי . Another is the <font color=d50505>»</font>terumah<font color=d50505>«</font>-offering for the altar, [which also consisted of] a <font color=d50505>»</font>bekka<font color=d50505>«</font> per head for the coffers [from which] the communal sacrifices were brought. And another is the <font color=d50505>»</font>terumah<font color=d50505>«</font>-offering for the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> — the donation of each individual. The thirteen items mentioned in this section were all needed for the works of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> or for the <font color=d50505>»</font>kohanim<font color=d50505>«</font> vestments, [as will become apparent] if you will scrutinize them. "

§§—2—§§ 25:2:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקחו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומתי YE SHALL TAKE MY HEAVE OFFERING — Our Rabbis said: the expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומה is used here three times, being an allusion to three different heave offerings; one is the heave offering which consisted of a beka (half a shekel) a head, and of which the sockets were made, as is set forth in the section <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקודי (Exodus 39:26-27); another is the heave offering for the altar — a beka a head that was given to the funds (more lit., “the basket”, in which collections for communal or charitable purposes were made) from which to purchase the communal sacrifices; (see 
§§—2—§§ 30:15) and the other one is that implied in the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תרומתי “My heave offering” and referred to by the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כסף in the next verse — the heave offering for the Tabernacle which was a free-will gift from each individual (Jerusalem Talmud Shekalim 1:1). Thirteen different articles (cf. Tanchuma) that are mentioned in this section were all required either for the work of the Tabernacle (i. e. the construction of the Tabernacle or making the articles contained therein), or for the priests’ garments, as you will find when you look closely into the matter."

—3— **Sollt ihr meine Hebe in Empfang nehmen.** Unsere Lehrer sagen (Megillah 29b), drei Heben stehen hier; eine ist die Hebe eines halben Schekel für jede Person, woraus die Füße gemacht wurden, wie in 38,27) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקודי) erklärt wird; und eine die Hebe für den Altar, ein halber Schekel für den Kopf, die in die Kassen, mit denen man die Opfer der Gemeinde bezahlte; und eine die Hebe für das Heiligtum, eine freiwillige Gabe jedes einzelnen. Die 13 Dinge, die in dem Abschnitt erwähnt sind, waren alle zum Bau des Heiligtums oder für die Kleider der Priester nötig, wenn du genau darauf achtest. 

---

////—1—//// 25:3:1,"**Gold, silver, and copper, etc.** All these were brought voluntarily, each person according to how his heart moved him, except for the silver which was donated by everyone equally — a half-shekel by each person. We do not find in all the works of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> that any more silver was needed, as it is said: “And the silver [which was used] in counting the congregation, etc., a <font color=d50505>»</font>bekka<font color=d50505>«</font> per head, etc.” The rest of the silver which <font color=d50505>»</font>was<font color=d50505>«</font> brought voluntarily, they made from it the holy vessels. "

§§—2—§§ 25:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זהב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכסף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונחשת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ GOLD AND SILVER AND COPPER etc. — All these came (were brought) as voluntary gifts, each man giving as his heart prompted him, except that silver which was brought by all in equal quantities (cf. Rashi above), a half shekel by each person. For we do not find in the account of the entire work connected with the Tabernacle that any silver was needed for the work there described in detail over and above this, for it is said, (Exodus 38:25-26) “And the silver of them who were numbered of the congregation [was an hundred talents, etc.] … a beka for every man etc.” and vv. 27 and 28 inform us that of this silver were made the Sockets and the hooks. Of the other silver which came (was brought) there, as a free-will gift they made the holy vessels (lit., vessels for service), and it is this silver that is referred to in this verse and which is stated in the preceding verse as having been brought voluntarily."

—3— **3. Gold, Silber und Kupfer,** alle diese wurden freiwillig gebracht; ein jeder, wie ihn sein Herz antrieb; außer dem Silber; dieses wurde gleichmässig gebracht, ein halber Schekel von jedem einen. Und wir finden nicht beim ganzen Bau des Heiligtums, dass noch mehr Silber nötig war; so heißt es (38,25), das Silber der Musterung der Gemeinde… ein halber Schekel für jeden Kopf; das übrige Silber, das freiwillig dorthin gebracht wurde, verwandte man für Dienstgeräte.

////—1—//// 25:4:1,**Greenish-blue [wool].** Wool that is dyed with the blood of the <font color=d50505>»</font>chilazon<font color=d50505>«</font>-fish whose blood is greenish-blue.

§§—2—§§ 25:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותכלת AND BLUE PURPLE — wool dyed with the blood of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חלזון (a kind of shell-fish), the colour of which was greenish-blue (Menachot 44a). "

—3— **4. Himmelblaue Wolle,** Wolle, die mit dem Blute des Chalson (eine Art Tintenfisch) gefärbt war, dessen Farbe grünlich (-blau) war (Menachot 44a). 

---

////—1—//// 25:4:2,**Dark red [wool].** Wool colored by a dye called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַרְגָּמָן .

§§—2—§§ 25:4:2,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וארגמן AND RED PURPLE — wool coloured with a kind of dye the name of which is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארגמן

—3— **Und purpurrote Wolle,** Wolle, mit einer Art Farbe, die <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארגמן heißt, gefärbt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:4:3,**And linen.** This is linen.

§§—2—§§ 25:4:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושש — this is what we call LINEN (Yevamot 4b).

—3— **Und Byssus,** das ist Flachs. 

---

////—1—//// 25:4:4,"**And goats’ [hair].** Hair of goats. It is for this reason that Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמְעַזֵי — “that which comes <font color=d50505>»</font>from<font color=d50505>«</font> goats,” and not the goats themselves, for Onkelos’ translation of goats is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזַּיָּא . "

§§—2—§§ 25:4:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועזים is GOATS’ HAIR; therefore Onkelos translates it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמְעַזֵּי which denotes something that comes from the goats — not the goats themselves, for the Aramaic translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזַּיָּא‎."

—3— **Und Ziegenhaar,** das Haar von Ziegen; darum übersetzt Onkelos <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעזי, was von Ziegen kommt, und nicht Ziegen selbst; denn der Targum von Ziegen ist. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזיא

---

////—1—//// 25:5:1,**Red-dyed.** They were dyed red after they were tanned.

§§—2—§§ 25:5:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאדמים RED — they were dyed red after having been tanned.

—3— **5. Rotgefärbte,** sie waren nach dem Gerben rotgefärbt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:5:2,**Tachashim.** A kind of animal which existed only at that time. It had many colors and Onkelos therefore translated it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סַסְגוֹנָא — [a contraction of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂשׂ — “rejoice” and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גַוְונָא — “color”] because it rejoices and is proud with its multi-colors.

§§—2—§§ 25:5:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחשים TACHASH was a kind of wild beast. It existed only at that time (when Israel built the Tabernacle). It was multi-coloured and therefore it is translated in the Targum by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ססגונה, and it is so translated because it delights (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂשׂ) and prides itself in its colours (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גונא) (Shabbat 28; Midrash Tanchuma, Terumah 6)."

—3— **Tachaschtieren,** eine Art Wild; es lebte nur damals und hatte viele Farben; darum sagt der Targum <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ססגונא, es freut sich und rühmt sich mit seinen Farben (Schabbat 28a, b).

////—1—//// 25:5:3,**And acacia wood.** Where did they get [acacia wood] in the desert? Rabbi Tanchuma explained: our forefather Yaakov foresaw through Divine inspiration that the Israelites were destined to build a <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> in the desert and he therefore brought cedars to Egypt and planted them and directed his children to take them along when they would leave Egypt.

§§—2—§§ 25:5:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועצי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שטים AND SHITTIM WOOD — But from where did they get this in the wilderness? Rabbi Tanchuma explained it thus: Our father Jacob foresaw by the gift of the Holy Spirit that Israel would once build a Tabernacle in the wilderness: he therefore brought cedars to Egypt and planted them there, and bade his children take these with them when they would leave Egypt (Midrash Tanchuma, Terumah 9; cf. Bereishit Rabbah 94 and 
§§—2—§§ 26:15)."

—3— **Und Schittim-** (Zedern-) Holz; woher hatten sie diese in der Wüste? Das erklärt R. Tanchuma, unser Stammvater Jaakob schaute mit prophetischem Geiste, dass Israel ein Heiligtum in der Wüste bauen würde; er brachte darum Zedern nach Mizraim und pflanzte sie ein und befahl seinen Söhnen, sie mit sich zu nehmen, wenn sie Mizraim verlassen würden. 

---

////—1—//// 25:6:1,**Oil for the lamp.** Clear olive oil to keep the lamp burning constantly.

§§—2—§§ 25:6:1,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למאר OIL FOR THE LIGHT — “clear olive-oil … to make the flame ascend continually”).

—3— **6. Öl für die Beleuchtung,** reines Olivenöl, das beständige Licht anzuzünden. 

---

////—1—//// 25:6:2,"**Spices for anointing-oil —** which was made for the purpose of anointing the vessels of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon,<font color=d50505>«</font> and the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> itself for the purpose of sanctifying them. This [oil] required spices as is explained in the <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִשָּׂא . "

§§—2—§§ 25:6:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשמים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשמן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשחה SPICES FOR THE ANOINTING OIL which was made for the purpose of anointing the vessels of the Tabernacle and the Tabernacle itself in order to sanctify it. For this oil spices were required as is set forth in the section <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשא (Exodus 30:23 ff.).

—3— **Gewürze für das Salböl,** das gemacht wurde, um die Geräte des Heiligtums und das Heiligtum zu salben, um sie zu heiligen; dazu waren Gewürze nötig, wie es in 23, 30) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשא) erklärt wird. 

---

////—1—//// 25:6:3,"**And for the incense of aromatic spices —** which they burnt every evening and morning, as is explained in the <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַתָּה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּצַוֶּה . The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קְטֹרֶת indicates the raising of steam (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קִיטוֹר) and a column of smoke. "

§§—2—§§ 25:6:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולקטרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הסמים AND FOR INCENSE OF AROMATIC SPICES that were burnt every evening and morning, as is set forth in the section <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תצוה (Exodus 30:7). The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קטרת signifies raising vapour (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קיטור) and a column of smoke."

—3— **Und für das Räucherwerk der Gewürzarten,** das man jeden Abend und jeden Morgen in Rauch aufsteigen Hess, wie es in 7, 30) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תצוה) erklärt wird. Der Ausdruck <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קטרת bedeutet, Dampf und eine Rauchsäule emporsteigen lassen.
