////—1—//// 25:28:1,"**It will be carried by them.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִשָֹּׂא is in] the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִפְעַל conjugation, i.e., the <font color=d50505>»</font>shulchan<font color=d50505>«</font> will be carried by them (the poles). "

§§—2—§§ 25:28:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונשא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בם — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונשא is a passive (Niphal) form; the meaning is: THAT THE TABLE MAY BE BORNE BY THEM.

—3— **28. Dass mit ihnen getragen werde,** Form des Nifal, mit ihnen werde der Tisch getragen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:29:1,"**Make its dishes and its spoons.** “Its dishes” refers to its forms which were made like the shape of the bread. The bread was made in the shape of a [topless] box that was open on two of its sidesA (<font color=d50505>»</font>see illustration 3 on page 140<font color=d50505>«</font>). It had a bottom underneath. It was bent upwards at both ends,B [forming] something like walls.C It is for this reason that it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֶחֶם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַפָּנִים — “the bread of the faces,” because it has a “face”D “looking” in two directions towards the sides of the House (i.e., mishkon) in one direction as well as in the other direction. It was placed lengthwise across the width of the shulchan with its walls standing vertically lined up with the edge of the shulchan. A golden form and a metal form were made for it. It was baked in the metal one and upon removing it from the oven it was placed in the golden one until the following day, which was Shabbos, when it was set up on the shulchan. That form is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קְעָרָה — “dish.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועשית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קערתיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכפתיו AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE DISHES THEREOF AND THE SPOONS THEREOF — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קערתיו are the forms (moulds) that were made to fit the shape of the bread (Menachot 97a). The bread was shaped like a case broken open as regards two of its sides (two opposite sides of which have been removed; these are what we would call the front and the back). It had a bottom underneath, but no top, and this bottom was turned up on both ends to form, as it were, walls. On this account it was called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפנים, “bread with faces” — because it had faces (surfaces) looking in both directions towards the sides of the House (the Sanctuary). The bread was placed lengthwise across the breadth of the table with its sides standing up exactly in a line with the edge of the table. There were made for it a golden mould and an iron mould: in the iron one it was baked, and when it was taken out from the oven it was put on the golden one until the next day, the Sabbath, when it was arranged on the table (the mould then being removed). This golden mould is here called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קערה (Menachot 94a; cf. also Berliner’s Rashi 2nd ed. p. 426)."

—3— **29. Mache seine Schüsseln und seine Schalen;** (Menachot 97a) Schüsseln, das ist die Form, die gleich der Form des Brotes gemacht war; (Menachot 94b) das Brot war gleich einem von beiden Seiten offenen Schranke gemacht; es hatte unten einen Boden; man bog es an zwei Seiten gleich Wänden in die Höhe; darum wird es Schaubrot genannt, weil es Vorderseiten hatte, die nach beiden Seiten den Wänden des Hauses zugewandt waren, da und dort; man legte seine Länge über die Breite des Tisches, und die Wände waren dem Rande des Tisches gegenüber aufgerichtet; es war dafür eine Form von Gold und eine Form von Eisen gemacht; in der von Eisen wurde es gebacken, und wenn man es aus dem Ofen nahm, legte man es bis morgen am Sabbat, da man es auf dem Tische ordnete, in die von Gold; jene Form wurde Schüssel genannt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:29:2,"“Its spoons” are [known] as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּזִיכִין (ladles) into which the frankincense was put. There were two for the two fistfuls of frankincense that were placed on the two piles, as is stated: “You shall put upon the pile pure frankincense.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:29:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכפתיו AND ITS SPOONS — ladles (or rather, cups with flat bottoms) in which the incense was put. There were two such vessels for the two handfuls of incense which was put upon the piles in which the loaves were arranged, as it is said, (Leviticus 24:7) “And thou shalt put pure frankincense upon each pile”."

—3— **Und seine Schalen,** Becher, in die man Weihrauch legte; es waren zwei für die zwei Hände voll Weihrauch, die man zu den zwei Schichten des Brotes hinzufügte; so steht (Lev. 24, 7), füge zu jeder Schicht reinen Weihrauch hinzu. 

---

////—1—//// 25:29:3,"**Its half-hollow tubes.** They are similar to hollow, half tubes which are split along their length.E There were similar to those made of gold and three were placed in a row atop each bread so that the next bread [above] should sit on top of these tubes and they would separate one bread from another so that air would enter between them and prevent them from spoiling. In Arabic anything hollow is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קסוא . "

§§—2—§§ 25:29:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקשתיו — These had the form of halves of hollow canes which are split along their length (Menachot 96a). Articles similar to these were made of gold and three of them were set in a row above each loaf so that another loaf (that above it) should rest on top of the “canes”; thus they (these canes) separated one loaf from another so that air could enter between and they would not become mouldy (Menachot 97a). In the Arabic language anything hollow is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קסוא (and this corresponds to the root of this word, which therefore denotes something hollow)."

—3— **Und seine Halbröhren,** (Menachot 96a) es waren eine Art Hälften von hohlen und in der Länge gespaltenen Röhren; gleich solchen machte man aus Gold und ordnete drei über jedem der Brote, damit das nächste Brot auf diesen Röhren ruhe; sie trennten zwischen einem Brote und dem anderen, damit die Luft dazwischenkomme und sie nicht schimmlig würden (Menachot 97a); im Arabischen wird jeder hohle Gegenstand <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קסיא genannt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:29:4,"**And its supports.** Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמְכִילָתֵיהּ, which are supports.F They were like golden pegs standing on the ground, rising up very high above the shulchan to the same height as the bread pile. They were notched in six places one above the otherG and the ends of the tubes that were between the breads would be supported by these notches so that the weight of the upper breads not weigh down on the lower ones which would cause them to break. The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְכִילָתֵיהּ [quoted above from Onkelos] [means] its supports, as in: “I am exhausted from (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָכִיל) carrying it.” But I do not know how the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְנַקִיוֹת applies to supports. There are among the Sages of Yisrael who say that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קְשׂוֹתָיו is a reference to supports because they keep it (the bread) hard and keep it firm so that it does not break. Whereas the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְנַקִּיוֹתָיו refers to the tubes, so called because they (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְנַקִּין) clean it (the bread) so that it does not spoil. But, Onkelos who translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְכִילָתֵיהּ agrees with the [Sage] who says that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְנַקִּיוֹת are supports. "

§§—2—§§ 25:29:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיותיו — It is translated in the Targum by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומכילתיה “and the trestles (supports) thereof” (cf. Menachot 96a). According to him these were attachments to the table like a kind of golden pegs (pillars) standing on the floor and reaching in height far above the table up to the height of the pile of bread. They were notched in five places, one above the other, and the ends of the canes which were between one loaf and another were supported on these notches so that the weight of the upper loaves should not press heavily upon the lower ones in which event these would be broken. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכילתיה used by Onkelos as a rendering of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיותיו denotes “bearers;” it is of the same root as the verb in (Jeremiah 6:11) “I am weary to bear (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכיל) it.” But as for the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיות (which is a Piel of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקה and would denote “cleansers”) I do not know how it is applicable to these attachments the purpose of which was not to keep the bread clean but merely to serve as supports for the canes. But there are some of the Jewish Sages who hold that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשתיו (connected with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשה “hard”) are the pegs (or pillars) and they are so called because they served to keep it (the loaves) hard and firm, so that it should not break, whilst <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיותיו are the “canes” which kept the bread clean so that it should not become mouldy. Onkelos, however, who translated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיותיו by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכילתיה understood it according to the opinion of him who holds that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיות were the supporting pillars (cf. Menachot 97a)."

—3— **Und seine Gestelle,** Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבילא, es waren Gestelle in der Form von Stangen, aus Gold, die auf der Erde standen und über den Tisch weit emporragten, der Höhe der Brotschicht entsprechend; und sie hatten sechs (fünf) Seiten arme, einen Arm über dem anderen, und die Enden der Halbröhren, die zwischen einem Brote und dem anderen lagen, stützten sich auf jene Seitenarme, damit nicht die Last der oberen Brote zu schwer auf den unteren liege und sie zerbrächen; der Ausdruck des Targums <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכילא bedeutet Träger, wie (Jir. 6,11), ich vermag ihn nicht ertragen; aber wieso der Ausdruck <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיות die Seitenarme bezeichnet, weiß ich nicht; manche von den Weisen Israels sagen,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשות sind die Seitenarme, weil sie das Brot festmachen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשה und stützen, dass es nicht zerbreche (Menachot 97a), und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיות die Halbröhren, weil sie es rein erhalten, dass es nicht schimmle; aber Onkelos, indem er mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבילא übersetzt, lernte wie derjenige, der <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנקיות mit Seitenarmen erklärt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:29:5,"**By which they shall be covered.** [Meaning:] by which they shall be covered. It is regarding its tubes that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲשֶׁר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֻסַּךְ is said, for they (the tubes) were as a covering over it (the bread). Similarly, elsewhere it is said: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאֵת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קְשׂוֹת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַנָּסֶךְ — “and the tubes for the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָסֶךְ” — and both <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֻסַּךְ and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָסֶךְ have the meaning of “covering.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:29:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהן means BY WHICH THEY SHALL BE COVERED. It is of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשות, the “canes,” that the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסך are said, because these lay over it like a cover and a screen. Thus, too, in another passage (Numbers 4:7) it says, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנסך, “and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשות for covering;” both words, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסך and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנסך, denote screening and covering."

—3— **Mit denen er bedeckt wird;** mit denen er überdeckt wird; von den Halbröhren sagt er, dass er bedeckt wird, weil sie wie ein Dach und eine Decke darüber waren, und ebenso sagt er an anderer Stelle (Num. 4, 7), die deckenden Halbröhren; beide Formen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יסר und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נסף bedeuten Dach und Decke. 

---

////—1—//// 25:30:1,**Showbread.** So called because it has <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּנִים (faces) as I have explained. The amount of bread and the order of piling it up are explained in the <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֱמֹר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַכֹּהֲנִים .

§§—2—§§ 25:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפנים SHEW-BREAD (lit., bread of faces) — It was so called because it had “faces” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנים) as I have explained (v. 29). The number of loaves and the way they were set in piles are fully explained in the Sidrah <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכהנים (Leviticus 24:5—9)."

—3— **30. Das Schaubrot,** das mehrere Seiten hat, wie ich erklärt habe; die Zahl der Brote und die Ordnung seiner Schichten werden in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמור (Lev. 24, 5) erklärt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:1,"**The Menorah must be made by hammering.** It must <font color=d50505>»</font>not<font color=d50505>«</font> be made in sections. [That is] its branches or lamps must not be made as individual parts and afterwards attached as is done by smiths [through a process] called <font color=d50505>»</font>solder<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French (to solder), but, rather, it should all originate from one piece, hammered with a hammer and cut with special tools, thereby separating the branches in two directions. "

§§—2—§§ 25:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תיעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המנורה OF BEATEN WORK SHALL THE CANDELABRUM BE MADE — i. e. one should not make it of separate pieces nor shall one make its branches or its lamps as separate limb — a kind of work called souder in old French, Engl, to solder, but is was to be made in its entirety of a single mass of gold. He (who made it) beat it with the hammer and cut away with the implements of his craft thus making the branches spread out in this direction and in that (cf. Sifrei Bamidbar 61:1)."

—3— **31. Aus getriebener Arbeit soll der Leuchter gemacht werden,** man mache ihn nicht aus Gliedern und mache nicht seine Arme und seine Ölbehälter aus einzelnen Teilen, um sie nachher zu verbinden, wie es die Goldschmiede tun; was man in anderen Sprachen löten nennt, sondern der ganze Leuchter werde aus einem Stück gemacht, er schlägt mit dem Hammer und schneidet mit dem Handwerksgerät und trennt die Arme nach beiden Seiten (Sifre <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהעל׳). 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:2,"**Hammering.** Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְגִיד, a term meaning: “drawn out,” for he draws out the parts from the mass [of gold] in two directions by hammering with the hammer. The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִקְשָׁה means “hammering with a hammer,” <font color=d50505>»</font>batedic<font color=d50505>«</font> (hammered) in Old French, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נָקְשָׁן) they banged against each other.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:31:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקשה — This word is translated in the Targum by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגיד, an expression for “drawing out;” he renders it thus because the parts of the candle-stick were drawn from the lump in this direction and in that by the blow of the hammer. The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקשה denotes knocking with the hammer — batediz in old French — as the verb in (Daniel 5:6) “and his knees knocked (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקשן) one against another”."

—3— **Getriebene Arbeit,** Targum <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגיד bedeutet ziehen, er ziehe die Glieder aus dem Block nach beiden Seiten, indem er mit dem Hammer daraufschlägt; das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקשה bedeutet Hammerschlag, geschlagen in anderen Sprachen, wie (Dan. 5, 6) schlugen aneinander. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:3,"**The menorah must be made.** [It shall be made] by itself. Because Moshe had difficulties with it, God said to him: “Throw the mass [of gold] into the fire and it will form itself.” Therefore it does not say <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּעֲשֶׂה — “you must make.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:31:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תיעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המנורה [OF BEATEN WORK] SHALL THE CANDELABRUM BE MADE — The passive form used here in contradistinction to the active forms of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה used throughout this section in connection with the making of the vessels indicates that it shall be made of itself (automatically). Because Moses was puzzled by it (the work of the candlestick), the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, “Cast the talent of gold into fire and it will be made of itself.” For this reason it does not say here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּעֲשֶׂה “thou shalt make” (Midrash Tanchuma, Beha'alotcha 3)"

—3— **Soll der Leuchter hergestellt werden,** von selbst, weil es Mosche schwer erschien, sagte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, zu ihm, wirf das Talent Gold ins Feuer, und er entsteht von selbst; darum steht nicht, du sollst machen (Tanchuma <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמיני). 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:4,**Its base.** This refers to the “leg” at the bottom which was made in a shape similar to a box from which the three legs protruded downwards.

§§—2—§§ 25:31:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ירכה — the foot (the base) below, which was made in form of a box, three legs coming out from it underneath."

—3— **Sein Sockel,** das ist der Fuß unten, der wie ein Kasten gemacht war, aus dem unten drei Füße hervorgingen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:5,"**Its shaft.** [This refers to] its middle branch which rose from the middle of the base vertically upwards. At the top of it was the middle lamp, made similar to a cup into which oil was poured and a wick was placed. "

§§—2—§§ 25:31:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקנה — ITS SHAFT — its middle branch that rose from the central point of the base vertically upwards. On it was the middle lamp, made in the form of a cup into which to pour the oil and to put the wick."

—3— **Und sein Stamm,** das mittlere Rohr, das in der Mitte des Sockels emporstieg, senkrecht aufgerichtet war und auf dem sich das mittlere Licht befand, das wie ein Becher gemacht war, um das Öl hineinzugießen und den Docht hineinzulegen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:6,**Its cups.** They were like goblets which are made of glass long and narrow called <font color=d50505>»</font>madernes<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French]. These were made of gold and they protruded and stood out from each branch according to the number given in Scripture. They were there only as ornaments.

§§—2—§§ 25:31:6," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גביעיה — They were like that kind of goblets which are made of glass and which are long and slender; in old French they are termed maderins (cf. Rashi on Genesis 44:2). These, however, were made of gold and came out as projections from each branch to the number which Scripture enjoins for them. They were on it for embellishment only."

—3— **Seine Kelche,** sie waren gleich langen, engen Trinkgefässen, die man aus Glas macht, man nennt sie lange, enge Gläser in anderen Sprachen; nur waren diese aus Gold gemacht, aus jedem Rohr nach außen hervortretend, gleich der Anzahl, die der Vers für sie angegeben hat, sie waren nur zum Schmuck daran. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:7,"**Its knobs.** They were like round apples around [the branch], projecting outward around the middle branch, in the manner that candelabras are made for the aristocracy, called <font color=d50505>»</font>pomels<font color=d50505>«</font> [in Old French]. Their number is given in this <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha,<font color=d50505>«</font> as to how many knobs protrude from it and how much space between one knob and another. "

§§—2—§§ 25:31:7," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתריה ITS KNOBS — These were like apples, globular, projecting all round the middle branch (shaft), such as are made for candlesticks of princely houses (lit., which stand before the princes), and which are called pommeaux in old French, apple-shaped ornaments. Their number is stated in this section — how many knobs projected from it (the middle branch) and how much was left plain between one knob and the other."

—3— **Seine Knäufe,** sie hatten die Form von Äpfeln, waren rund von allen Seiten, und traten rings um das Rohr in der Mitte hervor, wie man solche an den Leuchtern, die vor den Fürsten stehen, anbringt; man nennt sie apfelförmigen Schmuck in anderen Sprachen; ihre Beschreibung kommt weiter in diesem Abschnitt vor, wieviel Knäufe aus ihm hervortraten und wieviel zwischen einem Knauf und dem anderen glatt war. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:8,**And its flowers.** Engravings made in the shape of flowers.

§§—2—§§ 25:31:8, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרחיה AND ITS FLOWERS — Figures were made on it in the shape of flowers.

—3— **Und seine Blüten,** es waren Verzierungen in der Form von Blüten daran gemacht. 

---

////—1—//// 25:31:9,**Shall be of it.** [I.e.] all hammered out from the piece of mass and not made separately and then attached.

§§—2—§§ 25:31:9, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיו SHALL BE OF THE SAME — All shall be of beaten work coming out of this block-shaped piece: one must not make them separately and then join them on the branches.

—3— **Sollen aus ihm selbst sein,** alles aus getriebener Arbeit ging aus dem einen Block hervor und sollte nicht für sich gemacht werden, um es dann daran zu befestigen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:32:1,"**Shall extend from its sides —** in each direction diagonally going upwards until [they reach] the height of the menorah, which is the middle branch. They extend outward from the middle branch, one above the other. The bottom one is the longest one and the one above it is shorter and the top one is even shorter. [This was so] because the height at their top was the same as the height of the seventh middle branch, from which extended the six branches. "

§§—2—§§ 25:32:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצאים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצדיה [AND SIX BRANCHES] SHALL GO OUT OF ITS SIDE — on each side slantwise extending on high up to the level of the candlestick proper, i. e. of the middle branch. They came out from the middle branch, one above the other — the lowest being the longest, that above it being shorter than it, and the upper one even shorter than that, for the height of their tops was to be the same as the height of the middle branch — the seventh, the central one, from which the other six branches came out."

—3— **32. Sollen aus den Seiten hervorgehen,** sie zogen sich schräg nach beiden Seiten und stiegen bis zur Höhe des Leuchters, das ist des mittleren Rohres, empor; sie kamen aus dem mittleren Rohr hervor, eins über dem anderen, das untere war das längste, das darüber war kürzer, und das oberste war kürzer als dieses, weil die Höhe ihrer Spitze mit der Höhe des mittleren, des siebten Rohres, aus dem die sechs Arme hervorgingen, gleich war. 

---

////—1—//// 25:33:1,"**Engraved.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשֻׁקָּדִים is] as Onkelos translates it [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְצַיְירִין]: They were engraved in the manner that silver and gold vessels are made, called <font color=d50505>»</font>nieler<font color=d50505>«</font> (engraving) [in Old French]. "

§§—2—§§ 25:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים — Understand this as the Targum has it, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְצָיְרִין, chased. They were “modelled” in the way that is done on gold and silver vessels, a kind of work called in old French nieller."

—3— **33. Mandelförmig,** nach dem Targum waren sie modelliert, wie man dies an silbernen und goldenen Gefässen macht, was man in anderen Sprachen gravieren nennt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:33:2,**And three cups —** protruding from each of the branches.

§§—2—§§ 25:33:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גבעים THREE GOBLETS, projecting from each branch,"

—3— **Drei Kelche,** traten aus jedem Arm hervor, und jeder Arm hatte einen Knauf und eine Blüte. 

---

////—1—//// 25:33:3,**A knob and a flower —** was on each branch.

§§—2—§§ 25:33:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרח AND A KNOB AND A FLOWER was also on each branch.


---

////—1—//// 25:34:1,"**The [shaft of the] menorah shall have four cups.** In the body (center) of the menorah there were four cups, one protruding under the branches and three above from where the branches vented out, those that extended outward from its sides. "

§§—2—§§ 25:34:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובמנרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארבעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גבעים AND IN THE CANDELABRUM SHALL BE FOUR CUPS — i. e, on the body of the candlestick (on the vertical branch), were four goblets, viz., one jutting out from beneath the branches and three above the points from which emerged the branches that went out from its sides."

—3— **34. Und am Leuchter waren vier Kelche,** am Leuchter selbst waren vier Kelche, einer trat unterhalb der Arme hervor und drei über der Stelle, aus der die Arme hervorkamen, die aus seiner Seiten kamen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:34:2,**Engraved in almond shape patterns with their knob and flowers.** This is one of the five verses [in the Torah] in which [an adjective] is left undecided. [Here] it is not known whether [it should read]: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּבִיעִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשֻׁקָּדִים or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְשֻׁקָּדִים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּפְתֹּרֶיהָ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפְרָחֶיהָ .

§§—2—§§ 25:34:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתריה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרחיה GOBLETS MODELLED, WITH THEIR KNOBS AND THEIR FLOWERS (or it may be translated also: GOBLETS, MODELLED WITH THEIR KNOBS AND FLOWERS — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים being separated from the preceding by an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתנחתא seems to belong to the next words, to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתוריה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרחיה, but the fact that in the preceding verse it had been used of the goblets only suggests the reading <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גביעים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים. This is one of the five verses in Scripture the syntactical construction of which is undecided: it is not clear whether one should read <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גביעים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתריה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרחיה (Yoma 52b)."

—3— **Mandelförmig seine Knäufe und seine Blüte,** dies ist einer der fünf Verse, die sich nicht entscheiden lassen; es ist nämlich nicht zu entscheiden, ob <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משקדים nach oben zu Kelchen oder nach unten zu Knäufen und Blüten gehört (Joma 52a). 

---

////—1—//// 25:35:1,"**A knob under the two branches.** From the knob, the branches extended from the two sides in opposite directions. In the <font color=d50505>»</font>Beraisa d’Meleches Hamishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> we learned as follows: The menorah was altogether 18 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> high. [We arrive at this as follows:] 3 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> for the legs and the [lowest] flowerA (<font color=d50505>»</font>see illustrations on page 141<font color=d50505>«</font>). This is the flower that is mentioned together with the base, about which it says: “down to its base and its flower.” 2 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that were] unadornedB 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that was] a cup,C [i.e., one] of the four cups [mentioned in v. 34] as well as a knob and a flower [each of which was one] of the two knobs and two flowers that are mentioned with the menorah proper (i.e., the center branch), about which it is said (in v. 34): “the knobs and flowers were engraved,” from which we learn that the [center] branch had two knobs and two flowers besides the three knobs from which the [six] branches extended. [Regarding the latter three knobs] it says [here]: “and a knob under the two branches, etc.” 2<font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that were] unadorned.D 1<font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that was] a knob,E from which two branches extended in two directions.F They extended upwards to a height equal to the [center] of the menorah. 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that] was unadornedG 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that was] a knobH from which two branches extended.I 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that] was unadorned.J 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that] was a knobK from which two branches extended upward to a height equal to [the center of] the menorah.L 2 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> [above that] were unadorned.M 3 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim<font color=d50505>«</font> now remainedN, in which there were three cups (= 1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font>), and one knob (=1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font>) and one flower (=1 <font color=d50505>»</font>tefach<font color=d50505>«</font>). Consequently the total number of cups was 22: 18 for the six branches, [since there were] three for each one; and 4 in the menorah proper (i.e., the center branch), giving you a total of 22. And the total number of knobs was 11: 6 for the six branches (one for each) and 3 in the menorah proper (i.e., the center branch) from which the branches extended. and an additional 2 in the menorah proper, about which it is said (v. 34): “its knobs were engraved” [which indicates 2] [since] the minimum of anything plural is 2. One of these [knobs] was at the bottom near the base and the other one was in the three upper <font color=d50505>»</font>tefachim,<font color=d50505>«</font> together with the three cups. It (the menorah) had nine flowers: 6 for the six branches (one for each), as it is said (v. 33): “in each branch there was a knob and a flower,” and 3 for the menorah proper (i.e., the center branch). [Two of these are mentioned] when it is said “its knobs and <font color=d50505>»</font>flowers<font color=d50505>«</font> were engraved” and the minimum of “flowers” is 2, and [an additional one] mentioned in the <font color=d50505>»</font>parsha<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּהַעֲלֹתְךָ: “down to its base and its flower.” If you study the above <font color=d50505>»</font>beraisa<font color=d50505>«</font> carefully you will find them as they were enumerated, each in its proper place. "

§§—2—§§ 25:35:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכפתר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקנים AND THERE SHALL BE A KNOB UNDER TWO BRANCHES — The branches were drawn out from the two sides of the knob to this direction and to that. Thus we are taught in the Baraitha dealing with the construction of the Tabernacle (ch. 10): The full height of the candlestick was eighteen handbreadths, the legs and the flower taking up three handbreadths. — This is the flower mentioned in connection with the base, as it says, (Numbers 8:4) “unto the base thereof, unto the flower thereof”. — Then there was a space of two handbreadths that was plain; then one handbreadth in which was one of the four goblets (mentioned Exodus 25:34) and a knob and a flower of those two knobs and those two flowers that are mentioned together with the candlestick proper — for it states, (v. 34) “[And on the candelabrum (i. e. on the shaft) there shall be four cups] made like unto almonds with their knobs and their flowers,” which teaches us that there were on the middle branch two knobs and two flowers (the plural <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתריה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרחיה without stating the number suggesting “two” of each kind; besides the three knobs from which the branches emerged and of which it is said, (Exodus 25:35) “And there shall be a knob under the two branches etc.” — Then there were the following: two handbreadths that were plain; a handbreadth made up of a knob from which two branches emerged on each side, extending upward to the level of the candlestick proper; one handbreadth plain; one handbreadth made up of a knob with two branches emerging from it; one handbreadth plain, and a handbreadth made up of a knob from which two branches emerged and rose to the level of the candlestick proper; two handbreadths plain. Thus there remained three handbreadths in which were three goblets (three of the four mentioned in v. 34) and one knob and one flower (of the two mentioned Exodus 25:34-35). Consequently the goblets were twenty-two — eighteen on the six branches, there being three on each, and four on the candlestick proper, making altogether twenty-two; — and there were eleven knobs, — six on the six branches, one on each, and three on the candlestick proper from which the branches emerged, and two more knobs on the candlestick proper, — for it says, “made like unto almonds with its knobs”, and the minimum number implied by the plural <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפתורים, is two. One of these was below near the base and the other in the upper three handbreadths together with the three goblets. Furthermore it had nine flowers, six on the six branches, — as it says, (Exodus 25:33) “with a knob and a flower on the one branch” — and three on the candlestick proper, viz., two as is implied in what is said “made like unto almonds with its knobs and its flowers” — and the minimum number to be understood by the plural <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרחים is two, and one that is mentioned in the section <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהעלתך, (Numbers 8:4) “unto the base thereof and the flower thereof.” If you will study the above quoted Boraitha minutely you will find them (the different parts of the candlestick) enumerated according to their number, each in its position as laid down in this section (Menachot 28b)."

—3— **35. Ein Knauf befinde sich unter zwei Armen,** aus dem Knauf zogen sich die Arme aus den beiden Seiten dahin und dorthin heraus. So haben wir in der Baraitha 10) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאכת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן) gelernt, die Höhe des Leuchters betrug 18 Handbreiten, die Füße und die Blüte 3 Handbreiten, das ist die Blüte, die beim Fuß erwähnt wird; so heißt es (Num. 8, 4), sowohl ihr Fuß als auch ihre Blüte; zwei Handbreiten waren glatt, und eine Handbreite, an der ein Kelch von den vier Kelchen und ein Knauf und eine Blüte von den zwei Knäufen und den zwei Blüten, die am Leuchter selbst erwähnt werden, waren, so steht, seine Knäufe und seine Blüten; daraus entnehmen wir, dass am Stamm zwei Knäufe und zwei Blüten waren außer den drei Knäufen, aus denen sich die drei Arme herauszogen, wie es heißt, ein Knauf unterhalb von zwei Armen … und zwei Handbreiten glatt, und eine Handbreite war ein Knauf, aus dem zwei Arme nach beiden Seiten hervorgingen, die sich bis zur Höhe des Leuchters nach oben zogen; eine Handbreite war glatt und eine Handbreite ein Knauf, aus dem zwei Arme hervorgingen; eine Handbreite war glatt und eine Handbreite ein Knauf, aus dem zwei Arme hervorgingen, die sich bis zur Höhe des Leuchters nach oben zogen; zwei Handbreiten waren glatt; es blieben also noch drei Handbreiten, an denen drei Kelche und ein Knauf und eine Blüte waren; es ergeben sich daraus 22 Kelche, 18 an den 6 Armen, 3 an jedem einzelnen, und 4 am Leuchter selbst, das sind 22; und 11 Knäufe, 6 an den 6 Armen und 3 am Leuchter selbst, aus denen die Arme hervorgingen, und noch 2 am Leuchter; so steht, mandelförmig seine Knäufe, die kleinste Mehrzahl Knäufe aber beträgt 2; einer war unten am Fuße und der eine in den drei obersten Handbreiten bei den 3 Kelchen; und 9 Blüten waren an ihm, 6 an den 6 Armen; so steht, an einem Arm Knauf und Blüte; und 3 am Leuchter; so steht, mandelförmig seine Knäufe und seine Blüten, die kleinste Mehrzahl Blüten aber beträgt 2; und eine, die im Wochenabschnitt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בהעלתך (Num. 8) enthalten ist, sowohl ihr Fuß als auch ihre Blüte. Wenn du die hier niedergeschriebene Mischna genau lernst, wirst du alle Teile nach ihrer Anzahl finden, ein jedes an seiner Stelle (Menachot 28b). 

---

////—1—//// 25:37:1,**Its lamps.** They were a kind of cups into which the oil and the wicks were put.

§§—2—§§ 25:37:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נרתיה ITS LAMPS — a kind of small bowls into which the oil and the wicks were put. 

—3— **37. Seine Ölbehälter,** eine Art Becher, in die man das Öl und die Dochte legte. 

---

////—1—//// 25:37:2,"**So that they shine toward it.** I.e., make the mouths of the six lamps, which were at the top of the branches which extended from its (the menorah’s) sides, turned toward the middle one, so that when the lamps were lit they would shine <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֵבֶר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּנֶיהָ . [That is,] their shine would be turned towards the front side of the middle branch. which is the menorah proper.O "

§§—2—§§ 25:37:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והאיר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניה AND MAKE THEM GIVE LIGHT OVER AGAINST IT — Make the mouths of those six lamps which are on the top of the branches that come out from its sides so that they are turned towards the middle branch, in order that when you kindle the lamps they shall cast their light over against its (the candlestick’s) front-side, i. e. their light should be directed in the direction of the front of the central branch which forms the candlestick proper."

—3— **Und lasse nach seiner Vorderseite hin leuchten,** wende die Mündung der 6 Ölbehälter an der Spitze der Arme, die aus den Seiten hervorgehen, zum mittleren hin, damit die Lichter, wenn du sie anzündest, nach seiner Vorderseite hin leuchten; ihr Licht sei nach der Vorderseite des mittleren Rohres, das ist des eigentlichen Leuchters, hin gewandt. 

---

////—1—//// 25:38:1,"**Its tongs.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמַלְקָחֶיהָ] are the tongs which were made to pluck the wicks from the oil to set them up, and to pull them into the mouths of the lamps. Since they are used for “taking” (i.e., plucking) they are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַלְקָחַיִם (from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְקָח — “take”). The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִבְתָהָא with which Onkelos translates is from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צְבָת — <font color=d50505>»</font>tenálies<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 25:38:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומלקחיה — These were tongs made for taking the wicks out from the oil, to put them in position and to draw them into the mouths. Because people took things with them they were called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלקחים, (from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקח, “to take”). The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבתהא by which Onkelos renders it is the same as the more familiar term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבת, “a pair of tongs”; tenailles in old French"

—3— **38. Seine Zänglein,** das sind Zangen, gemacht, um damit die Dochte aus dem Öle zu nehmen, um sie geradezulegen und in die Mündung der Ölbehälter zu ziehen; weil man damit anfasst <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקח, wird das Gerät <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלקחים genannt, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבתהא im Targum von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבת Zange; Zange in anderen Sprachen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:38:2,"**And its scoops.** They were like small receptacles which were used to rake out the ashes from the lamp every single morning, when he would clean the lamps from the ashes of the wicks which had burned during the night and were extinguished. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַחְתָּה is <font color=d50505>»</font>puisedoire<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַחְתּוֹת) to rake fire from the oven.” "

§§—2—§§ 25:38:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומחתתיה AND ITS SNUFF-DISHES — These were like small bowls into which the High Priest raked the ashes every morning when he cleansed out the lamps from the ashes of the wicks that had burned all night and had become extinguished. The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחתה is fougère (feuchière) in old French, as in, (Isaiah 30:14) “to rake (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחתות) fire from the hearth.”"

—3— **Und seine Pfännlein,** das war eine Art kleiner Becher, mit denen man die Asche im Ölbehälter jeden Morgen herausnahm, wenn man die Ölbehälter von der Asche der Dochte, die in der Nacht gebrannt hatten und ausgegangen waren, reinigte; das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחתה bedeutet Lichtschere in anderen Sprachen; wie (Jes. 30, 14), eine brennende Kohle aus dem Feuer zu nehmen. 

---

////—1—//// 25:39:1,"**A <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> of pure gold.** Its weight, including all its vessels, should be only a <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar,<font color=d50505>«</font> no more and no less. The <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> [used to measure] mundane things was the equivalent of sixty <font color=d50505>»</font>manehs,<font color=d50505>«</font> whereas the one [used to measure] holy things was double that — 120 <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh.<font color=d50505>«</font> A <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh<font color=d50505>«</font> is the equivalent of a <font color=d50505>»</font>litra<font color=d50505>«</font> which is used to weigh silver according to the weight of Cologne. This is equal to one hundred <font color=d50505>»</font>zehuvim<font color=d50505>«</font> (dinars), equal to twenty five <font color=d50505>»</font>sela’im,<font color=d50505>«</font> a <font color=d50505>»</font>sela<font color=d50505>«</font> being four <font color=d50505>»</font>zehuvim<font color=d50505>«</font> (dinars). "

§§—2—§§ 25:39:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זהב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טהור OF A TALENT OF PURE GOLD [SHALL HE MAKE IT WITH ALL THESE VESSELS] — i. e. that its weight together with (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את) all its vessels shall he exactly one talent, neither more nor less (cf. Menachot 88b). A common (not holy) kikkar (one used for weighing ordinary articles) was sixty manehs, that used for sacred purposes double as much, hundred and twenty manehs; a maneh was equal to a litra (the Roman libra, a pound) by which silver is weighed, according to the standard weight of Cologne. This is hundred denars which is the equivalent of twenty-five Sela’im, one Sela being four denars (cf. Bekhorot 5a)."

—3— **39. Aus einem Talente reinen Goldes,** ihr Gewicht mit allen ihren Geräten soll nur ein Talent betragen, nicht weniger und nicht mehr; das gewöhnliche Talent hat 60 Minen; das heilige betrug das Doppelte, 120 Minen; die Mine ist ein Pfund, mit dem man Silber wiegt nach dem Gewicht von Köln; das sind 100 Gulden = 25 Sela, der Sela = 4 Gulden. 

---

////—1—//// 25:40:1,**Observe and make them.** See here on the mountain the pattern which I show you. This tells us that Moshe had difficulties with the constructing of the menorah until God showed him a menorah [model] made of fire.

§§—2—§§ 25:40:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועשה AND SEE AND MAKE — See here, in the mountain, the pattern which I shew thee. This teaches you that Moses was puzzled about the workmanship of the Menorah until the Holy One, blessed be He, showed him the pattern of it in a candlestick of fire (Menachot 29a)."

—3— **40. Schaue und mache,** schaue hier auf dem Berge die Gestalt, die ich dir zeige; das lehrt, dass Mosche das Werk des Leuchters schwer fiel, bis ihm der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, einen Leuchter von Feuer zeigte. 

---

////—1—//// 25:40:2,"**That will be shown to you.** As Onkelos translates it: “that you will be shown in the mountain.” If it were vocalized <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַרְאֶה with a <font color=d50505>»</font>patach,<font color=d50505>«</font> its meaning would be: “you will show to others.” But, now that it is vowelized with a <font color=d50505>»</font>kametz<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָרְאֶה), its meaning is: “that you will be shown” — that others show you. "

§§—2—§§ 25:40:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראה WHICH WAS SHOWN THEE — Translate as the Targum does: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דאת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתחזי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בטורא which thou hast been shown on the mountain. If it were punctuated with Patach (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַרְאֶה) it would mean which you show to others,” now, however, that it is punctuated with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קמץ (our <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קמץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטוף, short Kametz) it signifies, “which thou hast been shown” — i. e. which others show thee [for the punctuation distinguishes between the words denoting “one who does something” and “one who has something done to him” (i. e. between the active participle <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַרְאֶה and the passive participle <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָרְאֶה).]"

—3— **Welche dir gezeigt worden ist,** wie der Targum sagt, welche dir auf dem Berge gezeigt worden ist; wenn <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראה mit Patach punktiert wäre, so wäre die Deutung, du zeigst anderen; jetzt aber, da es mit kurzem Kamez punktiert ist, ist die Deutung, dir ist gezeigt worden, andere haben dir gezeigt (denn die Punktierung unterscheidet Aktiv von Passiv). 

---

////—1—//// 26:1:1,"**You shall make the mishkon out of ten drapes —** to serve as a roof and partitions on the outside of the planks, for the drapes were hung behind them to cover them. "

§§—2—§§ 26:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יריעת MOREOVER THOU SIIALT MAKE THE DWELLING OF TEN CURTAINS — that they should serve it as a roof and at the same thime as wall-coverings for the outside of the beards; — for the curtains hung behind them so as to cover them.

—3— **26, 1. Und die Wohnung mache aus zehn Teppichen,** damit sie ihr Dach und ihre Wände außerhalb der Balken seien; denn die Teppiche hingen an den Aussenseiten herab, um sie zu bedecken. 

---

////—1—//// 26:1:2,"**Fine twined linen, greenish-blue, dark red and crimson.** Thus you have four kinds [of material] together in each and every thread, one of linen and three of wool. Each and every thread was made six-fold. Hence the four materials when woven together made each strand consist of 24 threadsA (<font color=d50505>»</font>see illustration on page 142<font color=d50505>«</font>). "

§§—2—§§ 26:1:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משזר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותכלת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וארגמן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ותלעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שני OF FINE TWINED LINEN AND BLUE PURPLE, AND RED PURPLE, AND CRIMSON — Thus there were four different materials in every thread, one of linen and three of wool, each of the strands of which a thread was composed being sixfold (the word is taken here in the double sense of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שש “linen” and of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שש “six”). Consequently the four materials intertwined into one thread gave a twenty-four-fold thread (Yoma 71b; Baraita DeMelekhet HaMishkan ch. 2)."

—3— **Aus gezwirntem Byssus, himmelblauer Wolle, purpurroter Wolle und karmesinroter Wolle;** es waren vier Arten in jedem Faden, einer von Flachs und drei von Wolle; und jeder einzelne Faden war sechsfach; es ergaben also die vier Arten, wenn sie zusammengedreht waren, eine 24fachen Faden (Joma 7lb; Baraitha <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאכת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן). 

---

////—1—//// 26:1:3,"**Figures of cherubim, the work of a craftsman.** Cherubim were formed in them (the drapes) through weaving, and not through embroidery which is done through needlework. But, rather, by weaving on two sides, one image on one side and another image on the other side, a lion on this side and an eagle on the other side, just as silken belts are woven [nowadays], which are called <font color=d50505>»</font>feises<font color=d50505>«</font> (woven images) in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 26:1:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כרבים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חשב WITH CHERUBIM, THE WORK OF AN ARTIST — Cherubim were figured on them (on the curtains) in the process of weaving them, not afterwards by embroidery which is needlework — but by weaving it on its two surfaces, one design on one side, a different design on the other; e. g., a lion on one side and an eagle on the other side, just as the silken girdles are woven which are called in old French faisee (Yoma 72b, Jerusalem Talmud Shekalim 8:4)."

—3— **Mit Cherubim, Werk des Kunstwebers,** Cherubim waren im Gewebe geformt, nicht gestickt, Werk der Nadel; sondern gewebt mit zwei Wänden, eine Figur auf dieser Seite und eine Figur auf dieser Seite, ein Löwe auf dieser Seite und ein Adler auf der anderen Seite (Joma 72b), wie man seidene Bänder webt, die man fassoniertes Gewebe nennt. 

---

////—1—//// 26:3:1,**Shall be joined together.** They were sewn together with a needle one beside the other — each of five [drapes] separately.

§§—2—§§ 26:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תהיין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חברת SHALL JOIN TOGETHER — They sewed them together with a needle, each five separately."

—3— **3. Seien verbunden,** er nähte sie mit der Nadel zusammen, einen neben den anderen, fünf für sich und fünf für sich. 

---

////—1—//// 26:3:2,"**Together.** This is the way Scripture speaks (i.e., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִשָּׁה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲחוֹתָהּ) of an object in the feminine gender. And when the object is in the masculine gender it says: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִישׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אָחִיו, as it states regarding the cherubim: “they shall face one another (lit. one man to another).” "

§§—2—§§ 26:3:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחתה ONE TO ANOTHER (lit., a woman to her sister) — This is the idiom of Biblical Hebrew — to speak thus about a thing that is of the feminine gender when it correlates it with a thing of the same kind. In the case of a thing that is masculine it uses the expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחיו, lit., a man to his brother, as it is said, e. g. of the cherubim (Exodus 25:20) “and their faces were turned <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחיו‎”."

—3— **Einer mit dem anderen,** so ist der Gebrauch des Verses zu sprechen, für die weibliche Form wendet er <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחות Schwester und für die männliche <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אח Bruder an; wie bei den Cherubim steht (25, 20), ihr Angesicht, das des einen war dem des anderen zugewandt. 

---

////—1—//// 26:4:1,"**Loops.** <font color=d50505>»</font>Laçols<font color=d50505>«</font> (loops) in Old French. Onkelos, too, translates it thus: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲנוּבִין from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲנִיבָה (loop or bow).B (<font color=d50505>»</font>See illustration on page 142<font color=d50505>«</font>) "

§§—2—§§ 26:4:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ללאת are lacels in old French Similarly Onkelos translates it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ענובין, which has the meaning of “looping.”"

—3— **4. Schleifen,** Schleifen in anderen Sprachen; so übersetzt auch Onkelos <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ענובין von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עניבה Schleife. 

---

////—1—//// 26:4:2,**At the end of the group.** [I.e.] on that drape which is at the end of the group. The group of the five [joined] drapes is referred to as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חוֹבָרֶת .

§§—2—§§ 26:4:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקצה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחברת FROM THE EXTREMITY IN THE JOINING — i. e. the loops shall be made on that curtain which is the last in the section. The combination of five curtains is here termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חוברת. 

—3— **Am Saume des Zusammengesetzten Teppichs;** an dem Teppich am Ende der Verbindung; die Verbindung der fünf Teppiche wird <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חברת genannt. 

---

////—1—//// 26:4:3,"**Do the same on the edge of the drape which is at the end of the second group.** [I.e.] on that drape which is at the end. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קִיצוֹנָה is from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָצֶה (end), that is, at <font color=d50505>»</font>the end<font color=d50505>«</font> of the group. "

§§—2—§§ 26:4:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשפת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היריעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקיצונה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במחברה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השנית—  AND LIKEWISE SHALT THOU MAKE IN THE OUTERMOST EDGE OF ANOTHER CURTAIN IN THE JOINING OF THE SECOND — i. e. on that curtain which is the end-most — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קיצונה is connected in meaning with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קצה, end; — it is as much as to say: “at the end of the section.”"

—3— **Und ebenso mache am Saume des äussersten Teppichs an der zweiten Verbindung,** am äussersten Teppich, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קיצון von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קצה, das heißt am Ende der Verbindung. 

---

////—1—//// 26:5:1,"**The loops shall be opposite one another.** Take care that you make the loops exactly equidistant from one another. And the measurements used for one drape shall be the same as in the other one, so that when you spread out one group next to the other the loops of one drape [should] line up exactly opposite the loops of the other. And that is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַקְבִּילוֹת — “one opposite the other” [as indicated by] Onkelos’ translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶגֶד (<font color=d50505>»</font>opposite<font color=d50505>«</font>) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָקֳבֵל . [Each of] the drapes was 28 [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] long and four [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] wide. And when the five drapes were joined together their width totaled 20 [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>]. The same was true for the second group [of drapes]. The [interior] length of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> was 30 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>A (<font color=d50505>»</font>see illustration on page 143<font color=d50505>«</font>) from east to west, as it is said: “twenty planks for the southern side” and similarly for the northern side, each plank being 1½ <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> wide.B So you have 30 [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] east to west. The [interior] width of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon,<font color=d50505>«</font> from north to south, was ten <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>,C as it is said: “For the western side of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>, etc., and make two planks for the corners.” Hence [the eight planks] equaled ten [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of interior. [For two of the <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> covered the thickness of the plank on each side]. I will explain these verses in their places. The drapes were placed [so that] their length was across the width of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>, ten of their middle <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> covering the interior of the width of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>. An additional <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> on each side [covered] the thickness of the top of the planksD whose width was one <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font>. This left 16 amohs: eight [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] on the northern side and eight [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] on the southern side covered the height of the planks which were ten <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> high. Consequently, the bottom two [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of the planks] remained uncovered. The width of the drapes [totaled] 40 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> when they were all joined — 20 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> for each group. Thirty of the total [<font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font>] covered the interior of the length of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>; one <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> corresponded to the thickness of the tops of the planks on the western side and an additional <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> [was needed] to cover the thickness of the pillars on the eastern side, — for there were no planks on the eastern side, just five pillarsE from which the screen was spread and hung by their (the pillars’) hooks as a sort of a curtain. Consequently there remained eight <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> which hung in back of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> on the western side, leaving the bottom 2 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> uncovered. The above I found in the <font color=d50505>»</font>Beraisa of 49 midos<font color=d50505>«</font>. However, in <font color=d50505>»</font>Maseches<font color=d50505>«</font> Shabbos (98b) [we find]: The drapes did not cover the eastern beams, and nine <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> hung in back of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font> What is written in this section supports this, [for it states:] “Place the <font color=d50505>»</font>paroches<font color=d50505>«</font> under the clasps,” and if, in fact, it were as is stated in the <font color=d50505>»</font>Beraisa<font color=d50505>«</font> it would result in the <font color=d50505>»</font>paroches<font color=d50505>«</font> being a distance of one <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> westward from the clasps. "

§§—2—§§ 26:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקבילת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הללאת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחתה — Be careful that you make the loops (place them on the curtains) to one measurement: that the spaces between one loop and the other be exactly the same, and further, as their measurement is on the one so shall it be on the other, so that when you lay out one section next to the other the loops of the one shall come exactly opposite those of the other. That is what is meant by the expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקבילות, viz., “one opposite the other”. In the Targum the translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶגֶד “opposite” is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקבל (hence the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקבילות from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קבל). The curtains were twenty-eight cubits long and four cubits wide, so when they joined five curtains together along their lengths it followed that their width was twenty cubits. The same was the case with the other section. The Tabernacle was thirty cubits in length from East to West, for it is said, (Exodus 36:23) “twenty boards for the south side (which was the long side of the Tabernacle) southward,” and the same is stated with reference to the north side; and as each board was one cubit and a half in breadth you have thirty cubits from East to West. The width of the Tabernacle from North to South was ten cubits, for it is said, (Exodus 36:27, 28) “and for the side of the dwelling westward he made six boards … and two boards … for the corners of the dwelling,” so you have ten cubits (this appears to give a breadth of twelve cubits, but each of the corner boards stood partly behind the thickness of the adjoining board that stood at right angles with it, and as the thickness was one cubit it took off a cubit on each side from the inside measurement). — I shall explain these verses each on its place. — They spread the curtains with their length over the breadth of the Tabernacle, whereby the ten middle cubits served as a roofing for the inside over the width of the Tabernacle and a cubit on each side of these ten cubits went to cover the thickness of the boards which were one cubit thick, so that there remained altogether sixteen cubits — eight hanging over on the north side and eight on the south side, covering the vertical boards which were ten cubits in height; consequently the two lowest cubits of the boards were left showing. The breadth of the curtains after having been joined together was forty cubits, twenty cubits for each section. Thirty cubits of these served as a roofing for the inside of the Tabernacle over its length, and one cubit for the thickness of the tops of the boards of the westside and one more cubit to cover the thickness of the columns in the east side — for there were no boards in the east side but there were five columns on the hooks of which the screen was spread and hung as a kind of curtain (cf. Exodus 27:10). Thus there remained eight cubits which hung on the back of the Tabernacle on the west side, leaving the two lowest cubits showing. This I have found in the Boraitha <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ט <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדות. But in Treatise Shabbat 98b it is stated that the curtains did not cover the thickness of the columns on the east side, and consequently there were nine cubits of the curtains hanging on the back of the Tabernacle. The text of this section suppports this view, since it says (v. 33) “and thou shalt hang up the partition veil under the catches;” for if it were as the Boraitha states the partition veil would have been distant from the catches one cubit to the West."

—3— **5. Sie standen einander gegenüber, die Schleifen, eine der anderen;** achte darauf, dass du die Schleifen nach **einem** Maße machst, den Abstand der einen von der anderen genau gleichmässig, und gleich dem Maße an dem einen Teppiche sei es auch an dem anderen, damit, wenn du die zusammengesetzten Teppiche nebeneinander ausbreitest, die Schleifen des einen Teppichs genau denen des anderen gegenüberstehen; das bedeutet der Ausdruck, einander gegenüberstehend, der Targum von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגד ist <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לקבל. Die Teppiche hatten eine Länge von 28 Ellen und eine Breite von 4; wenn man 5 Teppiche miteinander verband, ergab sich eine Länge von 20, und ebenso bei der zweiten Verbindung. Die Wohnung war 30 Ellen lang von Osten nach Westen, so steht (V. 18), 20 Balken an der Südseite, und ebenso im Norden, und jeder Balken hatte 1V2 Ellen, das sind 30 Ellen von Osten nach Westen. Die Breite der Wohnung von Norden nach Süden war 10 Ellen, so steht (V. 22), an der Rückseite der Wohnung im Westen, und zwei Balken für die Ecken, das sind zusammen 10 Ellen; ich werde diese Verse an ihrer Stelle erklären. Man legte nun die Teppiche mit ihrer Länge über die Breite der Wohnung, die 10 mittleren Ellen für das Dach, den Hohlraum in der Breite der Wohnung, und eine Elle auf jede Seite für die Dicke der oberen Enden der Balken, deren Dicke eine Elle betrug; es blieben dann noch 16 Ellen übrig, 8 im Norden und 8 im Süden, welche die Höhe der Balken bedeckten, deren Höhe 10 Ellen betrug; findet sich, dass die zwei untersten Ellen unbedeckt blieben. Die Breite der Teppiche war 40 Ellen, wenn sie verbunden waren, 20 Ellen jeder der beiden verbundenen Teppiche; 30 Ellen davon waren für das Dach, den Hohlraum der Wohnung in der Länge, und eine Elle für die Dicke der oberen Enden der Balken im Westen, und eine Elle, um die Dicke der Säulen im Osten zu bedecken; denn im Osten waren keine Balken, sondern fünf Säulen, an deren Haken der Vorhang ausgebreitet und aufgehängt war wie unsere Türvorhänge; es blieben dann noch 8 Ellen übrig, welche an der Rückseite der Wohnung im Westen herunterhingen, und die zwei untersten Ellen blieben aufgedeckt; dies habe ich in der Baraitha <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מ״<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ט <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדות gefunden. Aber im Traktat Sabbat (98b) steht, die Teppiche bedeckten nicht die Dicke der Säulen im Osten, und 9 Ellen hingen an der Rückwand der Wohnung herab; der Vers (33) in diesem Abschnitt unterstützt unsere Meinung im Talmud, befestige den Vorhang unter den Spangen; wäre es aber, wie diese Baraitha sagt, so hätte sich der Vorhang eine Elle westlicher als die Spangen befunden.

////—1—//// 26:6:1,"**Golden Clasps.** <font color=d50505>»</font>Fermeilz<font color=d50505>«</font> (hooks or clasps) in Old French. One of their ends is inserted into [one of the] loops of one of the groups [of drapes] and their other end into the loops of the other group [of drapes,] thereby joining them through them. "

§§—2—§§ 26:6:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרסי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זהב CATCHES OF GOLD — Fermels in old French They put one end of them into the loops on one section and the other end into the loops on the other section and they thus joined them (these sections) together by means of them.

—3— **6. Goldene Spangen,** fermails Spangen in änderen Sprachen, man steckte das eine Ende von ihnen in die Schleifen des einen verbundenen Teppichs und das andere Ende in die Schleifen des anderen und verband sie durch sie miteinander.

////—1—//// 26:7:1,**Drapes of goats’ [hair].** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִזִּים here means:] of goats’ hair.

§§—2—§§ 26:7:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יריעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים CURTAINS OF <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עזים — i. e. GOATS HAIR (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 25:4).

—3— **7. Teppiche aus Ziegenhaar,** aus dem Haar von Ziegen.

§§—2—§§ 26:7:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאהל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן TO BE A COVERING UPON THE DWELLING — i. e. to spread them over the lower curtains (over those which had been already placed over the Tabernacle).

—3— **Als Zelt über der Wohnung,** sie über die unteren Teppiche zu breiten.

The lowest <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> of the plank, which was left uncovered by the drape, is the <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> that is inserted into the opening of the socket,A (<font color=d50505>»</font>see illustration 1 on page 144<font color=d50505>«</font>) for the sockets were one <font color=d50505>»</font>amoh<font color=d50505>«</font> high. "

§§—2—§§ 26:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שלשים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באמה [THE LENGTH OF ONE CURTAIN SHALL BE] THIRTY CUBITS — so that when they place them with their length over the breadth of the Tabernacle in the same way as they put the first curtains (the length of which was 28 cubits) it follows that they are in excess by one cubit on this side and one cubit on that side, thus covering one of the two cubits of the boards left showing. The lowest cubit of the boards which no curtain covered was that cubit which was inserted in the hole of the socket, for the sockets themselves were one cubit high."

—3— **8. Dreissig Ellen,** wenn er ihre Länge über die Breite der Wohnung legte, wie er die ersten gelegt hat, fand sich, dass diese auf jeder Seite eine Elle überhingen, um eine von den beiden Ellen, die von den Balken noch unbedeckt geblieben waren, zu bedecken; und die unterste Elle des Balkens, welche der Teppich nicht bedeckte, war die Elle, die in der Höhlung des Fußes steckte; denn die Füße waren eine Elle hoch.

////—1—//// 26:9:2,"****[...shall overhang] **before the entrance of the tent.** Half of its width hung and folded over the curtain on the eastern side, before the entrance, similar to a modest bride whose face is covered by a veil. "

§§—2—§§ 26:9:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מול <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האהל OPPOSITE THE FRONT OF THE TENT; half of its breadth (two cubits) hung down, being doubled, over the screen which was on the east side before the entrance, whereby the Tabernacle gained the appearance of a modest bride who has her face covered by a veil."

—3— **An der Vorderseite des Zeltes,** die Hälfte seiner Breite hing herab und lag doppelt auf dem Vorhang im Osten vor dem Eingang, einer sittsamen jungen Frau gleichend, deren Angesicht von einem Schleier verhüllt ist.

////—1—//// 26:12:1,"**The overlapping excess of the drapes of the tent — ** over and above the [lower] curtains of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font> The “drapes of the Tent” refer to the upper ones made of goats’ hairs which are referred to [in the Torah] as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֹהֶל, as it says, regarding them: “to be an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֹהֶל over the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font>” Wherever <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֹהֶל is used regarding them (the upper drapes) it means a cover [and not the literal: “tent”] for they cover and shield over the lower ones. They were longer than the lower [drapes] by [the width of] half a drape on the western side for half of the eleventh drape, which was the one in excess [of the ten lower drapes], folded [downward] toward the entrance of the Tent. Consequently there remained two <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> — half its width — in excess of the width of the lower [curtains]. "

§§—2—§§ 26:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וסרח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העדף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ביריעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האהל AND THE SURPLUS OF THE CURTAINS OF THE TENT over and above the lower curtains of the Tabernacle [SHALL HANG OVER etc.]. “The curtains of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל” were the upper ones made of goats’ hair which Scripture calls <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל, as it states about them, (v. 7) “they shall be an <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל over the dwelling.” The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל used in connection with them means only a covering (the word has not its usual meaning of “tent“) because they formed a cover and a screen over the lower ones. They exceeded the lower ones by one half curtain on the west side. For the other half of the eleventh curtain which was in excess of the number of the lower ones was folded over to hang in front of the tent (the Tabernacle) (cf. v. 9). There therefore remained two cubits, — the breadth of the half of it — in excess of the width of the lower curtains (it is this which is here described as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>היריעה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העדפת “the half curtain that exceeded”). This"

—3— **12. Und das Herabhängende,** das mehr ist an den Teppichen des Zeltes als an den Teppichen der Wohnung; Teppiche des Zeltes sind die oberen aus Ziegenhaar, die Zelt genannt werden, wie er von ihnen sagt (V. 7), zum Zelt über der Wohnung; überall, wo sie Zelt genannt werden, bedeutet es nur Dach, sie bildeten ein Dach und eine Decke über den unteren und waren um einen halben Teppich im Westen länger als die unteren; denn die andere Hälfte des elften Teppichs, der mehr war, war an der Vorderseite doppelt gelegt; es blieben also noch zwei Ellen, die Breite seiner Hälfte, über die Breite des unteren überhängend.

§§—2—§§ 26:12:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תסרח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן SHALL HANG OVER THE BACK OF THE TABERNACLE — to cover the two cubits of the boards that were left bare. 

—3— **Lass an der Rückseite der Wohnung herabhängen,** um die zwei Ellen zu bedecken, die an den Balken unbedeckt waren.

////—1—//// 26:12:3,"**The back of the mishkon.** This refers to the western side, [called the “back” of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>] because the entrance was on the eastern side which is its (the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon’s) “front.” The northern and southern sides are called “the right and left sides.” <font color=d50505>«</font>"

§§—2—§§ 26:12:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן THE BACK OF THE TABERNACLE — i. e. the west side. This is called “the back” because the entrance was on the east side which was therefore its front. The north and the south are accordingly called the “sides” in the right and the left directions.

§§—2—§§ 26:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והאמה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והאמה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה AND A CUBIT ON THE ONE SIDE AND A CUBIT ON THE OTHER SIDE — i. e. on the north and on the south,"

—3— **13. Und die Elle von dieser Seite und die Elle von dieser Seite,** im Norden und im Süden.

////—1—//// 26:13:2,**That were in excess of the length of the drapes of the tent —** that they were in excess over the length of the “drapes of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font>” (the lower ones) — by two <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> —

§§—2—§§ 26:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעדף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בארך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יריעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האהל OF THE SURPLUS OF THE LENGTH OF THE CURTAINS OF THE TABERNACLE — i. e. which were in excess over the curtains of “the Tabernacle” (the woollen ones) by two cubits,"

////—1—//// 26:13:3,"**shall overlap the sides of the mishkon.** [I.e.] the northern and southern sides as I explained above (v. 12, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחורי). The Torah thereby teaches a lesson in propriety: that a person should be protective of that which is beautiful. "

§§—2—§§ 26:13:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יהיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מרוח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צדי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן SHALL HANG OVER THE SIDES OF THE TABERNACLE — on the north and on the south as I have explained above. The Torah here teaches you a rule of life — that a man should take care of his artistic objects (this the Torah does by commanding that the beautiful lower curtains should be protected by coarse upper ones) (Yalkut Shimoni on Torah 422).

—3— **Hänge an den Seiten der Wohnung herab,** im Norden und im Süden, wie ich oben erklärt habe; die Torah lehrt uns hier eine Lebensregel, dass man das Kostbare schone (Jalk. 422). **Die Rückseite der Wohnung** (V. 12) ist die Westseite, weil der Eingang im Osten die Vorderseite war, und Norden und Süden werden rechte und linke Seite genannt.

////—1—//// 26:14:1,"**A covering for the tent.** For the roof made of the drapes of goats’ hairs, make an additional covering out of red-dyed ram’s skins. And above that still another covering made out of <font color=d50505>»</font>tachash<font color=d50505>«</font> skins. These coverings covered only the roof. Their length was 30 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> and their width ten. This is the opinion of Rabbi Nechemiah. However, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah there was only one covering, half of it [made] of red-dyed rams’ skins and the other half of <font color=d50505>»</font>tachash<font color=d50505>«</font> skins. "

§§—2—§§ 26:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכסה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאהל [AND THOU SHALT MAKE] A COVERING FOR THE <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל — For that roofing of goats’ hair (which is termed <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל in this section) make still another covering of rams’ skins dyed red, and above this also a covering of Tachash skins. These uppermost covers however covered the roof only (were not hanging over the sides), their length being 30 cubits and their width 10. This is the opinion of R. Nehemia (that the goats’ skins and the layer of rams’ and Tachash skins formed two different covers one above the other); according to R. Jehudah, however, there was only one cover, half of it being of rams’ skins dyed red and half of it of Tachash skins (cf. Shabbat 28a)."

—3— **14. Eine Decke für das Zelt,** für jenes Dach aus Ziegenhaarteppichen mache noch eine Decke aus rotgefärbten Widderfellen und ferner darüber eine Decke aus Tachaschfellen; diese Decken bedeckten nur das Dach, ihre Länge war 30 und ihre Breite 10 Ellen, das sind die Worte von R. Nechemja, aber nach den Worten von R. Juda war es nur eine Decke, zur Hälfte aus rotgefärbten Widderfellen und zur Hälfte aus Tachaschfellen (Schabbat 28a).
