////—1—//// 31:15:1,"**A Shabbos of complete rest.** [Means:] a restful rest and not a haphazard rest. **(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבַּת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבָּתוֹן .** The reason the verse doubles the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבָּת is to tell you that all “work” is prohibited, even that which is for preparation of food. So, too, regarding Yom Kippur, where it states: “It is for you <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבַּת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבָּתוֹן,” all “work” is prohibited. Whereas regarding Yom Tov, it states only: “On the first day it shall be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבָּתוֹן and on the eighth day it shall be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׁבָּתוֹן they (i.e., these days) are prohibited from all “work” of toil but are permitted in work that is for the preparation of food.) "

§§—2—§§ 31:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שבתון denotes, reposeful rest and not rest of a casual character."

—3— **15. Vollkommene Sabbatfeier,** vollkommene Ruhe und nicht flüchtige Ruhe. 

---

////—1—//// 31:15:2,**It is sacred to Adonoy.** The observance of its sacredness shall be for My Name and to obey My commandments.

§§—2—§§ 31:15:2, ‘<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לה HOLINESS TO THE LORD — The observance of its holiness shall be (it shall be kept holy) to the glory of My Name and by My command (because I have commanded it).

—3— **Heilig dem Ewigen,** die Hütung ihrer Heiligkeit sei meinem Namen zu Ehren und in meinem Auftrag. 

---

////—1—//// 31:17:1,"**And He rested.** As Onkelos translates it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנָח — “and He rested.” All forms of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נוֹפֶשׁ are from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶפֶשׁ — “soul,” i.e., he retrieves his soul and breath by his resting from the toil of his work. Now He, about Whom it is written: “He does not become faint, nor weary,” and all His “work” is accomplished merely by command, attributes “rest” to Himself only to accustom the ear to what it can possibly hear. "

§§—2—§§ 31:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וינפש AND WAS REFRESHED — Take it as the Targum renders it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונח “and He rested”. Every form of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפש is derived from the noun <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נֶפֶש, soul; the idea is, that one calms his soul and takes breath when one reposes after the toil of labour. — And He of Whom it is written, (Isaiah 40:28) “[… the Lord, the Creator of the ends of the earth] fainteth not nor is He weary”, and Whose every action is accomplished by His mere command had the term “repose” written of (ascribed to) Himself in order to make comprehensible to the human ear what it can understand."

—3— **17. Und ruhte Er,** wie der Targum sagt, und ruhte Er; überall bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נופש Erholung der Seele, man erholt seine Seele und seine Brust, indem man von der Mühe bei der Arbeit ausruht. Er aber, von dem geschrieben steht (Jes. 40, 28), Er ermüdet und Er ermattet nicht, und all dessen Werke durch Sein Wort entstanden sind, hat den Ausdruck Ruhe auf sich angewandt, um dem Ohr begreiflich zu machen, was es verstehen kann. 

---

////—1—//// 31:18:1,"**And He gave to Moshe, etc.** There is no “earlier” or “later” in the Torah. [Here, too], the event of the Calf preceded the command regarding the work of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> by many days. For on the seventeenth of Tammuz the tablets were broken and on Yom Kippur God was reconciled to the Israelites. On the following day they began contributing towards the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> which was erected on the first of Nissan. "

§§—2—§§ 31:18:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND HE GAVE UNTO MOSES etc. — There is no “earlier” or “later” (no chronological order) in the events related in the Torah: in fact the incident of the golden calf (related in ch. 31) happened a considerable time before the command regarding the work of the Tabernacle was given (ch. 25 and the following chapters). For on the seventeenth of Tammuz were the Tablets broken (when the people were worshipping the calf) and on the Day of Atonement God became reconciled with Israel (after Moses had prayed 80 days for forgivenness; so that it is very unlikely that the command for the building of the Tabernacle should have been given before that day) and on the next day, the eleventh of Tishri (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 33:11, at end of comment on <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המחנה), they began to bring their contributions for the Tabernacle which was set up on the first of Nisan. (From the seventeenth of Tammuz until the eleventh of Tishri are almost three months — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבים) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 31)."

—3— **18. Und Er gab Mosche,** die Abschnitte in der Torah sind nicht nach der zeitlichen Reihenfolge geordnet; denn die Begebenheit mit dem Kalbe war viele Tage vor dem Befehl, die Wohnung zu bauen; siehe, am 17. Tamus wurden die Tafeln zerbrochen, und am Jomhakipurim verzieh der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, Israel; am nächsten Tag begannen sie mit den Spenden für die Wohnung, und diese wurde am 1. Nissan errichtet. 

---

////—1—//// 31:18:2,"**When He finished.** It is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּכַלָּתוֹ (with no <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' after the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל') [suggesting] that the Torah was given to him as a gift, as a bride [is given] to a groom because [otherwise] he could not have learned it all in such a short time. An alternate explanation [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כְּכַלָתוֹ]: just as a bride adorns herself with 24 adornments — those enumerated in the book of Yeshaiyahu — so, too, must a Torah scholar be knowledgeable in the twenty-four books. "

§§—2—§§ 31:18:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככלתו WHEN HE FINISHED [SPEAKING] — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככלתו is written defectively (without a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו after the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל) to intimate that the Torah was handed over to Moses as a gift (note the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתן), complete in every respect, even as the bride (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככלתו is taken to be connected with “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלה”, bride) is handed over to the bridegroom completely equipped with all she requires — for in a period brief as this which Moses spent on the mountain, he must have been unable to learn in its entirety every law to be derived from it. Another explanation why the word is written defective is: just as a bride (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלה) bedecks herself with 24 ornaments — those which are mentioned in the book of Isaiah (ch. 3) — so a scholar (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תלמיד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חכם) ought to be thoroughly versed in the contents of the 24 books of Scripture (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 16)."

—3— **Als Er vollendet hatte,** steht ohne Waw <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כלתו, die Torah wurde ihm als Geschenk übergeben wie eine Braut dem Bräutigam; denn sonst hätte er sie in dieser kurzen Zeit nicht ganz lernen können; andere Erklärung: wie eine Braut mit 24 Schmuckgegenständen, nämlich den im Buche Jeschaia (3) erwähnten, geschmückt wird, so soll auch ein Torahgelehrter in den 24 Büchern der heiligen Schrift erfahren sein (Schem, r.; Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 31:18:3,**Speaking with him.** The statutes and laws in (<font color=d50505>»</font>parshas<font color=d50505>«</font>) Mishpatim.

§§—2—§§ 31:18:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו TO SPEAK WITH HIM the statutes and the judgments contained in the section beginning with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשפטים (ch. Exodus 21 ff.).

—3— **Mit ihm zu sprechen,** die Satzungen und die Rechte in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשפטים.

---

////—1—//// 31:18:4,**Speaking with him.** This teaches that Moshe would hear from God then they both reviewed and studied the <font color=d50505>»</font>halachah<font color=d50505>«</font> together.

§§—2—§§ 31:18:4,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו TO SPEAK “WITH” HIM — The use of the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו “with him” teaches us that Moses first heard the laws from the mouth of the Almighty and that then they both again repeated each Halacha together (Exodus Rabbah 41:5).

—3— **Mit ihm zu sprechen,** das lehrt, dass Mosche aus dem Munde des Allmächtigen die Halacha empfing und beide zusammen dieselbe noch einmal wiederholten. 

---

////—1—//// 31:18:5,**Tablets.** It is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לֻחַת (without a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו' after the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ח') to indicate that they were both of equal [dimensions].

§§—2—§§ 31:18:5,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחת TABLETS — The word is written defectively <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחת (without a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו between <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ח and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת), thus intimating that they were both alike in every respect (Exodus Rabbah 41:6)."

—3— **Tafeln,** steht ohne Waw <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחת, weil beide gleich waren (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:1:1,"**That Moshe was late.** As Onkelos translates it — a term for lateness. Similarly: “[Why] is the rider (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בּשֵׁשׁ) late?” [or:] “They waited until (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בּוֹשׁ) it was late.” For when Moshe ascended the mountain he had told them: “At the end of forty days I will return within [the first] six hours.” They thought that the day that he ascended is included [in the forty days] but, actually, he had told them “<font color=d50505>»</font>full [days]<font color=d50505>«</font>” [i.e.] forty days, each day with its preceding night. But the day that he ascended, its night was not part of it for he ascended on the seventh of Sivan. Consequently the actual 40th day was the seventeenth of Tammuz. On the sixteenth (of Tammuz) the Satan came and caused disorder in the world by creating the appearance of darkness, deep gloom and confusion [so as to lead people] to say: “Moshe has certainly died and therefore the world has been thrown into disorder.” He said to them: “Moshe <font color=d50505>»</font>has<font color=d50505>«</font> died, for six hours have already come and he still has not come, etc.” as is related in Tractate Shabbos. It is impossible to say that their mistake was due only to a cloudy day whether it was before or after noon, for Moshe did not descend until the following day, as it is said: “They arose early the next morning and offered burnt-offerings.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה [AND WHEN THE PEOPLE SAW] THAT MOSES DELAYED LONG — Understand (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשש as the Targum does, as an expression denoting “lateness”.. Similar are: (Judges 5:28) “[Why is] his chariot so long (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשש) [in coming]?”; (Judges 3:25) “And they waited until it was late (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בוש)”. For when Moses ascended the mountain he said to them (to the Israelites): at the end of a period of forty days (i. e. on the fortieth day) I shall return during the first six hours of the day (before noon). They thought that the day on which he ascended the mountain (the seventh of Sivan) was to be included in this number (thus — Sivan having 30 days — he was expected back before noon on the sixteenth of Tammuz). In fact, however, he had said to them “after forty days” meaning complete days — forty days, each day together with its night that precedes it — (as is the customary Jewish reckoning; cf. Genesis 1:5: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקר). Now, as regards the day of this ascent, its night was not part of it that it can be reckoned as a complete day, for he ascended on the seventh of Sivan early in the morning (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 19:3); it follows therefore that the fortieth day really fell on the seventeenth of Tammuz and not as the people had believed on the sixteenth. On the sixteenth of Tammuz Satan came and threw the world into confusion, giving it the appearance of darkness, gloom and disorder that people should say: “Surely Moses is dead, and that is why confusion has come into the world!” He said to them, “Yes, Moses is dead, for six hours (noon) has already come (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשש = ‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שש) and he has not returned etc.” — as is related in Treatise Shabbat 89a (cf. Rashi and Tosafot there and Tosafot on Bava Kamma 82a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ד""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כדי). One cannot, however, say that they erred only on account of it being a cloudy day, their mistake consisting in not being able to distinguish between forenoon and afternoon, and that thus they were correct in their supposition that he was to return on the sixteenth of Tammuz; for this assumes that he really returned on the day when they made the calf, but that they were under the impression that noon was past — for, as a matter of fact, Moses did not come down until the following day (the day after they had made the calf), for it is said (v. 6) “And they rose up early in the morrow, and brought up burnt offerings”— and only after wards the Lord said to Moses (v. 7) “Go, go down; for thy people … have corrupted themselves”."

—3— **32, 1. Dass Mosche zögerte,** wie der Targum sagt, von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איחור Zögern, ebenso (Richt. 5, 28), zögert sein Wagen, (Richt. 3,25) sie warteten, bis sie lange genug gezögert. Denn, als Mosche auf den Berg stieg, sagte er zu ihnen, nach 40 Tagen komme ich wieder in den ersten sechs Stunden des Tages; sie meinten nun, dass der Tag, an dem er hinaufgestiegen war, zur Zahl gehöre; er aber hatte gesagt, volle 40 Tage, die aus Tag und Nacht beständen, während der Tag seines Hinaufsteigens ohne Nacht war; am 7. Siwan stieg er hinauf; es war also der 40. Tag am 17. Tamus; am 16. kam der Verführer und verwirrte die Welt, indem er gleich Dunkel und Finsternis und Verwirrung erscheinen Hess, damit sie sagen sollten, sicherlich ist Mosche gestorben, (darum ist diese Verwirrung in die Welt gekommen; damit sagte er ihnen, Mosche ist gestorben), da die sechs Stunden schon vorüber sind und er nicht gekommen ist… wie im Traktat Sabbat (89a) steht. Man kann aber nicht sagen, dass sie sich nur an einem wolkigen Tage zwischen Vormittag und Nachmittag irrten; denn Mosche kam ja erst am nächsten Tag herab; so steht (V. 6), sie standen am anderen Tag früh auf und brachten Ganzopfer dar. 

---

////—1—//// 32:1:2,**That will lead us.** They yearned to have many gods.

§§—2—§§ 32:1:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילכו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפנינו [MAKE US GODS] WHICH SHALL GO BEFORE US — They wished to have many gods (the words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים is to be taken as plural since the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילכו is plural; cf. Sanhedrin 63a).

—3— **Die vor uns hergehen sollen,** sie wünschten sich viele Götter (Sanhedrin 63a). Denn dieser Mann Mosche; der Verführer zeigte ihnen gleich der Gestalt von Mosche, die man durch die Luft des Himmelsraumes trug. 

---

////—1—//// 32:1:3,"**For this Moshe, the man.** The Satan showed them a likeness of Moshe being carried in the air high in the sky. "

§§—2—§§ 32:1:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האיש FOR AS FOR THIS MOSES — This Moses implies that Satan showed them something that looked like Moses being carried on a bier in the air high above in the skies (cf. Shabbat 89a).

—3— **Der uns aus dem Lande Mizraim heraufgeführt,** und uns den Weg zeigte, den wir gehen sollten; nun brauchen wir Götter, die vor uns hergehen sollen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:1:4,**Who brought us up from the land of Egypt —** and taught us the way to go; now we need gods who will go before us.

§§—2—§§ 32:1:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העלנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מצרים [THAT MAN] THAT BROUGHT US UP OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT, and who used to show us the way we had to go; now that he is dead we need gods which shall go before us."


---

////—1—//// 32:2:1,"**On the ears of your wives.** Aharon thought to himself: the women and children fancy their jewelry, perhaps, [as a result], the thing will be delayed and in the meantime Moshe will arrive. But they did not wait [for the women and children] and took off [their own jewelry] from themselves. "

§§—2—§§ 32:2:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באזני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשיכם [BREAK OFF THE GOLDEN PENDANTS], WHICH ARE IN THE EARS OF YOUR WIVES — Aaron said to himself: women and children have a love for their ornaments; perhaps the matter will be delayed because they will hesitate to give their ornaments, and in the meantime Moses may arrive. They (the men), however, did not wait until the women and children made up their minds but they took the ornaments off themselves (cf. v. 3: they took off the pendants which were in their ears; there is no reference to the pendants belonging to the women) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 21)."

—3— **2. In den Ohren eurer Frauen,** Aharon dachte in seinem Herzen, die Frauen und die Kinder hängen an ihrem Schmuck; vielleicht wird die Sache dadurch verzögert werden und inzwischen Mosche kommen, sie aber warteten nicht und nahmen sie von sich selbst ab (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:2:2,**Remove.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּרְקוּ is a plural imperative (a command) derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פָּרֵק in the singular as in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּרְכוּ derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּרֵךְ .

§§—2—§§ 32:2:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרקו is an imperative plural derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרק which is used for the singular, just as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּרְכוּ is derived from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּרֵךְ‎ (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרקו and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברכו are both masculine imperative Piel)."

—3— **Nehmet ab,** ist die Befehlsform von einer Form <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרק in der Einzahl, wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברכו von einer Form . <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברך

---

////—1—//// 32:3:1,"**They removed.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִתְפָּרְקוּ] has the meaning of unloading a burden, for when they removed them from their ears they became “unloaded” of their rings, <font color=d50505>»</font>descharjier<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 32:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתפרקו AND [ALL THE PEOPLE] BRAKE OFF — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרק is a term denoting “unloading a burden”. Being a transitive verb one would expect <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויפרקו instead of the reflexive form <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויפרקו but when they took them (the pendants) off their ears they themselves became unloaded from their pendants and therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתפרקו “they unloaded themselves”, is the appropriate word to use; décharger in old French, English discharge."

—3— **3. Nahm sich ab,** bedeutet eine Last abladen; als sie sie aus ihren Ohren genommen hatten, waren sie von der Last ihrer Ringe befreit, entlastet in andere Sprachen <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנזמי = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נזמי, wie (9, 29), wenn ich die Stadt verlasse = . <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיר

---

////—1—//// 32:3:2,"** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִזְמֵי .** As if it were: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִנִּזְמֵי — “of the rings,” as in: “As soon as I go out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעִיר)” [meaning:] (from) of the city. "

§§—2—§§ 32:3:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נזמי is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מנזמי, (they unloaded themselves from their pendants), (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את having the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן), similar to (Exodus 9:29) “As soon as I am gone out <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיר”, which means <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העיר, from the city."


---

////—1—//// 32:4:1,"**And formed it with an engraving tool.** This can be translated two ways: The first: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּצַר as a term for tying and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֶרֶט as a term for a cloth, as in: “the shawls (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַחֲרִיטִים) and the cloths,” [or:] “He tied two <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> of silver in two (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֲרִיטִים) cloths.” The second: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּצַר as a term for forming images; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֶרֶט, a tool used by goldsmiths with which they scrape and engrave images into gold, like the stylus of a scribe who engraves letters onto tablets and ledgers, as in: “And write on it with a man’s (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּחֶרֶט) stylus.” This was Onkelos’ intent when he translated it: “He engraved it with a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִיפָא, from the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִיּוּף — “forgery.” It is a tool for engraving letters and designs in gold, referred to in Old French as <font color=d50505>»</font>neel,<font color=d50505>«</font> and through it seals can be forged. "

§§—2—§§ 32:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרט — One can translate this in two ways. The one is: to take <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר in the sense of “tying up” (Hiphil of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צרר) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרט in the sense of “a garment”, similar to (Isaiah 3:22) “and the mantles and the scarfs (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והחריטים)”; ‎(2 Kings 5:23) “and bound (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר) two talents of silver in two cloths (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חריטים)”. The other way is: to take <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר in the sense of “forming figures” (Hiphil of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צור) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרם as denoting goldsmiths’ tool with which they engrave and cut figures into gold, like a writer’s stylus that incises letters on boards and tablets, as we find it in, (Isaiah 8:1) ‘‘[Take a great roll] and write on it with a man’s pen (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרט)”. This (the second explanation) is what Onkelos means when he renders the passage by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וצר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בזיפא and he formed it with a “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זיפא”, a term which is connected with the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זיוף “forgery”. It is a tool with which letters and modelled figures are engraved in gold — a kind of work which they term niel in old French (cf. Rashi and our Note on Exodus 25:33), and by means of which seals are forged (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזיפין)‎."

—3— **4. Er formte es mit dem Meissei;** das kann man auf zwei Weisen übersetzen, die eine ist, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר in der Bedeutung einbinden und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרט in der Bedeutung Tuch zu nehmen, wie (Jes. 3, 22), die Bänder und Tücher, (II Kön. 5, 23) und er band zwei Talente Silber in zwei Tücher ein; und die andere ist, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצר in der Bedeutung formen und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחרט als Handwerksgerät der Goldschmiede, mit dem sie Formen ins Gold schneiden und meissein, gleich dem Stift des Schreibers, der Buchstaben auf Tafeln und Wachstäfelchen eingräbt; wie (Jes. 8, 1), und schreibe darauf mit Menschengriffel; so übersetzt auch Onkelos, er formte es mit dem Meissei; das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זייף bedeutet ein Handwerksgerät, mit dem man Buchstaben und Figuren ins Gold einschneidet, was man in anderen Sprachen gravieren nennt; man sticht auch damit Siegel. 

---

////—1—//// 32:4:2,"**A molten calf.** As soon as he threw it into the fire, in a melting pot, the magicians of the riffraff came — those who went up with them from Egypt — and made it (the Calf) by means of magic. Some say that Michah was there for he had come out of the foundations of a building into which he had been crushed in Egypt. He had in his hand an amulet and a plate onto which Moshe had written: “Arise ox! Arise ox!,” with which to bring up Yoseif’s bier from the Nile, and he (Michah) threw it into the melting pot and out came the Calf. "

§§—2—§§ 32:4:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עגל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכה A MOLTEN CALF — As soon as he (Aaron) had thrown it (the gold) into the fire in a melting pot the magicians amongst the mixed multitude who had come up with them from Egypt came and made it (the golden calf) by their magic art. There are some who say that Micah the idolator mentioned in Judges ch. 17, was there, who had been drawn forth from the foundations of a building in Egypt where he was nearly crushed. He had in his possession a “supernatural name” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם) and a plate upon which Moses had written: “Come up, ox, come up, ox!” in order to raise the coffin of Joseph who is compared to an ox (cf. Deuteronomy 33:17) out of the Nile, and he cast it (the plate) into the melting pot and the calf (the young ox) came out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העגל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 19)."

—3— **Ein gegossenes Kalb,** als er es im Feuer in den Tiegel geworfen hatte, kamen Zauberer des Mischvolkes, das mit ihnen aus Ägypten heraufgezogen war, und machten mit Zauberei ein Kalb; manche sagen, Micha war dort, der aus den Reihen des Baues, in den er in Ägypten schon hineingedrückt worden, herausgezogen worden war; er besaß den Schern und die Tafel, auf welche Mosche geschrieben, steige empor, Stier, steige empor, Stier, um den Sarg von Josef aus dem Nil emporsteigen zu machen; sie warf er in den Tiegel, und da ging das Kalb daraus hervor. (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:4:3,"**Molten.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסֵּכָה is] a word that relates to metal. An alternate explanation [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסֵּכָה]: There were 125 <font color=d50505>»</font>kikars<font color=d50505>«</font> of gold in it (the Calf), equal to the <font color=d50505>»</font>gematria<font color=d50505>«</font> (the numerical value) of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסֵּכָה . "

§§—2—§§ 32:4:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכה MOLTEN is a term connected with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתכת, molten metal (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ס and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת being interchanged in these words). Another explanation is: there were used in it (for making the golden calf) 125 talents of gold, corresponding to the numerical value of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכה, which is 125 (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 19)."

—3— **Aus Guss,** bedeutet Metallguss; andere Erklärung: 125 Talente Gold waren daran gleich dem Zahlenwert von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסכה (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:4:4,"**These are your Gods.** It does not say: These are <font color=d50505>»</font>our<font color=d50505>«</font> gods. From this [we derive] that the riffraff that came up from Egypt were the ones that gathered against Aharon and were the ones that made it (the Calf), and afterwards misled the Israelites to follow it. "

§§—2—§§ 32:4:4,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהיך THESE ARE THY GODS, [O ISRAEL] — It does not state that they said “these are our gods, [O Israel]”; hence we may learn that it was the mixed multitude which came up from Egypt that gathered themselves together against Aaron, and it was they who made it and afterwards led Israel astray after it (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 19)."

—3— **Dies sind deine Götter,** und es steht nicht, dies sind unsere Götter; daraus geht hervor, dass das Mischvolk, das aus Ägypten heraufgezogen war, sich um Aharon versammelt hatte; sie hatten es gemacht und verführten dann Israel, ihm zu dienen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:5:1,"**Aharon saw —** that it was alive as it is said [of the Golden Calf]: “in the form of an ox eating grass,” and he thereby saw that the Satan’s act succeeded and therefore had no excuse to put them off completely. "

§§—2—§§ 32:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן AND WHEN AARON SAW that there was the breath of life in it — as it is said with reference to the golden calf, (Psalms 106:20) “[They changed their glory] into a similitude of an ox that ate grass” — and he realized that Satan’s work had succeeded and that he had no argument (lit., mouth) to put them (the people) entirely off."

—3— **5. Da sah Aharon,** dass Lebensodem in ihm war; so steht (Ps. 106, 20), mit dem Bilde eines grasfressenden Stieres; und er sah, dass das Werk des Verführers gelungen war, da hatte er keine Worte, um sie ganz abzuweisen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:5:2,**He built an altar —** so as to stall them.

§§—2—§§ 32:5:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבח HE BUILDED AN ALTAR to put them off.

—3— **Und er baute einen Altar,** um sie hinzuhalten. 

---

////—1—//// 32:5:3,"**And he said, tomorrow will be a festival to Adonoy.** But [he did not say] “today,” in case Moshe would return before they worship it. That is its plain meaning. But its midrashic explanation is in Vayikra Rabbah: [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּרְא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אַהֲרֹן] Aharon saw many things: he saw that when his nephew, Chur, reprimanded them, they killed him [and accordingly] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיִּבֶן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִזְבֵּחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְפָנָיו [should be understood as:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָּבֶן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִזָּבוּחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְפָנָיו — “He understood from the one slaughtered before him.” He also saw [the situation] and he said: Better the blame be put on me and not on them. He saw yet another thing and he said: “If <font color=d50505>»</font>they<font color=d50505>«</font> build the altar, themselves, one will bring a chip of wood and another will bring a stone, resulting in their work being completed all at once. But through <font color=d50505>»</font>my<font color=d50505>«</font> building it and procrastinating in my work, in the meantime Moshe will come.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:5:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחר AND CALLED OUT … TO-MORROW IS A FESTIVAL TO THE LORD — to-morrow, not to-day, for he hoped that Moses might return before they would worship it (the calf). This is the plain meaning of the verse. The Midrashic explanation of it in Leviticus Rabbah 10:3 (— it supplies an object to the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא —) is: Aaron saw many things; he saw Hur, his sister’s son, who had reprimanded them, and whom they had killed. This is the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויבן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבח, viz., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיָבֶן, he realized (taking the word as from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בון, to understand, to realize) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִזָּבוּחַ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפניו from him who lay slaughtered before him (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבח is vowelled to be read as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִזָּבוּחַ) what would happen to him if he offered resistance. A further explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהרן in the Midrash is: He saw what the situation was and said: It is better that the offence should attach itself to me than to them. And yet a further Midrashic explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירא is: He looked into the matter and said: If they build this altar themselves, one will bring a clod and another a stone and the result will be that their work will be accomplished all at once; through myself building it and being dilatory in my work, in the meantime Moses may come."

—3— **Und rief, morgen wird ein Fest dem Ewigen sein,** und nicht heute, vielleicht würde Mosche kommen, bevor sie es anbeteten; dies ist die einfache Erklärung; der Midrasch Waj. rab. (10) sagt, viele Dinge sah Aharon, er sah Chur, den Sohn seiner Schwester, dass er sie zurechtwies und sie ihn töteten; das bedeutet <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויכן, er erkannte <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבוח = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבח aus dem vor ihm Getöteten; ferner sah er und sagte, besser, dass die Sünde mir zur Last gelegt werde als ihnen; ferner sah er und sagte, wenn sie diesen Altar bauen, bringt der eine eine Erdscholle, und der andere einen Stein; und es findet sich, dass ihre Arbeit auf einmal gemacht wird; dadurch aber, dass ich ihn baue und bei meiner Arbeit langsam sein werde, wird inzwischen Mosche kommen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:5:4,**A festival to Adonoy.** In his heart it was to God. He was confident that Moshe would arrive and that they would worship God.

§§—2—§§ 32:5:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לה׳ A FESTIVAL TO THE LORD — not to the golden calf. In his heart it (the feast) was for Heaven (the Lord). He felt confident that Moses would return by the morrow and that they would worship the Omnipresent (Leviticus Rabbah 10:3).

—3— **Ein Fest dem Ewigen,** in seinem Herzen meinte er für den Ewigen; indem er darauf vertraute, dass Mosche kommen würde und sie dem Ewigen dienen würden. 

---

////—1—//// 32:6:1,**They arose early.** The Satan hurried them for the purpose of sinning.

§§—2—§§ 32:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישכימו AND THEY ROSE UP EARLY [IN THE MORNING] — Satan made them zealous in order that they might sin, for later on in the forenoon Moses actually came down from the mountain."

—3— **6. Sie standen früh auf,** der Verführer trieb sie an, damit sie sündigten. 

---

////—1—//// 32:6:2,"**To amuse themselves.** There is the implication [in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְצַחֵק] of sexual immorality, as it is said: “to mock me” (Potiphar’s wife’s accusation against Yosef) and of bloodshed, as it is said: “Let the lads arise and ‘play’ before us.” Here, too, [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְצַחֵק alludes to] Chur’s being killed. "

§§—2—§§ 32:6:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לצחק TO PLAY — There is implied in this term besides idolatry also sexual immorality, — as we find the word used in, (Genesis 39:17) “to mock (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לצחק) me” where unchastity is meant as is evident from the context — and blood-shed, as it is said, (II Samuel 2:14) “Let the young men arise and play (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישחקו) before me; [and they caught every one his fellow by the head and thrust his sword in his fellows side]”— here, too, Hur was assassinated (Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:20)."

—3— **Um zu scherzen,** in diesem Worte ist sittliche Entartung enthalten, wie es heißt (Gen. 39, 17), mit mir Spott zu treiben; und Blutvergießen, wie es heißt (II Sam. 2, 14), mögen sich doch die Jünglinge erheben und vor uns ein Spiel aufführen; auch hier wurde Chur getötet (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:7:1,**[Adonoy] spoke.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְדַבֵּר] is a term of harshness as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיְדַבֵּר) He spoke with them harshly.”

§§—2—§§ 32:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידבר AND [THE LORD] SAID — This term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר when not followed by a word of the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר implies censorious speech, as (Genesis 42:7) “And he spake (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידבר) roughly (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשות) unto them”."

—3— **7. Sprach,** bedeutet Strenge wie (Gen. 42, 7), er sprach streng mit ihnen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:7:2,"**“Go down.”** I.e., “Descend from your exalted position. I did not give you your high position except for their sake.” At that moment Moshe was ostracized by the Heavenly Court. "

§§—2—§§ 32:7:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רד GO, GO DOWN from your high position; I have given you distinction only for their sake! (Berakhot 32a). At that moment Moses was excommunicated by a decree of the heavenly court (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 22)."

—3— **Geh, steige hinab,** ich habe dir die Würde nur um ihretwillen verliehen; in jener Stunde wurde über Mosche vom Gerichtshof im Himmel der Bann ausgesprochen (Ber. 32b). 

---

////—1—//// 32:7:3,"**Your people have become corrupt.** It is not said: “the people have become corrupt,” but, rather: “<font color=d50505>»</font>your<font color=d50505>«</font> people” — the riffraff whom you accepted, on your own accord, and you accepted as proselytes without consulting Me, and you thought it good that proselytes be joined to the Shechinah — they have become corrupt and have corrupted others. "

§§—2—§§ 32:7:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמך THY PEOPLE HAVE CORRUPTED THEMSELVES — It does not say the people have corrupted but “thy” people — the mixed multitude whom you received of your own accord and accepted as proselytes without consulting Me. You thought it a good thing that proselytes should be attached to the Shechina — now they have corrupted themselves and have corrupted others (Exodus Rabbah 42:6).

—3— **Dein Volk ist verderbt,** das Volk ist verderbt, steht nicht, sondern dein Volk, das Mischvolk, das du von dir selbst mitgenommen und ins jüdische Volk aufgenommen hast, ohne mich zu fragen, indem du sagtest, es sei gut, wenn sich Fremde der Schechina anschlössen; sie verdarben und verdarben andere (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:9:1,**Stiff-necked.** So-called because they turn their stiff necks towards those who reprimand them and refuse to listen.

§§—2—§§ 32:9:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערף STIFF-NECKED — They turn their stiffened necks towards those who reprove them (i e. they turn their back upon them) and refuse to listen.

—3— **9. Hartnäckig,** sie werden ihren harten Nacken denen zu, die sie zurechtweisen, und weigern sich zu hören. 

---

////—1—//// 32:10:1,"**Leave Me alone.** We have not yet heard of Moshe praying for them and already He has said, “Leave me alone”?! But He thereby gave him an opening and let him know that the matter depends on him, that if he will pray for them He will not destroy them. "

§§—2—§§ 32:10:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הניחה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לי LET ME ALONE — So far we have not heard that Moses had prayed on their behalf and yet He says “let Me alone!” which implies a refusal to his entreaty! But by saying this He opened the door to him (offered him a suggestion) intimating to him that if he prayed for them He would not destroy them (Shemot Rabbah 42:9; cf. also Berakhot 32a).

—3— **10. Lass ab von mir;** wir haben noch nicht gehört, dass Mosche für sie betete, und Er sagt, lass ab von mir; nur damit öffnete Er ihm eine Tür und tat ihm kund, dass die Sache von ihm abhänge; wenn er für sie beten würde, so würde Er sie nicht aufreiben (Tanchuma; Ber. 32a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:11:1,"**“Adonoy! Why,” etc.** Can there be a thought of jealousy, unless it is a wise man of a wise man or a powerful man of a powerful man. "

§§—2—§§ 32:11:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה‘ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יחרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפך WHEREFORE, O LORD, DOTH THY WRATH GLOW [AGAINST THY PEOPLE] — Does anyone become jealous of another, except a wise man of a wise man or a hero of a hero?! (Avodah Zarah 55a)"

—3— **11. Warum, Ewiger, entbrennt dein Zorn,** es ereifert sich doch nur ein Weiser über einen Weisen, ein Held über einen Helden (Abod. zar. 55a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:12:1,"**And reconsider.** I.e., formulate another plan to do good to them. "

§§—2—§§ 32:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנחם AND REPENT — form another resolution, viz., to do them good,"

—3— **12. Und nimm zurück,** fasse einen neuen Entschluss, ihnen Gutes zu tun. 

---

////—1—//// 32:12:2,**The evil —** that You had planned for them.

§§—2—§§ 32:12:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרעה INSTEAD OF THE EVIL You have thought to bring upon them.

—3— **Das Böse,** das du über sie beschlossen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:13:1,"**Remember Avraham.** If they transgressed the Ten Commandments, their father Avraham was tested through ten tests, and has not yet received his reward, give it to him [now] and let the “ten” offset the “ten.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:13:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאברהם (lit., remember for Abraham) — If they have transgressed the Ten Commandments, their father Abraham was tried by ten trials and has not yet received his reward for them. Give it to him now — remember for him this merit — and let the ten trials he successfully withstood countervail the infringement of the Ten Commandments (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 24; Shemot Rabbah 44:4)."

—3— **13. Gedenke Abrahams;** wenn sie die zehn Gebote übertreten haben, so ist ihr Stammvater Abraham mit zehn Prüfungen geprüft worden und hat seinen Lohn noch nicht erhalten; gib ihn ihm, dass die zehn durch die zehn ausgeglichen werden (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:13:2,"**Avraham, Yitzchok and Yisrael.** If [their punishment is to be] by burning then remember Avraham who offered himself to be burnt for Your sake in Ur Kasdim. If [it is to be] by the sword, then remember Yitzchok who stretched forth his neck at the “binding.” If [it is to be] through exile, then remember Yaakov who went into exile to Charan. And if they cannot be saved by their [forefathers’] merit, then what is this that You tell me: “I will make you into a great nation”? If a chair with three legs cannot stand before You at the time of Your anger [then this is] certainly [true] of a chair with one leg. "

§§—2—§§ 32:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאברהם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ליצחק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולישראל REMEMBER FOR ABRAHAM, FOR ISAAC, AND FOR ISRAEL — If they are to be punished with death by burning, remember for Abraham his merit that he gave himself over to be burnt for Your sake (for the sanctification of the Divine Name) in Ur (in the fire) of the Chaldees; if with death by the sword, remember for Isaac the merit that he stretched forth his neck to the knife on the occasion of the “Binding”. If by exile, remember for Jacob the merit that he went into exile to Haran (leaving the paternal roof in order to fulfil his father’s command). If, however, they cannot be saved by their ancestors merit what is the good of You saying to me, “and I will make of thee a great nation”? — if a chair with three legs (the merits of the three patriarchs) cannot stand before You in the moment of Your wrath, how much the less a chair with only one leg (the merits of myself alone) (Berakhot 32a)."

—3— **Abrahams, Isaaks, und Israels,** wenn sie den Feuertod verdient haben, so gedenke Abrahams, der sich selbst hingab, sich für dich in Ur Kasdim verbrennen zu lassen; wenn sie den Tod durchs Schwert verdient haben, so gedenke Isaaks, der seinen Hals der Opferung darbot; wenn sie in die Verbannung sollen, so gedenke Jaakobs, der nach Charan auswandern musste; wenn sie aber ob ihrer Frömmigkeit nicht gerettet werden, warum sagst du zu mir, ich werde dich zu einem großen Volke machen; wenn ein Thron mit drei Füßen keinen Bestand hat vor dir in der Stunde deines Zornes, wieviel weniger ein Thron mit nur einem Fuß (Ber. 32a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:13:3,"**To whom You swore by Your self.** You did not swear to them by something that is finite — neither by the heavens, nor by the earth, neither by the mountains, nor the hills, but only by Your Self. Who is eternal, and Your oath remains forever, as it is said: “‘By My Self I have sworn,’ says God.” To Yitzchok it was said: “I will establish the [same] oath that I swore to Avraham, your father.” And to Yaakov it was said: “I am God Almighty, be fruitful and multiply.” Thus He swore to him by “God Almighty.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:13:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשבעת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בך TO WHOM THOU SWAREST BY THINE OWN SELF — Thou didst not swear to them by a thing which is perishable — neither by the heavens nor by the earth, nor by the mountains, nor by the hills — but by Thy very Self, Who endurest forever and Whose oath endures for ever. For it is stated that God said to Abraham, (Genesis 22:16, 17) “By Myself have I sworn saith the Lord … [I will greatly multiply thy seed]”; to Isaac it was said, (Genesis 26:3, 4) “and I will perform the oath which I sware by Myself unto Abraham thy father … [and I will multiply thy seed]”; and to Jacob it was said, (Genesis 35:11) “I am God Almighty, be fruitful and multiply”; thus to him also God swore by Himself — by God Almighty (Shemot Rabbah 44:23)."

—3— **Denen du bei dir zugeschworen,** du hast ihnen nicht bei einer Sache zugeschworen, die vergeht, nicht beim Himmel und nicht bei der Erde, nicht bei den Bergen und nicht bei den Hügeln, sondern bei dir, der du ewig bestehst und dessen Schwur ewig besteht; so heißt es (Gen. 22,16), bei mir habe ich geschworen, ist der Ausspruch des Ewigen, und bei Isaak steht (Gen. 26, 3), und ich erfülle den Schwur, den ich deinem Vater Abraham geschworen habe, und zu Jaakob wurde gesagt (Gen. 35, 11), ich bin der allmächtige Gott, sei fruchtbar und mehre dich, Er schwur ihm zu als der allmächtige Gott (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 32:15:1,"**On both sides —** were the letters readable, and it was a work of miracles. "

§§—2—§§ 32:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עבריהם ON BOTH THEIR SIDES could the letters be read, and this constituted a miraculous piece of work (Shabbat 104a)."

—3— **15. Von ihren beiden Seiten,** konnten die Buchstaben gelesen werden; sie waren ein Wunderwerk (Schabbat 104a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:16:1,"**They were the work of God.** As it implies: He (God) Himself in His Glory made them. An alternate explanation: It is analogous to a person who tells his friend, “All the occupation of so-and-so is with that particular work.” So too is all the preoccupation of God with the Torah. "

§§—2—§§ 32:16:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המה [THE TABLETS WERE] THE WORK OF GOD — This means what it literally implies: God Himself (Hebrew: in His glory) made them. Another explanation (taking <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מעשה in the sense of “occupation”) is: Just as a man says to his fellow, “All that Mr. So-and-so occupies himself with is only with such-and-such a work”, so is the delight of the Holy One, blessed be He, confined to the Torah alone (cf. Proverbs 8:31 the whole of which chapter is taken as a description of God’s relation to the Torah) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 16)."

—3— **16. Waren das Werk Gottes;** wie der einfache Sinn ist, Er selbst in seiner Majestät hatte sie gebildet. Andere Erklärung: wie wenn einer zum anderen sagt, die ganze Beschäftigung von dem und dem ist mit der und der Arbeit; so ist die ganze Freude des Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, an der Torah. 

---

////—1—//// 32:16:2,"**Engraved.** The words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרֹת and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָרֹט are the same, both being terms for engraving, <font color=d50505>»</font>enteillier<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. "

§§—2—§§ 32:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרות — The expressions <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרת (which occurs only here in Scriptures) and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרט have the same meaning, both of them signifying engraving; entailler in old French"

—3— **Eingegraben,** die Wurzeln <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרת und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חרט bedeuten dasselbe; beide bedeuten eingraben, einschneiden in anderen Sprachen.

////—1—//// 32:17:1,"**Rejoicing.** [Meaning:] trumpeting — for they were blowing horns, rejoicing and laughing. "

§§—2—§§ 32:17:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברעה means WHEN THEY WERE SHOUTING for they were shouting for joy and making merry.

—3— **17. Bei seinem Jubel,** bei seinem Jauchzen, sie jubelten, freuten sich und lachten.

////—1—//// 32:18:1,"**It is not the sound of strength.** This sound seems neither the shout of the mighty, who cry out, “Victory”! nor the sound of the weak who cry out, “Woe”! or, “Let us flee”! [but, rather —] "

§§—2—§§ 32:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קול <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ענות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גבורה IT IS NOT THE VOICE OF THE CRY OF MASTERY —This sound does not seem to be the sound of the utterance of victors who cry, “Victory!” nor is it the sound of the defeated who cry, “Alas — let me flee!”."

—3— **18. Das ist nicht die Stimme, die Sieg verkündet,** diese Stimme scheint nicht die Stimme zu sein, wie sie Helden erheben, wenn sie den Sieg ausrufen, und auch nicht die Stimme von Schwachen, die «Wehe» oder «Flieht!» rufen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:18:2,"**A sound of song.** I.e., a sound of defamations and blasphemies (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַמְּעַנִּין) which torment the soul of those who hear them when they are related to him. "

§§—2—§§ 32:18:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קול <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ענות means, the sound of blasphemy and cursing (Shemot Rabbah 41:1) which distress (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַנֵּה to vex, to grieve) the soul of him who hears them — even when they are only related to him."

—3— **Eine Stimme, die mit Kränkung erfüllt,** eine Stimme der Lästerung und der Schmähung, welche die Seele der Hörenden, zu denen sie gesprochen werden, kränken.

////—1—//// 32:19:1,"**And he threw down from his hands, etc.** He thought to himself: Just as the <font color=d50505>»</font>korbon Pesach,<font color=d50505>«</font> which is just one of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> [of the Torah], yet the Torah says: “No stranger may eat from it”; but the entire Torah is here [on the Tablets] and all the Israelites have become apostates, how can I conceivably give it to them?! "

§§—2—§§ 32:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישלך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מידו AND HE CAST [THE TABLETS] OUT OF HIS HAND — He said: “What is the law regarding the Paschal lamb which is only one of the commandments? The Torah states: (Exodus 12:43) “No stranger shall eat thereof”! (cf. Rashi on that verse: a stranger means one who has enstranged himself by his doings from his Father in heaven — an apostate). “But the whole Torah is here (written on the tablets) and all the Israelites are apostates, can I possibly give it (the Torah) to them?!” (Shabbat 87a)."

—3— **19. Und er warf aus seinen Händen,** indem er sagte, wenn schon beim Pessachopfer, das nur eines von den Geboten ist, die Torah gesagt hat (12, 43), jeder Entfremdete esse nicht davon, hier, da ich die ganze Torah habe und ganz Israel abtrünnig ist, sollte ich sie ihnen geben ! (Schabbat 87a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:19:2,"**Beneath the mountain.** [I.e.,] at the foot of the mountain. "

§§—2—§§ 32:19:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תחת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ההר BENEATH THE MOUNTAIN — i. e. at the foot of the mountain.

—3— **Unten am Berg,** am Fuße des Berges. 

---

////—1—//// 32:20:1,"**He scattered it.** A term meaning scattering. Similarly “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְזוֹרֶה) there shall be scattered on his dwelling place, brimstone.” And similarly: “For naught (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְזוֹרָה) is the net spread out” [so called] because grain and beans are scattered in it. "

§§—2—§§ 32:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויזר AND STREWED IT — The verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זרה denotes scattering about, similar to, (Job 18:15) “Brimstone shall be scattered (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יזרה) upon his habitation”; (Proverbs 1:17) “Surely in vain the net is strewn (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזורה) [in the sight of any bird]” where this expression is used because people usually bestrew it (the net) with grain and pulse."

—3— **20. Und streute es,** bedeutet zerstreuen; ebenso (Job 18, 15), auf seine Stätte wird Schwefel gestreut; ebenso (Spr. 1,17) denn umsonst ist das Netz bestreut, in das man Getreide und Hülsenfrüchte streut. 

---

////—1—//// 32:20:2,"**And made the B’nei Yisrael drink it.** He intended to test them [in the same manner] as are women suspected of adultery. Three different death penalties were inflicted there: [1.] if there were witnesses and a warning [to the sinner] — by the sword, the same as an idolatrous city, when there are many involved. [2.] If there were witnesses but no warning — by the plague, as it is said: “God struck the people with a plague.” [3.] If there were no witnesses and no warning — by swelling up, for the water tested them and their stomachs swelled up. "

§§—2—§§ 32:20:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וישק <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל AND HE GAVE THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL TO DRINK OF IT — He intended to put them to the test as faithless wives were tried (cf. Numbers 5:12—31) (Avodah Zarah 44a). Three different death-penalties were inflicted there: It there were witnesses to the act of idolatry and a legal warning had preceded the deed the offender was put to death by the sword (cf. vv. 27, 28) as was the regulation regarding the inhabitants of an apostate city (Deuteronomy 13:13—18) when there were many (as was the case here; a single idolator, however, was subject to the death by stoning; cf. Deuteronomy 17:2—5). If there were witnesses but there had been no caution, they were destroyed by the plague, as it is said, (v. 35) “And the Lord plagued the people”. In cases where there were neither witnesses nor warning they were punished by dropsy — for the water which Moses gave them to drink put them to the test and if they were guilty their bellies swelled (cf. Yoma 66b)."

—3— **Und ließ die Kinder Israel davon trinken,** seine Absicht war, sie wie ungetreue Frauen (Num. 5) zu prüfen (Ab. zar. 44a); drei Todesstrafen wurden dort verhängt; wenn Zeugen und Warnung vorhanden gewesen, mit dem Schwert, gleich dem Gesetz für die Leute einer verführten Stadt (Deut. 13, 16), die viele sind; Zeugen, aber keine Warnung, durch die Seuche, so steht (V. 35), und der Ewige schlug das Volk; weder Zeugen noch Warnung, durch Wassersucht, das Wasser prüfte sie, dass ihre Leiber anschwollen (Joma 66b). 

---

////—1—//// 32:21:1,**What did this people do to you.** How much pain did you endure that they tortured you before you brought this sin on them?

§§—2—§§ 32:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה WHAT DID THIS PEOPLE UNTO THEE How many pains must you have endured — it must be that they inflicted suffering on you, before you brought this sin upon them!"

—3— **21. Was hat dir dies Volk getan,** wieviel Schmerzen, die sie dir bereitet haben, hast du wohl ertragen, bevor du diese Sünde über sie gebracht hast. 

---

////—1—//// 32:22:1,**That [the people] are set on evil.** They are always going on an evil way with temptations before God.

§§—2—§§ 32:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוא [THOU KNOWEST THE PEOPLE] THAT THEY ARE SET ON EVIL — They always go on the wrong way and with temptations, before the Omnipresent."

—3— **22. Dass es dem Bösen zuneigt,** sie gehen immer den bösen Weg und voll Versuchungen vor dem Ewigen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:24:1,**I said to them.** I said one thing to them — only: “Who has gold”? and they hurriedly removed it and gave it to me.

§§—2—§§ 32:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>להם AND I SAID UNTO THEM one single thing, — simply, “Who has any gold?” — but they hastened and broke it off from themselves and gave it to me."

—3— **24. Und ich sagte zu ihnen,** nur ein einziges Wort, wer hat Gold? Da eilten sie, nahmen es von sich ab und gaben es mir. 

---

////—1—//// 32:24:2,**I threw it into the fire —** and I did not know that this calf would come out and it <font color=d50505>»</font>did<font color=d50505>«</font> come out.

§§—2—§§ 32:24:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואשלכהו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באש AND I CAST IT INTO THE FIRE, and I did not know that this (i. e. this living) calf would come out, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויצא — BUT IT DID COME OUT."

—3— **Und ich warf es ins Feuer,** ich wusste nicht, dass dies Kalb entstehen würde, es entstand aber. 

---

////—1—//// 32:25:1,"**Exposed.** [Meaning:] exposed — its shame and disgrace were exposed, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפָרַע) He shall expose the head of the woman.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:25:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרע means UNCOVERED — its (the people’s) shame and disgrace were revealed; the word has the same meaning as in (Numbers 5:18) “[and the priest shall uncover (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ופרע) the woman’s head”.

—3— **25. Verwildert,** entblösst, seine Verfehlung und seine Schande waren enthüllt; wie (Num. 5, 8), er entblösse das Haupthaar der Frau. 

---

////—1—//// 32:25:2,**Disgraced among their adversaries.** [Meaning:] that this matter shall be a disgrace for them before all who rise up against them.

§§—2—§§ 32:25:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשמצה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקמיהם means, that this thing would become an ignominy for them in the mouth of all who will rise against them."

—3— **Zur Schande bei ihren Widersachern,** dass ihnen diese Sache zur Schande werde im Munde aller, die sich gegen sie erheben. 

---

////—1—//// 32:26:1,"**“Whoever is for Adonoy, to me”!** I.e., “Come to me.” "

§§—2—§§ 32:26:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי means, WHOEVER IS FOR THE LORD let him come TO ME."

—3— **26. Wer dem Ewigen angehört, zu mir,** komme zu mir. 

---

////—1—//// 32:26:2,**All the sons of Leivi.** From here it is derived that the entire Tribe was righteous.

§§—2—§§ 32:26:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לוי ALL THE SONS OF LEVI — All the sons — from this we may gather that all the tribe of Levi remained worthy men (consequently “slay every man his brother” in the next verse can refer only to one who was his brother from the same mother, as explained by Rashi there) (Yoma 66b)."

—3— **Alle Söhne Levis,** daraus geht hervor, dass der ganze Stamm fromm war (Jom. 66b). 

---

////—1—//// 32:27:1,"**This is what Adonoy said, etc.** Where [did God tell him] this? “He who sacrifices to a god must be condemned to die.” This is how this is presented in Mechilta. "

§§—2—§§ 32:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THUS SAITH THE LORD etc. — Where did he say so? In the command, (Exodus 22:19) “He that sacrificeth unto any god shall utterly be destroyed”. Thus is it stated in the Mechilta."

—3— **27. So hat gesprochen,** und wo hat Er so gesprochen? (22, 19), wer Göttern opfert, soll getötet werden; so steht in der Mechilta. 

---

////—1—//// 32:27:2,"**His brother —** having a common mother, and he (the brother) is an Israelite. "

§§—2—§§ 32:27:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחיו HIS BROTHER from the same mother, but from a different father, and who was therefore an ordinary Israelite and not a Levite (Yoma 66b)."

—3— **Seinen Bruder,** von der Mutter, der ein Israelite (und kein Levi) ist.

////—1—//// 32:29:1,"**Consecrate yourselves —** you who kill them, by this act you will install yourselves as <font color=d50505>»</font>kohanim<font color=d50505>«</font> to God. "

§§—2—§§ 32:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידכם CONSECRATE YOURSELVES — You who are killing them (your own relatives) will by this very act install yourselves as priests of the Omnipresent God,"

—3— **29. Weihet euch,** ihr, die ihr sie tötet, dadurch werdet ihr geweiht, Priester dem Ewigen zu sein. 

---

////—1—//// 32:29:2,**For each man — **Amongst you will be installed [as a result of what each did] to his son and brother.

§§—2—§§ 32:29:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש FOR EVERY MAN among you will consecrate himself <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בבנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובאחיו BY HIS SON AND HIS BROTHER (by their death at his hand).

—3— **Denn ein jeder** von euch weihe sich **durch seinen Sohn und seinen Bruder.**

////—1—//// 32:30:1,"**I will gain atonement for your sin.** [I.e.] “I shall put a <font color=d50505>»</font>cleansing, wiping away<font color=d50505>«</font> and a <font color=d50505>»</font>covering<font color=d50505>«</font> in front of your sins, to separate between you and the sin. "

§§—2—§§ 32:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכפרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטאתכם [PERADVENTURE] I SHALL MAKE AN EXPIATION FOR YOUR SIN — i. e. I shall put an effacing and a wiping off and a covering in front of your sin, to serve as a barrier between you and your sin."

—3— **30. Vermag ich eure Sünde zu sühnen,** kann ich Sühne, Auslöschen und Zudecken, auf eure Sünde, legen, um zwischen euch und der Sünde zu trennen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:31:1,"**A god of gold.** “You (God) are the One who caused this to happen to them for You gave them an abundance of gold and anything they desired. How could they not sin”? A parable comparable to a king, who fed and gave drink to his son and adorned him and hung a bag [full of money] from his neck and made him stand in the doorway of a house of ill-repute; how could the son possibly not sin? "

§§—2—§§ 32:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זהב GODS OF GOLD — Moses emphasized the word “gold” as some excuse for their sin: It is You who have caused them to do this, for You gave them gold in abundance and everything they wished; what else were they likely to do if not to sin? A parable: this may be compared to a king who provides his son with food and drink, attires him with beautiful garments and hangs a money-bag round his neck and then deliberately places him at the door of a house of ill-fame! What else is the son likely to do if not to sin!? (Berakhot 32a)"

—3— **31. Götter von Gold,** du hast es ihnen verursacht, indem du ihnen Gold und alles, was sie verlangten, Zuströmen ließt; was sollten sie tun, um nicht zu sündigen? Es ist dies mit einem König zu vergleichen, der seinem Sohn Speise und Trank gab, ihn schmückte und einen Geldbeutel um den Hals hing und ihn dann an den Eingang eines Hauses der Unzucht stellte, was sollte der Sohn tun, um nicht zu sündigen? (Ber. 32a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:32:1,"**Now, if You would bear their sin —** then well and good — I will not say to You, “Erase me,” but if not, erase me [from Your Book.] This is an elliptical verse and there are many such cases. "

§§—2—§§ 32:32:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטאתם YET NOW, IF THOU WILT FORGIVE THEIR SIN — well and good: then I do not suggest to You, “Blot me out [of Thy book], <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחני BUT IF NOT, BLOT ME OUT.” This is an elliptical sentence, the words “Well and good” being omitted; of such there are many in Scripture."

—3— **32. Und nun, wenn du ihre Sünde verzeihst,** so ist es gut, und ich sage nicht zu dir, lösche mich aus; wenn aber nicht, so lösche mich aus; es ist dies ein kurzer Vers, wie solche oft vorkommen. 

---

////—1—//// 32:32:2,"**From Your Book.** [I.e.] from the entire Torah, so that it should not be said of me that I was not worthy enough to ask for mercy on their behalf. "

§§—2—§§ 32:32:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מספרך OF THY BOOK — of the entire book of the Torah; that people should not say about me that I was not worthy enough to pray effectively for them.

—3— **Aus deinem Buche,** aus der ganzen Torah, dass man nicht von mir sage, ich sei nicht würdig gewesen, für sie um Erbarmen zu bitten. 

---

////—1—//// 32:34:1,**To [the place] of which I have spoken to you.** Here is an instance where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לָךְ is used connected with the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִבּוּר in the place of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵלֶיךָ . A similar instance: “to speak <font color=d50505>»</font>to<font color=d50505>«</font> him concerning Adoniyohu.”

§§—2—§§ 32:34:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך OF WHICH I HAVE SPOKEN UNTO THEE — Here we have an instance of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך connected with the verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבר being used in place of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליך (i. e. where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך actually means speaking to, not as its usual meaning it, speaking “concerning” someone or “in the interest of” someone as often pointed out by Rashi; cf. e. g., Rashi’s comment on Genesis 28:15). Similar is, (1 Kings 2:19) “to speak unto him (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו) for Adonijah” (cf. Rashi on that verse)."

—3— **34. Wohin ich dir gesagt habe,** es steht hier <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך neben <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבור an Stelle von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליך; ebenso (1 Kön. 2,19), mit ihm zu sprechen betreffs Adonijahus. 

---

////—1—//// 32:34:2,"**Behold, My Angel —** but not I. "

§§—2—§§ 32:34:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאכי BEHOLD, MINE ANGEL [SHALL GO BEFORE THEE] — My messenger, not Myself."

—3— **Siehe, mein Bote,** aber nicht ich. 

---

////—1—//// 32:34:3,"**On the day that I take account, etc.** As for now I shall listen to you [and refrain] from destroying them all at once; but always and consistently, whenever I will take an accounting of their sins, I will also account for a little of this sin along with their other sins. And, indeed, no punishment is meted out to Yisrael that does not have along with it some of the punishment for the sin of the Calf. "

§§—2—§§ 32:34:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וביום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקדי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND IN THE DAY WHEN I VISIT [I WILL VISIT THEIR SIN UPON THEM] — At present I listen to you and will refrain from consuming them all at once — but ever and ever throughout the ages, when I am visiting them for their sins I shall visit them at the same time for a little of this sin in addition to their other sins for which I am then punishing them. Indeed no punishment ever comes upon Israel in which there is not part payment for the sin of the golden calf (cf. Sanhedrin 102a)."

—3— **Und am Tage, da ich ahnde,** jetzt habe ich auf dich gehört, dass ich sie nicht auf einmal aufreibe; aber jederzeit, wenn ich ihre Sünden an ihnen ahnde, dann werde ich auch etwas von dieser Schuld ihnen heimzahlen mit den anderen Sünden; und keine Strafe kommt über Israel, in der nicht etwas von der Strafe für die Sünde mit dem goldenen Kalbe enthalten wäre (Sanhedrin 102a). 

---

////—1—//// 32:35:1,"**Adonoy struck the people with a plague.** [I.e.,] death at the hands of the Heavenly King, [for those who sinned] before witnesses without having received a warning. "

§§—2—§§ 32:35:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויגף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם AND THE LORD PLAGUED THE POEPLE — This was death inflicted by the heavenly Judge on those to whose offence there had been witnesses but no legal caution (cf. Rashi on v. 20).

—3— **35. Und der Ewige schlug das Volk,** das ist Tötung durch den Himmel, wenn Zeugen und keine Warnung vorhanden gewesen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:1:1,"**Leave, go up from this.** Eretz Yisrael is the highest of all the lands. Therefore it says: “Go up.” An alternate explanation [for the expression: “Go up”]: as opposed to what He said to him in time of anger: “Go down,” He said to him in time of good-will “Go up.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזה GO, GO UP HENCE — The land of Israel is situated higher than all the other neighbouring lands, therefore it said “go up” (Zevachim 54b). Another explanation is: As a compensation for what He had said to him (Moses) in a time of anger, (Exodus 32:7) “Go, go down”, He now said to him, at a time of good-will, “Go, go up”."

—3— **33, 1. Geh’, ziehe hinauf von hier,** das Land Israel liegt höher als alle Länder; darum steht, ziehe hinauf. Andere Erklärung: entsprechend dem, dass Er in der Stunde des Zornes zu ihm gesagt, geh’, steige hinab (32, 7), sagte Er in der Stunde des Wohlgefallens zu ihm, geh’, steige empor (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 33:1:2,**You and the people.** Here he did not say: “and <font color=d50505>»</font>your<font color=d50505>«</font> people.”

§§—2—§§ 33:1:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והעם THOU AND THE PEOPLE [WHICH THOU HAST BROUGHT UP] — Here — (in contrast to Exodus 32:7) it does not say “and thy people” (the mixed multitude which thou, of thine own accord, hast brought up from Egypt) (Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:26)."

—3— **Du und das Volk,** hier steht nicht, und Dein Volk. 

---

////—1—//// 33:2:1,"**And I will drive out the Canaanites, etc.** These are [only] six nations. [This is because] the Girgashite nation got up and cleared out on their own from before them. "

§§—2—§§ 33:2:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגרשתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הכנעני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND I WILL DRIVE OUT THE CANAANITE etc. — These are only six nations whilst in Deuteronomy 7:1 seven such are mentioned! But the Girgashites, the seventh, arose and emigrated of their own accord from before them (the Israelites) and therefore are not mentioned here amongst those who were driven out (Jerusalem Talmud Shevi'it 6:2; Leviticus Rabbah 17:6)."

—3— **2. Und ich treibe aus den Kenaani** … das sind sechs Völker; aber der Girgaschi erhob sich von selbst und räumte vor ihnen das Land (Jer. Scheb. VI).

////—1—//// 33:3:1,**To a land flowing with milk and honey —** do I tell you to bring them up.

§§—2—§§ 33:3:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארץ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זבת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבש UNTO A LAND FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY do I bid you to bring them up.

—3— **3. In ein Land, das von Milch und Honig fließt,** sage ich dir, sie hinaufzuführen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:3:2,**For I will not go up among you.** It is for this reason that I say to you “I will send an angel before you.”

§§—2—§§ 33:3:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקרבך BECAUSE I WILL NOT GO UP AMONG THEE, therefore I say to thee, I will send an angel before thee."

—3— **Denn ich ziehe nicht in deiner Mitte hinauf,** darum sage ich dir, ich schicke einen Boten vor dir her. 

---

////—1—//// 33:3:3,**For you are a stiff-necked people —** and when My Shechinah is among you and you are rebellious against Me it causes Me to increase My anger against you.

§§—2—§§ 33:3:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ערף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה FOR THOU ART A STIFF-NECKED PEOPLE, and if My Shechina were in thy midst and thou rebelledst against Me, I might become exceedingly angry with thee and destroy thee on the way. "

—3— **Weil du ein hartnäckiges Volk bist,** und wenn meine Schechina in eurer Mitte sein wird und ihr widerspenstig gegen mich sein werdet, so würde ich den Zorn gegen euch noch vermehren.

////—1—//// 33:3:4,**Destroy you.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲכֶלְךָ comes from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּלָיוֹן — “destruction.”

§§—2—§§ 33:3:4,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אכלך is an expression for ‘‘destroying”.

—3— **Aufreibe,** bedeutet Vernichtung.

////—1—//// 33:4:1,**This bad news —** that the Shechinah will not reside or go with them.

§§—2—§§ 33:4:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרע THIS EVIL THING — that the Shechina would not dwell nor go with them.

////—1—//// 33:4:2,"**[No] man [wore] his ornament.** [This refers to] the crowns given to them at Chorev when they responded, “We shall do and we shall listen.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:4:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עדיו [AND NO MAN PUT ON HIM] HIS ORNAMENT — the crowns which were given them on Horeb when they said: (Exodus 24:7) “we shall do and hearken” (Shabbat 88a).

—3— **Ein jeder seinen Schmuck,** die Kronen, die ihnen am Choreb gegeben worden, als sie «wir wollen tun und hören» sprachen (Schabbat 88a).

////—1—//// 33:5:1,"**Were I to go up among you for one moment. I would destroy you.** “Were I to go up among you, and you would be rebellious against me — in your stubbornness, I would be angry with you for [<font color=d50505>»</font>only<font color=d50505>«</font>] one moment which is the length of time that My anger lasts, as it is said: “Hide for almost a moment, until the anger passes,” and I would destroy you. It is therefore better for you that I send an angel. "

§§—2—§§ 33:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רגע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקרבך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכליתיך WERE I TO GO UP AMONG THEE ONE MOMENT, I SHOULD CONSUME THEE — If I were to go up amongst you and you rebelled against Me in your stiff-neckedness I would be angry with you but one moment — for this is the duration of His wrath (Berakhot 7a), as it is said, (Isaiah 26:20) “Hide thyself for a short moment, until the indignation be passed” — and I would consume you; therefore it is better for you that I should send an angel."

—3— **5. Einen Augenblick würde ich in deiner Mitte hinaufziehen und dich vernichten,** wenn ich in deiner Mitte hinaufziehen würde und ihr wäret widerspenstig gegen mich in euerer Hartnäckigkeit, so würde ich einen Augenblick, das ist die Zeit meines Zornes (Ber. 7a), wie es heißt (Jes. 26, 20), verbirg dich einen Augenblick, bis der Zorn vorüber, zürnen und euch aufreiben; darum ist es besser für euch, wenn ich einen Boten schicke.

////—1—//// 33:5:2,"**And now —** this is the punishment that you will receive immediately, that you will remove your ornaments from yourselves. "

§§—2—§§ 33:5:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועתה AND NOW — This punishment shall be inflicted upon you now, at once, viz., that you should put off your ornaments from you."

§§—2—§§ 32:34) I know what is in My mind to do unto you.

////—1—//// 33:7:1,**And Moshe —** from the time of the sin and on —

////—1—//// 33:7:2,** would take the tent.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִקַּח] is an ongoing action (present tense): he would take his tent and pitch it outside the encampment. He thought: one who is ostracized by the master ought to be ostracized by the disciple as well.

§§—2—§§ 33:7:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האהל USED TO TAKE THE TENT — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקח expresses an action continually going on — he used to take his tent and pitch it without the camp. He said, “One who has been placed under an interdict by the Master must be placed under an interdict by His disciple also” (Since God had stated that He would not dwell amongst the people, Moses, the disciple, also felt compelled to remove from their midst) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 27)."

—3— **Nahm das Zelt,** die Zukunft bedeutet die Wiederholung; er nahm das Zelt und schlug es außerhalb des Lagers auf, indem er sagte, wer vom Lehrer in den Bann getan ist, ist auch für den Schüler im Banne befindlich (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 33:7:3,"**A distance —** of two thousand <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs,<font color=d50505>«</font> similar to what is said: “Only let there be a distance between you (the B’nei Yisrael) and it (the Ark) of about two thousand <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> by measure.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:7:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הרחק DISTANT [FROM THE CAMP] — two thousand cubits, just as it is stated, (Joshua 3:4) Yet there shall be a space between you (the Israelites) and it (the Ark) about 2,000 cubits by measure” (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 27)."

—3— **Entfernt,** 2000 Ellen, gleich jener Stelle (Jos. 3,4), nur sei ein Abstand zwischen euch und ihr, ungefähr 2000 Ellen an Maß.
