////—1—//// 33:7:4,**And he called it.** He would refer to it as Tent of Meeting — a gathering place for those who seek knowledge of Torah.

§§—2—§§ 33:7:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לו AND HE CALLED IT — This does not mean that he so named it once for all but that whenever he spoke of it he used to call it the tent of meeting, i. e. a meeting-place for those who sought instruction in the Torah."

—3— **Und nannte es,** und er nannte es Zelt der Offenbarung, das ist Stätte der Zusammenkunft für diejenigen, die nach der Torah verlangten. 

---

////—1—//// 33:7:5,**Everyone who sought Adonoy.** From here [we derive] that one who seeks to be in the presence of an “elder” (a Torah scholar) is as if he is in the presence of the Shechinah.

§§—2—§§ 33:7:5,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבקש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ EVERY ONE WHO SOUGHT THE LORD — Hence (from the fact that anyone who visited Moses is described here as “one who seeks the Lord”) we may learn that he who makes a call on (Hebrew: seeks) a scholar (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זקן is a Rabbinical term for a wise man; cf. Kiddushin 32b: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זקן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חכם) may be regarded as paying his respects to the Divine Presence (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 27)."

—3— **Jeder, der den Ewigen aufsuchte,** von hier geht hervor, dass, wer das Angesicht eines Lehrers aufsucht, dem gleicht, der dem Angesicht der Schechina naht (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 33:7:6,"**Would go out to the Tent of Meeting.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵצֵא here is] the same [tense] as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יוֹצֵא (i.e., present tense). An alternate explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְבַקֵּשׁ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' . Even the ministering angels, when they would inquire as to the place of the Shechinah their fellow-angels would say to them: “But He is there in Moshe’s tent”! "

§§—2—§§ 33:7:6," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מועד WENT OUT UNTO THE APPOINTED TENT — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֵצֵא (the imperfect) has here the meaning of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יוֹצֵא (the participle: cf. Rashi on <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכו׳), i. e. he used to go out. Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מבקש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ is: The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל, “every one”, implies: even the ministering angels used to go out unto the appointed tent; whenever these enquired where was the place of the Divine Glory their fellow-angels used to answer them: See, He (God) is in the tent of Moses."

—3— **Ging zum Zelt der Offenbarung hinaus**, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יוצא = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יצא. Andere Erklärung: jeder, der den Ewigen aufsuchte, selbst die Engel des Dienstes, wenn sie nach dem Ort der Schechina fragten, sagten ihre Gefährten zu ihnen, siehe, Er ist im Zelte Mosches (Tanchuma).

////—1—//// 33:8:1,**Whenever.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהָיָה is] in the present tense.

§§—2—§§ 33:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והיה — This expresses an action continually going on (“and it used to be”),"

—3— **8. Und es war,** bedeutet die Wiederholung.

////—1—//// 33:8:2,**Moshe went out —** from the encampment to go to the tent —

§§—2—§§ 33:8:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כצאת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה WHEN MOSES WENT OUT from the camp in order to go <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האהל INTO THE TENT, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקומו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם ALL THE PEOPLE ROSE UP — they used to stand up before him and did not sit down until he vanished from their sight (Hebrew: was hidden from them)."

—3— **Wenn Mosche zum Lager hinausging,** um ins Zelt zu gehen.

////—1—//// 33:8:3,** all the people would rise.** They would stand up before him and would not sit until he disappeared from view.

§§—2—§§ 33:8:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והביטו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND THEY LOOKED AFTER MOSES — Not sneeringly but out of admiration; they exclaimed: Happy is the human being (Hebrew: one born of woman) who is so sure that the Shechina will enter the door of his tent after him (cf. Kiddushin 33b; Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 27, Exodus Rabbah 51:6)."

////—1—//// 33:8:4,"**And they would gaze after Moshe —** in an admiring way, [saying, in effect:] “Fortunate is one born of woman who is assured that the Shechinah will follow him into the entranceway of his tent.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:8:4,

—3— **Und schaute hinter Moscher her,** zu seinem Ruhme, Heil dem Weibgeborenen, dem so zugesagt worden ist, dass die Schechina nach ihm in den Eingang seines Zeltes eintreten würde (Tanchuma).

////—1—//// 33:9:1,"**And would speak with Moshe** — the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמְדַבֵּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משֶׁה (present tense). Onkelos translates it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמִתְמַלֵּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משֶׁה which is respect for the Shechinah, as in: “He heard the voice <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִדַבֵּר to him” and it does not read <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵלָיו . Because when it reads <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִדַּבֵּר its interpretation is: the Voice speaking to itself which the ordinary person happens to overhear, but when it reads <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר it implies that the king is speaking with the ordinary person. "

§§—2—§§ 33:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה — This means the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND HE USED TO SPEAK WITH MOSES (The verb <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר expresses the idea of an action always going on as Rashi has explained the preceding verbs). The Targum renders it by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומתמלל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה (Hithpeal) i. e. He used to speak to Himself with (in the presence of) Moses — which is an expression of respect used with reference to the Shechinah. A similar Hebrew expression is, (Numbers 7:89) “Then he heard the voice <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִדַּבֵּר to him” (= <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מתדבר, with assimilated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת), and it does not read there, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר, “speaking to him”. Where the reading is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִדַּבֵּר its interpretation is: The voice was speaking by itself (i. e. it was not directed to any particular person) and the ordinary man naturally heard it (because he was there); but where the reading is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְדַבֵּר, it implies that the King was conversing with the ordinary man."

—3— **9. Und redete mit Mosche**, = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומדבר; der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומתמלל, das ist Ehrerbietung vor der Schechina; wie (Num. 7, 89) vernahm er die Stimme, zu sich sprechend; man liest aber nicht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדבר; denn, wenn man <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדבר liest, so ist die Bedeutung, die Stimme sprach zu sich selbst, und dadurch hörte sie der Mensch; wenn man aber <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדבר liest, so bedeutet es, der König sprach mit dem Gewöhnlichen.

////—1—//// 33:10:1,**Prostrated themselves —** to the <font color=d50505>»</font>Shechinah.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 33:10:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והשתחוו AND THEY PROSTRATED THEMSELVES to the Shechinah.

—3— **10. Und sie bückten sich** vor der Schechina.

////—1—//// 33:11:1,**Adonoy spoke to Moshe face to face.** The correct reading of Onkelos is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמִתְמַלֵּל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עִם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משֶׁה .

§§—2—§§ 33:11:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנים AND THE LORD SPAKE UNTO MOSES FACE TO FACE — Here too (as in v. 9) in spite of the fact that the text states “face to face” the Targum is: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומתמלל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה‎.

—3— **11. Und der Ewige sprach zu Mosche von Angesicht zu Angesicht,** Targum <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומתמלל. 

---

////—1—//// 33:11:2,"**He returned to the camp —** after [God’s] conversing with him Moshe would return to the encampment and teach the elders what he had learned. Moshe acted in this way from Yom Kippur until the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> was erected but not longer. For on the 17th of Tammuz the tablets were broken and on the 18th he burned the Calf and judged the sinners and on the nineteenth he went up [the mountain], as it says: “The next day Moshe said to the people, etc.” and spent forty days there and asked for mercy [for the B’nei Yisrael], “and he would return to the encampment,” because it is in the present (ongoing) tense. The same applies to this whole section: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְרָאָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעָם (v. 10) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַחֲזַן — “would see,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִצָבוּ (v. 8) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וִקַיְימִין — “they would rise,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִבִּיטוּ (ibid.) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּמִסְתַּכְּלִין — “they would gaze,” <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהִשְׁתַּחֲווּ (v. 10) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְסָגְדִין — “they would bow.” But its midrashic explanation is: "

§§—2—§§ 33:11:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המחנה .( AND HE RETURNED INTO THE CAMP — After God had conversed with him, Moses used to return to the camp and teach the elders what he had learned. This Moses practised from the day of Atonement until the Tabernacle was set up, but no longer. For on the seventeenth of Tammuz the tablets were broken, on the eighteenth he burnt the calf and punished the of fenders, on the nineteenth he ascended the mountain, as it is said (Exodus 32:30) “And it came to pass on the morrow (the day after he had punished the wrongdoers; cf. vv. 26—29), that Moses said unto the people”, [Ye have sinned a great sin and now I will go up to the Lord]”. There he spent forty days and sought mercy for the people, as it is said, (Deuteronomy 9:18) “And I threw myself down before the Lord [as at the first, forty days and forty nights]”. These terminated on the last day of Ab (there were 11 days from the 19th to the 29th of Tammuz therefore 29 days in Ab complete the forty) and he then returned to the people. On the first day of the New Moon of Ellul it was said to him, (Exodus 34:2) “And be ready in the morning] and go up in the morning unto mount Sinai” — to receive the second tablets. He again spent there the forty days of which it is stated, (Deuteronomy 10:10) “[And I stayed in the mountain, according to the first, days, [forty days and forty nights]”. The words <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כימים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הראשונים, “like the first days”, cannot refer to the number of days for this is stated immediately afterwards; they are to be joined with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמדתי — I stayed in the same state as on the first days: How were the first forty days passed? In God’s good-will (because the Israelites had not yet sinned)! So, too, the last forty days were passed in God’s good-will — from which you must admit that the intervening forty days were passed in God’s anger. On the tenth of Tishri God became reconciled with Israel in joy and perfect affection and said to Moses: “I have forgiven!” and handed him over the second tablets, whereupon Moses went down and began to command them concerning the work of the Tabernacle (cf. Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 31; Seder Olam 6; 
§§—2—§§ 18:13, Deuteronomy 9:18 and also Taanit 36b). They were occupied in its construction until the first of Nisan and from the time when it was set up God did not converse with him any more except from the tent of meeting."

—3— **Dann kehrte er ins Lager zurück;** nachdem Er mit ihm gesprochen hatte, kehrte Mosche ins Lager zurück und lehrte die Ältesten, was er gelernt hatte. Diese Weise wandte Mosche von Jomhakipurim bis zur Errichtung der Wohnung an, aber nicht länger; denn, siehe, am 17. Tamus wurden die Tafeln zerbrochen; am 18. verbrannte er das Kalb und richtete die Sünder, am 19. stieg er hinauf; so steht (32, 30), am anderen Tag sagte Mosche zum Volk; dort blieb er 40 Tage und flehte um Erbarmen; so heißt es (Deut. 9, 25), ich warf mich vor dem Ewigen nieder; am Rosch chodesch Elul wurde zu ihm gesagt (Deut. 34, 2), steige am Morgen auf den Berg Sinai, um die letzten Tafeln zu empfangen; und er blieb dort 40 Tage; denn von ihnen heißt es (Deut. 10, 10), ich verweilte auf dem Berge gleich den ersten Tagen, wie die ersten voll Wohlgefallen gewesen, so waren es auch die letzten; daraus kannst du schließen, dass die mittleren voll Zorn waren. Am 10. Tischri verzieh der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, Israel mit Freude und ganzem Herzen und sagte zu Mosche, ich habe verziehen und gab ihm die letzten Tafeln; dann stieg er hinab und begann, den Bau der Wohnung zu befehlen; sie machten sie bis zum 1. Nissan; und als sie errichtet war, sprach Er nur noch aus dem Zelt der Offenbarung mit ihm. 

---

////—1—//// 33:11:3,"**God spoke to Moshe** that he must return to the encampment; he said to him: “I am angry and you are angry; if so, who will again bring them near to me.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:11:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המחנה AND HE RETURNED TO THE CAMP — The translation in the Targum is: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְתָיִב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למשריתא (a participle) “and he used to return to the camp”, because (as explained above) it denotes continuous action. Similarly, he translates all the verbs occuring in this section by participles: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העם he renders by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונצבו ;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחזן by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והביטו ;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקימין by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והשתחוו ;<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומסתכלין by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וסגדין. The Midrash explains <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה thus: And the Lord spake to Moses that he should return to the camp. He said to him: I am angry and you are angry; if this is to remain so, who will attract them to Me again? (cf. Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 27 and Berakhot 63b)."

—3— **Dann kehrte er ins Lager zurück,** der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תאיב (Partiz.), weil es die Bedeutung der Wiederholung hat; und so die ganze Begebenheit, das Volk sah <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחזן, es stand <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקיימין, schaute <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסתבלין, bückte sich <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סגדין. Der Midrasch sagt, der Ewige sprach zu Mosche, er solle ins Lager zurückkehren, indem Er zu ihm sagte, wenn ich zürne und auch du zürnst, wer wird sie dann wieder zur Pflicht zurückführen (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 33:12:1,"**Behold You say to me.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רְאֵה (lit. “see”) means: Set Your “eyes” and Your “heart” on Your words. You say to me, etc. [“lead this people up”] but You did not let me know, etc. [whom You would send with me]. And this that You said to me: “Behold, I am sending an angel” is not considered letting me know for I do not wish it [to happen]. "

§§—2—§§ 33:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי SEE. THOU SAYEST UNTO ME — Set Thy eyes and Thy heart to Thy own words (Think for a moment of what Thou, Thyself, hast told me)"

—3— **12. Siehe, du sagst zu mir,** siehe, richte deine Augen und dein Herz auf deine Worte; du sagst zu mir…, und du hast mir nicht kundgetan …; dass du aber zu mir gesprochen (23, 20), siehe, ich schicke einen Engel, das ist keine Kundtuung, da ich damit nicht zufrieden bin. 

---

////—1—//// 33:12:2,

§§—2—§§ 33:12:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הודעתני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THOU SAYEST UNTO ME [BRING UP THIS PEOPLE] AND NEVERTHELESS THOU HAST NOT LET ME KNOW [WHOM THOU WILT SEND WITH ME] — for what You have said to me (Exodus 23:20) “And I will send an angel before thee” is not “letting me know”, for I am not satisfied with it."

—3— **Und du hast gesprochen, ich habe dich mit Namen erwählt,** dich von den übrigen Menschen durch einen Namen der Auszeichnung unterschieden, da du zu mir gesagt (19,9), siehe, ich komme zu dir in dichtem Gewölk … und auch auf dich werden sie in Ewigkeit vertrauen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:12:3,"**You [also] said, “I know you by name.”** [Saying to me, in effect:] “I have recognized you from among other people ‘by name’ — i.e., to recognize your importance,” for You said to me [to indicate this importance]: “Behold I come to you in the thickness of the cloud, etc. and also in you will they believe forever.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:12:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ידעתיך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשם YET THOU HAST SAID, I HAVE KNOWN THEE BY NAME — I have distinguished you from all other human beings by a characteristic (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שם) which shows my importance in Thy eyes, for, see, Thou hast said to me, (Exodus 19:9) “Behold, I come unto thee in a thick cloud etc.… and also in thee they shall believe for ever”."


---

////—1—//// 33:13:1,"**Now —** if it is so that I have found favor in Your eyes please let me know Your ways — i.e., what reward do You give to those who find favor in Your eyes — "

§§—2—§§ 33:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועתה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ NOW THEREFORE etc. — If it is true that I have found favour in Thy eyes, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הודיעני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דרכך LET ME KNOW THY WAY — let me know what is the reward which Thou givest to those who find favour in Thine eyes."

—3— **13. Und nun,** wenn es wahr ist, dass ich Gunst in deinen Augen gefunden, so tue mir doch deine Wege kund, welchen Lohn du denen gibst, die Gunst in deinen Augen gefunden. 

---

////—1—//// 33:13:2,"**so that I will know You that I may find favor in Your eyes.** And through this (i.e., knowing Your ways) the degree to which You give reward — what is this “finding of favor” which I have found in Your eyes. Hence the interpretation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמַעַן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֶמְצָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חֵן is: so that I may appreciate the extent of the reward for “finding favor.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:13:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואדעך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעיניך means, that I may know by this (by Your letting me know Your way) the nature of the reward You bestow — what is this “finding of grace” which You have granted to me (Hebrew: which I found in Your eyes). The explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למען <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חן accordingly is: that I may find out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמצא) how great is the reward attendant on this “finding of grace”."

—3— **Dass ich dich erkenne, um Gunst in deinen Augen zu finden,** um dadurch die Eigenschaft deiner Vergeltung zu erkennen; worin nämlich das Finden der Gunst bestehe, die ich in deinen Augen gefunden; und die Erklärung von, um Gunst in deinen Augen zu finden, ist, dass ich er kenne, wie groß der Lohn dessen sei, der Gunst gefunden. 

---

////—1—//// 33:13:3,"**And consider that this nation is Your people —** so that You not say: “And I will make you into a great nation,” while You abandon these [the people]; consider that they are Your people of yore, and if You become contemptuous of them I could not be certain that those who descend from me will endure. And my reward for this people, please make known to me. Our Sages, however, give midrashic interpretations of it in Tractate Berachos, but my purpose is to explain the verses in their context and order. "

§§—2—§§ 33:13:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הגוי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה AND CONSIDER THAT THIS NATION IS THY PEOPLE so that You should not say, as You have said, (Exodus 32:10) “And I will make thee a great nation”, whilst these (the whole people) You will abandon! Consider that they are Your nation from of old, and if You reject them, surely I cannot rely upon it that those who are born of me will endure — rather let me know through this people the reward that is to be paid me (by sparing them). Our Rabbis have given a Midrashic explanation of this in Treatise Berakhot 7a but I come (my purpose is) to explain the verses in a manner fitting to them and in their context."

—3— **Und siehe, dass dein Volk diese Nation ist;** sage nicht, ich will dich zu einem großen Volke machen, indem du diese verlässt; siehe, sie sind von alters her Dein Volk; und wenn Du sie verwirfst, so verlasse ich mich auch nicht auf diejenigen, die aus meinen Lenden hervorgehen, dass sie bestehen werden; tue mir die Vergeltung meines Lohnes an diesem Volke kund. Unsere Lehrer erklären die Stelle im Traktat Berach. (7a) agadisch; ich aber bin nur gekommen, die Verse nach ihrem Zusammenhang und ihrer Reihenfolge zu erklären. 

---

////—1—//// 33:14:1,"**He [God] said, “My Presence will go [with you].** It is as Onkelos translates it: [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שְׁכִנְתִּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְהַךְ — “My Shechinah will go,” meaning:] “I will no longer send an angel, I, Myself, will go,” as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וּפָנֶיךָ) You, yourself, will go into battle.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילכו AND HE SAID, MY FACE SHALL GO WITH THEE Understand this as the Targum renders it: My Shechinah will go — I will no more send an angel with you, but I Myself will go. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פנים here has the sense of “Self” as in (II Samuel 17:11) “and that thou go in the battle in thine own person (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניך)”."

—3— **14. Und Er sprach, mein Angesicht wird mitziehen,** wie der Targum sagt, ich will keinen Engel mehr schicken; sondern ich selbst werde gehen, wie (II Sam. 17, 11), und du selbst ziehst in die Schlacht. 

---

////—1—//// 33:15:1,**He (Moshe) said to him —** “that is exactly what I wish that You not bring us up from here through an angel.”

§§—2—§§ 33:15:1,‎<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליו AND HE SAID UNTO HIM — This is what I desired: for if it is to be by an angel rather do not bring us up from here.

—3— **15. Und er sprach zu Ihm,** damit bin ich zufrieden; denn durch einen Engel führe uns nicht von hier hinauf. 

---

////—1—//// 33:16:1,**And how will it be known.** The finding of favor will be known only by Your Self going with us. But I ask one more thing of You that You no longer allow Your Shechinah to rest on the nations of the world.

§§—2—§§ 33:16:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובמה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יודע <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפוא FOR WHEREIN SHALL IT BE KNOWN HERE [THAT I AND THY PEOPLE HAVE FOUND FAVOUR IN THY EYES] — i. e. wherein shall the “finding of favour” be known, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הלא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בלכתך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמנו IF NOT BY YOUR GOING WITH US!? And yet another thing do I ask You: that You should not let Your Shechinah rest upon the other peoples of the world (Berakhot 7a)."

—3— **16. Wodurch wird denn erkannt werden,** wird das Finden der Gunst erkannt werden? Doch nur dadurch, dass du mit uns gehst; und um noch eine andere Sache bitte ich dich, dass du deine SeheChina nicht ferner auf den Völkern der Welt ruhen lassen mögest (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 33:16:2,"**So that I and your people will be distinguished.** I.e., through this we will be set apart from all other people, etc., as in: “God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הִפְלָה) distinguished between the cattle of Israel etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:16:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונפלינו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועמך SO SHALL WE BE DISTINGUISHED, I AND THY PEOPLE — through this very thing we shall become different from all the peoples. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפלינו is of the same root and meaning as in (Exodus 9:4) “And the Lord shall make a separation (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והפלה) between the cattle of Israel etc.”"

—3— **Dass ich und dein Volk ausgezeichnet sind,** dass wir uns dadurch von jedem Volke unterscheiden; wie (9,4), der Ewige wird unterscheiden zwischen den Herden Israels. 

---

////—1—//// 33:17:1,"**Also this thing —** that My <font color=d50505>»</font>Shechinah<font color=d50505>«</font> will no longer rest upon the nations of the world — I will do. But the [prophetical] words of Bilaam were not by means of the resting of the Shechinah [on him], but, rather, “when fallen (i.e., asleep) but with the eyes uncovered.” For example: “To me a word was stolen” — they (the prophets of the other nations) heard through an intermediary. "

§§—2—§§ 33:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הזה THIS THING ALSO — that My Shechinah shall not rest henceforth upon the other nations of the world, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעשה I WILL DO. And thus He did, for the prophetical words of Balaam (the heathen prophet) were not uttered by reason of the Shechinah resting upon him, but, as Scripture describes it, (Numbers 24:4) “[he saw the vision of the Almighty] fallen, but with eyes uncovered” (i. e. whilst fallen into a sleep his mental eyes were open and he saw in a dream what the Almighty was to reveal unto him) in a state of mind similar to that described by Job (Job 4:12) “a word was by stealth conveyed (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יגנב) to me” — they (the heathen prophets) used to hear God’s message through a medium."

—3— **17. Auch diese Sache,** dass meine Schechina nicht ferner auf den Völkern der Welt ruhen wird, werde ich tun; die Worte Bileams aber kamen nicht davon her, dass die Schechina auf ihm ruhte; sondern er war hinfallend mit offenen Augen (Num. 24, 4); wie (Job 4, 12), und zu mir stiehlt sich ein Wort; sie hörten nur durch einen Boten. 

---

////—1—//// 33:18:1,**He (Moshe) then said. “Please grant me a vision of Your Glory.”** Moshe saw that it was a favorable moment and that his words were finding acceptance. So he made an additional request to be shown a vision of His Glory.

§§—2—§§ 33:18:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הראני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבדך AND HE SAID I BESEECH THEE, SHOW ME THY GLORY — Moses saw that the hour was propitious and that his petitions were being favourably received, he therefore made a further request — that God should let him behold a reflection of His Glory."

—3— **18. Und er sprach, zeige mir doch deine Herrlichkeit,** Mosche sah, dass es eine Zeit des Wohlgefallens war und dass seine Worte angenommen wurden, darum fuhr er fort zu bitten, ihm die Erscheinung Seiner Herrlichkeit zu zeigen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:19:1,"**He (God) said, “I will cause all My goodness to pass, etc.”** I.e., “The time has come for you to see of My Glory, that which I will allow you to see, because I want and need to teach you the order of prayer. For, when you needed to ask for mercy for the Israelites, You reminded Me of the merit of the Patriarchs. You thought that were the merit of the Patriarchs to be exhausted there would no longer be any hope. I will, therefore, cause to pass all the attributes of My goodness before you on the rock while you are concealed in the cave. "

§§—2—§§ 33:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אגי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעביר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND HE SAID, I WILL MAKE ALL MY GOODNESS PASS [BEFORE YOU] — The time has arrived when you shall see of My Glory so much as I will allow you to see according as I wish, and therefore I find it necessary to teach you a set form of prayer. Just now when you felt the need to pray for mercy on Israel’s behalf you besought Me to remember the merits of the patriarchs and you thought that if the merits of the patriarchs are exhausted there is no more hope — I will therefore cause all the attribute of My goodness to pass before you on the rock whilst you are placed in the cave."

—3— **19. Und Er sage, ich werde vorüberziehen lassen,** die Stunde ist gekommen, dass du meine Herrlichkeit sehen darfst, soweit ich dir zu schauen erlaube; weil ich dich die Ordnung des Gebetes lehren will und es für nötig halte; denn, als du nötig hattest, für Israel um Erbarmen zu bitten, hast du vor mir der Frömmigkeit der Väter gedacht und gemeint, wenn das Verdienst der Väter zu Ende sein würde, so würde keine Hoffnung mehr vorhanden sein; ich werde aber die ganze Eigenschaft meiner Güte auf dem Felsen vor dir vorüberziehen lassen, während du dich in der Höhle befindest. 

---

////—1—//// 33:19:2,"**And will proclaim the Name, Adonoy, in your presence —** so as to teach you the order of asking for mercy even if the merit of the Patriarchs is exhausted. And in this order that you see Me, “wrapped [in a tallis]” while proclaiming “the thirteen attributes,” teach Yisrael to do likewise. And by mentioning before Me [My attributes] “Merciful One! Gracious One” they will be answered, for My mercies are never exhausted. "

§§—2—§§ 33:19:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וקראתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לפניך AND I WILL CALL ON THE NAME OF THE LORD BEFORE THEE, to teach you the formula when praying for mercy even though the merits of the patriarchs should be exhausted. And according to the manner in which you see Me doing this, cloaked — as it were — in the Talith and proclaiming the thirteen attributes of mercy, do you teach Israel to do. And because that they will make mention before Me of the attributes: “Merciful”, “Gracious!” thereby proclaiming that My mercies do not fail (even though the merits of the patriarchs are exhausted) (Rosh Hashanah 17b)."

—3— **Und ich werde den Namen Ewiger vor dir verkünden,** dich die Ordnung, um Erbarmen zu flehen, zu lehren, auch wenn das Verdienst der Väter zu Ende sein sollte; und nach der Ordnung, wie du mich eingehüllt und die dreizehn Eigenschaften verkünden siehst, so lehre Israel, dass sie also tun; und dadurch, dass sie vor mir «barmherzig und gnadenvoll» aussprechen, werden sie Erhöhung finden; denn mein Erbarmen hört niemals auf (Rosch hasch. 17b). 

---

////—1—//// 33:19:3,"**I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious.** [I.e.,] those times that I will wish to be gracious. "

§§—2—§§ 33:19:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחנתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחון I WILL BE GRACIOUS TO WHOM I WILL BE GRACIOUS i. e. in times when I shall be disposed to be gracious,"

—3— **Ich werde gnädig sein, dem ich gnädig sein werde,** in jenen Fällen, da ich gnädig sein will. 

---

////—1—//// 33:19:4,"**And I will be compassionate —** those times that I will wish to be compassionate. Up to this point He only promised him that “at times I will respond, at times I will not respond.” But at that time [when He actually proclaimed His attributes,] He said to him: “Behold, I establish a covenant,” thus promising him [that once the Attributes are invoked] they will never return unanswered (lit. empty). "

§§—2—§§ 33:19:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורחמתי AND I WILL SHEW MERCY — those times that I shall desire to show mercy (Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:27). For the time being He only gave him (Moses) the promise: At times I will answer your prayer, at times I will not answer it. But at the time this was carried out (i. e. when He proclaimed the Attributes) He said to him (Exodus 34:10) “Behold, I make a covenant…” (I make this irrevocable) — thus assuring him that they (the 13 Attributes of Mercy when invoked in time of need) will never prove ineffective (Rosh Hashanah 17b)."

—3— **Und mich erbarmen,** zur Zeit da ich mich erbarmen will; bis dahin verhieß Er ihm nur, zuzeiten werde ich erhören, und zuzeiten werde ich nicht erhören; aber in der Stunde der Anwendung sagte Er zu ihm (34, 10), siehe, ich schließe einen Bund, da verhieß Er ihm, dass die Erwähnung der Gnade Gottes nie leer zurückkehren werde. 

---

////—1—//// 33:20:1,"**And He said, “You cannot,” etc.** Even when I cause all My goodness to pass before you, I shall not permit you to see My Presence. "

§§—2—§§ 33:20:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויאמר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תוכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND HE SAID, THOU CANST NOT [SEE MY FACE] — and even when I make all My goodness pass before you I shall not allow you to see My face."

—3— **20. Und Er sprach, du vermagst nicht,** auch wenn ich alle meine Güte vor deinem Angesicht vorüberziehen lasse, gebe ich dir doch nicht die Erlaubnis, mein Angesicht zu schauen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:21:1,"**“Behold, there is a place with Me.”** In the mountain, where I constantly speak with you, I have a place prepared for your needs, where I will conceal you so that you will not be hurt, and from there you will see what you may see. That is the plain explanation. However, its midrashic explanation is that [“a place”] refers to the place where the Shechinah is and He, therefore, says: “The place is with Me” and He does not say: “I am in the place,” for God is “the place of the world” but the world is not “His place.” "

§§—2—§§ 33:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתי BEHOLD, THERE IS A PLACE BY ME — On the mountain where I am continually speaking with you there is a place prepared by Me for your sake where I will hide you that you may not be hurt by the vision. From there you will see what you will be permitted to see. A Midrashic explanation is that by the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקום Scripture is speaking of the place where the Shechinah is and that He therefore said, “The place is by Me” and He did not say, “I am in the place”, because the Holy One, blessed be He, is the “place” of the Universe (comprises the Universe) but His Universe is not His place (does not encompass Him) (Genesis Rabbah 68:8)."

—3— **21. Siehe, ein Ort ist bei mir,** auf dem Berge, auf dem ich immer mit dir spreche, ist von mir ein Ort für dich vorbereitet, an dem ich dich verbergen werde, damit du nicht geschädigt werdest; und von dort aus wirst du sehen, was du sehen darfst; das ist der einfache Sinn. Der Midrasch (Tanchuma) sagt, es bezieht sich auf den Raum, in dem sich die Schechina befindet; und Er sagte, der Raum ist bei mir; Er sagt aber nicht, ich bin im Raum; denn der Eieilige, gelobt sei Er, umschließt die Welt, aber die Welt umschließt nicht Ihn. 

---

////—1—//// 33:22:1,**When My Glory passes by.** [Meaning:] When I pass by you.

§§—2—§§ 33:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כבדי WHEN MY GLORY PASSETH BY – i. e. when I shall pass before you.

—3— **22. Wenn meine Herrlichkeit vorüberzieht,** wenn ich vor dir vorüberziehe. 

---

////—1—//// 33:22:2,**In a cleft of the rock.** [The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּנִקְרַת expresses the idea of a hole] as in: “Will you (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תְּנַקֵּר) bore out the eyes of those men”? [or:] “The ravens of the valley (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יִקְּרוּהָ) will bore it out” [or:] “I have dug and drunk water”; They all have a common root. Therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִקְרַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צוּר means “a place dug out in the rock.”

§§—2—§§ 33:22:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בנקרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצור IN A CLEFT OF THE CRAG — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקרה is similar in meaning to the verbs in (Numbers 16:14) “Wilt thou bore out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תנקר) the eyes of these men?”; (Proverbs 30:17) “The ravens of the valley shall pick it out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקרהו)‎”; (2 Kings 19:24) “I have digged a well (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרתי) and drunk strange waters”. All these have the same derivation. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נקרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצור thus means a place dug out of the rock.

—3— **In die Spalte des Felsens,** wie (Num. 16, 14), willst du die Augen dieser Männer ausstechen; (Spr. 30, 17) mögen die Raben des Baches aushacken; (II Kön. 19, 24) ich grub und trank Wasser; überall derselbe Stamm. **Felsenspalte,** Höhlung im Felsen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:22:3,"**And I will cover [you] with My Hand.** From here it may be derived permission is given to destroyers to destroy. Onkelos translates it (i.e., <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְשַׂכֹּתִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַפִּי) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאָגֵין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּמֵימְרִי — “I will protect you with My word.” This is a euphemism as a way [of explaining] respectfulness towards the One on High, Who, [obviously] does not need to cover him actually, with His Hand. "

§§—2—§§ 33:22:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושכתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפי AND I WILL SHELTER [THEE] WITH MY HAND — Hence it is evident that permission has been given to the destructive agencies to wound. The Targum renders <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ושכתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפי by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואגין <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במימרי “I will protect thee with My word” This is merely a circumlocution in a manner more respectful to the Most High God and the Targum did not translate it literally because He (God) does not need to cover a person with the hand actually in order to protect him.

—3— **Und ich breite meine Hand aus,** von hier geht hervor, dass den zerstörenden Kräften die Macht verliehen ist, zu zerstören (Tor. Koh. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י״<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדות); was der Targum sagt, ich werde dich durch mein Wort schützen, ist eine Umschreibung aus Ehrerbietung vor dem Ewigen, da Er nicht buchstäblich die Hand über ihn auszubreiten nötig hat. 

---

////—1—//// 33:23:1,"**Then I will remove My Hand.** [Onkelos translates it:] <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַעְדֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יָת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דִּבְרַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְקָרִי — “I shall remove the guidance of My Glory,” [Meaning:] “When I remove the guidance of My Glory from before your face” — to go away from there [then —] "

§§—2—§§ 33:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והסרתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כפי AND I WILL REMOVE MY HAND — The Targum renders this by <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואעדי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דברת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יקרי “I will remove the guidance of My Glory”; it means: when I shall remove the guidance of My Glory from before thine eyes — to go right away from that place,"

—3— **23. Und wenn ich meine Hand entferne,** Targum: wenn ich das Vorüberführen meiner Herrlichkeit weichen lasse, wenn sich das Vorüberziehen meiner Majestät vor deinem Angesicht entfernt, um von da fortzugehen. 

---

////—1—//// 33:23:2,**you will see My Back.** He showed him the <font color=d50505>»</font>tephillin<font color=d50505>«</font>-knot [behind the Head].

§§—2—§§ 33:23:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אחרי THEN THOU SHALT SEE WHAT IS BEHIND ME — He showed him the Tephillin-knot which is placed behind the head (cf. Berakhot 7a; Menachot 35b).

—3— **So wirst du mich sehen, wenn ich vorübergezogen,** Er zeigte ihm den Knoten der Tefillin (Ber. 7a).

---

////—1—//// 34:1:1,**Carve out for yourself.** He (God) showed him a quarry of precious stone from within his tent and said to him: The [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּסוֹלֶת — from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּסָל] chips shall be [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֶׁלְךָ — from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְךָ] yours. From there Moshe became extremely wealthy.

§§—2—§§ 34:1:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך HEW THEE — He showed him a quarry of sapphire in his tent and said to him: The chips (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסל = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסלת) shall be thine (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך). It was from this that Moses became so rich (cf. Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:29; Leviticus Rabbah 32:2). 

—3— **34, 1. Haue dir aus,** Er zeigte ihm einen Steinbruch von Sanpirinon (Edelsteinen) in seinem Zelte und sagte zu ihm, der Abfall soll dir gehören; und dadurch wurde Mosche sehr reich (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 34:1:2,"**Carve out for yourself.** You broke the First [Tablets], you carve out others for yourself. A parable: [this is comparable] to a king who went off to a faraway land and left his betrothed with the maidservants. As a result of the immoral behavior of the maidservants her (the betrothed’s) reputation was besmirched. Her bridesman arose and tore up her marriage contract, saying: “If the king will decide to kill her I will tell him: ‘She is not yet your wife’.” [Consequently] the king investigated and found that the immoral behavior was only on the part of the maidservants. He was reconciled with her, whereupon the bridesman said to him (the king): “Write her another marriage contract for the first one was torn up.” The king replied to him: “You are the one who tore it up. You buy other paper for yourself and I will write it for her in my handwriting.” Here, too, the king is God, the maidservants are the riffraff, the bridesman is Moshe, God’s betrothed is Yisrael. Therefore it says: “Carve out for yourself.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:1:2,"Another explanation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך is: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך HEW THYSELF — thou hast broken the first tablets, do thou therefore hew others. A parable: this may be compared to a king who travelled to a remote country (more lit., to a province over-sea) leaving his betrothed at home with her handmaids. Through the immoral conduct of her handmaids she also gained a bad reputation (more lit., there went forth against her an evil name). Her bridesman arose and tore up the marriage-contract saying: If the king proposes to kill her I shall say to him, “She is not yet thy wife” (the marriage contract which might have served as evidence being destroyed. The king made enquiry, found that the immorality had been only on the hand maids’ side and became reconciled with her. Her bridesman then said to the king, “Write another marriage contract for her because the first has been torn up”. Whereupon the king replied: You tore it up; do you therefore purchase for her new paper and I will write it for her in My handwriting. So, here, too: the King is the Holy One blessed be He, the handmaids are the mixed multitude, the bride’s friend is Moses, and the betrothed of the Holy One, blessed be He, is Israel — therefore it is said <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פסל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לך, “Hew thyself the new tablets” (Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:30)."

—3— **Haue dir aus,** du hast die ersten zerbrochen, darum sollst du die letzten selbst aushauen; das ist mit einem König zu vergleichen, der sich nach einem fernen Lande am Meer) begab und seine Angetraute mit den Mägden zu Hause ließ, infolge der Verderbnis der Mägde aber verbreitete sich ein böses Gerede über die Gattin des Königs; da ging ihr fürsorgender Unterführer hin und zerriss ihre Heiratsurkunde, indem er sprach, sollte der König sie zum Tode verurteilen wollen, so werde ich zu ihm sagen, sie ist noch nicht deine Frau. Der König untersuchte die Sache und fand, dass die Verderbnis nur unter den Mägden gewesen, und versöhnte sich mit ihr. Da sagte ihr Unterführer zu ihm, schreibe ihr eine neue Heiratsurkunde, da die erste zerrissen ist; und der König antwortete ihm, du hast sie zerrissen, so sollst du für sie anderes Papier erwerben, und ich werde eingenhändig darauf schreiben. So auch hier; der König ist der Heilige, gelobt sei Er; die Mägde sind das Mischvolk; der Unterführer, das ist Mosche; und die Angetraute des Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, ist Israel; darum steht, haue dir aus (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 34:2:1,**Be ready.** [Meaning:] prepared.

§§—2—§§ 34:2:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נכון means PREPARED.

—3— **2. Bereit,** vorbereitet. 

---

////—1—//// 34:3:1,"**No man shall go up with you.** Because the first ones (i.e., the First Tablets) were [given] with great uproar and sounds and great throngs, they were affected by the evil eye. There is nothing better for you than being reserved. "

§§—2—§§ 34:3:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואיש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יעלה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמך AND NO MAN SHALL GO UP WITH THEE — Because the first tablets were given amidst great noises and alarms and a vast assembly the “evil eye” had power over them (they did not endure) — there is no finer quality than to be unostentatious! (Midrash Tanchuma 3:9:31).

—3— **3. Und keiner steige mit dir hinauf,** über die ersten Tafeln, weil sie unter lautem Zuruf und in öffentlicher Versammlung gekommen waren, hatte das böse Auge Macht gehabt; es gibt nicht Besseres als Verschwiegenheit (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 34:5:1,"**And he called out the Name, Adonoy.** It is translated by Onkelos: “He called out in the Name of God.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ AND HE CALLED BY NAME, O LORD — We render this in the Targum by, '<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשמא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דה and he (Moses) called on the name of the Lord."

—3— **5. Und verkündete den Namen des Ewigen,** übersetzt der Targum, Er verkündete den Namen des Ewigen. 

---

////—1—//// 34:6:1,"**Adonoy, Adonoy.** This Name signifies the Attribute of Mercy, the first [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' represents mercy] before [man] sins and the second, after he sins and repents. "

§§—2—§§ 34:6:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ THE LORD, THE LORD — This is the attribute of Divine mercy. The one (the first <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳) alludes to God having mercy on the sinner before he sins and the other after he has sinned and repented (Rosh Hashanah 17b)."

—3— **6. Der Ewige ist der Ewige,** das ist die Eigenschaft des Erbarmens; einmal, bevor der Mensch gesündigt, und einmal, nachdem er gesündigt und sich gebessert hat (Rosch hasch. 17b). 

---

////—1—//// 34:6:2,"**Almighty.** This [Name], too, represents the Attribute of Mercy. Similarly, it says: “My God, My God, why have You forsaken me?” and it is not appropriate to say to the Attribute of Retribution, “Why have You forsaken me?” This I have found in Mechilta (15, 2). "

§§—2—§§ 34:6:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל GOD — This is also an attribute of Divine mercy (it is not, as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהים, an attribute of stern justice). Thus also does Scripture say, (Psalms 22:2) “My God, my God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי ,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלי) why hast Thou forsaken me?” — for surely one would not say to the attribute of stern Justice “why hast Thou forsaken me?”! Thus have I found in the Mechilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 15:2:2."

—3— **Gott,** ist auch eine Eigenschaft des Erbarmens; so heißt es auch (Ps. 22, 2), mein Gott, mein Gott, warum hast du mich verlassen; man sagt aber nicht zur Eigenschaft des Gerichtes, warum hast du mich verlassene; so habe ich in der Mechilta (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שירה) gefunden. 

---

////—1—//// 34:6:3,**Slow to anger.** He puts off His anger and does not rush to exact punishment in case he (the sinner) will repent.

§§—2—§§ 34:6:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ארך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפים SLOW TO ANGER — He defers (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאריך) His anger and does not hasten to punish — it may be that the sinner will repent.

—3— **Langmütig,** Er hält Seinen Zorn zurück und straft nicht schnell; vielleicht bessert sich der Sünder. 

---

////—1—//// 34:6:4,"**And abounding in kindness —** to those who require kindness, for they do not have sufficient merits. "

§§—2—§§ 34:6:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חסד AND ABUNDANT IN MERCY — to those who need mercy because they have not sufficient merits to be saved by them.

—3— **Und reich an Gnade,** für diejenigen, die Gnade brauchen, die nicht so viel Verdienste haben. 

---

////—1—//// 34:6:5,**And truth.** [Meaning: He can be depended upon] to reward those who do his will.

§§—2—§§ 34:6:5, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואמת AND TRUTH — faithfully rewarding those who perform His will.

—3— **Und Treue,** guten Lohn zu zahlen denen, die Seinen Willen vollbracht haben. 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:1,"**He preserves kindness.** [I.e., the kindness] which the person does before Him. "

§§—2—§§ 34:7:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נצר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חסד means God keeps (stores up) the mercy which a person does in His presence,"

—3— **7. Er bewahrt die Frömmigkeit,** die ein Mensch vor Ihm übt, auf. 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:2,"**For thousands.** [Meaning:] for two thousand generations. **[Iniquity, transgression.]** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עֲוֹנוֹת are sins committed knowingly; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פְּשָׁעִים are sins committed for the sake of rebellion, which a person does out of spite. "

§§—2—§§ 34:7:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאלפים TO THOUSANDS — to two thousand generations (the plural, “generations”, and “two” is the least that this can imply; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 20:6)."

—3— **Tausenden von Geschlechtern,** 2000 Geschlechtern. 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:3,

§§—2—§§ 34:7:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עונות — These are sins committed presumptuously (with premeditation). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פשעים — These are sins committed rebelliously.

—3— **Verzeiht Schuld und Missetat,** Schuld sind die Frevel, Missetat die Empörung, die ein Mensch begeht, um zu erzürnen (Joma 36b). 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:4,**He clears and He does not clear.** According to its plain meaning it conveys that He does not completely waive any sin but exacts retribution for it bit by bit. But our Sages explained it: He clears those who repent and He does not clear those who do not repent.

§§—2—§§ 34:7:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונקה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ינקה AND WHO WILL BY NO MEANS CLEAR THE GUILTY — According to its plain sense this means that He is not altogether indulgent to sin (He does not entirely remit the punishment), but little by little exacts punishment from, him (the sinner). Our Rabbis, however, have explained: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונקה, And he clears — He clears those who repent, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ינקה, He does not clear — but does not clear those who will not repent (Yoma 86a)."

—3— **Aber straflos lässt Er nicht ausgehen;** nach dem einfachen Sinn bedeutet es, dass Er die Schuld nicht ganz erlässt, sondern den Menschen allmählich abtragen lässt. Unsere Weisen erklären, Er lässt straflos ausgehen diejenigen, die sich bessern, aber nicht diejenigen, die sie nicht bessern (Joma 86a). 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:5,"**Visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children.** When they retain the deeds of their fathers in their hands (i.e., follow in their footsteps), as was already made clear in another verse “of those who hate Me.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:7:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עון <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בנים VISITING THE INIQUITY OF THE FATHERS UPON THE CHILDREN — when they retain in their hands (follow the example of) the evil doings of their ancestors. This must be the meaning because in another verse of a similar character it has already been stated: of them that hate Me (cf. Exodus 20:5: Visiting the iniquity of fathers upon the children, upon the third and fourth generation of them that hate Me (Berakhot 7a; Sanhedrin 27b)."

—3— **Er ahndet die Schuld der Väter an den Kindern,** wenn sie das Werk ihrer Väter festhalten (fortsetzen); er hat ja schon in einem anderen Vers erklärt (20, 5), denen, die mich hassen (Ber. 7a). 

---

////—1—//// 34:7:6,"**And fourth.** [Meaning:] the fourth generation. Consequently it follows that the Attribute of Good (i.e., reward) is greater than the Attribute of Retribution five hundred fold for regarding the Attribute of Good it states: “He preserves kindness for [two] thousand generations.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:7:6," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ועל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רבעים means AND UPON THE FOURTH GENERATION — It follows, therefore, that the measure of good (reward) is greater than the measure of punishment in the proportion of one to five hundred, for in respect to the measure of good it says: “Keeping mercy for thousands” (two thousands at least) (cf. Rashi above: Tosefta Sotah 4:1; see also 
§§—2—§§ 20:5)."

—3— **Und bis ins vierte Geschlecht,** das vierte Geschlecht; daraus ergibt sich, dass die Eigenschaft der Belohnung fünfhundertmal größer ist als die Eigenschaft der Bestrafung; denn bei der Belohnung sagt er, Er bewahrt die Frömmigkeit zweitausend Geschlechtern auf (Tosefta Sota 4). 

---

////—1—//// 34:8:1,"**Moshe hastened.** When Moshe saw the <font color=d50505>»</font>Shechinah<font color=d50505>«</font> passing by and heard the voice of the Proclamation, he immediately prostrated himself. "

§§—2—§§ 34:8:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וימהר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה, AND MOSES MADE HASTE — When Moses saw that the Shechinah passed by and heard the sound of the proclamation he immediately prostrated himself."

—3— **8. Und Mosche eilte;** als Mosche die Schechina vorüberziehen sah und die Stimme der Verkündung vernahm, warf er sich sogleich nieder. 

---

////—1—//// 34:9:1,"**Let My Master go among us —** as You promised us. Since You bear iniquity, and, therefore, if they will be a stiff-necked people and rebel against You — about which You said: “I may destroy you along the way” — You will [nevertheless] forgive our iniquity, etc. There are places where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כִּי is used in place of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אִם . "

§§—2—§§ 34:9:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקרבנו LET MY LORD, I PRAY THEE, GO AMONG US as Thou hast promised (cf. Exodus  33:14), since Thou forgivest iniquity. And even if it be a stiff-necked people and they have rebelled against Thee and Thou didst on that account say, (Exodus 30:3) “lest I consume thee in the way” — yet pardon Thou our iniquity etc. — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי is sometimes used in place of (in the sense of) <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם, “if”."

—3— **9. Möge doch der Ewige in unserer Mitte mit uns ziehen,** wie du verheißen hast; da Du die Schuld verzeihst, und wenn es auch ein hartnäckiges Volk ist und sie widerspenstig gegen Dich sein werden und Du darum gesprochen, dass ich dich nicht auf dem Wege aufreibe (33, 3), so wirst du unsere Schuld verzeihen… <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי ist zuweilen = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אם. 

---

////—1—//// 34:9:2,"**And take us as Your own possession.** Take us to Yourself as a special possession. This is the same request as: “so that I and Your people will be distinguished,” that You not rest Your <font color=d50505>»</font>Shechinah<font color=d50505>«</font> on the nations of the world. "

§§—2—§§ 34:9:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונחלתנו. AND TAKE US FOR THINE INHERITANCE — make us a special inheritance unto Thyself. This is the same request as that contained in (Exodus 33:16) “that we should be different, I and thy people [from all other peoples]” — which means that You should not let Your Shechinah rest upon the other peoples of the world (cf. Rashi on this verse)."

—3— **Und mache uns zu Deinem Anteil,** mache uns zu dem Dir geweihten Anteil; das ist die Bitte (33, 16), dass wir ausgezeichnet werden, ich und Dein Volk, dass Du deine Schechina nicht auf den Völkern der Welt ruhen lässt.

////—1—//// 34:10:1,**I hereby make a covenant —** on this [request of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִפְלִּינוּ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲנִי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְעַמְךָ].

§§—2—§§ 34:10:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כרת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברית [BEHOLD, I] MAKE A COVENANT about this."

—3— **10. Schließe einen Bund,** darauf.

////—1—//// 34:10:2,"**I will perform wonders.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִפְלָאוֹת] has a common derivation with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְנִפְלִינוּ, that is: that you will be set apart in this respect from all the nations of the world — that I will not rest My <font color=d50505>»</font>Shechinah<font color=d50505>«</font> on them. "

§§—2—§§ 34:10:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפלאת — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נפלאת is an expression of the same meaning as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ונפלינו (Exodus 33:16; so that the phrase means: I will make a difference) meaning that you shall be different in this respect from all other peoples — in that My Shechinah will not rest upon them.

////—1—//// 34:14:1,**Jealous is His Name.** He is jealous to exact punishment and He is not indulgent. And this is the idea conveyed by “Jealously” — He is steadfast in His ascendancy and exacts punishment from His enemies.

§§—2—§§ 34:14:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמו WHOSE NAME IS <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנא — Who is zealous (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקנא) to exact punishment from the sinners and is not indulgent towards idolatry. This (the above) is always the meaning of the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנא wherever it is used in connection with God. Consequently <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמו His name (His characteristic) is <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַנָּא that of a zealot, implies: He maintains (insists upon) his superiority over other gods, and punishes His enemies (those who worship idols)."

—3— **14. Eifervoller ist Sein Name,** Er eifert, zu strafen, und erlässt nicht; das bedeutet überall <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קנאה, Er wendet Seine siegreiche Kraft an und straft Seine Feinde.

§§—2—§§ 34:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואכלת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מזבחו AND THOU EAT OF HIS SACRIFICE — You might perhaps think that there is no punishable offence in eating of it, this is not so, but I will account it unto you as though you consent to his idolatrous worship because through this (through partaking of his meals) you will be induced to take your daughters unto your sons (cf. Avodah Zarah 8a)."

—3— **15. Und du würdest von seinem Mahle essen,** indem du meinst, dass dieser Genuss nicht bestraft würde; ich rechne es aber dir an, als hättest du ihren Dienst anerkannt; denn dadurch wirst du dazu kommen, von ihren Töchtern für deine Söhne zu nehmen (Abod. zar. 8a).

////—1—//// 34:19:2,"**And all of your livestock that is male, etc.** [Meaning:] and all of your livestock that is male of the first-born of the cattle and sheep [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פֶּטֶר — “opens,” meaning:] that a male <font color=d50505>»</font>opens<font color=d50505>«</font> its womb. "

—3— **Und alles, was deine Herde Männliches gebiert,** und deine ganze Herde, die Männliches gebiert, das den Mutterschoß erschließt von Rind und Kleinvieh; wenn ein Männliches ihren Mutterschoß erschließt. Erschließen bedeutet öffnen; ebenso (Spr. 17, 14), wie einer, der dem Wasser freien Lauf lässt, so ist der Anfang des Streites; das Taw von <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תזכר drückt die weibliche Form aus und bezieht sich auf die gebärende (Herde).

////—1—//// 34:19:3,**That opens.** A term meaning “opening.” Similarly: “As water (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פּוֹטֵר) is opened so is the start of conflict.” The letter <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת' of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תִּזָּכָר denotes the feminine referring to the birthing animal.

§§—2—§§ 34:19:3,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פטר is an expression denoting “opening”; similar is (Proverbs 17:14) “As if one openeth (letteth run) (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פוטר) water so is the beginning of strife”. The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ת of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תזכר expresses the feminine gender and refers to the animal in labour (i. e. the prefix is 3rd fem. sing., not 2nd masc. sing.: the subject to <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תזכר must be supplied “the mother animal”)."

§§—2—§§ 34:20:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפדה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בשה THOU SHALT REDEEM WITH A LAMB — one gives a lamb to the priest and it remains in his possession with the character of a non-holy object (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חולין — an ordinary animal). ////—1—//// 34:20:3,"**You must break its neck.** He breaks its neck with a large knife. He caused the <font color=d50505>»</font>kohein<font color=d50505>«</font> a monetary loss, therefore, he shall suffer a monetary loss. "

§§—2—§§ 34:20:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וערפתו THEN THOU SHALT BREAK ITS NECK — one breaks its neck with a hatchet and so slays it (Bekhorot 10b). §§—2—§§ 34:20:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בניך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תפדה ALL THE FIRSTBORN OF THY SONS THOU SHALT REDEEM — Five Sela’im are the ransom fixed for him, as it is said (Numbers 18:16) “And those that are to be redeemed, from a month old shalt thou redeem [according to thy valuation, for the money of five shekels]”. ////—1—//// 34:20:5,"**And you must not appear before Me empty-handed.** According to the plain meaning of the verse this is independent [of the first part of the verse] and does not refer back to the first-born, for there is no requirement in the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font> of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּכוֹר to appear before God, but, rather, it is an admonition concerning something else: “And when you go up for the festival to appear [before God], you shall not appear before Me empty-handed; [but] it is a <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvah<font color=d50505>«</font> upon you to bring the burnt-offering designated when appearing before God.” According to the midrashic explanation in the Beraisa it is a redundant verse and is “free” to be used in a <font color=d50505>»</font>gezeirah shavah,<font color=d50505>«</font> to teach about the severance pay to a Hebrew slave that it must be five <font color=d50505>»</font>sela’im<font color=d50505>«</font> worth of each kind, as is [the amount for] the redemption of a first-born. (This is found) in meseches Kiddushin. "

§§—2—§§ 34:20:5," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יראו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריקם AND NONE SHALL APEAR BEFORE ME EMPTY — According to the plain sense of the verse this is an independent statement and does not refer to the firstborn just mentioned — because in connection with the command concerning the firstborn there is no duty of appearing before the Lord; but it is another (a separate) prohibition merely connected by a conjunctive <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ו with the former statement and means: when you go up to the festival gathering to Jerusalem to appear before the Lord, none shall appear before Me empty; it is your duty to bring the burnt offering prescribed for the appearance before My face (Chagigah 7a). According to the Halachic explanation of the Boraitha this portion of the verse is redundant (since the same commandment already appears Exodus 23:15) and is consequently “free” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מופנה) to be used for a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גז""<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ש (an analogy based on verbal similarity in two texts, viz., the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריקם here and in the text Deuteronomy 15:13 <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשלחנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריקם “thou shalt not let him go away <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ריקם”) — it is repeated here after the law about the first born to teach you that the outfit given to a Hebrew slave when he leaves your service should consist of five Sela’im-worth of each of the things (mentioned Deuteronomy 15:14: thy sheep, thy threshing floor, and vinepress) just as the ransom of the firstborn is five Sela’im. Thus are we taught in Treatise Kiddushin 17a."

—3— **Und man erscheine nicht leer vor meinem Angesicht,** nach dem einfachen Sinn des Verses ist dies eine Sache für sich und bezieht sich nicht auf den Erstgeborenen; denn beim Gebot für das Erstgeborene ist das Erscheinen im Heiligtum nicht vorgeschrieben; sondern es ist dies eine andere Verwarnung, wenn ihr zum Feste hinaufzieht, um zu erscheinen, so sollt ihr nicht leer vor meinem Angesicht erscheinen; sondern es ist eine Pflicht für euch, Ganzopfer des Erscheinens vor mir darzubringen (Chagiga 7a). Nach dem Midrasch der Baraitha ist der Vers übrig und frei für eine <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גזרה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שוה, zu lehren, dass die Beschenkung des hebräischen Knechtes (Deut. 15, 13 5 (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רקם ־ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רקם Sela von jeder Art gleich der Auslösung des Erstgeborenen betrage, im Traktat Kiddusch. (17a).

////—1—//// 34:21:1,"**You must cease plowing and harvesting.** Why are plowing and harvesting [the only ones] mentioned? Some of our Sages say [that this refers] to the plowing of the year before the <font color=d50505>»</font>sheviis<font color=d50505>«</font> year which leads into the <font color=d50505>»</font>sheviis<font color=d50505>«</font> year, and the harvest of the <font color=d50505>»</font>sheviis<font color=d50505>«</font> year which extends into the post-<font color=d50505>»</font>sheviis<font color=d50505>«</font> year, so as to teach you that a part of the secular [year] must be added to the holy [year] (i.e., the <font color=d50505>»</font>sheviis<font color=d50505>«</font> year). Accordingly this is the meaning of the verse: “Six days you shall work but on the Seventh Day you must cease. But, of the six days’ work which I permitted to you there is a year in which plowing and harvesting are prohibited. There is no need to state [the prohibition of] plowing and harvesting of the Seventh Year for it has already been stated: “Your field you may not sow, etc.” However others [of the Sages] say that this [verse] speaks only of Shabbos, and [the fact that only] plowing and harvesting are mentioned [is] to teach you that just as the [prohibited] plowing is optional plowing so too is the [prohibited] harvesting optional harvesting, which excludes the harvesting of the <font color=d50505>»</font>omer<font color=d50505>«</font> which is obligatory and takes precedence over Shabbos. "

§§—2—§§ 34:21:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחריש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובקציר IN PLOUGHING TIME AND IN HARVEST [THOU SHALT LEAVE OFF] — Why are ploughing and harvesting specially mentioned (since all work is forbidden on Sabbath)? There are some of our Rabbis who say that this refers to ploughing in the year preceding the Sabbatical year which ploughing passeth into (produces its first fruits in) the seventh year and to harvesting grain that has reached one-third of its maturity during the Sabbatical year which harvesting actually goeth forth into (takes place in) the eighth year, that following the Sabbatical year; and that this statement is intended to teach you that one must add part of the secular time to the holy time (i. e. that one must apply to a certain period before the beginning and after the termination of the Sabbatical year the laws applicable to that year in order to prevent its desecration). Thus, the following is what it (this verse) means: “Six days thou mayest work, but on the seventh day thou shalt rest”; but even with regard to the six days’ work which I have permitted you there are years when ploughing and harvesting are forbidden. This must be the meaning, referring to ploughing in the sixth year and harvesting in the seventh, and it cannot refer to the seventh year itself for it is unnecessary to make any mention of ploughing and harvesting in the seventh year being forbidden, for it is already said (Leviticus 25:4) “[But in the seventh year …] thou shalt neither sow thy field [nor prune thine vineyard]”! Others, however, hold that Scripture in this part of the text, is only speaking of the ordinary Sabbath day, as in the first part, and ploughing and harvesting which are specially mentioned in it as being forbidden on the Sabbath are mentioned to suggest to you the following: What is the characteristic of ploughing? It is an optional act (no such work being commanded anywhere in the Law)! So, too, is harvesting forbidden on Sabbath only when it constitutes an optional act! There is, therefore, excluded the harvesting of the barley for the “Omer” (cf. Leviticus 23:10: ye shall reap the harvest thereof) which is obligatory and which therefore supersedes the Sabbath (occasions a suspension of the Sabbath laws) (Rosh Hashanah 9a)."

—3— **21. Im Pflügen und im Ernten;** warum sind Pflügen und Ernten erwähnt? Manche von unseren Lehrern sagen, es bezieht sich auf das Pflügen im sechsten Jahr, das in das siebte hineinwirkt, und das Ernten des siebten, das erst im achten stattfindet, um dich zu lehren, dass man vom Unheiligen zum Heiligen hinzufüge (Rosch. hasch. 9a); und so ist der Sinn, sechs Tage arbeite, und am siebten Tag feiere, aber für die Arbeit der sechs Tage, die ich dir erlaubt habe, gibt es ein Jahr, in dem das Pflügen und das Ernten verboten sind; und man braucht nicht zu sagen, Pflügen und Ernten im siebten Jahr selbst, da bereits steht (Lev. 25, 4), dein Feld besäe nicht. Und manche sagen, der Vers spricht nur vom Sabbat, und Plfügen und Ernten, die darin erwähnt sind, sagen dir, wie Pflügen immer freiwillig ist, so ist auch nur von freiwilligem Ernten die Rede; damit ist das Schneiden des Omer (Lev. 23,10) ausgeschlossen, das eine Pflicht ist und den Sabbat verdrängt.

////—1—//// 34:22:1,**The first crops of the wheat harvest.** When you bring the “two breads” made from the wheat.

§§—2—§§ 34:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קציר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חטים [THE FESTIVAL] OF THE FIRST OF THE WHEAT HARVEST — It is so called because on it you offer the two loaves of wheat (Leviticus 23:17).

—3— **22. Der Erstlinge der Weizenernte;** denn an ihm bringst du zwei Brote aus Weizenmehl.

////—1—//// 34:22:2,**The first crops.** So-called because it is the first <font color=d50505>»</font>minchah<font color=d50505>«</font> — “meal offering” which is brought to the sanctuary from the new wheat for the <font color=d50505>»</font>omer-minchah<font color=d50505>«</font> which is brought on Pesach [comes] from the barley.

§§—2—§§ 34:22:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורי OF THE FIRST [OF THE WHEAT HARVEST] — It is so called because it (the offering of the two loaves) is the first meal offering which is brought in the Temple of the new wheat crop; for the meal offering of the Omer which had already been brought on Passover was of barley (Menachot 84a).

—3— **Erstlinge,** denn es ist das erste Speiseopfer, das von neuem Weizen gebracht wird; denn das Speiseopfer, das Omer, das am Pessach gebracht wurde, bestand aus Gerste.

The term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֲסִיפָה here denotes bringing it into the house, as in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַאֲסַפְתּוֹ) bring it into your house.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:22:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וחג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האסיף AND THE FESTIVAL OF INGATHERING — the festival that falls at the time of the year when you gather in thy produce from the field into the barns. ////—1—//// 34:22:4,"**At the turn of the year —** which is when the year “returns,” [i.e.] at the beginning of the following year. "

§§—2—§§ 34:22:4," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקופת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השנה lit., [THE FESTIVAL …] THE YEARS CIRCUIT — i. e. the festival at the coming round of the year — at the beginning of the coming (the new) year. "

////—1—//// 34:22:5,**At the turn.** A term meaning going around and making a circuit

§§—2—§§ 34:22:5,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תקופת is a term denoting going round.
