////—1—//// 34:23:1,**All your males.** [Meaning:] all the males among you. [Some of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> mentioned here appear elsewhere!] Many of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mitzvos<font color=d50505>«</font> in the Torah are said and repeated. There are even some mentioned three or four times. This is to hold responsible and to punish [the transgressors] according to the number of negative precepts that they contain and according to the number of positive precepts which they contain.

§§—2—§§ 34:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זכורך means all the males among you (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 23:17 and the note thereon). — Many precepts of the Torah are stated and then repeated, aye, some of them three times and even four (this section, for instance, is, with a few alterations, identical with the contents of chapter Exodus 23:12—19) in order to declare him who infringes them guilty and to punish him for each of the number of prohibitions which are connected with them and for each of the number of positive commands which are connected with them."

—3— **23. Alle deine Männlichen,** alle Männlichen in deiner Mitte; viele Gebote in der Torah stehen wiederholt und manche sogar drei- und viermal, um auf die Anzahl der Verbote dabei und die Anzahl der Gebote dabei schuldig zu machen und dafür zu strafen. 

---

////—1—//// 34:24:1,"**I will drive out.** As Onkelos translates it: “I will drive out.” Similarly: “Begin (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רָשׁ) to drive out,” and similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיּוֹרֶשׁ) He drove out the Emorites.” All these being terms for “driving out.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אוריש means as the Targum has it <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתריך, I will drive out. Similar is (Deuteronomy 2:31) “Begin to drive out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>רש)”; and similar is, (Numbers 21:32) “and drove out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויורש) the Amorites” — all having the sense of expelling."

—3— **24. Austreibe,** wie der Targum sagt, austreibe; ebenso (Deut. 2, 24) beginne auszutreiben; ebenso (Num. 21, 32), und trieben den Emori aus, in der Bedeutung vertreiben. 

---

////—1—//// 34:24:2,"**I will expand your boundaries —** and, consequently, you will be far from the Temple and will be unable to appear before Me constantly. Therefore I establish for you these three festivals. "

§§—2—§§ 34:24:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והרחבתי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גבלך [I WILL DRIVE OUT THE NATIONS BEFORE THEE] AND ENLARGE THY BOUNDARIES — and consequently you may be far from the Chosen House (the Temple) and you will then not be able to appear before Me continually; therefore I appoint for you these three seasons.

—3— **Und ich dein Gebiet erweitere,** so dass du von dem Hause der Erwählung weit entfernt bist und nicht stets vor meinem Angesicht erscheinen kannst; darum bestimme ich für dich diese drei Feste. 

---

////—1—//// 34:25:1,"**Do not slaughter, etc.** Do not slaughter the <font color=d50505>»</font>korban Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font> while <font color=d50505>»</font>chometz<font color=d50505>«</font> still remains [in your possession]. This is an admonition to one who slaughters or to one who sprinkles [the blood] or to any member of the group. "

§§—2—§§ 34:25:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תשחט <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THOU SHALT NOT OFFER [THE BLOOD OF MY SACRIFICE TOGETHER WITH LEAVEN] — i. e. thou shalt not kill the Passover lamb whilst leaven is still existent in your possession. This is an admonition addressed to him who slaughters the Passover lamb, as well as to him who sprinkles its blood or to one of the members of the party formed to eat that lamb in company (Pesachim 63a)."

—3— **25. Schlachte nicht,** schlachte nicht das Pessachopfer, während noch Gesäuertes vorhanden ist; das ist eine Verwarnung für den, der schlachtet oder das Blut sprengt, oder für einen von der dazu gehörigen Gesellschaft (Pess. 63b). 

---

////—1—//// 34:25:2,"**Do not allow to remain overnight.** As Onkelos translates: [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְלָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יְבִיתוּן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְצַפְרָא — Do not allow it to remain overnight until morning. — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בַּר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מִמַּדְבְּחָא — away from the altar — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תַּרְבֵּי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נִכְסַת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חַגָּא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דְפִסְחָא — the fat of the <font color=d50505>»</font> korbon Pesach<font color=d50505>«</font>]. Remaining overnight does not render it unfit if it has been on top of the altar, and the infringement of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לִינָה — “remaining overnight” applies only [if left off the altar] till dawn. "

§§—2—§§ 34:25:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ילין NEITHER SHALL [THE SACRIFICE OF THE FESTIVAL OF PASSOVER] REMAIN OVER NIGHT — Understand this as the Targum renders it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יביתון ... <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממדבחא … ‎“There shall not remain overnight away from the altar till the morning the fat of the sacrifice” — this law of leaving the fat away from the altar overnight does not serve to invaliditate the sacrifice if it has been placed on the top of the altar some time during the night, even if it be not entirely burnt by morning, nor is the law about leaving the fat overnight infringed except if it has not been placed on the altar by the dawn of the morning (but any time during the night one may lift it up from the pavement on to the altar (Zevachim 87a; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 23:18)."

—3— **Und es soll nicht übernachten,** wie der Targum sagt, hat das Übernachten oben auf dem Altäre nicht diese Wirkung und beginnt das Übernachten erst mit dem Anbruch des Morgens. 

---

////—1—//// 34:25:3,**The offering of the Pesach festival.** [This refers to] the parts to be burnt on the altar. From here you may learn the laws of all fats and limbs that require burning.

§§—2—§§ 34:25:3, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זבח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חג <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפסח means the pieces of its fat (which had to be burnt on the altar). From here you may derive the law concerning all cases of burning the pieces of fat and the limbs of sacrifices (i. e. you may derive the general rule regarding all sacrifices).

—3— **Das Opfer des Pessachfestes,** seine Fettstücke; von hier entnimmst du die Vorschrift für jedes Verdampfen von Fettstücken und Gliedern. 

---

////—1—//// 34:26:1,"**The first fruits of your land —** of the seven species which are listed in praise of your land, “a land of wheat, barley, grapes, figs, pomegranates, etc.” the “honey” [in the list] referring to date-honey. "

§§—2—§§ 34:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ראשית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכורי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדמתך THE FIRST OF THE FIRST-FRUITS OF THY GROUND [THOU SHALT BRING INTO THE HOUSE OF THE LORD THY GOD] — but only from the seven kinds of produce which are mentioned as an excellency of thy land (Deuteronomy 8:8) “a land of wheat and barley and vines etc (Mishnah Bikkurim 1:3). The <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>דבש mentioned in this verse is date honey (not that of bees).

—3— **26. Das Vorzüglichste der Erstlingsfrüchte deines Bodens,** von den sieben Arten, die zum Lobe deines Landes genannt werden (Deut. 8, 8), ein Land des Weizens, der Gerste, des Weinstockes … und des Honigs, das ist Dattelhonig. 

---

////—1—//// 34:26:2,"**You must not cook a kid.** This is an admonition against mixing meat with milk. It is repeated three times in the Torah: once regarding eating, once regarding benefit from it, and once prohibiting the cooking of it. "

§§—2—§§ 34:26:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבשל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי THOU SHALT NOT SEETHE A KID [IN ITS MOTHER’S MILK] — This is a prohibition to mix meat with milk. This is written three times in the Torah: once to prohibit the eating of such mixture, once to prohibit us from deriving any other benefit (besides eating) from it and once to prohibit the cooking of it (Chullin 115b; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 23:19)."

—3— **Koche nicht das Bäckchen,** das ist eine VerWarnung, Fleisch und Milch nicht zu vermischen; dieselbe steht dreimal in der Torah, einmal, um das Essen, einmal, um den Nutzen davon und einmal, um das Kochen zu verbieten (Chullin 115b). 

---

////—1—//// 34:26:3,"**A kid.** Any tender young animal is included, even a calf or a sheep. From that which it is necessary [for the Torah] to explain in many places: “a goat’s kid” you may derive that a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גְּדִי by itself includes all sucklings (i.e., any animal). "

§§—2—§§ 34:26:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי A KID — Any tender young animal is comprehended under the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי, a calf and a lamb also. From the fact that the writer felt it necessary to state specifically in several passages “a kid of the goat” you may learn that the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גדי without further definition implies any suckling (young animal) (Chullin 113a; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 23:19)."

—3— **Bäckchen,** jedes zarte Junge ist darunter zu verstehen, auch Kalb und Lamm; da er an vielen Stellen erst erklären muss, ein Ziegenböckchen, kannst du daraus entnehmen, dass unter einem Bäckchen ohne weitere Bezeichnung alles, was noch saugt, zu verstehen ist. 

---

////—1—//// 34:26:4,"**In its mother’s milk —** to the exclusion of a fowl that has no mother’s milk, whose prohibition [against cooking it or eating it with milk] is not a Scriptural prohibition, but rather a Rabbinic decree. "

§§—2—§§ 34:26:4, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחלב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אמו IN THE MOTHER’S MILK — A fowl is therefore really excluded from this law since it has no milk; for the prohibition regarding it (using it with milk) is not a Biblical law but only an enactment of the Soferim (Chullin 113a).

—3— **In der Milch seiner Mutter,** schließt Geflügel aus, das keine Milch hat und das nicht von der Torah, sondern von den Weisen verboten ist (Chullin 113a). 

---

////—1—//// 34:27:1,**Write these words down for yourself.** But you are not permitted to write down the oral Torah.

§§—2—§§ 34:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדברים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>האלה [WRITE THOU] THESE WORDS — These words, but you are not permitted to write down the “Oral Law” (Gittin 60b)."

—3— **27. Diese Worte,** du darfst aber die mündliche Torah nicht aufschreiben (Schemot Rabbah). 

---

////—1—//// 34:29:1,**And when Moshe came down.** When he brought the Second Tablets on Yom Kippur.

§§—2—§§ 34:29:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויהי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ברדת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND IT CAME TO PASS WHEN MOSES WENT DOWN [FROM MOUNT SINAI] — when he brought the second tablets on the Day of Atonement.

—3— **29. Und es war, als Mosche herabstieg,** als er am Jomhakipurim die letzten Tafeln brachte. 

---

////—1—//// 34:29:2,"**That...had become radiant.** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָרַן is a term having a common root with <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קַרְנַיִם (horns) because light shines out and projects as a sort of “horn.” From where was Moshe privileged to these rays of splendor? Our Sages say [that it was] from the cave where God put His Hand on his face, as it states: “And I will cover with My Hand.” "

§§—2—§§ 34:29:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עור <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניו THAT THE SKIN OF HIS FACE BEAMED — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרן is an expression connected with the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרנים “horns”, and the phrase, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קרן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אור, the light-“horned” , is used here because light radiates from a point and projects Like a horn. And whence was Moses privileged to have the rays of glory? Our Rabbis said that they originated at the time when he was in the cave, for the Holy One, blessed be He, then put His hand upon his face, as it is said, (Exodus 33:22) “And I will shelter thee with My hand” (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 37)."

—3— **Dass strahlte,** vom Ausdruck Hörner; denn das Licht strahlt und verbreitet sich horn- (kegel-) förmig. Wodurch aber erwarb sich Mosche die Strahlen des Glanzes? Unsere Lehrer sagen, weil in der Höhle der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, Seine Hand auf sein Angesicht legte; so heißt es (33, 22), ich breite meine Hand aus (Tanchuma). 

---

////—1—//// 34:30:1,"**They were afraid to come close to him.** Come and see how great is the effect of sin! For before they stretched out their hands to commit sin (i.e., the Golden Calf) what is stated? “And the vision of the Glory of God was like a consuming fire at the top of the mountain before the eyes of the B’nei Yisrael,” and they had no fear nor trepidation. But once they made the Calf, even from the rays of Moshe they trembled and were frightened. "

§§—2—§§ 34:30:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וייראו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מגשת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אליו AND THEY WERE AFRAID TO STEP NIGH UNTO HIM — Come and see how great is the power (influence) of sin! For before they streched forth their hand to sin what does Scripture say? (Exodus 24:17) “And the sight of the glory of the Lord was like devouring fire on the top of the mountain in the eyes of the children of Israel”, — and yet they were not afraid and did not tremble! But after they made the golden calf they recoiled and trembled even at the sight of the rays of glory of Moses! (Sifrei Bamidbar 1:8) "

—3— **30. Und sie fürchteten sich, zu ihm hinzutreten,** kommt und sieh, wie groß die Wirkung der Sünde ist; solange sie ihre Hände nicht nach der Sünde ausgestreckt hatten, was sagt da der Vers (24, 17)? Und die Erscheinung der Herrlichkeit des Ewigen war gleich verzehrendem Feuer auf dem Gipfel des Berges vor den Augen von ganz Israel, und sie fürchteten sich nicht und bebten nicht; nachdem sie aber das Kalb gemacht hatten, erschraken und bebten sie sogar vor den Strahlen des Glanzes von Mosche (Sifre Naso). 

---

////—1—//// 34:31:1,**Leaders of the congregation —** is the same as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְשִׂיאֵי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הָעֵדָה — “the leaders of the Congregation.”

§§—2—§§ 34:31:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנשאים <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בעדה THE PRINCES IN THE CONGREGATION — is the same as the more usual expression <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשיאי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העדה, the princes of the congregation."

—3— **31. Fürsten in der Gemeinde** = Fürsten der Gemeinde. 

---

////—1—//// 34:31:2,**And Moshe spoke to them —** the message of God. Thus this entire subject is in the present (ongoing) tense.

§§—2—§§ 34:31:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלהם AND MOSES SPOKE TO THEM the message of the Almighty. This whole section (i. e. all the verbs in it) denotes frequentative action (thus <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידבר means “Moses used to say”, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקרא meant “He used to call”, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגשו means “they used to come near” etc)."

—3— **Und Mosche redete zu ihnen,** den Auftrag des Ewigen; der ganze Abschnitt bedeutet eine wiederholte Handlung. 

---

////—1—//// 34:32:1,"**After that, they came close.** [I.e.], after he taught the elders he would again teach that section or that law to all Yisrael. The Sages have taught: What was the order of the teaching of the Torah? Moshe would learn from the Almighty. Then Aharon would enter and Moshe would teach him his chapter. Aharon moved away and sat on Moshe’s left. Whereupon his (Aharon’s) sons would enter and Moshe would teach them their chapter. They then moved away and Elazar sat on Moshe’s right and Isamar on Aharon’s left. Whereupon the elders would enter and Moshe would teach them their chapter. The elders moved away and sat on the sides. Whereupon the entire people would enter and Moshe taught them their chapter. Consequently the lesson came into the possession of the people once into the possession of the elders, twice, into the possession of Aharon’s sons, thrice, and into the hands of Aharon, four times, etc., as it is all cited in Maseches Eiruvin. "

§§—2—§§ 34:32:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואחרי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נגשו AND AFTERWARDS [THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL] STEPPED NIGH — After he (Moses) had taught the elders he used again to teach the section or the single Halacha in question to the Israelites. The Rabbis have taught: How was the system of teaching? Moses used to learn the law from the mouth of the Almighty; Aaron entered and Moses taught him his lesson. Now Aaron moved away and took his seat to the left of Moses. Then his (Aaron’s) sons entered and Moses taught them their lesson. They moved away and Eleazar took his seat to the right of Moses, whilst Ithamar sat down at Aaron’s left. The elders then entered and Moses taught them their lesson. The elders moved away and took their seat at the side. Finally the whole people entered and Moses taught them their lesson. Consequently what was taught came into the possession of the whole people once, into the possession of the elders twice, into the possession of Aaron’s sons thrice and into Aaron’s possession four times etc. — as it is stated in Eruvin 54b."

—3— **32. Und dann traten hin,** nachdem er die Ältesten belehrt hatte, wiederholte und lehrte er Israel den Abschnitt oder die Halacha. Die Weisen lehren in einer Baraitha, wie war die Ordnung der Mischna? Mosche lernte aus dem Munde des Allmächtigen; dann trat Aharon ein, und Mosche wiederholte ihm den Abschnitt; Aharon erhob sich und setzte sich zur Linken von Mosche; dann traten seine Söhne ein und Mosche wiederholte auch ihnen den Abschnitt; sie erhoben sich, Elasar setzte sich zur Rechten von Mosche und Itamar zur Linken von Aharon; dann traten die Ältesten ein, und Mosche wiederholte abermals den Abschnitt; die Ältesten erhoben sich und setzten sich an die Seiten, und das ganze Volk trat ein; ünd Mosche wiederholte zum viertenmal den Abschnitt; daraus ergibt sich, dass das ganze Volk einmal, die Ältesten zweimal, die Söhne Aharons dreimal, Aharon viermal den Abschnitt gehört hatte; wie in Erubin (54b) steht. 

---

////—1—//// 34:33:1,"**He placed a cover over his face.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסְוֶה is] as Onkelos translates it: “a face cover”; it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסְוֶה) is an Aramaic word [meaning “to look”]. It is found in the Gemara: “Her heart (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סְוִי) saw.” Also in <font color=d50505>»</font>Kesuvos<font color=d50505>«</font> (60a): <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הֲוָה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קָא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסְוֶה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְאַפָּהּ where it has the meaning of “looking,” i.e., he gazed at her. Here, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסְוֶה refers to a cloth placed in front of the face and the area of the eyes. And out of respect to the “rays of splendor” so that they should not all become satiated by the sight, he would place the cover in front of them (his eyes). He would remove it when speaking to the Israelites and when God was speaking with him until he went out. And when he went out [to teach God’s words] he would go out without the cover — "

§§—2—§§ 34:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויתן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה AND HE PUT A VEIL ON HIS FACE — Render it (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה) as the Targum does: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אפי, a cover for his face. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה is an Aramaic expression (from the root <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סוי, “to look”). It occurs in the Talmud (Ketubot 62b) “her heart perceived (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סּוי), and again in Ketubot 60a “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאפה”, where <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה is an expression for looking: “he looked into her face”, i. e. he gazed at her. Here, too, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסוה denotes a cloth that was put in front of the face and of the region of the eyes. And out of reverence for the “rays of glory” — that not everybody should feast himself on them — Moses used to put the veil in front of them (the eyes), but took it off during the time when he spoke to Israel, and during the time when the Omnipresent conversed with him until the moment when he was going out and also when he went out he went out without the veil."

—3— **33. Legte er eine Hülle auf sein Angesicht,** wie der Targum sagt, eine Hülle fürs Angesicht; es ist eine Wurzel, die im Aramäischen vorkommt; im Talmud (Ketubot 62b) ihr Herz erkannte; ferner in Ketubot 60a, schaute das Kind in ihr Angesicht, bedeutet hinsehen, es betrachtete sie; auch hier eine Hülle, ein Tuch, das vor das Angesicht und vor die Augen gelegt wurde; dem Strahlenglanz zu Ehren, dass sich nicht alle daran weideten, legte er die Hülle davor und nahm sie ab, während er mit Israel sprach und während der Ewige mit ihm sprach.  **Bis er herauskam,** und wenn er herauskam, kam er ohne Hülle. 

---

////—1—//// 34:34:1,**and he would speak to the B’nei Yisrael —** and they would see the “rays of splendor” in his face. And when he would leave them —

§§—2—§§ 34:34:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ודבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל … <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וראו AND HE SPOKE UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL… AND THEY SAW the rays of glory on his face; and when he moved away from them ...

—3— **34. Und redete zu den Kindern Israel, und sie sahen** den Strahlenglanz in seinem Angesicht; und wenn er sich von ihnen entfernte. 

---

////—1—//// 34:35:1,**Moshe would replace the cover over his face until he would come to speak to Him.** And when he came to speak with Him he would remove it from his face.

§§—2—§§ 34:35:1,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והשיב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המסוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פניו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>באו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו MOSES REPLACED THE VEIL UPON HIS FACE UNTIL HE CAME IN TO SPEAK WITH HIM — but when he came in to speak with Him he took it off his face. 

—3— **35. Legte Mosche die Hülle wieder auf sein Angesicht, bis er hineinging,** dass Er mit ihm spreche, und wenn er hineinging, daß Er mit ihm spreche, nahm er sie von seinem Angesicht. 

---

////—1—//// 35:1:1,"**And Moshe assembled —** on the day following Yom Kippur when he came down from the mountain. It (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וַיַּקְהֵל) is in the causative form, for one does not assemble people, literally, with one’s hands but, rather, they are “caused to be assembled” by means of his saying so. The correct version of this in Onkelos is: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְאַכְנִישׁ — “He caused that they assemble.” "

§§—2—§§ 35:1:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקהל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND MOSES ASSEMBLED [ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL] — on the morrow after the Day of Atonement when he came down from the mountain. It (the word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקהל) is used in the verbal form that expresses the idea of causing a thing to be done, because one does not actually assemble people with one’s hands, but they are assembled by his command. The Targum therefore should be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואכניש (not <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכנש as some editions have)."

—3— **35, 1. <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקהל. Mosche versammelte,** am Tage nach Jomhakipurim, als er vom Berge herabgestiegen; <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויקהל ist Hifilform; denn man sammelt Menschen nicht mit den Händen, sondern sie versammeln sich auf eine Aufforderung hin; der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואבניש Afel. 

---

////—1—//// 35:2:1,"**Six days.** He first admonished them concerning Shabbos before commanding them about the works of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon,<font color=d50505>«</font> saying, in effect, that it does not supercede the Shabbos. "

§§—2—§§ 35:2:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ששת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ימים SIX DAYS [MAY WORK BE DONE] — He intentionally mentioned to them the prohibition in reference to the Sabbath before the command about the building of the Tabernacle in order to intimate that it does not set aside (supersede) the Sabbath (cf. Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 35:1:1).

—3— **2. An sechs Tagen,** er schickte die Sabbatverwarnung dem Befehl, die Wohnung zu bauen, voraus, um zu sagen, dass dieser nicht den Sabbat verdränge (Mech.). 

---

////—1—//// 35:3:1,"**You must not kindle a fire.** Some of our Sages say: Kindling a fire, a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לַאו — a negative precept, “went out” (i.e., was singled out to indicate this new law). Others say it “went out” (i.e., was singled out) to separate [the <font color=d50505>»</font>melachos<font color=d50505>«</font> of Shabbos]. "

§§—2—§§ 35:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תבערו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אש YE SHALL NOT KINDLE A FIRE [THROUGHOUT YOUR HABITATIONS ON THEE SABBATH DAY] — There are some of our Rabbis who say that the law about kindling fire is singled out (more lit., goes forth from the general proposition; i. e. it is specially mentioned here although it is included in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>תעשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאכה, the law prohibiting all work on Sabbath) in order to constitute it a mere negative command (thus indicating that, like all other negative commands, its infringement is punishable by lashes but does not make the offender liable to death as does the doing of other work on Sabbath). Others, however, say that it was singled out in order to separate the various kinds of work comprised in the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלאכה (thus indicating that each transgression of the Sabbath law is to be atoned for separately if several of them have been committed at the same time and under the same circumstances) (cf. Shabbat 70a; Yevamot 6b; Sanhedrin 35b; cf. also Pesachim 5b)."

—3— **3. Zündet kein Feuer an,** manche von unseren Lehrern sagen, das Anzünden steht besonders, um zu sagen, dass es nur ein einfaches Verbot (ohne Steinigung und Ausrottung) sei, und manche sagen, als Beispiel, dass das Sabbatverbot mit seinen Folgen auf jede einzelne Arbeit anzuwenden sei (Schabbat 70a). 

---

////—1—//// 35:4:1,"**This is the word that Adonoy has commanded —** me, to tell you. "

§§—2—§§ 35:4:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הדבר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשד <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה׳ THIS IS THE THING WHICH THE LORD COMMANDED me, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לאמר TO TELL you."

—3— **4. Das ist das Wort, das der Ewige befohlen hat,** mir, um es euch zu sagen. 

---

////—1—//// 35:5:1,**Who is generous of heart.** Since it is his heart that inspires him [to give] he is called “generous of heart.” I have already explained the contributions to the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> and its work in the place where they were commanded.

§§—2—§§ 35:5:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדיב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבו [WHOSOEVER] IS OF A WILLING HEART — Because his heart prompts one to generosity, he is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדיב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב, one who is prompted to generosity by the heart. I have already explained the various materials which formed the contribution towards the Tabernacle and the work done for it in the passages where the commands about them were given."

—3— **5. Der freiwilligen Herzens ist;** weil ihn sein Herz dazu antreibt, wird er <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נדיב <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לב genannt; die Gaben für die Wohnung und ihre Herstellung habe ich bereits am Orte ihres Befehles erklärt. 

---

////—1—//// 35:11:1,**The <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font>** The lower drapes which are visible on the inside are referred to as <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font>

§§—2—§§ 35:11:1,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן THE TABERNACLE — The lower curtains which were visible within the building are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכן.

—3— **11. Die Wohnung,** die unteren Teppiche, die im Inneren sichtbar waren, werden Wohnung genannt. 

---

////—1—//// 35:11:2,**Its tent.** This refers to the covering of the goat-hair drapes which serve as a roof.

§§—2—§§ 35:11:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהלו ITS TENT — this is the covering of goats’ skins which was made to serve as a roofing.

—3— **Ihr Zelt,** das ist das Zelt aus Ziegenhaarteppichen, das als Dach für jene gemacht wurde. 

---

////—1—//// 35:11:3,**And its cover.** The covering of the rams’ skins and the <font color=d50505>»</font>tachash<font color=d50505>«</font>-skins.

§§—2—§§ 35:11:3,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מכסהו AND ITS COVERING — the covering of rams’ skins and tachash skins.

—3— **Und ihre Decke,** die Decke aus Widder- und Tachaschfellen. 

---

////—1—//// 35:12:1,"**And the partition screen.** This was the <font color=d50505>»</font>paroches<font color=d50505>«</font> of the partition Anything that serves as a shield whether horizontally, whether vertically can be referred to as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָסָךְ or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סְכַךְ . Similarly: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שַׂכְתָּ) You have protected him [from above],” [or:] “Behold I (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שָׂךְ) will protect your road.” "

§§—2—§§ 35:12:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פרכת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המסך means THE CURTAIN OF (that serves for) PARTITIONING — Everything that screens an object, whether it hangs above or in front of it is called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָסָךְ or <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סְכַךְ. Of similar meaning are: (Job 1:10) “[Hast Thou not] put a partition in front of him?” (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שכת = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סכת); (Hosea 2:8) “Behold I will partition off (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סך = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שך) thy way [with thorns]”."

—3— **12. Und den Vorhang zur Scheidung,** den Vorhang der Scheidewand; jede Sache, die einen Schutz bildet, sei es oben, sei es seitwärts, wird <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסך und <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>סכך genannt; ebenso (Job 1, 10), Du schützest ihn; (Hosch. 2, 8) siehe, ich versperre deinen Weg. 

---

////—1—//// 35:13:1,**The show bread.** I have explained that it was so called because it had a face in two directions for it was made like an open box.

§§—2—§§ 35:13:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לחם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפנים THE SHOW BREAD — I have already explained (Exodus 25:29) that it was so called because it had two faces turning in this direction and in that, because it was made like a case open on two sides."

—3— **13. Schaubrot,** habe ich bereits erklärt, weil es nach jeder Seite ein Angesicht hatte; denn es war wie ein auf zwei Seiten offener Kasten gemacht.

////—1—//// 35:14:1,**And its vessels.** [I.e.] its tongs and its scoops.

§§—2—§§ 35:14:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כליה AND ITS VESSELS — the tongs and snuff-dishes.

—3— **14. Und seine Geräte,** Zänglein und Pfännlein.

////—1—//// 35:14:2,**Its lamps.** <font color=d50505>»</font>Loces<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French; the scoops into which the oil and wicks are put.

§§—2—§§ 35:14:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נרתיה ITS LAMPS — luces in old French — bowls into which the oil and the wicks were placed.

—3— **Seine Ölbehälter,** Lampen in andere Sprachen, Behälter, in welche das Öl und die Dochte kamen. 

---

////—1—//// 35:14:3,"**Oil for the light.** It, too, required talented people for it is different from other oils, as is explained in Tractate Menachos: He allows it to ripen on top of the olive tree and it thereby is crushed and [yet remains] clear. "

§§—2—§§ 35:14:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שמן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המאר AND THE OIL ALSO FOR THE LIGHT — This also required wise-hearted men for preparing it (and therefore Scripture mentions it also after its statement v. 10 “And every wise hearted man … shall make…”), for it was different from other oils, as it is explained in Menachot 86a: he lets it (the olive) ripen on the top of the olive-tree etc. and thus it (the oil) is “beaten and yet clear” as Scripture prescribes (Exodus 27:20)."

—3— **Und das Öl der Beleuchtung,** auch dafür waren Männer weisen Herzens nötig; denn es war von anderen Ölen verschieden, wie in Menachot (86a) erklärt wird, er pflückte vom Wipfel des Ölbaumes, und es war gestoßen und lauter. 

---

////—1—//// 35:15:1,**The screen for the entrance.** The curtain on the eastern side where there were no planks nor drapes.

§§—2—§§ 35:15:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הפתח THE SCREEN FOR THE ENTRANCE — the curtain that was in front of the east side of the Tabernacle, for there were neither boards nor curtains there."

—3— **15. Den Vorhang des Eingangs,** ein Vorhang vor der Ostseite, an der weder Balken noch Teppiche waren. 

---

////—1—//// 35:17:1,**Its pillars and its sockets.** Here you have <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חָצֵר referred to both as masculine and feminine. There are many such instances.

§§—2—§§ 35:17:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמדיו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדניה ITS COLUMNS AND ITS SOCKETS — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עמדיו has a masculine and <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדניה a feminine suffix; thus <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצר is here used as (lit., called) masculine and feminine noun. Similar it is with many things (cf. Rashi on Genesis 32:9)."

—3— **17. Seine Säulen und seine Füße,** siehe, der Hof <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חצר wird hier sowohl als Maskulinum als auch als Femininum gebraucht, und so viele Dinge (Gen. 32, 8). 

---

////—1—//// 35:17:2,**And the screen for the entrance of the enclosure.** A curtain spread on the eastern side over the 20 middle <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of the width of that courtyard. For the total width was 50 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of which 15 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of the northern end were closed as well as on the southern end as it is said: “and 15 <font color=d50505>»</font>amohs<font color=d50505>«</font> of curtain for one end.”

§§—2—§§ 35:17:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסך <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שער <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>החצר AND THE SCREEN FOR THE GATE OF THE ENCLOSURE — the curtain which was hanging on the east side covering the twenty middle cubits in the width of the enclosure which latter was fifty cubits wide. Of this fifteen cubits on the north side were closed by hangings and so, too, on the south side, as it is said, (Exodus 27:14, 15) “The hangings of one side of the gate shall be fifteen cubits … [and on the other side shall be hangings fifteen cubits]”."

—3— **Und den Vorhang am Tor des Hofes,** ein Vorhang war an der Ostseite ausgebreitet für die mittleren 20 Ellen der Breite des Hofes; der Hof war 50 Ellen breit, und 15 Ellen davon waren an der Nordseite geschlossen und ebenso an der Südseite; so heißt es (27,14), und 15 Ellen Vorhänge an der Seite. 

---

////—1—//// 35:18:1,"**The stakes.** To insert them and to tie into them the ends of the drapes into the ground, so that they will not sway in the wind. "

§§—2—§§ 35:18:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יתדת THE PINS — in order to insert them into the ground and to fasten thereby the edges of the curtains that they should not be moved about by the wind.

—3— **18. Pflöcke,** um sie in die Erde einzuschlagen und die Säume der Teppiche an der Erde daran festzubinden, damit sie sich nicht im Winde bewegten.

§§—2—§§ 35:18:2, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מיתריהם THEIR CORDS to bind with.

—3— **Ihre Seile,** Seile zum Festbinden.

////—1—//// 35:19:1,"**The covering cloths** — with which to cover the ark, the <font color=d50505>»</font>shulchan,<font color=d50505>«</font> the <font color=d50505>»</font>Menorah,<font color=d50505>«</font> and the altars when they had to be removed for the journeys. "

§§—2—§§ 35:19:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בגדי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השרד THE KNITTED GARMENTS — to cover up the Ark, the table, the candelabrum and the altars at the time of removing and packing up the articles in the Tabernacle when they set out on their journeyings."

—3— **19. Gewänder des Dienstes,** um damit die heilige Lade, den Tisch, den Leuchter und die Altäre beim Aufbruch auf den Wanderungen zu verhüllen.

////—1—//// 35:22:1,**And women.** [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עַל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הַנָּשִׁים means] <font color=d50505>»</font>with<font color=d50505>«</font> the women and close to them.

§§—2—§§ 35:22:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הנשים means with the women and closely following them.

—3— **22. Neben den Frauen,** mit den Frauen und neben ihnen.

////—1—//// 35:22:2,**Bracelets.** A round golden ornament worn on the arm. It is called a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צָמִיד — “bracelet.”

§§—2—§§ 35:22:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חח is a circular golden ornament placed upon the arm; it is the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צמיד which is often mentioned in Scripture (cf. e. g., Numbers 31:50)."

—3— **Armbänder,** ein rundes, goldenes Geschmeide, das an den Arm gelegt wird, dasselbe wie <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צמיד (Gen. 24, 22). <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בומז ein goldenes Gerät, das von Frauen am Leib getragen wurde; unsere Lehrer erklären das Wort <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כאן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מקום <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זמה = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כרמז Ort der Unzucht. 

---

////—1—//// 35:22:3,**And buckles.** A golden ornament worn against a woman’s private parts. Our Sages explained the derivation of the name <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כוּמָז as <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כָּאן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מָקוֹם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִמָּה — “here is the place of lewdness.”

§§—2—§§ 35:22:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כומז was a golden ornament worn by the women upon their private parts, Our Rabbis explain the name <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כּוּמָז as [an acrostic]: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כַּאן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מְקוֹם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>זִמָּה, [meaning] here is the place of licentiousness. (cf. Shabbat 64a)."

////—1—//// 35:23:1,"**Every man who had with him —** greenish-blue wool, <font color=d50505>»</font>or<font color=d50505>«</font> dark red wool, <font color=d50505>»</font>or<font color=d50505>«</font> crimson wool, <font color=d50505>»</font>or<font color=d50505>«</font> rams’ skins <font color=d50505>»</font>or<font color=d50505>«</font> <font color=d50505>»</font>tachash<font color=d50505>«</font> skins — they all brought. "

§§—2—§§ 35:23:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>איש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נמצא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אתו AND EVERY MAN WITH WHOM WAS FOUND blue purple, or red purple, or crimson, or rams’ skins, or tachash skins — all of them brought whatever they had."

—3— **23. Und jedermann, bei dem sich himmelblaue Wolle vorfand** oder purpurrote oder karmesinrote oder Widder- oder Tachaschfelle, alles brachten sie.

////—1—//// 35:26:1,**Spun the goats’ hair.** This was a craft of special skill for they spun it while it was still on the animals’ backs.

§§—2—§§ 35:26:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>טוו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>העזים [AND THE WOMEN] SPUN THE GOATS’ HAIR (lit., the goats) — This required extraordinary skill, for they spun it (the goats’ hair) from off the backs of the goats (whilst it was still on the living animals) (Shabbat 99a)."

—3— **26. Spannen das Ziegenhaar,** das war eine besondere Kunstfertigkeit; denn an den Ziegen selbst spannen sie es (Schabbat 99a). 

---

////—1—//// 35:27:1,"**And the leaders [of the tribes] brought.** R. Noson said: Why did the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְשִׂיאִים see fit to contribute to the dedication of the altar first whereas for the works of the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> they were not the first to contribute? But the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְשִׂיאִים thought as follows: “Let the public-at-large contribute whatever they will contribute, and whatever will be lacking we will supply.” Once the public supplied all that was needed, as it is said: “And the work was sufficient,” the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נְשִׂיאִים said, “what is left for us to do?” So “they brought the <font color=d50505>»</font>shoham<font color=d50505>«</font>-stones, etc.” It is for this reason that they contributed to the altar dedication first. And since, at first, they were somewhat lax, there is a letter missing, here, from their name and it is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַנְּשִֹאִם (without a <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>י' after the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שֹ'). "

§§—2—§§ 35:27:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנשאם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הביאו AND THE PRINCES BROUGHT [ONYX STONES] R. Nathan asked, “What reason had the princes to give their contributions at the dedication of the altar (Numbers 7:12ff.) first of all the people, whereas at the work of the Tabernacle they were not the first, but the last to contribute?” But — replied he — the princes spoke thus: “Let the community in general contribute all they with to give and what will then be lacking we shall supply” But when the community gave everything needed in its entirety — as it is said, (Exodus 36:7) “For the stuff they had was enough [for all the work to make it, and some was left]” — the princes asked, “What can we now do?” therefore <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הביאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אבני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>השהם <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ THEY BROUGHT THE ONYX STONES etc. That is why they were the first to contribute at the consecration of the altar. Because, however, they were dilatory at the beginning, a letter is missing here from their title (thus intimating that something, viz., zeal was lacking in them): for it is written <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנשאם instead of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנשיאים (Numbers Rabbah 12:16)."

—3— **27. Und die Fürsten brachten,** R. Natan sagt, was veranlasste die Fürsten, bei der Einweihung des Altares (Num. 7, 2) zuerst freiwillige Gaben zu bringen, während sie beim Bau der Wohnung solche nicht zuerst gelobt hatten? Nur, die Fürsten hatten gesagt, die Gemeinde soll geloben, was sie gelobt, und was sie noch fehlen lässt, das werden wir ergänzen; als aber die Gemeinde alles vollständig gegeben hatte, wie steht (36, 7), der Stoff reichte, da sagten die Fürsten, was können wir noch tun? Und sie brachten die Schohamsteine… Darum gelobten sie bei der Einweihung des Altares zuerst; weil sie aber zuerst nicht eifrig genug gewesen, fehlt ein Buchstabe in ihrem Namen; denn es steht <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>והנשאם ohne Jud (Tanchuma).

§§—2—§§ 35:30:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>חור HUR was the son the Miriam (Sotah 11b; cf. 
§§—2—§§ 24:14).

—3— **30. Chur** war der Sohn von Mirjam.

////—1—//// 35:34:1,"**And Oholiov.** He was from the Tribe of Dan, one of the lowliest of the Tribes, one of the sons of [Yaakov’s] maidservants. ////—1—//// 38:8:1,"**From the mirrors of the women who had gathered.** The daughters of Israel possessed mirrors into which they would look when adorning themselves. Even those they did not withhold from bringing as a contribution for the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font> However, Moshe found them repulsive since their purpose is to incite the evil inclination. God said to him: Accept [them], for these are dearer to me than everything else because through them the women raised huge multitudes in Egypt. When their husbands were exhausted from their crushing labor they (the women) would go and bring them food and drink and feed them. They would then take the mirrors and each one would look at herself and her husband in the mirror, and entice him with words, saying, “See! I am more beautiful than you,” thereby awakening their husbands’ desire and they would cohabit with them. They conceived and gave birth there. As is stated: “Under the apple-tree did I arouse you.” That is the intent of what is said: “By the mirrors of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צֹבְאוֹת .” The wash-basin was made out of them for it serves to bring about peace between a man and his wife, by giving to drink from the waters inside it to anyone whose husband expressed jealousy and she, nevertheless, concealed herself [with another man]. You can know yourself that these were actual mirrors, for it is stated: “The total copper donation was seventy <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar,<font color=d50505>«</font> etc. and he made from it, etc.” whereas the wash-basin and its base are not mentioned there. Hence you have learned that the copper of the wash-basin was not from the donated copper. Thus did Rabbi Tanchuma explain it. Onkelos also translates it this way: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְמֶחְזְיַת of the women [<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּמֶחְזְיַת] being the Aramaic for “mirrors,” <font color=d50505>»</font>mireors<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French. We find the like in Yeshaiyahu: “<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְהַגִּלְיֹנִים — “and the mirrors” which is translated <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מֶחְזְיָתָא . "

§§—2—§§ 38:8:1,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במראת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצבאת OF THE MIRRORS OF THE WOMEN CROWDING — The Israelitish women possessed mirrors of copper into which they used to look when they adorned themselves. Even these did they not hesitate to bring as a contribution towards the Tabernacle. Now Moses was about to reject them since they were made to pander to their vanity, but the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, “Accept them; these are dearer to Me than all the other contributions, because through them the women reared those huge hosts in Egypt!” For when their husbands were tired through the crushing labour they used to bring them food and drink and induced them to eat. Then they would take the mirrors, and each gazed at herself in her mirror together with her husband, saying endearingly to him, “See, I am handsomer than you!” Thus they awakened their husbands’ affection and subsequently became the mothers of many children, at it is said, (Song 8:5) “I awakened thy love under the apple-tree”, (referring to the fields where the men worked). This is what it refers to when it states, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצבאת “the mirrors of the women who reared the hosts (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צבאות)” (Midrash Tanchuma, Pekudei 9). And it was for this reason that the laver was made of them (the mirrors) — because it served the purpose of promoting peace between man and wife viz., by giving of its waters to be drunk by a woman whose husband had shown himself jealous of her and who nevertheless had associated with another (cf. Numbers ch. V) thus affording her an opportunity to prove her innocence (cf. Sotah 15b). You may know that the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראות mentioned in the text were really mirrors (and that the word does not mean visions, or appearance, etc.), for it is said, (v. 29) “And the copper of the wave-offering was seventy talents etc. … and therewith he made [the sockets etc.]” — the laver, however, and its base are not mentioned there amongst the articles made from that copper; hence you may learn that the copper of which the laver was made was not a part of the copper of the weave-offering, which is the only copper mentioned as having been contributed by the people. Thus did R. Tanchuma 2:11:9 explain the term <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הצבאת. And so does Onkelos also render it: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>במחזית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>נשיא, and this first word is the Targum translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מראות, in the sense of mireors in old French, for we find that for the word (Isaiah 3:23) “And the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>גליונים”, which are mirrors, we have in the Targum the same word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחזיתא."

—3— **8. Aus den Spiegeln der versammelten Frauen,** die Töchter Israels besaßen Spiegel, in die sie sahen, wenn sie sich schmückten; und selbst diese unterHessen sie nicht zu den Spenden für die Wohnung zu bringen; Mosche wollte sie zurückweisen, weil sie für den bösen Trieb gemacht seien; da sagte der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, zu ihm, nimm sie an, denn diese sind mir lieber als alles andere; denn durch sie haben die Frauen in Ägypten viele Scharen ins Leben gerufen. Wenn ihre Männer nämlich durch die harte Arbeit müde waren, gingen die Frauen hin und brachten ihnen Speise und Trank und veranlassten sie zum Essen; dann nahmen sie die Spiegel, und jede betrachtete sich mit ihrem Manne zusammen darin und redete ihm liebevoll zu, ich bin schöner als du; dadurch belebten sie das Eheglück ihrer Männer, willfahrten ihnen, wurden Mütter und gebaren auch dort, wie es heißt (Schir 8, 5), unter dem Apfelbaum habe ich dich erweckt; und das sagt unser Vers, mit den Spiegeln der Frauen, die Scharen hervorgebracht hatten. Aus ihnen wurde das Waschbecken gemacht, das da bestimmt war, Frieden zu stiften zwischen Mann und Frau, um von dem Wasser aus ihm derjenigen zu trinken zu geben, gegen die ihr Mann geeifert und die sich trotzdem mit dem fremden Manne verborgen hatte. Du kannst daraus erkennen, dass es sich um wirkliche Spiegel handelte, weil es heißt (V. 29), das Kupfer der Schwingung betrug 70 Talente … und man machte davon … aber das Waschbecken und sein Gestell sind dort nicht erwähnt, daraus kannst du entnehmen, dass das Kupfer des Waschbeckens nicht vom Kupfer der Schwingung war. So erklärt R. Tanchuma <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פקודי; und so übersetzt auch Onkelos <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בחזית, das ist der Targum von Spiegel, miroirs Spiegel in anderen Sprachen; so finden wir auch (Jes. 3, 23), die Spiegel, was der Targum mit <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מחזייתא übersetzt.

§§—2—§§ 38:21:2,"<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכן OF THE TABERNACLE, EVEN OF THE TABERNACLE — The word <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכן is mentioned here twice in allusion to the Temple that was taken in pledge (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משכן) — as it were — (as a security for Israel’s repentance) by being twice destroyed for Israel’s iniquities (Midrash Tanchuma, Pekudei 5)."

"

////—1—//// 38:22:1,"**Betzalel, son of Uri, etc. made all that Adonoy commanded Moshe.** “That which he (Moshe) commanded him (Betzalel) is not written here, but, rather, “all that God commanded Moshe,” [thereby implying that] even things which his teacher (Moshe) had not told him, his own opinion was in agreement with what was said to Moshe at Sinai. For Moshe had instructed Betzalel to first produce the vessels, and afterward the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon.<font color=d50505>«</font> Whereupon Betzalel said to him: “It is customary in the world to first construct a house and afterwards put furnishings in it.” [Moshe] responded to him: “[You are right] that is indeed what I heard from God.” Moshe [then also] said to him “You must have been (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בְּצֵל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אֵ־<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ל) in the shadow of God, for, certainly, so did God command me.” And so he (Betzalel) did it — first the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> and afterwards he made the vessels. "

§§—2—§§ 38:22:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובצלאל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אורי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עשה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צוה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ה' <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה AND BEZALEEL THE SON OF URI etc. MADE ALL THAT THE LORD COMMANDED MOSES — It is not stated here: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אשר <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צֻוָּה (Bezaleel made all that he had been commanded), but “[Bezaleel made] all that the Lord commanded Moses” — even regarding such things which his teacher (Moses) did not tell him, his own opinion was in agreement with what had been told to Moses on Sinai (Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1; Bereishit Rabbah 1:14). [For Moses bade Bezaleel lo make the vessels first and the Tabernacle afterwards but Bezaleel said to him: “Surely, it is the way of the world (the usual way) first to build a house and then to place the household utensils in it!” He (Moses) replied to him: “So, indeed, did I hear from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He”. Moses further said to him: (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בצלאל), you must have been sitting in the shadow of God (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בצל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל), for certainly did thus God command me!” And consequently Bezaleel made the Tabernacle first and afterwards he made the vessels (cf. Berakhot 55a)."

—3— **22. Und Bezalei b. Uri … machte alles, was der Ewige Mosche befohlen hatte;** was Er (oder Mosche) befohlen hatte, steht hier nicht, sondern, alles, was der Ewige Mosche befohlen hatte; selbst bei Dingen, die sein Lehrer Mosche nicht zu ihm gesprochen hatte, erfasste sein Geist das, was zu Mosche auf dem Sinai gesagt worden (Jer. Pea I); denn Mosche befahl Bezalei zuerst, die Geräte zu machen, und dann die Wohnung; da sagte Bezalei zu ihm, es ist der Gebrauch in der Welt, zuerst ein Haus zu bauen und dann die Geräte hineinzustellen; und Mosche sprach, so habe ich auch aus dem Munde des Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, empfangen; ferner sagte Mosche zu ihm, du warst im Schatten Gottes; denn bestimmt hat der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, mir so befohlen; und so machte er auch die Wohnung zuerst, und dann machte er die Geräte (Ber. 55a).

////—1—//// 38:24:1,"**Kikar.** A <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> is the equivalent of 60 <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh<font color=d50505>«</font> and the <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh<font color=d50505>«</font> associated with the Sanctuary was double [the weight of a common <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh<font color=d50505>«</font>] making the <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> equal to 120 [common] <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh,<font color=d50505>«</font> A <font color=d50505>»</font>maneh<font color=d50505>«</font> is equal to 25 <font color=d50505>»</font>selaim<font color=d50505>«</font> (<font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font>), making the <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> of the Sanctuary 3,000 <font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font> (25 x 120 = 3,000). It is for this reason that it counts as units all the <font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font> that add up to less than 3,000, because they do not add up to a <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar. <font color=d50505>«</font>"

§§—2—§§ 38:24:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ככר [TWENTY NINE] TALENTS — A common kikkar contains sixty common manehs, and the maneh of the Sanctuary (that used for purposes connected with the Temple) was double the common maneh. Consequently the kikkar here mentioned was 120 common manehs. Now a common maneh contained 25 Sela’im (or shekels), and the kikkar of the Sanctuary equals three thousand shekels. That is why Scripture counts (mentions the number of) all the shekels that are fewer than 3,000 as a separate item, because these do not together amount to a kikkar (cf. Bekhorot 5a)."

—3— **24. Talente,** je 60 Minen; die heilige Mine betrug das Doppelte; also hatte das Talent 120 Minen; die Mine hatte 25 Sela, also das heilige Talent 3000 Schekel; darum nennt er bei den einzelnen Schekeln alle Schekel unter 3000, weil sie kein volles Talent ausmachten.

////—1—//// 38:26:1,**Beka.** This is the name of the weight of one half of a shekel.

§§—2—§§ 38:26:1, <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בקע (from <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בָּקַע to split) is the name given to a weight of half a shekel.

—3— **26. Ein Beka,** das ist die Bezeichnung für das Gewicht eines halben Schekel.

////—1—//// 38:26:2,"**For six hundred (and three) thousand, etc.** This was the count of the Israelites and this, too, was what their number amounted to after the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> was erected [when they were counted again] in <font color=d50505>»</font>seifer<font color=d50505>«</font> Bamidbar. Now, too, at the time of the contributions to the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> they were that many. The amount of half-<font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font> for 600,000 totalled 100 <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar,<font color=d50505>«</font> where each <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> is 3,000 <font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim.<font color=d50505>«</font> How is this calculated? 600,000 half-<font color=d50505>»</font>shekels,<font color=d50505>«</font> which equal 300,000 whole <font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font> giving you 100 <font color=d50505>»</font>kikar<font color=d50505>«</font> (100 x 3,000 = 300,000). The remaining 3,550 half-<font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim<font color=d50505>«</font> total 1,775 whole <font color=d50505>»</font>shekalim.<font color=d50505>«</font> "

§§—2—§§ 38:26:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לשש <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מאות <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אלף <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ FOR SIX HUNDRED THOUSAND [AND THREE THOUSAND etc.] — Thus were the Israelites in number, and thus did their number amount to after the Tabernacle was set up, as it is stated in the Book of Numbers (ch. II), and at this time, also, when they contributed toward the Tabernacle they were just as many (cf. 
§§—2—§§ 30:16). The half-shekels of 600,000 amount to a hundred talents, each talents consisting of three thousand shekels (cf. v. 25). How is this? 600,000 half-shekels are 300,000 whole shekels, making one hundred talents and the remaining 3550 half-shekels make 1775 whole shekels, as stated in the text."

—3— **Für die 603550**, soviel betrug Israel, und soviel ergab ihre Zählung nach der Errichtung der Wohnung im Buche <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וידבר (Numeri); auch jetzt bei den Gaben für die Wohnung waren sie soviel; die Anzahl der halben Schekel von 600000 ergab 100 Talente, jedes von 3000 Schekel; denn 600000 halbe sind 300000 ganze Schekel = 100 Talenten, und die 3550 halbe ergaben 1775 Schekel.

As for the remaining sockets the Torah records them as “copper.” "

§§—2—§§ 38:27:2," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אדני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הקדש THE SOCKETS OF THE SANCTUARY — i. e. of the boards of the Tabernacle (the Sanctuary) which were forty-eight boards, and for these ninety-six sockets were required. The sockets for the partition vail were four in number, so we have altogether one hundred. As regards all the other sockets (those of the enclosure and of the vail at its entrance) they are not taken into account here, because “copper” was written concerning them (Scripture prescribes that they were to be of copper)."

////—1—//// 39:3:1,"**They beat.** As in: “(<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְרוֹקַע) He who spreads the earth,” and as Onkelos translates it: “they hammered out.” They hammered out plates from the gold. <font color=d50505>»</font>Estendre<font color=d50505>«</font> in Old French — “to hammer out into thin plates.” Here [the Torah] teaches you how they spun the gold with the threads: they hammered out thin plates from which they would cut threads along the length of the plate, to make threads [which were] combined with each kind [of material thread] separately for the breastplate and the <font color=d50505>»</font>eiphod<font color=d50505>«</font> whenever “gold” is stated; one thread of gold with six threads of greenish-blue wool and so, too, with each of the other kinds, for the strand of each of the kinds was spun six-fold, and the gold was the seventh thread with each. "

§§—2—§§ 39:3:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירקעו AND THEY DID EXTEND — <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירקעו is of the same root and meaning as, (Psalms 136:6) “To Him that stretcheth out (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לרקע) the earth”. Render <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וירקעו as the Targum does: <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורדידו, they extended by beating. Plates did they beat out of the gold; in old French estendre — to extend into thin plates. Here it informs you how they wove the gold together with the woollen threads. They beat out the thin plates and from them they cut threads along the length of the plates to make of these threads a mixture (to mix them) with each of the different kind of woolen threads in the ephod and the breast-plate in regard to which gold is mentioned in this connection. One thread of gold they intertwined with six threads of blue purple, and so with each kind of wool. For all the materials had their threads six-fold, and the gold formed the seventh with each of them (cf. Yoma 72a)."

—3— **3. Man dehnte,** wie (Ps. 136, 6), der die Erde ausgedehnt; wie der Targum sagt, sie dehnten die Bleche; man walzte Gold, dehnen in anderen Sprachen, zu dünnen Blechen. Hier lehrt er dich, wie man das Gold mit den Fäden zusammenspann; man walzte dünne Bleche und schnitt in der Länge des Bleches Fäden daraus, um diese Fäden mit jeder Art, die am Choschen und Efod verwendet wurde, zu vermischen, da bei ihnen Gold steht, ein Goldfaden mit sechs Fäden aus himmelblauer Wolle, und ebenso mit jeder einzelnen Art; denn bei allen Arten war der Faden sechsfach, und das Gold war der siebte Faden an jeder von ihnen.

////—1—//// 39:31:1,"**To fasten it to the turban from above —** by means of the threads he set it onto the turban, as a sort of crown. It is impossible to say [however] that the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ [proper] was on the turban for in Tractate Shechitas Kodoshim (Zevachim) we have learned that his hair was visible between the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ and the turban which was where he wore his <font color=d50505>»</font>tefillin<font color=d50505>«</font> and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ was placed on the forehead. Thus you see that the turban was high up and the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ lower down. Then what is the explanation of: “turban from above”? Another question that I have posed in this matter: Here it states, “They put (fastened) on it a greenish-blue wool cord,” and in the section where the command is given it states: “place <font color=d50505>»</font>it<font color=d50505>«</font> on a greenish-blue cord.” [To solve these seeming contradictions] I say: This greenish-blue wool thread is actually strands with which to attach it (the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ) to the turban. For the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ only runs from ear to ear and how is it to be fastened to his forehead? There were strands of greenish-blue wool inserted into it at its two ends and at its middle by means of which he ties it and hangs it from the turban when it is on his head. There were two strands at each end (of the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ) one on the outer side and one underneath towards his forehead and likewise at its middle for this makes it easier to tie and it is not usual to tie something with less than two strands. This is the reason it says: “on [a] greenish-blue thread,” and “on it [the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צִיץ] [was a] greenish-blue thread.” He now ties the two ends of each of all [the threads] together, behind him opposite his neck, and now places it on the turban. Do not wonder that it does not say: “<font color=d50505>»</font>threads<font color=d50505>«</font> of greenish-blue wool” since there were many, for we find [a similar syntax] regarding the breastplate and the <font color=d50505>»</font>eiphod<font color=d50505>«</font>: “They shall fasten the breastplate, etc.” and you are certainly forced to admit that there were no less than two [strands] for at the two corners of the breastplate there were the two rings of the breastplate and in the two shoulder-straps of the <font color=d50505>»</font>eiphod<font color=d50505>«</font> were the two rings of the <font color=d50505>»</font>eiphod<font color=d50505>«</font> opposite them (i.e., the rings of the breastplate). And the way it (the breastplate) was tied there were four strands. But under no circumstances could there have been less than two. "

§§—2—§§ 39:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לתת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המצנפת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מלמעלה TO FASTEN IT ON HIGH UPON THE MITRE — and by means of the threads he placed it on the mitre as though it were a kind of crown. It is, however, impossible to say that <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לתת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>על <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המצנפת means to put the plate on the mitre, for in the Treatise on the Slaughter of the Sacrifices (Zevachim 19a) we learn: His (the High Priest’s) hair was visible between the plate and the mitre, whereon he placed the Tephillin”. Now the plate rested on his forehead (cf. Exodus 28:38), consequently the mitre was above (on the crown of the head) and the plate beneath (on the forehead). What then can be the meaning of “to fasten it on high upon the mitre”? Besides, I have put another question about this: here it says, “and they put upon it (the plate) a thread of blue purple” and in the section where the command is given it states, (Exodus 28:37) “And thou shalt put it on a blue purple string” (so that the plate was above the thread, not beneath it as is here commanded). I therefore say that this <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>פתיל of blue purple mentioned here was not an ornament but threads by which to tie it (the plate) on the mitre. For the plate reached only from one ear to the other, so with what could they tie it to his forehead? So blue purple threads were attached to it at its (the plate’s) two ends and on the middle by means of which they tied it on and hung it on the mitre whenever this was on his head. There were two threads on each end (of the plate) one on its upper side and the other underneath, on the side next to the forehead and so also at the middle of it (the plate) — because in this way it was easy to tie it on. Since, however, the way of tying a thing on is by not less than two threads the text is justified in saying both, (Exodus 23:37) “[And thou shalt put it] on a blue purple thread” and here “and they put upon it a thread of blue purple”. He (the High Priest) tied both ends of all of them (of all the threads) together behind him on his neck, and thus placed it (the plate) on the mitre. Do not be puzzled because it does not say “threads of blue purple” seeing that there were many (three double threads altogether), for we find the same thing in the case of the breast-plate and the ephod: (Exodus 28:28) “And they shall fasten the breast-plate by the rings thereof unto the rings of the ephod … with a string (and not with strings) of blue purple” and you must admit that there could not have been less than two strings, for at the two ends of the breast-plate were the two rings of the breast-plate and on the two shoulder-pieces of the ephod were the two rings of the ephod opposite to them. Now according to the way the breast-plate was tied on there were four threads, and under any circumstances with less than two it would have been impossible to tie it on, and yet Scripture speaks of “a string” of blue purple."

—3— **31. Um es oben auf den Kopfbund zu legen,** durch die **Schnüre** legte man es auf den Kopfbund wie eine Krone; man kann aber nicht sagen, dass das Stirnband selbst auf dem Kopfbund lag, da wir in <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שחיטת <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>קדשים (Seb. 19a) lernen, sein Haar war sichtbar zwischen dem Stirnband und dem Kopfbund, und dorthin legte er die Tefillin, und das Stirnband lag auf der Stirn; also befand sich der Kopfbund oben und das Stirnband unten; was bedeutet also, oben auf den Kopfbund; ferner habe ich darauf gefragt (28, 37), hier sagt er, sie legten eine himmelblaue Schnur darauf, und im Abschnitt des Befehles sagt er (28, 37), lege es auf eine himmelblaue Schnur? Darum sage ich, diese himmelblaue Schnur bestand aus Fäden, um das Stirnband damit am Kopfbund festzubinden; denn das Stirnband ging nur von Ohr zu Ohr; womit sollte man es also an der Stirn festbinden? Darum waren himmelblaue Fäden an den beiden Enden und in der Mitte daran befestigt, mit denen er es am Kopfbund festband und herabhängen Hess, wenn es an seinem Haupte war. An jedem Ende waren zwei Fäden, einer von oben und einer von unten, der Stirn zugewandt, und ebenso in der Mitte; denn so konnte man es leicht festbinden, da man gewöhnlich zum Binden nicht weniger als zwei Fäden hat; darum steht, auf eine himmelblaue Schnur, und darauf war eine himmelblaue Schnur; und er band die beiden Enden alle hinten zusammen, dem Nacken gegenüber, und machte es über dem Kopfbund fest. Wundere dich aber nicht darüber, dass nicht steht, himmelblaue Schnüre, da es mehrere waren; denn auch beim Choschen und Efod finden wir (V. 21), sie machten das Choschen fest… und dort können es nicht weniger als zwei gewesen sein, da an beiden Enden des Choschen zwei Ringe des Choschen und an den beiden Schulterbändern des Efod zwei Ringe des Efod jenen gegenüber waren; wie man gewöhnlich bindet, waren es vier Fäden, jedenfalls unmöglich weniger als zwei.

////—1—//// 39:33:1,"**They brought the mishkon, etc. —** for they were unable to erect it. Because Moshe did no work whatsoever in the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> God left it for him to erect, for no man was able to erect it because of the weight of the planks for no man had the strength to stand them up, but Moshe stood them up. [Actually, Moshe himself could also not do it but...] Moshe said to God: How is it possible for man to erect it? [Whereupon] He answered him: “You busy yourself with your hand”! It appeared as if he (Moshe) had erected it but it had stood upright of its own. This is what is meant by what is said: “The <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> was erected” — it was erected of its own. From the Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma. "

§§—2—§§ 39:33:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויביאו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>את <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המשכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND THEY BROUGHT THE TABERNACLE [UNTO MOSES etc.], for they themselves were unable to erect it. Since Moses had done no work in the Mishkan, the Holy One, blessed is He, left for him the task of erecting it, for nobody was able to set it up because of the weight of the boards which no human strength was capable of setting up. Moses, however, succeeded in placing it in position. Moses said to the Holy One, blessed be He, “How is its erection possible by human beings?” God answered him: “You be busy with your hand!” He appeared to be erecting it, but in fact it set itself up and rose of its own accord. That is why Scripture says, (Exodus 40:17) “The Tabernacle was erected (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הוקם)” — was erected by itself. This is a Midrash of Rabbi Tanchuma 2:11:11."

—3— **33. Und sie brachten die Wohnung;** denn sie konnten sie nicht selbst aufrichten; und weil Mosche keine Arbeit an der Wohnung selbst verrichtet hatte, ließ der Heilige, gelobt sei Er, für ihn die Aufrichtung derselben; denn durch die Schwere der Balken konnte kein Mensch sie aufrichten, weil keiner die Kraft besaß, diese aufzustellen, und Mosche stellte sie auf; da sagte Mosche vor dem Heiligen, gelobt sei Er, wie vermag sie ein Mensch aufzurichten? Und Er sprach, beschäftige du dich damit mit deiner Hand; es sah aus, als richte er sie auf, sie richtete sich aber selbst auf und stand von selbst; das ist, was steht (40, 17), wurde die Wohnung aufgerichtet, von selbst aufgerichtet; Midrasch von R. Tanchuma.

////—1—//// 40:22:2,"** <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יֶרֶךְ —** is as Onkelos translates it, “the side” just as the thigh is on the side of the person. "

—3— **Seite,** wie der Targum sagt <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>צידא, wie sich die Hüfte an der Seite des Menschen befindet.

////—1—//// 40:29:1,"**He sacrificed on it, etc.** Also on the eighth day of the Installations which was the day the <font color=d50505>»</font>mishkon<font color=d50505>«</font> was erected. Moshe performed the service and offered the communal <font color=d50505>»</font>korbonos,<font color=d50505>«</font> except for those which Aharon was commanded on that very day, as it states: “[Moshe said to Aharon:] Approach the Altar, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 40:29:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ויעל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וגו׳ AND OFFERED UPON IT etc. Not only during the first seven days of the consecration of Aaron and his sons during which Moses set the dwelling up and then dismantled it, but also on the eighth day of the consecration which was the day of the final erection of the dwelling for its ordinary purposes did Moses officiate and offer the congregational sacrifices except those which had been commanded exclusively for that very day, as it is said, (Leviticus 9:7) “[And Moses said to Aaron], approach unto the altar and offer etc."

—3— **29. Und er brachte darauf dar,** auch am achten Tage der Einweihung, das ist am Tag der Errichtung der Wohnung, verrichtete Mosche den Dienst und brachte die Opfer der Gemeinde dar außer denjenigen, die nur für jenen Tag vorgeschrieben worden waren; wie es heißt (Lev. 9, 7), tritt zum Altäre hin …

////—1—//// 40:29:3,"**And a meal-offering.** [I.e.,] the <font color=d50505>»</font>mincha<font color=d50505>«</font> of the libations of the <font color=d50505>»</font>tamid.<font color=d50505>«</font> As it is said: “[And with one lamb bring] a tenth [of an <font color=d50505>»</font>eipha<font color=d50505>«</font>] of flour mixed with oil, etc.” "

§§—2—§§ 40:29:3," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואח <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>המנחה AND THE MEAL OFFERING — The meal offering brought together with the libation which was made with the daily burnt offering, at it is said, (Exodus 29:40) “[And with the one lamb] (of the daily burnt offering) shall be brought a tenth deal of flour mingled with … oil; [and the fourth part of a hin of wine for a libation …]”."

—3— **und das Speiseopfer,** das Speiseopfer, das zum Gussopfer des beständigen Opfers gehörte, wie es heißt (29, 40), und ein Zehntel feines Mehl, in Öl verrührt.

////—1—//// 40:31:1,"**Moshe and Aharon ... washed ... from it. ** On the eighth day of the Installations all of them (Moshe, Aharon and his sons) were equal in the priesthood. Onkelos’ translation [of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>וְרָחֲצוּ] is: And they sanctified themselves from it. On that very day Moshe was sanctified with them. "

§§—2—§§ 40:31:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורחצו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ממנו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ואהרן AND MOSES AND AARON [AND HIS SONS] LAVED [THEIR HANDS] — On the eighth day of the consecration all of them mentioned here, including Moses, were alike in respect of the priestly office. The translation of <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ורחצו in the Targum should therefore be <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומקדשין, and they were hallowing (i. e. they then hallowed their hands and their feet), for on that day Moses laved his hands together with them (Aaron and his sons)."

—3— **31. Und sie wuschen sich daraus, Mosche und Aharon und seine Söhne,** am achten Tage der Einweihung waren sie alle in der Priesterwürde gleich; der Targum sagt,<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ומקדשין, an jenem Tage heiligte sich Mosche mit ihnen.

—3— **32. Und wenn sie hintreten** = <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ובקרבם, sobald sie hintreten.

////—1—//// 40:35:1,"**Moshe was unable to enter the Tent of Meeting.** Yet, another verse states: “And when Moshe would come into the Tent of Meeting” There comes a third verse [later in our verse] and reconciles them: “for the cloud was upon it (on the Tent of meetings)” Say, therefore: as long as the cloud was upon it he could not come in; once the cloud left he would enter and speak with Him. "

§§—2—§§ 40:35:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ולא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>יכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>משה <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לבא <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>אהל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מועד AND MOSES WAS NOT ABLE TO COME INTO THE APPOINTED TENT — But another verse says, (Numbers 7:89) “And when Moses came into the appointed tent [to speak with Him then he heard the voice]”! There comes, however, a third verse and reconciles these apparently contradictory verses, for it says here <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כי <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>שכן <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>עליו <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>הענן “For (or when) the cloud abode thereon (on the appointed tent)”. Hence you may say: so long as the cloud was upon it “he was not able to come into the appointed tent”, but as soon as the cloud disappeared he entered it and spoke with Him (Sifra, Braita d'Rabbi Yishmael 18)."

—3— **35. Und Mosche konnte nicht ins Zelt der Offenbarung hineingehen,** und ein Vers sagt (Num. 7, 89), wenn Mosche ins Zelt der Offenbarung hineinging; darum kommt der dritte Vers und gleicht sie aus, nämlich weil die Wolke darauf ruhte; daraus ergibt sich, solange die Wolke darauf ruhte, konnte er nicht hineingehen; sobald sich die Wolke entfernte, ging er hinein, und Er sprach mit ihm (Torat Kohanim 13 38. (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מדות.

////—1—//// 40:38:1,"**Before the eyes of the entire Beis Yisrael in all their travels.** At every station that they stopped the cloud would rest at the place where they encamped. Their encampment is also called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסָּע Similarly: “He went to his (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לְמַסָּעָיו) resting places.” Similarly: “These were (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסְעֵי) the stations.” Because from the place of encampment they again journeyed, therefore, they are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מַסָּעוֹת . "

§§—2—§§ 40:38:1," <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>לעיני <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>כל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בית <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>ישראל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>בכל <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסעיהם [THE CLOUD WAS ON THE TABERNACLE] … IN THE SIGHT OF ALL THE HOUSE OF ISRAEL, THROUGHOUT ALL THEIR JOURNEYS — At every <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסע which they made (according to Rashi this means: at every station at which they stopped) the cloud rested upon the Tabernacle in the place where they encamped. A place where they encamped is also called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסע (the literal meaning of which is “journey”). Similar is, (Genesis 13:3) “And he went on to his resting places (<font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>למסעיו)“ (cf. Rashi on this verse); similar also is, (Numbers 33:1) “These are the <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסעי” — “the places of encampment”. Because from the place of encampment they always set out again on a new journey therefore all the different stages of their journeys (including the places where they encamped) are called <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסעות."

—3— **Vor den Augen des ganzen Hauses Israel auf allen ihren Zügen,** an jedem Lagerplatz zu dem sie zogen, ruhte die Wolke an dem Orte, an dem sie lagerten; der Ort, an dem sie lagerten, wird auch <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסע genannt; ebenso (Gen. 13, 3), er zog zu seinen Lager plätzen; ebenso (Num. 33, 1), dies sind die Lagersplätze; weil sie vom Lagerplatz wieder aufbrachen, werden sie alle <font color=#d633ff>🟌</font>מסעות Aufbrüche genannt.
